column21: Heavily constructed cooking platform (see drawing measurements) on west wall in northwest corner of room. Sits on reconstructed brick base that spans the length of the wall. Evidence of a base that spans the length of the wall.  Base length 223 cm x width 83 cm x height 43 cm.   Hearth depth 61 cm x height 73 cm X width 86 cm.  Opening 53 cm front to back x 49 cm height x 45 cm across.

column14: North of peristyle and water feature
column15: North of peristyle and water feature
column21: Three niches on north, west, east walls wide opening overlooking peristyle and water feature. Original frescos retained on east, west and north walls. Niches are decorated with shells at top. Niches tall, deep, segmental in plan. Half domes with molded shell motifs. Flanking wall niches symmetrical in size shape. North niches smaller and not as deep. Modern concrete support and top facing peristyle. Decoration on north wall not accessible.Floor not accessible. Look for it in  PPM.

column14: No other features except shelves on right of counter.  To east of hearth, may have been another feature where Anglo-American group has excavated. Counter faces upon street with other rooms on rear.
column15: Counter faces upon street with other rooms on rear.
column16: No other features except shelves on right of counter.  To east of hearth, may have been another feature where Anglo-American group has excavated.
column21: L-shaped serving counter, marble top, seen in front of the shop to the east of entrance. At northeast end of the counter structure, it is hollow inside. An opening at top is rectangular; there is opening on the front side for fuel.  There are two small stepped shelves at the southeast end of the counter, 51 cm wide.  They face toward the city gate, attracting customers coming into the city. The counter is without embedded dolia, and wearily reconstructed.

column8: Eschebach, 1993, shows a long bench against west exterior wall.
column14: On sidewalk, northwest of counter (feature # 4).  To left of entrance 2. West of room 1, on the sidewalk east of street.
column15: To left of entrance 2. West of room 1, on the sidewalk east of street.
column21: Bench on sidewalk outside room 1.  Currently restored as a L-shaped bench. Extent evidence suggests it was originally L-shaped. Presumably this bench was used for overflow customers from food and drink shop. Indentations on painted wall above bench suggest it could have served as a public notice board. Bench is in close proximity to gate.
column53: Wide shot bench with counter 69 and 70

column14: contiguous to street
column21: Large open room. Counter to north with series of small rooms opening, any one of which could be dining room. Small window in north exterior wall, larger window in south exterior wall.

column14: Contiguous to street
column21: Small U-shaped counter largely reconstructed. Very narrow with no embedded dolia four steps to north side. Reconstructed on east side. It would have just enough room for one person to serve.Counter looks down street, attracting customers leaving city.  Directly across from 6.17.4 (hospiticum) and another small food and drink shop.

column15: Latrine located down corridor and to right
column21: Irregularly shaped platform with tiled surface. Plan is preserved but sides are eroded with stones missing. No recesses for wood storage. Walls not high enough preserved to indicate window. Platform clearly built after walls.

column14: Adjacent to room 7, 9, 10, 12.
column21: Square triclinium with entrance in east corner.  Window overlooking peristyle garden in west corner. Limited traces of wall painting in northeast corner with red border.  Extensive sign of restoration on north, east, west walls. Southeast corner alcove framed by blocked door leading into tablinum. Floor consists of marble chippings.

column8: Jones cites this as dining room, but there are other rooms of this size in proportion.
column9: Jones cites this as dining room
column14: Southeast of atrium, adjacent to rooms 4, 10, 12, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21
column15: Southeast of atrium, adjacent to rooms 4, 10, 12, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21
column21: Larger rectangular room with narrow entrance to west into atrium. Large tufa blocks visible either side of doorway, no evidence of lintel remains that would have been high.  Floor best preserved in north portion of room, irregularly shaped marble insets, and narrow marble border.  All four walls have evidence of red and yellow paint.  South wall is low and in poor state of repair.

column14: To south of latrine.
column21: Heavily restored, too low to be for convenient use.  No arched openings beneath for fuel storage.  Addition to north separates platform from latrine.  Small squarish window in wall above (wall looks restored, perhaps it's only resurfaced, because window looks original).

column14: To south of corridor leading to rear entrance of house, contiguous to street, rooms 17, 19, 20.  Opposite to west is room ideal for storage but too large for simply storage for food and drink.
column15: To south of corridor leading to rear entrance of house, contiguous to street, rooms 17, 19, 20.  Opposite to west is room ideal for storage but too large for simply storage for food and drink.
column21: Southeast corner of house reached by corridor coming south from portico and another coming west.  Space is not as much room as it is large opening.  Room contains on east wall latrine and cooking platform.  East and north walls restored.  South wall original.  Access from kitchen to major triclinia could be by either corridor because room door is at opposite corner.

column14: East of atrium, Contingent to street, rooms 15, 16, 12, 13
column15: East of atrium, Contingent to street, rooms 15, 16, 12, 13
column21: Because of its proximity to garden, could also have served as a study, ref. to Pliny.  Vaulted ceiling, north facing window overlooking garden, window sill intact.  Layout of wall pantry supports association with dining room.  Fourth style painting with evidence of red, yellow, and aqua.  Red border with the real masks and animals (sea monsters and leopard).  Tondo. Plaster molding and vault.  Black and white marble floor not fine enough to be opus sectile.  Black with white interspersed.  Ceiling reconstructed.  Door to northeast corner has marble threshold intact.  Step down from door.  Sea monster on bottom south wall.

column14: fronts onto the street.
column21: Eschebach identifies a shop but we need to translate to know if this had a connection to food and drink.  There is a cistern and hearth located in this room.

column14: rooms 1 and 2
column21: L-shaped serving counter with marble top. Counter in front facing the street.  One circular hole in east end of counter near the end of the long arm but with no dolium inside and no indication of whether there once was. Stepped shelf at north end consists of two steps.  Top step makes a shelf.  Current counter is heavily restored.
column53: Video:  room and counter.  Photographer - Lee Payne

column14: Adjacent to street on east.
column21: Rectangular counter room, has side opening to street (west). Shares same tall tufa pier with VI.1.17. No evidence for lintel. Entire door threshold and grooves for wooden panels preserved. Doorway with jambs is preserved on south side. L-shaped counter extends from north wall halfway across entrance, then turns a right angle to rear (east). Brick pier to left and north of staircase is a later repair.

column8: Eschebach, 1993, shows staircase leading up to living quarters above rear of shop in southeast corner

column14: Two rear rooms lie to east, adjacent to east-side of street.  Latrine connects off southeast corner of counter room.
column15: Two rear rooms lie to east, adjacent to east-side of street.  Latrine connects off southeast corner of counter room.
column21: Room contains L-shaped counter in south of room in convenient position to attract business of those entering and exiting city from street (follows Ellis' theory re: field of vision). Marble threshold extends across front of shop with indentations for wood partitions.  Large tufa piers frame entrance. Two doors lead off counter room to rear (east).

column14: Possible latrine.
column21: L-shaped counter extends from south wall, halfway across from frontage of shop, and then has right angle turn to rear [east].  Hearth is at significantly lower level at east end of counter. Counter has stepped rack on south end, and is unusual.  Upper surface is a step, but more of a shelf.  Three square cuttings directly above level of masonry shelf may or may not relate to shelf.  South wall forms obtuse angle, storage niche is beneath stepped area of counter. No imbedded dolia. Top shelf measures 64 x 57.  Counter surface is largely reconstructed.

North is red with traces of small (3) central tondos.  Brick column stands to the southwest of the couch supporting roof now removed.  Traces of post supports survive in north wall.

column21: Square dining room overlooking peristyle garden to south.  Plaster survives on north, east, and west walls.  Traces of coloring survive.  Red trim with yellow background with green vertical stripes.  Vaulted ceiling with trace of plaster surviving northwest corner.  Trace of molding on north wall.  No trace of flooring.  Doorway to dining room #11 in southeast corner.  Marble threshold survives.

column15: Dining room #10 to the west and peristyle garden to the south.

Traces of plaster decoration surviving on north, south, east, and west walls with color surviving in northwest corner consisting of red lower register.  Traces of red also in southwest corner.  No flooring survives.

column21: Small room inside rear door (posticum).  Kitchen has a rebuilt cooking platform against west wall.  Wall above not preserved enough to prove the presence of a window but a small circular hole (no height in it) could serve as some type of exhaust.

column14: Small space to north of kitchen no features visible but presently (June 2005) being excavated by students from Naples.
column15: Small space to north of kitchen no features visible but presently (June 2005) being excavated by students from Naples.
column21: Small window preserved in east wall and small opening for terra cotta pipe but no pipe there.  Both that opening and that mentioned on FS #30 both are situated on the same horizontal plane above 5-6 courses of brick.  Better preserved on outside of building.

column14: Rectangular dining room opening west into garden, through a wide doorway.  To north is corridor #16, the room is in southwest corner of house.
column15: Rectangular dining room opening west into garden, through a wide doorway.  To north is corridor #16, the room is in southwest corner of house.
column21: Trapezoidal.  Rear east wall follows axis Via ----- (see Lindley).  East and south walls have been capped and weather proofed.  Difficult to discern extent of ancient wall plaster.  Most of southeast walls retain most of wall plaster - check volume by PPM.  Doors not preserved to height of lintels. Original flooring appears to have been mosaic.  Small patches beneath lapilli.  Best in southwest corner.

column14: Peristyle in west (#10).  Atrium in east (#4).  Corridor in north #7.  No access.
column15: Peristyle in west (#10).  Atrium in east (#4).  Corridor in north #7.  No access.
column21: Rectangular dining room with steps to atrium in east wall.  South wall paintings survive with surviving arch. Dec. Central tondo removed from blue background.  Red and yellow decoration survives extensively in lower register.  West wall opens to peristyle garden.  Excavated mosaic and stone flooring forming center of red clay matrix floor.  Klinea would have been arranged around central mosaic and stone decoration.  North wall is undecorated.  Note:  the mosaic was excavated by U - Naples, 2005.

column8: (Look at Vol. Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, for better ID of paintings).
column14: Opens to east into garden, #10 and northeast corner peristyle #8.  In southwest corner of peristyle and the house.  North of dining room is small room made into posticum (back door).
column15: Opens to east into garden, #10 and northeast corner peristyle #8.  In southwest corner of peristyle and the house.  North of dining room is small room made into posticum (back door).
column21: Rectangular room on east-west axis opening through a large doorway with a variegated marble piece of revetment serving as a threshold. Tufa threshold in north door.  Doors of medium height preserved to both north and east.  Walls well preserved, 3 meters thick, leveled off, capped roof tile for protection.  Substantial remains of wall plaster with shadows of paintings on north south and west walls.  Some remains of pavement, cocciopesto (crushed red brick).  Portions visible just inside eastern opening.  A small circular window over east doorway set in low segmented arch reflecting the shape of the suspended vault.  Fine example of lotus and palmet molding plaster that defined the segmented arch and also served as a crown molding for the wall.  The arch is not preserved on west wall but only on east wall.REMEDIATED JUNE 30, 2011 NO NEW DESCRIPTION NEEDED

column14: Door to dining #11 off southeast corner of atrium #5.  To north is Jashemski #A or #12; (north side of garden) -- Opposite dining room #13.
column15: Door to dining #11 off southeast corner of atrium #5.  To north is Jashemski #A or #12; (north side of garden) -- Opposite dining room #13.
column21: Largest room in house, situated in southeast corner of house.  Wide opening provides good view to north wall of garden.  Larger than average doorway in west wall opens to atrium.  At west end of north wall is opening that seems too low for use as doorway, but fact that it goes through to floor means that it may be too low to be appropriate to pass things through wall. Lintels over doorways not preserved -- Walls topped off with modern tile for waterproofing.  Small door in wall is an anomaly.

column14: Opens south into garden 12.  Dining room is an extension beyond simple rectangular plan of House of Amazons.  Abuts to north and west to next house up street 6-2-15, House of Pupius.  On east side is VI.ii.24, House of Cossii.
column15: Opens south into garden 12.  Dining room is an extension beyond simple rectangular plan of House of Amazons.  Abuts to north and west to next house up street 6-2-15, House of Pupius.  On east side is VI.ii.24, House of Cossii.
column21: One of the best examples of painted interiors. See full doc in PPM.  Doorway appears to have been part. Blocked suggesting a different phase.  A single course preserved in two blocks (how high was it and did it affect view into garden?) New tiled roof installed sloping from west to east.  Windows preserved above molded cornice in north wall.  Damaged mosaic floor will be better documented in PPM.

column14: Room opens with wide west opening.  To south a low door connects tablinum dining room to a dead end space.  To north is an identical low doorway that has been blocked.
column15: Room opens with wide west opening.  To south a low door connects tablinum dining room to a dead end space.  To north is an identical low doorway that has been blocked.
column21: Was originally used as a tablinum, because in a small house such as this, the formal room (tablinum) opposite doorway could be used for dining as well.  Interior of room has well preserved example of first style décor.  The dado is undecorated, above is a single course of horizontal bricks, above is a series of tall panels topped by plaster molding.  Two more courses of horizontal blocks topped by another molding.  All of these depictions of blocks in plaster have been painted- greens, reds, yellows, purples, and blues  (look at PPM).  Pavement is white tesserae with crushed brick in a geometric pattern.  Above level of second plaster molding is a low panel dentilated frieze-fragment preserved is about 10 cm long on southeast corner.

column14: contiguous with peristyle, latrine inside
column21: Small rectangular room; entrance in southwest corner from garden, square cooking platform in northwest corner.  Latrine in southeast corner.  Opus signinum in east half of room.  Some original plaster on north wall.

column14: large open room on north side of house, flanked by two smaller rooms.
column15: large open room on north side of house, flanked by two smaller rooms.
column21: Dining room faces south on axis with impluvium, because there is no tablinum in house, this room presumably served both purposes (dining room and tablinum).  Floor is raised slightly above level of atrium and paved in white tesserae in a pinkish ground (cocciopesto).  Fragments of faded wall plaster preserved on all three walls.  On east wall is a good stretch of dentilated frieze, another portion on north wall in east corner without dental work is present.  No evidence of vault alone, but a good place for one.

A sign on east wall records restoration in 1977.  Remains of faded wall plaster preserved on south wall; no visible remains of original floor covering.

column14: Southeast of dining room (21).
column21: An opening on the west wall into dining room (21). A large opening on the south wall into the garden. An unusual feature is found in the room as a shallow marble lined pool in the center of the room with perhaps enough room around it for dining. Other than the pool and threshold the is no other evidence of floor remaining. Large fragments of terracotta are found in the wall, mature where the final surface applied remains.

column14: Northwest corner
column21: Badly eroded not reconstructed.  Indications of full storage below north end, not under arched opening.  Stone indicates it might have been covered with a lintel.  Set against west wall into northwest corner.  Another feature could be located south of platform, but without excavation no evidence of what it is.

column14: Located in lower level, in southeast corner of property.  Easternmost room in suite, below terrace above, reached by staircase in southwest corner of atrium.
column15: Located in lower level, in southeast corner of property.  Easternmost room in suite, below terrace above, reached by staircase in southwest corner of atrium.
column21: Large rectangular room, opened to south to large window.  Nice remains of painted wall plaster on west and east, not so preserved against north end as well as poorly preserved fragments of plaster beneath segmental arch of vault.  The floor is exceptionally well preserved but dirty.  White tesserae create octagonal and diamond forms.  Octagons displayed pieces of colored marble all in a darker matrix ( matrix not mosaic) (See PPM Vol. 8).  Toward back, that is north of room is rectangular panel bordered by stripes, black and white tesserae, with white central mosaic in which larger pieces of colored and veined marble displayed.  Circular discs in center.  Squares and triangles of various shapes.  Unique features are the furniture niches which are cut into the east and west flank walls.  West is clearly visible, but east obstructed by large wooden frame.  The niche is deeper and taller than most and has protruding bench like feature within.   The two niches are not opposite.  West wall niche is further south than mate in east wall.  On west wall, above niche, is a patch of plaster that has been removed in a regular shape suggesting that the painting was taken.  Smaller hole through existing painted wall in northwest.  Note: not discussing features of paintings.  Found in PPM.

column14: Room four to east and terrace to south.
column15: Room four to east and terrace to south.
column21: A rectangular room - south facing - with a doorway to room four in southeast corner.  Wall painting survives on south and west sides.  White and red with red lower register with red trim.  Some yellow is present.  Position with view and wall painting, however, note traffic and proximity to stairs.

column8: Jashemski, 1979, does not mention this house

column14: Doorway to room 8 in southwest corner.  Passageway (room 3) to the north of the apsed end formed by the nymphaeum.
column15: Doorway to room 8 in southwest corner.  Passageway (room 3) to the north of the apsed end formed by the nymphaeum.
column21: South facing rectangular vaulted room.  Marble slab floor.  Molded plaster (First Style?) in southwest corner.  Niche with blue, white and yellow mosaic decorating the arch in north wall.  Contains stepped nymphaeum draining down into plastered basin which runs across the width of the north end of the room.  Decorative niches in exterior face of the basin.  Surviving plaster.  Doorway in southwest corner opens into room 8.

column14: Off northwest corner of atrium and immediately west of house entrance.  Connects low door to room 2 to west (storeroom.)  Wall to south separates from narrow passage leading east-west from house 30 to house 29.
column15: Off northwest corner of atrium and immediately west of house entrance.  Connects low door to room 2 to west (storeroom.)  Wall to south separates from narrow passage leading east-west from house 30 to house 29.
column21: One of the most informative in town, although with a great deal of restoration.  Entered from atrium by door in southeast corner.  L-shaped platform in northeast corner.  Large, partially-preserved window in north wall.  Low doorway connects to west (room 2, storage.)  Brick oven set on platform, slightly higher than cooking platform in northwest corner.  Unique at least to paint; we've looked at houses and kitchens so far in regions 6, 7, and 8, is the floor of cocciopesto with its characteristic reddish color.  Perhaps as a means of facilitating washing of floors, is a beveled edge around walls and platforms.  Floor does not look repaired.  Drain beneath western space beneath platform leads out to street and was way of washing down floor and letting it drain out.

column14: Window in north above it.  Oven to west (attached.)
column16: Window in north above it.  Oven to west (attached.)
column21: L-shaped platform against east and north walls and set into northeast corner.  Is heavily restored.  Three spaces beneath platform covered not by arches, but by modern concrete lintels.  Storage for fuel is east and northeast; partially closed off by low beveled pavement edging, but the third one to northwest is open for drainage to street.  Reconstruction in small stone block and includes broken tile upper surface.  No front lip preserved but a bit of edging material is found along south wall.

column14: West of cooking platform. West drain.
column16: West of cooking platform. West drain.
column21: Small brick oven set on a stone platform in northwest corner.  Front of platform is restored (upper portion at least) and arched opening provides for fuel storage beneath.  Small cubicle oven opens south to allow opening by a flat arch in brick.

column14: Room 9 to the north.
column21: A small square room to the south of the stairs in room 10 goes to the floor above.  Eschebach identifies this as a kitchen; no features survive.  Small arched opening in the northeast accesses the storage space beneath the stairs.

column14: Atrium (room 2) to the west.
column21: Rectangular room facing atrium (room 2) to the northwest.  South and west walls survive only at the base.  Traces of plaster survive on the east wall with red trim and white background.  Fragments of plaster on the north.  The north wall consists of lava outcrags, with floor level of house 6 at a higher level.

column14: If PPM is correct, Atrium (room 2) to the northeast.  If Eschebach is correct, none.
column15: If PPM is correct, Atrium (room 2) to the northeast.  If Eschebach is correct, none.
column21: The shop is entered through Entrance 4.  Room may have been decorated but no longer extant.  The room is rectangular in shape.  Eschebach indicates a counter perpendicular to the street.  It lacked embedded dolia though it may have had a place for cooking.  The counter is no longer extant.  Eschebach indicates a place for a brazier in western corner, yet no longer extant.  Eschebach shows no access to house I.2.3.  PPM does show a door to house in the northeast corner of the sales room.

column21: Small square room with doorway opening south to peristyle (room 8).  Plaster survives on all walls, but no decoration.  Support for beams in the north and east walls exist for floor above.  There is a plaster-lined latrine in the northeast corner with a drain above to a similar plaster lined latrine in the room above.

column21: Rectangular dining room with wide doorway opening north to peristyle (room 8).  Third style wall painting with red upper register and white lower register survives in places.

column16: Cooking platform 2304 is to the E.

column14: The latrine 2303 is to the E.
column16: The latrine 2303 is to the E.

column14: None
column21: Above the entrance to I.II.1 on the north wall on the outside of the shop is an aediculate lararium. It appears to have been decorated but much of it is gone today.

column14: Atrium to the south, street to the north.
column15: Atrium to the south, street to the north.
column21: The counter room is entered from the street to the North to the west of the counter. Two counters and work area make up most of the eastern part of the room which is on an E/W axis. On the west wall is a window looking into dining room 8. Along the southern wall are two doors leading into the atrium. The western door is accessed from the doorway of the counter room, the eastern door from the work area between the two counters. Unable to tell what kind of floor although it was probably beaten cement. The walls were painted, but little remains of the design. On the western wall to the upper right of the window are two rectangular cavities, use unknown. On the eastern wall above the counter are small rectangular holes that may have supported beams for an upper floor.

column14: Counter 2308 to the east
column21: The second counter, which takes up much of the room, is zig zag shaped. One short arm parallel to the street, and just inside the shop lies on an E/W axis. There is a small connecting arm on a N/S axis, linking the arm with the middle arm, also on the E/W axis. It lies farther into the shop, and as reconstructed may have held an imbedded dolium. The third arm, the longest one, lies on a n/S axis and it stands all the way to the south wall, where abutting the south wall on  an E/W axis is a brazier with a small platform to the east. The sides of the central counter were stuccoed and painted, though it is difficult to tell if the top had tiles. The zig zag shaped counter creates a work area in the NE corner of the room and in the center of the room, between the two counters.

column14: Counter 2307 to the west.
column21: An L shaped counter lies against the eastern wall on a N/S axis from the south wall, to within a short distance of the north wall. On the short arm of the E/W axis is made up primarily of a step shelf which abuts against the east wall. The step shelf has two shelves. In the long arm of the counter, near the south wall, there may have been an imbedded dolium, no longer extant. As reconstructed, it is difficult to tell how the counter was surfaced, either on the top and sides though there appears to be some plaster on the top and side step of the step shelf and on the bottom west side of the counter.

column14: Atrium 2 to the north
column21: Rectangular room with a N/S access, cocciopesto floor with white tessera decoration in a geometric pattern, In the center of the wall there is a door opening to the atrium 2 with restored lintel and no threshold. In the center of the south wall, there is a large window looking south into the garden. The ceiling is restored. The painting style was fourth on all walls. There is a black lower register, red above and details are poorly preserved.

column14: Atrium 2 to the south
column21: Cocciopesto floor in a rectangular room with a N/S axis. Doorway in the center of the south wall opening to atrium 2. Square plaster window high on the north wall, the narrow end is to the north. Ceiling restored. In the center of the east wall, a restored window opens to the counter room. Painting survives on all four walls, best preserved on the north wall. Black lower register, white above with fantastical elements with masks and birds. The central image has been removed. In the NE corner, there is an insert depicting a bird and container. The lintel of the doorway is restored and there is a stone threshold.

column14: Kitchen (28) to the south.
column21: A plastered, painted storeroom off the kitchen with barrel vaulted ceiling which has partially collapsed.  Plastered with 4th style painting with red bands.  A Rondo is gold, red, gold and cream painted.  *Drawing unavailable due to collapse.

column14: Garden (18) to the west.
column21: Entrance is off a walled garden (dining, 18) in the western wall.  Doorway to small rectangular room with a painted storage room door on the western wall.  Slightly barreled ceiling.  Plastered walls and the plaster is cream colored.  On the south wall are two great snakes arched above an altar with a pine cone burning on the altar.  The larger snake is crested and bearded and is yellow with red scales and sharp forked tongue.  The crest and beard are red.  The female snake can be seen from head to tail.  The burning sacrifice may include fruit, cakes and nuts.  The snakes are surrounded by garlands and ribbons.  There is a high window on the outside wall and a spherical stone that looks like an omphalos is on the top of a broken column on the floor.  Below the window and in front of the storage room.  Floor is mostly obscured by debris but parts show a polychrome marble chips.

column14: Lararium (2397) is to the southwest and latrine (2396) to the north.
column16: Lararium (2397) is to the southwest and latrine (2396) to the north.
column21: Large rectangular cooking platform, masonry plastered frontage.  Plastered surface.  High lip w/restored terra cotta molding.  At the rear are 5 masonry and terra cotta supports for grills.

column14: Cooking platform (2395) to the south.
column21: Latrine inserted into the NE corner of the kitchen separated by a interior wall and lipped threshold.  Plastered floor largely obscured by earth.  The latrine itself is in the N corner but any trace of the drain is obscured.  Against the partition wall to the west is a low masonry bench supporting the seat.  Undecorated plaster on the E wall overlies a blocked plastered doorway from earlier phase.

column14: Cooking platform (2395) to the east.
column21: Lararium niche and painting extending over southern wall of kitchen.  Two snakes (agathadaemones) on either side of partially preserved picture of altar.  The snakes are against a background of white w/vegetation.  Above the right hand snake is a lower half a lar and a smaller image (still extant of a flute player or tibicen).  Above the left hand snake the painting is no longer extant although there is a largely restored lararium niche with traces of white plaster, red border and indeterminate decoration.  Fragments of molding above.

column14: None
column21: The triclinium was located in the SE part of the house.  One enters from a doorway in the NW corner.  Room is roughly rectangular with a SE-NW axis.  On the SW wall just after the entrance is a small window looking into the garden anteroom.  Just past the window, the wall juts slightly into the room creating a small antechamber.  Farther in room on the same wall is a window looking into the garden (12).  On the SE rear wall is a window onto the triclinium (13).  The floor is cocciopesto with irregular pattern of square and rectangular marble pieces.  The walls were painted in antiquity in the 3rd style with a dado around walls showing plants.  At the top of ceiling is crown molding with evidence of a timbanium on SE wall.  Off center of the floor is a slab of marble of indeterminate shape in center of which is a round hole of indeterminate use; perhaps a drain or socket to support a table.

column14: Garden 12 to the west.
column21: Rectangular room E/W access opening to the west to garden (12).  Partially preserved threshold w/placings for door.  Cocciopesto floor, partly obscured by vegetation and earth.  Window ? (modern) is in the center of the N wall into triclinium (11).  Plaster survives on all 4 walls.  Red lower register w/yellow panels above w/red borders and white trim.  High in the east wall are placings for joists.  In the SW corner at ground level there is a drain leading out to the garden (12) to the west.  Paintings third style.

column14: Atrium (2) to the northwest.  Stairway (7) on the southwest side.
column15: Atrium (2) to the northwest.  Stairway (7) on the southwest side.
column21: The cenaculum is located at the back southeast of the atrium (2).  One approaches the cenaculum by way of stairs (7) to the south corner of the atrium.  Ascending the stairs one approaches the cenaculum from the southwest.  The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest, northeast access.  On the northwest side overlooking the atrium are six columns.  The end columns southwest, northeast are engaged*.  The capitals are in all cases ionic.  Since the cenaculum has been totally reconstructed there is no way to determine the nature of the floor, ceiling or decoration.  *In antiquity, there seems to have been two railings (iron bars) connecting the columns.  This is evidenced by two holes on both sides of the interior columns and a single set of holes in the end columns.

column14: Room 14 to the west, room 16 to the north
column15: Room 14 to the west, room 16 to the north
column21: A small rectangular room on a north/south axis. Northeast from the main entrance near the middle of the house. As one walks into the dining room through a large doorway from the west, one sees three columns with capitals that overlook the garden triclinium (19). The room is decorated in the fourth style. Lowest dado typical black with aloe plants on all four walls alternating with a yellow upright images and a yellow boarder. The second segment of the decoration is alternating red panels with white architectural details and gold stenciling. The back wall to the northeast, the first gold panel has a medallion with a face of a garlanded woman with earrings, chubby cheeks and a wistful smile. To the east of the gold anels is a thin panel of 2 1/2 pine cones with green and red garland of flowers. A large central panel has a picture obliterated. White densiling was around the picture. Next to the east another thin panel is obliterated. The final panel to the east is yellow with a medallion (Dionysus) with grape garland in their hair, holding perhaps a thrysus. The east wall shows the same yellow, white, red, white and yellow patterns as on the north wall. However, the medallion in the northwest corner is faded. The thin panels are white architectural features. The red panel is gone. Traces of yellow panel on the south wall is indeterminate. Sloping ceiling of modern construction approx. 15' feet high, sloping to the south. Traces of tessarae are found on the floor. The doorway threshold is gone.

column14: Room 14 to the east, room 15 to the northeast, room 27 to the southeast
column15: Room 14 to the east, room 15 to the northeast, room 27 to the southeast
column21: A square room, along the northeast wall is a plastered wall with a three columned portico that has been subsequently been blocked by a a partition. The northeast corner is a window to room #27. At the base of the wall is a shallow plastered water channel. There is a lead grill at the southeast end of the channel and a plaster raised water channel with a lip continues along the southeast wall (2615). In the southeast corner, this is a plaster and a rectangular insert for a table or similar object. In the center of the western half of the room is a masonry triclinium couch (2613). To the east of the couch is a circular masonry cistern (2614). At the junction of the couch and the southwest wall, plaster survives. Below the northwest wall is modern. Between the couch and the north corner there is a stone block.

column14: Cistern (2614)  to the ease, gutter (2615) to the northeast.
column16: Cistern (2614)  to the ease, gutter (2615) to the northeast.
column21: A large masonry U-shaped couch, plastered surface. The eastern arm surface is restored. Between the couches is a plastered floor with a drain at the base of the western couch. The interior face of all three couches are plastered. In the center between the couches is a rectangular plastered table. In front of the two couches is a marble structural block that is not in situ.

column14: Couch (2613) to the west, gutter (2615) to the east and north.
column16: Couch (2613) to the west, gutter (2615) to the east and north.
column21: Circular masonry cistern head, tiled surface, plaster external face. Two masonry blocks on the top

column14: Cistern (2614) to the southwest, couch (2613) to the southwest
column16: Cistern (2614) to the southwest, couch (2613) to the southwest
column21: At the base of the southeast wall of the room, there is a shallow plastered gutter. At the southeast end of the gutter there is a lead grill. The gutter continues as a raised bench with a plastered channel and a lip.

column14: Room 22 to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is located just as one enters entrance #12 through a doorway to the southwest. The room is roughly rectangular and is on a southeast/northwest axis. On the northwest wall of the kitchen there is a window into room #23. The floor is indeterminate, as is the ceiling. Although the walls were probably stuccoed and painted, no evidence remains. There is no evidence for a cooking platform or a latrine. The sill is unusually wide, part of which extends to the west wall.

column14: Room #23 to the north, Storeroom #26 to the east.
column15: Room #23 to the north, Storeroom #26 to the east.
column21: A rectangular room on a southeast/northwest axis. The doorway opens to the street to the southeast with a high step of modern restoration. Traces of undecorated plaster is seen on the south wall. The doorway has a modern lintel. In the northeast corner the room continues into room #23. The floor is not preserved, in the northwest corner, a wide open doorway with a masonry plastered threshold and a modern lintel to room #26. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: Room #25 to the east.
column21: A rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis. A modern ceiling with an earth floor. The areas of the room are obscured by usage as storage for roof tiles. The upper courses of the walls are restored. Plaster survives at the base of the east, south and west walls. The plaster in the south and southwest corners shows white with a red trim. In the southeast corner there is a wide doorway with a plastered masonry threshold and a modern lintel leading to room #25. in the southwest corner, there is a blocked plastered cupboard niche. From earlier phase. The ceiling is modern reconstruction.

column14: Room #14 to the northwest
column21: One enters the sales room through a wide doorway from the southeast corner. The room is rectangular in shape on a east/west axis. The wall across the street contain many amphorae. Step down from the street. Wide doorway entrance to the northwest leading to the hallway (14). Traces of plaster are seen on all four walls. Due to the nature of the restaurant, we think food could have been sold in this commercial space. Cement floor. Walls intact to the first floor level. Ceiling is non-extant.

Oven shares a wall with bakery oven at VII.2.3.Vann suggests both ovens could have been installed at same time. Room has large arch protruding 6 ft over oven.

column21: Atrium (converted to workspace), On south wall there is a kneading machine. It is round made of stone with a cavity in the center. It is broken on side. In the center of the basin is a small metal square-pivot- with an indentation. Curtis says there would have been a wooden vertical post inserted into the indentation. Horizontal post would have been attached to the vertical to turn the machine. On the south side of machine there is a groove. Curtis says a spike would have been inserted here and that there probably was another one on the opposite side (area broken away now) There is evidence of lines on inner part of basin.

column14: adjacent to 3 other mills

column14: entered through atrium to workroom
column21: Second room on left to the east. There is an entrance off the atrium/converted into workspace) There is evidence of a stone threshold. column14: adjacent to the kneading machine
column21: Atrium, In the center of the former atrium, is a large rectangular water trough. There is evidence that the former impluvium was waterproofed and the walls expanded. The outer walls are unfinished. The outer rim has evidence of finish stone work and broken areas. Curtis thinks it is a water trough for animals.Mayeske claims it could have been used to wash grain or for the processing work in the bakery.Vann states it is too large to be a water trough for animals.

column21: Facing east is a very large oven. It has a large arched opening. Recessed within the archway is a shelf with a square opening beneath the shelf. There about one third is just rocky material. There is a small rectangular opening on the south side of the front wall. On the ground in front of the front of the south side is an L-shaped group of masonry rocks. On the north side there of the structure there is a large rectangular opening

There is no other mosaic pattern intact.  The room has a barrel-vaulted ceiling with lunettes. The three walls have extensive wall decorating.  The north wall has much of its decoration missing.  The south wall has a large center section missing.  The east wall has patches of wall decoration missing.  There is a marble threshold.

column21: entrance 31,51To the east is a large triclinium with a very large entrance way. There is an intact marble-faced step and threshold. In the east wall is a semicircle. In the center of this semicircle is a long recessed rectangular structure with an arched shape top. There is evidence of wall decorations on all walls. There is a rebuilt roof of terracotta covering the semicircular east back wall area. On the south wall there is a long narrow reconstructed shelf covered in terracotta. It appears to be protecting the wall decoration.

column21: Cooking platform is in northeast corner of house, situated in the northeast corner or U-shaped kitchen.  The unrestored platform has a typical fuel storage area underneath comprised of frame and cut stone.  Top of platform is eroded in front (S).  Back edge contains remains of terra cotta tiles and vertical lip on edge.  Walls in back are approximately 3M high with no evidence of chimney.  At southeast of cooking platform attached to east wall is a 1/2 column topped by two pieces of tile to create its capital (edges are broken away).  A raised spiral yellow  band wraps three times around the white 1/2 column.  Is this a kitchen lararium and this represent a serpent?  The broken bottom of the 1/2 column reveals construction consisting of broken terra cotta tiles and decomposed ferrous fasteners.  Patches of wall plaster remain but no paint is extant.

column14: Located at southwest corner of atrium, flanked by corridor #10 to East, open through window to garden #13 to south, to the north is a lararium along the west wall of the atrium.  A possible lararium niche is near the doorway into the dining room next to a bricked up (ancient times) doorway to house next door (entrance #13 Pompeii #14).
column15: Located at southwest corner of atrium, flanked by corridor #10 to East, open through window to garden #13 to south, to the north is a lararium along the west wall of the atrium.  A possible lararium niche is near the doorway into the dining room next to a bricked up (ancient times) doorway to house next door (entrance #13 Pompeii #14).
column21: This smaller dining room is surrounded by very high walls where much of the plaster and paint still survives.  The north wall provides a good example of two successive layers of red paint and plaster.  The inner coat is chiseled to prepare for the addition of an outer or later coat.  The west wall includes a lower window broken through to the bakery warehouse, below the house next door.  (Entrance 13 Pompeii 14)  The edges are not finished and does not look like a normal opening made as part of the architecture.  A large window in the middle of the south wall looks onto a garden area.  A large circle shaped opening is approximately centered above the window.  Fragments of plaster or cream and green colored paint are found on the pile on the floor as is a loom weight and a bit of molded decorative plaster.  This window contains large fragments of blue, green sheet glass embedded under opus reticulatum facade in garden room.

column15: Kitchen to south; hallway to east

To south, square opening to kitchen; recess for bench on north wall, arch on south wall.

column21: Large market for meat, fish, and vegetables. On south wall are 11 openings for small shops (A-K) with entrance onto street in southeast corner. Market enclosed by high walls with evidence of plaster on all walls, very well preserved fresco on west wall with food + drink items depicted. Rectangular space with drainage channel occurring central area of market with circular fish market area of which 12 column bases remain (no longer with columns or roofs at center. On west wall are two areas dedicated to the imperial cult, one area in southeast corner has counters for display and sale shops also along north exterior wall and along west wall opening onto the Forum, all with a food and drink connections.

column21: Around atrium section of Macellum, now grassy, is a large u-shaped travertine gutter. It would have circled whole grassy area originally, but only segments remain in situ today to north, east and west. Gutter was used for water drainage by whole Macellum commercial space and particularly for the fish market, which it surrounds.

column21: This kitchen, located near the #60 entrance, is just south of the garden.  A large masonry structure remains that includes two rectangular enclosed spaces.  The longer "space" to the west may have been the base to a staircase.  The "space" to the east may have been a well.  Neither structure is visible more than 1 m from he surface and most are less than 15 cm.  A small terracotta vessel base appears to be embedded into the ground at the southwest corner of the well.  The northeast corner of this room is missing.

column8: Sogliano NSC 1899;  artifacts in the museum (bones).  There is no evidence of bone scatter visible on the surface in this shop room.

column21: Shop for meat (7). Opposite the Macellum is this one room that contains a well. The element that defines this feature (well) as related to food and drink was the recovery of the cache of bones reported in literature. The masonry well is located against the back south wall of the room. Approximately one meter stands above the ground surface.

column14: None
column21: Unexcavated room could prove to be a kitchen due to location in structure and existence of a window to street. No archaeologists have ever called this a kitchen, however possibility of its presence remains. No drawing required.

The small altar noted by Jashemski is no longer remaining at the site.

These rooms appear to be on an upper story reached from somewhere in the industrial rooms. In this room there is also the remains of a marble threshold jutting from the south wall.

column21: Large tufa blocks define door frame; limestone blocks at base frames have cuttings for facing material; no threshold (appears to have had mosaic over threshold). Mosaic floor is uncovered in northeast corner showing two broad black lines parallel to east wall on white background. No preserved wall painting. The room is trapezoidal in shape.

column14: Located on south wall of room 2.
column16: Located on south wall of room 2.
column21: Recessed niche at appropriate site for a dining couch on south wall. Evidence of plaster remains.

column15: kitchen is approached to the north by corridor 8.  it is located at the south end connected by a doorway south into atrium (2) that belongs to entrance (12).
column21: Kitchen has plaster remnants still visible. There is a vertical embrasure in north wall above low doorway connecting to corridor 8.  Small circular window is located on western wall.  Structure appears to have three different structures prior (9,10,12).  There is latrine located at the south end.  The room is quite small and rectangular.  A hearth is located at the south end of the room next to the latrine.  Tall doorway located on eastern wall looks out onto the atrium (2).  A threshold of marble still remains below the small door on the northern side.  No lararium appears to be found.

column14: located east of dining room (9).  South of room 17.
column15: located east of dining room (9).  South of room 17.
column21: Large rectangular room with entrance located on the west side of the north wall.  There is no threshold visible.  The latrine (19) is located in the northeast corner of the room.  Only the west side of the foundation of the latrine remains.  On the south side of the room, along the eastern portion of the south wall remains a cooking platform.  No smooth top of the platform remains.  There is what looks like a hearth underneath the platform on the western side of it.  On the bottom of the south side of the room, on the western side, is a semicircular hole that is defined by an arched brick border.  It appears to lead out into street.  Plaster remains on the east, west, south walls of the room, but no paint.  There are three post holes along the middle portion of the eastern wall.

column14: platform is located on the southern wall of the kitchen (18).  And directly south of the latrine (19) across from it.

There is a hole, the same height of the platform, in the platform indicated a hearth  it is located near the western end of the platform.

column15: connects to the west side of the atrium (2) through two doors.  Connects to garden (8) to the south through the third door.
column21: Large rectangular room with three doorways. First two obvious doorways are found on opposite sides of the eastern wall of the room.  The third doorway is tentative as to whether it is a doorway or simply a large window looking out onto the garden (8) to the south.  On the western side of this "doorway", there appears to be a definitive smoothness of the stone from top to bottom (to the ground).  Giving support to the proposal to it being a doorway, however, the eastern side of the "doorway" barely remains, is broken up and only reaches about 3 feet high.  The two doorways that do exist look out onto the atrium (2).  The only plaster remnant in the northwest corner of the room.  There is evidence of pink paint on this plaster portion.  A stone threshold remains in the doorway on the eastern wall to the south.  It has two visible imprints showing evidence of a door.  The doorway on the opposite side has no threshold remaining.

column14: west facing room into garden (18).  At southeast corner of the garden but is not aligned with the garden, tablinum, atrium axis.

Paneled tiled floor, multi colored, in opus sectile found in the center of the floor.  Most of the floor is covered in dirt.  Remnants of plaster can be found on all four walls.  Evidence of red paint remains on upper portion of walls.

No indication of sales counter but this could have had wooden counter like the one depicted of the baker selling bread.  A piece of a mill stone seems to be set in the northeast corner of shop.

Post hole on top of west wall (northwest corner) suggests a second story.  No other attributes are evident.

column21: Counter is L-shaped and quite narrow.  There are no dolia nor space for them.  There are three holes along the northern side of the counter.  A hearth is located at the southern end of the counter (see bibliography).  Counter has a stone surface.

column14: East of Latrine
column15: At north extension of House.  Approached by corridor (7) leading from atrium aposticum (backdoor) leading to street.  Latrine (9) in northwest corner Cooking platform on the East side.  Kitchen connects south to room 13. Eschebach calls this a Officina Lanifricaria (woolen garments).
column21: Cooking platform at east.  Encompasses all of east wall, and north and south walls to doorways.  Tiled surface.

column14: None
column21: Marble threshold. Mosaic floor.  Overlooking garden. Remains of plaster with paint.

column14: None
column16: South of fauces.  Located off atrium
column21: recessed niche of appropriate height for dining couches across entire south wall.  Remains of plaster along all four walls with remnants of paint.  Door located on northeast corner

column14: attached south of kitchen
column21: Small rectangular room attached at south to kitchen. Niche on east wall (lower half). Plaster remains on all four walls with paint on north and east walls. East and west walls have molding along top. South wall has herringbone brick pattern (later intersect, very rough masonry. Upper portion broken tiles (brick) set in heavy mortar without any precision).

column14: None
column15: Approached from north by corridor (8).  Kitchen at south end and connects via doorway South into atrium (2) that belongs to entrance (12).  North of latrine
column21: Arch opens to north for storage of fuel underneath. Top of hearth is not preserved to its original horizontal surface. Remains in situ suggest very high cooking platform. Appears to be a combination of three earlier small structures
column70: Small Craft Shop with workshop and shop

column8: Eschebach, 1993, reports this as a craft shop.
column14: Connects northeast to atrium (2) that belongs to entrance (12).
column15: Connects northeast to atrium (2) that belongs to entrance (12).
column21: Small rectangular room with doorway at northwest corner. Remnants of plaster on all four walls. Red paint on lower part of east and south wall. This can only be a dining room if facility opens to door 12, if it was still a house at time of eruption. Certainly originally a house and certainly a dining room originally. LV agrees with Eschebach's identification of this as a craft shop; BJ sees the entire property 7, 10, 9, 12 as a large eating facility.

column8: Fiorelli reports a grafitto mentioning Saturnalia in VII, 10, 12.
column9: Fiorelli reports a grafitto mentioning Saturnalia in VII

column14: Far west end of house.  Parallel to street.  Door 24 (west side) led to an irregular shaped entrance court on the street.  Connected with a room on other side of court at entrance 25, which is associated with this house by Eschebach.
column15: Far west end of house.  Parallel to street.  Door 24 (west side) led to an irregular shaped entrance court on the street.  Connected with a room on other side of court at entrance 25, which is associated with this house by Eschebach.
column21: A trapezoid shaped room with a doorway on the south wall and a low doorway on the west wall opening to street. Evidence of plaster on east wall. Cooking platform in northwest corner encompasses half of north wall. Terracotta vessel buried in northeast corner of room. No lararium is evident here. Kitchen is shared with House of Cornelius Dademus. Must go out of house to access kitchen.

column14: Northwest corner of room.
column21: Located in kitchen (17) in northwest corner next to low door. Low platform, tiled. No storage area evident here. Terracotta vessel in northeast corner buried.

column14: Connects to the very small entrance court (atrium testudinate).  Two steps up from the level of the atrium and is opened by a window in North wall for a view of the garden.  (Many discoveries of garden sculpture.).
column15: Connects to the very small entrance court (atrium testudinate).  Two steps up from the level of the atrium and is opened by a window in North wall for a view of the garden.  (Many discoveries of garden sculpture.).
column21: Medium doorway on east wall. Marble threshold. Mosaic floor. Large window in north wall. Window opening on upper part of south wall. Plaster remnants on all four walls. A large rectangular room. Square cutouts on either side of threshold for door.

column14: South door faces peristyle garden (6);  west doorway leads to open air courtyard (11).  Attached to room (12) at west.
column15: South door faces peristyle garden (6);  west doorway leads to open air courtyard (11).  Attached to room (12) at west.
column21: Large rectangular room. Extra large doorway in south with marble threshold overlooking garden. Door opening in southwest corner of west wall. In center of room a marble geometric pattern (opus sectile?) Plaster remnants on all four walls. Wall with evidence of red and yellow paint. On west wall stone overhang protecting (??) painting. On east wall evidence of a blocked window beneath plaster.

column14: None
column15: South of kitchen (14).  West of open air courtyard (11).
column21: Latrine. Small rectangular room with door opening on north side. Possible oil niche in west wall. Window opening in east wall facing open courtyard (11). Niche in south wall: would not be a lararium if in latrine.  Evidence of plaster on west wall.

column14: Located north of the latrine (15); west of room 13; northwest of open-air courtyard (11).
column15: Located north of the latrine (15); west of room 13; northwest of open-air courtyard (11).
column21: Small rectangular room with a stone step underneath a single doorway which leads to a second portion of the room.  This second portion consists of a large divided stone wall.  The use of this area is uncertain.  The planks on the bottom of this squared area is reasonably modern but older than the wooden and tile roofing atop it.  Lindley believes that only the lower portion of the two flanking walls is ancient because there is modern mortar patching above it.  This leads to an uncertainty as to how high the flanking walls actually were.  The ancient mortar height goes against speculation that this is where the cooking platform was.*  Lindley wants the ancient mortar sealing in southwest corner to be measured from ground up.  The main portion of kitchen has a sealed window on the southern end of the west wall.  There is also a horizontal array of post holes indicating a second story.  There are a few remnants of plaster on eastern and western wall.  There is another entrance, also with a step leading into the second portion of the room (with the alcove) which looks out onto open-air courtyard (11)

column14: The location of this room is west of the peristyle garden (6) and south of room 8.
column15: The location of this room is west of the peristyle garden (6) and south of room 8.
column21: Medium sized room with a large opened entrance overlooking the peristyle garden (6) to the east.  The location and its existing paint decoration support that this room could also be used for dining.  There is plaster remnants along with red paint on the north, south, and west walls of this room.  There are two post holes up on top of the southern wall indicating a second floor.  There is a small semicircular lararium niche on the upper central portion of the west wall.  There are no remnants of decorated flooring, nor a threshold.

column14: None
column15: Located in the northeast corner of the kitchen (18) directly north of the cooking platform within the kitchen.
column21: Latrine. Small square room located within the northeastern corner of the kitchen (18).  Only the western wall appears to remain and it is merely a foundation at that.

column14: Located to the south of room (10); east of the peristyle garden (8); west of the kitchen (18).
column15: Located to the south of room (10); east of the peristyle garden (8); west of the kitchen (18).
column21: This room appears to be a medium-sized room although most of the room is majorly destroyed.  A wide entrance appears to have existed on the west side of the room.  The room overlooks a low wall which has a tiled surface and which surrounds a peristyle garden to the west.  The room also has a single doorway on the western portion of the north wall leading out to a small room (10) next to it.  A small amount of plaster remains on the eastern back wall of this room.  No decoration, nor thresholds exist.

column14: South of storage room (3)
column21: L-Shaped Room.  Oven to south.  Stable to north.  Lararium is on west side of the oven room (exterior of east wall of Room 8).  Where oven room turns corner (northwest) a lead downspout from roof of neighboring building. Are no mills but broken mills outside in fauces (2) and no heavy paving stones that indicate mill activity.  Preserved painting on lararium wall of Vesta flanked by Lares.  On bottom register two snakes flanking an altar with what could be pine cones (BJ)

column14: Located south of lararium.  South of stable and raw storage room (8).  Connected east of preparation room (9).
column16: Located south of lararium.  South of stable and raw storage room (8).  Connected east of preparation room (9).
column21: South of room 7, oven room . A large arched opening with square oven opening. On left side of oven is a lead pipe leading to a lead water tank, water coming from a cistern.  A passthrough on each outside wall of oven leads to heated cooking area.

column14: South of the storage room (8).  East of oven (7).
column15: South of the storage room (8).  East of oven (7).
column21: Located in far southwest corner of bakery.  Small rectangular room with doorway in the northeast corner leading to oven room.  Plaster remains on southwest and east walls. On the west and south walls small cutout holes.  On the east wall a passthrough leading to oven.  Post holes on west wall.

column14: North of preparation room (9).  South of stable.  Located behind lararium.
column15: North of preparation room (9).  South of stable.  Located behind lararium.
column21: (L-shaped) preparation (counter) platform.  Small rectangular room.  A medium-sized square window is located in the exact center of the south wall.  Niches on the south and east walls for oil lamps.  Storage for raw materials of proximity to oven.  Plaster remains on all four walls. Post holes along the north wall.

column14: West of storage room 3.
column21: Catillus.  Two pieces of top half of the mill.

column14: Northeast of lararium.
column21: Hearth attached at the south of counter. Semicircular opening in center of hearth.

column14: Southwest of hearth
column21: Lararium located on the west wall in southwest corner.  Plaster and evidence of red paint remain.  Stone shelf protruding from the bottom of the lararium.

column14: South of room 1 (counter room)
column21: Irregularly-shaped dining room with entrance directly off counter room.  Room retains much of original wall decoration with large sections of plaster still showing red and yellow paint color.  Alcove-like area is formed on east wall by position of wall, possibly resulting from unusual corner position of structure.

column14: East to garden (11); south to hallway (12).
column15: East to garden (11); south to hallway (12).
column21: Large rectangular room.  Large window on east wall looking out onto the garden (11).  A small window is centrally located directly above the large window.  There is a single stone fresco centrally located on both north and south walls which resembles, purposefully, a column.  There is a double relief border, which still exists, running along the north, south, and east walls.  All walls have major remnant of red and blue paneled paint.  There appears to have been two bordered paintings on either side of the fake column on the north wall and on the western end of the south wall.  There is a tall doorway on the eastern end of the south wall leading to corridor 12.  Directly west of doorway is a niche, possibly for an oil lamp.

column14: Located east of the peristyle garden (11);  Connects to atrium area (4) from the northeast via doorway.
column15: Located east of the peristyle garden (11);  Connects to atrium area (4) from the northeast via doorway.
column21: Medium sized rectangular room.  West wall is completely opened up to the garden (11).  Threshold at base of west wall still remains (made of marble).  There is a doorway on the western end of south wall leading out to the atrium (4)- not a very tall doorway.  A great amount of plaster with red and yellow paint still remains on all walls;  A bordered relief decoration remains along the top of the walls.  Second story appears to have existed; this room contains a high ceiling intact.
column70: House of the King of Prussia

column14: None
column21: Long rectangular platform spans entire south wall of room 16.  Parts of (tiled) original surface remain in situ.  Nice section of edging tile retained on platform in front of the southeast side.
column70: House of the King of Prussia

column14: Located east of room 14 and room 15 (latrine).  Located south of storage room (17).  Kitchen is in close proximity to back door and corridor 13
column15: Located east of room 14 and room 15 (latrine).  Located south of storage room (17).  Kitchen is in close proximity to back door and corridor 13
column21: Small rectangular room; wide entrance located to the west leading to room 14;  Another wide doorway located o the north; cooking platform located along the south wall;  small arched opening remains on east wall but original purpose uncertain- possibly a lararium.  Entrance on north side leads out into the storage room (17).
column70: House of the King of Prussia

column14: Located right below the lararium on the east wall of room 2
column16: Located right below the lararium on the east wall of room 2
column21: Located on east wall of room.  Contains a tiled surface.  A large fuel storage area is located under the north end of the platform.  Platform on south end has two levels- lower level is tiled and upper level is plastered.  Surface above fuel storage has two protruding blocks on either side of lararium on east wall.  Lararium is directly above cooking platform

column14: Room is located east of room 10, west of the peristyle garden (5); south of room 11.
column15: Room is located east of room 10, west of the peristyle garden (5); south of room 11.
column21: Large rectangular room; entrance with single- step stone threshold located on the northern end of east wall, overlooking garden (5).  Plaster and red paint remain on north, south, and west walls; there appear to be two single-step entrances into room 10.  One entrance is located centrally in the west wall and the other entrance is located at the west end of the north wall.  There is a vertical pipe located at the south end of the west wall.

column14: Located west of latrine (15).  Located northwest of the peristyle garden (5).
column15: Located west of latrine (15).  Located northwest of the peristyle garden (5).
column21: Large room; exit out onto the street located on the eastern end of the north wall; small cooking platform located at the northwest corner of room.  Entrance into the latrine is located at the north end of the east wall.  Remains of a staircase located along the east wall. A small doorway with stone threshold is located on the south wall, overlooking a peristyle garden; medium rectangular window is located on the north wall above the cooking platform.  Small opening is located above the north exit, possibly for ventilation.  Post holes along the east wall as well as staircase suggest a second story.

column14: Room is contiguous with porticoed atrium (5) to north.
column15: Room is contiguous with porticoed atrium (5) to north.
column21: Large rectangular room, narrowing to the east end.  Room is entered from the atrium.  Travertine threshold remains in situ at entrance.  Remnants of plaster remain on east, south, and west walls some of which retain evidence of red color.
column53: Two views because of awkard doorway

column14: Located east of room 5 and northeast of corridor 3.
column15: Located east of room 5 and northeast of corridor 3.
column21: Small square room; there is an exit at the north end of the east wall leading out to the street via two steps.  There are barely remnants of a cooking platform along the south wall.

column14: None
column15: Shop/room is located east of shop/room 16
column21: Very small rectangular room with a rather low cooking platform along the north end of the west wall.  There is a tall doorway leading out onto the street on the north side of the room.  A tiny window is located right above the doorway.  The platform has a tiled surface and there are remnants of plaster and red paint on the east side of the platform.  There are plaster and red paint remnants on all three walls (east, west, south).  The platform is higher in height than a bed.  This block has been previously reported as a row of brothel cubicles.  BJ thinks the possibility of a series fast food related cooking platforms should not be overlooked given the tiled top surfaces and un-bed like characteristics.  The size is variable.

column14: North to room 4- counter room; west of room 3- dining room
column15: North to room 4- counter room; west of room 3- dining room
column21: Rectangular room containing cooking platform in northwest corner.  Room is open to street to west and would have (?) main public entrance to dining room (3) to rear.  To south, room is open to and connected to serving room.  Plaster is retained on west wall.  On north wall, counter circular terra cotta pipe section is built into wall.

column14: Located along the south wall of "roasting room" (1)
column16: Located along the south wall of "roasting room" (1)
column21: Located entirely along the south wall of "roasting room".  No apparent tile formation remains.  There is a roasting pit located in the middle of the platform which is lined with terra cotta on the inside.  There is a tiled surface remaining at the base of the pit.

column14: Located east of the kitchen; north of storeroom (37); north, further, of storeroom (39) and northwest of the latrine (40).
column15: Located east of the kitchen; north of storeroom (37); north, further, of storeroom (39) and northwest of the latrine (40).
column21: Medium-sized rectangular room.  The ceiling is rather low and appears to be a modern reconstruction.  The ancient ceiling was probably higher.  This ceiling is exactly the same height as doorway.  All the walls appear to be ancient, however, they've been painted over recently with white paint.  There is a small square window centrally located on back east wall with modern bars blocking the view.  The doorway is centrally located on west wall directly opposite the window.  The doorway has a step in front of it, leading to kitchen, which appears to be modern.  The door installed here is modern.

column14: Located south of dining room (3) as well as of corridor 1.
column15: Located south of dining room (3) as well as of corridor 1.
column21: Long rectangular room with a U-shaped counter with hearth located at the west end of room in front of the open entrance out onto the street.  There are remains of plaster and red paint in the southeast corner of the room.  There is a water basin (Betty Jo's uncertain) located on the ground in the southeast corner of the room.  The wide entrance out onto the street on the west side of the room shares itself with the corridor.

column14: Located north of corridor 1 and further north of the counter room (2).
column15: Located north of corridor 1 and further north of the counter room (2).
column21: Long rectangular room which has a large entrance on its south side opening up to corridor 1.  There are no remnants of a threshold nor plaster or paint on any of the walls.  There are no remnants of decorated flooring either.

column14: Located west of the cooking platform and even further west of the oven.
column16: Located west of the cooking platform and even further west of the oven.
column21: Possible lararium.  Is quite small, of a semicircular shape, found on west wall of kitchen above the cooking platform.  Only plaster remains on it - no paint.

column8: Eschebach, 1993,  plan shows a square feature.
column14: Southeast Corner.  South of room 7 (other).  East of room 1 (sales room).
column15: Southeast Corner.  South of room 7 (other).  East of room 1 (sales room).
column21: Long rectangular room.  Oversized oven in southeast.  Oven in southeast corner faces west.  Blocked low door in middle of south wall.  Blocked normal sized door in west wall, southwest corner.  Square feature shown in Eschebach plan is missing.  Lararium mentioned by Mayeske was not found.  Although no millstones were found, no heavy pavement preserved, room is of appropriate size to have had milling.

column14: None
column21: A T-shaped platform attached to front of oven located south has a recess for bread or fuel (for cooking).  Top part of oven was missing.

column14: None
column16: Located northeast of the oven room. Would be located adjacent to pass-through on north side of oven (no longer existent).
column21: Undecided.  Might have been used for preparation, or more likely used for storage of baked bread after baking.

column14: None
column21: Large rectangular room with wide opening onto street.  Large travertine blocks evident on either side of entrance.  No built-in features, such as sales counters, remain.

column8: Eschebach, 1993, describes this as a dormitory.
column14: None
column21: Undecided.  This could have been used as a storeroom for finished baked goods prior to being moved out to sales room.  In west wall is niche which would have held bed for sleeping.

column14: Located south of room 1; east of corridor 3.
column15: Located south of room 1; east of corridor 3.
column21: Rectangular room with doorway overlooking room 1 and street.  On the west and south walls there are two niches for dining couches.  In southwest small section of plaster with red paint survives intact.  North wall no longer existent.

column14: None
column21: Not a masonry biclinium; only niches remain on south and east walls.  Niche on east wall does not extend to southeast corner.  It leaves flat wall space for south couch to extend to west wall.

column14: Directly south of dining room; accessed by corridor 3.
column15: Directly south of dining room; accessed by corridor 3.
column21: Small rectangular room.  Minimal remains of cooking platform on south wall.  Room very overgrown.  Opening to 8 is not original.

column14: North of room 2 and corridor 3
column21: Very wide opening to street.  Large travertine blocks on either side of opening.  Large rectangular room.  Plaster remains on east and southwest corner of room.  Square cutout on east wall.  Opening in south to room 2 and corridor 3.

column14: Room lies to south of oven room.
column15: Room lies to south of oven room.
column21: Small rectangular room south of large oven room.  Although no longer visible, a pass through from front of oven would have come directly into room.  Circular window opening on south wall.  Post holes horizontal suggest roofing on second story.  Plaster in situ on south wall.Room contains catillus, kneading oven, stone mortar.

column14: Southwest of stone mortar.  Northeast of catillus (slave mill)
column16: Southwest of stone mortar.  Northeast of catillus (slave mill)
column21: Intact kneading basin.  Stone with holes for wooden kneading components to be attached.

column14: Southwest of kneading basin.
column21: Upper portion of slave mill with poorly preserved upper rim.  Square recess for wooden turning component still visible.

column14: Northeast of kneading mill.
column21: Stone Mortar.  Jagged upper edge.  Broken into two pieces.  Circular stand base intact.  Would have been used for grinding.

column14: North of room 5 garden.  South of room 2.  East of corridor 4.
column15: North of room 5 garden.  South of room 2.  East of corridor 4.
column21: Irregularly shaped room with wide opening overlooking garden (5).  Small square window on north wall opening to room 2.  Evidence of wall decoration, particularly in northeast corner where red paint remains.  Paint in northwest corner as well as on west wall contains plaster in upper sections.  Plaster remains on all four walls in sections.

column14: South of corridor 4.  South of dining room 6.
column15: South of corridor 4.  South of dining room 6.
column21: Room probably in use as a garden.  Currently room contains millstones but it's unknown if these are in situ.  Large irregularly shaped room.  Plaster on east, south, west walls.  Slight tint of red in plaster on all walls.
column70: School of LL Cornelii Amandus Porclus

column14: Atrium (3) at north; Fauces (1) at west; Room (6) at east.
column15: Atrium (3) at north; Fauces (1) at west; Room (6) at east.
column21: Overlooking atrium (3) north, Fauces (1) west, Room (6) east.  Small rectangular room with north opening to atrium.  Large window on east wall opening to room 6.  Plaster remnants on south and west walls with evidence of red and yellow paint.  Marble threshold.  No evidence of flooring.

column14: None
column21: Triclinium niche located on west wall.  Curtis unsure if it is a niche or modern repair.

column14: Northwest of garden (2)
column21: Northwest corner of garden (2), faces south into garden.  Looks to have major painting removed from middle of east wall.  Another panel removed from west wall (north of center).  Circular tondo on both east and west walls are badly damaged.  Marble threshold with opening overlooking garden.  Low door in southeast corner (east wall) looks for service.  Evidence of plaster remains with red and yellow paint.  Decorative molding in northwest corner.

column14: Southeast corner of house
column21: Kitchen (room 12) same as room 17 in the House of Camillus (VII, 12, 23).  Shared by both houses.  Highly unusual.  Located immediately adjacent east of fauces.  Communicates to fauces by a doorway.  Second door from kitchen opens southeast (VII, 12, 25) into small courtyard off of street.

column14: None
column21: Mill stone (meta) quern, located on far northeast corner of L-shaped portico that surrounds extremely small garden on north and east.  Out of context.  Second mill stone in room 3.

column14: Located east of garden (2)
column21: Small square room with a doorway on the west wall.  A threshold remains below it.  Remnants of plaster with red paint can be found on bottom half of all four walls.  Post holes above on north and south walls indicates a second story.  Narrow doorway mentioned overlooks garden (2).

column14: Located near south wall of room 3.
column16: Located near south wall of room 3.
column21: Catillus (top) quern.  Remainder of a small catillus found on ground of room 3 near south wall.

column14: None

column21: Platform is located at the southwest end of the kitchen in between the oven and the west wall.  The platform has a tiled surface.  There are two storage areas below, side-by-side, for fuel.  These areas are defined by a bricked archway bordering the openings.  There are remnants of a bordered tile running along above the platform on the south wall.
