column21: Large rectangular dining hall.  Overlooks peristyle with lararium niche to southwest.  Plaster remains on west, north, and east walls.  No evidence of paint left.  Post holes in east walls show evidence of a covering over hall, not dining hall.  There are no matching post holes in west wall.  Large south opening one step up from peristyle garden.  Smaller entrance to the southeast, one step up from peristyle garden.  Cistern in southwest corner of room.  No evidence of couch niches.  Evidence of a high ceiling.
column70: House of the King of Prussia

column14: Directly above cooking platform.

column21: Small rectangular room.  Small entranceway located in southeast corner of east wall.  Small window top northeast of east wall.  Stone threshold.  Plaster on north, south, west walls.  No paint evidence.

column14: None
column21: Latrine, Located northeast of kitchen (14).  Small rectangular room with a small entrance on the west wall.  There is a small window on north wall facing the street.  There are plaster remnants on all four walls, but no paint remains.  There are niches on the north and south walls towards the bottom which may have held a seat going across.  Directly in front of seat spaces is a stone (horizontal north to south).  Stone threshold to latrine.

column15: To the north of atrium (5) and east of kitchen (14).

Height of platform seems to be higher than average cubiculum bed.  This block has been previously reported as a row of brothel cubicles.  BJ thinks the possibility of a series of fast food related cooking platforms should not be overlooked given the tiled top surfaces and un-bed- like characteristics size is valuable.

column15: Located west if dining room (3); north of second shop and south of preparation room (1)

Entrance on northwest corner of north wall connecting to room 4 (See counter room Region 7, 13,20).  Roasting counter on south wall.

There is a lararium above the preparation table on the eastern end of the south wall.  The lararium is slightly covered by a bush.  There is a small niche (possibly lararium) located above the cooking platform on the south end of the west wall.  There is a rather large doorway which exits out onto the street at the north end of the west wall.  There are two post holes (low ones) on the west wall.  Latrine is located directly opposite the cooking platform to the north.  No plaster or paint remain in room.

column14: Located west of atrium (4).

Threshold has a square impression in the northern corner indicating a possible door.

column14: Cooking platform is located north of the latrine, along the west wall of the kitchen.
column16: Cooking platform is located north of the latrine, along the west wall of the kitchen.
column21: The cooking platform is of average size and has a tiled surface.  A brick arched storage area for fuel lies centrally beneath the platform.  There are two protrusions from the wall on the south side of the platform suggesting some type of support for cooking equipment.

column14: Latrine is located south of the cooking platform in the southwest corner of the kitchen (7).
column16: Latrine is located south of the cooking platform in the southwest corner of the kitchen (7).
column21: Latrine is located in the southwest corner of the kitchen.  There are remnants of Fourth Style painting (white paint with red lines) on the south wall of the latrine.  Only a portion of the west wall of latrine is visible.  The south wall of kitchen and the south side of platform could serve as the walls of the latrine.

column14: Located north of room 2
column21: Large rectangular room; Due to a wide entrance located on the west side of the room, there appears to have been both preparation and sales activity here.  There are plaster and red paint remnants on every wall.  There is a terra cotta pipe exposed in the north wall leading directly down into the cooking platform which is located at the northeast corner of the room.  There is a doorway at the east end of the south wall leading into room 2.  There are four low post holes on the north wall.

column14: Catillus is to east of oven and to south of preparation platform with quern situated on its top surface.
column16: Cattilus is to east of oven and to south of preparation platform with quern situated on its top surface.
column21: Masonry catillus remains against east wall of room.  Only top section of catillus remains.  Structurally, it is in poor repair, with two cracks running from top to bottom.  Mill would have been turned by an animal.  Probably not in situ.

column14: Mill-oven room is located east of storage room (23) and north of corridor (19).
column15: Mill-oven room is located east of storage room (23) and north of corridor (19).
column21: The room is sizably small due to the space taken up by the features in the room.  It is rectangular in shape.  There is the top half of a catillus embedded in the ground at the southeast end of the room.  There is an oven built in the west wall and there is the base of a quern set in the northeast corner on a platform.  There are remnants of plaster and paint at the south end of the west wall.  There is an arch of brick, which appears to be blocked, on the north wall above the quern remnants -- purpose is unknown.

column14: The preparation platform is located directly under the quern base in the northeast corner of the room.  It is north of the catillus remnant and northeast of the oven.
column16: The preparation platform is located directly under the quern base in the northeast corner of the room.  It is north of the catillus remnant and northeast of the oven.
column21: The platform is located in the northeast corner of the room.  It has a base of a quern centrally located on top of it.  It is about 2.5 feet high and is of a teardrop shape coming out of the corner of the room.

column14: The quern is located on the preparation platform located in the northeast corner of the room.  It is north of the catillus remnant and northeast of the oven.
column16: The quern is located on the preparation platform located in the northeast corner of the room.  It is north of the catillus remnant and northeast of the oven.
column21: There is the remnant of the base of a quern (hand-mill) found on a preparation platform located in the northeast corner of the mill-oven room.  The quern still has metal pieces within the center hole of the quern.

column14: The dining room is located east of the atrium (2), south of corridor (6), and north of room 3.
column15: The dining room is located east of the atrium (2), south of corridor (6), and north of room 3.
column21: The room is large and rectangular in size.  There is a somewhat wide opening at the west side of the room looking out into the atrium.  The full threshold (travertine) within the opening to the atrium remains intact with grooves on either side indicating the presence of a door at one time.  There are a few remnants of plaster and red paint on the north, south, and east walls.  The room looks to have been quite tall, although no post holes are visible.  There is a tall doorway to the west end of the north wall of the room leading out to a corridor which leads to the kitchen.

column14: Kitchen is located to the east of the garden (12) and to the south of the dining room (15).
column15: Kitchen is located to the east of the garden (12) and to the south of the dining room (15).
column21: This room is small and rectangular in shape.  There is no wall to the east indicating either an entirely open space out onto the garden (12) or simply just a missing wall. A doorway is located at the eastern end of the north way, which leads into a dining room (15).  There is a large stone block and some rubble along the eastern end of the south wall possibly suggesting that a cooking platform used to be here.  There is a large terra-cotta pipe running up the southern end of the east wall.  Some plaster remains on the south wall and a horizontal array of post holes on this same wall indicated a second story.

column14: The dining room is located to the west of the tablinum and to the northwest of the atrium
column15: The dining room is located to the west of the tablinum and to the northwest of the atrium
column21: This room is rather small and rectangular in shape.  There are plaster and red paint remnants on every wall.  There is an average size doorway at the south end of the east wall which leads into the tablinum (6).  There is a large window centrally located on the south wall which ideally looks out onto the atrium.  No threshold or flooring remains.

column14: The lararium is located on the west wall of the kitchen above the cooking platform.  It is southwest from the other lararium on the north wall.  It is north of the small oven and further northwest of the large beehive oven.

There is a small protruding platform in front of the opening of the oven which measures about 4 feet high.  The interior of the oven is domed, suggesting it to be a mini version of a beehive oven.

column14: Northwest of mill-oven room (22).
column21: Long rectangular room in northwest corner of room (22).  Narrow entrance in southeast corner with marble threshold.  Plaster remains on north and south walls.  Post holes in west and east walls may have possibly supported shelves.  No other attributes are evident.

No evidence of mosaic or couch niches.

No evidence of mosaic or couch niches.

On bottom of south wall is an opening at floor level for drainage.  In front of south groove is another groove to the north separated from the back groove by a small elevation.  Plaster remains on all four walls with red paint.  Bottom register is raised slightly from wall.

column15: West of latrine, east of Kitchen

Oven has flat top with terra cotta half pipe going from east to west side where it hangs over.

column14: The platform is directly north (next to) the small oven along the west wall of the room.  It is located just below the lararium on the west wall and is southwest of the lararium on the north wall.

The platform is rather high, about 4.5 feet -- higher than the platform of the oven next to it.  The platform has a raised border which is covered in arched terra cotta tiles.  The platform has a tiled stone surface.

column14: The lararium with the altar is located on the north wall northeast of the other lararium, cooking platform, and small oven respectively.  It is also located northwest of the large oven.
column16: The lararium with the altar is located on the north wall northeast of the other lararium, cooking platform, and small oven respectively.  It is also located northwest of the large oven.
column21: This is the second lararium found in this room.  It is large and square in shape, located on the west side of the north wall.  Plaster remains within the lararium, but no paint.  There is a small U-shaped tile, for possibly a spout, situated centrally on the base of the lararium also associated with this lararium is an altar which stands directly below it, about a foot away from the wall.  The altar has a stone surface with arched tile.  It looks to be the same height as the platform.  Plaster and some paint remains on all sides of the altar.

column8: Eschebach, 1993, calls this a sitting room.
column14: Room is to west of dining hall (9) and to south of garden (15).
column15: Room is to west of dining hall (9) and to south of garden (15).
column21: Small rectangular room has a wide entrance overlooking colonnaded garden (15) and with a nicely preserved travertine threshold.  Remnants of plaster are preserved on all walls, with yellow and red color still visible.  On south wall, evidence that a painting was cut out is visible.  Narrow doorway to west leads to corridor 8, which connects to south with corridor 6 for easy kitchen access.

column14: None
column21: On north wall, second full panel contains a depiction of a woman wearing a wreath and holding a tray, the tray of the mysteries, in her left hand, and herbs in her right hand.  It may be presentation of the tray and herbs for use in cult activity.  In center of fresco, there is a woman sitting down with her back to the viewer holding herbs in right hand.  Woman next to her standing is holding a small pitcher, pouring over the herbs.  It may be for purification of herbs for cult activity or for washing the herbs.  On east wall an older man wearing wreath, holding a pitcher filled with what could be a libation.  To the right a man a young boy peering into the picture, possibly drinking or looking at reflection.  Behind the boy, possibly Dionysus holding a mask.
column53: Two views of frescos for food and drink

column14: Along east, southeast, and west walls.

Banked and wider in northwest corner as it moves from room 48 to room 50.  Outside of channel in room 52 are two embedded dolia.  Drainage channel of masonry construction and water proofing plaster has been added along channel ad wall that runs along the side of the channel.

column16: East of embedded dolium, East of drainage channel, East of large hole (FS 915)
column21: Three holes, two small and one large.  Two small holes built to contain the vertical pieces of the press drum.  Large hole possibly to accommodate a screw mechanism.  Located south corner of room.

column21: Located in the west corner of room there is a large hole that would have been used for a screw mechanism.  Two smaller holes directly in front of the large hole currently have medium press pieces in them.

column14: Located east of hallway F1, west of bedroom 8, and southwest of corridor 7
column15: Located east of hallway F1, west of bedroom 8, and southwest of corridor 7
column21: Very elongated, large rectangular room which opens up at the south end out onto the peristyle garden.  The entire mosaic flooring is still intact (white with black border and tiny black flowers arrayed in the center).  Beautiful 2nd style frescoes cover every wall.  The central scene bordering the room depicts fruit (possibly cherries) creeping over a wall.  A door is depicted on the north back wall.  There is a doorway on the south end of the west wall with threshold and door jams intact leading into hallway F1.   The open area overlooking the peristyle has no threshold remaining.  There is a blocked door on the east wall directly opposite of the doorway on the west wall.  The threshold and door jam are visible from underneath the stone blockage.  This door probably once led to the portico next door.  There is another doorway, with no threshold, at the northern end of the east wall leading to a small corridor (7).

column14: Located in the southeast corner of the processing room, directly east of a second curbed anchorage area, and southeast of the a large dolium embedded in the ground.
column16: Located in the southeast corner of the processing room, directly east of a second curbed anchorage area, and southeast of the a large dolium embedded in the ground.
column21: A small rectangular area in the southeast corner of the room is separated from the rest of the processing room by a curb.  Within this area are two holes.  The small hole to the west supports the rear portion of the press.  The larger hole to the east is the access to the bottom of the vertical piece at the rear of the press to secure it to the floor.

column14: Located in southwest corner of the processing room, directly west of second curbed anchorage area, and directly south of a large dolium which is embedded in the ground.
column16: Located in southwest corner of the processing room, directly west of second curbed anchorage area, and directly south of a large dolium which is embedded in the ground.
column21: A small rectangular area in the southwest corner of the room, directly opposite of the other curbed  containment area, is separated from the rest of the processing room by a curb  Within this area, are two holes.  The small hole to the east supports the rear portion of the press (a recreation of a press is in place here).  The larger hole to the east is the access to the bottom of the vertical piece at the rear of the press to secure it to the floor.  Only the hole remains; there is no recreation in place.

column14: Underground storage room located within garden (63) and surrounded by portico (62).
column15: Underground storage room located within garden (63) and surrounded by portico (62).
column21: Underground storage room located within garden (63) and surrounded by portico (62).  The storage area is accessed by a stairwell from the garden.  Then entrance is rather short and covered with a small tiled roof.  From the base of the stairs, the storage area turns right into what looks like a passageway.  There is a hole above ground, with terra cotta piping within which leads into this passageway from the roof.  The passageway has four niches, two on each wall with arched brick above them.  It then appears to turn left.

column14: None
column15: Located south of processing room; northeast of atrium (62).
column21: Large square room on the second floor.  A portion of the floor still exists within the first set of post holes to the south.  A doorway on the east end of the north wall remains on this upper story, although a modern gate inhabits it.  Plaster and Third Style wall paintings remain on the west and north walls.  The east wall is not visible due to a locked gate.  On the west wall, the paintings are divided into two panels with similar central images.  On the north panel, a thin blue platter is shown with a fig (pomegranate?) placed atop of it alongside five cherries.  On the south panel, a thin blue platter is barely visible with a small bird perched atop of it alongside two cherries.

column14: Bedroom (7) to the east, Peristyle garden (9) to the Northeast, Dining room (10) to the Northeast.
column15: Bedroom (7) to the east, Peristyle garden (9) to the Northeast, Dining room (10) to the Northeast.
column21: Large fairly rectangular garden with a window to the bedroom (7) on the east and a walkway to a peristyle garden (9) on the northeast. Window to a dining room (10)  on the northeast. Possible identification as a garden because of the location and size. No evidence of plantings.

column14: Dining Room (10) to the north, Kitchen (8), Storeroom (6), Stairs (7) and Dining Room (5) to the east.
column15: Dining Room (10) to the north, Kitchen (8), Storeroom (6), Stairs (7) and Dining Room (5) to the east.
column21: Peristyle garden with a single surviving column in the northwest corner with foundations of wall surrounding garden on the north and east sides. Eschebach reports an open air triclinium; "Zweischenkeliges Pseudoperistyl mit AuBentridinium" of which no trace remains. [Check why Eschebach locates a triclinium here.] Jashemski refers to a lararium painting on the south wall of the portico and animal painting on the south wall of the garden. No trace of either survives.

column14: None
column21: Small Lararium (penates) in the south wall of the storeroom.

column14: Latrine is considered part of the kitchen which also has a cooking platform within.
column16: Latrine is considered part of the kitchen which also has a cooking platform within.
column21: Poorly preserved latrine found in the southeast corner of the room.

column14: Located northwest of processing room 48 and further northeast of corridor 27.
column15: Located northwest of processing room 48 and further northeast of corridor 27.
column21: The processing room accommodates two wine presses.  The back portion, on a higher level, supports the rear portion of the presses and the base for the grapes.  The floor slopes down and to the northwest at the corner of which it meets a drain.  The front portion of the room, at the lower level, contains the anchors for the front part of the press.  Below the head of each beam, is a deep hole-possibly to accommodate a screw mechanism.  At the northwest corner of the room, the drain turns 90 degrees to the west and empties into an open area where the juice in placed in dolia embedded in the ground.  The upper floor has a curb to contain the juice and to prevent it from entering the holes used to anchor the back part of each press.

column14: Dolium lies directly adjacent to drainage channel which begins at north corner of room.
column15: To southwest room 48 connects with corridor 47, and portico area 62.
column16: Dolium lies directly adjacent to drainage channel which begins at north corner of room.
column21: In northwest corner of processing room a large embedded dolium.  Dolium is large and bulbous in shape with a wide lip still fully intact, although crack is visible.  Dolium is more fully embedded in northeast side than it is the northwest side  Curtis speculates that this was used to collect the solid materials as they came down the drainage channel.  Solids would have been scooped out of drainage channel into this dolium.

column14: None
column15: on Southeast wall of dining room
column21: Small painting inside on southeast wall, possibly a bird bath sitting on base next to column.  Column has pitcher sitting atop on its side with wine or a libation pouring into bird bath.  Paint is chipped off where wine or libation would  be.

column14: North of latrine (40), storeroom (39), corridor (38).  East of kitchen (61).
column15: North of latrine (40), storeroom (39), corridor (38).  East of kitchen (61).
column21: Small rectangular room with entranceway to west.  Post holes on east-west wall suggest support for a second story.  In north going from west  to east, platform with stairs is a modern addition.  Window on east wall in northeast corner. No other attributes are evident.

column14: Dining garden (2) found to the northeast.
column15: Dining garden (2) found to the northeast.
column21: Room with a Platform. Northeast corner contains preserved plaster. Faded plaster also found on the west wall. North wall contains a recessed area thought to be a lararium. U shaped platform is located running the entire length of the west wall and 1/3 way down the north and south walls. A narrow doorway is found to the southeast.

column14: Found next to the cooking platform.
column15: Entered through the Viridarium and adjacent to cubiculium.
column16: Found next to the cooking platform.
column21: Low rectangular platform is found on the west wall of the kitchen. Platform has a top tiled surface partially remaining. Masonry construction platform with a reticulated arch a the base for strength, but no recessed opening or lip. Lararium is found above.

column14: room is to north of rooms 11, 12, and 13.  Porticoed garden is to northwest and porticoed garden is to SE
column15: room is to north of rooms 11, 12, and 13.  Porticoed garden is to northwest and porticoed garden is to SE
column16: contains food and drink related frescos
column21: Small rectangular room with black and white mosaic tile still visible in sections in northeast side of room.  Second style frescos survive intact on south wall to full height of room, including an arched section and roof detailing.  Fresco depicts birdbath still life with either wine or water pouring into fountain.  Color is predominantly red in central panel, with black lower section and white section above.  Room has been heavily reconstructed on northeast and northwest walls.  Originally this room would have been one room made up of rooms 12, 13, and 14.  In last phase, room was subdivided into current state of three rooms.  Use of room 14 as a dining room in this later phase is therefore questionable- room appears to have had narrow doorways to northwest and southwest, both of which would have offered a porticoed garden view.

column21: Large rectangular room with highly decorative frescoes on all four walls depicting rites of the Mystery cult in Second Style.  Floor is opus sectile (white tile with black inserts and borders), with a border of harlequin black and white tile and smaller, white mosaic tiling at very edge.  Wide entrance to south would have provided view of gardens and the water through a large window in adjacent portico (P2).  Small doorway opens onto a bedroom to west.  Ceiling is bordered with yellow paint and is arched in center, although this is probably modern.

column21: Dining bench in semicircular shape for reclining and eating.  Masonry installation is now in state of disrepair.  This is the only stababium (semicircular dining bench) in Pompeii.  Diners would look out to west, where a space for entertainment is located.

column14: To north of space 9 (dining room).
column21: Large garden with narrow doorway in west wall.  Northeast corner is oddly angled.  Low wall and portico extends along south and west sides of garden.

column14: Dining garden to north.
column21: Rectangular dining space which could have expanded into spaces 1 and 2.  Doorway to street is on south wall.  Doorway to north leads out to porticoed garden area.

column14: Contiguous to room 2Lii and stairway 2Li.
column21: Second level down.  Vaulted storeroom w/partitioned wall dividing chamber into two runs (iii and ii).  Doorway common with iv.  Small niche in west wall.  Access to upper level in northeast corner (stairwell) with passageway formed by partitioned wall along part of the east wall.  Stairs run left behind wall up a level.   Walls are opus reticulatum.

column14: East of room 2, east of street.
column15: East of room 2, east of street.
column21: Large open room with food counter to south side. One room opens to south of counter. One room opens north, two rooms open east. Of the two latter rooms the north one opens to rear chamber. Three or four styles of masonry show current configuration. Numerous remodeling. Room opposite 6.17.1 which is, judging from curb cut in sloping pavement the major entrance for wheeled vehicles. Opposite hotel facility with stables.

column21: To the south of a peristyle garden the rear portion of the house is lost.  With precedence from other houses we usually are able to identify a dining room at the rear with a wide opening overlooking a peristyle garden.  In this instance it would have had a view to the south as well and would have been a very light and airy setting appropriately.

column14: Contiguous to A1 which is to the east of A2.  (No access between the 2).
column15: Contiguous to A1 which is to the east of A2.  (No access between the 2).

South wall appears to be an addition indicated by light well extending beyond the south wall.  Second light well in center of east wall (ceiling).  Some extant plaster in west wall; plain yellow paint.  No other decoration.  No trace of original flooring.

column14: To south of access corridor A1.  Room is accessed through A1
column15: To south of access corridor A1.  Room is accessed through A1
column21: Square storeroom, vaulted ceiling with light well in center.  Entrance in north wall (large archway).  Small platform base in the northwest corner partially obscured by rubble.  No decorational flooring.

column21: Square vaulted storeroom with threshold and lip.  Floor obscured by dirt and debris.  Light well in center of ceiling from peristyle/garden above.  No extant décor.  Access from south wall from corridor A4.

column14: Contiguous with A3
column21: Vaulted square storeroom.  Central light well from garden above.  Doorway in east wall.  No trace of décor.  Floor obscured.

column14: None
column21: Room number identification is in plan by Lehman-Hartleben.  Room is on lower level on south corner of the upper peristyle.  It is down a half level below the kitchen and storerooms.  The rear north wall and east is preserved and springing of the vaulting remains in place for almost the entire length of the east wall.  Some painted plaster remains on the vault but it is badly faded.  Has some indication of geometric borders.  Wall on the west side is only partially preserved, not to the height of springing of the vault.  No plaster on the west wall.  Room is filled with debris and floor level cannot be seen.  Room's southern outer limit has collapsed but it does have a brick pier.  No clear indication of rear extent of room remains.

column14: Contiguous with iii and iv.
column21: Second level down.  Storeroom formed by partition of Room iii.  Square room with doorway making majority of south wall (entrance).  Vaulted - opus reticulatum - entrance contiguous with Room iii.

column14: None
column21: Built against city wall (north wall is city wall) in a rubble wall on top.  North wall surface gone, but subsurface includes pottery up to 10 cm in length.  Presumably vaulted room considering thickness of walls.  Full length of room preserved doorways to southwest.  In northeast corner large section of paving, buckled sloping to west, utilitarian in nature, no decoration.

column14: West of and connecting to III
column15: West of and connecting to III
column21: First level down.  Small rectangular room to west of and connecting to III.  Walls intact enough that shape and size could be reconstructed.

Built above wall between rooms IV and V on this level.  Brick pier preserved in south wall aligns with this reconstructed east wall.

column14: None
column21: Built against old city wall with V room below.  Area between wall and portion of vaulting in northeast corner of room is preserved.  North wall has been patched many times.  East wall has eroded niche.  Vault wall below level -3 has collapsed with ceiling of this room that it supported in north half of room.  In south half substantial reconstruction evident.

column21: Level, fairly high above what had been a blank area inside city wall.  Wall had to be used as fortification, at least as late as social war, the "impressive" thing is that so much fill had accumulated before the structure was built (3m).  Garden - read Bradford with respect to amount of protective plastic around site would indicate excavations not complete and could be coming back this summer.  The north corner of the triclinium is a an "opus signinum" lined channel runs to the west wall of room.  Closer proximity of the triclinium to edge of the pool.  Vann reports they are not contemporary uses.  On north wall above triclinium on central axis are traces of a removed "painting".

column14: None

column14: Northeast of the platform
column21: Lararium located on north wall on right side, directly across from door at southeast corner. Height is 1 meter --- ground. There is a paint present - white, red, blue, yellow, northeast of platform.

column21: Garum shop.  Stairs to upper floor in southwest corner; large entrance to street in west wall; No traces of counter, but proximity to processing room and wide west entrance suggest function as a shop.

Observation, and Eschebach plan, doesn't show door on west end of south wall noted by Jashemski.  Some plaster preserved in northeast corner and in northwest corner.  No evidence of paint except a touch of faded red.  Door jamb on right, i.e. south, large blocks of tufa (also door jamb to tablinum) other side of tablinum has same type construction.

Three vats on north wall which graduate.  Smallest vat in northeast corner.  Single vat in east wall adjoining rectangular well. Fresh water would have been necessary to processing.  Related to shop 16.

column21: Rectangular with door in northwest corner.  Walls are 3-4 inches high -- no indication of windows.  There is a niche on the north wall.  North and east walls have plaster (and red paint in the northwest corner).

column14: Portico #15 and garden #16.  Immediately north in connecting through low doorway at the end of the portico is access to spaces (presumably open to the sky) behind the central and east municipal offices.  Opens southeast into the atrium #2 and adjacent to tablinum #7 which is to the south.
column15: Portico #15 and garden #16.  Immediately north in connecting through low doorway at the end of the portico is access to spaces (presumably open to the sky) behind the central and east municipal offices.  Opens southeast into the atrium #2 and adjacent to tablinum #7 which is to the south.
column21: This is a large rectangular room with a west opening into portico  #15 and garden #16.  What is most unusual about the room is the floor which is white tesserae forming octagons set in a cocciopesto (crushed red brick) matrix.  That paving pattern extends west beyond the room into the portico (Room #15).  The northeast and south walls stand to 314 meters.  Plaster remains on all three walls.  No painting is preserved.  In the north wall over the doorway (not centered) is a small square opening at an angle.  The use of this is undetermined.

column14: Garden/portico
column21: There is a small doorway off the peristyle (portico/garden).   The room is small and rectangular and contains a latrine.  No plaster is evident.  A storage area is adjacent.  There is no evidence of a window above the cooling platform.

column14: None
column21: There are heavily restored structures to support the cooking platform.  No surface is in evidence now.  The latrine is next to the platform on the west wall.  Storage is just on the other side of the west latrine wall and is almost as spacious as the kitchen.

column14: Kitchen/latrine, portico
column21: The storage area is rectangular and has a passage into the kitchen.  It also has a north entrance from the portico/garden areas.  There is no evidence of plaster or paint.  The walls look to be resurfaced or patched.

column14: None
column21: Niche - Niche is across the north wall.  It extends for most of the north wall and is broken by the location of the doorway, leaving a small and confusing niche on the northeast corner.  Question - Why is a niche in this room at all?  Niches have been seen in bedrooms before and in larger dining rooms.

column14: Northwest corner of house.  Opens west into exedra (Eschebach #8)
column15: Northwest corner of house.  Opens west into exedra (Eschebach #8)
column21: Walls stand 4m tall with large square window in east wall.  No clear indication of other windows.  West door not preserved to height of lintel.  Wall plaster preserved in small patches on north, east, and south walls.  No evidence of paint remains.  More than half of plaster on south wall has collapsed and is on floor.  Pavement is not mosaic, but is a white colored "terrazzo" material.  Door jambs for west door in brick, remainder in rubble.  It appears that floor level in dining room is a few centimeters lower than exedra floor.  Exedra floor is same white "terrazzo", but in patches, subfloor contains broken tile and pottery in its matrix.

column14: None
column21: In southwest corner of house; check the dimensions on drawing.  This is one of the larger dining rooms that have been identified.  North wall was rebuilt.  Original wall is approximately 4 m on west end, but 2 1/1 m high in center.  Along center of wall is a small relieving arch in lower portion.  Probable presence of drain to lower level.  Subfloor collapsed in east half of room.  Floor is obscured now but was white on black mosaic most probably.  Patches on north and west walls of plaster.  Wide doorway opens from southeast corner of room and looks into atrium.  Fairly large window in upper east wall.

column14: Opens into service corridor west wall.  A number of rooms for storage are contiguous.  #15 is lararium.  North end of Room #12 could also be storage.  Kitchen to north-south corridor with other to atrium.
column15: Opens into service corridor west wall.  A number of rooms for storage are contiguous.  #15 is lararium.  North end of Room #12 could also be storage.  Kitchen to north-south corridor with other to atrium.
column21: No plaster on walls.  Large rectangular room containing two large cooking platforms without storage beneath, but both with tile surfaces.  Two large limestone blocks on the floor may not belong to the room.  Walls are resurfaced without indication of 70's restoration.  There is no indication of windows.  No doorways are preserved to height of their lintels.

column14: None
column21: Cooking Platform A - on west wall, smaller.  Short and deep.  Reconstructed platform, inside west door.  Narrow gap is left between rock wall.

column14: None
column21: Cooking Platform (B) - Larger cooking platform on north wall.  Reconstructed.  Platform was set into northeast corner.  Does not have evidence of fuel storage beneath (probably due to extent of reconstruction).

column14: Open to south of kitchen and opens to north/south service corridor.  Door in east wall connects to room 14 (could have been more storage).  Additional storage might also have been provided by other side of kitchen in northeast of corridor (room 12).
column15: Open to south of kitchen and opens to north/south service corridor.  Door in east wall connects to room 14 (could have been more storage).  Additional storage might also have been provided by other side of kitchen in northeast of corridor (room 12).
column21: Lararium niche (penates) in south wall. Large tufa block on floor; origin unknown.  Not a lintel or threshold; no door preservation to lintel and no window evidence.  Reconstruction on north wall and around doors clearly demarcated from original part below.

column14: South of door VIII, 3From west of entrance to VIII, 2, 23 (private bath) It opens into room 4 (northeast) kitchen and southeast (storage)
column15: South of door VIII, 3From west of entrance to VIII, 2, 23 (private bath) It opens into room 4 (northeast) kitchen and southeast (storage)
column21: L-shaped counter against west side of wall attached to cup rack creating space for one person to work. Not a good view east or west down street. Food shop connected to booth at south door.

column14: None
column21: L-shaped counter on northwest corner of room. Set back from curb so wooden shutters that closes shop goes on front of counter.  Narrow with no imbedded dolia. Heavily restored. South end of counter where we might find evidence of hearth, not restored. Counter abuts to stepped platform to west against the wall connecting to entrance VIII, 2, 23. Stepped platform not reconstructed and in poor condition. L-shaped counter and platform creates "U" configuration with space for someone to work behind.

column14: opens west into counter room (#3)
column21: Small narrow room with east and west orientation. Cooking platform to north with window high above. Shallow niche to south with window lower in wall. east end of room, a water proofed sloping surface leads into a hole in wall directing water down into the latrine next door (#11). Door preserved through height of lintel (timber replaced)

column14: None
column21: Extends across full length of room against north wall. From west half arched opening for fuel storage below. Against east half is circular water feature mentioned in FS 1087. Top and front of counter restored and resurfaced. No lip, no tile surface.

column14: None
column21: Waterproof Drain: Drain against east wall. Wall above drain has thick pinkish waterproof surface across width of room. That water proofing surface about same about same height as cooking platform in north. Water proof surface also applies to southeast face of cooking platform that is adjacent to partially preserved 1/4 circular sloping surface (also waterproofed) that is leading through hole in wall into the latrine next door.

column14: Access from corridor (17 2L) to south.
column21: Rectangular room with doorway through south wall.  Vaulted ceiling.  Floor obscured by marble fragments.

column21: Rectangular room with doorway in south wall.  Vaulted ceiling with traces of concrete finish.  Floor obscured by marble fragments.

column14: Two rooms to west.  Corridor to east.

column21: Cold Room.  Rectangular room with large rectangular bath/plunge pool at north end.  Three semicircular steps into bath from southeast corner.  Blue painting survives on all four sides.  Nilotic landscape scenes with pygmies, ibises, and architectural features surviving on north and west sides of bath.  Expensive decoration on north and east walls of room.  Red architectural decoration with painted moldings depicting miniatures and figure.  Molded panels above that with landscape scenes and fabulous figures.  Central tondo surrounded by two karytids depicting seated figure in red.  Identification of figure to follow.  East wall - red architectural decoration.  One extant image shows poorly preserved reclining figure.  Painted plaster molding survives in northeast corner.  Molded plaster ceiling survives in places in length of room with red painted border and red inserts on white background.  Arch in center of room.  Two windows in south wall.  Doorway in west wall and other doorway in southeast and southwest corner.

column14: Room 19 to west.
column21: Separate warehouse area.  Rectangular high vaulted room.  Window in south wall.  Doorway in southwest corner.  Plain coarse plaster on north and northeast corner and south wall.  Earth and marble fragments obscure floor.

column14: Room 20 to east, number 17 to west.
column15: Room 20 to east, number 17 to west.
column21: High vaulted ceiling.  Rectangular room.  Doorway to 20 in southeast corner.  17 in southwest corner.

column14: Room 17 to south.
column21: Floor level is two feet above that of room 17.  Small doorway in south wall.  Square room with high vaulted ceiling.

column14: 19 to north6 to east.
column21: Rectangular east facing DR, mosaic of white tesserae with 15 cm black line from wall white paintings with red borders and red lower register. Position, wall paintings, and lack of other features indicate use as dining room.

column14: 18 to south.
column21: Rectangular room: blocked doorway in west wall. Traces of rectangular feature (possible preparation) in northeast corner. Position next to dining room 18 and presence of feature in northeast corner suggest role in food preparation. No extant decoration on walls. Marble threshold.

column14: Peristyle to east.
column21: Rectangular dining room facing east over looking peristyle. Mosaic of white tesserae with black line 15 cm from wall. Wall paintings on north, west, and south walls with red panels over white lower register. Position, wall paintings, and lack of other features indicate use as dining room.

column14: peristyle 26
column21: Large square dining room adjoining peristyle.  Views to south of harbor.  Northwest and southwest walls largely destroyed.  Northeast wall restored.  Possible gaeata.  Identification based on view.  Well/circular-like wall in center of room.

column14: Room #17 to east.  Room #19 to west.
column15: Room #17 to east.  Room #19 to west.
column21: Rectangular west facing room looking out at garden 20.  Doorway northeast corner to 17.  No decoration.  Identification based on west view of garden.

column15: Room #19 to west.  Room #17 to north.
column21: Large rectangular west facing dining room.  White tesserae mosaic in north half of room.  Doorway to 17 northeast corner.  Coarse plaster decoration on east and south wall bases.  Debris obscures southeast corner.  Identification based on position overlooking garden.

column14: 11 to west
column21: Long rectangular dining room with traces of vaulted ceiling in northeast corner.  Overlooks harbor to south.  Fragments of wall painting on north wall, northeast corner and above, base of northwest corner with red lower register and traces of white above in northeast corner.  Rectangular recess in southeast corner.  Doorway in southwest corner.  No trace of flooring.  Identification of dining room based on wall painting and position looking to south.

column14: Northwest corner of house; northwest corner of atrium open directly to hallway.  Immediately to east entrance corridor to south small room #17.
column15: Northwest corner of house; northwest corner of atrium open directly to hallway.  Immediately to east entrance corridor to south small room #17.
column21: Metal frame indicates plan for room.  Large size and wider doorway suggest function as a triclinium.  Fragments of wall paintings on all four walls.  Floor pavement better preserved.  White tesserae and broken pieces of colored marble/tesserae in patterns of alternating octagons with alternating squares-all set in pink cocciopesto.   Nice marble threshold - doorway (west wall) doorjamb appears to be later repair.  It's in block and brick.

column8: Jashemski, 1979, , calls this room C, with A to north and B to south.
column14: South side of peristyle (20).  Opens north into peristyle, opens south into small garden, partially preserved (now filled with oleander).  Two small rooms to both east flank and west flank.  Whole group could be considered dining suite.
column15: South side of peristyle (20).  Opens north into peristyle, opens south into small garden, partially preserved (now filled with oleander).  Two small rooms to both east flank and west flank.  Whole group could be considered dining suite.
column21: Rectangular room on north-south axis facing through wide doors to gardens on either side.  Looks to be late construction with brick piers in four corners.  Four doorways, also framed in brick, flank walls between brick portions are in rubble.  Doorways preserved to lintel height.  No indication of preserved flooring.  Two metal gates - presumably light wells to lower levels (how were they closed).  Large dining room-reception opened to small dining rooms in all four corners.  In southwest corner are two large blocks not in situ.  One is pedestal with base and crown, large hole in center, perhaps well.

column14: Northwest corner of large dining room 21.  Southwest corner of peristyle 20.
column15: Northwest corner of large dining room 21.  Southwest corner of peristyle 20.
column21: Open at northwest corner to Room #21 communicating through north wall by wide window set low to ground.  No wall features, no floor materials preserved.  Window in north wall framed by tufa, door framed by brick.

column14: Northeast corner of feature sheet 1111 (room number 21).  Southeast corner of peristyle (room number 20)
column15: Northeast corner of feature sheet 1111 (room number 21).  Southeast corner of peristyle (room number 20)
column21: Similar to feature sheet 1112 , but reversed in relation.  Door in northwest corner framed with brick. Window in north side framed with small block.  View out window to fish tank in peristyle (20).

column8: Jashemski, 1979, refers to peristyle 20 as A.
column14: Southeast corner of peristyle 20.  Peristyle had low wall in the intercolumnations.  Tank extends into bay between southeast corner column and one immediately to North.  Does this mean low barrier wall was removed at this point or was this bay always open as entrance to garden?
column16: Southeast corner of peristyle 20.  Peristyle had low wall in the intercolumnations.  Tank extends into bay between southeast corner column and one immediately to North.  Does this mean low barrier wall was removed at this point or was this bay always open as entrance to garden?
column21: Southeast corner of peristyle 20.  Long rectangular basin with waterproofing throughout.  Does not align with east-west alignment of peristyle 20.  Small jars set at bottom of pool at east and west ends.  West end - eight jars above, nine below, topped off by shelf.  East end- five jars below, six above.  Leaving room in southeast for steps in and out.  Rounded joints in four vertical corners of pool.  Transition between vertical wall and floor strengthened by beveled thickening of west platform.  No indication open to air.  Top edge not preserved.

column14: Southwest corner of large dining room 21.
column15: Southwest corner of large dining room 21.
column21: Walls preserved.  Twelve meters in height.  Opens wall to 21.  South opens by door or window into portico 19.  West into area now collapsed but presumably had room.  Doors framed by bricks.  Unlike other rooms, large opening to south appears to be a door rather than a window.

column14: Located in northwest storage space under cooking platform.  East of oven.
column16: Located in northwest storage space under cooking platform.  East of oven.
column21: Leading down from northwest fuel storage space to street.  Wash water would drain from kitchen to street.

Light colored terrazzo floor. (check flooring types) Steps to room 16 in southeast corner.  Step stone threshold to east.  Size, decoration and position looking over garden suggest use as dining room.

column14: Portico 18 to the west.
column21: Small l-shaped garden narrowing to the south.  Masonry triclinium in northeast corner.  Two cisterns in south end and center of the west end.  Plaster lined architectural decoration survives along east side of garden with red paint preserved in places.  Square rectangular platform adjoins cistern to the south.  Garden is replanted with vines and a grape arbor.  Stone and plaster gutter runs below the garden along the edge of the portico.
column70: A. Cassius Libanus House of Sallust

column14: Portico (room 19) and garden (room 19A)  the south; dining room (room 16) to the west; stairs (room 18) to the east; kitchen (room 13) to the north.
column15: Portico (room 19) and garden (room 19A)  the south; dining room (room 16) to the west; stairs (room 18) to the east; kitchen (room 13) to the north.
column21: Rectangular south-facing dining room with vaulted ceiling with yellow painted plaster molding.  Wall painting survives on the northeast and west walls with black lower register with yellow and red borders.  Upper register has a yellow background with red geometric swastika decoration which continues to the plaster painted vault above. Room looks out over the garden (room 19A) with water feature.  Block doorway inset in corner was subsequently covered with plaster.  There is a cocciopesto floor.

column14: Portico (room 19) and garden (room 19A)  the south; dining room (room 17) to the east; corridor (room 15) to the west; kitchen-storage (room 15) to the north.
column15: Portico (room 19) and garden (room 19A)  the south; dining room (room 17) to the east; corridor (room 15) to the west; kitche-storage (room 15) to the north.
column21: Rectangular south-facing room overlooking the garden (room 19A).  Doorway to room 15 is in the southwest corner.  Floor is obscured by debris.  No trace of ceiling.  Wall painting survives on the north, east and west walls: white lower register with yellow border and red inserts, and red upper register with white borders.

column14: Looks out onto narrow portico.  The Jashemski plan shows stairs along the west side up from the portico leading down to a lower garden.  This area is now filled with oleander and not available for investigation.
column15: Looks out onto narrow portico.  The Jashemski plan shows stairs along the west side up from the portico leading down to a lower garden.  This area is now filled with oleander and not available for investigation.
column21: Unexcavated, but presumed to have been a dining room on the basis of the plan and room location.  A door in the southeast corner connects to room 15 on the east.  The piers defining the south opening are built of brick and block, unlike rubble in the remains of the room; would certainly be a later change in the configuration of these rooms (rooms 14, 15, 16, and 17) facing onto the portico and terrace.

column14: Portico 18 to the east.  Room 20/10? To south east.  Room 17 to the south.  Garden to the north.
column15: Portico 18 to the east.  Room 20/10? To south east.  Room 17 to the south.  Garden to the north.
column21: Square room facing east.  Partially obscured platform along north wall.  Plaster faced column inserted in center of north wall.  Extensive restoration of northwest and west walls.  Ceiling is restored.
column70: A. Cassius Libanus House of Sallust

column14: Against north wall of kitchen 19
column21: Poorly preserved rectangular platform.  West half is obscured by debris.  East half is rubble.  No recesses, surface, etc. preserved.
column70: A. Cassius Libanus House of Sallust

column14: Opens off the northwest corner of atrium; to east is entrance corridor (room 1).  To west is shop VIII.2.38.
column15: Opens off the northwest corner of atrium; to east is entrance corridor (room 1).  To west is shop VIII.2.38.
column21: Faces south through low door with a new concrete lintel.  No indication of original floor material.  Principal features include cooking platform in the southeast corner and along the east wall.  To the north is the latrine.  In the southwest corner is what appears to be a rather unique round chimney, the curved cylinder of which can be seen on the other side of the wall in shop VIII.2.38.  Walls not preserved to extent to indicate presence of window.  At the south end of the east wall above the level of the cooking platform is a patch consistent in size to those openings cut by later salvagers.

column14: Latrine to north of cooking platform.
column16: Latrine to north of cooking platform.
column21: Inside door and against east wall.  It is heavily restored.  No facility for fuel storage.  Wall above is not preserved to any extent that there is an indication of a window. At the north end of the platform is a partition wall that separates the platform from the latrine.

column14: Cooking platform to the south.  In the northeast corner of the kitchen.
column16: Cooking platform to the south.  In the northeast corner of the kitchen.
column21: Located in the northeast corner of the kitchen.  There is a low masonry shelf located in the north wall against the east wall.  There is a single stone protruding on the south side from the partition wall separating the latrine from the cooking platform.

column14: Cooking platform and latrine to east.
column16: Cooking platform and latrine to east.
column21: Chimney in the southwest corner of the room just inside the door.  This is a very unusual feature.  Lowe and Vann cannot recall another example of an interior chimney in a Pompeiian house.  The flue is much larger than the standard water pipe (this is why it is being called a chimney instead of a drain) (there are niches cut back into the surface of a wall with drainage below.  These are sometimes identified as latrines.  That is not what is seen here because its position is just inside the door to the atrium and there is a better latrine feature across the room.)

column14: Exterior of the complex to the east and south.  Bath calidarium (room 3) to the west.  Corridor (room 6) and stairs to the level above in the northwest.  Room 2 to the north.
column15: Exterior of the complex to the east and south.  Bath calidarium (room 3) to the west.  Corridor (room 6) and stairs to the level above in the northwest.  Room 2 to the north.
column21: Square room.  Vaulted ceiling with plaster lining.  Two large windows facing south.  Circular opening in ceiling at south end and another blocked window in the northeast corner of the room.  In the west wall there is a low opening accessing the hypocaust in the bath suite to the west.  Bath suite is accessed through arched doorway with three steps in the northwest corner of the room.  Northwest corner of north wall has high arched doorway with four steps and a ramp to the floor above.  Doorway has plaster.  Center of north wall has a high arched doorway opening into room 2.  Northeast corner of the room is taken up by a 3 foot high, 4 foot by 6 foot rectangular platform of oven (feature 1155).  Adjoining the oven in the center of the east wall is a blocked doorway.  In the southeast corner of the room is a rectangular stone basin.  No trace of lining.  Multifunctional room with oven and furnace for baths.

column14: Doorway of room 2 adjoining to the north.  Blocked doorway adjoining to the east.  Basin in the southeast corner and a furnace for the bath suite in the center of the west wall of the room
column16: Doorway of room 2 adjoining to the north.  Blocked doorway adjoining to the east.  Basin in the southeast corner and a furnace for the bath suite in the center of the west wall of the room
column21: Rectangular masonry platform oven in the northeast corner of the room.  Oven opening to the west.  Rectagonal oven chamber with lower courses of a beehive preserved.  Stone base of the oven heating chamber.  Oven chamber better preserved on the north and east sides.  Platform is 3 foot high, 4 foot by 6 foot.

column14: None
column16: Room 25 to the south; room 23 to the east; room 16 to the north.
column21: Rectangular south-facing room looking out over a terrace.  Two windows in the east wall look out over open room 23.  Extant wall paint in northwest corner shows pink lower register, faded white with red above and green trim.  Position, size and decoration suggest use as a dining room.

column14: None
column21: Jashemski shows a rectangular room facing south over a terrace and identified as a dining room.  Now almost completely destroyed, leaving no basis for identification, although the position overlooking a terrace would support its use as a dining room.  Traces of cocciopesto floor and red wall painting remain against the northwest corner.

column14: None
column16: Room 8 to the south; room 12 to the north; room 2 to the east.
column21: Square room facing east onto the atrium.  Floor is of cocciopesto with white tesserae making a diamond pattern.  Plaster on wall has no trace of color.  There are holes for supports for three layers of shelving on the north, west, and south walls.

column14: None
column16: Room 13 to the north; room 11 to the south; room 2 to the east.
column21: Square room facing east onto the atrium.  Marble threshold with fittings for a doorway.  Cocciopesto floor with white tesserae making square and swastika geometric patterns.  Plaster survives on the north, west, and south walls; no traces of color.  Holes survive on the north, west, and south walls to support three layers of shelves.

column14: None
column15: Paintings on east and west walls of inner fauces whose floor is decorated with famous mosaic of wild boar.  To north of outside of doorway was vestibulum with white tesserae on pink cocciopesto.  Mosaic abutment at south doorjambs to fauces.
column21: Entrance corridor of fauces.  Painting on west wall of fauces.  Figure holding platter with food (?) in upraised left arm against red ground.  Could have been figure on east wall but has been removed.

column8: Jashemski, , does not call this a garden.
column14: Room 12 and corridor 11 are north of dining room.  Southeast corner of atrium opening south to garden or terrace (Jashemski did not call it a garden).
column15: Room 12 and corridor 11 are north of dining room.  Southeast corner of atrium opening south to garden or terrace (Jashemski did not call it a garden).
column21: Southeast corner of atrium opening south on what may be garden or terrace.  Nice marble threshold in door southwest corner, south doorjamb and whatever else might have formed southwest corner of room is gone.  West wall over two meters high.  Substantial portion of wall plaster but half has fallen off.  North and east walls not as well preserved.  Portion of white ground mosaic visible in southeast corner under modern gravel.

column14: Kneading basin to left.  One mill to right.
column16: Kneading basin to left.  One mill to right.
column21: Two stone supports.

column14: Room 1L1 is to the south.
column21: Square room; north corner large well preserved cooking platform; tiled with lip.  Two arched storage recesses below.  To the left, water channel and drain running from north wall to west wall's center.  Small arched storage area off northwest corner - Small arched latrine off southwest corner.  Plaster window in center of south wall and doorway in southeast wall.  Plaster survives throughout.  Cocciopesto flooring survives throughout as well.  South wall does not reach ceiling, which poses the question of when the gaeta suit was added - high vaulted ceiling.  Line runs (ridge) 3' high around perimeter of wall.

column14: None
column15: In northeast corner of room 2 with 1 room to south.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform; well-preserved surface and lip; plaster facing and two arched storage recesses below with plaster lining.

column14: None
column21: Small rectangular latrine off kitchen (2), vaulted ceiling with plaster lining on all four walls, and plaster seat at rear on west wall.  Small wall, 1/2' high in center of south wall.

column14: First of 3 rooms off south corridor (#1) on lower level that could have been used for dining.  Kitchen #2 immediately to west, room five to east.
column15: First of 3 rooms off south corridor (#1) on lower level that could have been used for dining.  Kitchen #2 immediately to west, room five to east.
column21: Room facing south. Barrel vault.  Door in northwest corner leading to Room 4.  Fragments of painting on black background on east and north walls.  More poorly preserved fragments on west wall have collapsed.  Of vault above, pieces of molded cornice in northwest and northeast corners at point of springing.  Patches of restored vaulting on south side but without photos when room was discovered, hard to describe.  Large piece of original plaster still covers east jamb of big south window.

column14: Contiguous to room eight.
column21: Rectangular vaulted ceiling; window in north wall looking into number eight; doorway in northeast corner.  Traces of coarse plaster on south wall.

column14: Contiguous to room # 10
column21: Rectangular room - Low arched vault.  Doorway to #7 in southeast corner - doorway in northwest corner - cistern in center of north end of room - no decoration; coarse plaster.  Windows in south and north.  It is locked and not able to access room to northeast.  Well preserved metal window grill on north wall - (NOTEWORTHY).

column14: Entrance through northwest corner from peristyle 5. Room 6 sits to southwest of corner.  Room 1 to the south.
column15: Entrance through northwest corner from peristyle 5. Room 6 sits to southwest of corner.  Room 1 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room with masonry counter along east wall. No traces of window or other decoration. Doorway in northwest corner. Short partition against north end of cooking platform. No trace of floor.  Rubble throughout most of the room.  Corridor runs from peristyle 5 to the northwest corner of the room.

column14: Largest room on lower level 2 on the north edge of the property.  To the west is a lower garden; to the north is a service corridor not connected to the room.  To the east the room opens to a large common space (room 2).
column15: Largest room on lower level 2 on the north edge of the property.  To the west is a lower garden; to the north is a service corridor not connected to the room.  To the east the room opens to a large common space (room 2).
column21: Large rectangular barrel-vaulted room on an approximate north/south axis.  Open to south through a large window, partially preserved.  View would have been to lower terrace and the valley/bay beyond.  Remains of a doorjamb in the east wall appear to be restored.  Patches of painted plaster remain in the northeast, northwest, and southwest corners; the southwest patch is the best preserved and shows the remains of several colors (red, green and white) used in framing of wall decoration (see PPM Volume 8).  Only the northernmost portion of the vault is preserved; the remainder of the room is open to the sky.  Plaster molding is preserved along introdos of vault.

column14: Terrace to the south; room 23 to the west; external wall of the house to the east.
column15: Terrace to the south; room 23 to the west; external wall of the house to the east.
column21: Rectangular south-facing room.  Two large windows are in the west wall, facing out onto open room 23.  Room is open to the terrace on the south.  Position and size suggest the room was a dining room.

column14: Storeroom (room 11) to the north; atrium (room 2) to the east; storage niche (room 9) to the west.
column15: Storeroom (room 11) to the north; atrium (room 2) to the east; storage niche (room 9) to the west.
column21: Rectangular room with wide opening at the east.  Engaged columns on either side of the opening.  Plaster remains on north, west, and east walls and on the columns (red, yellow, and green).  There is a storage niche on the west wall.

column14: West of storeroom (room 8 / feature 1205).  South of storeroom (room 11).
column15: West of storeroom (room 8 / feature 1205).  South of storeroom (room 11).
column21: Storage niche.  Large storage niche located on west wall of room 8 (feature 1205).  Some plaster remains.  There is evidence of three hole for shelf supports; height is floor to ceiling.

column14: room 4 to westroom 8 to south
column15: room 4 to westroom 8 to south
column21: Long rectangular dining room.  South facing high vaulted ceiling preserved at north end with restored molding on east wall.  Two registers of molding survive northeast corner.  Red painted molding survives at junction of wall and vault.  Fragment of white plaster molding 3 feet below.  Wall painting preserved in northeast and northwest corners consisting of black lower register with green trim with faded black and white (light colored) background with red trim.  Doorway in southwest corner opens to room 4.  Decoration, position, vault, and size suggest use as dining room.

column14: # 1 to south# 3 to east
column21: Small square room with doorway in southeast corner.  Previous rooms--cubicula modeled to storerooms.  Wall painting, preserved plaster on north, east, south walls.  Yellow lower register, red border with white trim, black above.  Joist floor shelving surrounding north wall.  Blocked recess in northwest corner of west wall, function unknown.  It aligns with the joist and may indicate floor above.

column14: 4 to south, 5 to east, 1 to west
column15: 4 to south, 5 to east, 1 to west
column21: Square south facing room looking out over room #4.  Fragments of wall painting in northeast and northwest corner reveal burgundy red background with blue trim.  No evidence of ceiling.  Decoration and position overlooking terrace suggest use as dining room.

column14: Room 2 to north; room 4 to east; room 8 to south.
column15: Room 2 to north; room 4 to east; room 8 to south.
column21: Rectangular south-facing dining room with high vaulted ceiling.  No decoration survives.  Low wall to south blocks view of terrace; the wall is not sufficiently preserved to tell if it was a wall or a window to provide a view.  Doorway to room 4 is in the southeast corner.  The position of the room suggests it was used as a dining room.

column14: Room 6 to the northwest; room 4 to the north; room 7 to the northeast.
column15: Room 6 to the northwest; room 4 to the north; room 7 to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular terrace looking out over harbor area.  There is a rectangular preparation platform in the northwest corner.  Large stepped doorways open to rooms 4 and 7 to the north.  Presence of the platform and the proximity suggests this is a food preparation area as per Penelope Allison.

column14: Proximity to dining rooms to the north.
column16: Proximity to dining rooms to the north.
column21: Square masonry preparation platform in northwest corner of the terrace. No lip; recessed storage below.

column14: Room 6 to the south; room 1 to the east.
column15: Room 6 to the south; room 1 to the east.
column21: Square room with a high vaulted ceiling and traces of plaster.  There is a rectangular recess in the east wall.  The doorway to room 1 is in the southeast corner.  Floor is obscured by debris, leaving no indication of a platform.  There is a drain in the southwest corner.  The position of the room in relationship to the dining rooms, and the position of the drain suggests a use associated with food preparation.

column14: Corridor (room LL1/1) to the south; room LL1/2 to the west; room LL1/4 to the east.
column15: Corridor (room LL1/1) to the south; room LL1/2 to the west; room LL1/4 to the east.
column21: Small square room.  Doorway to room 1 in the center of the south wall.  Wall paintings survive on the north, east, south, and west walls:  yellow lower register, red division with white trim and black above.  Row of support for shelving or floor joists; however, painting continues above the holes, suggesting they are for shelving.  Cubiculum converted to use as a storeroom.

column14: Room 1 to the south; room 3 to the east.
column15: Room 1 to the south; room 3 to the east.
column21: Small square room with doorway in the southeast corner.  Previous rooms -- cubicula modeled to storerooms.  Wall painting and preserved plaster are on the north, east, and south walls:  yellow lower register, red border with white trim, and black above.  Holes for floor joists or shelving survives along the north wall.  Blocked recess in the northwest corner of the west wall; function unknown.  It aligns with the joist and may indicate a floor above.

column14: Room 15 to the north; 3 to the east; 10 to the south; 19 to the west.
column15: Room 15 to the north; 3 to the east; 10 to the south; 19 to the west.
column21: Square room opening east into the atrium.  Plaster survives on all four walls; no paint survives.  Blocked plastered-over doorway in the northeast corner.  Marble threshold with fittings for a door out to the atrium.  North, west, and south walls contain holes/joists for two tiers of shelves.  Restored joists for floor above along the top of the north wall.

column14: Atrium (room 3) to the north; terrace to the south; room 13 to the east; room 14 to the west.
column15: Atrium (room 3) to the north; terrace to the south; room 13 to the east; room 14 to the west.
column21: Wide doorway north into the atrium with a threshold of black and white geometric square and swastika mosaic.  White mosaic floor with central motif removed; possibly the doves but no evidence.  No wall decoration survives.  Facing south over the terrace.  Mosaic layout and position of the room support its use as a possible dining room.

column14: Room 12 to the west, room 8 to the north; atrium (room 3) to the northwest.
column15: Room 12 to the west, room 8 to the north; atrim (room 3) to the northwest.
column21: Facing south over the terrace.  Doorway in the northwest corner opening out to the atrium with marble threshold and fittings for a door.  White mosaic floor with central decoration removed.  May be the dove mosaic.  No wall decoration survives.  There is a small drain in the center (in mosaic) of the north wall.  The mosaic flooring and room position supports its use as a dining room.

column14: Room 21 to the east; room 15 to the south contains couch niche in the south wall and stairs to the floor above that runs along the west wall.
column15: Room 21 to the east; room 15 to the south contains couch niche in the south wall and stairs to the floor above that runs along the west wall.
column21: L-shaped room.  No floor or wall decoration survives.  Northwest corner gives access out onto the street.  Large masonry L-shaped platform in the northeast corner.  Window in north wall above the cooking platform.

column14: In northeast corner of the kitchen (feature 1219).
column16: In northeast corner of the kitchen (feature 1219).
column21: L-shaped masonry platform in the northeast corner of the kitchen.  No storage recesses below; no lip, tiled surface.  Window in the north wall above the platform.

column14: Atrium (room 3) to the south; kitchen (room 16) to the north and west; fauces to east.
column15: Atrium (room 3) to the south; kitchen (room 16) to the north and west; fauces to east.
column21: Rectangular room originally with doorway opening south into the atrium; now blocked.  Window in southwest corner opening into the atrium.  Access to kitchen in the southwest of room.  Originally a room running off the atrium, subsequently converted to use with adjoining kitchen.  Pile of rubble in the northwest corner possibly overlying the base of a platform.

column14: Street to north.
column21: Small rectangular counter room opening out onto the street to the north, with a stepped marble threshold with indications of a door.  Poorly preserved rubble base of U-shaped counter with a hearth at the southern end; too poorly preserved for any indication of counter or dolia.  Stairs up to a masonry platform in the southwest corner with an adjoining blocked doorway.  Shallow plaster-lined platform along the east and south walls; function unknown.  Small plaster-lined red painted niche in the wall behind the counter in the northeast corner.  There is a larger red plastered semicircular recess in northwest corner.

column14: At the north end of the shop, fronting on the street.
column16: At the north end of the shop, fronting on the street.
column21: Poorly preserved U-shaped counter.  Only the lower course of a rubble base survives.  There is a hearth at the southern end.

column14: South of kitchen #14
column21: Note:  definition by location.  Small recessed stonework opening through north wall from kitchen (#14).  Blocked doorway in east wall to peristyle.  Traces of plaster on south and west walls.  Yellow coloring survives as plaster adjoining blocked doorway.

column14: North of storeroom #13
column21: Note:  definition by location.  Located northeast corner of house.  Plaster remnants in northeast corner.  Access to peristyle in northeast corner.  Southeast corner doorway opening to storage room #13.  Door in northwest corner.  No platform, no window.

column14: 2 to north, 4 to south, 5 to west
column15: 2 to north, 4 to south, 5 to west
column21: Rectangular room facing west into peristyle 5.  No trace of original ceiling.  Fragments of cocciopesto floor at foot of southwest corner of wall, otherwise floor obscured by small rock deposit.  Plaster contrast on south and east walls with red lower register with white trim and white above.  Traces of plaster decoration, plant motifs, on lower register.  Position and decoration suggests use as a dining room.  Doorway to dining room (2) in northwest corner.

column14: On east wall of kitchen
column21: Heavily restored.  Two arched openings for storage or fuel below.  That to north partially blocked by wall.

column14: West of combined kitchen/latrine connecting by a door in its southeast corner.
column15: West of combined kitchen/latrine connecting by a door in its southeast corner.
column21: Currently being excavated by team of students from Naples.  Walls are 1-2 meters in height. No preserved original wall surface or flooring. Read upcoming report to know what is going on.

column14: None
column15: north end of corridor, north of door to east wall connecting to shop.
column21: L-shaped platform along north and west walls with just enough room for one person to stand.  It is not preserved to a height convenient for work but as stated above, it's heavily restored.  No provisions beneath for fuel storage.

column14: at end of north-south corridor #4.  opens east into room 3 which is a shop whose door is VI.2.23.  corridor opens into atrium a northeast corner.
column15: at end of north-south corridor #4.  opens east into room 3 which is a shop whose door is VI.2.23.  corridor opens into atrium a northeast corner.
column21: Room is nothing but a long narrow corridor.  Wall above cooking platform shows no indication of window.  Doors to south and east show no indication of preservation to lintels.

column14: House #7 on south (doorway), street on west.

Small niche against shop entrance in northwest corner.

Support for platform over plaster lined basin below with the lined drain to the north.  No other features in the room.  Function of the room is not clear as there are no cooking platforms extant. column15: Rooms #2 and #3 to the north of the room. Room #4 is to the northwest.

column14: Room #2 to south. Room #3 to west. Stairs to upper story of doorway VI.3.23 in southeast corner.
column15: Room #2 to south. Room #3 to west. Stairs to upper story of doorway VI.3.23 in southeast corner.
column21: Niche in northwest corner. Traces of shelving along north wall. Windows to garden/dining area on west wall. Doorway to room #3 in southwest corner. Room #2 to south. Traces of plaster on north wall.

column14: Contiguous to room 7 adjacent to house 28 in south room 14 probably a store room of kitchen of 28. adjacent to house 28 in south. Tiny room connected to house by door on south east. column15: Contiguous to room 7 adjacent to house 28 in south room 14 probably a store room of kitchen of 28. adjacent to house 28 in south. Tiny room connected to house by door on south east. column21: Kitchen is in a small extension of southwest portion of house. The area has been added at a later date. Small passage #9 leads north from room 10 into a tiny room with the ruins of cooking platform on west side, with a niche for fuel storage beneath and a niche in the wall in east side. It doesn't look large enough for a latrine.

column14: Contiguous to garden? and fauces
column21: A niche in south west corner present, still painted in red. Blocked doorway in northwest corner; surviving painting is red in color.

column14: Located between #14 (storage) and #12 (small room).
column21: Small kitchen contains a cooking platform on west wall with a window above which goes into dining room of next house (26). Small door to east leads in to #14 and door to south leads out of kitchen (storeroom) via small east-west corridor.

column14: None
column21: In kitchen - cooking platform on west wall and extends width of wall. Single arched opening beneath for fuel storage. Not clear how much has been restored, but clearly on south side of platform's surface.

column14: Kitchen to west.
column21: Small square room. No décor or flooring. Small doorway in southwest corner opening to kitchen room #13. Use of storage indicated by proximity to kitchen.

column14: Room #4 to south and room #6 to west.  Adjacent to street to the east.
column15: Room #4 to south and room #6 to west.  Adjacent to street to the east.

Identification as dining room based on size and width of doorway overlooking large room with two columns subsequently subdivided.  Room #6 was examined as a possible kitchen (in view of small size and proximity to dining room), however, no indication of use survives.

column14: #1 to south.  Atrium #4 to east.  Street to west.

No other features but large shop frontage, waters supply and lararium suggest shop for food and drink.

column21: Beautiful mill/oven room.  Three restored meta and catillus, one perfect meta.  Small pantry oven.  Meta is missing catillus.  Preparation platform.  Two stone supports for platform.  Animal mills.  Great enclosed oven.  Fuel rectangle.  Pass through on left.  Two water basins built in on left.  Kneading basin on right of oven.  Used to be called "Bakery of the Christine"

column21: Recreation pond lined with opus signinum. No other features such as amphorae. Cistern in southwest and southeast corner with colonnade. Drain running north-south around colonnade.

Another thin partition wall separates the latrine from the kitchen.  Nicely preserved casement window is in north wall leading to street.  Window is low in wall with approximately 90 cm above level of modern fill inside room.  Same ledge is 1.95 meters above level of exterior sidewalk.

Traces of wall painting in the northeast and northwest corner.  No other decoration used.  Dining room indicated by position.

column14: Outside room and to west at 45 degree angle is large block of Sarno Baths.  Approached from ground level by corridor number 1 leading to number 2.
