column14: Window to street in south wall. Kitchen to west (room 16).
column15: Window to street in south wall. Kitchen to west (room 16).
column21: Small, rectangular room, plaster-lined with a vaulted ceiling.  Plastered window high on center of south wall.  Access through a low arched window in southwest corner from kitchen (room 16).  Access to room 24 to north is due to a modern collapse.

column14: Peristyle (7) to southwest.  Garden (8) to west.  Kitchen (9) to north.
column15: Peristyle (7) to southwest.  Garden (8) to west.  Kitchen (9) to north.
column21: Rectangular Dining Room opening southwest to peristyle garden.  Traces of wall paint survive in each corner with white and red trim.  In west corner painting survives with red panels to traces of flooring or ceiling.  Identification of dining room in respect to position to garden, shape of room, size of opening and decoration.

column14: On the eastern and the southern sides is hallway (7).  On the south wall to the south of the masonry triclinium is a window looking onto a small room (6).  On the northern wall of the eastern side is a Lararium filled with rubble.
column15: On the eastern and the southern sides is hallway (7).  On the south wall to the south of the masonry triclinium is a window looking onto a small room (6).  On the northern wall of the eastern side is a Lararium filled with rubble.
column21: On the western part is the garden triclinium oriented southwest-northeast.  On the south wall to the south of the masonry triclinium is a window looking on a small room (6).  On the southern corner is the entrance to the garden triclinium from the hallway (7).  On the south/southeast side of the garden are four columns.  The western column is an engaged column into the west wall.  On the east side are two additional columns.  The column on the north wall is engaged.  If there were any decoration on the wall it is no longer extant.  Abutting the west wall is the masonry triclinium.  Beneath the floor is a cistern with openings at the inside front of the lectus summus and at 110 cm distance from the end of the lectus imus is another cistern.  The intercolumnal spaces are filled with a low wall of indeterminate height.  On the eastern and southern sides of the room is hallway (7).  Abutting the north wall and the east end of the lectus imus is a low platform that could have served as a serving table or a bench for diners who would sit to eat.  (A buttress?).

column14: None
column21: The masonry triclinium is located in the western part of the dining garden.  It has the usual form of three beds.  The lectus summus is longer than the lectus imus.  The lectus medius and imus abut against the western and northern walls respectively.  On the north wall extending from the lectus imus is a structure that could be a podium, serving platform or seat bench.  There is a pathway between the southern edge of the lectus summus and the wall of room 6.  In the middle among the three lecti are the remains of a low table.  As extant, shape is indeterminate.  Beneath and within the lecti, is a series of rectangular niches.  (3,4 & 4 going from summus to imus).  On eastern end of the inside of the lectus summus, and engaged in it, is the entrance to the cistern.

column14: Garden 8 to west.  Dining room 10 to south.
column15: Garden 8 to west.  Diningroom 10 to south.
column21: Rectangular kitchen with small beehive oven in northeast corner with rectangular cooking platform in southeast corner.  No storage recess but tile surface extant.  Preparation platform in southwest corner.  Latrine in northeast corner adjoining oven.  Along north wall is a separate rectangular storage room.  No extant floor or ceiling.  Two rectangular holes in south wall to support something.  Function is unclear for what they support.

column14: Cooking platform 1763 to south latrine 1762 to west.
column16: Cooking platform 1763 to south latrine 1762 to west.
column21: Small beehive oven.  Brick built base obscured by debris.  Oven opens to south.

column16: Oven 1761 to east.  Storeroom 1765 to west.
column21: Small rectangular latrine immediately to west of oven.  Floor is obscured by debris.  However, the narrowness of room and recesses for seat in the east and west walls against north wall suggest it's function is a latrine.  A narrow doorway in south wall separates latrine from kitchen.

column14: Oven 1761 to north.  Masonry supports 1764 to west.
column16: Oven 1761 to north.  Masonary supports 1764 to west.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform in the northeast corner of the kitchen extending along east wall towards oven.  The structure of the platform survives intact but is obscured by debris on platform.  No recesses below.  Cooking platform has tile surface extant.  Opening in wall above seems to be from collapse.

column14: Cooking platform 1763 to east.  Storeroom 1765 to north.
column16: Cooking platform 1763 to east.  Storeroom 1765 to north.
column21: Single masonry support in middle of south wall.  The southwest corner is obscured by debris.  Opening above seems to be collapsed rubble.  Above masonry support is a small plaster recess, perhaps for counter surface.

column14: Kitchen 9 to south.  Peristyle garden 8 to west.  Peristyle 7 to west.  Contains plaster Lararium niche in northeast corner immediately outside door to kitchen.
column15: Kitchen 9 to south.  Peristyle garden 8 to west.  Peristyle 7 to west.  Contains plaster Lararium niche in northeast corner immediately outside door to kitchen.
column21: Small rectangular room with narrow doorway in southeast corner.  Full of debris but proximity to kitchen (room 9) suggests related use perhaps as a storeroom.

column14: None
column21: Tannery: On the south side of the house at a level lower than "Peristyle" which is approached by stairs on the west side is a garden.  Half way down on the north side along the wall is a basin coated on the interior with opus signinum.  At the bottom of the stairs on the west wall are the remains of an unknown feature.

column14: None
column21: On the north wall of the garden is a waterproof basin coated with opus signinum.  In the east and west walls are holes in the basin approximately 1/3 down from the top.  On the outside of the eastern wall on level with the holes in the basin is a large slab of concrete that seems to direct water into the basin.  In the western corner of the basin at the bottom is a small depression probably used to clear the basin.  On the north wall above, level with the basin and inserted into the wall is a broken amphora which seems to lead from the peristyle above.

column14: None
column21: Unknown feature abutting from the north wall at the bottom of the stairs.  Low platform of indeterminate of shape and usage.

column14: None
column21: Large square room opening into a peristyle to the North and garden( four ). Traces of plaster survive on the East and South walls with red panels.  Floor is not visible.  PPM identifies this as a exedra .  Identification as a dining room is based on the size, room shape and position with respect to the garden.

column14: None
column21: A small rectangular room with a large entrance to the southwest close to the odeon.  Podium in the southwest corner with evidence of a niche in the north side for support of wooden stairs.  Recessed niche in the north corner, possibly for storage.

column14: Room 4 to the south.  Room 2 to the west.
column15: Room 4 to the south.  Room 2 to the west.
column21: Small rectangular room with doorway in the southeast corner.  South and west walls do not survive above the first course of stones.  Plaster lined Lararium niche [1773] in the east wall above rectangular cooking platform [1772].

column14: Lararium niche (1773) above platform in the east wall.
column16: Lararium niche (1773) above platform in the east wall.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform along north wall to northeast corner.  Surface is eroded, however tiles surface survives at northeast end of platform and opus signinum/coccio pesto surface in the southwest corner of the platform.  Recessed storage area below possibly arched.

column14: Cooking platform [1772] below.
column21: Rectangular plaster lined Lararium niche.  None of the decorations survives, although the extant plaster is light in color.  Lararium is in the east wall.

column14: None
column16: Peristyle (3) to the north and garden (4) to the north.
column21: Square room opening North into a peristyle and garden.  Traces of plaster survive in the corners without any additional traces of decoration. Large plastered window in the center of the east wall opening into 14 subsequently blocked.  Plaster lined couch niche in the southeast corner.  Threshold with doorjambs for a door to close off the room from the peristyle.
column53: (Video) last 2-3 seconds, should be cut.  Camera didn't turn off properly.

column14: None
column21: Small plaster lined couch niche in the south east corner with black decoration.

column14: None
column16: 6-central room/open space to the south7-storage room to the southwest9-bedroom to the east
column21: A large dining room with irregular, rectangular shape.  Doors in the southwest corner with a fine lintel.  Open in the southwest wall to a storage area or light well.  North corner was built in area for possible biclinium.  Apparent 4th style remaining plaster and painting with red.  Pass through to the storage room just outside door.

column14: None
column16: 10- hallway with a water basin to the west.
column21: In the east corner of the house is the kitchen.  Doorway is in the northwest corner.  On the north wall are three lararia, two smaller nearer the door, side by side and a larger one to the northeast.  No other identifiable remains.  PPM notes a masonry bench in the southeast corner.  If walls were decorated, no evidence remains.

column14: None
column21: On the north wall are three lararia, two smaller ones nearer the door, side by side.  A large one farther towards the northeast.  Remains of plaster exta nt in all three.  No signs of decoration or paint.

column14: None
column21: One enters the shop from the street on the south side.  Immediately to the west is a counter with three sides.  The north side is flush against the north wall and contains three dolia, possibly four.  Just to the east of the entrance there's a large stone which Riddell (sp?) indicates was a stove.  To the east is a doorway leading to a small room under which Fontana's tunnel can be seen.  Directly across the street from the shop is the temple of Aesculapius.

column14: None
column21: The counter on the west wall has three dolia and this side looks upon the street.  The counter on the south side has an additional one dolium for a total seven or eight.  On the south corner of the counter the masonry has fallen away.  To judge from the lips of the dolia exposed to the countertops, the dolia vary in size.  The eastern dolium of the north counter has a much larger mouth than the others as reconstructed.  Three additional dolia exist on the north wall counter.

column14: Room 6 to the north; Room 7 to the north; Room 9, Garden to the west
column15: Room 6 to the north; Room 7 to the north; Room 9, Garden to the west
column21: Large rectangular room with doorway in the northwest corner. Large window in center of west wall opens to garden nine. Traces of decorations survive in southwest corner, red in lower register and white above. In center of  east wall there is a partially filled in plaster lined recess, approximately 6 ft long by 30 cm. ******[please measure]***********   Floor is obscured by gravel. Blocked plaster cupboard or window in east corner of south wall and locked plastered window in south corner of east wall.

column14: None
column21: In the south corner of the house is a rectangular shaped triclinium.  The identification is based primarily on a comment by Fiorelli description that when excavated there was a triclinium present (no longer extant).  Fiorelli also mentions the present (no longer present) of a puteal implying a cistern.  The triclinium appears to overlook the garden (room 9) to the east.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature: Masonry triclinium described by Fiorelli is no longer present.

column14: None
column16: Diningroom and portico (room 10) to the west, diningroom (room 8) to the east, tablinum (room 5) to the north.
column21: Rectangular garden surrounded by a covered portico on the north and west sides.  Gutter survives along the north, east and west sides.  Four embedded dolia are recorded in southeast corner of which only two survive.  Jashemski reports puteal in the west portico and an alter "On the rights side of the peristyle" of which there is no sign today.  Traces of plaster survive along the southern wall in and a large window is found in the middle of the east wall looking out from dining room (room 8).

column14: None
column15: Gutter along the north, east and west sides of the garden; no longer extant masonary triclinium in the diningroom (room 10) to the west.
column21: Four dolia are recorded as being embedded in the southeast corner of the garden, two of which survive today.  The use of the dolium is unknown.  Both dolia are well preserved.  The eastern dolia appears to have a possible uncertain graffito on the eastern rim.  Dolia one closest to the eastern wall dimensions are 74 deep; 11 width on the lip; 34 ID (inside dimension ?); lip height 13 from the ground.  Dolia two closest to the north wall dimensions are 66 deep; 9 lip width; 33 ID (inside dimension?); lip height 12 from the ground.

column14: None
column16: Room number two to the southwest.
column21: Large rectangular room with two openings onto the Vicolo del Menandro, on the northwest wall.  The west entrance has stairs going up, second entrance to the shop.  The lararium niche no longer extant.  Newly reconstructed counter on the northwest wall with dolium with step shelf which does not match the original archeology report.  Entrance to the house in the southwest corner.

column14: None
column21: (Counter) beautifully reconstructed counter with a marble top and a dolium in the southwest arm with a step shelf in the north corner along the street.  Reconstruction does not match the archeological report.  Hearth is missing.

column14: None
column21: Rectangular room faces into a peristyle to the south east with a large entrance. Two niches for the triclinium benches are on the north and west walls. There are remnants of fourth style painting on the east and south walls near the entrance.

column14: None
column21: Two couch niches: one each on the north and west walls.  The west niche is longer than that on the north wall.

column14: None
column16: Store room (6) to the north, peristyle (9) to the west, stairs (7) to the west.
column21: Small rectangular room with a doorway opening in the southwest corner to the peristyle (9).  Window in the middle of the east wall opens out into the street.  Small round hole in east wall above opens onto the street, not clear whether original or not.  There is small rectangular hole at the top of the south end of the eastern wall.  PPM refers to this as the kitchen and refers to an adjoining latrine that could not be identified.

column14: Room 9 Portico of the garden to the westRoom 6 Storeroom to the south
column15: Room 9 Portico of the garden to the westRoom 6 Storeroom to the south
column21: Located on the northeast side of the house, dining room entered by narrow doorway onto portico of the garden. The room is roughly square and was elaborately decorated with painted walls and stucco reliefs, some of which are extant.

column14: Room 9 Garden to the westRoom 8 Kitchen to the south Room 5 Dining Room to the north
column15: Room 9 Garden to the westRoom 8 Kitchen to the south Room 5 Dining Room to the north
column21: One enters the storeroom on the northwest side of the house through opening through stairs to second level. The room is rectangular long side east-west orientation. No decoration extant. Storeroom looks out to garden (room 9) to the west.

column14: Garden (room 12) to the south. Tablinum (room 15) to the east. (room 13) to the west.
column15: Garden (room 12) to the south. Tablinum (room 15) to the east. (room 13) to the west.
column21: Square room opening south to peristyle garden (room 12). Doorway in east wall with step up to tablinum (room 15). Narrow opening, possibly window, in the west end of north wall, opening into adjoining property I.3.22. Plaster lined couch niche at the north end of west wall with traces of red trim. Above the extant niche are traces of a second plaster lined recess from an earlier phase that has been filled in. No other decoration survives. The northeast corner of the room is completely obscured by rubble. Small hand quern resting on the wall in the southeast corner. Tufa blocks in the colonnade outside to the southeast of the room described by PPM as an altar.

column14: None
column21: Plaster lined couch niche at the north end of west wall with traces of red trim. Above the extant niche are traces of a second plaster lined recess from an earlier phase that has been filled in.

column14: The southeast corner- dining room (room 14)
column21: Hand quern placed on wall at entrance to dining room (room 14).

column14: Atrium to west (room 1)
column21: Located on northeast part of house, entered from atrium (room 1). On the northwest wall is a low cooking platform. Room is roughly square with opening on east wall to latrine. No evidence of decoration extant.

column14: None
column21: Cooking platform is located on the west wall of kitchen extending just inside to back wall to latrine. As extant no façade or the surface, if there ever was one.

column14: None
column21: Painting depicting the fight between the Nucerians and Pompeiians at the amphitheater in AD 59 (Tacitus Annals 14.17) was originally on the west wall of the peristyle garden (room 12); no longer in situ. Now in Naples Museum.

column14: Garden to the northwest (room 9).
column21: A small rectangular exedra with fourth style paintings with large figures on the northeast, south and west walls. There is a recent article describing the room. [********** ]. Molding on the ceiling. Gladiator motif in the paintings.

column14: garden (room 8) to the west. Peristyle (room 9) to the south. (room 11) to the west.
column15: garden (room 8) to the west. Paristyle (room 9) to the south. (room 11) to the west.
column21: Large rectangular room with east west axis. Traces of plaster survive in the northeast and northwest corners. No sign of decoration. Doorway western end of south wall opens to peristyle (room 9). Collapse of southern end of west wall look through into garden. South wall survives only to about two and a half feet, therefore unclear if window was facing south to the garden. Size and position to garden suggests dining room.

column14: kitchen (room 12) to the north. Atrium (room 2) to the west. Fauces (room 1) south. Street to the east
column15: kitchen (room 12) to the north. Atrium (room 2) to the west. Fauces (room 1) south. Street to the east
column21: Rectangular room with east-west axis, north and south walls not preserved above two and a half feet. North end of west wall collapsed away. Doorway opening into room 2 in the west-southwest corner with preserved plaster decoration with yellow lower register and white upper register. Traces of plaster survive along east wall with no decoration. Small narrow window high in east wall with larger square window high in east wall. Perhaps originally matching previously noted window one and a half feet to the north in size and shape, however lower two thirds collapsed underneath. Small, narrow, at east end of south wall plastered at same height and shape as ones on east wall. No trace of flooring.

column14: dining room (room 13) to the east.
column21: Located on the north corner of the house is the kitchen. One enters the kitchen from the atrium (room 2). The room is rectangular in shape, roughly northeast to southwest. In the back (to the northeast) is the latrine separated by a wall. No extant decoration. On the northeast wall above eye level is a large window.

column14: None
column15: to the atrium (room 2) to the west. Street to the east. Dining room (room 13) to the south.
column21: The latrine is in the northeast corner of the kitchen. An L-shaped bench against the northeast corner and partition wall at the western end separates the latrine from the rest of the kitchen. Partition wall contains a recess for a seat that is contiguous with the height of the L-shaped stone bench. Traces of plaster survive at the joining of the bench with the wall along the east and north. In the middle of the eastern wall above the latrine is a plaster-lined square window opening out to the street. Floor is not visible.

column14: 1 - Entrance room to the north. 7 - stable to west. 3 - Preparation room to south. 5 - storeroom to south.
column15: 1 - Entrance room to the north. 7 - stable to west. 3 - Preperation room to south. 5 - storeroom to south.
column21: Very long rectangular room with entrance to the street to the east. On the eastern wall one large lintel and two small windows on each side. Entrance is sloped perhaps for animals to enter. Doorway has grooved threshold for door. Two supports for wooden platform just inside doorway on south wall. Along north wall are four rubble mill bases. Midway down the south wall after entrance to preparation room is a raised oven with a passthrough to kneading room and a passthrough to the storage room. Underneath oven is a post and lintel fuel storage area.

column14: 1813 - Mill base to north. 1814 Mill base to north.
column16: 1813 - Mill base to north. 1814 Mill base to north.
column21: Close to the entrance, along the south wall are three masonry supports for a wooden platform possibly for preparation or sales.

column14: Oven Room (room 4) to the southwest, Mill/Oven room (room 2) to the north
column15: Oven Room (room 4) to the southwest, Mill/Oven room (room 2) to the north
column21: Lying on the south part of the house and east of the oven/mill room. One enters the room from the northwest. Room is rectangular on a northwest/southeast axis. Just to the left almost blocking the entrance is the basin for a mechanical kneading machine. In the south corner is a small alcove of indeterminate usage. Although once decorated nothing remains. On the southwest wall just as you enter the room is an opening leading to the oven.

column14: None
column21: Just to the east, almost blocking the entrance is the basin for a mechanical kneading machine. The rim of the basin is very thick and penetrated by four holes for the insertion of wooden stakes. In the bottom of the basin is the fixture for the insertion of the iron pivot (non extant). The stone used for the basin is tufa.

column14: Mill Base (1815) to the north, Mill Base (1816) to the north
column16: Mill Base (1815) to the north, Mill Base (1816) to the north
column21: Midway down the south wall after the entrance to the preparation room is a highly raised oven with a pass through to the preparation room and a pass through to the storage room. Located under the oven is a post and lintel fuel storage area. Oven is brick built and of bee hive construction.

column14: Mill/Oven room (2) to the north, latrine (non-featured) to the west.
column15: Mill/Oven room (2) to the north, latrine (non-featured) to the west.
column21: Square room with doorway to mill/oven room (2) at the western end of the northern wall. Northeast corner obscured by rubble. Entire floor is obscured. Undecorated plaster survives in the southwest corner. Oval opening 1/2 up the northern end of the east wall provides access to the oven to the east.

column14: Mill/Oven Room (2) to the east
column21: Long rectangular room (east-west axis) with doorway to the mill/oven room (2) at the southern end of the east wall. Poorly preserved masonry platform along the eastern half of the north wall (trough?). Square plaster lined basin in the north east corner. Plaster is well preserved but the base of the basin is obscured by accumulated debris. No visible decoration. Floor is obscured. Wall collapse in the southwest corner.

column14: None
column21: NON-FEATURE SHEET: (Graffito) Fiorelli: Excavation Report Description 40 (Mayeske 1972, 83-84), Eschebach pg. 25 does not refer to the graffito. See Non-Feature sheet for detailed graffito content & description.

column14: None
column21: One enters the shop from the northeast. On the southeast is an L-shaped counter above which on the southeast wall is a lararium. The counter has three embedded dolia on the northeast/southwest arm. At the end of the northeast/southwest arm was a hearth (no longer extant). To the northwest of the entrance just as one enters the room is a large cooking platform on top of which are raised masonry supports for two cooking pots. The platform has at the base of its southwest side an arched storage area. On the back southwest wall are two low masonry supports possibly used for cooking. High on the north wall, above the large cooking platform is a window looking onto the street. The room was decorated at one time - most of which is no longer extant. On the north wall, slightly above and to the northeast of the large window has been inserted into the wall the neck of a amphora has been inserted into the wall to the outside.

column14: 1805 - Masonry supports to north. 1814 - Mill base.
column16: 1805 - Masonary supports to north. 1814 - Mill base.
column21: Close to north wall are four rubble mill bases. No paving stones extant. Bases are in close proximity to each other.

column14: 1805 - Masonry supports to north. 1813 - mill base to east. 1815 - mill base to west.
column16: 1805 - Masonary supports to north. 1813 - mill base to east. 1815 - mill base to west.
column21: Close to north wall are four rubble mill bases. No paving stones extant. Bases are in close proximity to each other.

column14: Oven (1808) to the south, Mill Base (1814) to the east, Mill Base (1816) to the west
column16: Oven (1808) to the south, Mill Base (1814) to the east, Mill Base (1816) to the west
column21: Close to north wall are four rubble mill bases. No paving stone extant. Bases are in close proximity to each other

column14: Oven (1808) to the north.
column21: Close to north wall are four rubble mill bases. No paving stone extant. Bases are in close proximity to each other

column14: 1820 - Lararium to south, 1818 - cooking platform to north, 1819 - Masonry supports to west.
column16: 1820 - Lararium to south, 1818 - cooking platform to north, 1819 - Masonary supports to west.
column21: L shaped counter facing east to the Vicolo del Citarista. Marble surface with shorter face onto the street. Longer face within shop with three inserted dolia. Lip preserved on the eastern most dolia, but not on 2 western most dolia. Southern, northern and southeastern faces preserve red painted plaster. At western end of long-arm of counter is a rubble base of a hearth that is not restored.

column14: 1819 - Masonry support to west. 1817 - Counter to south.
column16: 1819 - Masonary support to west. 1817 - Counter to south.
column21: Square cooking platform with arched brick built recess below, well preserved. Tile cooking surface above. Against wall to the east are three masonry supports for cooking vessels. Behind supports against east wall at junction of the two, the plaster wall decoration is preserved. The platform is immediately adjacent to the shop entrance to the Vicolo del Citarista to the south. Above the platform, high in the east wall is a square window opening onto the street.

column14: 1817 - Counter to east. 1818 - Cooking Platform to east.
column16: 1817 - Counter to east. 1818 - Cooking Platform to east.
column21: Two masonry supports for no longer extant surface above and against the west wall. Plaster survives between supports and wall behind.

column14: 1817 - counter to north.
column21: Semicircular, arched lararium. Plaster lined with no extant decoration. Located in the eastern end of the south wall beside counter.

column14: Small bedroom to the southwest.
column21: One enters the kitchen through the doorway to the northwest. It is L shaped with the northwest/southeast is the long axis; northeast/southwest is the short axis. The designation as kitchen derives mainly from its position since there are no extant features associated with them. (Fiorelli, p.61 identifies this room as a kitchen). In the north wall in the back of the room is a window looking out onto the street. To the southwest is a doorway leading to a small bedroom (7). If the kitchen was decorated in antiquity, nothing remains.

column14: 2 - Atrium  to south. 6 to the east.
column15: 2 - Atrium  to south. 6 to the east.
column21: Square room with large doorway south to atrium (2). Traces of molded cornice, decoration survives at east of north wall. Small rectangular in north end of west; possible window opening to adjoining property or perhaps collapse. Painting survives on north, south, east and west walls. The best preserved is in northeast wall, however coloring survives on remaining walls. Red lower register with white trim and depiction of plants. Yellow panes above with white trim. Fiorelli calls this room a tablinum.

column14: 2 - atrium to the west. 1 - Fauces to the north.
column15: 2 - atrium to the west. 1 - Fauces to the north.
column21: Large, rectangular room with east/west axis. Doorway at northern end of west wall opens to room 2; NW corner and western of north wall does not survive. Square plastered window in western end of south wall opens to street. Small rectangular hole in center of south wall opens to street. Traces of plaster along southern wall with no surviving decoration. Identified as dining room because of size and identified as such by Fiorelli.

column14: 2 - atrium to the northeast.
column21: Located in the south part of house, one enters from the small atrium (2). The room is rectangular in shape on a SW/NE axis. Identification as a dining room rest primarily on its size and orientation to the atrium (2). If it were decorated in antiquity, nothing remains today.

column14: The peristyle garden (Room 6) is to the west.
column15: The peristyle garden (Room 6) is to the west.
column21: The dining room is a large rectangular room with a north-south axis.  The doorway in southern end of west wall opens to the peristyle (Room 6).  There is a large, low window in the northern half of the west wall.  It opens directly over the garden in peristyle (Room 6).  Wall painting survives on northwest, northeast and southeast corners - white with red border.  There is a square lararium niche above; plastered and painted buttress in the southern end of the east wall.  To the south of the dining room are stairs to the floor above accessed from the peristyle (Room 6).  Below the stairs is an arched storage area with a recess for shelves.

column14: Atrium (room 2) is to the northeast.
column21: Room 3 is entered from steps on the west side through a large opening which can be closed off with a shutter.  On the north side is an L-shaped counter with one enclosed dolium in arm parallel to street and two dolia in arm perpendicular to street as restored.  A doorway to the northeast leads into the atrium (Room 2).  The room appears to have been decorated in antiquity.  Only traces remain today.

column14: None
column21: This is an L-shaped counter with one dolium in the northeast/southeast arm of it and two dolia in the northeast/southwest arm.  There does not seem to be a hearth as reconstructed.  As reconstructed, there is a marble top.

column14: None
column21: This is a square lararium niche.  There is no extant decoration or plaster.  It is set high in the southern end of the east wall.  There is a high plastered buttress that stands in front of the niche to the height of the bottom of the lararium.

column14: None
column21: One enters Room 2 from the south by ascending two steps.  Directly to the west of the entrance is a cooking platform set back into the wall.  The rest of the room is roughly rectangular with a north-south axis.  On the north wall is a window that has been blocked up.  On the south wall is a large window looking on to Room 1.  Below the window is an irregularly shaped recess which may have been used for a couch or counter.  The room was decorated in antiquity but not enough remains to say anything about it.  On the north and east walls are places to insert ceiling beams to create what Eschebach calls a half floor or mezzanine, probably for storage.  He refers to steps in this room but all indications of them are missing.

column14: None
column21: Cooking platform inset into west wall as one enters the room from Room 1.  As reconstructed there is an arched storage area in bottom and hard surface/platform area of terracotta.

column14: Room 12(bath room)
column21: Small irregular kitchen with a large cooking platform on the north wall and a tile top from north to northwest back lip of the platform.  There is a lararium on the northeast wall above a small water basin on the east wall.  On the northwest of the wall is an elegant large latrine with a door lintel.  Tiled floor on latrine.  Sloping in back into wall on northwest corner. Seat support somewhat intact.  On (?) south wall is furnace to heat bath in the adjacent bathroom(Room 12).

column14: 1834 cooking platform to east1835 water basin to south
column16: 1834 cooking platform to east1835 water basin to south
column21: In northwest corner of kitchen (14) is a tiled latrine sloping towards drain (? Obscured by debris).  Recess for seat in north end of east wall.  Latrine is separated from cooking platform(1834) by wall and from rest of kitchen by wall and doorway with lintel to south.  Undecorated plaster on west wall.

column14: None
column21: Storeroom 16 is accessed by a narrow hallway from kitchen to west.  The room is vaulted and is roughly rectangular,east/ west axis.  Just inside the room to the south is what appears to be a cistern.  In the northeast corner is a semi circular construction about waist high faced on the interior with what appears to be water proof opus signinum, creating a large water basin.  On the south wall is the entrance to storeroom 17.

column14: 1832 to west
column21: On north wall.  Raised lip on back of platform from north to northwest.  Tiled. Large.  Built in water basin on north wall at front northeast corner of platform.  (Pictures will show an opening to a cistern(?); disregard as part of room.

column14: 1834 to west and south
column21: In north wall.  Small built-in basin with signinum.  Directly beneath lararium.

column14: 1835 below1834 northwest
column21: High up on northeast wall, above water basin.  No painting.

column14: 16- storeroom to northwest
column21: Located to southeast of storeroom (16) is storeroom 17, entered through a narrow door.  This room is vaulted with a large light well in ceiling.  The room is roughly rectangular on a southeast to northeast axis.  The room was surfaced with plaster that appears to be painted in solid red.

column14: None
column21: In the northeast corner of storeroom (16) is a water basin.  It has a semi circular construction about waist high faced on the interior with what appears to be water proof opus signinum.

column14: 63 bedroom to north66 peristyle to east
column15: 63 bedroom to north66 peristyle to east
column21: Rectangular room with east-west axis opening east to peristyle (66).  Doorway at east end of north to (63).  Black and white mosaic floor covered over.  Traces of plaster survive on south wall.  4th style paintings with Endymion and Selene on west wall, Adonis and Aphrodite on south wall, no longer extant.  That of the north wall, showing Io, Argos, and Mercury (4th style) is preserved in the Naples museum.

column14: None
column21: One enters the large dining hall (69) to the east from the triclinium.  At the entrance were two columns resting on rectangular bases, dividing the entrance into a large central one and two small ones on each side.  The room is quite large: rectangular in shape on a northeast-southwest axis.  The floor was covered with a black and white mosaic.  Central area of mosaic too damaged to tell, but seems to have been bordered by squares alternating with meander designs.  In antiquity the walls were elaborately painted with large central mythological scenes on two if not all three sides.  On the east wall is a scene of Ariadne abandoned by Theseus.  Included in the scene are Dionysiac motifs, including Pan and an aged Silenus.  On the north wall is shown Orestes and Pilas with Iphigeneia.  The sitting male figure with bluish clothing is King Toantes (?).

column14: 45 oecus to north
column21: Located in northwest corner of the house with peristyle 20 is a large oecus (45).  On the north side of the oecus is triclinium 57.  One enters the triclinium through a wide doorway on the north side of the room.  The room is rectangular in shape on a north-south axis.  The room in antiquity was elaborately painted but little remains to judge what was there.  The room opens onto oecus (45) on the north wall opposite.  Easily seen from the triclinium is a painting of the Judgment of Paris.

column14: 20 peristyle
column21: Room 60 triclinium is located on the western side of peristyle 20.  At the entrance are two columns situated so as to divide the entrance into three entrances: a large central entrance and two small ones.  The room faces to the east into peristyle 20 with a direct view of the fountain and bronze statues.  Room is roughly rectangular in shape on a north-south axis.  In antiquity, the room was elaborately decorated.  On the west wall was a roundel with a portrait of an old man.

column14: 20 peristyle to westanteroom to south which opens to room 44
column15: 20 peristyle to westanteroom to south which opens to room 44
column21: Large rectangular dining hall with east-west axis opening west to peristyle (20).  Doorway at west end of south wall.  Black and white mosaic floor with geometric pattern at threshold.  Doorjambs with fitting for doors in both doorways.  Plaster survives on north, west, south walls.  Best preserved is in center of south wall with elaborately decorated plaster: blue, yellow, red, green, pink and black paint.  Depiction of Maenad and Antiope in center of south wall now in Naples museum.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1, 117-119
column14: None
column21: Rectangular built in cupboard niche. Evidence of painting on the back wall. Traces of red and black paint.
column53: possible narration error, may have narrated room not feature.

column14: 20 peristyle to south
column21: Opening onto the north porticus of peristyle 20 is a small entrance into the storeroom.  I n the northwest corner of the room is a built-in cupboard (1844).  Evidence of painting on north, east and south walls.  Red framed square painting, rectangular in shape.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1, 117-119
column14: storeroom to the south (room 39). Room 37 to the north.
column15: storeroom to the south (room 39). Room 37 to the north.
column21: Small kitchen with doorway from (room 37) in the west end of north wall. There are holes along the east wall to support shelves or modern supports. Large square window high in east wall opening to street outside. Latrine in northeast corner (1848). Cooking platform (1847) in southwest corner. Room continues to southeast down a narrow passage to the store room (room 39). Above cooking platform in west wall is a small square recess. Lower center of the east wall is a drain to the street outside. Below the drain in the floor there is a tiled indentation that survives in the upper north and south edges but is filled in with earth. Remains of multicolored plaster on north wall above the latrine and is on the northwest corner.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1, 117-119
column14: The latrine (sheet 1848) to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform with no recesses. Surface does not survive but obscured by litchon but underneath appears to be tiled. Surface slopes towards southwest corner. Exterior edges are restored. Traces of plaster remain in southwest corner between surface of platform and the wall. Plaster survives in southwest corner above platform. Small square recess in west wall above the platform. Possible rubble base of rim on eastern lip.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1, 117-119
column14: cooking platform (sheet 1847) to the southwest.
column21: Tiled latrine in the northeast corner. Drain is obscured by soil and tile survives only along the west side. To the south are foundations of a wall, perhaps a partition that separated it from the rest of the room. There are holes in the in fill of the latrine opening down into the drain below. Stone support in the southeast of the latrine. Large recess for seat along the east wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1, 117-119
column14: kitchen (room 38)
column21: Located in the southeastern corner of the upper part of the house (entrance 25) and behind the triclinium (room 41) is the storeroom. One enters the storeroom from the north through the kitchen (room 38) via a small corridor. The room is roughly rectangular on an east west axis. On the eastern wall is a window. Today as you enter the storeroom there seems to have been something embedded in the floor that has been removed. Likewise, in the front of the northwest wall are two similar areas in the floor. It is uncertain whether any of these constitutes the cistern. If the room were decorated in antiquity, nothing remains today.

column14: 24 Peristyle to east
column21: Large dining room opening east to peristyle (24).  The colonnade was enclosed in final phase to form an anteroom.  Floor does not survive; however, plaster survives on north, east, south, west walls with red panels above white lower register in southeast corner.  On west wall there is red background with white trim.

Dining room 41 is located on the northeast side of atrium (24).  One enters from the atrium by way of a large doorway.  The room is roughly rectangular on an east-west axis.  In the south corner is a doorway leading into room 42.  The room was elaborately decorated in antiquity, although little remains today.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Room 14 garden to westRoom 11 to north
column15: Room 14 garden to westRoom 11 to north
column21: Rectangular room with east/west axis. Doorway in center of west wall opens to small garden(room 14) Doorway at west end of north wall to 11. Painting survives in northeast corner along east and south wall. Red lower register, yellow above with a border. Indeterminate yellow decoration in lower register. Fiorelli reports painting of Hercules of which no trace remains. Identification as dining room based on size, location in respect to garden and decoration.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Room 8 garden to the southShop to the east
column15: Room 8 garden to the southShop to the east
column21: Large entrance to large rectangular dining room. Minimal signs of painting on walls, with notes saying 4th style. Traces remain of red painting in southwest corner with stencil work. Traces of red paint remain on east and north walls. Dining room overlooks the garden with a shell niche in the south wall and statue base in shape of an aedicula shrine along the east wall of the garden, faced with white marble and painted inside with red, yellow and blue with red stencil design on top.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Room 4 to the west
column21: Rectangular room east/west axis. West wall to storeroom (room 4) does not survive, traces of undecorated plaster along north wall with small arched recess high in the center of the wall (for lamp?). Latrine in northeast corner (1856). Inserted into wall behind latrine at the north end of the east wall is a terracotta pipe draining from floor above. Cooking platform (1855) in southeast corner separated from latrine by poorly preserved course of partition wall. In the southwest corner of room, there is a pile of debris, possible poorly preserved platform. Traces of undecorated plaster on south wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Latrine (1856) to the north
column21: Poorly preserved rectangular cooking platform. Structure and surface completely corroded. No discernible attributes along the north edge is a poorly preserved partition wall separating platform from latrine to the north.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Platform (1855) to the south
column21: Rectangular area divided from cooking platform (1855) by poorly preserved partition wall. Along the east wall is a recess for a seat. At north end of east wall is a semicircular recess with a terracotta drain from floor above. Any other attributes of the latrine are obscured by debris. Small indentation into eastern end of north wall above latrine with plaster lining of indeterminate meaning.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.
column14: Kitchen (room 5) to the east.Atrium (room 2) to the south
column15: Kitchen (room 5) to the east.Atrium (room 2) to the south
column21: Narrow rectangular storeroom, north/south axis with doorway, south to atrium (room 2) and east to kitchen (room 5) north end of west wall there is a plaster lined doorway from an earlier phase that has subsequently been infilled. The lower course of the infilled doorway in north east corner has collapsed, creating "a recess" perhaps supporting a seat/wooden table (?) but is so poorly preserved, cannot be defined. East wall which separates storeroom from kitchen does not survive.

column14: Passageway to south leads to garden (room 10)Room 8 to the south
column15: Passageway to south leads to garden (room 10)Room 8 to the south
column21: Rectangular room with north/south axis with doorway in south wall, leading to south passageway in room 10. In center of floor, is a marble tile insert with diamond patters around, where the klina would be placed. No other flooring extent. Plaster survives on the north, east, west and south walls. White lower register with red panels above with borders; 3rd style. Identification as dining room based on floor decoration, wall decoration and size.

column14: Contiguous to hallway (room 10)
column21: Located at back of the house in the east corner. Is approached from small hallway from tablinum. In the eastern corner of kitchen is a cooking platform ( 1860 ). The map for Eschebach seems to indicate a platform extending along the south wall. Today that space is filled by a solid wall, rising to a great height. PPM map is correct as seen. However, neither Eschebach or PPM show a platform along the north wall that appears today. The surface of the platform on east corner seems to have been of terracotta.

column14: None
column21: It is located along the southeast wall. Surface was covered with tile in antiquity. As seen today, the platform continues the northeast wall in a construction not found in Eschebach or PPM.

column14: Room 4 to the west.
column21: Square garden opening to the west (room 4). Jashemski lararium painting and masonry alter in the north wall and a latrine in the southeast corner, that does not survive, although there is a rectangular slab against the center of the north wall. There is a terracotta drain pipe imbedded in the wall of the southeast corner. Subsidence against the corner of the east of of the garden. Traces of plaster on north, south, and east walls with no traces of decoration. Against the east wall there are three holes for supports for the second floor. Identification as a dining garden is based on use of structure as a whole for food and drink.

column14: Kitchen (room 2) to the northeast.
column21: One enters the salesroom from the street from the southwest. The sales room is rectangular in shape with a southwest-northeast axis. To the right was imbedded a large dolium. Eschebach indicated when excavated the room also contained a counter. In the northeast corner is an entrance to the kitchen, to the southeast of which is the entrance to the room behind. If decorated in antiquity nothing remains.

column14: Counter no longer in extant (Sheet 1864).
column21: Dolium is embedded in floor of sales room (room 1) just to the right of the entrance.

column14: None
column21: Eschebach, 1993, 28. Fiorelli, 66.

column14: None
column21: Entrance is located in northwest corner of salesroom, room 1. Immediately upon entering room on southeast wall is the cooking platform (1866). If decorated in antiquity, nothing exists. Room itself is rectangular in shape, narrow on southwest/northeast axis.

column14: None
column21: Is located along southeast wall of kitchen, surface seems to have been of terracotta. As extent today, the platform seems to have been constructed with a rectangular opening, which would allow fire to go underneath the pot although it is uncertain whether this was its original shape or not.

column14: (2) Mill Oven Room to east.
column21: Rectangular sales room with east/west axis. Threshold with step to Via Stabia. Threshold preserves placing for sliding door. Doorway at north end with low threshold to mill oven room (2) to east. The blocked doorways in south wall from earlier phase. Traces of plaster survive in the base in north wall and south wall. Meta (1868) of small mill in center of room, possibly not in situ.
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column14: None
column21: Small mill meta, possibly not in situ. At the apex of the meta is a small circular hole lined with lead to support spindle of the catillus.
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column14: (2) - Mill oven room to north.
column21: Rectangular room with east/west axis with blocked doorway opening to the west to the Via Stabia. Three blocked doorways in north wall to room (1) to the north from earlier phase. In the north west and southwest corner there are plaster couch niches with the southwest corner one filled in. In cent of west wall there is a small pile of rubble, tiles and against the wall there is opus signinum preserved between the wall and rubble. In the center of the south wall is a recent plastered pilaster. Along south wall plaster survives with red below and white above. In center of western half of room are two masonry supports (1871) for preparation platform. In center of south wall is a high, shallow arched plaster lined lararium with smaller, poorly preserved recesses with collapse. In center of south wall there are niches for three sets of shelves. High in south wall are the holes for joists above. In center of eastern half of room is kneading basin [1870]. In the east end of north wall, doorway opens to mill oven room (2). North end of east wall is a plaster passthrough to oven to east.
column53: Missing start time. Find end time of 1856.
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column14: 1871 - Masonry supports  to west.
column21: Circular kneading basin with holes on the east/west axis. Base is obscured. [Check what stone this is made of?]
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column14: 1870 - Kneading basin to east

column14: Room 3 to south. Room 1 to west. Room 6 to east. Room 5 to southeast.

column21: One enters the mill-oven room (2) through room (1) on SW part of the room. As one enters, on the right (to the south) no longer extant was a low platform and next to it, in the south corner was a small dolium (2 negative feature sheets). The the left (N) of the entrance no longer extant was a platform. Along southeast wall is the oven. Between the dolium and the oven was the entrance to the preparation room (3). East of the oven was the entrance to room 5, probably a preparation room or store room. Along the northeast wall was the entrance to room 6, probably a stall/stable. In the corner of the room were stars to the upper floor. In the middle of the room were arranged 4 mills, two flanked the opening into the stables. To the west of the mill [1874-2] was a cistern. Today none of the mills exist in situ, only portions of the mill foundations exist reconstructed. Portions of four catilli and one meta lie scattered in the room. On the north wall, to the west of the stairs is the entrance to room (7).  If the mill room were decorated in antiquity, none exists today. In the northwest corner of the room is the back portion of the oven for room (11). The four mill installations are all surrounded by a stone floor most of which is extant.
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column21: In the southeast part of room 2 is the oven.  It is the typical bee hive oven enclosed in brick.  The oven itself is preceded by an arched opening below which is an arched niche for the fuel or ashes.  To the left and right of the oven opening are passthroughs to the east (room 5) and west (room 3) .  Extending out on the front of the southwest of the oven opening is a rectangular brick pier.
column70: Bakery and Shops of D. Iunius Proculus

column14: Mill room (Room 2) is to the northwest.
column15: Mill room (Room 2) is to the northwest.
column21: Room 5 is located in the east corner of the bakery.  One enters into an anteroom from the north.  At the end of the outer room appears to have been stairs. Room 5 itself has two entrances one at the north end and one at the south end of the anteroom.  Room is roughly rectangular on a north-south axis.  If the room was decorated in antiquity it is no longer extant.  There appears to have been a low wall running east-west that divides the room in half.  In the southeast corner of the room was embedded an amphora, usage unknown.

column15: Contiguous to mill oven room (Room 2) to southeast.
column21: A long rectangular room. Along northeast back wall, evidence of rafters, possibly for grain storage.  In center of room is a water feature- a basin to water donkeys.  Southwest-northeast access.  This analysis does not agree with Fiorelli or Eschebach that is it a drying room.  No plaster decoration or floor remains.  Northwest end of room is obscured by debris.  Is contiguous to mill oven room.

column14: Room 8 - Sales Room to east.
column21: Square room opening to north and west on the Via Del'Abbondonza and the Via Stabia.  Threshold preserves placing for sliding doors on both north and east thresholds.  Doorway at north end of east wall opens to sales room (8).  Plaster survives on north, east and south walls.  Red trim with white background and red lower register survives in southwest corner.  In corner of south wall are two rectangular lararia with preserved plaster and paint.  Lower lararium, the rear is decorated with with red marks in a diagonal pattern on white background and concave in shape.  Upper lararium is arched with traces of red but background is not visible-similar to lararium below (?).

column21: Rectangular room opening north to the Via Del'Abbondanza.  Threshold with step to street outside.  Threshold preserves indentation for sliding door to close off shop from street.  In the north end of west wall there is a doorway and threshold to sales room (9).  In west end of south wall is a doorway and step down to room 10 and eastern end of south wall is doorway and threshold to room 7 at lower level.  At southern end of eastern wall there are two terracotta pipes inserted in wall at base.  High in the southern wall are two recesses for floor joists for floor above that are contiguous with the base of the doorway in floor above.  Possible small plastered window to east of this doorway below this doorway is a circular hole extending through wall to room 7.  Eschebach refers to two sunken dolia used to store grain no longer extant.  Plaster on north, south and east walls remain with no trace of decoration.

No counters or mills visible. No lapilli on floor nor decorations on wall.  Small amount of painted plaster found on northwest wall.

High on north wall are holes for joists above.  At the southern end of the east wall is a circular opening through the wall to room 7.  Partially burned catillus in southeast corner.

Round back of beehive enclosure is apparent from room 2.

Evidence of marble door sill.  Door on east corner leading to oven room (11).

column21: One enters the storeroom (7) from room 8 to the northwest corner.  Room is rectangular on a northeast-southwest axis.  In the south wall there is a wide doorway leading into mill room (2).  Sales room (8) to the northwest is at a higher level than the storeroom (7), therefore there must have been wooden steps (not extant) to allow passage.  In the north corner of the room are the remains of a catillus (?).  If the room was decorated in antiquity, nothing remains.  On the southeast wall to the northeast of the entrance into room 2 was apparently a window--not shown on the maps.  There remains on the northeast side of the window some decorative stucco that had been covered in AD 79.

column14: None
column21: Large east opening onto rectangular room with a door in the south wall into room (11).  On west wall, extensive nice partially plastered.  We are identifying this as a dining room because its view of the atrium and elegant table.  Material above niche is being prepared for repainting (striations on existing plaster).

column14: 2 atrium to north with elegant marble table
column15: 2 atrium to north with elegant marble table
column21: Rectangular room opening north to atrium (2) with marble threshold with placing for door.  Square window high in east wall.  Plaster survives on east and south walls with red lower register with lines for border; color cannot be determined.  Flooring survives in southern end of room.  No decoration survives.  Cistern survives in northeast corner.  Northwest corner wall only preserved at lower course.  Jashemski, following Propelli, divides this room into two.  The southern half is a triclinium with northern half as a small garden.  Beyond evidence of cistern and window looking in cannot see any evidence of garden in northern portion of room.  Eschebach refers to it as an open triclinium.  Soprano refers to it as a wooden or other triclinium.

column14: 4 storeroom to west
column21: It is located in the northeast corner of the house.  One enters the kitchen through a narrow doorway I n the southwest corner of the room.  The room is oriented on a roughly north-south axis and is roughly rectangular.  Along the eastern side of the room, extending to the northeast corner, is a tall cooking platform.  In the northwest corner of the room is an unknown feature: whether a latrine or not is indeterminate (not mentioned by Fiorelli or Eschebach).  In the southeast corner are the remains of what may have been a preparation platform.  High up on the wall is a small window looking onto storeroom 4.  Room was decorated in antiquity, but little remains today.

column21: On the east wall, extending into the northeast corner, is a cooking platform, rectangular in shape.

column14: Room 2 to the southwest
column21: Large rectangular room with opening to north onto Via Del Abbondanza with threshold with indentations for door to close up shop.  In eastern corner of south wall is an opening into Room 2.  On the southwest corner are stairs leading up to the second floor mezzanine.  Under the stairs was a latrine based on location and previous description.  In the northeastern corner is an L-shaped counter.  Traces of wall painting with yellow and red are on the east wall and in the northeast corner.  On the eastern and western walls are holes for joists or beams.  Above these holes are two horizontal built-in rectangular structures for an unknown function.  On the west and south walls plaster remains with no trace of painting.  On the north wall above the entrance is a small rectangular hole which could have functioned as a window.

column14: Latrine (1898) to the southeast.
column21: L-shaped counter with each arm of equal length facing the Via Del Abbondanza to the north.  There is a tile surface.  Two imbedded dolia are on the interior arm.  The containers are filled with lapilli.  No traces of the terracotta vessels survive.  At the southern end of the counter are two masonry supports for a hearth in from of which (to the south) is a large masonry plastered step.

column14: Counter feature (1897) is to the northeast.
column16: Counter feature (1897) is to the northeast.
column21: There is a narrow latrine underneath the stairs along the south/southwest cornered shop.  It is separated from the rest of the shop by a partitioned wall along the northern edge of the latrine.  The drain of the latrine is obscured by earth.  On the northern edge there is a recess for a toilet seat. At the same height of the stairs, the latrine is inserted in the southwest corner.  However, other features are obscured by earth.  On the west wall above the latrine are traces of plaster and two holes for supporting stair (?).

column14: Atrium (room 2) to the south
column21: Room 14 is a square room with masonry tile stairs along the east, north and west walls to the floor above.  It had plastered walls; however there are no traces of decoration.  There is molding with ionic volutes on the stairs to the north - curved plaster (?) in final phase.  Below the stairs in the northeast corner is an arched storage area (1902) in which 16 ceramic vessels with found, some of which had evidence of heaving been used for cooking.  In the northwest corner below the stairs is an arched plastered recess containing a preparation platform (1900).  At the northern end of the western wall, to the immediate south of the preparation platform (1900) is an arched plastered lararium niche (1901).  In the corner between the lararium and the platform is a small square step.  The room was used to store and reheat food brought form the kitchen prior to serving.

column14: The lararium (1901) is to the southwest.  The storage area (1902)  is to the east.
column16: The lararium (1901) is to the southwest.  The storage area (1902)  is to the east.
column21: Rectangular masonry platform in arched recess below the stairs.  There is no recess storage.  The platform is located in the northwestern corner of the room. It has a plastered surface.  There is a plastered rim along the north, east and west sides and down the middle of the platform dividing the preparation area into two.  The eastern most half is flat plaster.  In the western most half there is an indentation in the middle of the preparation area, possibly original.  In front of the preparation platform (to the south) there is a low square platform in the southwest edge of the platform ste(?).

column14: Preparation platform (1900) to the northeast.  Storage area (1902) to the east.
column16: Preparation platform (1900) to the northeast.  Storage area (1902) to the east.
column21: There is an arched plastered lararium niche in the northwestern corner of room 14.  There are no traces of any decoration.  In front of the lararium, to the north, is a low, square platform or step.  The lararium is low in the wall.

column14: The preparation platform (1900) is to the west.  The lararium (1901) is to the west.
column16: The preparation platform (1900) is to the west.  The lararium (1901) is to the west.
column21: The arched recessed storage area is below the stairs in the northeast corner of the room.   Allison records the find of 16 ceramic vessels, some of which preserved traces of burning having been used for cooking.

column14: Peristyle (room 15) is to the southwest.
column21: The dining room opens to the southwestern corner of the peristyle (15).  In the middle of the southern wall is a window opening onto room 11.  On either end of the threshold entrance are rectangular holes for doors on rectangular marble.  The doorway was partially blocked in its final phase.  The walls are painted with a red lower register.  Above this are small rectangular panes (with a green background) and framed with black feston and poutti-like vertical panes.  On the top of the panels runs a narrow ornamental freeze.  Above this is a larger frieze running around the room depicting centaurs chasing maidens.  On the west wall the central panel represents Perseus holding the head of Medusa and sitting next to Andromeda.  The other two central panels are not well preserved.  On the southeast wall a small panel represents a building with a marine landscape.  Above the red frieze at the top are large panels with traces of architecture mostly destroyed.

column14: Peristyle (room 15) to the northwest.  Dining hall (room 21) to the north.  There corridor is to the southwest,
column15: Peristyle (room 15) to the northwest.  Dining hall (room 21) to the north.  There corridor is to the southwest,
column21: This is a square room with a wide doorway opening west to peristyle (room 15).  There is a doorway at the west end of the north wall leading to the dining hall (room 21).  There is a tunnel into the room at the south end of the west wall from corridor.  Fourth style painting with extant mythological scenes in north and south walls (check identity of scenes).  The (?) in the east wall does not survive.  There is a red over register, which is yellow above.  The floor is of marble chips without decoration.
column53: Second video shot of 1904.  Original feature assignment canceled.

column14: Peristyle (room 15) is to the south.
column21: Room 6 is a large dining room on a roughly north-south axis.  In the southwest corner is an entrance to the andron (room 7).  The major entrance, which is open to almost its fullest extent, looks to the south to the peristyle (room 15).  Both entrances are capable of being closed off.  The room had a very high ceiling and in antiquity was elaborately decorated in the fourth style.  The paintings have black framing with decorative flowers framing a large alternating yellow and red rectangular area in the center of which was a smallish animal; in one case a panther, the other a bird.  The other animals are too damaged to identify completely.  High up on each wall was a stucco cornice.  The floor seems to have been beaten cement.

column14: Peristyle (room 15) is to the east.  Hallway (room 20) is to the south.
column15: Pristyle (room 15) is to the east.  Hallway (room 20) is to the south.
column21: This rectangular dining room opens to the west to the peristyle corridor (room 15).  The doorway in the south wall opens to a hallway (room 20).  There is a black and white diamond patterned mosaic floor with stone inserts.  There is fourth style painting with a black lower register with plants interspersed with architectural decoration. There are red panels above.  Mythological scenes are on the northeast and south sides of the room.  (Check the myths depicted.  The south scene shows a bull with an unidentified female figure.  The east wall shows two figures; left is a female figure pointing to a stooped figure on the right.  The north wall shows four figures.)

column14: Peristyle (room 15) is to the southwest.  Hallway (room 20) is to the northwest.
column15: Peristyle (room 15) is to the southwest.  Hallway (room 20) is to the northwest.
column21: Room 21, a dining hall, is a large room, roughly rectangular, on a northeast-southwest axis.  The large entrance, which goes most of its width, looks to the southwest onto the peristyle (room 15).  In the northwest corner of the room is a doorway leading into the hallway (room 20).  Under the floor of this room excavators discovered remains of republican rooms with mosaics.  The room was elaborately painted in the fourth style in antiquity.  The ceiling appears to have been stuccoed and decorated in antiquity, fragments of which have been restored.  The wall painting was done in black, red and gold in large panels of which there were various still life motifs, including fish.  The floor seems to have been of beaten cement.

column21: Wooden triclinium in Peristyle garden. Jashemski 47 records the findings of the imprint of a wooden triclinium in the center of the garden. Occupies an area of 1.74 x 2.69m.

column14: None
column21: One enters the room from the southeast. The room is roughly rectangular with a southeast northwest axis. Along the north and east wall is an L shaped cooking platform. Below the platform on the north wall are two semi circular niches. In the southwest corner along the west and south walls is a water feature. If the room was decorated in antiquity none exist today. Along the north wall appears evidence of vaulting of the room.

column14: water feature (sheet 1912) to the south.
column21: Large L-shaped masonry cooking platform with two arched brick built storage recesses below. It has a tiled surface with a tiled lip constructed out of roof tiles along the junction of the platform on the north, east and west walls.- extant on the west and northeast corner.

column14: 1911  cooking platform to north
column21: Semicircular plastered surface partially preserved, with a terracotta drain at an angle pointing toward the south.  According to Ling, it drains into room 56 to the south where he locates a latrine.  The structure itself consists of rubble.  It is in the southwest corner of the room.

column14: 6L to west4L to north
column21: One enters the oven room, a small, rectangular room, through a low arched entry on the northwest wall.  The room is barrel vaulted.  A stuccoed preparation platform is located on the east wall.  The oven is on the northeast wall.  The room was plastered in antiquity, but little remains.  There are two terracotta pipes above the chamber of the beehive oven in the ceiling of room 4 that allowed the circulation of heat to the bath suite above.

column14: None
column21: Beehive oven is on northeast wall of oven room.  A small post-and-lintel niche is underneath.  The lintel before the oven is good-sized.  It is a brick arch that's been interrupted.  Middle section is no longer extant.  Usable space on either side of oven (north and east sides) but no passthrough.  Post-and-lintel entrance.

column21: Barrel vaulted room with entrance from room (24) to the west.  Another doorway leads to oven room (5L) to the southwest with another small arched doorway leading to room (4L) to east, with access to the back of the oven.  Above the eastern wall is a blocked up light well.  Plaster survives on the vaulted ceiling with no decoration extant.  I n the south corner is the remains of a preparation platform and in the center of the northeast half of the room are two masonry supports for a cooking platform.  In the north corner of the room is a semicircular access to (2L).

column14: 3L preparation room to south
column21: One enters the room from the southwest.  The room is roughly rectangular on a southwest/northeast axis.  Along the northwest wall is a low platform that extends the full length of the wall.  The room is vaulted on a northwest/southeast axis.  In this room near the low platform along the northwest wall near the entrance was found the chest with the silver serving pieces.  There appears to have been an entrance or window along the southern wall into the preparation room (3L)…  If the room was decorated in antiquity, nothing remains.  In the top of the north wall was a light well.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature.Wooden chest, 0.8 x 1.5 m.  The bottom layer contained silver services; the upper layer contained jewelry and coins.

column14: Stairs in the north wall access corridor 55 above
column15: Stairs in the north wall access corridor 55 above
column21: Rectangular garden accessed by stairs in northeast corner down from corridor 55.  Masonry cutter runs from the southeast corner to the east.  Opus signinum floor (?) inserted into south wall above the gutter with square recess at east end.  Function is unclear.  Below there is a square recess with a terracotta drain above.  The opus signinum floor is perhaps an insert during reconstruction of the south wall.  Along the west wall there are rectangular holes: function is unclear.  High in the south wall there are sporadic holes (for a mezzanine?).  In the north wall there are rectangular holes.  Some of the holes appear to be manmade; others may be collapse.Maiuri found circular holes throughout the garden, each of which contained a root cavity.  Jashemski identifies this as a vegetable garden.  Weeding hooks and an iron brazier were found in the subterranean storerooms.  The garden is separated from a lower area to the east by a low wall.  The lower area is called a "heliocaminus" by Maiuri, arranged around a square, shallow plaster basin.  O n the southwest corner of the basin is a circular masonry platform.  To the north of the basin is the doorway to the subterranean storerooms.  No traces of decoration survive.  It is not clear if the bath suite in the floor above extended over the lower area of the garden.

column14: None
column21: Lies in the rustic quarter at the end of the long hallway.  The room is entered from the west.  There is a second entrance to the room from the northwest of the first entrance.  The room is roughly square and has a window high up on the eastern wall.  Room was decorated simply with lower area of red paint and an upper area of white.  The floor seems to be simple beaten cement.

column14: 49 to north
column21: Rectangular room, east-west axis.  Slanted room above visible on the west wall.  Undecorated plaster on the north, west and south walls.  Holes for shelves along the wall.  Narrow low doorway in the west end of the north wall.  Opens to 49 to the north.  Floor is not preserved but appears to be at a lower level than that of 49.  I n the southwest is a cooking platform (1924).  At the eastern end of the north wall is a small plastered window opening north to 49 opposite which, on the eastern end of south wall, is a small plaster-lined lararium niche.  The kitchen area is separated from the rectangular room to the east by a partition wall of which only the lower course survives, but does not seem to have reached ceiling height as it is below the small window and the lararium.  The eastern area consists of a rectangular room on a north-south axis with undecorated plaster on the south and west walls and a door way at the eastern end of the north wall opening to 49 to the north.  In the center of the west wall there are poorly preserved traces of a painting in red depicting a pair of figures as well as decorative elements but it is not possible to determine the content of the scene.  The room is now used as a storeroom by the custodi.  It contains fragments of amphora and fragments of architectural decoration, other pottery and a terracotta puteal that have been brought in from elsewhere.

column14: Corridor to west
column21: Square room with doorway to west.  Square window in center of west wall above.  Square window opposite, high in east wall with opening to street outside.  Holes for joists for floor above high in east wall.  Traces of undecorated plaster on north, south, east, west walls.  Amphorae have been placed in room by custodian, along with architectural fragments.  High in west wall are two rectangular holes for floor above, and threshold above for second story.

column14: 1925  Lararium to the east
column21: It's a masonry cooking platform in the southwest corner of the room.  Only the corner is preserved.  There is a plaster lip preserved at the junction of the wall and platform but the remainder of the surface is too poorly preserved to determine its character.  To the east of the platform are three holes in the wall of indeterminate function, perhaps caused by the destruction of the platform.

column14: 1924  cooking platform to west
column21: Small arched plaster-lined lararium niche.  No traces of decoration.  Is on eastern end of south wall.

column14: Corridor to west
column21: Square room with doorway in west wall.  In west wall above doorway is a rectangular window into corridor, above which are holes for joists for floor above; above that is a doorway in second story.  In east wall is a square window opening to street outside and above that are holes for joists for floor above.  At northern end of east wall is a small rectangular recess of indeterminate age and function opening to street.  On north, south, east, west walls is undecorated plaster.  Room is identical to room 40 to south.

column14: None
column21: Room 23, an oven room, is located I n the rustic quarters.  One enters through a door on the southeastern wall.  The floor level of the room is lower than that of the outside.  The room is roughly rectangular on a southeast-northwest axis.  In the east corner of the room is an oven.  The room was simply decorated in red.  The floor seems to be of beaten cement.  Above the entrance to the room, as reconstructed, is a large window.

column14: None
column21: The oven is in the eastern corner of the room made of broken tile and cement.  The part that lies into the room is semicircular; as extant the cooking area inside the oven is large at the bottom and tapers as it goes up so that the hole at the top is smaller than the floor area.  The surface was made of plaster, as reconstructed.

column14: Corridor to westStreet to east
column15: Corridor to westStreet to east
column21: Square room with a doorway in west wall to corridor.  Above doorway in center of west wall is a rectangular window.  I n center of east wall is a doorway to street outside.  Above doorway is a rectangular window to street, and above that are holes for joists for floor above.  On either side of doorway are small rectangular holes opening to street of indeterminate date and function.  East, south and west walls have undecorated plaster.  The position in respect to rooms 39, 40, 41, similarity to rooms and use of this area of house for food and drink category suggest a storeroom; however, the doorway in east wall to street outside has been expressed as a concern.

column21: Large rectangular courtyard separated from covered portico (33) to the north and west by rectangular masonry pillars.  In the east wall there is a wide doorway to the street that is blocked with volcanic debris that preserves carbonized wood (from a door within the fill).  Two doorways in south wall, both with thresholds and placings for doors.  There are two rectangular windows in the south wall of which there are holes for joists.  The west doorway into the colonnade has been partially filled in in final phase with doorway and window above in the second story.  I n the north wall there is the threshold for doorway(s) and window(s) I n the floor above.  I n the northwest corner there is a semicircular plaster basin in the floor: trough (?).  From the basin a terracotta drain runs southwest at floor level into the base of the wall.  I n the southeast corner there is a small oven (1931) around which 43 amphorae (1932) were found.  Remains of a cart were found in this room and a restored cart is now preserved here.

column14: 43 amphorae (1932) were found around it.
column21: Room: courtyardSmall, semicircular oven, tile base opening to the north.  Located in southeast corner of the room.  The upper courses are restored and the superstructure is not preserved.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature.Room: courtyard43 amphorae
