column14: Atrium (room 2) to the northwest.  Room 9 to the southeast.
column15: Atrium (room 2) to the northwest.  Room 9 to the southeast.
column21: The square dining tablinum opens to the northwest off the four-columned atrium (room 2).  The entrance runs the full extent of the northwest wall.  In the middle of the back (southeast) wall a large window looks onto space 10 and a small courtyard behind (room 9).  If the room was decorated in antiquity, nothing remains but fragments of plaster on the southwest wall.

column14: Peristyle garden (room 9) is to the west.
column15: Peristyle garden (room 9) is to the west.
column21: It is a square room with a doorway with rough hewn threshold facing peristyle garden (room 9) to the west.  Only the lower courses of all walls survive with no traces of decoration.  No visible flooring.

column14: Room 13 is to the east.   The courtyard (room 11) is to the north.
column15: Room 13 is to the east.   The courtyard (room 11) is to the north.
column21: The room is entered from the northwest through the doorway leading down by four steps to the courtyard (room 11).  The door opens into a vaulted, small anteroom, which gives access into the dining room to the west and to the garden to the south.  At the back of this long rectangular room is a masonry triclinium to the west.  To the northwest of the entrance is a built-in cooking platform with an oven below.  Along the southern wall there are five rectangular horizontal windows looking onto the garden; nine small opening high along the north wall.  The south and west walls were decorated with a large, red lower register and yellow panels above on the south wall.  Three unequally spaced elements are built into the wall.  They may have been used as hooks, but their function remains uncertain.  In the middle of the northern wall two smaller windows open into a bedroom of the adjoining house.

column14: Garden (room 18) is to the east.
column21: The masonry triclinium is room 17.  It takes up the entire southern part of the room.  The lectus sumus is along the eastern wall.  The lectus medium is along the southern wall.  The lectus imus is along the western wall.  In the middle, among the three lectii, is a cylindrical shaped masonry table.  On the inside of the lecti, surrounding the table, is a low platform.  The northern ends of the lectus imus and sumus are defined by a bench that slopes toward the east and west walls respectively.   To the north of these sloping walls are L-shaped benches.  The branch of the benches, parallel and abutting the walls, are at the level of the back of the lecti.  The benches that are perpendicular to the walls are at a level below that of the front of the lecti.  At the northern end of the low bench on the western wall is a large preparation platform.  The low bench parallel to the east wall has, at floor level, a drain opening leading to the garden (room 18).  The floor of the room in this area seems to slope slightly toward the drain.  The facades of the perpendicular platform, lecti, table and benches are elaborately painted in vegetation, birds and other shrubs.  The walls on the east, south and west walls are likewise painted in red but without figural motifs.  The red paint extends up 82 centimeters above the bench.  Above that the paint seems to have been yellow or gold.  As reconstructed the wall on the eastern side rises 134 centimeters from the top of the bench.  There are two pillars rising higher to support the ceiling thereby creating two large rectangular windows along the eastern wall of the triclinium. The floor seems to be cocciopesto.

column14: None
column15: The triclinium (room 17) is to the east.
column21: The cooking platform in room 17 lies just to the west of the entrance to the room.  It is inserted back into the wall.  It is composed of a platform, the surface of which is plaster with a lip in the front.  The lip is composed of two layers of terracotta.  Beneath the platform is a semicircular niche which runs the full depth at the platform itself.  The ceiling of the inserted cooking platform is rather high and vaulted.  In antiquity the east, north and west walls were plastered and painted, perhaps red.

column14: The loggia (room 17) is to the north.
column15: The loggia (room 17) is to the north.
column21: The large square garden is surrounded by the cryptoporticus on the north, east, west and south.  Della Corte reports that this was used for cabbages and leeks.  The garden is accessed by six steps down from the loggia (room 17) in the northeast corner.  Along the north wall above the arches of the cryptoporticus there are terracotta drain holes from the floor level of the loggia (room 17), and rectangular holes for an awning or other function.  Along the east and west sides, in the northwest corner and in the north center, the ground level of the garden has subsided several feet to the level of the cryptoporticus below.

column14: The cryptoporticus is built on the north, east and west sides of the garden (room 18).
column15: The cryptoporticus is built on the north, east and west sides of the garden (room 18).
column21: There is a subterranean passageway on the north, east, and west sides of the garden (room 18).  WEST ARM - The west arm is on a north/south axis.  The doorway is in the southeast corner (from room 27) with a step and tile ramp leading down to the lower floor level of the cryptoporticus.  High in the south wall is an opening to the south.  The small rectangular area to the west of the ramp (now filled with boxes of finds and amphorae) is separated from the rest of the cryptoporticus to the north by a partition wall of which the lower course survives.  It has white plaster with red geometric decorations.  High in the east wall are five large arched windows to the garden.  Traces of second style painting survive with panels in the lower register, architectural detail above, and scenes of figures in comat above that - from the Iliad.(?)  Paintings have been removed from the walls and are now in the Naples Museum, although fragments of the figure scenes are in the center of the west wall.  Traces of molded relief survives on the ceiling on the northeast corner.  This arm is separated from the north arm by a rough hewn and inserted doorway.NORTH ARM - The north arm is rectangular and on an east/west axis.  Plaster relief decoration survives intermittently along the ceiling.  In the center of the north wall is an arch painted alcove with relief decoration and rectangular niche in the north.  Second style painting survives on the southern and northeastern walls, the best preserved being that on the northeastern wall.  Panels with architectural elements above with portrait masks and scenes with figures above.  In the northeastern corner there is a doorway to the stairs to the peristyle garden above.  At the western end of the southern wall four circular holes have been inserted into the plaster and are of uncertain use.  High in the southern wall are five arched windows that provide access to the garden above.  At the eastern end there is a large rectangular doorway opening to the bath suite.  EAST ARM - The east arm is divided into two by the insertion of a rough hewn wall and doorway.  There are traces of plaster relief decoration on the ceiling and poorly preserved second style painting on the west wall.  In the eastern wall from north to south there is a rectangular doorway to the calidarium of the baths.  There are two round plastered windows opening to the bath suite and a doorway in southeast corner into the baths.  The doorway in the southwest corner opens to the south.  High in the west wall there are four arched windows opening to the garden.

column14: Room 9 to the north
column21: The kitchen is located in the eastern part of the structure.  The room is entered through a small door from the northwest.  The room is rectangular in shape.  It is on a northeast/southwest axis.  If the room was decorated in antiquity, non exists today.  In the southeast corner is a cooking platform.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform is located in the southeast corner of the room.  It is poorly preserved today, but seems to have been rectangular.  The height is indeterminate.

column14: None
column21: Masonry biclinium in northwest corner of garden.  The structure is poorly preserved.  Arched storage recess below north couch, partially obscured by debris.  Above the couch, in the west corner, is a square plastered lararium niche and to the southeast of the couches Mau has a pool.

column14: None
column21: Feature: nicheShallow plastered niche in northwest corner of room 6.  Red plaster survives in eastern half.  The height of the niche makes its use for a dining couch uncertain.

column14: (room 13) to the northwest. (Room 12) to the southwest.
column15: (room 13) to the northwest. (Room 12) to the southwest.
column21: Dining room lies in the southeast part of the house. It is entered from the anteroom (room 13) to the northwest. On the southeast wall is a long rectangular opening high up in the wall and one small ground level opening to the right. On the far end of the southwest wall in the entrance to the cubiculum (room 12). The black and white mosaic floor is divided into two sections which are separated by a band. The band is decorated in a scroll. The southeast portion of the mosaic is a plain white mosaic of tesserae. The northeast section of the mosaic is decorated with a grid of 3x3 square panels. The panels are ornamented with black and white geometric designs. The panels as a group are framed by one strand guilloche. The wall panels are divided into two sections along the lines of the mosaic sectioned divisions. The northeast and southeast sections are divided by long rectangular bands of different colors and widths. The southwest and southeast walls are decorated with three large red panels supported by a large band ornamented with a yellow structure that looks like a podium. The other half of the dining room is decorated with figurative panels containing life size figures. In the northwest wall is partly destroyed female figure sitting on a low support and wearing a long robe. In her right hand she is holding an unidentified object. In northeast wall is left only a male figure dressed in a white mantle. He is sitting on a low based support. He is looking right but at what is no longer discernible. In southeast wall represents to large elephants standing on either side of an alter. On the right elephant, on its back are two small figures holding indiscernible objects. This elephant is ornamented with a garland around its neck.

column14: (Room 8) to the northwest. (Room 14) to the southwest.
column15: (Room 8) to the northwest. (Room 14) to the southwest.
column21: Roughly square room with doorway in north end of the west wall to Room 8. Rectangular masonry cooking platform (sheet 1948) in the northeast corner extending on the east wall. In the center of the east wall is a partially preserved partition wall separating the latrine (sheet 1949) in the southeast corner from the rest of the room. Traces of undecorated plaster survive on the north wall.

column14: Latrine (sheet 1949) to the south.
column21: Rectangular masonry cooking platform. No recessed storage. Tiled survice molded masonry lip on the southern edge.

column14: Cooking platform (sheet 1948) to the north.
column21: Rectangular area in the southeast corner of the kitchen separated from the rest of the kitchen by a partition wall on the north side of which only the lower courses survive. Eschebach identifies this as a latrine. No traces of the latrine survive as the floor is obscured. However, the shape, size, and placement would be appropriate as a latrine.

column14: Atrium (room 2) to the south.
column21: Room 3 is located east of the fauces (room 1). One enters the room through a doorway in the southwest corner. The room is rectangular in shape on east-west axis. The room is elaborately painted in fourth style with tall rectangular architectural motifs alternating with panels in red. In the center of each panel is a square or rectangular painting. Four of the painting contain food and drink motifs, three along the west wall and one along the east wall.

column14: (sheet 1952) to the west.
column21: The painting on the east wall is heavily damaged and exists only in a fragmentary state. On the left (northwest) is a bird moving to consume a piece of fruit to the right (southeast). The fruit appears to be a yellow colored fruit, possibly a peach.

column14: (Sheet 1953) to the west. (Sheet 1951) to the east.
column16: (Sheet 1953) to the west. (Sheet 1951) to the east.
column21: Small rectangular panel showing at the center a kanthera. To the right are, in the background, a drinking cup of glass. In the foreground there appears to a silver cup. Directly to the left of the kanthera is a silver laddle, to the left of which is a silver drinking cup. Leaning against the kanthera going from south to north is a long stirring apparatice (?).

column14: Painting 1952 to the east.  Painting 1954 to the west.
column16: Painting 1952 to the east.  Painting 1954 to the west.
column21: To the west of painting 1952 is a square panel divided in half, top and bottom.  The bottom is too heavily damaged to make out.  The top shows a branch and leaves going west to east below which are three figs.

column14: Painting 1953 to the east.
column21: To the west of painting 1953 is a small rectangular panel.  The motifs are mostly indeterminate, but there appears to be on each end a glass pitcher.

column14: None
column21: In the southwest corner of the house behind the garden (room 14) is a courtyard (room 15).  In the eastern corner of the courtyard is a vaulted, partially subterranean storage area.  The subterranean aspect of the storage area would imply the need to cool what was stored there, such as wine, oil or other food items.  On the southeast side of the courtyard area was a drain that drained water from the room, perhaps into containers no longer extant.

column14: Hallway (room 10) to the west. Fullery (room 8) to the northeast.
column15: Hallway (room 10) to the west. Fullery (room 8) to the northeast.
column21: Kitchen is located in the southwest corner of the house. One enters the kitchen through a hallway (room 10) from the northwest. The room is L-shaped. In the west part of the room, as you enter, is a cooking platform. In the east/west branch of the room was an area for storage in addition to cooking. There appears to have been shelving in the west wall. Along the south wall, near the southeast corner, appears to have been a drain coming from the room above. Stored in the southeast corner were amphorae and other vessels (including an ancient bird feeder). There appears to have been a doorway in the north wall leading to the area of the fulling (room 8).

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform is located in the southwest corner of the room, abutting the west and south walls. It is large and rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis. It has on its east side an arched storage area below. There seems to have been a lip on all sides of the cooking platform.

column14: (Room 5) to the west. (Room 6) to the south.
column15: (Room 5) to the west. (Room 6) to the south.
column21: Rectangular room with a north-south axis opening south to (room 6), doorway at southern end of west wall to (room 5). Window in corner of north wall opens to (room 4). At southern end of east and west walls is plaster molded decoration in the form of flat columns with patterned lower course in red. Traces of second style painting survive on north, east, and west walls with yellow and green architectural elements above the red panels, in turn above white panels. On north wall is red border with black lower panels. In the center of the east wall is a plaster couch niche in black [Sheet 1960] subsequently filled in. In northwest corner is a shallow square niche (sheet 1959). Marble chipping survives in various places in the floor.

column14: (sheet 1960) to the east.
column21: High rectangular plaster shallow niche. Too high for dining couch.

column14: (Sheet 1959) to the west.
column21: Plastered couch niche is painted black. The niche was filled in and plastered over, however, the head of the couch niche is visible.

column14: Room (2) to the south.
column21: Rectangular room with east/west axis with two large doorways opening north to Via dell' Abbondanza. Thresholds preserve placing for sliding doors to close off shop. Plaster survives on north, south, east, and west walls with no indication of paint. On the west wall there are holes for two layers or shelves. On south wall large doorway opens to room (2). Cocciopesto flooring survives. In the center of the floor are two marble door jams that would have isolated the front of the shop from the rear. In the eastern part of the room there remains the imprint in the floor of a wooden L shaped counter [1962]. In the final phase, room 1 was not distinguished from room (2) to the south.

column14: None
column21: Imprint of an L shaped wooden counter is preserved in the cocciopesto floor. The longer arm faces north to the street.

column14: Counter room (1) to north. Room three to the west. Corridor (6) to the southwest. Dining tablinum (5) to the south.
column15: Counter room (1) to north. Room three to the west. Corridor (6) to the southwest. Dining tablinum (5) to the south.
column21: Atrium room converted to a commercial function in its final phase. North/South axis with wide doorway north into counter room (1). In the final phase there does not appear to have been a distinction between these two rooms. In the east half of the doorway are two partially submerged dolia (1965-1966). In the northeast corner there is a cooking platform (1964) and along the east wall proceeding south from platform. There are two dolia (1967 and 1966) and a masonry preparation platform (1969). Fragments of two further dolia lie to the south but they are not in situ. Along the south wall there is a wide doorway opening into the dining tablinum (5) and in the southwest corner corridor (6) leads south to the peristyle. In the northwest corner of the room there is a small room (3). In the center of the room the impluvium has been converted into a basin (1970). To the immediate south of the basin is a cistern. While plaster survives in the northeast, east, and south walls. Along the western wall there is a course of red plaster. There are no traces of painting. High on the south wall is a portico of three tufa doric columns on the floor above.

column14: Dolia (1966 and 1965) to the west. Dolia (1967 and 1968) to south.
column16: Dolia (1966 and 1965) to the west. Dolia (1967 and 1968) to south.
column21: Two masonry and brick supports for a platform, the surface of which does not survive intact. What survives shows that it would have been a masonry surface with storage below. The surviving surface is tile and the tiles abut directly onto the plaster of the wall. There are no indications of the front of the surface. The cooking platform is a later addition resting against the earlier plaster wall.

column14: Dolium (1966) to south. Wooden counter (1962) to north.
column16: Dolium (1966) to south. Wooden counter (1962) to north.
column21: Cylindrical terracotta dolium, the base of which is embedded in the cocciopesto floor of the counter room (1) to the north. No indications of content survive. Neither does a stamp or graffitto survive. Its joined to the dolium to the south (1966) by a masonry and concrete fill that may be the remains of a no longer extant counter.

column14: Dolium (1965) to the northCooking platform (1964) to the east
column16: Dolium (1965) to the northCooknig platform (1964) to the east
column21: Cylindrical terracotta dolium in the base of which is embedded cocciopesto floor of room 2 (preparation room) No indications of content survive. Neither does a stamp of graffito survive. It is joined to the dolium to the north (1965) by a masonry and concrete rill that many be the remains of a no longer extent counter.

column14: Dolium (1965) to the southCooking platform (1964) to the north.
column16: Dolium (1965) to the southCooking platform (1964) to the north.
column21: Cylindrical terracotta dolium, not embedded. No indications of contents, stamp or graffito.

column14: Dolium (1969) to the north.
column21: Partially preserved large cylindrical dolium the loose of which is embedded in the floor. Only a quarter of the rim survives against the east wall. No indications  of content, stamp or graffito remains.

column14: dolium to the northwater basin to the west
column16: dolium to the northwater basin to the west
column21: Square masonry platform the surface of which does not survive. The south side of the platform rests directly on the opus signinum floor below, however in the northwest corner of the platform the flooring extends over the face of the platform. Only the lower course of the platform survives. It is obscured by rubble, tiles and dolium fragments; however there are no visible traces of the original platform surface. To the south of the platform are fragments of two dolia tat are not embedded and only the bases survive. It is not clear if these are situ.

column14: Masonry preparation platform is to the east
column16: Masonry preperation platform is to the east
column21: Earlier square impluvium converted into a basin. Opus signinum basin with drain in the center of the north south sides preserving original floor of the room that consisted of terracotta with white marble inserts. Along this was added masonry sides to the basin, the interior face of which was plastered to render waterproof. The base of this basin is no obscure by lapilli.

column14: Prep room to the northwestCorridor to northeastCourtyard to southwest
column15: Prep room to the northwestCorridor to northeastCourtyard to southwest
column21: Square room opens to northwest through a large door above which are three large rectangular opening framed by piulars . Opposite the entrance on the southwest wall a large window looks onto the adjoining colonnade courtyard. In the southwest corner a narrow door leads to a corridor. The northeast and northwest walls show traces of plaster. If they were decorated in antiquity, no traces remain. Prior to ad 79 the room most likely was used as a tablinum.

column14: Peristyle to the north
column21: The dining room is located in the southwest part of the house. One enters the room from the area of the peristyle to the north. The room is rectangular in shape with a northwest/southeast axis. The walls were elaborately decorated in 4th style with the dominant color being red. It seems that the room in the last years was converted to a dining room a window in the wall was closed up and plastered over and receive a painting. There seems to have been an entrance to a cryptoporticus or storage area in the northeast corner of the room which runs along east a d south perimeter of the peristyle. The floor of the dining room was a hard plaster, perhaps opus signinum.

column14: garden to the south
column21: The dining room was located in the back of the house to the southeast. It looked onto the harded to the south. There was also an entrance to the room in the southwest corner from room 7,. The room is rectangular in shape on a north/south axis. Nothing can be seen of the ancient walls because the room has been converted into a modern room. Both the maps in Eschebach and PPM  indicate that there is a small decorated room to the north seemingly without any entrance, although Eschebach implies in his map the presence of a window from this dining room.

column14: None
column21: One enters the small rectangular room from the east. There is a cooking platform to the north that extends the width of the room. The back of the platform against the wall has two large tiles attached to the wall of the northeast corner. There is no recessed for fuel. The northwest end of the platform is very deteriorated. There is a water basin in from of the platform the the northwest. It has a terracotta drain in the center. There is a window high up in the south wall. Fragments of sconced plaster remain in the northwest corner and on the north wall above the cracked platform tiles. There are fragments of tile on the floor in the northwest corner in front of the cooking platform.

column14: None
column21: Cupboard against western wall

column14: Water basin to the southwest.
column21: The cooking platform is located on the north wall of the kitchen. It extends the width of the room. There is a lip on the front of the platform in the northeast corner. There is no recess for fuel. The northwest end of the platform is very deteriorated.

column14: Cooking platform to the north
column21: Small circular water basin containing a terracotta drain in the center. Only the base of the basin remains. It is located in from of  the cooking platform to the west.

column14: None
column21: In the south corner of the atrium was located a small cooking platform. It abuts against the west and south walls with the front in a semi circular shape. It seems to have had a surface lined with tile.

column14: None
column21: Located in room 11 in the west side of the house was the meta to a small hand mill. There is no reason to believe that it was originally found in this spot, if not in the house at all.

column14: None
column21: A rectangular room with east west axis. North wall poorly preserved with only lower courses courses of the east west still extant. Possible remnants of two locked doorways remain however the state of the preservation is so poor it is impossible to be certain. The southern wall dividi ng the room from corridor (room 4) does not survive. In southwest corner is a pile of large masonry blocks and structure debris. The western wall too street is intact but demonstrates or protraction. In center of the western wall there is a door way with thresholds opening to atrium (room 2) to east. The doorway was reached in size from a leather doorway in earlier phase and plastered over but no traces of decoration remain. Traces of red paint plaster survives on original southern face of original. No traces of flooring survive and room is currently used for storage for custodian.

column14: Garden (room 9) to the northwestAtrium (room 2) to the southeast
column15: Garden (room 9) to the northwestAtrium (room 2) to the southeast
column21: The dining tablinum, located behind the atrium is roughly rectangular in shape on a NE/SW axis. Is opens fully into the atrium (room 2) to the southeast and had a window onto the harden ares (room 9) to the northwest. If the room was decorated in antiquity,nothing remains.

column14: Garden (7) to north. Atrium (2) to south. Andron (10) to the east.
column15: Garden (7) to north. Atrium (2) to south. Andron (10) to the east.
column21: The room has two entrances. The one to the north is the largest and faces the garden (7). The other entrance is smaller and leads down on to the atrium (2) through two steps. Adjoining this entrance is a long rectangular window. There is small window high up on the west wall. Fragments of plaster remain on the wall but no traces of decoration remain. The floor mosaic remains. In the center is an emblem with a black and white square panel surrounded by geometric band of white tesserae. The central emblem is framed by one strand of guilloche and a band of vegetable motifs spreading out of a crater. The emblema contains a grid poised square in opus sectile. Around that is an octagonal pattern of interesting octagonals, forming oblong hexagonals. Irregular shaped squares of multicolored marble are inlaid in a geometric band. The door jams remain between which is a threshold mat of black and white geometric design. The garden (7)facing the dining room is decorated with a hunting scene among wild animals (boars, panther, bulls and gazelles) on the north wall. On the northeast wall is a landscape painting containing small human figures, but is too damaged to identify the scenes.

column14: Atrium (2) to south. Corridor (10) to west.
column15: Atrium (2) to south. Corridor (10) to west.
column21: Rectangular room with north/south axis. Doorway with threshold opening to south atrium (2). Small doorway at southern end of the west wall opening to corridor (10) to the west. Black flooring with white marble inserts and opus sectile inset in center. 4th style painting on north, south, east, and west walls. Black lower register with red and black panels alternating above. Upper register is white with architectural features, vegetation and birds above which is white plaster molding. The center of the north wall is tunneled through destroying center of paintings originally Osiris was depicted. The center piece of west wall is Dionysus and eastern wall is Itys, according to PPM.

column14: Atrium (2) to north.
column21: The kitchen is located in the south corner of house, just to the west of the fauces. It's roughl square in shape and is entered from atrium (2) in the north corner by descending two steps. Just to the west is a preparation platform where at present a hand mill is situated. Just inside the door to the east are two masonry constructions which probably served as supports for a preparation platform. In the south corner of the room is the latrine, with a sloping floor to the cesspool. The room was decorated simply in antiquity in what appears to be the 3rd style. In the southeast wall at an elevated height is a large window to the outside. As reconstructed, there appears to have been a large window above the entrance on the north wall. On the west corner of there may have been room for a shelf under the stairs that rose to the second story. Along the west wall are remnants of what appears to be the original floor of beaten cement and is at a higher level than the masonry supports.

column14: Cooking platform [1987] to the west.
column21: It is located along the eastern wall. As extant today only the supports are present. The top is not extant; it may have been wooden.

column14: Cooking platform [1987] to the north.
column21: It is located in the southern corner of the room. As extant, there is a sloping floor directed to the south south toward the cesspool. The sloping floor in made of stone.

column14: Mill (1988) on top of preparation platform.
column16: Mill (1988) on top of preperation platform.
column21: It is located just to the right as one enters the room in the southwest corner. One side of the platform abuts against the north wall; the other against the west wall. The front of the platform is semicircular and is partially incorporated into the bottom step. The surface seems to have been of a beaten cement. There are no traces of tile.

column14: Cooking platform (1987) underneath.
column21: The hand mill rests today on the cooking platform (1987) located just to the west as one enters the room. As presently situated there is a catillus on bottom and meta on top (the mill is upside down). The catillus has clearly shown a slot for the wooden handle.

column14: Corridor (room 20) is to the north (which contains a cistern and stairs to the floor above).
column15: Cooridor (room 20) is to the north (which contains a cistern and staris to the floor above).
column21: It is a square room with a doorway in the west end of the north wall opening to room 20.  The threshold contains placings for a door.  There is a plastered window in the center of the east wall opening to the street and a plastered window opening in the south wall opening to garden (room 22).  The north, east, south and west walls preserve undecorated plaster.  In the east, south and west walls there are rectangular holes for a low ceiling or shelving.  In the northeast corner there is a rectangular cooking platform (1980).  To the immediate south of 1890, in the southeast corner, is a latrine (1891).  To the immediate west of the latrine (1891), along the south wall, to the southwest corner, are two masonry supports for a platform with a recessed area below for storage.  Allison notes that there were no finds relating to cooking in this room and she suggests that is was not in use at the time of the eruption.

column14: None
column15: Latrine (1891) to the south.  Platform (1892) to the southwest.
column21: It is a rectangular cooking platform, masonry and tile construction with recessed storage below - excellently preserved.  It has a tile surface with a tiled rear lip at the junction with the east wall.  The tiled lip at the front consists of three arched roof tiles laid along the front edge.  The south edge consists of a masonry lip lined with plaster.  Immediately above the south end of the platform, in the east wall, is a square plastered window looking out to the street.

column14: Preparation platform (1892) is to the west.  Cooking platform (1890) is to the north.
column16: Preparation platform (1892) is to the west.  Cooking platform (1890) is to the north.
column21: In the rectangular area to the south of the cooking platform (1890) there is a plastered floor sloping south to a drain running through the southeast corner of the wall that drains into the garden (22) to the south.  The base of the latrine is obscured by soil.  Along the western edge of the plastered floor is an arched plastered lip.

column14: Cooking platform (1890) to the north.
column21: There are two masonry supports in the center of the south wall to the southwest corner.  Traces of plaster survive and between the two supports.  There is a shallow rectangular pit for storage (?).  No traces of the platform itself survive although there is a line in the plaster in the south wall which may mark the location.  In the center of the south wall above is a square plaster lined window opening to garden (room 22) to the south.

column14: Room 16 to northeastCorridor ( ) to the southwest
column15: Room 16 to northeastCorridor ( ) to the southwest
column21: Square room opens to the northwest through a large opening facing the outdoor triclinium.  Two smaller doors open on either side of the northeast wall.  Both doors lead out to open space.  The door to the southeast corner has traces of a threshold slightly above the room's floor.  In the northwest and southwest walls on the bottom are long rectangular niches for holding couches.  Bronze fittings for couch were found in this room and a wooden reconstruction of an L-shaped couch is now in place.  The floor is decorated with a "T" and "U" layout.  The U-shaped band is simply concrete floor.  The "T" portion is ornamental with a central emblem of opus sectile.  It contains flowers and other vegetables and is framed by a band of geometric motif in opus sectile.  The walls are painted with large white panels framed by architectural elements.  Panels in the southwest wall contain same draped female figures, one holding plate and animal and the other wheat and handle sickle.  On the northeast wall one remaining central panel remains with two warriors chasing a woman.  The vaulted ceiling is decorated with polychrome stucco artwork with only one panel remaining of a naked woman.

column14: None
column21: Two long rectangular niches open along bottom of northwest and southwest walls, joined together to make a single L-shaped niche.  The niches in both walls are painted with plant and amphora motifs with gold and red frames.  The niches were evidently designed for holding dining couches because of the floor mosaic and bronze fittings found in room.

column14: Room 18 to the southwest
column21: Dining room (24) is located in the center of the house to the east of the atrium (9) and room 16.  Its full length is open to room 18 to the southwest.  The entrance is delineated by a mosaic on a northwest-southeast axis.  In the center of the room, toward the front, is a large, rectangular mosaic.  On three sides of the rectangular mosaic there is delineated in a simple mosaic line the outline for three benches of a portable triclinium.  The walls were elaborately painted in the 4th style with numerous vignettes of animals: goats, birds, a leopard and an owl, most of which remain extant.  The room looks toward the southwest along the long axis of room 18 to the southwest wall where one can see an elaborate lararium painting and niche.

column14: Atrium (9) to west
column21: Rectangular room on an east-west axis with doorway in the west wall stepping down to atrium (9).  The threshold preserves placing for door.  Blocked doorway in the south end of east wall; the street is outside.  Shallow recess at north end of east wall for latrine.  Undecorated plaster along north wall.  Allison reports a bench with a tripod for cooking which is no longer extant.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature: cooking platformNo longer extant bench with cooking tripod along north wall.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature: cooking tripod

column14: Negative feature: platform to the west (1997)Negative feature: cooking tripod to the west (1998)
column16: Negative feature: platform to the west (1997)Negative feature: cooking tripod to the west (1998)
column21: Latrine in northeast corner of kitchen.  The original floor level is obscured.  Contiguous with modern floor level is a recess for a seat in the northeast corner.  At the north end of the east wall there is a recess into which the latrine is placed.  Further features of the latrine are not visible.

column14: Room (5) to southeast
column21: The triclinium is located in the west corner of entrance 10.  One enters the room through a doorway to the southeast from room 5.  In the east corner of the room is a rectangular cooking platform on a roughly southeast-northwest axis.  Beyond the cooking platform there is a niche in the northeast wall for a couch.  On the southwest wall there seems also to have been a niche or a couch.  The room itself is rectangular in shape on a northeast-southwest axis.  If the room was decorated in antiquity nothing remains.

column14: Niche (2002) to the northeast
column21: It is located along the northeast wall extending from the entrance in a southeast-northwest axis.  The surface seems to have been of beaten cement (opus signinum?).

column14: Cooking platform (2001) to southeastNiche (2003) to the south
column16: Cooking platform (2001) to southeastNiche (2003) to the south
column21: There is a niche for a couch located on the northeast wall, approximately two feet beyond the northwest end of the cooking platform and extending all the way to the northwest wall.  Its height is greater than that of the couch niche on the southwest wall.

column14: Niche (2002) to southwest
column21: The couch niche on the southwest wall begins approximately three feet from the southeast wall and extends all the way to the northwest wall.  Its height is considerably less than the dining couch niche (2002) on the northeast wall.  Undecorated plaster remains today.

column14: Atrium (9) to northwestBedroom (14) to west
column15: Atrium (9) to northwestBedroom (14) to west
column21: Rectangular room with north-south axis.  Doorway at north part of west wall opens to atrium (9).  Doorway in center of west wall is open to room (14).  Collapsed wall in center of north wall to room (13).  High in east wall are two square, plastered windows opening to the street to the east.  Decoration consists of black lower registers, yellow border.  Black panels above with white and red trim: 3rd or 4th style.   Windows of east wall were inserted into upper register painting.Above in southeast corner there is molding above which is modern construction (?).  There are 4 pilasters along the east wall supporting a modern roof.  Marble chipping survives in floor.  In south end of eastern wall is a shallow, rectangular niche (2005).

column14: None
column21: Rectangular, shallow niche with plastered black paint in southeast corner of room.

column14: Loggia (19) to northwest
column21: The dining garden (22) is located in the south part of the house.  One enters the garden through a door in the north corner through the loggia (19) and down two steps.  To the northeast there is a water basin.  On the southwest side of the garden is a large masonry triclinium with a center serving table, to the southeast of which, along the southeast wall, is a fountain.  The east part of the garden seems to have been a vegetable garden.  On the southwest wall there seems to have been perhaps a rectangular niche but only portions of the roof are extant.  The walls of the garden were painted.  Nearly all of it is no longer extant; however, on the southeast wall to the southwest of the fountain is a paradeisoi painting similar to that of the house of the Ceii.  To the northeast of the lectus imus is a large pillar made of rubble and coated with stucco rising to approximately 3.5 to 4 feet, similar but slightly larger than the columns forming the pergola over the masonry triclinium.

column14: None
column21: Masonry triclinium in center of garden (22).  The interior faces of the clinia of the north are decorated depicting Nilotic scene with boats, architectural elements and pygmies.  The northern end of the western arm shows an erotic scene below an awning.  The northern end of the eastern arm shows a shrine containing a statue with surrounding portico.  Along the interior face of the 3 couches there is a serving ledge.  On the northern edge of the western edge is a plastered arched lip.  Between the 3 couches there is a rectangular marble podium.  At the base of the interior faces and the northern faces there is a lead-lined water channel.  The plaster floor slopes from the water channel towards the central, rectangular podium.  In center of podium is a circular hole with lead water pipe that supplied water for the water feature.  In the center of the central couch to south--lectus midius--there is marble, lead-lined water channel that extends south through the triclinium to the rectangular basin of the water fountain to the south.  The lead-lined channel referred to above is on the exterior of the triclinium as well.  To south of the triclinium is a plastered, painted fountain in the form of a small shrine with white molding and red and blue painted decoration.  To the rear is an arched molded niche with plaster shell above that contained the water source from which the water would have cascaded down 4 marble steps into the square basin.  At the base of the north wall of this is a terracotta pipe which drains into the plaster and lead-lined channel in the triclinium to north.  At southern end of the base of the east and west walls there is a lead pipe that drains through wall to east and west.  The basin preserves opus signinum lining in places, a marble top and plastered exterior.  The triclinium stands below a pergola consisting of 4 columns placed in 4 corners of clinia.  The columns are plastered and painted blue with red trim at base of capitals.  Traces of the white plaster molding survives on capital of the northeast column.  The two northernmost columns have brick-built plastered painted pilasters on northern face that perhaps served as bases for statuary.  The exterior face of the clinia preserves traces of red paint on the plaster with no other visible decoration.

column14: Peristyle (18L) to the south
column21: Dining room (13L) opens to the south through a large opening onto the peristyle (18L).  It is a square room.  It is decorated with wall painting on the northeast and southwest walls.  The northeast wall represents white panels framed by red bands.  The central upper panel contains a high platform supporting containers for liquids.  The reminder of the painting is too deteriorated to determine content.

column14: None
column21: Feature: hand millRoom: bedroomSmall hand mill in north corner of room.  It has three grinding stone discs.  The middle disc has the hole for the turning mechanism.  The mill is not in situ.  There is no evidence that it was originally located in the room or the house.

column14: 10L to the west
column21: The kitchen is located in room 12L.  It is situated at the end of the andron (8L).  One enters the kitchen through a small door on the west.  On the southeast, northeast and northwest walls is a cooking platform constructed as one unit.  Plastered walls, but if decorated in antiquity nothing remains.

column14: None
column21: On the southeast, northeast and northwest walls is a cooking platform constructed as one unit.  The cooking platform on the northwest wall has a large vaulted niche below for storage.  The platform on the southeast wall has a small arched niche for storage.  The cooking platform on the northeast wall has a wide arched niche which seems to have been plastered in antiquity, as was also seemingly the niche under the southeast cooking platform area.  Today there is a small dolium inserted under the niche in the northeast part of the cooking platform, though it probably doesn't belong.  The cooking platform on the northwest wall is much larger than those on the southeast and northeast walls, perhaps suggesting that the northwest section was a cooking platform with the northeast and southeast sections being preparation.

column14: Atrium 2 to west
column21: The rectangular room opens to the southeast onto atrium 2 through a small door in the southwest corner.  Three differently-sized windows open in the upper part of the southeast wall and look out onto atrium 2.  A further one opens into the adjoining tablinum to the northeast.  The walls are painted with large red panels framed by black band of ornamental motifs.  In the central panel of the northeast and northwest walls is a white small panel containing figurative motifs which are difficult to identify because of the badly preserved state of the decoration.  The floor is ornamented with a series of white tesserae orderly arranged among smaller irregular red tesserae.  The threshold is slightly above the room floor and shows evidence of placings for door.

column14: Corridor (7) to the south.
column21: The square room opens to the south onto porticus (7) and the peristyle (14) beyond through a wide entrance. In the southwest corner is a small door opening to room (5). The walls are decorated with large rectangular red panels framed by ornamental column-like bands. Above the panels runs a black band between yellow bands. Above those are horizontal panels alternating with square panels. All the panels contain ornamental reliefs. Traces of further painting are above but are not well preserved. On the floor a simple, white mosaic frames a long rectangular band decorated with an ivy scroll with fruit and birds inside (figs and cherries). To the north of the band is a square panel containing a grid of four squares framed by a strand guilloche. The squares contain comedy masks (two facing south and facing north). The northeast corner of the floor has been destroyed. The threshold marble is slightly elevated in relation to corridor (7).

column14: Storeroom (8) to the west. Portico (7) to the south.
column15: Storeroom (8) to the west. Portico (7) to the south.
column21: Rectangular room with an east/west axis. The western end of the southern wall has a doorway to portico (7) to the south. In the southern end of the western wall, there is a doorway to (8) with a threshold preserving placings for door. On the threshold for the doorway on the south wall there is a geometric pattern in white tesserae in diamond pattern and two lead placings for a door or gate (date unknown). Cocciopesto flooring with large marble inserts. In the center of the eastern half of the room there is a mosaic insert around which the clinia would have been placed. The mosaic consists of black, white and red borders around a central rosette depicting a boat with pygmies in a Nilotic landscape containing fish, crocodiles, a smaller boat, a larger animal (hippopotamus ?) with a shrine and palm trees. The pygmies in the smaller boat hold fishing rods and are fishing. Walls are decorated in third or fourth style with burgundy lower register with plants and red, black and yellow panels above, burgundy border above that with miniatures of bords and sea creatures with white background with vegetation and architectural details above. Inserted into the eastern center of the north wall is a rectangular window. At the eastern end of the north wall is a plastered niche (2015).

column14: Mosaic (2018) to the south.
column21: Shallow, rectangular niche in the northeast corner of the room. The niche is painted in accordance with the decorative motifs of the rest of the room with burgundy lower register containing vegetation. White border with red panels above.

column14: None
column21: Wooden triclinium under the pergola in the center of the peristyle.

column14: The peristyle porticus (room 7) is to the north.
column15: The peristyle porticus (room 7) is to the north.
column21: The rooms opens to the north to the peristyle porticus (room 7).  The room was entered through two unequally sized doors.  The northwest door was small and a marble threshold remains.  The room is rectangular and on an east/west axis.  The room was probably completely floored in mosaic but only fragments of a simple pattern of white tesserae remain in the west end of the room.  On the northwest wall, to the east of the small entrance, are races of red painting.  The walls on the south and east are preserved at a low levels and all plaster, if it existed, is gone.  The east wall has collapsed.

column14: Niche (2015) to the north.
column21: In the center of the eastern half of the room there is a mosaic insert around which the clinia would have been placed. The mosaic consists of black, white and red borders around a central rosette depicting a boat with pygmies in a Nilotic landscape containing fish, crocodiles, a smaller boat, a larger animal (hippopotamus ?) with a shrine and palm trees. The pygmies in the smaller boat hold fishing rods and are fishing.
column35: Mosaic, Floor Food and Drink Related

column14: Dining Room 9 is to the east.  The portico (7) of the peristyle (14) is to the south.
column15: Dining Room 9 is to the east.  The portico (7) of the peristyle (14) is to the south.
column21: The small rectangular room opens to the south on the northern portico of the peristyle (room 14).  A farther small door opens in the southeast corner to the dining room (room 9).  The well preserved threshold still keeps traces of the hole for the door.  Opposite this door in the southwest corner is a tall rectangular niche slightly above the floor.  On the north, east and west walls are small square holes, perhaps to support shelves.  The walls are plastered but no signs of decoration remain.  The flooring is obscured by debris as the room is currently used for storage.

column14: Room 3 is to the north.  Room 2 is to the south.
column15: Room 3 is to the north.  Room 2 is to the south.
column21: Room 17 is a small, narrow rectangular room below the stairs to the floor above with a doorway opening at the south end of the west wall to atrium (room 2).  The marble faced threshold and door are preserved.   The south and east walls preserve undecorated plaster.  Four amphorae are embedded in the volcanic debris at the south end of the room.  One is well preserved and is a dressel 2-4 wine amphorae in the southeast corner.  The amphorae to the southwest corner is not preserved above the shoulder but the body appears to be the same as the previous amphorae.  Against the previous amphorae, to the north, there is a poorly preserved section of the lower body of the third vessel, which in dimensions and profile is similar to the two 2-4 dressel vessels.  The remaining vessel lacks handles and a lip, but has a ovoid body (dressel 7/11 (check?)).

column14: Room 2L to the north.  Room 4L to the east.  Room 7L to the south.  Room 6L to the south.  Room 1L to the east.
column15: Room 2L to the north.  Room 4L to the east.  Room 7L to the south.  Room 6L to the south.  Room 1L to the east.
column21: The cryptoporticus is entered from the northwest corner.  Other doorways open in the north, east and south walls, leading into other rooms, perhaps also used for storage.  On the top of the western wall are three clere story windows opening onto the eastern portico of the peristyle.  The cryptoporticus is long and rectangular with a vaulted ceiling.  The walls are partly covered with plain plaster with no evidence of decoration.  Leaning against the eastern wall are 15 amphorae of different sizes which may not be in situ. The typology of the containers whos that some were used for storing wine and others for oil.  No traces of flooring remain.

column14: 8L to the northwest.  10L to the northwest.
column15: 8L to the northwest.  10L to the northwest.
column21: The storage room, where carts could be brought in, was located on the second (lower) level on the southeast side of the house.  The entrance from the street, which divides I.6 and I.7, is very wide.  Someone entering the room would need to step up two steps but carts could be brought in with a ramp provided.  Above the doorway is a large rectangular window to provide light.  The room is oriented on a southeast/northwest axis.  It is vaulted the entire length.  On the southwest wall, near the northwest end, is a doorway leading into room 8L and the rest of the house.  On the southwest wall, just to the left of the street entrance is a doorway leading into room 10L and two more rooms behind it.  The walls were plastered in antiquity; but if it was decorated nothing remains.  On the west wall to the back (rear) of the room, toward the southwest, appears to have been a quarter circle window.  (This window may be modern.)  In the ceiling, approximately 70% of the way back to the rear (west) end of the room is what appears to be a large light well though at present it is blocked to the floor above.  In the west wall, in the southwest corner, at floor level, is a drain which seems to drain from the peristyle (room 14) above.  A gutter, which runs the entire length of the southwest wall, appears to empty into the street but there is no evidence for it.

column14: Room (2) to the southeast. Room (3) to the southeast.
column15: Room (2) to the southeast. Room (3) to the southeast.
column21: The counter room is entered through two doorways. The major doorway is entered from the northwest to the Via del' Abbondanza (Entrance 8). There is a minor entrance from the street dividing insula 7 and 8 on the east side (Entrance 9). In the north corner of the room is an L shaped counter. The longest side parallels the Via del Abbondanza and blocks one half of the entrance. The western side of this arm has one embedded dolia. The short arm, which is perpendicular to the Via del Abbondanza contains one embedded dolia. The surface of the counter is made of broken fragments of marble as reconstructed. In the southeast part of the counter room are entrances to rooms (2) and (3). The walls have been plastered but no traces remain if it was decorated in antiquity. In the northwest corner of the room, embedded in the wall is a large drain from the second floor. In the northeast wall appears to have been a niche which seems to have been sloped downward towards the room; a characteristic making the determination of use difficult (lararium ?).

column14: None
column21: In the north corner of the room is an L shaped counter. The longest side parallels the Via del Abbondanza and blocks one half of the entrance. The western side of this arm has one embedded dolia. The short arm, which is perpendicular to the Via del Abbondanza contains one embedded dolia. The surface of the counter is made of broken fragments of marble as reconstructed.

column14: Peristyle garden (5) to the south and room #14 to the north.
column15: Peristyle garden (5) to the south and room #14 to the north.
column21: Rectangular room facing south to the peristyle (5). Cocciopesto floor with white marble chips, plaster decoration survives on all three walls with a red lower register with black above and traces of while and blue/black trim. Two blocked entrances in the northeast and center of the north wall. The decorations matches the decorations found in the two rooms to the north.

column14: None
column21: The shop is to the west of the House of Stephanus entrance. The shop opens to the north into the Via del Abbondanza. At the front of the shop on the west side is an L shaped counter. The one side of the counter takes about 1/2 of the doorway, while the second half of the counter, although no longer present, would extend into the shop. At the rear on the east side of the shop is a tall doorway leading into the atrium of the house. This doorway also has slots in the threshold to close the shop off from the remainder of the house. On the south wall is a doorway leading into what may have been a storeroom for the shop. On the west wall, above the level of the counter and a little to the south, is a large lararium. The walls of the shop were painted, but very little remains today. The front entrance to the shop still retains its threshold with the slots used to close off the entire width of the entrance during the night. High on the west and east walls are holes that may have supported beams. In the middle of the east wall, accordingly to Eschebach, where were steps which may have lead to a loft supported by the beams. The floor appears to be a beaten floor. Inside the shop entrance approximately 40% into the shop seems to be a stone which appears to have a cutting to seat something such as a wooden pole, its function is unknown.

column14: A lararium appears on the west wall a little to the south above the level of the counter.
column16: A lararium appears on the west wall a little to the south above the level of the counter.
column21: The masonry counter has 2 arms. One arm parallels the house entrance running roughly east-west. The second arm would extend into the shop, however, this arm has been destroyed and is missing today. According to Eschebach, the counter contained 2 dolia, only 1 exists today where the two arms join as reconstructed. Where the second dolia possibly existed, now exists a rectangular opening, created during reconstruction. The exterior of the counter was decorated with paint. The decoration on the north side has an elaborate figural decoration showing on the east side, which appears to be a large bronze vessel with a staff leaning against it. In the center there appears to be a large round platter or shield (bronze ?). The decoration on the west side appears to be another vessel though it is indistinct. The vessels and platter are in gold paint, all on a background of red. The decoration on the east end of the counter is heavily damaged. The foreground was in read and if there were any figures they no longer exist. In the center, near the bottom is a tall slender hole that extends into the counter, function unknown.

column14: Room #18 to the northeast and the atrium (#2) to the southwest.
column15: Room #18 to the north-east and the atrium (#2) to the southwest.
column21: Indication of this room on the map used is wrong. The storeroom is a small rectangular room on a northeast to southwest axis with a door at the northeast side of the room, leading into the shop. A second door in the southeast leads into the atrium. Plastered walls with a whitish colored paint. There is a small lentil at the atrium entrance and is shows evidence of a secure door to the atrium.

column14: Peristyle (5) to the south, atrium (19) to the north and tablinum (17) to the west.
column15: Peristyle (5) to the south, atrium (19) to the north and tablinum (17) to the west.
column21: Rectangular shaped dining room facing south to the peristyle (5). Traces of undecorated plaster on all three walls in the east wall are traces of two blocked plaster recesses/niches(?). In the northeast corner of the north wall there is a doorway leading to the atrium (5), in the southwest corner of the west wall there is a doorway leading to the tablinum. A marble threshold survives with inserts for a door. Unable to determine floor as obscured by debris.

column14: Peristyle garden (5) to the north.
column21: The dining room lies at the south end of the house and looks upon the peristyle garden to the north through a wide door. On the west wall is a couch niche. The walls were once decorated; little remains, except for what can be seen in the couch niche. The room is roughly square in shape and the floor is obscured by debris.

column14: None
column21: On the west wall of the dining room is a couch niche that runs north-south, extending approximately three quarters of the wall. It was originally painted which appears to be a combination of a block lower and a whie with a red border upper. The niche is rectangular in shape.

column14: Peristyle garden to the west and another room (possible storage, filled with rubble) to the north
column15: Peristyle garden to the west and another room (possible storage, filled with rubble) to the north
column21: The entrance to the kitchen is leading to the peristyle. At the rear of the kitchen appears to be which possible could be another back room or store area, however it is currently filled with rubble. The room is entered by the south and is on a north-south axis. A cooking platform exists on the east wall of the kitchen. The condition of the room is poor. The kitchen is entered by stepping down 2 (possibly) 3 steps. Floor is obscured by debris.

column14: None
column21: A small, approximately 6' x 3' cooking platform is found on the east wall. Two areas for recessed storage is found, one filled with debris from a collapsed wall. Tiled surface.

column14: Portico (3) to to the north.
column21: Rectangular garden at the rear of the property. The garden is on a east-west axis. Portico with three red plastered columns to the north and low wall. Shallow plastered drain runs east-west to the south of the wall with a drain through the wall to the east guttering into the street below. To the south of ts, in the northeast corner, there is a plastered chute/drain to a cistern below. The eastern half of the garden has a plastered floor, with a masonry couch triclinium (2035). Above the couch is a pergola supported by two brick columns with red plastered decoration. Between the couch and the southern wall of the property, there is a shallow plastered lined drain, obscured by debris. Against the southern wall this is a visible part of a shallow plastered drain that appears to have run across the garden in front of the triclinium, but most of this is obscured by earth. Adjoining the drain in the south wall is a small recess/guttering. A column from an earlier colonnade survives in the west wall. Jashemski says there was a garden painting on the east wall of which no traces remain. Garden has been replanted in modern times.

column14: None
column15: Garden (6) to te west, portico (3) to the north.
column21: Well preserved masonry garden triclinium, preserved to the opus signinum surface. Traces of opus signinum floor survives between the arms of the couch. Traces of yellow painted plaster in the interior corners of arms of the couch. On the exterior corners of the couch are two brick columns with red painted plaster decoration, supporting the pergola above the couches. At the western end of the southern couch, traces of yellow paint plaster survives. At the eastern end of the southern couch there is a low wall, decorated with yellow painted plaster.

column14: Garden Triclinium to the southeast and the andron to the southwest.
column15: Garden Triclinium to the south-east and the andron to the south-west.
column21: The large dining room is located to the north of the garden looking directly onto the masonry triclinium to the south. Room is rectangular with a southeast to northwest axis. The roof has been reconstructed, the floor is a beaten cement with a simple pattern with white square stones both large and small except for the center with have large fragments of marble imbedded in the floor. In the west corner is a small couch niche. In the northeast corner is a couch niche roughly twice the length of the first. The niches probably accommodate a biclinium. On the south corner is a small doorway leading to the andron. The walls on three sides are elaborately decorated in the fourth style. The colors are predominately red and black and blue or green. On the east wall there is a long rectangular yellow painting of a woman riding on a bull. To the right and left of the large rectangular painting was a small painting which has been removed. The threshold of the room shows places where the room could be closed off. The floor of the dining room is higher than the level of the andron.

column14: Couch niche (2038) to the west.
column21: In the northeast corner is a couch niche. The wall containing the couch niche appears to have been painted black. Within the niche is a small shallow platform which may have functioned as a support for the couch.

column14: Couch niche (2037) to the north.
column21: In the west corner of the room is a couch niche. The wall of the couch niche seems to have been painted in black. Within the niche is a small shallow platform which may have functioned as support for the couch.

column14: None
column21: Third style white and red painting. This small dining room is filled with broken amphora, decorated lead basin and a a top and bottom quern. Coccio pesto floor in black and white. A window smaller on the outside and larger in the interior is found on the east wall. A large roughly painted couch niche is found on the east corner of the north wall. Bird pictures in red frames are found on the north, east and west walls. On the west wall this is a recessed lararium painted yellow in the interior and has molding around the niche. The room is entered using a door leading leading to the atrium in the south corner of the west wall

column14: None
column21: Along the north wall in the east corner there is a long niche with plaster. No decoration or painting extant.

column14: Couch niche (2040) to the east.
column21: Along the east wall of the dining room exists a aedicular shaped lararium with an interior painted in yellow. Directly below the lararium is a offering shelf ledge. No decoration remains.

column14: Room #12 to the southeast, room 10 to southwest.
column15: Room #12 to the south-east, room 10 to south-west.
column21: Rectangular shaped counter room opening to he north onto the street. Threshold survives in the northwest corner with a jamb for a door. Large U shaped marble sales counter against the eastern wall, north along the street frontage and in the center of the room. White plaster survives on the east and west walls with a red trim. In the northwest corner of the west wall there is a low masonry platform of uncertain usage. In the west end of the south wall there is a doorway with a threshold and a post of a door opening south into room 10. Doorway in the south wall to room #12 with a marble threshold with holes for a door. In the center of the south wall there is a lararium (2044). Terracotta drain through the wall high in the center of the east wall. Location of shelving survives and plaster is found on the southeast corner of the east wall.

column14: Lararium (2044) to the south.
column21: A U shaped counter with the short face to the north along the street. Marble surface and a marble facing along the north exterior face. Red painted plaster survives in the center of the west exterior face. Thirteen (13) dolia are found ; 10 are inserted into the counter with three smaller dolia in the northeast corner. It is not clear if these were inserted into the counter as the surface at that point has not been restored. To the east of the entrance to the street, there are five small holes of decreasing size inserted into the marble counter, function unknown. In the center of the east arm there is a low masonry cooking platform on top of the counter in front of which there is a low covered marble slab in the counter with a central circular emblem surrounded by a frame.

column14: Counter (2043) to the north.
column21: Lararium painting inserted into black background. Plaster molded temple frontage with white, blue and burgundy paint and Corinthian columns on either side with plaster. Seron vines above, painted with blue on a red background. The lararium itself is decorated with two registers of seams, the lower register consists of two snakes on a burgundy background with an alter between them. The upper register includes four figures from left to right: Mercury with a bag and a wand; Lar, Genius performing offering at a brazier with cornucopia in left hand; Lar, Dionysus with staff and goblet and panther at his feet. Above the lararium traces from earlier painting survives depicting & plaster molding lararium with burgundy decorations on a white background.

column14: Room 2 to the south.
column21: This is a rectangular room on an east-west axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli and earth.  Traces of plaster survive on all four walls.  There is no indication of decoration.  However, it is possible to discern an upper and lower register on the east wall.  A doorway is located in the southeast corner of the room.  The threshold has inserts for a door.  It is a large room and its identification is based on Eschebach, page 50.  There is a blocked, plastered, vaulted niche-lararium (?) in the southwest corner near the door.

column14: None
column16: Room 1 to the south, room 3 to the east.
column21: A rectangular counter room opening west onto the street with steps, thresholds and jambs for a door. L-shaped counter with one dolium. Fragments of red plaster survives in the northeast corner.

column14: Atrium to the south, Counter room to the north and dining room to the east.
column15: Atrium to the south, Counter room to the north and dining room to the east.
column21: From the restaurant entrance, one continues south to a large dining room. A large entrance way with a marble lentil south to the atrium. A small door to a dining room to the east. A large door to the counter room is found to the north. A nice marble G shaped pattern encircled be a red marle strip, then a green marble strip. The marble squares are pink, red green, white and gray. The walls are totally bare down to the floor. Beyond the marble squares the floor is bare. There is no ceiling present.

column14: Counter (2043) to the east.
column21: Located on the western wall of room #11 is an unusual feature located next to the corner of the wall leading to the shop front. Due to the poor condition of the remains it is difficult to determine exactly what type of feature it is. Discussions and examinations have included: a water basin, cupboard niche and possible latrine. Final determination cannot be made without further research, however, the feature should be recorded for further study.

column14: Atrium to the north, peristyle garden to the south.
column15: Atrium to the north, peristye garden to the south.
column21: Walking south from the entrance of the restaurant passing through the atrium, one steps up a white marble lentil to the dining tablinum. The floor has black tesserae with large white chips in the center and large marble chips in pirus in while and yellow. There is a step up painted tufa at the end. Most of the stucco and painting is gone, with exception of the red wall to the south corner. The dining tablinum overlooks the peristyle garden.

column14: Dolium (2054) to the north and dolium (2055) to the south.
column16: Dolium (2054) to the north and dolium (2055) to the south.
column21: Low masonry rectangular cooking platform added to the counter (2043). Surface does not survive.
column53: No photo team or drawing team notes or signitures found on the feature sheet.

column14: South of the counter room (11) and southwest of the dining room (10)
column15: South of the counter room (11) and south-west of the dining room (10)
column21: The dining room is located to the south of the counter room through a doorway. In the southwest corner is a doorway leading to room 10. The room is roughly on a southeast northwest axis with a beaten floor with simple decoration of small white marble. Except for eh center where there is a large rectangular area made up of four large marble squares,  surrounding that is a large rectangular area made up of broken pieces for colored marble. The wall were at one time highly decorated in the late 3rd style with the dominate color being red and are still to relatively good condition. The dining room is slightly at a lower level to the counter shop.

column14: contiguous to the peristyle garden
column21: The kitchen lies on the north conner of the peristyle and underneath the masonry triclinium of the garden of region 1.8.9.  Kitchen is rectangular, roughly SE-NW.  The ceiling is barrel vaulted.  Has a window on the NE wall, one above the cooking platform, one above the latrine.  The cooking platform lies along the NE wall and may have been inserted later than the 3 archways that lie along the NE wall. The back wall to the NW may have at one time had a door, now closed off.  The walls show no sign of decoration though the ceiling shows signs of plaster.  The floor seems to be beaten dirt.  The kitchen had two latrines, one located on either side of the entrance doorway but on the garden side.  Two windows that open onto the street extending through the wall with the wider side inside the kitchen and the street side opening much smaller.  The kitchen seems to be used as a storage area as there were many fragments of roof tiles, a puteal modern bricks 2 meters and a fragment of a moterareien and amphana.

column14: south 2066 quern
column21: Cooking platform extends along NE wall beginning in SE corner.  It seems to have been inserted as it almost totally blocks the first archway and extends into the 2nd archway edging along the NE wall.  Cooking platform seems to have a surface of stone- it lacks a lip.  No storage area although the upper part of the first arch allows a small area that could be used for storage.  As extant, the façade of the cooking platform shows no sign of a covering.

column14: cooking platform (2064) to the S
column21: The latrine lies in the N corner of the NE wall.  It seems to have been inserted into the 3rd archway and below the window.  It's in damaged condition but it seems to have been a place for the insertion of a wooden seat.

column14: 2064 to the N
column21: The meta of a small hand quern was found just past the entrance of the kitchen on the floor almost abutting the cooking platform.  No evidence for the catillus.

column14: 2065 north, 2069 east
column21: The meta of a small hand quern was found on the floor along the SW wall in the kitchen (about 60% into the kitchen).  There is no evidence of a catillus.

column14: None
column21: The wall on the northwest has a shallow, low entry into the kitchen.  The wall is plastered and includes one large rough area for painting and a Pompeiian red slab underneath it.  The feature is a rectangular lararium, with minimal evidence of bottom edge.  Beneath the lararium niche is one great snake and the suggestion of the presence of a second.  The interior of the lararium is painted with white plaster on top, bottom, two sides and rear and is painted with 38 red roses with green stems and leaves.  To the north of the lararium on the wall we discerned blue, red and green figural elements.  The snake below is burgundy and amber in color.  This wall is outside of room 9 and is in poor condition.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., Page 826
column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE. PPM, page 826.

column14: Peristyle garden (1) to the north.
column21: Rectangular dining room on a east-west axis with a wide doorway in the center of the north wall looking north to the peristyle (1). Southwest corner is obscured by tiles, floor is obscured by debris and pumice. Traces of plaster survives in the northwest and northeast and southeast corners and along the base of the east wall. No traces of decoration are visible. The room seems to have undergone several modifications, in the center of the east wall there is a blocked window, in the west wall there is a possible blocked doorway and short walls on either side of the doorway are late editions. This identification as a dining room is based on the width of the doorway and its possible location outside of the peristyle.

column14: The  hallway to the atrium is behind the south wall. South is garden, peristyle.
column15: The  hallway to the atrium is behind the south wall. South is garden, peristyle.
column21: The room is large and rectangular, with the door opening to the NE facing a small garden. On the east corner of the south wall is a small doorway leading to the hallway. The threshold is stone and has evidence of circular representations which may be from a folding screen. Along the south wall, situated in the center is a drain (#2078). It is well preserved. The floor is heavily damaged with the remains of the non-patterned tesserae evident. The north and the west walls display third style paintings. The southern wall is severely damaged. On the north wall the decoration is black and framed with red. The western wall has a decoration framed with green contains red, yellow and gold. The picture is framed in the same red as is on the north wall. The picture contains water nymphs. On the top of the wall are white architectural elements and herm like figures that are standing in plinths. We can see a door to the left and an open window containing a faraway scene between the figures. Also present are garlands.

column14: Contiguous to room #3
column21: The dining room is in the northwest corner of the house and is rectangular in shape. The room is laid out on a northeast southwest axis. Two entrances are found in the eastern corner. The entrance on the northeast wall leads to room #3. The ceiling is barrel vaulted with a second floor above. The floor is cement with multiple fragments of small white marble. On the north and south walls are large couch niches. The dining room is decorated in third style.

column14: Couch Niche (2074) found on the opposite wall of the room.
column16: Couch Niche (2074) found on the opposite wall of the room.
column21: The large couch niche is located on the southeast of the dining room. It is rectangular is shape and the top curves in slightly. The décor in the niche continues the décor found on the rest of the wall.

column14: Couch niche (2073) found on the opposite wall of the room.
column16: Couch niche (2073) found on the opposite wall of the room.
column21: The large couch niche is located on the northwest wall of the dining room. It is rectangular is shape and the top curves in slightly. The décor in the niche continues the décor found on the rest of the wall.

column14: 14 to the north, 16 to the west, Eschebach map shows stairs to the floor above in the southwest corner beginning in atrium. No traces of this survived.
column15: 14 to the north, 16 to the west, Eschenbach map shows stairs to the floor above in the south-west corner beginning in atrium. No traces of this survived.
column21: Large rectangular dining room opening east/west axis to atrium 16. Marble threshold in west doorway.
