Marble chip floor, early third style paintings well preserved on northeast and south walls with alternating red and yellow panels. The paintings in the center of the north wall is poorly preserved but shows a female figure holding a jug in her right hand, a variety of tableware and a large amphora. The painting in the center of the east wall is not discernible, below is a scene of two blue birds on either side of a pair of fruit. The central scene on the south wall shows a series of male and female figures, animals, cupid seated around a pool (need to check myth diana/ acteon? Narcissus?) (will check PPM). Architectural molding survives at top of the eastern wall. At western end of the north there is a doorway to 14.

column14: Room #8 to the east.
column21: Rectangular shaped room with a doorway in the center of the east wall. Along 3/4 of the north wall, beginning in the northeast corner, is a low, narrow cooking platform (2077). At the western half of the north wall are five large holes for beams supporting the floor above. The southwest corner is obscured by pipes and tiles and floor fragments. In the center of the south wall there is a blocked doorway.

column14: None
column21: Long narrow rectangular shaped masonry cooking platform found in the northeast corner. Collapsed in the middle front of the platform. The surface is obscured by earth but where is it is visible, consists of tile.

column14: None
column21: The drain has 9 by 11 holes and is rectangular in shape. Along the eastern section the cover is damaged with a small semicircular hole. The material is unknown, however, most likely lead.

column14: Dining room (13) to the north.
column21: The room is small and rectangular in shape and is entered through a door found on the east wall of the atrium. The floor of the storeroom is earth with no signs of tessera. A high and narrow window is found on the east wall. Also on the east wall are post holes, possibly for storage shelving. Some remains of plaster are found on the walls. The doorway has a marble lintel with two steps; the first much larger than the second. Doorway also showing marking to enable the ability to secure the entrance to this room. Ceiling is entirely reconstructed in concrete.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: 15 amphorae found in Blacksmith workshop per Eschebach, page 45. No record of their content.

column14: Room 6 to the north. Room 2 to the south.
column15: Room 6 to the north. Room 2 to the south.
column21: Rectangular shaped dining room on a east-west axis. Doorway with threshold opening south to atrium (2). Doorway in the northwest corner of the north wall leading to room 6. The floor is obscured by lapilli. No extant decoration. Blocked doorway in the northwest corner of the west wall opening to room 10 of the house of I.VIII.14.

column14: Opening to space 13, identified by Della Corte as a work area. However it looks more like a former peristyle.
column15: Opening to space 13, identified by delle Corte as a work area. However it looks more like a former peristyle.
column21: The entrance is southwest and is a large entrance, roughly square with a brick curb corner. On the east wall is an entrance to a room filled with a mount of debris. On the remaining walls there is lime stone. There is some evidence of cement on the floor and a rectangular tufa with a dug out circle in the middle, use unknown. This dining room looks out at an ovticular shrine and an area either used for work or possibly a garden, although Jashemski does not list it. At the front entrance you can see a small toilet hourse. In the west wall is a large window which has been filled.

column14: Atrium (7) to the southwest
column21: The kitchen is located in the north corner of the house, behind the garden. One enters the kitchen from the atrium (7). To the left of the entrance in room #7 there is a structure which may have been a lararium. The kitchen is rectangular in shape, on a northeast southwest axis. The entire back part of the room, approximately 1/2 of the room, is a visible platform. In the eastern corner at the rear seems to have been the location of a brazier. The flooring of the raised platform is made of plaster with terracotta fragments embedded. In the northeast wall, near the ceiling was a large window. The walls at one time were painted, perhaps reddish but little remains. The lower floor may have been constructed in a fashion similar to the platform. The threshold leading to the room is rather rustic and not sculpted in any way.

column16: Room 3 to the nrotheast, room 2 to the northwest.
column21: Square sales room opening south to the street.  The wall of the street outside has been built up.  In the corner of the room there is a large L-shaped sales counter with six dolia and a hearth, plaster survives on the north, east and west walls with traces of red paint and high along the east wall the decoration survives consisting of red rectangular panels and lines on a white background.  In the east wall there are 4 narrow slits to the street outside - Modern(?). In the northeast corner of the east wall the plaster has been reworked prior to restoration with stripping to provide a surface over which a new layer of plaster can be laid.  In the east wall above the end of the northeast wall of the counter there is a niched lararium 2086.

column14: Lararium 2086 is above the northern end of the eastern arm in the east wall.
column16: Lararium 2086 is above the northern end of the eatern arm in the east wall.
column21: U-shaped plastered masonry counter are six dolia.  At the northern end, the east arm of the counter is damaged exposing the broken dolium inside.  The surface of the counter is plastered.  The two dolia in the eastern arm are spherical with narrower mounds compared to the wider mouth and rectangular profiles of the four remaining dolia along the southern and western arms.  At the northern end of the western arm there is a brick built cooking hearth.

column14: Above the northeast end of the eastern arm of the counter (2085).
column16: Above the north-east end of the eastern arm of the counter (2085).
column21: Square niches lararium lined with plaster. Faded red paint on the rear of the niche, no other decoration survives. The top of the lararium is formed by a tile inserted into the wall and along the base of the lararium at the front. There is a trace of a molded lip.

column14: Posticum 16 to the east.
column21: One can enter the kitchen, located to the south, or directly through the posticum (entrance 16) to the west.  The room itself is rectangular in shape, on a North south axis.  The back part of the room, along the eastern wall, extending it full width, is a cooking platform.  In front of the cooking platform abutting the north wall, is a semicircular water basin opening into a cistern embedded in the floor (#2091).  At the SW corner of the room is a small, oblong trough of unknown function, perhaps water.  The room as extent shows no sign of decoration, but there is some painted stucco in the north corner of the cooking platform.  On the east wall, near the SE corner, above the cooking platform, is a hole that may have held a lararium, but is too destroyed to determine.

column14: Water basin/cistern (2091) to the west, trough (2092) to SW.
column16: Water basin/cistern (2091) to the west, trough (2092) to SW.
column21: The back part of the room, along the eastern wall, extending its full length, is a cooking platform.  The surface of the platform has been destroyed.  On the north corner of the cooking platform are the remains of the wall plaster with red paint still remaining.  It appears that the cooking platform had been inserted into the room as an addition.

column14: Contiguous to room 6 to the east and room to the south
column15: Contiguous to room 6 to the east and rom to the south
column21: A rectangular room - only N and W walls survived, making the relationship of the room with the other rooms difficult to determine.  In the center of the west wall white plaster survives with rectangular couch niche surviving below.  A rectangular masonry plastered bench in the supporting couch?  Traces of black plaster survive in the western corner of the North wall.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  A plastered channel runs along the west wall preserved in places.  Eschebach calls this a courtyard identification as a dining room based on the presence of the couch niche.  Fragments of Opus Signinum floor survives against the west wall approximately 3/4 of the way down to the south.

column14: In the NW corner of Room 5.
column16: In the NW corner of Room 5.
column21: Rectangular couch niche lined with plaster - decoration is not visible - in the center of the niche there is a rectangular masonry plaster-lined bench to support the couch.  Traces of black paint in the plaster.

column14: Cooking platform (2088) to the east, trough (2092) to the south.
column16: Cooking platform (2088) to the east, trough (2092) to the south.
column21: In front of the cooking platform, abutting the north wall, is a semicircular water basin, or opening to  cistern, embedded in the floor.  Its original appearance is hard to determine because of its present condition.

column14: Cooking platform (2088) to east.  Water feature (2091) to the north.
column16: Cooking platform (2088) to east.  Water feature (2091) to the north.
column21: In the SW corner of the room is a a small stone trough, E-W axis, as presently located.  Use is unknown but may have held water.  Because it seems to extend into the hallway leading to the shop to the south, the trough may not be original to the room.

column14: Room 4 to the south
column21: Small rectangular room on a north-south axis with a narrow doorway in southeast corner of the east wall opening to the latrine (2095). Traces of undecorated plaster high in the north wall. Floor obscured by debris. Northern quarter of the room consists of the platform (2094).

column14: Latrine 2095 to the east.
column21: A masonry and tile-built platform at the northern end of the kitchen.  The surface is obscured by debris.

column14: Cooking platform 2094 to the west.
column21: The room is completely obscured by earth.  It is identified as a latrine by Eschebach and positioned in relation to the kitchen.

column14: Room 6 to the north and Room 4 to the west.
column15: Room 6 to the north and Room 4 to the west.
column21: A small, square room with traces of undecorated plaster on the north, south and east walls.  In the southeast corner, there are traces of a plastered crown molding.  In the north and south walls, there are four holes in each wall to support two sets of shelves.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  A doorway in the center of the west wall opens to Room 4, identified as a storeroom related to food and drink based on shelves and proximity to the kitchen.

column14: The room looks northwest onto the atrium.
column15: The room looks northwest onto the atrium.
column21: A dining room with an entrance to the east of the house's main entrance.  A large rectangular room on a north-south axis with one window to the street on the south wall.  There is some evidence of white, yellow and red colors on the north, probably in the Fourth Style.  The ceiling is not present, but there is evidence of a second floor above. A bench like structure made of rubble is a part of the southeast corner of the east wall.  The top of the seat is plaster with a shallow indentation for comfortable sitting.  The floor is covered by lapilli.  In the southwest corner is a large pile of rubble.  There appears to be sign of a possible couch outline near the pile.

column14: Contiguous to the atrium to the west.
column15: Contiguous to the atrium to the west.
column21: The dining room is rectangular in shape on a north-south axis.  One enters the triclinium from the west by way of the atrium. On the north wall is a lararium.  The condition of the floor is unknown since it is covered with volcanic material.  On the west wall to the north of the entrance is a window looking onto the garden.  The walls were once elaborately painted, fragments of which can be seen in the southeast corner.  Along the north wall are five column fragments but it's impossible to tell if they belong to the room  In the south wall near the southeast corner there's a large hole in the wall.  It is impossible to determine its use (other than as destruction).  On the west wall in the southwest corner there seems to have been a niche that may have been part of an earlier use of the room, as painted plaster had been painted over.

column14: None
column21: On the north wall is a small niche lararium.  It has a plaster covering on the inside and was probably painted at one time but its evidence does not remain.

column14: (1) to the south and (3) to the west.
column15: (1) to the south and (3) to the west.
column21: Small square room with wide doorway opening to sales room #1 to the south.  Traces of plaster survive on E and SW walls.  Shallow high recesses in the NE half of the east wall and NW half of the W wall.  For furniture cocciopesto floor.  Traces of red paint survive on plaster in SW corner.  Blocked doorway in center of W wall converted into a window.

column14: Opens to the atrium on the southeast.
column15: Opens to the atrium on the southeast.
column21: The dining tablinum is located on the west side of the atrium.  The room is roughly square in shape and opens the full width of its opening to the atrium to the southeast.  The room was capable of being closed off, as evidenced by sockets on either side.  The walls were originally decorated in the third style, as can be seen from the remnants on the northwest wall.  The floor appears to have been made of beaten plaster.

column14: Kitchen storage to the southeast; atrium to the south.
column15: Kitchen storage to the southeast; atrium to the south.
column21: Room 9 is entered through the door from the atrium.  This entrance passage is piled high with rubble, lapilli and earth.  An eastern door leads to the kitchen.  The doorway next to this door is a stairway to the upper floor with access to the storage area.  Next to this is a low wall.  This area shows no sign of a roof.  On the south wall is a large dolium half broken away probably for water.  Next to it is a red circle, now filled, and probably a cistern.

column14: Room !0 the east; Room 9 to the north.
column15: Room !0 the east; Room 9 to the north.
column21: A small rectangular room with an east-west axis.  The floor is obscured by debris; the roof, modern.  The doorway to Room 9 is in the center of the north wall to the west of the doorway.  In the north wall is a downspout drain lined with terra cotta.  In the east wall is a partially or totally blocked doorway into Room 10.  Debris obscures much of the doorway making it impossible to determine how much is obscured.  The room may have been originally a bedroom with original decoration surviving in the southwest corner where there is red lower register.  The function of the room seems to have changed with an activity relating to the adjoining kitchen -- a storeroom?  A large lararium has been inserted in the south wall.  The original decoration of the bedroom has been prepared for a new layer of plaster an the lararium painting has been overlaid over the earlier layer of plaster.  The lararium consists of a vaulted, plaster niche with tiled base -- traces of red painted survive.  In either side of the niche, figures of two lares.  Below the lararium niche is a pine cone and altar between two snakes.

column14: W/NW to 2105.
column21: On the southeast wall is a rubble semicircle.  Within the semicircle is a circle that probably led to a cistern.  It had a plastered top.

column14: S/SE to 2104.
column21: A large ceramic dolium is embedded in the floor in the south wall.  Wooden clamps hold the back together.  Two-thirds are gone.  It's up against the south wall.

column14: None
column21: The large lararium is inserted in the south wall.  The original decoration of the bedroom has been prepared for a new layer of plaster and the lararium painting has been overlaid by an earlier layer of plaster.  The lararium consists of a vaulted plaster-lined niche with tiled base -- traces of red paint survive.  On either side of the niche are figures of two faces.  Below the lararium niche is a pine cone and altar between two snakes.

column14: Room 14 to the north, Peristyle (7) to the south.
column15: Room 14 to the north, Peristyle (7) to the south.
column21: Small rectangular room with a southeast northwest axis. Doorway is in the northwest corner with another doorway in the southwest corner. Well preserved opus signinum floor with a lip at threshold to the northwest door. The rooms seems to have originally been an andron decorated in 4th style of which a substantial panel survives on the wall in 14 and traces survives in 13. The room was then transformed for use as a kitchen although traces of the original décor survives on the east wall and at the junction of 2110 on the west wall. Decoration survives on south wall as well. The decoration consists of yellow panels with red borders. There is  blocked doorway with surviving plaster facing in center of the east wall. There is a low rectangular masonry corking platform (2111) in the north northeast corner. A semicircular platform (2110) is also found against the wall

column14: Stairs go up to/down from the peristyle.
column15: Stairs go up to/down from the peristyle.
column21: Storage room below kitchen. The entrance to the underground storeroom is located in the NW corner of the peristyle.  One descends into the storeroom down an undetermined number of stairs to the NW.  The room is vaulted and has been subdivided at a right angle to the axis of the room, leaving access to the back of the room on the W side.  Behind the dividing wall is a low wall subdividing the back of the room into two parts.  This low wall is also at a 90 degree angle to the axis.  The axis of the room is NW/SE.  The west corner of the room appears to continue down.  However, it is difficult to tell if that is merely destruction.  Walls were plastered but it cannot be determined if they were painted.  The floor of the room is covered with rubble and is not visible.

column14: Peristyle to South and Tablinum to West
column15: Peristyle to South and Tablinum to West
column21: One enters the room from the tablinum through a door on the east wall of the tablinum.  The dining room is rectangular in shape, on a SE/NW axis.  On the S wall is a large window opening onto the peristyle.  In the N wall is a small window at higher elevation that the window in the S wall.  The window on the N wall looks into room 5.  The dining room was originally well decorated in the Fourth style, large sections of which remain.  As part of the decoration of E and W walls, at halfway point of each, is an engaged column of stucco; at the top of each is a damaged (possibly Corinthian) column.  It is impossible to tell what kind of floor remains.  As reconstructed, the N half of the ceiling of the room is lower than the front or S half.

column14: Platform 2111 to East
column21: Semicircular masonry platform: Added against W wall; yellow plaster survives behind platform.  The surface is tiled and slopes towards wall to W where there is a terracotta drain sloping W to drain outside.

column14: None
column21: Low masonry square cooking platform inserted into N/NE corner:Surface does not survive.  The platform is against the original plaster decoration and blocked wall to E.  A stone threshold has been placed against the S end - not in situ.

column14: Atrium to W; Room 3 to N; Room 5 to S.
column15: Atrium to W; Room 3 to N; Room 5 to S.
column21: Dining room: There is a large doorway with a wide marble threshold into the room which is roughly square, without a ceiling.  The room looks onto an atrium with highly decorated impluvium.  Mosaic floor in room shows a couch pattern for wooden couches.  Central emblems.  There are 9 peach, beige, brown-colored tiles enclosed by a marble square.  Evidence of spots where other marble floors show.  Door on N to cubiculum and a larger door to SE.  On entering this adjoining room we see couch niches which have been filled in.  The dining room walls have been stuccoed but there is no evidence of paint.  There is a good view of the atrium.
column53: One colour photo with Bob Curtis

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. page 919-920
column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: The entire dining room is missing as it has collapsed into the structure below.

column14: Opens onto shop on the NW; opens to room 5 in the SE.
column15: Opens onto shop on the NW; opens to room 5 in the SE.
column21: Dining Room 4 lies to the SE of the counter room. Roughly rectangular in shape, on a NW/SE axis. The entrance to the dining room opens to it's full width. On the SW wall is a small window opening to it's atrium. A larger window on the SE wall opens onto room 5. Floor seems to be of beaten cement. Walls were elaborately decorated and painted. May have been a doorway leading into the atrium on NW corner of room, but was closed off.

column14: Dining rooms to the SE and S
column15: Dining rooms to the SE and S
column21: One enters the shop from the NW at entrance 4. Access is at north corner since the north arm of the counter stretches almost across width of entrance. Approximately 5' into shop on the floor is a brace to secure door at night. Room is roughly square in shape. To SE, open across the width of the shop is entrance to room 4. The counter occupies most of the west part of the room, and is constructed with 3 arms. The NW arm parallels the street. The SW arm abuts the SW wall. The long arm is at a right angle to NW arm, extends most most of the ay into the shop. In SW corner is a door leading to room 2. In the south corner of back wall is a window opening onto the atrium (16). This opening may have been a door previously, as it seems to be partially blocked. This opening may have been a door previously, as it seems to be partially blocked. On NE wall are 2 large holes, one near the north corner of the room, and the second about half way in. Below the half way hole are 2 small rectangular holes. These may have supported shelves (?). The room was plastered and painted and it shows signs of redecoration. The floor seems to be of beaten cement.

column14: None
column21: The counter occupies the west portion of the room. It is a U shaped, open to the interior. As reconstructed, the countertop has colored marble fragments. Two dolia are embedded on west arm, 2 embedded in east arm. Between the west dolia is a 3 step counter. Below the 3 step counter is a storage area, the floor of which is marble. The marble " floor" of the under-counter storage has a removable slab. Below the lid/slab appears to have been a space for storage (?). On the south end of the eastern arm is a hearth. The hearth is rectangular in shape on a NW/SE axis. The fire would have sat in the middle with pots placed above it, using the the east and west arms of the hearth as support. The SE end of the hearth is closed off. The north arm of the counter has a rectangular indentation where the north and west arms meet.

column14: None
column21: Dining room is rectangular with a NW to SE axis opening south to atrium 16. There is a doorway in SE corner opening to shop room 3. The upper courses of walls are heavily restored. Traces of undecorated plaster survives on east jamb of the south doorway. The NW corner has a section of non-extant wall, but none of the plans show a doorway here. Floor is obscured by lapilli. Identification as dining room based on shape of room, south doorway and position with view of the atrium.

column14: None
column21: Rectangular room on East/west axis. Opening to tablinum to west. Vaulted ceiling w/molding surviving against the N,E and S walls. The paintings are fourth style; yellow backgrounds with red trim. Red lower register w/plant motifs. The central painting is removed from north wall and not discernible on east and south walls. A window opens to garden in S/SW corner with modern shuttering. The floor is obscured by dirt and boxes of the custodi which are stored here.

Shallow, plastered, well preserved couch niche in north corner of room. The decoration is contiguous with the decoration for the rest of the room, with red background with plant motif with yellow panels above, in the fourth style. The niche runs for almost entire north wall from NE corner to almost NW corner.

column14: Room 10 is to the east; room 12 to the south; room 9 to the north.
column15: Room 10 is to the east; room 12 to the south; room 9 to the north.
column21: Rectangular room on eat/west axis. Doorway in the north corner of east wall opens to room 10. Doorway in west corner of south wall opens to room 12. Doorway in north corner of west wall opens to peristyle. Western third of of room consists of stairs down from the garden above, divided from the rest of the room by a low masonry wall. Fragments of undecorated plaster survive on all walls. A low arch is in the center of the south wall, subsequently filled in. There is a low masonry cooking platform 2121 in the center of the north wall.

column14: None
column21: Low, rectangular cooking platform poorly preserved. Earth obscures the platform itself and the facing. There are some visible tiles through the surface. Located against north center wall of room.

column14: None
column21: Small, square room with doorway to the west to kitchen 11. Undecorated plaster survives on all four walls. The floor is obscured by earth. There is a rectangular masonry platform with large central recess that runs along the south to east corner of the room. The platform would have supported a seat of a latrine, but now the drain underneath is obscured by the earth.

column14: Kitchen 11 is to the north.
column21: Rectangular room, north/south axis. Undecorated plaster survives on all 4 walls with multiple layers on east wall. Earlier layer of red and yellow plaster visible below final phase. Blocked archway in center of north wall opening to kitchen. Along the east wall, there are 3 masonry bases in north corner, south corner/support for a platform or bench. Locked doorway collapsed in the center of the south wall. Floor is obscured by earth. Two rounded windows on center upper east and south walls. East window is closed up.

column14: Atrium (reception room) 16, and room 6, dining room
column15: Atrium (reception room) 16, and room 6, dining room
column21: Small dining room has E/W axis with entrance 6" lower than previous atrium, which may now serve as a reception area for a restaurant. Fourth style painting. NW wall has a window to the dining room off counter room. On NE wall is a high window. The room shows evidence of 4th style with beach deco and stencil work in red and brownish red. On north wall it appears as if a picture has been removed from a yellow painted surface. Above the second stencil area is a red picture with perhaps a water scene. Modern ceiling. Bare floor, except concrete work at entrance.

column14: Atrium to the north. Window to peristyle to the south.
column15: Atrium to the north. Window to peristyl to the south.
column21: One enters the room from the atrium to the north. The room is roughly rectangular on a N/S axis. In the south end is a large window opening onto the peristyle. At present there are numerous amphorae stacked along the east wall. Walls of the room were stuccoed. Decoration (if any) no longer exists. The floor is too heavily damaged to tell what it was made of.

column14: South wall kitchen with latrine, room 11. 13 and 18 to the north.
column15: South wall kitchen with latrine, room 11. 13 and 18 to the north.
column21: Large dining garden with portico at north end. Enter from extension of the tablinum which has a roof supported by two double columns. We can see 5 columns begin a colonnade. Two are stuccoed and three are bare brick. On the west wall there is a lararium niche. The wall shows minimal painting and small sections of molding. The colors are white and red. On south wall there is evidence of fourth style; lowest register is black, stenciling above, brownish yellow. Above that is red in color. This large area could have accommodated wooden biclinia and triclinia. There's evidence of a cistern and puteoli in NE entrance. North portico had a statue of a young boy with a dove on NW corner.

column14: Room 14 behind the Tablinum SW; S corner opening to bedroom.
column15: Room 14 behind the Tablinum SW; S corner opening to bedroom.
column21: Large dining room: One enters the dining room from the SW corner from Room 14 behind the tablinum.  In the S corner is a doorway into the small bedroom.  The dining room is rectangular in shape on a SE/NW axis.  The floor is of cement with a simple black and white mosaic design.  Black and white tesserae except for the center of the room which has a large rectangular mosaic design.  The design is more complicated.  The walls are intricately decorated in late Third style or early Fourth.  In the center of each wall are large rectangular panels showing mythological scenes.  In the SW upper corner stucco suggests a vaulted ceiling.

column14: Kitchen 10 is to the E, peristyle 13 to the NW.
column15: Kitchen 10 is to the E, peristyle 13 to the NW.
column21: Large rectangular room opening to the peristyle to the N.  A doorway in the W corner of the E wall opens to the kitchen (room 10). No decorations survive on any of the walls.  The floor is coccio pesto with white tessarae in geometric patterns.  Large areas of the floor are crumbling away.  On either side of the peristyle entrance stone supports the door.

column14: Opens onto the peristyle garden
column21: Dining Room: This room is a dining room overlooking the garden.  A large entrance with a raised (4") marble threshold enters through a large SW  entrance from the peristyle garden.  A central emblem contains 16 marble rectangles; colors are white, peach, pink, black and gray.  The NE wall is missing decoration except for the top design - 2 sections of molding.  There are rectangles of red, yellow and Betty's favorite green.  The S wall contains 7 rectangular post holes as does the N wall.

column14: Latrine to N and street to SE
column15: Latrine to N and street to SE
column21: Kitchen is roughly square and is located in SE corner of house to E of garden.  There is a posticum to side street on NE corner of room.  One enters the room from W corner by passing through the latrine.  On SW wall at W and S corners are masonry and rubble platforms, roughly square in shape in S corner but rectangular in W corner. The platforms may have served as supports for a wooden table or may have served other uses.  No evidence of decoration extant.  On NE wall (high) is a window looking out onto the street.  Beam holes high on two walls indicate a second floor above.

column14: SW 2132 cooking platform in kitchen area
column16: SW 2132 cooking platform in kitchen area
column21: Latrine lies to N of kitchen area and is rectangular in shape on E/W axis.  As reconstructed, it is a "one-seater."  The seat lies above a sump which slopes down toward the street.  Roof tiles direct materials down toward an opening in the wall which goes under the street and probably into the sewer.  On the E wall, above the seat, is a window opening into the street.

column14: NE 2131 Latrine 1
column21: On SW wall at W and S corners: masonry and rubble platforms which may have supported a wooden table.  The S platform is square and the W platform rectangular.

column14: The fauces enters the atrium.  There are two bedrooms on the northeast wall.  A hallway and bedroom are on the southwest wall.
column15: The fauces enters the atrium.  There ar two bedroms on the northeast wall.  A hallway and bedroom are on the southwest wall.
column21: One enters the atrium from the fauces on the NE side.   The atrium is rectangular in shape on a NW-SE axis.  The north corner is a door leading to a bedroom.  There is Another opening to a bedroom to the east f the fauces.  The latter bedroom has a window looking into the atrium.  Along the southwest wall in the west corner is a doorway to a bedroom.  The southeast of that door is a hallway leading to the back of the house.  On the southwest wall, just to the southeast of the hallway, is a tank.  Above the tank is a small window looking into the kit chen.  In the south corner of the atrium is a large dolium.  The walls of the atrium were painted.  Only the color of the lower half is identifiable, a faded red.  It is not possible to determine the floor.  There is no ceiling.  Because of the reported find of four fish sauce urcei and the presence of what appears to be a water tank in the atrium, the house has been designated in literature as a fish shop.  If so, then the atrium of the house was probably a sales or preparation room.  The dolium seems to have contained lime, probably used in the reconstruction of the house as a commercial property.

column14: None
column21: A rectangular tank lies along the southwest wall to the southeast of the hallway.  The axis is roughly southeast-northwest.  It was coated inside with waterproof plaster.  It seems to  have been an addition to the atrium when the house was converted to commercial use, although the date is uncertain.  The exterior of the tank is also covered in plaster.  There is a drain in the north corner of the bottom of the tank and appears to drain under he atrium in a north-northwest direction, probably into a cistern.

column14: Room 8 to the southeast.
column21: A small rectangular room facing southeast to the entrance four Room 8.  The room is on a northwest southeast axis. The north and east walls survive, with traces of undecorated plaster.  There is a blocked doorway in the east wall into which a rectangular window has been inserted.  The west wall does not survive. The floor is obscured by lapilli.  There is a basalt mortar, perhaps used for grinding dye?  There is no reason to identify this room as a kitchen except that it is identified as such by Eschebach, page 50.

column14: Room 3 is to the north.
column21: This is a square room with two doorways in the east and west ends of the north wall.  The plans show the doorway to the west was, in fact, steps to the floor above.  In the eastern end of the north wall between the two doorways, a large terra cotta pipe has been inserted draining from the floor above.  In the center of the east wall, there is a small rectangular window that has been inserted into a blocked doorway.  Traces of plaster survive on all four walls with no visible decoration.  In the southwestern half of the south wall, there is a masonry cooking platform (2137).  The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: None
column21: This is a high, rectangular masonry cooking platform with traces of a tiled surface visible among the lichen.  The north corner has collapsed.  The platform is located in the southern corner along the western half of the southern wall.

column14: West window to former garden; north wall doorway to 3 hallway.
column15: West window to former garden; north wall doorway to 3 hallway.
column21: this is a dining room, rectangular in shape with an east-west axis.  A door opens on the north wall in the northwest corner.  A large window opens on the west wall which overlooks a small garden area, although the garden area has been paved.  There is a couch niche with black paint on he northeast wall.  On the east wall, the yellow-white color is also apparent with a red stripe.  On the west wall beneath the window, black paint is covered over with rubble and then replastered with block in the lower register.  The floor is covered with dirt and lapilli.  There is evidence of both ancient and modern reconstruction.

column14: None
column21: On the northeast wall is a couch niche that shows black paint.  There is moderate preservation.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE:  5 urceii, four containing fish sauce and one containing "defrutum" (four Romulus "garum").

column14: The atrium to the northwest; the storeroom to the southwest.
column15: The atrium to the northwest; the storeroom to the southwest.
column21: One enters the kitchen from the atrium to the northwest.  The kitchen is rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis.  On the southwest wall there is a doorway leading to he store room.  Along the southeast wall on the right is a cooking platform and on the left the latrine.  The kitchen seems to be at a slight elevation in comparison with the atrium.  The walls may have been painted at one time, but no evidence remains.  On the northeast wall, high up, there are two small windows.  On the southeast wall, above the cooking platform, is another window.  The type of floor cannot be ascertained.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform lies along the southeast wall as a tiled surface and may have had a lip.  On the eastern end of the platform is a low wall guilt up to conceal the latrine to the northeast.

column14: None
column21: The latrine is located to the northeast of the cooking platform and seems to be built up with stones.  The front part of the latrine seems to slope toward the rear, perhaps allowing the pour of the latrine into the sump.

column14: Room 1 to the east.
column21: This is a large rectangular room on an east-west axis.  There is a doorway in the center of the east wall and high window brackets (original ?) in the north end of the east wall.  Undecorated plaster survives in patches on all four walls.  There are also possible traces of red in the lower register with yellow in the upper register on the south wall.  It is a Cocciopesto floor with chips in a variety of colors.  The room was identified as a dining room by Eschebach, page 50.  There is a possible blocked couch niche in the northwest corner.

column14: Kitchen to the northeast.
column21: One enters the storeroom from an area of the kitchen to the northeast.  The storeroom is rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis.  The type of floor cannot be ascertained because of the rubble.  On the southwest and southeast walls there appear to be beam holes for supporting he roof.  The walls were one time finished but the decoration does not exist, if any.

column14: Room 1 to the north.
column21: This is a small rectangular room on an east-west axis.  There is a doorway in the center of the north wall.  High in the west wall are three supports for floor joists supporting the floor above.  In the northwest corner, there is a fragment of undecorated plaster that has been prepared for redecoration.  In the northwest corner there is volcanic debris, in situ, containing an amphora (2147) in situ.  The floor is obscured by earth.  A possible plastered window survives, in part, in the center of the extensively collapsed south wall.

column14: None
column21: An amphora embedded in volcanic debris is located in the northwest corner of the room.  Flamiar amphora - either an halion imitation or Rhodin vessel or directly ??.  Parella, c "shratigrafie Della terme O st ie use Della N uotafore" Recherches sur les Amphores kerieincs (Ecole francaise des Rome 10, 1972) p. 73.

column14: Storeroom #8 to the north; kitchen/latrine to the northwest; and Room 2 to the northwest.
column15: Storeroom #8 to the north; kitchen/latrine to the northwest; and Room 2 to the northwest.
column21: One enters the shop from the south through entrance #11.  The room is rectangular on a east-west axis.  The eastern part of the room is taken up by an L-shaped counter and work area.  To the north is an entrance to a storeroom (#8).  On the northwest corner is the entrance to Room 2.  In the northwest corner is also the opening to the kitchen and latrine (#7).  The walls of the counter room were probably decorated atone time, but no trace remains.  The type of floor is indeterminate.

column14: None
column15: Room 8 to the north; cntained within Room 1.
column21: The L-shaped counter is located in the east corner of the room.  One arm is perpendicular to the street; the second is parallel to the street.  The arm on the east and parallel to the street has a 4-stepped shelf.  As reconstructed, there are no dolia, nor is there conclusive evidence of a hearth.  The counter may have been coasted with a surface, but it no longer exists.  As reconstructed, t counter top on both arms is made of pieces of colored marble.

column14: Room 1 to the south.
column21: The storeroom is entered from the south, trough the counter room.  It is rectangular in shape on a southwest-northeast axis.  The north wall has a narrow shelf stretching across its full width.  High on the north wall appears to be beams supporting the second floor.  The type of floor is undetermined.  Walls were decorated at one time, but little remains to distinguish it.

column14: Room 1 is to the south; Room 6 is to the north.
column15: Room 1 is to the south; Room 6 is to the north.
column21: This is a square room with a doorway to Room 1 in the center of the south wall.  In the center of the north wall, there is a doorway with a stepped threshold leading to Garden 6.  Along the west wall, there is Latrine 2153 ad in the northeast corner there is Masonry Cooking Platform 2152.  On top of the platform is the base of an amphora.  High in the north corner, there are two circular holes - collapsed? - or support of the floor above?  In the southeast corner there is a rectangular base supporting a wooden bench?  The original tile floor is only visible in front of the latrine.  The rest is obscured by earth.

column14: None
column21: A low rectangular masonry cooking platform.  The surface does not survive.  NE corner of the kitchen.

column14: None
column15: The cooking platform (2152) is to the norteast.
column21: A rectangular masonry bench is located along the west side of the room.  In the center there is a rectangular recess for the seat.  Beneath the seat, a tile floor slopes toward the drain.  The drain is filled with earth.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE:  A masonry triclinium couch. Eschebach:  P. 50 refers to the existence of a masonry triclinium under a pergola. Jashemski:  45

column14: Room 1 to the east; Room 3 to the north.
column15: Room 1 to the east; Room 3 to the north.
column21: This is a square room.  The floor has been dug out revealing an earlier phase of construction.  The room has undergone extensive modifications.  The wall from the north corner extending to the west includes two brick-built columns into which a wall has subsequently been built, and the excavated area reveals a smaller square room from an earlier phase.  Along the northwest and south walls, traces of red painted plaster survive.  To the north there are alcoves contiguous with this room, however, they seem to have served a distinct function.  Unfortunately, the state of the room means we cannot ID the division between these areas.  Against the southwest corner there is a large plaster-lined couch niche with a central branch.  Extensive painted red plaster survives.  Above this there is a rectangular opening to the room beyond.  In the east wall, there is a doorway to adjoining properties.  The function of the room is unclear.  However, the presence of a couch niche suggests a dining function.

column14: NW -  Room 5; W - Latrine; S - Kitchen, Room 7
column15: NW -  Room 5; W - Latrine; S - Kitchen, Room 7
column21: The dining garden is entered from the south through the Kitchen 7.  It is a roughly square, large room.  Another entrance is in the northwest corner opening to a peristyle garden in Property 12.  The floor is in poor condition due to modern excavations below the AD 79 level.  With ??? Three columns in the west wall enclose a latrine.  The walls have very little remaining plaster and no remaining signs of decoration.  Eschebach refers to two water basins in the north wall with terracotta tile under the north wall as a fountain.  Basins have waterproofing cement.  18-27 ???  ???  ???  The west wall opens to Property 12.  Two negative features are important to analysis of the room, many amphora and a masonry triclinium.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Eschebach:  pp. 50-52. Jashemski 1999, 45.  Many amphora were found in the garden.

column14: None
column21: Rectangular plaster-lined couch niche; In center of niche is a masonry plastered bench.  Plaster is painted red throughout.

column14: Room 6 to E, Room 11 to N, 13 to W and 15 to S.
column15: Room 6 ro E, Room 11 to N, 13 to W and 15 to S.
column21: Rectangular dining tablinum N/S axis.  Wide doorway opening N into peristyle and large wide window across south wall looking into the atrium.  White mosaic floor with black border and black geometric central rosette.  There are three couch niches in W, S and SE corners.  In the S/SW corner there is a rectangular preserved chest not in situ.  The room is decorated with early 3rd style painting surviving on E, W and S walls.  Black lower register with red panels above with blue and yellow trim, with white above.  In NE corner there is a narrow doorway with threshold opening to room 6 to the east.  In NW there is a narrow doorway with a mosaic threshold opening to room 13.  The threshold of the N doorway to peristyle consists of a polychrome mosaic pattern consisting of a series of squares surrounded by a rectangular black border with white, red, burgundy and blue patterns.  At the base of either side of the doorway is a marble slab with base for a barrier of some kind in the E side of the door.  Ceiling has been reconstructed, but traces of plaster molding on E and W walls remain.

column14: None
column21: Long deep couch niche running along 3/4 of S wall from E towards W.  No traces of plaster survive.  In center of niche is a rectangular masonry bench.

column14: 2160 and 2165 to E.
column21: Long shallow couch niche along W wall running approximately 3/4 length of wall from S.  Mosaic does not extend into niche which is floored with stone slabs.  No traces of decoration survive on plaster fragments.

column14: The atrium to the west.
column21: Triclinium is located in the E Corner of the atrium.  One enters the room from the doorway in the W corner.  Room is rectangular in shape on SE/NW axis.  The walls were elaborately painted with what appears to be transitional 1st to 2nd style.  The bottom seemed to show garlands.  The floor is of cement with random placement of small pieces of white marble in black basalt.  The roof is not extant but has been reconstructed.  The beam holes seem to indicate where beams are placed.  High on the NE wall is a break in the wall which may have been a window.  High on the SE wall as reconstructed the portion of the wall between the two center beams and at the level of the vaulted roof slopes to the SW, thereby creating a slot that allows in light.  It's unclear if this reflects original construction.  Extant plaster implies roof was vaulted.

column14: 2164 couch niche west.
column21: In the SE corner of the east wall is a couch niche approximately half the length of the niche on the opposite wall.  It is also taller than the niche on  the opposite wall.  This niche is cut deeper into the wall with the top sloping downward to a shelf.  This niche seems to continue the painting pattern of the dado.  The dado of the wall was cut into the wall so that the upper part of the wall extends slightly into the room.

column14: 2163 couch niche to E.
column21: There is a couch niche cut into the dado bottom on the SW wall, rectangular in shape.  The back of the niche has an easy curve.  As extant, it is difficult to tell if the niche is painted, though it looks like it may have been.  The niche runs approximately 3/4 of the length of the wall from back to front.

column14: 2160 an d 2161 to W and S, respectively.
column16: 2160 an d 2161 to W and S, respectively.
column21: Rectangular shallow couch niche preserved in center of E wall, extending S towards E corner of room approximately 3/4 of wall in length.  The north half of the couch is now obscured by plaster and cement from restoration.  In the center of the niche there is a shallow angled bench.  No traces of plaster survive.

column14: Garden 9 to N.  Peristyle 11 to W.
column15: Garden 9 to N.  Peristyle 11 to W.
column21: Rectangular room E-W axis.  Restored floor and ceiling; upper S and W walls restored for use by custodi.  Windows in these walls are modern.  In SE corner, custodii have installed a drain pipe leading down from ceiling.  Extensive surviving late 3rd  style painting consists of black panels with red trim.  Plaster molding for vaulted ceiling survives in N wall with holes for joists for the vaulted ceiling.  In center of N wall is a plaster lined window looking out into a garden.  This has been subsequently reduced in size (filled) by about 3/4 for use by custodi.  In SW corner is a doorway opening to Room 11.

column14: Room 9 garden south.
column21: In the NW corner of the garden is the kitchen.  One enters the kitchen through a door on the SE corner of the room.  The room is very small, rectangular in shape lying on a N/S axis.  In the SW corner, taking up about half of the W wall is a masonry structure which was probably the cooking platform as extant the center part of the structure is missing.  There could have been a wooden top to allow for cooking.  To the N of the cooking platform is a small area for a latrine.  The walls were once plastered, but no decoration remains.  The floor seems to be a beaten plaster.  As extant on the S, W and N walls there are small holes that let in light.  It is unknown if these are ancient windows.  Ceiling has been reconstructed.

column14: Latrine 2169 North.
column21: The cooking platform lies on the W wall behind the SW corner.  It is rectangular on a N/S axis.  As extant, it is made up of three masonry walls with the wall of the room serving as the 4th wall.  The center is empty.  It may have been filled in in antiquity and later emptied, or the cooking area was wooden, extending across the open area.  The outer walls of the platform may have had an exterior coating, but no longer extant.

column14: Cooking platform 2168 south.
column21: The latrine is located in the NW corner of the kitchen.  As extant, no facilities can be identified, although it appears that the latrine could be flushed with water at the bottom of the W wall onto the street outside.

column14: Garden 6 to W.
column21: Rectangular room E/W axis with doorway W to garden.  Seemingly restored, cocciopesto floor largely obscured by custodian stores.  Ceiling is restored.  High in S wall a window has been inserted.  4th style paintings on N, E and S walls with alternating red and black panels with white upper register.  In the center of the central panel on N wall is a winged female figure. To the north of the doorway, part of the marble threshold survives, and on S end as well as N placings for a door or other barrier.  The shape of painting high on E wall indicates the room was originally barrel-vaulted.

column14: 6 TO w, 5 of property 11.
column21: Rectangular room N/S axis.  In the center of the room running across from E-W is a tilted drain.  In the center to N is a sound recess inserted into the floor, the base of which is unclear.  In the center of the N wall is a blocked plaster lined doorway.  In NW corner there is a pit in the floor, function uncertain.  The south 1/3 of the room consists of a high masonry cooking platform 2172.  High in south wall is a blocked doorway from the floor above.  In the center of the W wall there is a doorway opening with stone threshold opening to the peristyle.  In the center of the E wall there is doorway opening to  room 5 for property entrance 11.  In SE corner there is a high rectangular small window.  Undecorated plaster survives in SW and NW corners.  Two sets of two niches are in the north wall for shelving in the blocked plaster mentioned above.

column14: None
column21: High rectangular masonry cooking platform across entire S wall.  Tiled surface and tiled lip survive in SW corner.

column14: Atrium to the N.
column21: Triclinium is located to the W of the fauces as one enters the house.  One enters the triclinium through the doorway in the NE corner of the room.  Room is slightly rectangular in shape on an E-W axis.  Walls were stuccoed but all e]evidence of painting is gone.  On SE wall are two small windows as extant. They seem to flank a ;large central window.  There is no way to tell if that was the  case in antiquity.  The floor is obscured by debris/earth.

column14: Peristyle to S.
column21: Narrow rectangular room at north end of peristyle on NW axis.  Undecorated painted plaster on E,W and N walls.  Cocciopesto floor.  Eschebach and Jashemski refer to amphora being stored in this room.  Base of a single amphora remains in NW corner. Also, a marble table top (decorated) in this room.  Immediately outside door to S is a rectangular drain running into E wall.

column14: Room 4 is to the east
column21: Small, square room, Jashemski identifies as a courtyard. In the NE corner there is a doorway opening to room 4. In the center of the east wall there is a window that has been restored, looking into room 4. In the SE corner there is a plastered downpipe for a drain. In the center of the south wall and in the SW corner are two niched recesses that area shaped like lararia. The niche in the center of the wall is higher than that to the west. Traces of undecorated plaster survive in the wall. In the center of the room is a buried dolium (2177). In the center of the north wall is a lararium (2179). In the NW corner, there is a cooking platform (2176) with tiled surface and recessed storage beneath. In the SW corner, there is a latrine (2178) that is separated from the rest of the room by a partitional doorway. Floor is overgrown with ivy.

column14: 2178 to the south. 2179 and 2177 to the east
column16: 2178 to the south. 2179 and 2177 to the east
column21: Masonry cooking platform in NW corner with arched recessed storage below. The surface survives intact and is tiled. The tiled lip is restored.

column14: 2179 to the north. 2176 and 2178 are to the west.
column16: 2179 to the north. 2176 and 2178 are to the west.
column21: Large dolium inserted into the floor of the room, slightly off center to the east. The dolium is filled with earth and lapilli.

column14: 2176 to the north. 2177 to the east.
column16: 2176 to the north. 2177 to the east.
column21: Narrow latrine in the SW corner of the kitchen, separated by the rest of the kitchen by a wall. The drain and floor is obscured by earth. However, on the east and west walls, recesses for a seat are clearly visible. In the south wall above the latrine, a molded lip extends across the entire wall. Above this is an arched, plaster lined niche that has been partially blocked by the addition of a partition wall separating the latrine from the rest of the kitchen. Traces of undecorated plaster survive on the east and west walls. In the NW corner of the west wall is a low, arched recess for a lamp. (?) At the junction of the latrine with cooking platform 2176 is a plastered, circular hole running into the wall. There are 2 rectangular holes in the wall that separates the latrine form the cooking platform.

column14: 2177 to south. 2176 to the west.
column21: Plastered, niched lararium on north wall. Traces of yellow paint survive on the base. No other visible decoration.

column14: Room 3 to the SE and Room 4 to the SW
column15: Room 3 to the SE and Room 4 to the SW
column21: Square room with wide doorway (threshold does not survive) which opens to the street to the N.  In the center of the room is a poorly preserved U-shaped counter, 2181. On the E and W walls red painted plaster survives. In the E wall there are two niches supporting a shelf.  In the NW corner there is a rectangular recess leading through to the fauces.  The doorway in the SE opens to a storeroom; the doorway in the SW opens to the atrium.  The floor is obscured by lapilli and earth.

column14: None
column21: Poorly preserved U-shaped counter with the long surface to the West.  The lower courses have been fortified.  The upper courses and surface do not survive.  The bases of two terracotta dolia survive in the counter.  There is a rectangular hearth at the southern end of the counter.

column14: Room 2 to the north
column21: Rectangular Storeroom on a N/S axis with doorway and jamb opening N to counter room 2.  Traces of yellow painted plaster survive on the E wall.  The W wall is a modern reconstruction.  The floor's surface is obscured by earth and lapilli.  A square stone stands in NE corner with red painted plaster on N and E faces.  The upper levels of all walls are extensively restored.

column14: Room 4 to N; Room 6 to S.
column15: Room 4 to N; Room 6 to S.
column21: This is a square room opening to the atrium.  There is a cocciopesto floor with a grid of white tesserae.  At the threshold of the room the grid is replaced by a geometric pattern of white tesserae that survives in the NW corner.  White Third Style painting with red borders survives in the SW corner.  In the center of the S wall there is a wide window looking into a light-well/garden

column14: Room 8 to N.
column21: Small rectangular room on an E/W axis at the rear of the property.  The N wall does not survive.  Plaster survives on the W wall with red lower register and white above.  In the SW corner there is a plaster lined drain inserted into the wall which then runs down into the latrine (2185).  Along the W wall is a line of 8 holes for shelves; three of the holes are in Room 7 and the remainder continue along the wall to the N of the room (8 and 9) identified as the kitchen based on size, position and latrine.

column14: None
column21: Latrine in SW corner of room with base of masonry support for a seat.  The masonry support for the west side of the latrine does not survive. The drain itself is visible only at the subsidence in the floor, obscured by earth, lapilli, tiles and stone blocks.  Behind the center of the latrine in S wall there is a recessed plaster-lined drain running down the wall from the floor above and emptying into the drain beneath the latrine.

column14: Room 12 to the east
column21: Rectangular kitchen on a N/S axis. It has a restored wooden and stone wall on the north and east corners that is separated from the stairs above, running along the north and west side of the room. There is a wide open doorway on the east to peristyle 12. The floor is obscured by earth. Traces of plaster survive on the south and west walls. Traces of decoration survive on the south wall with lower register. In the register above is a large, circular motif. In the SW corner is a small, plaster corner shelf. The west wall consists of a large, well preserved cooking platform masonry with traces of plaster facing. Arched spacing beneath. Tiled surface with tiled lip at front and rear. In the SW half of the cooking platform are 3 masonry supports for cooking. Above the platform is an arched ceiling supporting the stairs above.

column14: None
column21: The west wall consists of a large, well preserved cooking platform, masonry with traces of plaster facing. Arched spacing beneath. It also consists of a tiled surface with tiled lip at the front and rear. In the SW half of the cooking platform there are 3 masonry supports for cooking. Above the platform is an arched ceiling supporting the stairs above.

column14: Peristyle 12 and kitchen 11 to south. Tablinum 8 to east.
column15: Peristyle 12 and kitchen 11 to south. Tablinum 8 to east.
column21: Rectangular room with N/S axis. Doorway in center of south wall looking out  to garden with peristyle. In the SE corner there is a narrow doorway to room 8. High in the center of east wall there is an unfinished square window. In the NW corner of the north  wall and south half of west wall, there are two openings cut through the wall by looters/excavators. On all 4 walls there are decorations of 3rd style; black lower register with plant motifs, red panels above with architectural trim. In the west wall and NW corner, there are traces of plaster molding with yellow panels above and black trim. Two central paintings survive in north and west walls. The west wall is poorly preserved but shows a togatge figure to the right. The north scene shows dining (2189). The floor consists of marble chipping; any decorative motif is obscured. Fragments of painted ceiling have been restored on north half of the room (with geometric pattern decoration). Traces of vaulting survive in plaster on celling in south half of room.

column14: None
column21: In center of north wall: Dining scene. Two diners, male on right, female to his left, reclining on a couch. At the foot of the couch to left of scene, there are two male slaves. The slave to the far left is holding a tray. Teo possible figures at rear center of scene. The architectural backdrop consists of columns with hanging curtains between. To the right of the dining couch, there is a large circular object. (A shield?) There are buildings behind the people. The shield may be resting on a LOW semicircular table.

column14: Room 10 to the north. Room 12 to the south. Room 8 to the west.
column15: Room 10 to the north. Room 12 to the south. Room 8 to the west.
column21: The dining room is located on the SE corner of the house, opening onto the back garden to the south. One can enter from the tablinum in the south corner. The room is rectangular on the N/S axis. The opening to the garden to the south is almost full width of the room. The floor is in cement with a simple white marble design. In the NW corner is a couch niche, just to the south of which was found at least one, possibly two humans and a dog; the bones remain in situ. The walls are decorated in the 4th style with large panels on the east and west walls. On the east wall inserted into the panel later is a small lararium. On the north wall is a window into room 10. The ceiling isn't extent, but has been reconstructed and there is no evidence that it was vaulted.

column14: The lararium on the east wall
column16: The lararium on the east wall
column21: In the northwest corner of the west wall is a couch niche which slopes gradually inward from the top and appears to continue the black paint of the dado of the 4th style wall painting.

column14: The niche on the NW corner of the W wall
column16: The niche on the NW corner of the W wall
column21: The lararium is located on the eastern wall, rectangular in shape on a N/S axis. It was inserted into the wall off center to the 4th style. The lararium was painted, showing a red border along each side and although difficult to see, there seems to be 2 snakes moving toward the altar to the south.

column14: Portico 12 to the north.
column21: Rectangular garden on an E/W axis. Separated from peristyle 12 to the north by two plastered square columns. A masonry drain runs along the south face of the portico. Between the east column and the east wall there is a basalt cistern with decorated cistern head. Jashemski and Elias refer to a triclinium or stibadium under a pergola at the center of the garden. No trace remains. Agricultural tools and a wooden cart were also found in the garden. Jashemski also identifies traces of cultivation. A statuette of Hercules was found here. There are six holes in the west wall, four holes in the east wall, and one hole on the south wall. On the interior faces of the two end columns (east and west) and on the opposing faces of the two columns in the middle are matching holes for a garden fence.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE. Elias refers to stabalium covered by a pergola, Jashemski says it was a wooden triclinium covered by a pergola.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg. 398
Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.2, pg. 398
column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE. Lararium painting originally cited on the south wall outside of the kitchen.

column14: None
column21: Rectangular room. Small store room is located to the west just after you enter the door to the house. The room is rectangular in shape on a E/W axis. Abutting the west wall is a low wall which seems to delineate in the NW corner a latrine. In the SW corner between the low wall and the south wall are seven amphora of various shapes. It's difficult to tell whether these are in situ. In the SE corner however, is a broken amphora which appears to be in situ. The floor seems to have been beaten plaster or cement. Running diagonally from east to west appears to be a terracotta drain, going from the latrine area toward the ESE corner. In the south wall there appears to be evidence of post eruption intrusion. (?) The ceiling is non extent, but modern reconstruction of the second floor ceiling has been done. In north wall is a small window looking to the outside.

column14: None
column21: The SE corner of room, in situ, is a large amphora. Top portion is broken off and removed. What it held is unknown.

column14: Room 2 to the west, room 7 to the southwest, room 14 to the southeast.
column15: Room 2 to the west, room 7 to the south-west, room 14 to the south-east.
column21: Rectangular room on a north south axis. The northwest corner has a step down to the doorway to the atrium (2). The step down is divided from the rest of the kitchen by the base of a masonry wall. It is not possible to see how high the wall would have originally run. In the northeast wall there is a shallow cupboard niche (2199). The floor is preserved opus signinum flooring. The rest of the floor is obscured by lapilli. Traces of plaster survive in the northeast and east with red and white panels. High in the east wall is a circular hole and in the center of the wall above there is a insert or placing for a down pipe. Southeast doorway leads to a short corridor to the kitchen latrine (14). Southwest doorway leads to a storeroom (7). In the southwest corner there is a flight of stairs to the story above with an arched recessed storage area beneath that has subsequently been partially blocked. High in the northwest corner of the north wall there are four holes or joists for the floor above. In the center of the north wall high above, there is a blocked doorway.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: None
column21: Shallow rectangular cupboard niche found in the northeast corner of the kitchen with traces of undecorated plaster, floored with opus signinum.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: Room 6 to the north.
column21: Small rectangular storeroom found at the rear of the kitchen. The storeroom is on a east west axis. The floor is obscured by lapilli. Traces of undecorated plaster are found on all four walls. In the northeast corner there is a rectangular recess similar to a cupboard niche with a restored lintel. Identified as a storeroom because of its position at the rear of the kitchen.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: None
column21: Narrow rectangular room on a north south axis. Floor is obscured by lapilli and tarpaper. In the east wall is an opening tunneled through to house 7. In the southeast corner there is a place for a drain with a downpipe running from the floor above. The lower courses of the drain are preserved as a terracotta pipe. Any traces of the latrine are not visible, however, the shape of the room, the drain and the position with respect to the kitchen suggest a latrine.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: Atrium to the north.
column21: Dining room opens to the north northwest looking onto the atrium. Square floor panels with three painted walls. The floor is obscured by earth. The ceiling is modern wood beam reconstruction. There is a high large window opening to the atrium on the north wall. The lower registry is partially intact on the three walls. Red stencil is found along the bottom below a yellow egg and additional dark stencil. Above the egg and dark stencil are twelve separate examples of plants painted on the walls, depicting at least three different types of plant life. The plants are interspersed with red columns and faces. Above the columns is additional red stencil with garland. Colors include: cream, white, yellow, red and white with ochre. Fourth style painting. There is a new concrete wall/forms along the east half of the north wall.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: Room 13 to the southeast.
column21: The dining room lies a the rear of the house overlooking the garden to the southeast. One enters the room from the south corner through the andron. The room is rectangular in shape, on a southeast northwest axis. The southeast wall has a window looking directly into the garden. The room was once painted, through little remains today, possibly 4th style. As extent, the room lacks a ceiling and the floor type can not be determined as it is obscured by lapilli. In the southeast corner is what appears to be a blocked doorway leading to room 13.
column70: House and Textrina of Minucius Fuscus

column14: None
column21: One enters the shop from the NE by way of the doorway to the N of one arm of the counter.  The room is rectangular in shape on an E/W axis.  In the SE corner is an L-shaped counter.  One arm of the counter, in the doorway, is parallel with the  street.  The second arm is at a right angle and extends into the shop.  The roof is reconstructed.  The walls were at one time painted but little remains except for some red fragments  In the SW corner of the room is a structure that may have supported a stairway but it's function is uncertain.  The floor cannot be ascertained.  In the high in the upper N and S walls are hole/niches which may have supported an upper floor.

column14: None
column15: Takes up E corner of the room
column21: A masonry L-shaped counter in the E corner of the room.  One arm without dolia parallels the street to the front of shop.  The second arm runs perpendicular to the first and enters the room.  This arm at one time held two small dolia.  The exterior of the counter, top and sides was covered with a smooth surface.

column14: Atrium to the east; peristyle to the northeast.
column15: Atrium to the east; peristyle to the northeast.
column21: One enters the triclinium from the atrium via a door in the east corner.  The room is rectangular on a northeast/southwest axis.  The room opens via a wide door on the northeast wall into the peristyle.  Above this door at the level of the ceiling is a large light well.  The light well takes up part of the northeast wall and the ceiling.  The ceiling was vaulted and highly decorated; the walls were covered with early Fourth style painting.  The floor was of beaten cement with no mosaic design.  Near the south corner of the southwest wall is a large hole, probably as a result of post-eruption tunneling.

column14: Storeroom 16 to the E; peristyle to the N.
column15: Storeroom 16 to the E; peristyle to the N.
column21: Rectangular room on an E-W axis.  Floor is obscured by dirt.  Ceiling has been restored.  In the NE corner there is a narrow doorway to Storeroom 16. In the SE corner there is a tunnel through the wall into the storeroom.  In the center of the W wall there is a tunnel through into the adjoining room.  High in the center of the wall there is a circular opening.  In the center of the N wall there is a doorway opening to the peristyle.  Traces of undecorated plaster survive.  In the center of the E wall there is a vaulted, plastered lararium niche (2209).  Below the niche there is a painting of a single coiled snake.  Along three quarters of the S wall there is a large masonry cooking platform (2008).  Adjoining the platform in the SW corner there is a water basin (2210).  In the NW corner a terracotta puteol has been placed.

column14: Water basin 2210 to the W.  Lararium 2209 to the NE.
column16: Water basin 2210 to the W.  Lararium 2209 to the NE.
column21: Large rectangular masonry cooking platform on the S wall with a tiled surface.  There is a tiled lip at the rear against three quarters of the S wall.

column14: Cooking platform 2208 to the SW.
column21: A vaulted, plastered lararium niche in the center of the E wall with a tiled base.  Below the niche there is a painting of a single coiled snake.  Below the niche, above the painting, the base of an earlier, larger lararium niche is visible in the wall.

column14: 2208 to NE.
column21: In the SW corner of the kitchen in the corner against the platform is a plastered water basin  It slopes down to a drain in the SW corner that drains outside into the street.  The basin is obscured by rubbish but appears to have been plastered throughout.  At the highest point the basin is approximately one foot high.

column14: Room 17 to the West.
column21: Rectangular room on a N/S axis.  The roof is restored.  The floor is covered by dirt.  Plaster survives on the N, W and S walls.  Red lower register with white above.  High in the south wall there is a narrow rectangular window, the frame of which is plastered, which is narrow on the street side of the wall, and widens on the room side.    In the S corner of the W wall there is a rough cut opening (tunnel?) into the kitchen.  In the N of the W wall there is a narrow doorway into the kitchen.  Roof tile, tufa column base and a tufa block have been placed in here against the S wall.

column14: None
column21: On the east wall on the second floor overlooking the peristyle is a dining room, 204, identified because of its location and because there are three rectangular windows.  The center window is twice the size of the other two.  Much reconstruction is seen.  The windows overlook the peristyle garden face west.  There seems to be a small room in the NE corner (203)

column14: None
column21: Circular rosette depicting a basket. The contents of the basket are unclear, however there are traces of yellow paint. Betty Jo identifies it as bread basket.

column14: None
column21: Painting in the center of the south wall, depicting a peacock. In the lower right there is an unidentified set of fruit. In the top left, an additional variety of fruit is depicted, figs(?) pears(?).

column14: Atrium 2 to the east
column21: Rectangular bedroom with doorway in center of east wall. E/W axis with fourth style decoration on all 4 walls. Black lower register with motifs of plants. Alternating red and yellow panels. Architectural decoration and theatrical masks on the upper register. Plaster molding above. Ceiling restored. Marble chip floor obscured by dirt. A plastered  square niche has been inserted in the middle of the north wall. Circular opening high in the center of the west wall; modern? In the center of the south wall there is painting of food and drink. (2214)

column14: Fauces 1 to the West. Peristyle to the East
column15: Fauces 1 to the West. Peristyle to the East
column21: Large atrium with plastered impluvium obscured by wooden planks. Two phases of flooring are visible around the impluvium; earliest phase of cocciopesto floor with black and white tesserae quatrefoil decoration. 2nd phase cocciopesto floor with white tesserae inserted in a grid. 4th style painting with black lower register, red panels above with inserted scenes of white upper register with architectural motifs. The fauces to the west are decorated in 1st style. In the center of the east wall is a wide doorway opening to the peristyle with placing for door or other barrier. The marble threshold. In the alcove of the south wall there is an ala. In the NW the doorway opens to a shop. In the NE corner, the doorway opens to a dining room (2206). In the Se corner there are stairs to the floor above. The second story floor is indicated by windows in the upper levels of the walls. Three windows are found on the south wall. Two windows are found on the NE wall. One window on the west wall, and one window on the north wall. The ceiling has been restored.

column14: Rooms #1 and #4 to the east, room #7 to the southeast, room #11 to the south.
column15: Rooms #1 and #4 to the east, room #7 to the south-east, room #11 to the south.
column21: Large L-shaped counter room with a U-shaped counter (2218) in the north half of the room. The shorter arm of the counter abuts directly onto a stepped threshold of the wide doorway, stepping down directly to the street to the north. White plaster with a red lower register on the west wall. The south wall has red plaster. The floor is covered by dirt. Along the west wall are four holes for floor joists for the upper floor. To the east is a low window to room #1. To the south is a plastered window or passthrough leading to the dining room (11). In the southeast of the room at the junction with room #7 is a low masonry L-shaped bench. At the east end of the south wall are two vertical grooves approx. 1/2 meter apart running parallel to each other ending approx. 1/3 meter above the floor, function unknown. There are 2 small holes in the south wall at a 45 degree angle to each other.

column14: None
column21: Large U-shaped counter with the shorter arm to the north facing the street. The surface of the east arm does not survive. At the south end is the tiled base of a hearth. The upper courses of which do not survive. The north arm preserves a marble tiled counter top. Polychrome decorated marble frontage is facing the street. The west arm is poorly preserved with no surface or front. Contains 4 large embedded dolia. Between the first and second dolia is a masonry platform which has been added against the wall. Beneath the platform is a recessed area for storage, revealing black painted plaster against which the counter is added. Between the second and third dolia is a smaller spherical inserted dolia.

column14: Counter Room (12) to the south.
column21: This dining room is entered via the south wall. There is molding evidence of a barrel vaulted ceiling which is now modern reconstruction. On the west wall there is a large low rectangular window overlooking the shop counter. High in the north wall is a medium sized rectangular window. On the north and south walls there are painted and structural evidence of couch niches. It is finely decorated in the fourth style. The dominant colors are cream with red and yellow architectural elements. Delicate frameworks in yellow frame 3 medallions in the room. The pattern is for edorninantly triangles with inverted triangles with a motif of a vertical with two crosses in each space. Above the large rectangular window on the west wall is an interesting pine cone (tree) with a bird on either side. The cone is green with a lighter color denoting a decorated molted surface. The birds face the cone. The stucco molding around the barrel is composed of small inverted stylized leaves. The floor is obscured by earth and Costodi crates with some plaster remaining.

column14: Couch niche (2221) to the south.
column21: Couch niche found on the north wall. The red dado demarcation is apparent in the niche with red freehand painted stylized plant material as seen in much more representational form in the fourth style.

column14: Couch niche (2220) to the north.
column21: Couch niche found on the south wall. The red dado demarcation is apparent in the niche with red freehand stylized plant material as seen in much more representational form in the fourth style.
