column14: Counter room to the north, hallway to the east, storeroom to the south.
column15: Counter room to the north, hallway to the east, storeroom to the south.
column21: One enters the dining room from the north through the doorway leading to the counter room. In the northeast corner is a small door leading to the hallway behind. The room is rectangular on an east west axis. On the north wall is a small window looking into the counter room. On the west wall is a small opening that looked out onto the street. In the north and south walls are couch niches. The walls were once decorated, but little remains today. The east and west walls seems to show a human figure. In the southeast corner is a doorway leading to a small storeroom. The floor appears to be cement mixed with terracotta.

column14: Couch niche (2224) to the north
column21: In the southwest corner of the south wall is a couch niche. Little of it remains, other than the plaster which slopes in and downward.

column14: Couch niche (2223) to the south
column21: In the northwest corner along the north wall is a couch niche. The niche curves gradually in and downward, bearing some black paint.

column14: Counter room (12) to the west.
column21: A rectangular shaped dining room on a east/west axis. The west doorway opens up the entire room. There is random red tessera floor. Decorated in the fourth style with dominant red with a cream colored background. The lowest register has evidence of two plants with flowers in green. The next register is above in a yellow line, above which is a red columnar frame which itself is framed on either side with blue on the inside and yellow vegebal (?) motif and a vertical line on the outside. Inside the frame in the center is a rectangular from from which the picture is missing. In the frames on either side are the remains of yellow griffins. The south wall is the best preserved examples of the decoration which are repeated on the other walls. The green framework shows repeated circles, the red pattern is the traditional wave curl pattern. No evidence of a ceiling, but modern reconstruction.

column14: Dining room (11) to the north.
column21: The storeroom is located to the south of the dining room (11). One enters in the eastern corner. After entering, one turns west to actually enter the room itself. The room is very narrow, perpendicular on an east/west axis paralleling the axis of the dining room, but extending only 1/2 of the distance. In the southeast corner, directly opposite the entrance, the wall has been recessed probably to create shelf space. To judge from the markings in the east and west walls of the recessed structure, there was at least one upper shelf.

column14: Room #6 to the north, room #9 to the west.
column15: Room #6 to the north, room #9 to the west.
column21: A rectangular room on a east/west axis with plaster surviving on all four walls. No visible decoration. High in the center of the west wall is a rectangular window. In the center of the east wall is a shallow plastered recess for a lamp (?). The floor is obscured by earth and lapilli. At the end of the north wall is a door leading to room #6. In the south corner of the west wall is another doorway leading to room #9. In the southeast corner there are two masonry supports for a wooden platform extending approx. 1/2 meter into the room. Between the two supports on the south wall an earlier layer of decoration is visible, consisting of opus signinum with a small circular hole or pipe leading downwards into the wall. The south corner of the east wall are traces of a filled terracotta drain pipe from the floor above.

column14: None
column21: In the east corner of the south wall are found two masonry supports for a wooden platform. The upper course does not survive. Between the two supports on the south wall an earlier layer of decoration is visible, consisting of opus signinum with a small circular hole or pipe leading downwards into the wall. The south corner of the east wall are traces of a filled terracotta drain pipe from the floor above.

column14: Room #5 and #6 to the south.
column21: A rectangular room on a north/south axis with a stepped threshold down to the street. The threshold contains placings for a door, closing off the sales room from the street to the north. The floor is obscured by earth and lapilli, although traces of marble chip flooring survive in some places. Against the south, east and west walls are traces of decorated plaster surviving with yellow panels with white boarders. In the southwest corner there is a blocked plastered doorway or niche. In the southeast corner is a matching doorway or niche. Above the north doorway is a large restored window in the story above. In the center of the east wall is a square plastered lararium niche (2231). Against the west wall are two masonry supports (2232) that had been added against an earlier painting. Inserted horizontally into the west wall are 2 terracotta pipes. In the northeast corner is a rectangular masonry trough (2230).

column14: Lararium (2231) to the south, Masonry supports (2232) to the southwest.
column16: Lararium (2231) to the south, Masonry supports (2232) to the south-west.
column21: In the northeast corner of the sales room is a rectangular masonry trough, plaster lined. The bottom is obscured by earth. Against the east wall are traces of plaster, yellow in color. The trough appears to have been added subsequently against this plaster.

column14: Trough (2230) to the north, Masonry supports (2232) to the southwest.
column16: Trough (2230) to the north, Masonry supports (2232) to the south-west.
column21: Lararium, Salesroom. The niche lararium lies on the east wall to the south of the trough. It is approx. square in shape, with the walls painted in a deep red.

column14: Lararium (2231) to the east, Trough (2230) to the northeast.
column16: Lararium (2231) to the east, Trough (2230) to the north-east.
column21: Two masonry supports lie along the west wall of the room. One lies in the southwest corner, the other lies to the north budding the west wall. As reconstructed, both are of rubble with a tiled surface. They probably supported a wooden platform, no longer extent. The masonry supports were a later addition to the room as seen from the wall painting of the west wall behind the supports.

column14: Garden to the east, dining room to the north
column15: Garden to the east, dining room to the north
column21: One enters the counter room from the south.  One arm of the counter extending to the west takes up much of the entrance.  The L-shaped counter and work area take up most of the west side of the room.  On the north wall in the northeast corner was an aediculate lararium elaborately painted, much of which is extant on the north wall. To the west of the lararium is a window looking into a dining room.  To the west of the window is a doorway leading to a pass through area.  In the northeast corner of the room is a doorway leading to a small room and then the garden on the eastern wall in the southeast corner is a doorway into the garden.  In the south and north walls as extant are beam holes to support a second floor.  The walls of the counter room were at one time painted but little remains.  The floor seems to be of beaten terracotta and cement on the floor to the west of the doorway leading into the garden is a brace to secure the door.

column14: lararium to the northeast
column21: The L-shaped counter and work area take up most of the western side of the room.  The short arm on the south side runs parallel to the street.  The longer arm extends on a north/south axis into the counter room, as reconstructed.  This counter incorporates two dolia one of which is missing. The north end of the long arm is slightly larger than the counter and may have supported a brazier.  The counter was made of rubble and cement and may have been covered in plaster but none is extant.

column14: Room three to west; Room six to west; Room seven to west; street to southwest; Room ten to south
column15: Room three to west; Room six to west; Room seven to west; street to southwest; Room ten to south
column21: Large rectangular garden on an east/west axis. In the south corner of the east wall there is a painted niche lararium.  In front of the lararium there is a circular masonry feature with an off center square column.  In the center of the north wall, room seven from house twelve joins into the room with a window opening south into the garden and a blocked doorway.  To the east of this room in the northeast corner of the garden there is a rectangular masonry base.  In the center of the south wall, room ten has been added with extant red and yellow decoration and black lower register.  In the southwest of the room, there is a wide open doorway, (entrance ten) opening to the street. To the west of this, in the corner of the room, there is a masonry hearth 2238.  In the center of the west wall, there are the foundations of the north and east walls of a small room.  Two doorways with thresholds step down to counter room three.  A window opens to dining room six.  In the northwest corner there is a lararium painting with a painted masonry lower register and upper register depicting  a coiled snake among the vegetation approaching an altar with pine cones and fruit to the left.  The painting decorates the exterior face of a plastered latrine with seat and drain against the north wall under the stairs and a small square basin in the southwest corner.  Extant painting with black lower register, red border and cream upper register.  To he south of the entrance to the latrine there are two incised rosettes.  The floor of the latrine is plastered ad two square holes for a door at the entrance.  The ceiling is restored.  Extending above the latrine are plastered stairs to the floor above.  In front of the entrance to the latrine is the base of a mill.  In the center of the garden are two dolia 2236 and 2237.  Jashemski found 32 vines in this garden and identified it as a commercial winery.  Plastered blocked narrow window in the middle of the south wall.  Small circular recess in restored northeast wall.  There are thirteen small holes high in the south wall between room ten and the entrance to the street.  There are traces of red painted plaster on the wall below.  The holes appear to be modern cement

column14: dolium 2237 to the east
column21: Large, spherical dolium partially embedded.  The lip is partially preserved.  The base is filled with lapilli and fragments of dolia.  The dolium was used in the preparation and formation of wine.

column14: dolium 2236 to the west
column21: The buried base of a dolium is partially visible.  Jashemski refers to two dolia.

column14: dolia to the northeast
column21: HEARTH: In the southwest corner of the garden to the west of entrance ten is a low platform made of rubble and cement.  It probably served as a cooking platform for a brazier.  As extant there is no evidence of a plaster surface.

column14: southeast of vineyard
column21: A plaster arched lararium niche with yellow painted plaster.  No other decoration is visible.  The wall around the lararium was plastered with yellow paint and black lower register.  A tiled overhang is above the lararium (modern?) to protect the paint.  The lip for the plaster survives on either side of the lararium on the wall.  One foot in front of the lararium in the garden there is a circular masonry base surrounded by a smaller rectangular block, function unknown.

column14: counter room to the south, garden to the east, pass through to the west
column15: counter room to the south, garden to the east, pass through to the west
column21: The dining room lies to the north of the counter room.  One enters the room from a doorway in the southwest corner. On the south wall there is a window looking into the counter room.  On the east wall is a window looking into the garden.  The room is rectangular on a north/south axis.  The floor is a beaten cement with fragments of colored marble in the middle.  The walls were elaborately painted primarily gold, red, green, and white. On each wall are birds and flowers.  On the west, north, and east walls there are small rectangular holes with unknown purpose.  The roof is not extant, but high on the north wall are some remains of stucco that seem to project into the room, implying a stucco ceiling at least partially painted in red.

column14: counter to the south, southwest
column21: On the north wall in the northeast corner is a lararium.  It is unusually wide.  The painting is framed by stucco columns.  It appears to have been an aediculate lararium although the tympanum is no longer extant.  The painting is in very good condition illustrating a single snake moving from east to west towards an altar.  Genus and lares figures do not appear.  There may have been an altar in the northeast corner, if so, no longer extant.

column14: Horticulture (vineyard) 9 space itself to the north
column15: Horticulture (vineyard) 9 space itself to the north
column21: This small dining room is located in the vineyard of Euxinus.  The door is located to the southeast of the vineyard.  This small dining room is behind (to the east) of door ten.  The general condition of the room shows no evidence of tiles or mosaics on the floor.  Appears floor was beaten cement with some evidence of red paint extant.  Three of the five walls are decorated.  The walls show red, yellow, and stenciling in the corners.  There is no ceiling apparent.

column14: 2236 dolium southeast2237 dolium southeast
column21: A large, sacred snake with seven plants interspersed between five of his coils.  He honors an altar with a pine cone and a grape (?).  The background color is a rosy white with stencil lines in green and red.  It is painted to the floor.  The wall containing the picture is the outer wall of the latrine, on which the opposite side (flip) contains the whitish color.

column14: atrium 13 to west
column21: Rectangular room with east/west axis with doorway in center of west wall next to the opening of atrium thirteen.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  On the north, east, west, and southeast corner traces of plaster survive with lower and upper register but no visible decoration.  In the northeast corner of room, there is couch niche 2245, and in the south wall there is couch niche 2246.  Above the latter niche in the east half of south wall, there is a square window looking out into the garden.  Vanderpool and Eschebach show a semicircular feature in northwest corner of which no trace remains.  The floor seems to have been cleared away to beneath the ancient floor level.

column14: 2246 to south
column21: Rectangular plastered couch niche; no visible decoration; in center of couch is a masonry bench.  The niche is raised above the floor approximately 3 inches.  This is in the east corner of the north wall.

column14: 2245 to northeast
column21: The couch niche is in the east half of south wall.  It is shallow, high recessed with undecorated plaster and does not reach the floor as extant today.

column14: 13 atrium to the west15 bedroom to the north; 17 to the east
column15: 13 atrium to the west15 bedroom to the north;17 to the east
column21: The garden is located at the back of the house at entrance 12.  The garden is roughly rectangular in shape on an east/west axis.  In the south wall is a lararium.  To the east of the lararium is a small room that could have been either a bedroom or storeroom.  On the west wall is the entrance to a bedroom.  One enters the garden in the northwest corner from the atrium area of entrance 12.  Just to the south as you enter the garden is a water basin subdivided into two parts.  To the south of the water basin on the west wall is a window looking into a bedroom. When Jashemski excavated the garden she found evidence of grapevines.  Since sculptures were found in the garden, according to Jashemski, the garden was probably a private viridarium.  No dolia were found in the garden.  The walls on the north side seem to have been painted but little evidence remains.

column14: water basin to the west 2249
column21: On the south wall is an aediculate lararium.  When excavated, Jashemski reports that there were sculptures on either side.  As extant, the sides and floor of he lararium are defined by pieces of roof tile.  The typanum is made of rubble; the back recess is curved.

column14: 2248 lararium southeast
column21: Two water basins to south of the entrance of the garden.  Both are plastered and the base of both are obscure by earth and debris.  The west basin is square; the east basin is circular.

column14: Atrium 2 to the east.
column21: Square room with undecorated plaster on all 4 walls.  Ceiling restored.  Floor obscured by earth.  In the SE corner there is a doorway to atrium 2.  In the center of the west wall there is a plastered window that narrows toward the street outside.  The window is high up in the wall.  The NW quarter of the room consists of water feature 2252.  In the NE corner there is a cooking platform 2251.

column14: 2252 to the west.
column21: A square cooking platform in the NE corner.  The exterior face is rounded.  Built of brick and masonry.  The surface is not visible.

A large low masonry platform.  The northern third is higher than the southern two-thirds.  However, the original surface doesn't survive and there are signs of modern restoration.  In the center of the platform there is roughly oval basin that is completely filled with lapilli.  It is impossible to discern the size and function.  Eschebach says there is a fountain in this room, this would appear to be it.

column14: Atrium 2 to the west.
column21: Rectangular room, E/W axis with doorway in the center of the west wall opening to atrium 2.  Traces of plaster survive in the west wall with no decoration visible.  In the NE corner, fragments of plaster with red trim in the corner remain above the plastered niche 2254.  The floor is obscured by lapilli and appears to be excavated below the original floor level.  In the center of the south wall, a window looks out into the garden.

column14: None
column21: Plastered couch niche with black painting.  Plastered masonry bench in the middle of the niche.  The modern floor level has been cleared away below the base of the niche.

column14: Opens onto the atrium with a sight line through to the entrance.
column15: Opens onto the atrium with a sightline through to the entrance.
column21: This rectangular dining room has a SE entrance to the atrium.  On the NW wall is a single couch niche.  The walls are rubble with a very minimal appearance of plaster in the NE corner.  Next to the entrance to the room on the south side is a lararium which has been filled in from the floor to halfway up on the E wall.  There is evidence of a cupboard outline.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: None
column21: On the NW wall is the couch niche with indications that it has been enlarged.  It is now a mixture of stucco and fill.

column14: Room 14 to the west.
column21: Rectangular room with E/W axis, with doorway in the center of the west wall.  Traces of plaster survive with traces of red trim in the SE corner.  In the center of the east wall there is a blocked plaster-lined window that has been plastered over in later phase.  In the SW corner there is a blocked plaster doorway into which has been inserted a blocked plastered window, all of which has been subsequently plastered over.  In the center of the south wall, there is a blocked rectangular recess.  In the NE corner, there is couch niche 2258.  In the south wall, there is couch niche 2259.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: 2259 is to the south.
column21: Rectangular niche with extensive modern cement.  Traces of red painted plaster survive.  In the corner of the niche, there is a masonry bench.

column14: 2258 is to the north.
column21: Long rectangular couch niche extending from the middle of the south wall toward the east corner.  Traces of red painted plaster survive.  There is a long masonry plastered bench in the center of the niche.

column14: Peristyle 7 to the west.
column21: Square room with doorway in the center of the west wall opening to peristyle 7.  The ceiling is restored, with no visible decoration.  The room is decorated with well-preserved 2nd style painting on the north and east walls.  On the east wall, the plaster preserves the line of the vaulted ceiling.

column14: Contiguous to the colonnaded peristyle room 7 and to the dining room on the E. (10).
column15: Contiguous to the collonaded peristyle room 7 and to the dining room on the E. (10).
column21: There is a NW entrance to a dining hall with E/W axis.  On the NE wall, there is a rectangular window opening.  Over the top frame of the window there is a high arched niche.  One-half inches of lapilli covers a cement tile floor.  The walls are high but reconstruction is apparent on more than half of the top half of the W wall.  Small portions of wall still preserve a yellow painted plastic covering.  Evidence of a shallow vaulted ceiling on the east wall overlooking the garden by virtue of remaining rafter holes.

column14: Contiguous garden (room 11),
column21: Entrance on N/S axis to the kitchen pounded mud floor, modern ceiling covers kitchen and store room.  On N. wall is a lararium niche with a shelf.  On NW wall is a small, high cooking platform.  On the E wall is a large toilet, with 2 masonry supports and a sloping tile floor with a clear demarkation on the latrine tiles.  On the cooking platform, there is a tiled surface.  On NE wall is a high window.  The W. wall gives evidence of having been blocked in AD 79.  This is likely a very late addition.  A wall divides latrine from a storage area with a window and a door to SE leading to a garden, planted with trees, amenable with outside dining, however, no evidence of benches or couches.

column14: 2265 lararium to N.  2264 latrine to E.
column16: 2265 lararium to N.  2264 latrine to E.
column21: Small high cooking platform on NE wall contains a tile surface, featuring a rounded corner on E.

column14: cooking surface 2263 and lararium 2265
column21: On NE wall is a large latrine.  Remains of 2 masonry blocks are evident.  The tiles are sloped inward with a perimeter, which demarks the space.  There is a window over the latrine.

column14: 2263 cooking platform S. wall; latrine 2264 on E.
column16: 2263 cooking platform S. wall; latrine 2264 on E.
column21: High on N. wall is an arched lararium niche with a shelf.  Slight pinkish-red color remains.

column14: Atrium to the southeast.
column21: The dining room lies to the west of the atrium. One enters the dining room from the southeast corner through a wide doorway. The room is rectangular in shape with roughly a east/west axis. High on the west wall are beam holes for the ceiling. The floor seems to be a beaten cement with no decoration design detectable. The room is painted in probably the fourth style. Though much of the plaster remains there is little of the decoration. On the east wall high up is a large possibly reconstructed window. To judge from the beam holes in the west wall, if the window is ancient, the holes are probably for a second floor.

column14: Room 202 to the south.
column21: A rectangular room on a east/west axis, one enters the room stepping up into a doorway on the western end of the south wall. There are windows in the center of the east and west walls. The floor and ceiling are restored. Fourth style decoration are found on the east, west, north and south walls that is well preserved in places. The lower register is alternating in red and yellow panels. The upper register contains black panels alternating with architectural motifs. The central image on none of the walls survive.

column14: Peristyle garden (11) to the north.
column21: A rectangular room on an east/west axis. In the northeast corner of the north wall there is a doorway with a threshold. In the center of the north wall there is a window looking out onto the peristyle. Cocciopesto is visible on the floor by the doorway. The ceiling is restored. Fourth style decoration is visible on all four walls with a black lower register and red above with motifs of erotoi, dea, leopards and deer. The central scene on the south wall is 50% preserved, with 3 surviving figures, one complete with a landscape behind. Myth needs to be identified. Center of the east wall does not survive. Only the lower right corner of the west wall scene survives, showing the lower half of a seated figure. The ceiling has been restored.

column14: Peristyle (11) is to the north.
column21: A rectangular room on a east/west axis. The room is entered by two doorways at the eastern and western halves of the north wall. The ceiling is restored and the floor is obscured by dirt. Traces of undecorated plaster on the east, west and south walls and possible traces of some form of platform in the southeast corner. The identification of the kitchen is based on the utilization characteristics and position in relation to the latrine and dining rooms and the lack of any other clearly identifiable kitchen.

column14: Masonry triclinium and hallway to the east. Kitchen to the south, fauces, bedroom and triclinium to the west.
column15: Masonry triclinium and hallway to the east. Kitchen to the south, fauces, bedroom and triclinium to the west.
column21: The counter room is approached from the fauces of the restaurant to the west. The room is rectangular in shape on a north/south axis. As you enter the room from the fauces, there is a L-shaped counter on axis with the room. On the east wall is a wide doorway leading into a large room with a masonry triclinium. To the north and south of the doorway on the east wall are windows looking out onto the masonry triclinium. The faucets opens into the counter room in the northwest corner. In the southeast corner of the east wall is a doorway leading to a hallway leading to the back of the restaurant. The hallway is of a slightly higher level than the counter room. On the west wall are two entrances into two other rooms. To the north is a small bedroom and to the south is a triclinium. On the south wall in the southeast corner is a doorway leading to a kitchen and storeroom. The floor of the counter room is made of beaten cement. The walls of the counter room were once painted, probably in the fourth style, but little details can be discerned. As reconstructed, the ceiling is very tall, but it is impossible to determine the height in antiquity. The floor appears in places to have a black color with crushed stone in the cement. The L-shape of he counter creates in the northeast corner a small work area for the worker outside of the general area of the counter room.

column14: None
column21: The long arm of the masonry counter abuts against the north wall and lies on a axis with the room (north/south). The short arm of the counter lies at a right angle to the long arm and extends to the east a short distance. On the north end of the long arm is a step shelf with three steps. Just south the stepped shelf, embedded in the long arm of the counter is amphora. On the east side of the stepped shelf, below the top and second shelf, is a small cavity rectangular in shape which may be used as a storage area. To the south of the embedded amphora at the rear of the long arm and where the short arm extends to the east is a large round opening for placement of a kettle. The opening extends down to a platform area that extends further to the south. The part of the platform below where a kettle could be placed, probably is where a fire was built. The part of the platform that extends beyond the long arm of the counter has a lip on three sides. The area could also be used for a brazier or other vessels of food. The exterior of the counter was plastered and appears to have been painted. It is difficult to determine the materials of the top of the counter, plain plaster or tiles. The stepped shelves extends beyond the corner of the long arm towards the east. Below the small rectangular cavity in the northeast corner, the lip curves inward towards the west. The portion of the end of the step shelf to the south forms a lip that extends down slightly. This lip extends to within a couple of inches of the south end of the step shelf. The purpose of the lip and extension are unknown.

column14: Counter Room (2) to the west, portico (10) to the south.
column15: Counter Room (2) to the west, portico (10) to the south.
column21: A rectangular room on a east/west axis with two square columns and a low wall with a wide open doorway in the west wall. The south wall consists of a low wall or bench separating the dining area from the hallway (10) In the center of the south wall is a square plastered column. In the southwest corner the masonry wall/bench is broken, creating a doorway into the portico from the south. The floor is plastered. In the northwest corner there is a double lararium (2274). In the center and eastern half of the room this is a large masonry U-shaped dining bench with a cooking platform and a low table (2273). To the north, east and south of the masonry dining bench there is a plastered channeled water feature into which 4 drain pipes are visible. The north, east and west walls are decorated with a garden motif giving the impression that this room is an open air garden without a ceiling. On the east and north walls, on the lower register there is a painting of a garden fence with scenes of vegetation, bird baths and birds with a heron and flamingo at the top of the east wall. In the northeast corner is plaster molding. The floor is plastered with opus signinum.

column14: Lararium (2274) to the west.
column21: A large masonry plastered dining couch. The north arm is the longest at the western end. There is a plastered molded wall that separates the couch from the rest of the room. The couch slopes from interior to exterior and on the exterior face there is a low masonry lip on all three sides, through which three drain pipes drain out into the water feature between the couch and the north, east and south walls. There are two drains in the northern arm and one drain in the eastern arm. Between the three arms of the couch there is a low circular table. The southern arm is the shortest and at the western end is a low plastered wall matching that on the northern arm. Against the western end is a plastered hearth with arched recess below used to keep food warm. In the northern arms exterior face there are square holes that may have originally have been plastered over as lower course of plaster does not survive.

column14: Masonry dining couch (2273) to the east.
column16: Masonry dining couch (2273) to the east.
column21: A well preserved double plastered arched lararium niche joining in the corner. One on the north wall and the other on the west wall. There is a tile base over which is a layer of plaster. The northern niche preserves blue shell pattern. The western niche preserves little to no decoration, however traces of blue paint suggests that is matched the northern niche.

column14: None
column21: A wine amphora propped in situ against the masonry bench of the triclinium and the eastern end of the hallway (room 10). The top part is missing and the remaining portion is filled with lapilli.

column14: Latrine (2279) to the south, storeroom (2280) to the south, hallway (room 10) to the north.
column15: Latrin (2279) to the south, storeroom (2280) to the south, hallway (room 10) to the north.
column21: This room is an un-roofed kitchen with a floor of cement and the walls showing residual plaster. The threshold is higher that the floor of room 5. On the east side of the room are two doorways. The eastern doorway leads to a latrine and the western doorway leads to the storeroom for food and drink.

column14: Dining, Other with masonry dining couch to the north, kitchen (room 8) the the south, dining room (room 6) to the south.
column15: Dining, Other with masonry dining couch to the north, kitchen (room 8) the the south, dining room (room 6) to the south.
column21: The hallway runs on an east/west axis connecting the counter room (room 2) and the kitchen (room 8) of the house. The northeast wall appears to consist of glossy black painting framed in red with a top register of white and green colored frieze. The decoration is continued on the east wall. On the west side of the hallway a masonry bench or half wall shows the remains of fourth style painting with a black glossy background with plants separating the hallway from the room with the masonry dining couch. The floor appears to be made of cement and the ceiling is reconstructed.

column14: Kitchen latrine (2279) to the southeast
column21: In the northeast corner of the kitchen is found a cooking platform. One third of the platform is a single limestone block, the other two thirds consists of random tiles with an irregular surface at a higher level. Above this platform is a large storage area within the wall over the storeroom (room #9) just outside the kitchen.

column14: None
column21: On the east side of the kitchen is a long rectangular latrine. It shows minimal evidence of plastering. The floor to the end of the latrine from the doorway slopes downward. There are two tiles which could indicate the placement of a drain.

column14: None
column21: This rectangular room, just to the south of the kitchen (room 8) is a storeroom for food and drink with five holes on the east wall for possible roofing, but only two holes on the opposite wall. In this storage room we see two ancient lead pipe lengths together with a broken lapilli filled amphora in situ. There is residual plastering remaining on all the walls.

column14: Cooking platform (2278) to the east.
column21: The water basin feature platform structure runs along the west wall of the kitchen. There is a tiled basin on the east side of the water basin platform in the shape of a curved area. Opposite the room is the cooking platform (2278). The basin platform is constructed of rubble.

column14: Hallway (room 10) to the northeast.
column21: On the east wall, at the end of the hallway (room 10) next to the kitchen and amphora is a storeroom. It is plastered with a cement floor and reconstructed ceiling. Signs of a folding door on the threshold with a true east opening to the kitchen (room 8). The room shows residual signs of plastering.

column14: Counter Room (room 2) to the east
column21: The triclinium lies in the southwest corner of the counter room (room 2). One enters from the east into a room which is roughly rectangular on a east/west axis. On the west wall is a window looking out onto the street. The floor is of beaten cement. The walls were painted although it is difficult to determine the style from the remains. In the northeast corner the wall protrudes into the room be a few inches. On the east wall above the window seems to be post holes for beams to support a second floor.

column14: Hallway (room 10) to the north.
column21: A rectangular room on a north/south axis with a doorway in the center of the north wall containing a threshold for placing a door. Plaster survives on all four walls but the decoration is faded out, with possible blue or green at the base of the south wall. Cocciopesto floor is found in the southwest corner. In the center of the west wall there is a tunnel though to the next room. Circular collapsed recess cut into the southwest corner.

column14: Counter Room (2) to the north, Storeroom (12) to the south.
column15: Counter Room (2) to the north, Storeroom (12) to the south.
column21: We enter the kitchen area decorated with fourth style glossy black paint, which continues through 1/2 of the kitchen area. As we enter there is a vaulted ceiling over the cooking platform and an opening in the ceiling for smoke. The cooking platform is low with 1/3 of it in a semicircular portion. A small arched storage area for storage is found at the rear of the kitchen. The floor is slightly lower than the counter room from which the kitchen is entered. The floor is obscured by dirt and unable to determine its make at this time.

column14: Kitchen (5) to the north.
column21: The storeroom contains plastered walls with a bare floor and modern roofing. There is a 6-8 inch recessed arch in the eastern wall. The room is rectangular in shape and contains four broken amphora and roofing tiles. Evidence of tunneling via a large hole in the east wall. Plaster shows some signs of white paint.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform is low with a plastered wall behind the platform. 1/3 of the masonry platform has a raised semicircular area on the north end. The ceiling over the platform is arched with a small opening to allow smoke to escape.

column14: Room 5 to the south.
column21: The kitchen is a rectangular room on a north/south axis. The ceiling is restored, the floor is obscured by dirt. Undecorated plaster is found on the north, east and west walls. In the center of the west wall is a small rectangular niche. At the northern half of the room there are six holes for floor joists on the east wall. On the west wall there are seven parallel holes. High above the south doorway there is a rectangular window that narrows to the south. The northern 1/3 of the room is the latrine (2291) that is separated from the rest of the room by a partition wall. Against the wall extending against the east wall to the south is a masonry cooking platform (2289). Above the platform in the east wall is a lararium (2290). Above the lararium is the line of a lip preserved in the wall. To the east of the entrance is a partially embedded dolium and two large amphora filled with volcanic debris.

column14: Dolium (2294) to the south, lararium (2290) to the east, latrine (2291) to the north.
column16: Doilum (2294) to the south, lararium (2290) to the east, latrine (2291) to the north.
column21: A long rectangular masonry cooking platform is found along the east wall with a arched recess below. The surface is tiled with a tiled lip at the junction of the wall.

column14: Cooking Platform (2289) to the west, Dolium (2294) to the south.
column16: Cooking Platform (2289) to the west, Dolium (2294) to the south.
column21: A lararium painting is found on the east wall of the kitchen above the cooking platform. Two partially preserved lares are painted in burgundy, yellow and green on either side of vegetation. The alter does not survive.

column14: Cooking Platform (2289) to the south.
column21: Found along the northern 1/3 of the kitchen, separated from the remainder of the kitchen by a small partition wall, is a small square latrine. Joists for the floor above the latrine are found in the east and west walls. Against the east wall there is a U-shaped bench supporting a no longer extant seat. The bench is built out of masonry and bricks, below the seat is a drain now filled in with earth. The floor is plastered and slopes down toward the drain in the east.  Undecorated plaster is found in the north and west walls. The ceiling is high above and restored.

column14: Room 2 (atrium) to the east.
column21: The dining room is found south of the atrium and is entered through a tall doorway without a sill. The room is on a north/south axis and is rectangular in shape with evidence of plaster in white. Small examples of orange and brown paint remains near the doorway. On the east wall is a couch niche, which is plastered. On the east wall appears to be a window, which may have existed at one time but is not filled in in antiquity. The floor is obscured by earth, debris and remains of ancient columns.

column14: Room 5 to the south, atrium (2) to the west.
column15: Room 5 to the south, atrium (2) to the west.
column21: The triclinium lies to the east of the atrium, which one enters through a wide doorway at the center of the west wall. The room is rectangular in shape and is on an east/west axis. The floor is beaten cement. The walls are elaborately painted in the third style. The central painting in the center panel of the east wall has been removed. Small paintings on panels to either side show birds on the right and a cupid on a chariot drawn by a deer or (being hunted?). On the east wall above the third register there is an arch which implies a barrel vaulted roof, the arch is in plaster. In the south wall there is a large window opening onto room #5. Above this window, the wall slopes to the south, creating a small window for light. The wall and window is painted in a stylish way that does not continue the style of the remainder of the room.

column14: Cooking platform (2289) to the north.
column21: Small circular dolium filled with lapilli. Partially embedded. Found at the end of the cooking platform.

column14: None
column21: There is a couch niche on the east wall. It shows no signs of plaster, no decoration is extant.

column14: None
column21: Alter to Lares Compitales. Masonry plastered alter to the east side of the street. Scrolled surface and boarder base. On the wall above the alter there is a painting of the Lars Compitales. A lar is shown on the south with a genius above the alter to the north. Above the figures a garland is depicted. No other figures survive. Traces of red (graffiti?) above. In the left hand of the lar he is holding a jog from which wine fountains down into the alter.

column14: room 4 to the north, room 10 the east
column15: room 4 to the north, room 10 the east
column21: Rectangular room or exedra with N/S axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Traces of plaster survive with red paint (faded) lower register and white above.  In the center of the west wall, there is a wide window looking into the garden (14).  In the center of the north wall there is a wide open doorway looking out into the atrium (4 and 3).  To the east side of this doorway, there is a the  marble placement for the barrier.  In the east wall, there is a doorway leading through to room 10 and the street at entrance of 8.  There are two holes in the upper northwest corner for the joists of the second floor.

column14: fauces to entrance 8 to the S, hallway to the tablinum to the W.
column15: fauces to entrance 8 to the S, hallway to the tablinu to the W.
column21: One enters the kitchen from the S from the fauces of entrance 8 and through the SW corner.  Along the E wall is a cooking platform.  According to Eschebach there is a latrine to the N.  High on the W wall are 4 holes to support beams for the ceiling (floor of the second floor).  Floor is obscured by lapilli.  Some plaster remains on the wall over the cooking platform with no decoration extant.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform is located on the E wall extending the full length of the room on a N/S axis.  The top seems to have been covered in tiles.  The front was probably faced with plaster but none survives.

column14: Tablinum (4) to the west
column21: The dining room lies to the east of the tablinum. One enters the dining room from the large doorway in the northwest corner. The room is basically square in shape. The floor type is indeterminate. High on the eastern wall are four holes to support beams to create the ceiling. The walls were decorated and shows under the top layer of plaster the plaster of a previous decoration which has been chipped as preparation for the final decoration. The colors of the final decoration to the extant that they can be determined are: yellow, red and white. The floor is obscured by lapilli. Along the south wall there is a hole , perhaps made by more modern tunnelers (?).

column14: Room 7 to the West
column21: This is a rectangular room on a N/S axis.  The doorway in the SW corner opens onto garden 7.  High in the center of the E wall there is a plastered window.  The ceiling is restored as are the lintels, the window and the door.  The floor is obscured by dirt (plastered?).  The room is lavishly decorated in Fourth Style with a burgundy lower register and yellow panels above.  The upper register is architectural motifs, figures and animals on a white background.  The central paintings survive on the N and E walls.  The E wall depicts a male figure being attacked by dogs with a female figure to the left = Diana and Acteon.  The N scene depicts an elderly male figure and Mercury pointing towards three female figures on the left of the scene.  The female figure seated wears a turreted crown; the standing female figure wears a helmet and carries a shield = Athena.
column70: House of Venus in a Bikini

column14: None
column16: Room 7 o the W by a blocked doorway
column21: A rectangular room on an E/W axis wit a doorway in the W wall, blocked in the modern period.  The floor is obscured by earth and there is no ceiling.  The N and W walls are extensively restored.  The S wall does not survive.  Against the S wall are two poorly preserved masonry supports 2304.  In the E wall there is a plastered semicircular recess for a latrine 2303.  In the NE corner there is a narrow plastered recess or window that narrows to the E and is still filled with volcanic debris.
column70: House of Venus in a Bikini

column14: Courtyard (Room 5) to NE, and hallway to the north.
column15: Courtyard (Room 5) to NE, and hallway to the north.
column21: From a wide passage we enter the kitchen from a door in the north corner of the east wall. The floor is trampled earth. Today there is no roof. On the west wall, however, we see four indentations for beams and a line of masonry that seems to indicate a ceiling. On the west wall, you see two masonry supports, which indicate a cooking platform. On the SE wall, there is wall only partially to the ceiling. Behind the wall is the latrine(2316) that shows a slope towards a water drain. There is minimal platform, painted utilitarian white. WE can see a niche for a lamp on the SE wall. There are 6 wall holes for shelves or for beams, however the croos wall is heavily reconstructed on the SE wall. We can see a small rectangular window on the SE wall, angled inwards toward the street with remains of plaster.

column14: latrine 2316 to the S
column21: One support is embedded in the NW wall.  Anther is shorter and embedded in the N wall.

column14: Room 6 to the west, Room 3 to the NW, room 4 to the northeast.
column15: Room 6 to the west, Room 3 to the NW, room 4 to the Ne.
column21: Courtyard or Viridarium. Square room with small peristyle garden. In the center of the room is a rectangular red plaster garden area with plaster floor surrounded on the NE and west sides by a low masonry plaster wall. In the NW corner is a drain, and in the SW corner there is a circular cistern. To the immediate north of the cistern head the floor has been cleared to create a drain. In the SW corner of the room, there is a circular hole in the floor, exposing a drain beneath. In the south end of the west wall there is a doorway through to the latrine. The south wall preserves red painted plaster. The west wall preserves undecorated plaster. Along the east wall, ascending from the south, is a flight of plastered stairs below which are two plastered vaulted recesses. The first in the center of the wall has a step down from floor level of the room. The north and south walls are yellow with garlands and theatrical masks. The east wall is undecorated. The ceiling is white with garlands and dots of red, green, yellow and burnt umber. In front of this recess the exterior face is plaster and painted with yellow and red trim. In front there is a low masonry plastered podium. Beneath the northern most recess is a cooking platform (2314) in front of which, to the west there is a low rectangular step. In  the center of the north wall there is a wide window opening to dining room 3. In the west end of the north wall, there is a doorway with restored lintel and stone threshold. At the north end of the west wall, there is a doorway through to the kitchen. The cocciopesto floor is preserved in places. The ceiling would have been open.

column14: NE corner of the room
column21: Masonry cooking platform inserted into arched plaster recess beneath the stairs in the NE corner of the room. Surface is plastered with tile below. The northern third of the platform consists of three masonry supports for braziers. In front of the platform, there is a low masonry step.

column14: Atrium 2 to the north
column21: Rectangular room with cocciopesto floors obscured by dirt. Plaster with no visible decoration on all four walls. Ceiling is restored. Large window in the center of the east wall, looking to a corridor. Doorway in the north wall with a stone threshold and restored lintel.

column14: Masonry supports to the north. (2312)
column21: This latrine is separated from the kitchen by a low wall. It is entered from the viridarium from the west wall entrance. The entrance shows a water drain and slabs sloping up towards a block.

column14: street to north, storeroom to south, room 25 to south, mill room to east
column15: street to north, storeroom to south, room 25 to south, millroom to east
column21: One enters the salesroom from either entrance 1 or 2 located on north wall.  The room is L-shaped with longest branch parallel to the via Del'Abbondanza on east-west axis.  The short branch lies on north-south axis in the direction of storeroom (24).  On the south wall of the east-west branch is a doorway leading into room 25.  On the northeast corner of the short branch is a doorway leading into 25.  On the east end of the long branch is a doorway into the mill room.  On the north and south walls of the east side of the long branch are benches.  The floor is indeterminate.  In antiquity walls were plastered but no evidence is extant.  On the west wall of the short branch are two rows of rectangular holes probably for beams to support shelving.  Above the shelf,in the northwest corner is a small window.  High on the west wall at the dividing wall between the salesroom and storeroom seems to be a window that has been closed in antiquity.  It lies next to window clearly. Above the bench is a window looking onto the street.  On the east wall of the long branch, the floor is at a level higher than that of the mill room.  On the north wall of the long branch as reconstructed are four, tall rectangular windows.  The western most is shorter than the other three.

column14: salesroom(1)-north, triclinium (21)-south
column21: Storeroom lies to south of the salesroom.  It is rectangular in shape on a north-south axis.  The doorway on the north wall is almost the full width of the room.  On the south wall, as reconstructed, there appears to be a window looking into the triclinium to the south.  Walls are plastered and appear to have been painted, though no evidence remains.  Floor is indeterminate. High on the west wall just inside the room.  There seems to be a rectangular window which was closed off in antiquity.  There is no direct evidence for the second floor, the window may have been associated with this room.

column14: hallway to south-salesroom to west
column21: We enter the mill room on a north-south axis through the front hallway.  It contains four mills of varying size and degree of completeness.  A circular rubble foundation supports and raises the bottom stone.  The four mills have evidence of metas but only one mill is covered with a catillus.  Along the unbroken northeast wall of this room is a rubble block balustrade with a break in the middle with the remains of a catillus propped beside it.  Within this masonry area grain could be stored in bags or bins.  There is a large deep niche over a block and next to niche are discernible graffito red letters EBIVM(?).  There are two round columns of brick and two large rectangular windows on the Via Del'Abbondanza.  The high ceiling is restored.  Lava paving stones appeared around all mills.  On the northeast wall is evidence of plaster.  Two square buttresses and two circular columns support the second floor.  Two small rectangular openings in the west wall.  On the southeast wall there is a small rectangular window and in the north wall there is a small high window opening into the house next door.  Under the window in the southeast wall are two holes for shelf supports.

column14: Portico (20) to the south, garden (18) to the south.
column15: Portico (20) to the south, garden (18) to the south.
column21: Large rectangular room on a North-South axis with wide doorway in the center of the south wall opening to the garden. Restored lintel with stone threshold with placings for door or other barriers. At the South end of the East wall there is a smaller doorway opening to a corridor to the East with a restored lintel. The floor is cocciopesto, with white tesserae inserts, however there are not enough to identify the decorative scheme. In the Northwest corner there is a couch niche (2321). At the North end of the East wall there is a small rectangular recess with modern cement and a square hole. Fourth style painting with burgundy lower register with while panels and yellow trim with architectural elements above. The ceiling is restored. In the center of the North wall there is a large with restored lintel

column14: None
column21: Couch niche in the north corner of the western wall.  Plastered and decorated to accord with the decorative scheme of the rest of the room.  Burgundy with vegetation, yellow trim above and white panel.  The base of the niche has been cleared away below the floor level of the room.

column14: broken catillus against flour sack enclosure 2326 to N.
column16: broken catillus against flour sack enclosure 2326 to N.
column21: A circular rubble foundation supports and raises the bottom stone.  In this mill a circular lead metal fitting is attached.  It catches the flour as it rests on the foundation.  There is evidence of holes in the lead sheet which would allow attachment to the meta.  The meta is solid lava, described as being bell shaped.  The top part is curved.  The middle part is steep and the bottom part flattens out.  The upper mill stone, catillus, is lava and looks like a double cone or hourglass.  The catillus is hollow and on opposite sides are square exterior sockets with two small holes on either side.  These would be for the exterior wooden or metal fittings.

column14: 2324 mill to south2339 other to east
column16: 2324 mill to south2339 other to east
column21: A circular rubble foundation and a meta partially block the eastern doorway to the shop area.  There is no catillus.  The floor around has lava stones.

column14: 2325 to south, 2323 to north
column21: A circular rubble foundation supports a meta without catillus.  The floor surrounding is paved with blocks of lava.

column14: 2324 to north, 2326 to east
column21: A circular rubble foundation supports a meta with a complete catillus. Two large blocks remain leaning against the meta. The surrounding floor is a lava block.

column14: 2339 to north2322 to south
column21: Catillus only. A broken catillus lies against the grain enclosure on the East wall.

column14: Room 1 to the N. and W., room 23 to the S., and corridor to the portico and garden to the S.
column15: Room 1 to the N. and W., room 23 to the S., and corridor to the portico and garden to the S.
column21: Rectangular room, N/S axis.  Traces of undecorated white plaster on the N. wall.  The E. wall is almost completely restoration and contains 2 small square holes, a small rectangular hole at the S. end and 2 large unfinished holes through to the mill room.  In the NE corner, there is a platform formed of column drum, masonry tile, opus signinum, and volcanic debris.  This rests against the plaster and may be unexcavated debris.  In the center of the E. wall there are 2 masonry supports for a platform 2330.  in the SE corner, there is a catillus.  In the S. wall there are 2 doorways, both restored lintels.  In front of the western of the 2 doors, there is the head of a small cistern, a second catillus is in the SW corner against the center of the W. wall, there is a column drum and a long rectangular stone block that is not in situ.  The upper corses of W. wall are restored.  At the N. end of the W. wall there is a doorway with restored lintel, and at the W. end of the N. wall there is a doorway with restored lintel, both of which open out into the sales room.  This room would have been used to place bread before going to the sales room.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: 2329 to the W., 2330 to the N.
column16: 2329 to the W., 2330 to the N.
column21: the catillus of a rotary mill operated by animals that was originally placed on a meta in the mill room.  The base is embedded in the modern earth layer and damage is visible.  Fragments of this catillus have been placed inside.

column14: 2328 to the E., 2330 to the NE.
column16: 2328 to the E., 2330 to the NE.
column21: The catillus of a rotary mill operated by animals that was originally placed on a meta in the mill room.  The base is embedded in the modern earth.

column14: Mill 2328 to the S.  Mill 2329 to the SW.
column16: Mill 2328 to the S.  Mill 2329 to the SW.
column21: Two masonry supports against the extensively rebuilt E. wall.  The southern is rectangular and built of masonry.  The northern is rectangular and built of tile with masonry upper register.  The surface of neither survives.

column14: 2332 bench
column21: In the E. side of the long branch along the N. wall is a bench.  It extends from just before doorway to mill room on E. side to a little short of entrance 2 on E/W axis.  As reconstructed, the top has tiles.

column14: Bench, second branch (2331) to the north.
column16: Bench, second branch (2331) to the north.
column21: Bench. On the east side of the long branch on the south and east walls is a low bench. The long side of the bench lies on the south wall on an east/west axis. The short side on a north/south axis extends from the south wall to just short of the doorway leading to the mill room. As reconstructed, the surface of the bench is tiles.

The small bench lies to the W. entrance 1, and runs on a N/S axis from the S. wall to the end of W.  Wall.  As reconstructed, the bench is not perfectly rectangular, but it seems to taper to N. as it runs toward the street.  No evidence for plaster façade over tiles on top.

column14: 2333-west
column21: The bench-dining located to the east of entrance two runs on an east-west axis from east wall to just before entrance two.  As reconstructed, the bench is not covered with plaster nor tile.

column14: mill room to south-hallway to west
column15: mill room to south-hallway to west
column21: There is a large entrance to the mill room on the north side and a large entrance on the east side to the oven room.  Six beam brackets in the east wall over masonry blocks perhaps for the support of wooden platforms on which to store flour and grain.  East and south walls have been reconstructed.  Small patch of plaster remains on east wall.  No decoration extant.  Floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: oven to south2337 to south2340 to west
column16: oven to south2337 to south2340 to west
column21: To the north of the oven is the basin for a kneading machine.  Its position abutting against east wall makes impossible to have functioned as a kneading machine.  One and perhaps two of the holes in the wall of the basin may have been plugged in antiquity.  It may have functioned as a water container used in conjunction with the lead pipes inserted in the north wall of the brick facade of the oven.  The pipes lead to a lead water container located to the north of the opening of the oven.

column14: 2336 to the northeast, 2340 to the west, Oven to the south
column16: 2336 to the north-east, 2340 to the west, Oven to the south
column21: Located to the South Southwest of basin to kneading machine (2336) is an embedded amphora. It is extant as only the lower portion can be seen; function unknown, but may have a relation to basin of kneading machine that seems to have been used as a water container.

column14: Mill room to the north, Atrium to the West, Stables to the South
column15: Mill room to the north, Atrium to the West, Stables to the South
column21: Bare floor covered with lapilli. The door to the North leads to the hallway to the mill room. The door to the East leads to a very small slave sleeping area. Propped against the wall is a kneading basin with evidence that three of the four sprocket holes for mixing brackets have been stopped up. Next to the doorway in the North wall is evidence of a staircase, behind which is a high threshold leading to the stable area. There is a doorway to a hall or to a hall to a water through and to the preparation room in the South wall. Along the Southwest wall is a water cistern opening. Along the East wall is the oven.

column14: Mill (2324) to the west, Mill (2325) to the SW, Mill (2323) to the NW, 2326 Catillus to the South, 2322 Mill to the South
column16: Mill (2324) to the west, Mill (2325) to the SW, Mill (2323) to the NW, 2326 Satillus to the South, 2322 Mill to the South
column21: Grain Storage. On the East wall of the mill room opposite the second mill, (2324), is a rectangular shaped area marked out by a low wall. The rectangular area is on a North-South axis, and in the middle of the West wall is a brake that allows access to the space. As reconstructed there is no evidence that walls were covered with plaster, though it is possible.

column14: Oven to the east, Kneading machine to the NE
column16: Oven to the east, Kneading machine to the NE
column21: The cistern is located on the west side of the oven room just to the north of the doorway leading into the peristyle.  As reconstructed, there is a rectangular puteal placed over the mouth.

column14: Water Cistern (2340) to the west, 2336 Water Basin to the north.
column16: Watern Cistern (2340) to the west, 2336 Water Basin to the north.
column21: The oven feature is on the eastern wall of the oven room.  This oven is a large elaborate structure, mostly of brick.  It is rubble that encloses the inner beehive to the ceiling.  Brick masonry encloses the beehive on the bottom half of the oven.  The hole of the mound is laid on a stone base.  The bottom course is a hard stone, better to resist blows from shovels.  The oven opening is faced with lava blocks and is rectangular.  Held in place above rectangular opening is the only iron door to be seen in Pompeii.  The floor to the opening is a table like slab supported by bricks.  Below the slab is a semicircular opening to store kindling wood, dry brush wood or charcoal.  Sometimes this cavity might have been use as an ash pit.  The passageway opening on the right side of the oven connects with a large preparation room.  On the left (north) side, a square led container is located, raised above the surface, with a smaller round opening in the top.

column14: Oven room to the NE (2338)
column21: You enter the preparation room through a northwest door.  It is the prep room in a bakery.  This room is far from the entrance on a north/south orientation.  The ceiling has been restored.  The floor is bare earth; the walls are ruble with plaster over more than half of the area.  The southwest corner of the room is curved and the southern area has a 3” raised floor.  The eastern wall has a low bench which extends the entire way along the wall.  It shows signs of plaster.  It could be used for positioning the bread for both raising and proofing the waves. There are shelf holes, six across and three down undoubtedly to hold baking utensils, and also a niche for a lamp. On the north wall which is plastered white midway and red over register we see a passthrough to the oven and a drain.  On the western wall there is still plaster and close to the door high up, a lararium niche with two rectangular windows.  There is a kneading basin and three masonry supports for heavy table top, maybe wooden planks or marble.

column14: Bench (2345) to the east, Masonry supports (2344) to the south.
column16: Bench (2345) to the east, Masonry supports (2344) to the south.
column21: The first feature in the preparation room is a lava kneading basin in the North end of the room. This basin could be turn by slaves or animals. It is a round container with two bottom holes for medal brackets. This basin is in good shape but none of the fittings are in place.

column14: Kneading machine (2343) to the north, Bench (2345) to the east.
column16: Kneading machine (2343) to the north, Bench (2345) to the east.
column21: In the center of the preparation room are 3 masonry supports.  These supports would hold heavy wooden planks or perhaps marble table top on which bread could be shaped.

column14: Masonry supports (2344) to the west, Kneading machine (2343) to the west.
column16: Masonry supports (2344) to the west, Kneading machine (2343) to the west.
column21: Bench. A low bench runs along the wall from N to S ending in a rectangular column.  The bench shows signs of plaster.  This would be a good place for the bread to both rise and proof.  It is beneath the three long shelves and the lamp niche.  We see a curious small rectangle in the bench underneath.  The lamp niche which might have been used as a heat source if necessary.  It looks as though there were two large engaged columns running from the bench to the ceiling which are no longer extant.

column14: Oven room to the north
column21: The stable lies on the N – S axis to the S of the oven room.  The room is entered from the N side by way of a door to the E of the stairs.  The room is narrow and rectangular in shape.  It is difficult to determine the height of the E wall.  The walls as extant do not appear to have been covered with stucco and decorated.  Along the W wall is a series of roughly round holes for beams to provide a roof for the animals.  The floor is indeterminate.

column14: Atrium 2 is to the south of corridor 10 to the east.  11 to the north.
column15: Atrium 2 is to the south of corridor 10 to the east.  11 to the north.
column21: Square tablinum with wide doorway.  South to atrium 2- threshold survives with placings for shutters.  NE corner doorway with step to corridor 10.  Part of blocked door in earlier phase.  There is a low arched blocked doorway with plaster frame in center of west wall.  In the southwest corner of the west wall there is a plastered bench/couch niche.  2348. Fragments of paint survive in corners and in east wall some traces of yellow and red.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Open north wall - window? Or collapsed?

column14: None
column21: Plastered, rectangular couch niche partially blocked at southwestern edge in final phase. No decorative features survive.  Dusty pink in color.  Northern end abuts the blocked plastered doorway in the center of the west wall. This feature is in the southwest corner of the room.

column14: Room 13 to the southwest.
column21: One enters the room from the southwest from room 13.  The room lies on a roughly SW/NE axis.  In the western corner are the remains of a cooking platform.  In the rear of the room to the northeast was the latrine.  The room is a trapezoid and narrow and becomes more so as one goes further back toward the latrine.  There may have been a window high on the southwest wall above the door.  Floor is obscured by debris.

column14: None
column21: In the southwest corner of the room are the remains of the cooking platform.  At this time there is so little of it that one cannot discern its shape or size.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE:  In the northeast part of the room was the latrine.  Nothing remains. Eschebach, p 131

column14: Rooms 12, 14, 15, 16, 11;  12 to south; 14 to east; 15 to east; 16 to east; 11 to south;
column15: Rooms 12, 14, 15, 16, 11;  12 to south; 14 to east; 15 to east; 16 to east; 11 to south;
column21: At the rear of the house in the west corner lies the garden.  The garden lies on a roughly NW/SE axis.  On the northeast corner is the entrance to the kitchen.  On the eastern side is the entrance to triclinium 15.  The doorway to triclinium 15 is higher than the doorway to kitchen 14.  On the east wall is the entrance to triclinium 16.  The doorway is taller than the doorway to triclinium 15.  In the southeast corner of the garden there is a window into triclinium 17.  On the southeast wall, in the south corner, there is a window looking onto triclinium 12.  On the east corner is the entrance into the garden from room 11. There appears to be an eastern wall high above the doorway to the triclinium post holes to support a second floor.  On the west wall in the northwest corner high on the wall is a window which appears to be at he height of the second floor. In the northeast corner of the block wall seems to have an amphora embedded in the wall.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: 15 Amphora were found in this garden (13) per Jashemski pg. 111

column14: Room 17 to the south and Garden 13.
column15: Room 17 to the south and Garden 13.
column21: Rectangular shaped room with a wide doorway facing west to Garden 13.  Floor is obscured by lapilli. In the northwest corner there is a pile of lime.  Undecorated plaster survives on the NE and S walls.  The upper course of the walls appears to have reconstruction in the SW corner.  A low doorway opens south to 17.

column14: Window overlooks garden.  Small door leads to second dining room (16) to the north.
column15: Window overlooks garden.  Small door leads to second dining room (16) to the north.
column21: NE/SW axis; Northeast door off of Room 11.  The room has been plastered with evidence of paint.  Rectangular room with a door to the adjacent dining room 16.  This room has been determined to be a dining room.  Floor obscured by debris. Room has been plastered with evidence it will be replastered.  Nice large window overlooking garden 13 is evident.  There is no ceiling.

column14: (14) Garden (13) to west.
column21: Stone threshold with signs of a door opening to garden (13) to east.  With good sized doorway.  Floor obscured by debris.  No ceiling. This is a dining room.  Evidence of plaster with paint.  Overlooks garden.  No features remaining.  Walls are above second floor level.  NE-SW axis.

column14: None
column21: Rectangular, masonry platform with tile surface - restored found in the northeast corner of the room.  In the east wall above there is a window.  In the North wall above, there is a down pipe from the floor above.  No other features appear.

column14: None
column21: Small square room facing south to the street.  Threshold survives with placing for doors.  Floor obscured by lapilli.  No extant decoration on walls.  Low rectangular masonry preparation platform.  2357 in the north east corner with downpipe from the floor above in the north wall.  In the center of the east well is a partially blocked window (or door?) from earlier phase.

column14: Room 2 to the north.
column21: Room is roughly rectangular on an east-west axis.  One enters from the south through a wide doorway capable of being closed up.  To the north, on the northwest side, is a large doorway into room 2.  To the east of that today appears a second narrower door, but in antiquity this was probably walled up.  On the east side of this doorway are the remains of a lararium that has been bisected when the wall fell.  In the northwest corner there was a water feature, either a fountain or cistern.  In the southwest corner are the remains of a small dolium on the floor.  The kind of floor is indeterminate.  Rudell links this room with the atrium of V24.  It is possible that there was once a doorway in the northeast corner that was walled up, but it is not certain.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: In the northeast corner of room 1, according to Eschebach, page 130 had a cistern.

column14: Room 1 to the south.
column21: To the north of room 1 lies room 2, which is entered through the doorway in the northwest corner of room 1.  The room is roughly square shaped with indeterminate floor.  On the north wall of room 2 is an archway that probably was used for storage, such as amphorae.  In the southeast corner of the room were stairs.

column14: None
column21: On the north wall on the right side of the narrow doorway which, was once walled up, was a niche lararium as extent.  Though it was plastered there are no remains of decoration.  Only a portion of the right side of the lararium remains.  The rest fell away with the wall.

column14: Lararium (2362) to the north.
column21: In the southwest corner, embedded in the floor, is the remains of a small round dolium.

column14: Garden 10 to south.  Dining room 12 to the east.
column15: Garden 10 to south.  Dining room 12 to the east.
column21: Large square room with wide low window facing south to the Rhodian pseudo-portico and garden, 10.  Cocciopesto floor, well preserved.  Plastered decoration survives on the northeast and west walls.  Yellow - lower register.  Red border above.  White upper register.  South end of the east wall there is a narrow doorway to dining room 12.  At the east end of the south wall there is a doorway to the portico with stone threshold placing for the door.  No evidence of ceiling.

column14: Dining room 11 to the west.  Rhodian pseudo peristyle and garden 10 to the south.
column15: Dining room 11 to the west.  Rhodian pseudo peristyle and garden 10 to the south.
column21: Rectangular dining room facing south to garden 10.  Stone threshold.  Cocciopesto floor, well-preserved.  Narrow doorway at southern end of west wall opening to dining room 11.  Shallow bench couch niche at the north end of west wall (2370).  Plaster survives on all four walls.  Yellow lower register.  Red border.  White register above.  Fourth style.

column14: On the southwest is room 3.
column21: One enters triclinium 8 from the doorway in the southwest corner from atrium 3.  The room lies on the eastern side of the house and is rectangular in shape on a rough north-south axis.  On the north wall are two large windows opening onto room 17.  The window on the west side appears larger than the  one on the east.  The floor seems to be a solid cocciopesto.  The room was at one time elaborately painted, though little remains, on the east and west walls.

column14: Portico (10) to southwest.  Storage room (15) to northeast.
column15: Portico (10) to southwest.  Storage room (15) to northeast.
column21: Northwest small door off the Rhodian pseudo peristyle.  There is a low lintel doorway to a small room which we are calling a kitchen.  In the kitchen there is a small window to a decorated bedroom.  There is evidence of white plaster on the walls.  There is no evidence of ceiling.  The walls are opus incertum.  To the left there is a pile of rubble - perhaps a latrine or perhaps a cooking platform.  Floor obscured by lapilli.  Northeast - southwest axis.

column14: Kitchen (13) to the southwest.
column21: A northeast room for storage with a stone threshold separating if from the kitchen.  It is a small irregular rectangle.  There is evidence of rubble on the south wall.  No ceiling.  Minimal evidence of plaster.  Floor obscured by debris.  East - west axis.

column14: Tablinum 6 to the west; Rhodian pseudoperistyle 9 and garden 10 to the south.
column15: Tablinum 6 to the west; Rhodian pseudo-peristyle 9 and garden 10 to the south.
column21: Square room with wide doorway opening N to Rhodian pseudoperistyle to the north.  Floor is obscured by lapilli.  Plaster survives on SW and N walls.  Red with white above.  The placing for a central image survives in the center of the west wall, although no trace survives of the painting itself.  Traces of the trim survive.  In the SE corner there is a narrow doorway to Tablinum 6.  Third style/poorly preserved.

column14: None
column21: Shallow recessed couch niche.  Traces of plaster survives with no indication of decorating.  The join with the plaster wall decoration does not survive.

column14: Room 3 to the north. Room 2 to the northwest.
column15: Room 3 to the north. Room 2 to the northwest.
column21: One enters the square shaped counter room from the south. To the west of the entrance, there is a base for steps to the upper floor. To the east of the entrance and inside the shop, is an L-shaped counter with 4 dolia, three on the east/west axis and one on the north/south axis. On the eastern end of the counter arm that runs parallel with the Via 'Nola is a two-stepped shelf. The shelf lies to the south of the dolium, but within the shop. The floor is indeterminate. The room was at one time painted, but little remains. The upper floor, which the stairs serviced, no longer exists.

column14: Room 1 to the south
column21: Square shaped dining room with a wide doorway opening to the south to sales room #1. Doorway partially blocked by a low wall in later phase. Plaster survives on all four walls. White background with red trim. Floor is obscured by Lapilli.

column14: None
column21: The L-shaped counter lies approximately 3 feet inside the counter room. The arm parallel to the Via D'' Nola lies on an east to west axis and contains 3 dolia. The shorter south-north arm contains one dolia. Inserted in between the east-west arm and the front of the shop, abutting to the east wall and on a level with the east arm is a two-step shelf. The L-shaped counter may have been coated with a plaster in antiquity, but none remains.

column14: Room 1 to the south.
column21: Narrow, rectangular room with narrow access passageway leading south to the sales room (1). Floor obscured by Lapilli. Traces of undecorated plaster on the west wall. Placing for floor joists for floor above in the east wall. In the northwest corner there is a low rectangular masonry cooking platform (2376) that rests against plaster with decoration. In the north wall behind the platform is a blocked plaster lined recess or cupboard area. Adjoining the platform to the east in the northeast corner of the room is a latrine (2375).

column14: Cooking platform (2376) to the west
column21: Masonry supports for a seat of a latrine survives in the northeast corner of the room. The floor and any indication of a drain is obscured by lapilli. Eschebach identifies this as a latrine.

column14: Latrine (2375) to the northeast
column21: Low masonry cooking platform. Surface does not survive, however, there are fragments of what may be a plastered surface and lip along the front of the platform.

column14: Room # 2 to the north.
column21: One enters room # 1 through a wide doorway from the south. To the northwest there is a large doorway into room #2. Room is rectangular in shape lying on a northeast axis. There is a base for stairs leading to the upper floor on the north wall. To the east of the door to room #2 is a niche lararium. The floor is indeterminate. The walls seemed to have been painted in antiquity but little traces remain.

column14: None
column21: Small plastered arched lararium niche with white plaster background with a red border. No other decoration survives.

column14: Sales room #1 to the south.
column21: Small rectangular room opening to the south to sales room #1. Floor is obscured by lapilli. Plaster survives on all four walls and is best preserved on the west wall. Fourth style with alternating red and yellow panels. Several of the central panels have been transferred to the Naples Museum depicting Paris & Helen and Odysseus and Circe.

column14: Garden peristyle 16/17 to the east. Room 25 to the north.
