column15: Garden peristyle 16/17 to the east. Room 25 to the north.
column21: Rectangular (long) room facing the east to the peristyle garden (16-17). In the east end of the north wall there is a narrow doorway opening to 25. Threshold of the main doorway does not survive, however, there are placings for the door. Restored vaulted ceiling. Fourth style painting on all our walls. Circular medallions with details now faded. Black background. Vegetation on lower register indespersen. Among architectural elements. Mosaic floor survives throughout mosaic obscured by dirt. However, it seems to be monochrome black/white with some decorative elements. Dark boarder approx. 3" wide around edge of the mosaic approx. 1 inch from the wall. In the center between diamond patches there is a square decorative element consisting of a double boarder surrounding alternating diamond shapes. Room is on a east-west axis.

column14: Room #16 to the North
column21: The dining exedra lies almost on axis with the entrance in the rear or south part of the house.  One enters the exedra from the north through a doorway that extends the entire width of the room.  The room is rectangular in shape on east-west axis.  The walls are painted in early second style much of which remains.  The threshold consists of a black and white meander design extending across the entire width.  The floor of the room seems to have been in cocciopesto with marble and small other multi-colored stones.

column14: room 19 to the W, room 16 to SW
column15: room 19 to the W, room 16 to S-W
column21: One enters the dining hall from the SW through a large wide doorway.  The room is rectangular in shape on NE SW axis.  The room is a Corinthian oecus as it has 4 columns.  The front two located on either side of the room about half way in.  The rear columns stand about 3 feet from the back wall.  The floor is a black & white meander mosaic design around the periphery.  It is impossible to determine today the internal pattern because of construction / ceiling collapse.  The walls are painted in early 2nd style - the ceiling was vaulted.  In the W corner is a doorway leading to room 19.

column14: Tablinum 8 to the west.  Rhodian peristyle to 16 to south.
column15: Tablinum 8 to the west.  Rhodian peristyle to 16 to south.
column21: Square room w/wide doorway facing s to peristyle garden 16/17.  (Rhodian peristyle).  The threshold preserves placings for door.  The threshold consists of polychrome mosaic w/angular key/swastika design in white/red/black tessarae.  Mosaic floor survives throughout.  Black border on white around diamond pattern w/red/yellow/orange and black diamonds on white.  The walls preserve unfinished plaster w/no decoration.  The upper course and ceiling are modern.  In the southern end of the western wall is a narrow doorway to the tablinum.

column14: Rhodian peristyle 16 to the SW 39 to the NW
column15: Rhodian peristyle 16 to the SW 39 to the NW
column21: Large rectangular garden now partially filled with debris.  According to Jashemski there was a non longer extant portico.  Jashemski reports various irrigation channels and soil contours suggesting that it was a kitchen garden.  In the center of the garden is pool 2386 and masonry triclinium 2385.

column14: Fountain 2386 to the east.
column21: U-shaped masonry triclinium.  Rubble structure and shape preserved.  But no extent decoration survives.  Partially preserved step on the interior faces.  In the center between the 3 couches is a circular table consisting of a brick shaft a round marble table top.  In the center which is a hole for a water feature for triclinium.  Jashemski: L. medius 4.45, L imus and L. summus 3.0 m.  Round table top .8 m in diameter.  Jashemski says the masonry triclinium was a later insertion into the portico.

column14: Masonry Triclinium (2385)
column21: Rectangular pool lined w/opus signinum.  The base is obscured by debris.  Jashemski gives the dimensions as 2 x 3.53 m and 1.7 m deep.  In the center is a plastered column w/jet of a fountain in the center.  In the west wall extrudes a lead water pipe - overflow water pipe?

column14: None
column21: In the center between diamond patches, there is a square decorative element consisting of a double border surrounding alternating diamond shapes.  Central emblem between dining couches.

column14: Contiguous southeast door to storeroom (fallen in).  Southwest door to large open area with swimming pool and water well.  Contiguous to the hallway to atrium and looking out to the colonnaded peristyle.
column15: Contiguous southeast door to storeroom (fallen in).  Southwest door to large open area with swimming pool and water well.  Contiguious to the hallway to atrium and looking out to the collonated peristyle.
column21: Off the hallway from the atrium there is a southwest entrance to a kitchen.  It is in the southwest corner of the peristyle. The floor is obscured by lapilli.  It is a rectangular room with one door on the south side leading to the swimming pool to the south west and a well and a large open area around the swimming pool.  On the south east side of the wall, there is a door with a barred padlocked entrance with a store room which has half-collapsed filling the room with rubble.  On the Prae-furnium (?) east wall, there is a rounded tufa  channel.  High on the northeast wall, there is an indication of a lararium that has been blocked up.  You can see an arch or a rectangular top.  There is a window between the southwest door and the south east pantry above the cooking platform.  There is a column top on the eastern section obviously moved from another location.  The northwest wall nearest the entrance door shows a blocked  up door in the northwest.  The room shows signs of painted plaster and above door to pantry is archaeological stamped date "R1978".  There is a preparation plate form on the east corner with step up.

column14: Cooking platform (2390) to the west and water other (2391) to the north.
column16: Cooking platform (2390) to the west and water other (2391) to the north.
column21: Probably a preparation platform located in the east corner.  Tall rectangular structure with a stone step-up.

column14: Prep-platform (2389) to the east.  Water Other (2391) to the east.
column16: Prep-platform (2389) to the east.  Water Other (2391) to the east.
column21: No discernible top.  Beneath a southern window is a cooking platform.  No discernible tiles, top or lip.

column14: Atrium (2) to the SW
column21: Small square room w/window in center on N wall to street outside.  Doorway at southern end of the west wall opens to atrium 2.  Earth floor w/no visible original.  Ceiling is modern although high in W wall is placings of floor joists.  At north end of west wall there is a plastered recess for cupboard or other storage w/low plastered bench.  Inserted into the NE corner and separated from the rest of the room is latrine 2396.  Adjoining the latrine and extending along the remainder of the E wall is the cooking platform 2395.  On S wall is lararium niche and painting 2397.

column14: Room 11 is to the north.
column21: One enters the room from the north by way of the ala (11).  The doorway is fairly narrow but the room itself is fairly large.  Rectangular in shape on roughly N/S axis.  Walls are painted in the 4th style with pygmies prominantely featured in vignettes on three walls (none on fourth wall).  On the east wall just inside the doorway on which one pygmy is painted, is a small pillar extending the height of the wall.  The floor is in cocciopesto with small pieces of white marble arranged in a simple pattern.  The ceiling is not existent but was probably very high.  The windows on the west wall belong to the second floor.

column14: The garden (14) to the north. Tablinum (16) to the southwest.
column15: The garden (14) to th north. Tablinium (16) to the southwest.
column21: We enters this rectangular dining room through a large entrance Tablium hall (16) and a high doorway. The room is on a southwest to northwest/southeast axis. There is a raised marble threshold, the floor is small tessarae/white floor with black boarder around the room. Large window overlooks the garden (14). With a marble sill with closures at each end. The walls are all intact. Floor is also intact. The floor has been restored. Black socle runs all around the walls with three layers of panel paintings. Socle has stenciling of green and red diamonds. Second panel yellow is interspersed with phyches in each. Surviving panel with two small cream/white panels on each end and two large panels in the center on the sides of larger on north east wall. On the southeast wall there are 2 cream/white panels missing, 2 yellow panels on the ends. Southwest wall only the central picture panel can be seen but the picture is gone. Northwest wall alongside the window has two yellow panels. On the northeast wall aqua/turquoise colors are found around the center panel. Inside a seatt (?) figure on Hemaphradite. 2 figures, one has green fabric draped over legs with a hand over the forehead. Figure 2 has a hand out as if asking for something. Southwest wall panel has aqua/turquoise boarder molding top panel. Egg & Dart first molding narrow, top molding wider. Appears on 2 walls the background is cream in color. Fancy temple façade with garland, birds and figures. Dancing figures are found in the center. Blue Green aubergene colors appear. Crown molding with reconstructed ceiling and slight evidence of a vaulted ceiling on the southeast wall.

column14: Room 16 to the southeast
column21: One enters the large triclinium through a large doorway in the southeast corner of the ablinium (16). The room is rectangular in shape on a north-south axis. In antiquity, the wall was elaborately decorated in fourth style painting with mythological figures on each wall. The floor was of a smooth plaster over coccio pesto. As reconstructed, it is difficult to tell if the ceiling was originally vaulted.

column14: Room 12 to the north, tablinum (16) to the south.
column15: Room 12 to the north, tablinum (16) to the south.
column21: Rectangular shaped room on a east-west axis with a doorway in the southeast corner opening to a narrow corridor leading to the atrium. The northeast corner opens to room 11. Traces of plaster survives on the east, south and west walls with no visible decorations.  In the center of the east wall is a plastered window that narrows towards the garden to the east. In the southwest corner a drain has been inserted to the street outside. Modern, not clear if anything is ancient. Lararium niche (2404) is found above. A latrine (2405) is along the west wall, cut by a partition wall (not clear how much of this is modern). The north wall is preserved to only four feet in height. The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: None
column15: Lararium found above the laterine (2405) in the west wall of the kitchen.
column21: Arched plaster lararium niche, traces of red color but no visible decoration.

column14: None
column21: The latrine is running along the west wall of the room, divided into by a partition wall. It is not clear how much of this wall is original. At the base of the wall is an arched stone channel linking the two halves of the latrine. The northern half consists of a triangular drain (masonry finished surface), narrows towards the wall to the west and slopes down to the west by a drain emptying through the wall to the street outside. Above the drain, inserted into the west wall is a plastered arched recess. Southern half of the latrine is quarter circular in shape with traces of plaster lip on the exterior face and plastered interior. The base of the drain is obscured with debris. To the south of the drain is a low masonry support for a seat, the placing of which is visible on the south face of the partition wall.

column14: Kitchen (11) to the south.
column21: Small square room, floor obscured. Doorway in the southeast corner with restored lintel. Plaster fragments on the south wall, white background with red trim and indeterminate yellow decorative elements. In the high end west wall are placings for four joists. In the northeast corner there is a cupboard niche (2407).

column14: None
column21: Shallow rectangular recess inserted into the eastern wall. Traces of plaster, modern concrete in lintel.

column14: Storeroom (13) to the northeast, kitchen (11) to the south.
column15: Storeroom (13) to the northeast, kitchen (11) to the south.
column21: An L-shaped room, no extend wall finish, floor is obscured by lapilli. The long arm of the room is narrow and the room is on a east-west axis opening at the east ends of the room leading to rooms 11 and 13 broading to the north-south. North end is obscured by a pile of building material. Square window at the north end of the west wall. The function of the room is unclear although is probably related to the adjoining storeroom and kitchen. High in the east and west walls of the shorter arm are placing for joists.

column14: Serving room (3) to the north
column21: One enters the roughly square shaped shop (1) from the southwest through a small door. In the south corner is an L-shaped counter with three dolia in the arm perpendicular to the street. In the north corner at the back of the room is the entrance to the serving room (3). The L-shaped counter has one arm that extended on a southwest-northeast axis into the shop area. The arm parallel to the street runs on a southeast - northwest axis with the southeast end abutting the southeast and southwest walls. The floor is indeterminate. The walls are plastered through no decoration remains. Roof is non-extant.

column14: None
column21: The L-shaped counter lies in the southeast part of the shop. The arms are roughly equal in length. One arm with three dolia embedded runs on a southwest-northeast axis. The second arm parallel to the street runs on a southeast-northwest axis and contains no dolia and abuts against the southeast and southwest walls. The counter seems to have been covered in plaster and probably painted, although little remains. The counter is set back from the street, creating a step up.

column14: Counter Room (1) to the southwest, fauces (2) to the southwest, Room #4 to the northeast.
column15: Counter Room (1) to the southwest, fauces (2) to the southwest, Room #4 to the northeast.
column21: One enters the serving room (3) from the street to the southwest through a medium faces into a good sized serving room. The room is rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis and has a door to the living quarters to the northeast side of the room. On the southeast wall there is a high (7') round window. On the southwest wall in the southern corner there is the remains of a large lararium painting (2412) next to the doorway leading to the counter room (1). Another doorway leads to the fauces of address V.II.C and the rectangular room shows spotty evidence of plastering (white). The floor is lapilli. Contiguous to the food shop and living quarters. There is a rectangular cooking platform (2413) with a hearth appearing off-center close to the doorway to the fauces and the counter room (1).

column14: Cooking platform (2413) to the north
column21: Little remains of this lararium, however a cream/peach color background can be seen along with what appears as Lars with dark brown boots kneeling down. Bottom of the alter the second Lar is missing. One third of a snake remains and at the top there is a garland.

column14: Lararium (2412) to the south
column21: The rectangular cooking platform (containing a hearth) contains an inner area for wood and/or charcoal. The north opening to the floor is where the fuel could be inserted. The cooking platform appears off-center in the room close to the doorways leading to the fauces and the counter room (1).

column14: Room #10 to the north, Room #2 to the south.
column15: Room #10 to the north, Room #2 to the south.
column21: A square room accessed through a narrow corridor from room #2, half of the room contains a vaulted ceiling. The vault extends west to room #11. Center of the north wall there is a collapse through to the garden. Eschebach shows a window to be here. Against the north wall there is a masonry support or partition (2415). In the southeast corner a small red masonry base is found. The room contains undecorated plaster in the process of being decorated on the east wall and the lower part of the vault. Floor is obscured by earth and debris.

column14: None
column21: Low masonry supports against the north wall. The floor is obscured by earth and debris and the function of this feature is unclear, perhaps a masonry support for a platform or a partition wall for a latrine.

column14: Garden (10) to the southeast.
column21: One enters the triclinium through a doorway in the south corner from the garden (10). The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest-northeast axis. There seems to be some renovation to the southwest wall in the southern corner. As extant, there is some plaster on the northeast wall. There is no evidence of how it was decorated. The floor is indeterminate. No ceiling extant.

column14: Garden (10) to the southeast.
column21: A rectangular shaped dining room overlooking the garden (10), one enters the room from the garden. Floor is covered in lapilli with chunks of plaster containing paint from the walls. There is molding about 8 feet high apparent on the north and northeast walls. Beneath the molding cream color paint with bands of red and large yellow panels. There are red panels bordered with yellow stencil, yellow panels have red boarders. Patterns and colors are repeated. The doorway to the garden (10) is moderate in size. Found just outside in the garden is a storage area under a stairway leading to the second floor.

column14: Encircles the bedroom (21), garden (15) to the south.
column15: Encircules the bedroom (21), garden (15) to the south.
column21: A U-shaped room running around the west, north and east sides of the bedroom. The floor is obscured by earth and vegetation. Traces of plaster survive preserving in the northwest corner with a black lower register and white above. Doorways to the portico and garden at the south end of the east and west axis. High in the northwest corner of the west axis are placings for joists in the east and west walls. High in the east wall is a small square window with restored lintel in the floor above. At the north end of the east axis there is a masonry support (2419). In the southwest corner of the east arm there is a latrine (2420) to the west of the doorway to the garden. Ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: Latrine (2420) to the south
column21: Low eroded masonry support abutting the plaster facing of the east wall of the kitchen. No other support is found. To the south of the base of the wall there is a hole through the wall, drain? Collapse? At the base of the south face of the support are traces of plaster.

column14: Masonry support (2419) to the north.
column21: Plaster based latrine at the south end of the west wall of the east axis of the kitchen. Two masonry blocks with tiled and plastered surface with a drain in between. Part of the tiled drain chute survives although the base of the drain is obscured by debris. Plaster survives against the wall to the read of the latrine. The latrine is separated from the remained of the kitchen by a plastered partition. Directly to the east of the latrine is a doorway leading to the garden.

column14: Garden (15), Room #21 to the southeast, room #20 to the northwest.
column15: Garden (15), Room #21 to the southeast, room #20 to the northwest.
column21: From an eastern large doorway we enter a beautifully decorated rectangular shaped dining room with a northwest - southeast axis. The door is roughly axial to the main entrance of the house. The southeast wall of the dining room has a good sized window overlooking the portico of the garden (15). The floor construction appears to be concrete. The general condition of the room: all four walls are in place, the ceiling shows molding for a barreled vault, but the modern construction of the roof is a higher angled ceiling. It is not certain that this follows the ancient design but it is possible. The modern ceiling is perhaps 6 feet higher that the vaulted evidence. The placement of the banquet symposium consists of one on the south wall, one on the north wall and one center of the west wall. The banquet symposium paintings have been removed, but they commemorate feasts specific to this house and its owners. The socle represents typical fourth style paintings. On the east wall, there is a large notched area with an extrusion (painted) next to the couch niche (also painted red with the plants perhaps a aloe vera plant like the one currently in the peristyle). The second panel area has a stenciled divider with a white background. These panels have red, yellow and gold. There are large black rectangular frames with vaulted tops. There panels include interior gold stencil frames. There are eight such panels. There are three intriguing banquet scenes that have been removed. The remaining panels show winged figures (sexist and very cute). The black panels are divided by the yellow panels which there are 11. The same white boarder is across the top of this level of panels. A third level is largely obscured, but the dominant element are white stencil boarders. Above that we come to molding. Above the molding on the south wall is a circular window which appears in the center of the wall. A doorway to a small oddly-shaped storeroom is reportedly walled of in antiquity, but there is a new lintel and opening. On the southwest wall to the peristyle, there is a long high rectangular window.

column14: None
column21: There is a niche on the southeast wall which is nicely painted indicating that they do not utilize a masonry couch, only a portable one. The niche covers almost the entire length of the wall and is in very good condition.

column14: Atrium (2) to the east, Tablinum (6) to the east.
column15: Atrium (2) to the east, Tablinium (6) to the east.
column21: The triclinium lies on the west side of the atrium. The atrium, entrance is through a narrow door. The room is L-shaped. The wing which leads to a doorway on the east side opening to the tablinum. The doorway provides access from the area of the garden (15) and the kitchen (19). The triclinium itself is rectangular in shape on a north-south axis. Plaster remains on the south wall indicating that the room was decorated, but none survives. The floor is indeterminate nor is the ceiling extant.

column14: None
column21: On the south wall about waist high built into the wall is a slightly convex all the way back to the west wall to accommodate a portable triclinium. Small fragments of plaster painted in red survive on the edge on the east side of the south wall.

column14: atrium (3)
column21: The dining room is a rectangular shaped room with a NW/SE axis.  It is entered from a doorway to the southeast from the atrium (3).  Threshold survives & is marble.  Floor is obscured by lapilli, does not appear to exist.  No ceiling extant.  Traces of plaster still exist on all 4 walls.  Evidence of paint, red lower register.  Part of the crown molding on the southeast and northwest walls.  No pattern discernible, in poor condition  however part of the tynpanum still exists on the northwest wall in the north corner leading to the conclusion of a vaulted ceiling.  Along the southeast wall next to the entrance is a window open to the atrium (3) in the south corner.  This room is northwest of the entrance in the first portion of the house.  Lintel of the window and doorway are modern reconstruction.  The center of the northwest wall is partially brick and the rest rubble.

column14: Overlooks garden dining peristyle (10) to the north.  Hallway (4) east.  Dining room (7) to west.
column15: Overlooks garden dining peristyle (10) to the north.  Hallway (4) east.  Dining room (7) to west.
column21: Entering dining room from the east, on N wall the window has fallen to floor which overlooks garden (10).  Rectangular room NW-SE axis w/lapilli and no ceiling.  On NW wall there is door w/stone threshold leading to another dining room (7).  4th style painting red/yellow is apparent on S wall. Stenciling appearing on 2 red panels on S wall, one yellow panel in between.  One red panel on NE wall.  Bottom panel around room shows evidence of yellow paint.

column14: Dining room (7) to SW, kitchen (13) to NE, dining room (26) to N, hallway (4) to NW.
column15: Dining room (7) to SW, kitchen (13) to NE, dining room (26) to N, hallway (4) to NW.
column21: Enter through hallway (4) in line w/front entrance to wide entrance from NW.  It is framed by 2 columns which has doric capitals.  Has flower planter w/indications on 2 columns w/red plaster along NE side.  Columns predate the flower planter.  Dining room 26 on our North West of entrance, on NW wall there aedicular lararium w/shelf.  Banded in red w/cream no design or persons appear.  There is a masonry triclinium w/4 columns doric only SE one in rear is fully seen along SW wall.  The dining room has minimal evidence of 4th style painting on the south corner.  On E side of the entrance to dining room (7) there is a scavi protective shelf above painting on plaster of blue and yellow.

column14: None
column21: Slope still apparent.  Masonry triclinium w/ 4 doric columns for a pergola only one of which is fully seen today.  Triclinium is in poor condition with the left arm on the northwest side of the dining garden.  A top of a column and slap is currently in position where a table would have been placed.

The dining room is a rectangular room with northwest/southeast axis.  One enters the room from the southeast through a wide doorway from the dining garden/peristyle (10).  The door threshold remains with post holes for doors.  The floor is obscured by debris and vegetation.  Ceiling no longer extant.  Evidence of plaster and decoration remains on all walls.  Decoration appears to be 4th style with red paint.  Part of the crown molding remains on the southwest wall, from the west corner extending halfway into the room.  Molding also exists along the northwest wall extending from the north corner for about 1/3 of the wall.  The rest of the northwest wall is obscured by vegetation.  The room probably had a vaulted ceiling at one time, but evidence is obscured by vegetation.  Evidence suggests the NW wall was painted / decorated differently than the other walls with traces of yellow paint along both the north and west corners.

column14: Cont. to garden (10) SW.  Dining room (26) to east.  Hallway (15) to NW.
column15: Cont. to garden (10) SW.  Dining room (26) to east.  Hallway (15) to NW.
column21: We enter kitchen from SE doorway.  You immediately see lararium on E wall.  Prep platform on E wall is plastered.  Surface filled w/debris.  Move on and see on E wall a cooking platform w/small segment piece of lip.  The arched storage area for fuel.  SW there is small window leading into dining garden (10).  Doorway leading to hallway (15) to the NW.

column14: None
column15: Above preparation platform on east wall
column21: Because of debris cannot check for method of exhaust from cooking.  Have good surface (4 tiles) tiny evidence of lip.  The arched recess goes to floor to hold cooking fuel.  Platform is on the E wall.

column14: Below lararium on east wall.  Below cooking platform on east wall also.
column16: Below lararium on east wall.  Below cooking platform on east wall also.
column21: Prep platform one E wall in trapezoidal shape no clear cut surface.  Shows 3 plaster layers.

column14: Above prep platform on east wall
column16: Above prep platform on east wall
column21: On E wall small proj shelf aedicular shape.  Evidence of restoration because 2 layers of painted plaster appear.  Earlier layer cream w/red.  Newer layer is red.

column14: NW room 20, SE hallway 15
column21: The kitchen is a long narrow rectangular room with a NW SE axis.  One can enter the kitchen from a doorway SE to a hallway (15) or from a doorway NW onto a room (20).  The floor is obscured by vegetation and debris and celling is no longer extant.  Both lintels on each doorway are modern constructions.  The lintel on the NW door is collapsed.  The kitchen opens to a preparation room 17 along the middle of the SW wall.  Along the NE wall of center is a cooking platform (2435) with an arched recess for storage.  The masonry cooking platform is in poor condition.  Only a small amount of plaster remains in the NE wall in the E corner with no signs of paint or decoration.

column14: None
column21: Along the NW wall off center is the remains of a masonry cooking platform.  The platform has an arched recess for storage.

column14: kitchen 16 to the NE
column21: The room is rectangular in shape with a NW SE axis.  It is entered through a doorway approximately center of the NE wall.  The floor is obscured with vegetation and debris and the ceiling is non extant.  All walls have some remaining plaster.  SE wall the paint is non discernible.  Along the SE wall high end centered in the wall is a small window opening onto hallway (15).  Along the NW wall in the N corner is another window in mid-height of the wall with remaining plaster.  Next to this window in the middle of the NW wall is a large rectangular window looking onto room (20).  The lintel of the window is a modern wooden construction.  Also high in the NW wall is 3rd round window with very little evidence of plaster remaining.  Along the SW and part of the SE wall there remains evidence for some kind of shelving.

column14: To garden dining peristyle (10) to north, and dining room (6) to west.
column15: To garden dining peristyle (10) to north, and dining room (6) to west.
column21: We move into S to rectangular dining room on NW-SE axis.  Lapilli floor, signs of plaster.  No ceiling.  On new red after 62 AD painting, patches of wall.  Thresholds step from dining room (6) to the east leads into this dining room.  Overlooks door w/stone threshold overlooking garden, dining peristyle (10).  On NW wall there is unusual replastering which may indicate a niche.

column14: dining garden to the SE
column21: The dining room is a rectangular room NW SE axis.  The room is entered from a doorway in the S corner from the dining garden 10.  The threshold for the doorway is a modern reconstruction.  The floor is obscured by vegetation and debris and ceiling is no longer extant.  Plaster remains on all walls with very little evidence of decoration / paint.  Some paint remains along the bottom of the NE wall.  In the W corner of SW wall remains a couch niche with partial plaster remaining.  On the NW wall is some slight evidence that the room perhaps had a vaulted ceiling in antiquity along with a small post pole SW wall for support.

column14: None
column21: Along the SW wall in the W corner is a couch niche extending to approx. 1/3 of the wall.  Some plaster remains within the niche however there is no discernable evidence of painting.  Condition is really poor.

column14: None
column21: Lararium.  NW wall we see aedicular shaped lararium.  Eye level projecting shelf.  Red border in aedicular shape w/cream background.  No persons or flowers etc. appear.

column14: To dining room and garden dining peristyle dining room (10)
column16: To dining room and garden dining peristyle dining room (10)
column21: SW corner of irregular garden area there is evidence of a water source, well.  The circular well is filled in with large pieces of stones & plaster.

column14: To hallway and garden dining room peristyle (10).
column16: To hallway and garden dining room peristyle (10).
column21: Drain appears in SE corner of irregular shaped room.  Evidence of slope leading underneath wall of the hallway.

column14: atrium 3 is to the NW
column21: Small square shop, rough step down to the street.  Wide open doorway facing S.  Floor obscured by lapilli.  Poorly preserved plaster on N-E-W walls.  Narrow doorway on NW corner to atrium (3).  Two large steps to the E of the shop entrance in the street outside.  Traces of plaster survived in the corner.  No clear association with food & drink.  Identification is based on relationship to the restaurant entrance 15 and proximity to the Porta di Nola.  Fountain down the street at the junction with the next insula.

column14: With serving room to the NW and room 8 to the SE.
column15: With serving room to the NW and room 8 to the SE.
column21: Enter the Dining room through an entrance the full length of the two walls to the SW.  This rectangular dining room contains a window in the southeast wall looking on the garden.  NW/SE Axis.  The floor is concrete.  There is a reconstructed wooden ceiling.  Over the N entrance, there is a reconstructed lintel.  In the east corner there is a couch niche for the sumus lecturs.  The walls are decorated in the 4th style with a black socle, alternating red, cream, & yellow panels, with blue & green edging.  There is white molding.  Today all three walls are in place, but the N wall is partially reconstructed & the SW wall is almost entirely reconstructed, s indicated by the brick dividing layer.

column14: None
column21: The niche is located in the East corner of the room.  It is low, with a decorative, painted nothed area above.  The guest of honor overlooks the serving room, street counter, programmate, & entrance to an unexcavated structure.

column14: Room 2 to the NW, Room 10 to the W
column15: Room 2 to the NW, Room 10 to the W
column21: Rectangular room with doorway opening N to Room 2.  Axis NW/SE the floor is obscured by dust - coccio pesto.  Third style painting white base with architectural elements, birds, theatrical masks and figures.  There is a pleotened window with a restored linked in the SW wall.  On the N frame of the window there is a geometric grath to.  In the SE wall there is a tunnel through the wall.  The central picture survives in the center of the SW wall, poorly preserved images of figures and trees.  Partially Preserved crown molding and vaulted plaster ceiling with joist holes above in the S wall.  Modern ceiling above.  Threshold to door obscured by dirt.  On either side of door way are holes for beam to close door.  Threshold preserves placinps to door.  Shallow couch niche 2456 at the Southern end of the E wall.  Shallow couch niche 2458 at the Southern end of the W wall below windows.  At the E end of the N wall painting 2457.

column14: serving room to the SE(room #2)
column21: One enters the large counter room from the SE by way of the serving room (Room #2).  The room is defined by the 2 arms of the counter.  The counter room space is roughly square.  As extent today, the N corner of the floor has been excavated to reveal the foundation of the counter arm that is parallel with the Via de Del'Abbondanza.  The floor seems to be of coccio pesto.  The wall as extent shoes 3rd style wall painting dominated by red color.  Ceiling appears to have been quite high but is no longer extant and has a modern reconstruction.  On SW wall approximately. 1/2 way up appear 2 post holes for showing bizow the post hole in the SE is another post hole of Unknown use.

column14: None
column21: The L-shaped counter defines the NW and NE sides of the room.  The longest arm in the NW parallels the Via Dell' Abbondanza.  The second arm is perpendicular to he Via Dell' Abbondanza and runs NW to SE.  As extant, on the interior within the room, the counter is about 3 feet high.  On the SE end of the arm perpendicular to the Via Dell' Abbondanza was a hearth slightly wider than the counter arm itself.  The conditions is poor.  The counter was decorated on he interior of the room the decoration is nearly gone, but the Eastern arm, shows sign of red paint.  On the exterior of the Eastern arm, the decoration appears to be 3rd style, with a white background and at least one lion still visible, and a bird.  On the exterior of the N arm which ninspara ael with the Via Dell' Abbondanza, the decoration in red, blue, and orange is in a stylistic pattern bordered by a red stripe.  In the NE corner, as reconstructed a marble pillar, defines the corner.

column14: Garden 7 to the W
column21: Rectangular room NW/SE axis.  Doorway with stone threshold to garden at W end of SE wall.  Plastered window in the center of the SW wall narrowing towards garden, floor obscured by earth.  Opening through NW wall tunnel?  In the SW wall there at an anghe consistence with staircase?  Over the southern 2/3 of room a low floor above has been restored-of storage?  Undecorated plaster on all four walls, poorly preserved.  At the N end of the NE wall there is a lararium painting excellent condition 2451.  In the N corner there is a low narrow working plat form 2450.

column14: Lararium painting 2451 is above the platform on E wall.
column16: Lararium painting 2451 is above the platform on E wall.
column21: Low rectangular masonry cooking platform with wide shallow concrete surface partially filled with earth.  N lower of Kitchen extending along NE wall.  Surface of platform up is well preserved.

column14: Above cooking platform 2450.
column21: Well preserved lararium painting on the NE wall.  However register shows 2 serperate - agathadaemons on wither side of an altar with vegetation in the background.  Upper register shows the lares on wither side of the of a lararium with garlands above framing the scene.  The two lares are powering liquid from a rhytom into a jug in their opposite hand.

column14: Triclinium (9) to the southeast, Room 1 to the northwest, hallway (10) to east, Dining room (4) to the east.
column15: Triclinium (9) to the southeast, Room 1 to the northwest, hallway (10) to east, Dining room (4) to the east.
column21: One enters the serving room from the north by way of room #1. The room is rectangular in shape on an SE/NW axis. The entrance to the counter room is located in the northwest corner. Entrance to the triclinium (9) to the southeast. To the east of the triclinium (9) is hallway (10) leading to the garden to the east of the entrance to room 10 is the doorway to triclinium (4). On the northeast wall are stairs to the upper floor. In the center of the room on axis with room 1 is a large table. The floor seems to have been of hard plaster cocciopesto. Along the southwest wall is a large counter containing five large, embedded dolia. As reconstructed, the upstairs rooms to the northwest and southeast may have overlooked the serving room. The walls were decorated in what appears to be 3rd style. On the SW wall between the hallway and the triclinium (4) is a painting of a dog wearing a jeweled collar, probably representing the lares and was probably a lararium. On the west wall between the entrance to the counter room (11) and the entrance hall (1) is a painting of Mercury (?). The ceiling as reconstructed is very tall, but is no longer extant.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.

column14: None
column21: On the southwest wall of the room, there is a large counter lying roughly northwest to southeast. Embedded in the counter are 5 large dolia. The counter runs from the northwest wall almost, but not quite to the entrance of the triclinium (9). The counter was stuccoed and painted probably gold in color, though it is very faded.

column14: Other - Table (2455) to the northwest
column21: On the southeast wall between the entrance to room 10 that leads to the garden and the entrance to the triclinium (4) is the painting of a dog sitting on his haunches wearing a jeweled collar. To his right is a tree without foliage. The dog probably represents the lares as guardians of the house and as such, the painting constitutes a lararium.

column14: Counter (24543) to the west, lararium (2454) to the east
column16: Counter (24543) to the west, lararium (2454) to the east
column21: A rather large table lies off center of room #2 on an axis with the doorway of the house. The table has a circular base approximately 3 feet high made of rubble and covered with stucco that was painted red. On top of the base is a large marble basin, round in shape, but shallow with a double lip. In the center of the basin, there seems to have been a socket to support a statue or some decorative element.

column14: Couch niche (2459) to the west, Painting (2459) to the north.
column16: Couch niche (2459) to the west, Painting (2459) to the north.
column21: Shallow, plaster couch niche with plaster surviving in the upper half, black lower register, white above with red boarder and trim. Niche is placed on east and southeast walls.

column14: Couch niche (2456) to the SW, couch niche (2458) to the southwest.
column16: Couch niche (2456) to the SW, couch niche (2458) to the southweswt.
column21: Still life painting in the east corner of the north wall, showing a cockatiel eating cherries from a upturned wicker basket. There is a cherry beneath the foor of the cockateil.

column14: Couch niche (2456) to the east, Painting (2457) to the northeast.
column16: Couch niche (2456) to the east, Painting (2457) to the northeast.
column21: Plastered shallow couch niche. Plaster preserved. Black lower register, white above, red trim. The top of the niche is cut by the window above.

column14: Garden (15) to the south.
column21: Square room with a floor obscured by lapilli. Undecorated plaster on all four walls. Fragments of white plaster survive above the lararium niche (2460) off the center of the northwest wall. At the north end of the northeast wall there is a collapse through to the adjoining room - perhaps original to allow access to small windows in the northwest corner of the north wall. At the east end of the southeast wall there is a doorway with poorly preserved stone threshold and modern wooden restored lintel. In the center of the southeast wall there is a square window with a restored lintel (sp?) looking out into the garden. Ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: None
column21: Arched plastered niche with a tile base. No visible decoration. Indistinct red on seen on the rear wall. Placed off center of the northwest wall.

column14: Room #6 through the doorway to the northwest.
column15: Room #6 through the doorway to the northwest.
column21: Dining room # 5 is located in the south corner of the house. One enters the dining room from a doorway to the northwest. The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest-northeast axis. On the southwest wall, towards the south is a rectangular hole in the wall of unknown use. If the walls were decorated in antiquity, no evidence remains, though there is some stucco on the southwest wall. Floor is indeterminate, obscured by lapilli and debris. Roof is non-extant.

column14: Portico before garden peristyle (15) to the southwest.
column15: Portico before garden peristyle (15) tol the southewest.
column21: We enter the dining room over a threshold from the portico of the peristyle to the southwest. There is a lave threshold to an average sized doorway. The floor is lapilli. The walls are more or less in place. There is no ceiling. On the southwest wall there is a large window looking over the garden. On the southeast wall there is a window high on the wall. There is a quern in the room by the doorway. The northeast wall shows signs of plaster without any color or design. On the southeast wall there is some colorless plaster without any color or design. The southeast wall contains some colorless plaster and a small portion on the wall overlooking the garden. Rectangular room with a northwest - southeast axis. A hole is found on the north base corner of the southwest wall, it appears to be a collapse. A large block in the south corner of the southeast wall, probably from a collapse. Lintels for the doorways appear but are modern. There are at least 8 beam holes present at ceiling height in the northeast corner. There is a arch found in the north wall for support of a cistern below the room.

column14: Garden (15) to the south.
column21: Large rectangular shaped dining room with a northeast-southwest axis. Floor is obscured by debris. Large dip is found at the base of the east and west walls perhaps indicating the original floor level. No plaster is found. In the center of the northeast wall 1/2 foot above the ground there is a terracotta lined drain through the wall to the street outside. At the west end of the southwest wall there is a unfinished opening through to room #12 perhaps providing common access to a small window in the northwest wall. At the south end of the southwest wall is a doorway with no visible threshold and restored lintel opening to the garden (15). Upper courses of all walls are extensively restored. No ceiling.

column14: Garden (15) to the northeast, storeroom (7) to the south.
column15: Garden (15) to the northeast, storeroom (7) to the south.
column21: The kitchen is located in the southwest portion of the house. One enters the kitchen from the northeast from an area of the garden (15). On the southwest wall all the way across is a low cooking platform. To the south is a doorway to a storeroom. On the northwest wall sloping to the northeast there seems to be a groove in the wall, perhaps indicating a covering of sort over the cooking platform. On the southwest wall is a small lararium or light niche. The floor in indeterminate. The ceiling is non-extant. On the northwest wall, above the groove, there is a window leading to room #9. High on the west wall is a window to the outside. Rectangular room with a northwest-southeast axis.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform abuts the northwest wall and southwest wall and extends across the width of the room. As extant, there is no sign of a plaster covering. Masonry construction

column14: Kitchen (2464) room 8 to the north.
column21: One enters the storeroom through a doorway in the northeast corner from the kitchen (8). The room is rectangular in shape on a northeast-southwest axis. Floor is indeterminate, ceiling is non-extant. No evidence of plaster on the walls, though it probably has some in antiquity. As reconstructed, the north wall raises only to a height of the cooking platform in the kitchen and it is not possible to determine if it went any higher in antiquity.

column14: Room 1 to the North.
column21: Rectangular room on SE/NW axis.  Doorway in the NW wall in West corner to Room 1.  To the NW wall, there is a window to Room 1.  Both door and window have restored lintels.  Third style wall painting with traces of decoration on all four walls.  Large areas on NE and SW walls survive; white with black and red trim.  High at the North end of the NE wall is a painting (2470).  In the center of the NE wall there is a fragmentary landscape scene with trees, buildings, statues, altars and other architectural elements.  At the East end of the NE wall, there is a painting (2469).  Above, there is a square window, modern.  The plastered floor is obscured by earth.  Poorly preserved plaster threshold.  Room is in Eastern corner of structure next to entrance.

column14: Wall painting 2470 is to the North.  Painting 2469 is to the West.
column16: Wall painting 2470 is to the North.  Painting 2469 is to the West.
column21: Low rectangular plastered concave niche; plastered bench in the center of the niche, plastered front no longer extant.  White plaster, black border and red trim at the top to fit with the 3rd style pattern elsewhere in the room.  East end of the NE wall.  Niche is in good condition.

column14: Couch niche 2468 is to the SE.  Wall painting 2470 is to the NE.
column16: Couch niche 2468 is to the SE.  Wall painting 2470 is to the NE.
column21: Wall painting in the center of the SW wall.  Landscape scene with portico and tower above.  Lower register tree with two figures sacrificing at an altar with two pillars or similar decorative elements on either side of sacrificial scene.  To the left, the painting is poorly preserved - possible vegetation or landscape above with a reclining animal.

column14: Couch niche 2468 to the SE.  Painting 2469 to the SW.
column16: Couch niche 2468 to the SE.  Painting 2469 to the SW.
column21: Wall painting in 3rd style.  Two extant figs? (In upper register).  Possible third and bird. At North end of NE wall.

column14: Kitchen (4) to NW.  (2) to SW.  (6) to SE.
column15: Kitchen (4) to NW.  (2) to SW.  (6) to SE.
column21: One enters the storeroom from the doorway in the SW corner.  The room is rectangular in shape on a roughly NW/SE axis.  The width of the room on the SE is shorter than the NW.  The walls were covered in stucco and probably painted, though no decoration remains.  The floor is cocciopesto.  On the East wall are a series of seven post holes for the ceiling.

column14: Storeroom (5) to SE.  (2) to SW.
column21: One enters the kitchen from a short doorway past the storeroom near the floor on the SW wall of the hallway.  The entrance is on the South.  In the SE corner just after entering the room is the preparation platform.  In the North corner is an L-shaped cooking platform.  The area along the NW wall has a built-up structure used as a drain that opens through a small hole into the garden.  On the West corner of the SW wall, adjacent to the West end of the cooking platform, is the latrine.  The floor seems to be of a simple beaten plaster.  High on the NW wall is a window that opens onto the garden.  The walls of the kitchen were at one time plastered and painted.  Decorations indeterminate.  On the East wall, above the preparation platform is a lararium painting that has almost completely disappeared.  A portion of the floor below the lararium, between the preparation and cooking platforms, is missing today. On the NE wall, in the East corner, there seems to have been two post holes on line with the post holes that supported the roof of the storeroom.  On the SW wall, just after you enter the room, is a small hole that may have served as a lamp niche.  As reconstructed, there is no evidence of the height of the ceiling above the window on the NW wall.

column14: Lararium painting (2477) to SE.  Preparation platform (2474) to the SE.  Water feature-drain (2476) to NW.  Latrine (2475) to W.
column16: Lararium painting (2477) to SE.  Preparation platform (2474) to the SE.  Water feature-drain (2476) to NW.  Latrine (2475) to W.
column21: The cooking platform is L-shaped with one arm along the NE wall, second arm along NW wall.  As extent, the surface of the platform is indeterminate.  On the arm along the NW wall is a built-up platform used as a drain to the garden.

column14: Cooking platform (2473) to NW.  Lararium painting (2477) to NE.  Latrine (2475) to NW.  Water feature-drain (2476) to NW.
column16: Cooking platform (2473) to NW.  Lararium painting (2477) to NE.  Latrine (2475) to NW.  Water feature-drain (2476) to NW.
column21: The preparation platform lies in the SE corner of the room.  The platform is slightly rectangular in shape on a NE/SW axis.  In the middle, but slightly off-center, is a large round hole.  The platform seems to have been covered with plaster.

column14: Water-feature-drain (2476) to N.  Cooking platform (2473) to NE.  Lararium painting (2477) to E.  Preparation platform (2474) to E.
column16: Water-feature-drain (2476) to N.  Cooking platform (2473) to NE.  Lararium painting (2477) to E.  Preparation platform (2474) to E.
column21: On the NW wall, West corner, is the latrine.  The latrine is essentially inserted into the wall, the top of which is arched.  At the bottom is the seat with semicircular area for an amphora or other container.  The interior of the niche was plastered, though little remains today.

column14: Latrine (2475) to SW.  Cooking platform (2473) to E.  Lararium painting (2477) to E.  Preparation platform (2474) to SE.
column16: Latrine (2475) to SW.  Cooking platform (2473) to E.  Lararium painting (2477) to E.  Preparation platform (2474) to SE.
column21: On top the arm at the cooking platform arm of the NW wall is a rubble construction, built-up approximately 18 inches.  The surface slopes slightly toward the NW toward hole in NW wall, which opens into the garden.  As extant there is no indication of a plaster covering.

column14: None
column21: On the NE wall was a lararium painting.  But, no extant niche or altar, if it existed at all.  The scene is barely visible.

column14: Street with high step, to SE hallway (2) to SW.
column15: Street with high step, to SE hallway (2) to SW.
column21: We enter on a small door to the North.  A horticultural area of good dimensions; it is rectangular.  Axis NE/SW.  There is currently clover and dandelions, peach tree, plum tree and beechnut tree?  The entire area is enclosed above 8 feet from the house, road and two other structures.  Jashemski reports there were planting beds and water irrigation places.  The NW wall, see an arch lararium with a shelf.  Next to it is an arch with a smaller shelf perhaps for a candle.  A water cistern (2479).  The water recedes, another cistern along the long NW wall.  The wall that we look at is rubble.  There are small examples-plaster at the ground level spotted in 3 areas at this NW wall.  The SW short wall shows elements of plaster on the W corner.  This wall contains door 14 to the street with a high stop to the street.  This long wall shows a walled-in doorway.

column14: Lararium (2480) to N.  Well (2481) to S.
column16: Lararium (2480) to N.  Well (2481) to S.
column21: One well at the NW wall, quern next to well.  Plaster remains in interior of well.

column14: Well (2481) to S.  Well (2479) to S.
column16: Well (2481) to S.  Well (2479) to S.
column21: On the NW wall is a lararium niche with small shelf.  Plastered with perhaps a cream paint.  Next to it is an arched recess possibly for a lamp.

column14: None
column21: It is a well with plastered interior walls found in the center of the garden.  Shape is undetermined due to collapse.

column14: Alnum 2 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room.  NW/SW axis.  Doorway with restored lentil at the southern end of these wall.  Traus of stone threshold.  Blocked doorway in the center of the SE wall.  The upper threshold, Blocked doorway in the center of the SE wall.  The upper corses of all four walls are heavily restored.  High in the center of the NE wall is a small window with modern lentil.  The floor is obscured by lapilli the room was in a process of being redecorated.  A large ceramic vessel containing lime is in the center of the room.  Traces of plaster survive at the base of the NE wall this red layer over lies all earlier layer of yellow plaster.  At the base of these wall, are several shards of an amphora partially buried in the floor.  Ceiling no longer extant.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, pg 752-3

column14: Hallway 11 to the SE
column21: The kitchen is located on west side of house.  One enters the kitchen through a doorway to the northwest.  The kitchen is roughly rectangular in shape on a southwest-northeast axis.  On NW wall is W corner is coking platform.  To NE to cooking platform are remains of sm, dolium.  On the SW wall is the latrine.  On NE wall above cooking platform is a window looking into room 8.  The floor is uncertain.  The walls retain no evidence of stucco.  The ceiling is not extant.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, pg 752-3

column14: cooking platform to the northwest latrine to the west
column16: cooking platform to the northwest latrine to the west
column21: To the SE of cooking platform is a partially-embedded sm, dolium.  The dolium is only partially extant and seems to tilt slightly toward the door.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, pg 752-3

column14: cooking platform to the North east and dolium to the east
column16: cooking platform to the North east and dolium to the east
column21: Southwest wall are the remains of the latrine.  Only the two bases remain - as reconstructed.  The base on the NW wall abuts the wall and partially blocks an arched opening into the SW wall.  The use of this archway is unknown.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, pg 752-3

column14: Dolium to the SE, Latrine to the West
column16: Dolium to the SE, Latrine to the West
column21: The cooking platform is located on NE wall in the N corner.  Made of rubble, there is no evidence of stucco or decoration.  As reconstructed, the top is flat and made of broken tiles.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, pg 752-3

column14: Portico (12) to NE
column21: We enter this kitchen from a low doorway with a stone threshold.  Outside is a portico around which was a peristyle garden to the northeast.  The first thing you see in this ancient kitchen are 10 assorted storage containers filled to the brim and one (1) wrapped bag.  I note broken quern.  The floor is soiled, but appears to have been beaten plaster.  The walls are in place and plastered with no signs of paint or decoration except for Lararium. The kitchen is a rectangular room with a SE-NW axis.

column14: Cooking platform (2489) to west.  Prep platform to (2490) to south.  Lararium (2498) to west.
column16: Cooking platform (2489) to west.  Prep platrom to (2490) to south.  Lararium (2498) to west.
column21: In the Eastern corner is a raised semicircular feature which is probably a well.  Signs of white plaster in the interior of the well.  It is now filled in with lapilli.  There are also remains of plaster on the exterior top and sides.

column14: Lararium (2498) to West.  Water Feature (Cistern-2488) to East.  Prep Platform (2490) to southeast.
column16: Lararium (2498) to West.  Water Feature (Cistern-2488) to East.  Prep Platform (2490) to SouthEast.
column21: On the southwest wall at the west end is a fine cooking platform.  It is square, with the top being cement.  Examples of high lips on the platform touching the walls. Larger deep-arched fuel storage space filled with Custodi containers,on the top is what appears to be an ancient grill which could serve to lift cooking equipment off the hot coals, but could be a modern window grate.  Construction is masonry and brick.

column14: lararium (2498) to NW, water feature (2488) to NE, cooking platform (2489) to NW
column16: lararium (2498) to NW, water feature (2488) to NE, cooking platform (2489) to NW
column21: There is evidence in the walls for slots to support a wooden preparation platform.  Slots for one large wooden platform and underneath for a smaller one.  Slots have plaster inside remaining and indentations in the SE wall in the remaining plaster for the shelf.

column14: None
column16: 13 ti the Northeast, 3 to the Southwest, 12 and 8 to the Northwest.
column21: Large rectangular room Northwest/Southeast axis.  Poorly preserved fragments of undecorated plaster on the Northeast and Southeast walls.  Floor is obscured by lapilli.  At the western end of the Southwest wall, there is a narrow doorway to 3.  Wide doorway in Northwest wall - no visible threshold.  Opens to peristyle and garden 8.  In the Northeast corner there is an alcove formed by the insertion of room 13 to the Southeast.  At the Northern end of the Northwest wall, there is a rectangular window with placing for shuttering in the frame.  In the Northeast corner of the room there is a large dolium.

column14: None
column16: 10 to the Northwest. 12 to the Southeast.
column21: One enters the processing room from the South by way of area 12.  The room has a Southeast-Northwest axis.  The processing room was a pseudoperistyle with two columns in the southeast side of the puteus that has been converted for processing fish sauce.  The pseudoperistyle is defined by a low wall (Pouteus) which begins against the Northeast wall and runs roughly Northeast-Southwest, turning to the Northwest just before reaching the Southwest wall.  The Northwest-Southeast arm extends to just past bedroom 7 where it ends and makes a right angle turn to the Northeast where it ends about 3 feet. The end stone of this third arm has a decorative design and may in fact be a reused stone.  Farther to the Northwest, where the 3rd arm turns at a right angle along the southwest wall are three large dolia, each containing the remains of fish sauce (Allec).  Along the North wall, running roughly Southwest/Northeast are 2 additional dolia, just beyond the 2nd dolia a doorway with 3 steps leads to garden 10 to the Northwest.  In the Northeast corner of the processing room is the latrine.  TO the Southeast of the front wall of the latrine is a dolium containing the remains of fish sauce.  In the East corner of the processing room is a built-up platform up to the level of a hole in the Northeast wall that extends to the street on the outside.  Along the Northwest wall on either side of the doorway to garden 10 is a garden painting.  The latrine in the Northeast corner seems to have been inserted into the corner as the painting shows a ground line of plants at the top.  It is uncertain if the garden painting extended to the Northeast before the latrine was inserted.  The condition all along the wall is poor, though it clearly has dense foliage and birds.  Portions of the Southwest wall have plaster, but little remains of decoration.  The Northeast wall, as extent, lacks plaster.

column14: Dolium (2500) to SE.  Dolium (2501) to SE.  Dolium (2502) to NW.  Dolium (2503) to N.  Latrine (2494) to N.  Dolium (2504) to E.  Water feature - drain (2495) to E.
column16: Dolium (2500) to SE.  Dolium (2501) to SE.  Dolium (2502) to NW.  Dolium (2503) to N.  Latrine (2494) to N.  Dolium (2504) to E.  Water feature - drain (2495) to E.
column21: Located to the N of 2501 along the SW wall, 2493 still contains the remains of fish sauce.  The dolium is of the large globular type with a thick lip.  As extant today, the circular lid sits atop the lip.  The dolium shows evidence of having been reconstructed.  Partially buried in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2500) to SW.  Dolium (2501) to SW.  Dolium (2493) to SW.  Dolium (2502) to W.  Dolium (2503) to W.  Dolium (2504) to SE.  Water feature - drain (2495) to SE.
column16: Dolium (2500) to SW.  Dolium (2501) to SW.  Dolium (2493) to SW.  Dolium (2502) to W.  Dolium (2503) to W.  Dolium (2504) to SE.  Water feature - drain (2495) to SE.
column21: The latrine lies in the NE corner of the processing room.  One enters the latrine through a small doorway on the NW side.  The seating platform is made of rubble & abuts the N & E walls.  As extant today, there are 2 amphorae that appear to have been broken and formed to accommodate the seating platform.  The floor is too changed to determine its construction.  On the N wall are five post holes as evidence of a roof.  As extant, the walls show no sign of stucco or decoration except above the post holes where a continuation of the garden painting still remains.

column14: Dolium (2500) to W.  Dolium (2501) to W.  Dolium (2493) to W.  Dolium (2502) to W.  Dolium (2503) to NW.  Latrine to NW.  Dolium (2504) to NW.
column16: Dolium (2500) to W.  Dolium (2501) to W.  Dolium (2493) to W.  Dolium (2502) to W.  Dolium (2503) to NW.  Latrine to NW.  Dolium (2504) to NW.
column21: In the E corner of the processing room abutting against the wall has been constructed a podium built up nearly to the height of a hole in the east wall that is open to the street on the outside.  The podium was probably used for the cleaning of utensils used in fish processing.

column14: W garden extends into room 9, peristyle 8 is to the SE.
column15: W garden extends into room 9, peristyle 8 is to the SE.
column21: Large rectangular area accessed through doorway in the SE wall with three steps down to peristyle (8).  Originally a garden.  In its final phase, this was converted into a storage area indicated by the presence of quantities of amphora (2497) in the N corner.  In the center is cistern 2499.  NW/SE axis.  Ceiling now extant, floor earthen.

column14: Cistern 2499 is to the S.
column21: At least 44 amphorae embedded in lapilli and volcanic debris.  The amphorae have been stacked upside down to drain the residue of their contents.  The amphorae are principally dressel 21-22 amphorae.  Several tituli are visible as well as a stamp, brackets not able to read.  Publication indicate tituli identified the contents as principally wine as well as defrutum.  Excellent condition.

column14: Water feature (2488) to E.  Cooking platform (2489) to E.  Prep platform (2490) to SE.
column16: Water feature (2488) to E.  Cooking platform (2489) to E.  Prep platform (2490) to SE.
column21: On the two walls behind the cooking platform exist a lararium painting.  On the west end NW wall we see one protective snake, colors are cream, red and green.  The SW wall in west corner has a painting of a cream-colored background w/foliage and red flowers.

column14: Amphora 2497 to the N.
column21: Poorly preserved masonry plastered lip of cistern.  The cistern is now completely full of earth.  It is in the center of the garden.

column14: Dolium 2501 to NW, Dolium 2493 to NW, Dolium 2502 to NW, Dolium 2503 to N, Dolium 2504 to NE, Latrine 2494 to N, water feature-drain 2495 to E
column16: Dolium 2501 to NW, Dolium 2493 to NW, Dolium 2502 to NW, Dolium 2503 to N, Dolium 2504 to NE, Latrine 2494 to N, water freature-drain 2495 to E
column21: The southernmost dolium is partially embolded in the ground.  It still retains the dried remains of fish sauce.  As extant, the dolium is the globular type, but one side of it has been broken off.  Located along the SW wall.

column14: Dolium 2500 to SE, Dolium 2493 to NW, Dolium 2502 to NW, Dolium 2503 to N, Latrine 2494 to N, Dolium 2504 to NE, water-feature-drain 2495 to E
column16: Dolium 2500 to SE, Dolium 2493 to NW, Dolium 2502 to NW, Dolium 2503 to N, Latrine 2494 to N, Dolium 2504 to NE, water-feature-drain 2495 to E
column21: Located to the NW of 2500 Dolium along the SW wall 2501 is a dolium of the type with straight sides.  Contains remains of fish sauce.  As extant today, the lip has been broken off, Partially buried in the ground.

column14: Dolium 2500 is S, Dolium 2501 is S, Dolium 2493 to SE, Dolium 2503 to E, Latrine 2494 to E, Water feature- Drain to SE, Dolium 2504 to E.
column16: Dolium 2500 is S, Dolium 2501 is S, Dolium 2493 to SE, Dolium 2503 to E, Latrine 2494 to E, Water feature- Drain to SE, Dolium 2504 to E.
column21: Located in the NW corner of the N wall is a large dolium with straight sides and large lip.  It is partially buried in the grounds still contains the remains of fish sauce.

column14: Dolium (2500) to SW, Dolium (2501) to the SW, Dolium (2493) to the SW, Dolium (2502) to the west. Latrine (2494) to the northeast. Water Feature, Drain (2495) to the SE, Dolium (2504) to the east.
column16: Dolium (2500) to SW, Dolium (2501) to the SW, Dolium (2493) to the SW, Dolium (2502) to the west. Laterine (2494) to the northeast. Water Feature, Drain (2495) to the SE, Solium (2504) to the east.
column21: To the east of 2502 is a large dolia with straight sides. Still containing the remains of fish sauce. The lip has been broken off, but it is still partially buried in the ground. This dolium is a little smaller that 2502.

column14: Dolium (2500) to the west, Dolium (2501) to the west, Dolium (2493) to the west, Dolium (2502) to the west, Dolium (2503) to the west. Latrine (2494) to the north. Water Feature, drain (2495) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2500) to the west, Dolium (2501) to the west, Dolium (2493) to the west, Dolium (2502) to the west, Dolium (2503) to the west. Laterine (2494) to the north. Water Feature, drain (2495) to the southeast.
column21: A large globular dolium with thick lips, still containing the remains of fish sauce, lies to the southwest of the latrine. It is partially buried into the ground.

column14: Garden (7) ti the northeast.
column21: You enter this kitchen from a portico peristyle garden on the southeast wall with a restored lintel.  This kitchen is a long rectangular room on the northwest ending wall of the structure with a SW-NE axis.  There is a low entrance to a small platform with a water drain hole to the outside.  A latrine takes up the southwest corner of the kitchen.  We look at a sizable cooking platform with two large fuel receptacles.  The top surface is concrete with four lips.  On the northeast wall and the southeast wall there is evidence of a lararium painting.  There is a pounded soil floor, the walls are in place with a replaced ceiling.  There is a triangular opening, northeast over doorway.  On the southwest wall, there is a rectangular window over the latrine.  Along southwest and southeast wall, south corner dividing kitchen and latrine there is the remains of plaster with evidence of decoration and paint.  Condition makes subject matter impossible to discern.  High in northwest wall in west end is a small window or post hole.

column14: Latrine to the southwest, water basin to the west, lararium to the southeast.
column16: Latrine to the southwest, water basin to the west, lararium to the southeast.
column21: Long rectangular cooking platform with four ceramic lips protecting the cement surface along the southeast wall of the kitchen.  There are 2 rectangular fuel storage spaces reaching the floor.  On the southeast and northeast walls above the platform is a lararium painting.  Turquoise, crimson garlands, also yellow; turquoise arch.  On the southwest wall is a raised semicircular platform with raised lips and a drain to the street.  Masonry construction.

column14: Cooking platform below.  Latrine to the southwest.  Water basin to the west.
column16: Cooking platform below.  Latrine to the southwest.  Water basin to the west.
column21: On the southeast and northeast walls above the platform is a lararium painting.  Turquoise, crimson, yellow garlands.  Turquoise arch below garland.

column14: Water basin to the northwest.  Cooking platform to the northeast.  Lararium to the northeast.
column16: Water basin to the northwest.  Cooking platform to the northeast.  Lararium to the northeast.
column21: Latrine with window above it in the southwest wall.  In the south corner is the latrine.  Part of the two masonry supports remain with some plaster also remaining.  Interior filled with earth and debris.

column14: Latrine to the southeast.  Cooking platform to the northeast.  Lararium to the northeast.
column16: Latrine to the southeast.  Cooking platform to the northeast.  Lararium to the northeast.
column21: On the southwest wall, west corner is a raised, semicircular platform with raised lips and a drain to the street.  Masonry construction.

column14: Room 7 to the northeast.  Room 3 to the southeast.
column15: Room 7 to the northeast.  Room 3 to the southeast.
column21: Square room, large doorway in the center of the northeast wall looking to the garden (7).  Modern lintel over the door and masonry threshold.  The floor is plastered.  Nine holes are placed symmetrically through the floor.  Function unclear - placings for triclinia? Or modern? The holes along the southeast and northwest walls and are open; the remaining four are blocked.  Early 4th style painting survives on all four walls.  Faux marble lower register.  Yellow panels above with simple architectural elements and still-lifes of birds. White upper register with animals, birds, vegetation inserted into simple geometric borders.  A large window with modern lintel has been inserted into the eastern end of the southern wall.

column14: Dining room (4) to the northwest.  Atrium (2) to the northeast.
column15: Dining room (4) to the northwest.  Atrium (2) to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular room NE-SW axis.  Plaster floor, no threshold.  Doorway in the center of the northeast wall opens to the atrium.  In the center of the northeast wall, a large window with modern lintel has been inserted.  High in the southwest wall a square window with modern lintel.  The upper course is modern with modern ceiling.  4th style painting on all four walls alternating red and yellow panels with still-lifes of animals, griffins, musical instruments, and trophies.  Black central panels in northwest and southeast walls.  The southeast wall preserves a central painting showing a swimmer.  In the northeast and especially the southwest and southeast walls, extensive areas of the earlier wall decoration is visible underlying the later 4th style painting.  The earlier decoration appears to have included a landscape scene in the center of the southwest wall and a second possible landscape in the southeast wall, points to it being 3rd style.

We enter this restaurant from a southwest entrance off a rectangular atrium.  A large entrance to this rectangular dining room with NW-SE axis.  A third of the floor remains and is beaten plaster.  To the southeast there is a door to the street food shop.  There is evidence of plaster on all walls.  The evidence consists of white and cream ground with red panels.  Evidence also of a small stenciled band.  From this room we look out on the atrium which repeats the wall pattern.  Perhaps 10' on the southwest wall of the atrium are two circular shaped lararia.  One has a slightly protruding shelf.  There is no ceiling.

column14: Garden (7) to the southwest.  Room 10 to southeast.  Room 12 to southwest.
column15: Garden (7) to the southwest.  Room 10 to southeast.  Room 12 to southwest.
column21: Triclinium (9) is located in the back of the house in the north corner.  One enters through a doorway in the south corner of the room.  The room is rectangular in shape on a roughly SE-NW axis.  In the southeast corner is the doorway to room 10.  The floor seems to be of a cocciopesto.  The walls all contain painting, probably 4th style.  Among the motifs in the panels are various types of birds.  On the southwest wall, there is a large window into the garden.  High in the center of the northeast wall is a small window.  To the north of this window on the northeast wall is a small window.  The original ceiling is not extent and has been reconstructed.

column14: Room 13 to the northwest.
column21: One enters the shop at entrance 10 from the southeast through a large door.  The room is rectangular in shape on a SW-NE axis.  In the west corner is the doorway into room 13.  The foor is cocciopesto and the roof is non-extant.  The room was covered in tucco, but no painting remains.  On the north wall, to the east of the doorway to 13, there was a second doorway to 13 that has been walled-up.  In the southeast corner of the room is the base for stairs to the upper floor.

column14: Rooms 4 & 5 to NW, rooms 3 & 11 to W.
column15: Rooms 4 & 5 to NW, rooms 3 & 11 to W.
column21: N/W S/E axis of rectangular room originally open air dining area.  The lararium 2516 has two terracotta gables to protect it from the elements.  There are two doorways in the N wall opening to two small rooms.  The N wall is poorly preserved although traces of pink plaster are visible.  A small alcove at the northern end of the E wall contains a cooking platform 2519.  In the center of the E wall is a small square plaster and terracotta lined downpipe into the wall.  Below this at the base of the wall there is a poorly preserved drain.  The wall preserves plaster throughout with traces of red color but the state of preservation is too poor to determine any decorative scheme.  The southern half of the E wall is taken up by lararium 2516 and its associated paintings.  Poorly preserved southern wall with traces of plaster but no decoration.  Large window in the center of the western wall.  Terracotta lined downspout in the wall to the N.  Below this is cistern 2518 at the base of the wall.  Areas of red plaster survive in the lower register.  At the N end of the W wall there are 2 doorways.  The doorway to corridor 11 has a marble threshold with placings for door.  Stone flooring preserved immediately adjoining threshold.  The adjoining doorway to the N to garden 3 has a stone threshold.  The southern half of the room consists of masonry triclinium 2517.  Opus signinum floor survives along the western wall between the dining couch 2517 and the cistern 2518.  The remainder of the floor is obscured by lapilli.  Room located at rear of the property.  The angle of the three surviving downpipe in the E and W walls suggest they may have supported the poles for an awning or similar cover over the dining couch.

column14: Above E arm of couch 2517; cistern 2518 to W; cooking platform 2519 to NW.
column16: Above E arm of couch 2517; cistern 2518 to W; cooking platform 2519 to NW.
column21: Conical plastered lararium niche on the rear wall.  A Gordon's head with garland above which there is a crescent moon.  Red trim, blue stars on white background.  The interior face of the frame shows 2 deer with garland above.  The exterior face of the frame is decorated with vegetation on a white background.  Above the niche are two tile gables.  Below the niche 2 snakes agathadaemones on either side of an altar with vegetation in the background.  On either side of the niche are depicted 2 lares pouring liquid from a rhyton into a jug with garlands above.  The whole is framed with 2 painted herms.  To the left of the lararium is a restored downpipe (see comments about awning in room description).  The decoration below the snakes does not survive.

column14: Above the eastern arm is lararium 2516.  NW is cistern 2518; N is cooking platform 2519.
column16: Above the eastern arm is lararium 2516.  NW is cistern 2518; N is cooking platform 2519.
column21: Masonry U-shaped triclinium.  The western arm preserves red plaster facing.  The surface of the couch is plastered and slopes down towards the three walls.  The southern and eastern couches are less well preserved.  Between the arms is obscured by vegetation, lapilli and earth.  Drawings from Jashemski and PPM do not show any feature between the arms of the couch although Oliva's drawing in PPM has a circular capstone.  At the northern end of the western arm a drain has been cut into the surface of the couch which drains into a terracotta drain at the base of the N face of the couch.  The water will then have drained across the opus signinum floor to the drain into cistern 2518.  Above the western arm of the couch there is a large window to room 9.

column14: Couch 2517 to S; cooking platform 2519 to NE; lararium 2516 to SE.
column16: Couch 2517 to S; cooking platform 2519 to NE; lararium 2516 to SE.
column21: Circular cistern with the top of a dolium used as a ???.  Large opus signinum lip around the head of the cistern extending into opus signinum floor to the S.  On the southern side of the interior side of the cistern there is a terracotta pipe that drains from the southern base of the opus signinum lip.  A second plastered pipe runs from the northern interior face of the cistern.  Water would have flowed into the southern drainpipe across the opus signinum floor which is bowed to allow its passage from a terracotta drain at the base of the triclinium 2517.

column14: Couch 2517 and lararium 2516 to the SE.  Cistern 2518 to the S.
column16: Couch 2517 and lararium 2516 to the SE.  Cistern 2518 to the S.
column21: Rectangular masonry cooking platform.  Terracotta tiled surface, plastered frontage.  Lip is not preserved.  Well preserved platform except in W corner.  Located in alcove in north corner of room.

column14: Horticultural area #3 to the N.
