column21: The kitchen is located in the SE corner of the horticultural space #3.  One enters the kitchen from the NE.  To the SE is a vaulted niche with two masonry supports for a cooking platform.  Each abutting a wall.  In the SW corner of the kitchen is a latrine.  To the NW of the latrine is a small storage space.  On the SW wall is a large window.  The floor is indeterminate.  As extant, the ceiling seems to have been vaulted, but higher than the vault over the cooking platform.  The walls were stuccoed and probably painted in antiquity, but no decoration remains.  The vaulted ceiling supports a stairway to the upper floor.

column14: Storage space to the northeast, cooking platform to the southeast
column16: Storeage space to the northeast, cooking platform to the southeast
column21: The latrine is located in the southwest corner of the kitchen. The floor is indeterminate. The height of the walls to the latrine is unknown, but probably extended to the height of the kitchen's vaulted ceiling. The walls were plastered, but no decoration exists. The north wall of the latrine is approximately 12-14 inches above the floor. There is a small shelf running the entire length of the wall which may have served to support a shelf or seat.

column14: Latrine to the southwest, storage space to the northwest
column16: Latrine to the southwest, storeage space to the northwest
column21: The cooking platform is located to the southeast. The room is a high vault. Floor is indeterminate. A masonry support on the north and south wall extends from the southeast wall and ends just before the opening. Both supports are in bad shape, so its original appearance is uncertain.

column14: None
column21: The storeroom lies in the southeast corner of the horticultural space (3) to the northeast of the kitchen. One has access to the storeroom from the northwest through a small door. The room is not very deep; perhaps three feet and is vaulted. The floor is indeterminate. Walls were stuccoed in antiquity, but no decoration remains. As extant, the northwest wall does not extend to the vaulted ceiling so it is uncertain if the storeroom was open or closed with the exception of the door. The vaulted ceiling supports a stairway to the upper floor.

column14: Atrium (12) opens to the south.  The outdoor triclinium (7) is to the east entrance.
column15: Atrium (12) opens to the south.  The outdoor triclinium (7) is to the east entrance.
column21: This is a rectangular space, and Jashemski stated that it was cultivated.  Today we see a large fig and plum tree.  We enter the space from a southwest door.  Mid-wall high, in the south wall, is a large window to the atrium (12).  Modern repairs with steel and concrete lintel.  (Video northwest).  Remains of some plaster on the north wall in southwest corner with no signs of paint of decoration.  To the southwest is a room with under-step storage area under stairway with a kitchen and latrine.  There is an eastern door to the outdoor triclinium.  Room axis is "roughly" E-W.

column14: Cooking platform to the southeast.  Latrine to the southwest.
column16: Cooking platform to the southeast.  Latrine to the southwest.
column21: Northeast of the latrine is a small storage area entered from the doorway in the southeast.  The floor is indeterminate as is the ceiling.  But probably extended to the height of the vault in the kitchen.  The walls were stuccoed in antiquity but no decoration remains.  Filled with debris.

column14: Room #3 to the southwest
column21: Dining room #4 is located in the back of the house in the northeast corner. One enters the dining room through a doorway on the southwest wall. The room is rectangular in shape on a northeast-southwest axis. High in the northeast wall is a window. Floor is indeterminate, as is the ceiling. The walls were stuccoed in antiquity but no decoration remains. A stone door threshold remains with placing for a door.

column14: Hallway (6) to the northwest
column21: We enter the room from the hallway (#6) to the northwest. The kitchen is rectangular in shape. The floor is obscured with lapilli. The walls are intact and there is no ceiling. The room is on a northeast-southwest axis. We see a cooking platform on the southeast wall opposite the entrance to the room. A wall is apparent connecting to the southeast wall, beyond Eschebach recorded a latrine, the latrine is not visible.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform has an arched fuel recess. The top of the platform is irregular in shape and shows no tiles or lips. Masonry construction with brick and limestone arch. The cooking platform is found along the southeast wall in the southern corner.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Eschebach, page 66 indicates a latrine behind the wall which is no longer extant.

column14: Garden (13) to the northwest, room #7 to the northeast.
column15: Garden (13) to the northwest, room #7 to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular shaped room on a northwest-southeast axis. Wide open doorway looking out to the peristyle and garden to the northwest. The floor is obscured by lapilli. On the southwest wall traces of plaster survive with alternating red and yellow panels. PPM identifies this a late 3rd style. In the western doorjamb there is a large square hole. At the north end of the northwest wall there is a doorway leading to room #7.

column14: Room 10 to the southwest.
column21: The kitchen is located in the rear of the house in the eastern corner. One enters the kitchen from room #10 to the southwest. The room is rectangular in shape on a northeast-southwest axis. To the rear of the room on the northeast wall is a cooking platform running the width of the room. On the northwest wall there is a lararium. The floor is indeterminate. The walls were stucco, but no evidence of decoration exists. On the northwestern and southeastern walls post holes indicate the height of the ceiling.

column14: Niche lararium to the northwest
column21: At the back of the kitchen against the southeast wall, running the width of the kitchen there are the remains of a cooking platform. At present little more than the foundation remains.

column14: Cooking platform (2532) to the east.
column21: On the northwest wall as you enter the kitchen is a niche lararium as extant, only its shape is discernible. There is no signs of stucco or decoration remaining.

column14: Room #9 to the east, portico (14) to the north
column15: Room #9 to the east, portico (14) to the north
column21: A square room with a portico along the north side with 2 square plastered columns, red lower register, white above. Between the columns and the walls there is a low masonry wall heavily reinforced with traces of plaster. To the west of the western column inserted into the wall is a partially buried dolium. In the center of the west wall there is a preparation platform (2540). In the center of the south wall there is a lararium niche (2536). In the southeast corner a small shrine building has been inserted secellum (2537). In the center of the east wall there is a low bench with plaster and opus signinum top (2539). At the northern end of the east wall there is a wide doorway opening to room #9. There is a masonry and tile threshold. The southern half of the garden is taken up with a large masonry triclinium (2535). The triclinium is below a restored wooden pergola with 6 uprights over which vines grow. To the north of the eastern arm of the triclinium is a dolium (2538). Undercoated plaster is found on all four walls.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column21: Large masonry couch with cocciopesto surface sloping to the exterior. At the northern end of the western arm is a masonry pillow. The area between the three arms is plastered and traces of plaster yellow color survives on the faces of all three arms. The surface of the triclinium is a modern restoration.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Dolium (2538) to the north, triclinium (2535) to the north, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2538) to the north, triclinium (2535) to the north, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column21: Plastered square lararium with modern wooden frame. White plaster rear with no discernible decoration. A bronze statuette of Athena was found in the lararium with an inscription reading "Theodor Mas" on the base. Above the lararium is a plastered triangle gable with red painted decoration of a circle (sum?) and garlands.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, triclinium (2535) to the northwest.
column16: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, triclinium (2535) to the northwest.
column21: (Secellum) A small building inserted into the southeast corner entered through a small doorway with a high threshold and one step down into a secellum. In the northwest corner of the secellum is a square masonry plastered podium with a large terracotta plastered lip, creating a square basin on the top. White plaster survives intact on all walls with red and yellow boarders and black and red trim. Simple plaster crown molding along the north wall, plastered floor obscured by vegetation. Roof is modern.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Triclinium (2535) to the south, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column16: Triclinium (2535) to the south, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column21: Small partially buried dolium full of debris to the north of the eastern arm of the triclinium (2535).

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, triclinium (2535) to the west, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, triclinium (2535) to the west, platform (2540) to the west, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column21: Masonry rectangular dining couch; cocciopesto and plaster surface is a modern restoration. Against the center of the east wall of the garden.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, triclinium (2535) to the east, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2538) to the north, lararium (2536) to the south, bench (2539) to the east, triclinium (2535) to the east, secellum (2537) to the southeast.
column21: Masonry preparation platform in the center of the east wall. Yellow plaster fragments survive on the base of the three faces. Plaster surface; no extant rim.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Room #9 to the southwest, room #8 (garden) to the east
column15: Room #9 to the southwest, room #8 (garden) to the east
column21: We enter the kitchen from room 9. It is a small rectangular room with a pounded earth floor on a northwest southeast axis. On the northeast wall a small window opening onto what was probably a small garden. The northeast doorway is very narrow and tall, opening onto a light well. There is a quern in the north corner and a cooking platform wit a dirt pot. No signs of a lip but the edge is built up with stones against the northwest corner and wall. The roof has been replaced. On the northeast and northwest walls of the kitchen there is a lararium with a splendid scene of worship. The background is cream in color.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Lararium (2543) above to the north, Quern (2544) to the northeast.
column16: Lararium (2543) above to the north, Quern (2544) to the northeast.
column21: There is a cooking platform on the northwest wall in the western corner of the kitchen. The top has dirt. There is recessed arch of storage or fuel. On the west wall there are examples of stone reinforcing the back edge. Packed earth.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Cooking Platform (2542) to the southwest, Quern (2544) to the northeast.
column16: Cooking Platform (2542) to the southwest, Quern (2544) to the northeast.
column21: A great lararium painting appears in the north corner of this kitchen. On the northwest wall there is an arched lararium. The background is cream color and we see a garland at the top and two skewers containing meat, garland and possibly eggplant(?). Inside he lararium niche is a green garland, a raised half shelf. The bottom beneath the lararium is a protective snake next to another altar where there is burning food offerings. To the left is a hamhock which shows how it is tied up. On the northeast side, the lararium painting extends to the window. There is a large garland that extends over these. A gold rhyton is in one hand (of a man). On the ground line, we see a scene of a household sacrifice. The worshippers have shoes on. We can see clearly fourteen worshippers plus feet. A tipica player is piping, standing next to the altar. Two women with veils over their heads with the female sign of worship. On the altar is a sacrifice. The males, both full grown and one boy, most of them wearing tunics and holding their right hand over their hearts. Most are looking at the altar. Some look to the viewer. Beneath this is a picture of a depiction of half cow, next to him looks like a hourse with a backpack. Faint figure of a donkey or camel.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Lararium (2543) above to the north, Cooking Platform (2542) to the southwest
column16: Lararium (2543) above to the north, Cooking Platform (2542) to the southwest
column21: A quern is found in the north corner, beneath the lararium next to the cooking platform.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Atrium (18) to the north, Room #14 and the garden (13) to the south, Andron (20) to the east.
column15: Atrium (18) to the north, Room #14 and the garden (13) to the south, Andron (20) to the east.
column21: The triclinium lies to the south of the atrium (18). One enters the triclinium from the andron (20) to the southeast. The room is rectangular in shape one a southeast northwest axis. On the south wall there is a large doorway looking out onto the garden (13). The floor is of cocciopesto with a design in white marble chips. The ceiling is indeterminate with a modern reconstruction. Walls are covered with stucco and painted in the fourth style. The walls have a whie background with a bird painted in each of the large panels. The dado is black background with plants and birds. On the west and east walls, at the bottom of the walls become convex to accommodate the dining couches. The convex area on the west wall is longer than that on the east wall. On the north wall is a large window looking onto the atrium (18). A stone threshold to the garden (13) remains. A stone threshold to the andron (20) which is a higher level than the dining room also remains.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Couch niche (2547) to the west.
column21: On the east wall there is a couch niche. Covered in stucco, painted in black with foliage. For most of its length, there is a slight protrusion of the wall which may have served to support one arm of a triclinium.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Couch niche (2546) to the east.
column21: On the west wall, running most of the length of the room, from north to south is a couch niche. About 3/4 of the distance of the north wall is a narrow bench-like structure which may have served to support one arm of a triclinium. The niche is stucco, painted black and decorated with foliage and two birds.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 860-861

column14: Room #5 to the east.
column21: The kitchen is located in the back of the house in the southwest corner. One enters the kitchen from room #5 to the east. The kitchen is rectangular in shape roughly on a north south axis. On the west wall is a large window. On the north end of the room there is an arched ceiling under which probably was the oven (non extant). Eschebach indicates that there was a latrine in the room which is also non extant. The floor in indeterminate as is the ceiling, although the remains of a vaulted area in the north seems to indicate a ceiling only slightly higher than the vault. The walls today have little evidence of ancient stucco.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Best guess is that the latrine was in the south part of the room because the vaulted ceiling in the north was probably covered by the oven.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Probable location is under the vaulted area in the northern part of the room.

column14: Rooms #11 & 12 to the west.
column21: The dining room is located on the east side of the house. The room is on a north south axis. One enters the room from the east. The entrance has  a fauces, atrium, cubliculian then room #4. It is a rectangular room overlooking the garden with a cistern, large arched lararium niche with cream and red dots. The ceiling is of modern restoration. The floor is concrete. Window half way up the east wall about 8 feet up. The south wall has a large window with a marble lintel. Walls have been decorated since 62. The lower wall (socle) reverts back to the first style. Colors in the lower panels are green, red, peach and yellow. Panels are divided into separate panel sections. Colored set of panels up are predominantly, yellow with red stencil boarder. Griffins inside the panels of the south wall. Central panel on the northeast wall has a small picture of reclining tibicen player. Figure possibly reclines on a kline. On the south wall is another reclining figure of a musician on a kline, holding in right hand what appears to be a harp. Lions on the side panels of the east wall. In all there are seven distinct animals on the side panels (possibly 1 missing?) Top panels are divided into zones of turquoise, red and yellow. Ceiling is of modern construction.

column14: Room #7 to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is located in the rear of the house in the south corner. One enters the kitchen from room #7 through a doorway in the northeast part of the kitchen. The room is rectangular in shape on a southeast northwest axis. In the west corner is the latrine which is no longer extant. The walls are covered in stucco and painted. The height of the ceiling is indeterminate. Note, the room and description varies from Eschebach.

column14: None
column21: The latrine lies in the west corner of the room. The walls were probably plastered but none remains. The height of the ceiling is uncertain but probably conforms with what appears to be three post holes in the north wall. The shape of the latrine is indeterminate because the northeast wall of the latrine is damaged.

column14: Room #7 to the west
column21: Entered on the southeast by possible steps which are no longer extant. The dining room is a rectangular shaped room on a northwest southeast axis. Cocciopesto floor with small marble square ships in a linear design. Low wall on the southeast,southwest side. The south wall has a window (no longer extant) overlooking a raised garden area. If the window was large enough it would over look the sacellum. On the northwest all white plaster with a medallion in the relief and a ridge under the medallion about 12 feet high. Bottom level is portion of ref course (which is also seen on the northeast wall in bits). Plaster traces on the south corner of the southwest wall. No ceiling is extant. The north northeast wall 7 feet in the north corner, 9 in the northeast corner.

column14: Andron (10) to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is located in the back of the house against the southwest wall in line with the andron (10). The room is roughly rectangular in shape on a southwest northeast axis. The floor is indeterminate as is the ceiling. On the southeast wall above the cooking platform is a window looking into room #4. The walls may have been stuccoed and painted, but no evidence remains. In the west corner near the floor is a small niche of unknown purpose. There does not seem to be a wall on the northwest side, separating the kitchen from the garden.

column14: Latrine (2557) to the northeast.
column21: The cooking platform is located in the south corner along the southeast wall. All that remains are portions of the masonry supports.

column14: Cooking platform (2556) to the southwest.
column21: The latrine is located in the east corner along the southeast wall. None of the feature structure remains.

column14: Room #2 to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular room on a northeast southwest axis with a large doorway in the northeast wall opening to the atrium. No visible threshold but a modern lintel. Undercoated plaster is seen on all four walls in poor condition. The floor is obscured by lapilli. In the center of the northwest wall there is a large blocked window looking onto the light well. The three vertical openings remain. High in the southwest wall there is a doorway in the floor above blocked (modern). There is no ceiling. High in the center of the southeast wall there is a square window with modern lintel. Traces of plaster remain on the door frame.

column14: Storeroom (11) to the northwest, room #7 to the southeast.
column15: Storeroom (11) to the northwest, room #7 to the southeast.
column21: The kitchen is located in the back of the house in the west corner. One enters the kitchen from room #7 to the southeast. The room is roughly square in shape. In the north corner along the northeast wall from the entrance to room #11 to the wall defining the latrine there is a cooking platform. The latrine lies in the southwest. To the northwest of the entrance to storeroom #11 which is entered through a archway only partially extant. The floor is indeterminate. The walls were covered with stucco, but little remains. On the south wall  are the remains of post holes for a ceiling. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: Latrine (2561) to the southwest.
column21: The cooking platform is in the north corner along the northwest wall from he entrance to room to the wall defining the latrine. As reconstructed, the top may have been surfaced with tiles. The east end of the cooking platform is engaged with the pillar that forms the entrance to the storeroom (11). Although it may have been stuccoed and painted in antiquity, no evidence of either remains today.

column14: Cooking platform (2560) to the northeast.
column21: The latrine lies to the southwest of the cooking platform. The wall to the west, which the cooking platform abuts with extends more than half way into the room and serves to define the space of the latrine. In the doorway, just inside the latrine area, seems to be the remains of a wall running north/south roughly which may have narrowed the actual entrance to the latrine. No evidence of facilities remain in the latrine. The walls indicate that the area of the latrine was stuccoed, but no decoration remains. The floor is indeterminate. Post holes on the south wall indicate the level of the ceiling.

column14: None
column16: Kitchen (6) to the southwest, Sacrarium (12) to the southeast.
column21: The storeroom is located to the east of the kitchen and is entered through an archway of which the two pillars made of brick remain. The vaulted storage area is preceded by a rectangular anteroom from the area of the anteroom is an entrance to the southeast providing access to a sacrarium with a lararium. The floor is a cocciopesto. The walls were stuccoed and painted, though no decoration remains. On the north wall, is what appears to be a light niche with evidence of stucco and paint. The ceiling of the storage area is vaulted but that of the anteroom is indeterminate but possibly higher to the level of the second floor.

column14: None
column21: We are entering this dining room with a southern door opening to the atrium. The room is an uneven rectangular room wit a east west axis. The floor is cocciopesto, but mainly lapilli. This dining room is north of the entrance. Generally, poor condition of the room. Virtually no paint remains. There is a small window on the northeast wall. This room contains 18 column drums and four entablatures. No ceiling remains.

column14: Atrium (2) to the southwest
column21: MINORITY REPORT: This is a rectangular room on a northeast southwest axis. This room is locked within a locked structure. On the east side of the fauces overlooking the atrium is a dining room. The door is high and it overlooks a light well past the atrium. We enter and see all four walls in place and a restored ceiling. The floor is cocciopesto. There is a window on the rear northeast wall about 12 feet high. All four walls are decorated in fourth style. The northeast wall has a black lower panel, as does the southwest wall. The southeast and northwest panels are cream/peach in color. There is a red boarder on the northeast, west and southeast walls, and half in the west wall. It is not apparent in the niche. The next panel, shows gold stencils with architectural elements. On the southwest wall is a framed picture of a bird. There is also a winged lion. There are two deer. The top panel is different with a yellow band with minimal architectural elements. Two couch niches are seen on the southeast and northwest walls. The two niches extend almost the length of the walls. They are sloped at the top and painted. The architectural elements on the southeast, west and northwest walls depict temples.

column14: Room #4 to the north, room #2, 5 and 7 to the south.
column15: Room #4 to the north, room #2, 5 and 7 to the south.
column21: A rectangular shaped garden on a northeast southwest axis. Eschebach identifies a triclinium (2570) in the south corner of which no trace remains. It is divided from the remainder of the garden by a buttress of a no longer extant wall. The placing a wall lies in the opposite northwest wall of the garden. At the north end of the northeast wall, traces of plaster survive at ground level. At the north end of the northwest wall, a doorway with a masonry threshold and modern lintel opens to the latrine (4). In the northwest wall are placings for joices. Eschebach refers to stairs to the floor above and PPM refers to a portico. Traces of blue painted plaster survives at the base of the northwest wall. In the northwest corner is a masonry biclinium (2566). At the exterior angle of the biclinium there is a brick and masonry pillar. To the northwest of the pillar, at an angle between the pillar and the biclinium is a marble pedestal. To the north of the pillar is a dolium (2568).

column14: None
column21: The biclinium lies in the western corner of the garden. The longest arm is on a northwest southeast axis, perpendicular to room #2 to the southeast. The short arm is on a southwest northeast axis, parallel with room #2. To the northeast there is a low wall running northwest to southeast that joins the shorter arm of the biclinium on the northeast and abuts a pillar to the southeast. How high this wall was is indeterminate. In the area formed by the benches off center towards the south was a well head that may have also been used as a table base for the biclinium. On the southeast end of the long arm there is a water channel extending to the south that parallels the southeast end and extends to the south/southeast allowing for water to drain off when cleaning the biclinium. The floor in front of the area of the biclinium is indeterminate. The height of the original ceiling is unknown. The entrance to the biclinium from the southeast, judging from the remains of a threshold, was capable of being closed off. The southwest and northwest walls were stuccoed and painted. On the southwest wall there is a window to room #1. The decoration on the southwest wall shows garlands at the top of two panels. The decoration in the panels are difficult to discern, but may have been a garden scene, although to judge from the decoration on the northwest wall there may have been a small panel within each larger panel. The decoration on the northwest wall is divided into three sections with an overall erotic theme. The western most section shows a framework of vines with birds at the top. In the upper left hand corner appears to be a cluster of phalli. A large phallus is in the center with two smaller phalli below. All three incorporated within the outline of a larger phallus. In nearly the center of the panel there is a smaller panel which seems to show a sacro-idyllic scene. Below this where the wall is indented, is a painting of a statue of Venus holding a mirror and to the right of the statue of Priapus. The center panel also has a framework with a smaller central panel showing a bedroom scene with sexual activity. The third and smaller panel is too damaged for description.

column14: Biclinium (2566) to the northwest.
column21: On the southeast end of the long arm of the biclinium is a water channel and drain part of which parallels the southeast end of the biclinium and then extends to the south southeast, allowing for water to drain off when cleaning the biclinium. The drain looks to have waterproofing coating and extends almost the entire width of room #1. Exactly how high the sides of the drain were is indeterminate.

column14: Biclinium (2566) to the west.
column21: Small, half buried terracotta dolium, half filled with earth. Well preserved. Spherical in shape.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Per Eschebach, this area refers to a kitchen.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Per Eschebach, this area refers to a triclinium.

column14: Atrium (1) to the northeast.
column21: We enter into the kitchen from the atrium to the northeast of the kitchen. It is a relatively small door with a modern lintel, not too high with no indication of a threshold. The floor is obscured by earth and vegetation. The four walls are intact. On the southwest wall to the  street there is a window about 8 feet high. This kitchen shows evidence of plastering with no painting. On the northwest wall there is a raised cooking platform in the north corner. There is a rectangular on the southwest wall , an open rectangle within the platform. The open rectangle possibly could have contained a grill. The plaster continues to the bottom of the rectangle.

column14: None
column21: There is a low cooking platform with an open rectangular space within it on the west wall. There is a sprocket which may have supported a grill. The plaster starts within the open rectangle. It is a very low.

column14: Atrium (1) to the southwest, Garden (3) to the northeast.
column15: Atrium (1) to the southwest, Garden (3) to the northeast.
column21: A rectangular shaped room on a northeast southwest axis. A small doorway in the center of the southwest wall to the atrium with no threshold and a modern lintel. Plastered floor can be seen along the northeast wall, also poorly preserved plaster is seen on the southeast wall. Plaster survives on all four walls with a pink lower register and white above. This overlies earlier plaster decoration in the northwest wall with a red lower register and white above. At the north end of the northwest wall, a spherical hole looks through the wall. In the center of the northeast wall is a square window with a modern lintel looking through to a small garden to the east. High in the southeast wall there are four holes for possible joices. In the middle of the southeast wall are two smaller holes. Diagonal to and above the east hole there is a small circular hole through the wall.

column14: Rooms 1 and 2 to the west and southwest.
column15: Rooms 1 and 2 to the west and southwest.
column21: A rectangular room on a northwest southeast axis. Floor is obscured by lapilli. A wide open doorway south to the street with a stone threshold and placings for a door. Step down onto pavement and street. Modern lintel. Plaster survives in fragments on the east and north walls with a pink lower register and white above. High in the east wall is a window to the street with a modern lintel. Eschebach places a counter (2575) in this room, which is no longer extant. The west wall opens to a storeroom (2) and doritorium. Eschebach, page 69 identifies this as a food & drink shop.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Eschebach refers to a counter with four urns and three dolia. All is no longer extant.

column14: Atrium (1) to the southeast
column21: The dining room is located in the front of the house, northwest of the atrium (1). One enters the room from the southeast. The room is roughly rectangular in shape on a southeast northwest axis. The floor is indeterminate. Post holes on the north wall indicates the height of the ceiling. High on the southwest wall, looking out onto the street there is a window. The room was plastered and painted, but decorations are no longer extant. On the north wall near the northwest corner is a window looking out onto the garden (4). The door threshold is stone with sockets indicating a door. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: Atrium (1) to the southwest, Kitchen (5) to the west.
column15: Atrium (1) to the southwest, Kitchen (5) tp the west.
column21: A rectangular shaped room on a northeast southwest axis. A wide doorway opening to the southwest to the atrium (1). Stone threshold with placings for a door. At the base of the door fraces are two holes. The floor is obscured by lapilli. High in the northwest wall are places for floor joices. In the center of the northeast wall is a square window with a modern lintel. High in the southeast wall is a plastered window that narrows to the south with a modern lintel. High on the southeast wall are also placings for floor joices. Plaster survives on all four walls with visible decoration on the northwest wall. Decorations are poorly preserved but show a red lower register with red and yellow boarders and trim with a white upper register. Painting is in the third or fourth style.

column14: Room #6 to the northeast, room #4 to the northwest.
column15: Room #6 to the northeast, room #4 to the northwest.
column21: One enters the kitchen from the southeast from the atrium (1). Northeast of the kitchen is a rectangular (almost square) shaped plastered room (6). On the west wall of the kitchen is a large arched area situated under the stairs to the upper floor. Raised course of stones with a semicircular area. On the northwest wall is a door to the garden (4). Traces of plaster remain in the kitchen on all walls. Pink color paint remains in the plaster. No ceiling extant. The kitchen is entered by a tall doorway. The doorway to the north leading to the garden (4) is 5-6 feet in height. Floor is obscured by lapilli. The ceiling over the garden door is preserved second story with floor beams and lower window lintel. Plaster remains exists to the second floor. The kitchen is on a northeast southwest axis and is located in the middle of the structure northwest of the entrance.

column14: None
column21: A hearth raised above two courses of stone with evidence of a tile on top of the stone. The hearth shows evidence of walls around a semicircle, which perhaps held a grill. No area for fuel is evident. The entire large archway (5' high, 5' wide) is plastered. The rear south arm of the grill survives in better condition with most of the hearth otherwise heavily damaged.

column14: None
column15: Crossroads shrine 2595, Via di Nocera and Via di Castricio, and three steps leading to the Palestra.
column21: Northwestern corner, a basin with ten stone blocks forming a basin with floor of basin showing signs of waterproof cement. On the eastern corner two stone blocks protecting from cart traffic. The plinth of basin shows a woman's face open mouth to provide water with Augustan hairstyle, diadem and earrings. Is on the corner of Via di Nocera and Via di Castricio. Overlooks the back of three steps to the east is the road leading to the Palestra.

column14: Garden 9 is to the south, corridor 6 is to the east, atrium 4 is to the north.
column15: Garden 9 is to the south, corridor 6 is to the east, atrium 4 is to the north.
column21: Rectangular room, northwest southeast axis, narrow doorway with no threshold and modern lintel at the west end of the north wall, cocciopesto floor preserved through most of the room. High in center of t east wall there is a window with modern lintel opening to corridor 6. In the center of the south wall large window with modern lintel opens to garden. Undecorated plaster on all four walls. At the southern end of the west wall the lower register of earlier decoration is visible black with striping to take ??? Plaster. Above this there is a lararium 2582.

column14: None
column21: A plastered arched lararium niche, undercoated plaster survives on the frame and rear, the base is indeterminate cement. Located on the southwest corner of the room along the west wall.

column14: Andron 6 to the NW
column21: The garden lies at the back of the house to the SE. It's roughly rectangular in shape on a SW/NE axis. One enters the garden via andron 6 to the NW. In the NW wall to the W is a large window opening into triclinium 7. On the SE wall is a large aediculate lararium from which the house gets its name. On the SW wall is a small niche lararium. In the NW wall to the NE is a small window into kitchen 8. In the same wall to the NW is a light well in the area above the kitchen. Along the NE wall today are whole and broken amphorae. It is not obvious that they are in situ. However, along the NW in the NE corner are two small and one slightly larger dolia, apparently in situ. In the S corner is a cylindrical dolium likely a puteal for cistern apparently in situ. The floor is indeterminate (if there was one). The walls were plastered in antiquity, but the decoration except the lararium is gone. As a garden, it probably did not have a roof.

column14: Small niche lararium 2585 to the west.
column16: Small niche lararium 2585 to the west.
column21: The large aediculate lararium abuts the SE wall almost on axis with andron 6. Surrounding the lararium on three sides is a channel (as reconstructed). This may have contained water, since in the NW wall of the channel on the inside appeared to be three drain holes. The foundation on which the lararium presently sits seems also to be modern reconstruction. The decoration on the lararium is clearly food related. The front façade below the niche appears to show a port scene -a personification of the Sarnus River on the left, showing water pouring from an amphora and representing the river. On the river is a boat with two boatmen. The boat, loaded with onions? Perhaps, is being pulled by two animals on the shore. Above the register with the boat to the left shows a large bushet with two handles with three people, one of whom carries a basket on the shoulder. The rightmost person points to his left toward the two individuals weighing baskets of food. On the back wall of the deep niche shows the genius figure sacrificing at an altar.

column14: Lararium 2584 to the east.
column21: On the west wall is a small niche lararium. The painting at the back of the niche shows a figure (female?) reclining on a couch. In front of the couch is a tripod table on which rests a glass(?) drinking vessel and other indeterminate utensils. Framing this scene, there appears to be a garland, perhaps representation of a pergola.  Around the table, apparently on the floor, seem to be leaves or some other vegetation. The platform of the lararium protrudes about five inches from the wall. There seems to have been a roof that likewise protruded but now is broken off.

column14: Hallway 6 to the southwest.
column21: Kitchen is a rectangular room with roughly E/W axis. Enter kitchen from hallway 6 from the SW. Enter small doorway approximately 5'6," pounded dirt floor. Four walls in second style room. South wall has small rectangular window leading to the garden with light well and four circular post holes for second floor. Ceiling very low as seen by nine holes for ceiling posts on east walls, with addition five post holes in north wall. Evidence of a cooking platform very low. No arch for fuel but is a cooking platform. North corner over cooking platform is a long rectangular niche used for storage or light source. In small areas some evidence of plastering.

column14: None
column21: Running north to east along the east wall is a cooking platform approximately 1/4 the size of the kitchen. A window is seen above the platform on the east wall. The platform is very low and no tiles or lip is discernible. Overall, the cooking platform is found in poor condition.

column14: Atrium 4 to the south.
column21: Rectangular sales room Northwest-Southeast axis.  Wide doorway in North wall, no threshold, modern lentil opens North to street.  North end of East wall, high masonry buttress that may have been related to #2590 referred to by Eschebach.  Plaster floor, south end of the east wall, pile of lime against which there are traces of plaster on the wall.  At the base of the buttress and along the East wall, traces of poorly preserved plaster.  At the western end of the south wall, doorway to Atrium #4.  At the North end of the west wall. Lararium #2589.

column14: Podium (2590) is to east.
column21: Square lararium niche, modern lintel, undecorated plaster survives on base and left frame, no other plaster or decoration survives.  Extensively restored with modern cement.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Podium for a Wooden Table

column14: Atrium 1 to the northwest, Rooms 3 & 7 to the west
column15: Atrium 1 to the northwest, Rooms 3 & 7 to the west
column21: Rectangular room northwest - southeast axis, plaster floor collapsed at the southern end of the room, wide doorway, with partial plaster threshold in the center of the north wall with wooden lintel; at the southern end of the west wall there is a window with a modern lintel; in the north and west walls fragments of plaster, on the south and east walls, large areas of damaged plaster survived.  Black lower register, red and yellow panels above, white upper register with traces of molding and vaulted ceiling, the central image on the south and east wall has been removed.  Early fourth style, modern ceiling is reconstructed.

column14: Atrium 1 to North.  Small bedroom (Room 5) to Northwest.
column15: Atrium 1 to North.  Small bedroom (Room 5) to Northwest.
column21: Enter Dining Room w/a step up.  The large step runs the length of the dining room.  Entry is through a small North door, overlooking the entrance.  Good sized rectangular room with a northeast-southwest axis.  Walls on all four sides but all the walls show signs of reconstruction at various levels.  Floor is pounded dirt with grass and flowers.  East wall towards rear of the room.  Ancient door was filled in.  On the west wall is a high narrow doorway with a threshold step up to a small bedroom.  Tiny patch of poorly preserved plaster on the west wall, and in northeast corner.  Ceiling no longer extant.

column14: Room 11 to Southwest.  Room 7 to Northwest.
column15: Room 11 to Southwest.  Room 7 to Northwest.
column21: (Courtyard)  Room 9 is located in the Southeast part of the house.  The room is rectangular in shape on a Northeast-Southwest axis.  One enters the room from the Northwest by way of Room 7.  On the Southeast wall to the Southwest, a wall runs northwest-southeast to about halfway into the room, dividing the room into unequal parts.  In the North corner is an oven.  In the east corner, along the Northeast wall, there was once a fountain and built-up basin (according to Eschebach).  On the Southwest wall there is a doorway to Room 11.  The floor seems to have been of cocciopesto and there is evidence along the Northeast wall where floor and wall meet, there is an ovolo.  Along the Northwest wall from the oven running in a westerly direction, the floor slopes toward the Southeast as evidenced by a built-up area using roof tiles.  It seems that the floor of the room may have generally sloped toward the area of the fountain.  The walls of the room were stuccoed in antiquity, but no decoration remains.  The wall that runs at a 90 degree angle to the southeast wall has two small windows in it, looking into the large part of the room.  In the south corner of the Southwest wall is a window into Room 11.

column14: None
column21: (Courtyard) In the north corner of room #9 is an oven. The oven sits on a triangular base slightly higher than the floor and inserted into the corner. The area of the base extends beyond the furnace, especially along the northeast wall towards the southeast. To the southwest of the over, where the base meets the northwest wall, the base rises to a higher level. At the back of which, there is a hole for an unknown purpose. The oven itself, as reconstructed, lacks most of the roof, although it appears to have been domed. The interior of the oven had a low floor, or shelf like structure. In the latter, in the very center was a rounded area lower than the shelf that may have contained the fuel. As extant, there does not seem to be evidence of plaster or decoration.

column14: None
column21: Shrine abuts public fountain #b2580 and outside of a shop along with public sidewalks, the altar slightly juts out from the fountain, most shrine is missing.  The top of the altar, the first level seen, rectangular with more than half missing.  No plastering or finishing.  On the North Stone of fountain, circular drain.  Six more stones on the east side of the fountain for protection.

column14: Atrium (14) to the southeast.
column21: The dining room is located on the northwest side of the atrium (14). One enters the triclinium from the southeast through a moderately wide doorway. The room is roughly square in shape. The floor is cocciopesto. The walls are brightly painted in the third style. Approximately six feet from the floor on all three walls appears to be a stucco molding. On the northwest wall there is painting that appears above the molding indicating that the ceiling was at a higher level. As reconstructed, there is no way of determining the original height or shape of the ceiling. However, there is a small rectangular hole high upon the northwest wall which does not penetrate the entire wall. If ancient, its purpose is unknown.

column14: Cooking Chamber or Oven (2605) to the north.
column16: Cooking Chamber or Oven (2605) to the north.
column21: In the large garden a large masonry square poorium with brick columns supporting a cover in each of the four corners. One column remains embedded in the north corner and a second column lies on the surface in the west corner. South and east columns are heavily eroded. The surface is paved with opus signinum that has been laid over at least twice earlier with opus signinum. The floors are visible on the northern tip of the platform. The eastern face preserves plaster facing overlaid with earlier plaster. Along the north and west sides of the platform there is an "L" shaped tank. The southern edge does not survive, destroyed by construction of the fontina aqueduct which also destroyed the east corner of the platform. In the center of the north arm is a circular stone column, lined with plaster. The base of the tank is filled with earth and debris. All faces of the basin (tank) are plastered with no decoration. Embedded in all the long walls are a line of the upper halves of amphorae. In the center of the north wall there is an upper register of two embedded vessels. Collapse has exposed or destroyed several of the embedded amphorae. The function of this is unclear. However, the amphorae suggest nestings for fish and this tank was used for fish breeding. The square podium in unclear, the position next to the tank in dicates its position is deliberate and its structure suggests a function related to the tank such as dissection of the fish.

column14: The room is adjacent to room #12 (2604) to the north. Room #10 to the west.
column15: The room is adjacent to room #12 (2604) to the north. Room #10 to the west.
column21: A rectangular shaped room on a north south axis. One enters the room from a small door in the northwest corner of the room. The floor is concrete mixed with stone. On the northeast wall is a gutter sloping down to the south wall. There is another door in the northwest corner with three steps down to the floor. We can see a slope of the floor, higher on the west than the ease side all sloping to the southeast corner. At the south wall is a raised platform showing water proof plaster. Adjacent to it, on the east side is a round cistern. In the southwest corner is an opening for water from outside of this room. The ceiling is non-extant. Traces of plaster on the east, west and south walls. The east, west and south walls are preserved to the first floor height. The north wall is about 3 feet high. The east wall 1/2 way down from north to south is about 3 feet high. The room is adjacent to room #12 (2604) to the north. Room #10 to the west.

column14: It is adjacent to the cistern (2600) to the east.
column16: It is adjacent to the cistern (2600) to the east.
column21: In the southwest corner of the room is a water basin with an opening for a water source on the west wall. There is signs of waterproof concrete on the inside. It is adjacent to the cistern (2600) to the east. It is found in good original condition.

column14: Water Basin (2599) to the west.
column21: A cistern is found in the center of the south wall of this room and is to the east of the water basin (2599). About 1/8 of the cistern side is non-extant but the interior circle is complete. No evidence of plaster remains.

column14: Room 10 and 13 to the east.
column21: A large rectangular garden with a northwest southeast axis. The room is traversed in a roughly north/south axis by Fontana's aqueduct. At the north end of the west wall, there is a doorway with a step leading to the street with a modern lintel. The threshold has placings for a door. In the center of the west wall there is an alcove. In the east wall of the alcove, traces of yellow painted plaster remains. At the base of the wall is a plastered channel through to the basin in room #9. Fragments of plaster flooring is also seen. Access from poorly preserved walls from room #10 and a wide doorway to the hallway (room #13). In the northern corner there is a fish tank (2597) and to the immediate north there is a cooking chamber of an oven (2605) which is accessed from the alla (12). In the east end of the north wall there is faded pink plaster at the base of the wall. High on the wall there is undecorated plaster with five holes for cover or awning.

column14: Room #15 to the northwest
column21: The kitchen is located on the southeast side of the house to the southwest side of the atrium. One enters the kitchen from the northwest through a doorway in the north corner of the kitchen. The room is roughly square in shape. On the southeast wall, running the length of the room, is a cooking platform. There seems to be a short step up running the width of the room in front of the cooking platform, although it is difficult to determine due to the floor condition. High on the west wall is a window. The floor is indeterminate. Walls were covered with stucco, but no decoration remains. The height of the room is indeterminate with no ceiling extant. On the southeast wall in the south corner are two holes of equal height of unknown use. High on the northeast wall are the remains of stucco molding, but again it is difficult to tell the height of the ceiling.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform lies on the southwest wall, extending the entire width of the room. The platform surface is only about 18 inches in depth. The cooking platform was covered with stucco and may have been decorated, but the evidence is unclear.

column14: Room #13 (hall) to the south, room #4 (atrium) to the east.
column15: Room#13 (hall) to the south, room #4 (atrium) to the east.
column21: A large open ala, the walls of the southern and eastern corners of the room are no longer extant making the shape of the room unclear. Fontana's aqueduct runs through this area and is probably responsible for its destruction. A section of wall in the southeast corner survives, possibly demarking a large doorway at the south end of the east wall to the atrium. There may also have been a large opening in the southern wall to corridor #13. Lower register of plaster survives in the northeast and west walls. Black base, yellow above with black trim and red above. High in the northwest corner, there is fragments of stucco molding. Traces in indeterminate plaster and tile of the western end of the north wall. Inserted into this is a circular recess. Below this inserted into the northwest corner of the wall and overlying the earlier plaster decorations is a large masonry platform with a tiled surface that opens to an oven (2605).

column14: None
column21: Rectangular masonry platform with well preserved tile surface is inserted into the west corner of the room. Opening through to the cooking chamber to the west. Tile base with a beehive brick circular above, the upper third is no longer extant.

column14: Atrium (4) to the north.
column21: A rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis with a door entrance from the northeast corner. A raised lintel on the high door. One enters the room from the southeast corner of the atrium. The room is divided in half. The northern half of the room has plaster on all four walls. Plaster on the west wall is placed short distance out from the structural walls. The lower floor is cement. In the lower register of the south, east and north walls is plaster which is painted gold. There seems to be white plaster above that level. White plaster fragments are also seen on the north, west and east walls. The back half of the room (southwest end) shows a raised cocciopesto floor. The northwest corner has a big mound of unexcavated rubble. We are speculating that wooden couches could have been moved into this raised area. The room looks into the atrium where excavators reported a impluvium (not longer extant) and out onto the street. Walls are preserved to the first floor height. Above the northwest corner is a high rectangular window. Ceiling is no longer extent.

column14: Garden (8) to the west, Atrium (4) to the east.
column15: Garden (8) to the west, Atrium (4) to the east.
column21: A large rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis. A doorway at the southern end of the east wall with a poorly preserved threshold and step down to the atrium to the east. A modern lintel is found over the door. Wall are extensively restored. Undecorated plaster fragments are found in the north corner and along the south wall. High in the center of the west wall is a restored window. Plaster floor survives throughout. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: garden (8) to the northeast.
column21: The very small kitchen is located off the garden in the back of the house in the south corner. One enters the kitchen from the northeast. The kitchen is roughly square in shape, with most of the room being occupied by the cooking platform in the south corner. In the northwest corner, the wall protrudes slightly to the southeast, creating a small space between the northwest wall and the cooking platform. The northwest wall, running on a southwest/northeast axis, extends beyond the point where the east wall adjoins to southeast wall. The floor is indeterminate. The ceiling extends up to the level of the post holes in the southeast wall. The walls of the kitchen were probably stuccoed, but no evidence remains. There is no evidence in this small room for a latrine, but if there were one, it was probably in the space formed be the northeast wall of the room and the northeast wall of the cooking platform.

column14: None
column21: The cooking platform lies in the south corner of the kitchen. The platform is relatively low and is defined by two arms. One arm, the longest, abuts the southeast wall and is on a southeast/northwest axis. The short arm abuts the southwest wall and is on a southeast/northwest axis - roughly. The walls of the platform may have been stuccoed in antiquity, but no evidence remains.

column14: Room 14 to the southwest.
column21: The large dining hall (16) is located in the northeast corner of the restaurant. One enters the hall in the southwest through a tall, but not particularly wide, doorway. The hall is roughly rectangular on a northeast/southwest axis. The east wall in the southeast corner is indented approximately 15" forming a shallow niche, roughly 10' long. The floor is cocciopesto. All wall covered in fourth style painting. One the northeast wall in the center is a large panel mostly intact, showing Perseus and Andromeda. It is impossible to determine the original height of the ceiling, but a room of this size would probably have a tall one. The doorway in the southwest wall opens to room 14, but also provides a view of the garden (6). He threshold in the entrance to the room is at a higher level than room 14. There are sockets in the threshold, indicating that the room could be closed off.

column14: Room #5 to the southwest, Room #2 to the northeast.
column15: Room #5 to the southwest, Room #2 to the northeast.
column21: The dining room is located to the southwest of he atrium (2). One enters the dining room from a doorway in the north corner. The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest/northeast axis. On the southwest wall is a window (noted by Eschebach, but today appears as a door). Floor is indeterminate. Walls are stuccoed but little decoration remains. Traces of decorative paint still remain on the southwest and southeast walls. The height of the ceiling is indeterminate. In the north corner of the northwest wall there is a small niche in appearance like a couch niche, but smaller than usual

column14: None
column21: On the northwest wall of the north corner, is a low couch niche, seemingly smaller that usual for a triclinium. The floor level of the room, due to the dirt level may be lower than what is visible today. The niche is covered with plaster and appears to have been painted black. The niche itself is in two parts. A slight indentation from the surface of the wall followed by a curving deeper into the wall.

column14: Room 14 to the northeast
column21: A large rectangular garden on a northeast/southwest axis. Along the east wall, to the north opening to a portico with a large plastered water basin with three terracotta drains at the base of the north and northeast corners. Adjoining the basin to the north is a circular, plastered cistern head. To the south of the water feature, central to the east wall, there are stairs to the floor above. Below the stairs is a plastered water channel running from the water basin, diagonally, through the wall, under the stairs and joining a terracotta channel that runs along the east wall to the eastern corner of the room. Traces of faded pink plaster lie at the junction of the channel and the eastern wall. In the angle of the channel, beneath the stairs, there is a low masonry platform with a central hole. At the eastern end of the south wall, a masonry cooking platform (2624). To the west of the cooking platform there is a masonry triclinium (2623). Traces of undecorated plaster survives on the wall to the south above the cooking platform and couch. Jashemski reports 49 root cavities, four of which were large trees at the edge of the garden. Large roots near the south wall were olive trees. Olive pollen was found in the area of #2623. A large root cavity near the north wall was a fig tree, carbonized figs were found in the area. Fragments of planting pots were found along the north wall. Carbonized beams were also found in the garden. In the southwest corner, a limestone block, which Jashemski says may have been an altar. At the southern end of the east wall, there is a square window with a modern lintel overlooking the atrium. To the west of 2630 there is an unidentified masonry feature with a rectangular hole.

column14: Platform (2624)to the east, and water basin (2630) to the north.
column16: Platform (2624)to the east, and water basin (2630) to the north.
column21: Poorly preserved masonry couch. Only the southern arm of the interior faces and the interior faces of the other two arms survive intact. The masonry frontage is restored and the original surface does not survive. At the base of the interior faces, traces of plaster some of which show red paint survive. Between the arms of the couch is a circular masonry base for a table. Jashemski reports finding four holes for a pergola over the triclinium. Jashemski reports finding food in the vicinity of the couch.

column14: Couch (2623) to the west, water basin (2630) to the north
column16: Couch (2623) to the west, water basin (2630) to the north
column21: A rectangular masonry cooking platform with traces of red plaster facing on the north, east and west faces. Terracotta tile surface with no lip. Jashemski reports the discovery of carbonized wood, probably for cooking to the east.

column14: None
column16: Atrium (2) to the southeast, Room 14 to the west, Cubiculium (12) to the east.
column21: A west facing dining room with a wide entrance to the west. Flooring is black & white tessarae. Outer boarder is black tessarae with a regular linear symmetrical pattern of white tessarae. Counter boarder on the outside is a reverse swastika with a flora pattern of one stem and leaves in each corner. Inside this is a large circle with eight pie triangles inserted with diamonds. The southeast corner has a door to the atrium (2). There is also an east lower door, leading to a cubiculum (12). The walls rise to the restored ceiling with fourth style painting evident on all four walls. The most complete panel is on the northeast wall. Other walls do not have much left but appears to repeat the pattern and the colors. The bottom panel is red with gold stenciling with one yellow flower with leaves in green. This panel is divided from the upper panel with a white boarder. Central to the wall is a red panel bordered by yellow in a sloppy panel with a white stencil boarder. The figure is a seated woman wearing white with her arms raised from the elbows. Something is on the floor to the left of her but it is indeterminate. The central panel is framed by cream color columns, followed by twin green boarders contained within each. The architectural section to the left of the central panel is all yellow. The one to the right is mottled red with yellow and a mostly yellow bottom with red on the top. Ceiling is reconstructed at about 10' high. In the architectural panel are balconies with deep perspectives with a bird on the balcony. There is a portion of a hunt scene with a dog on the right chasing a deer or rabbit into a net. On the east wall is a miniature picture of a bust of a woman with a lovely face and necklace.

column14: None
column21: One enters the kitchen through a hallway (13) from the southwest in the northwest part of the house. The room is rectangular in shape on a southeast/northwest axis. Along the northeast wall in the north corner is a latrine. Along the southeast wall, though it is difficult to tell as extant, is a possible cooking platform. The floor is indeterminate. The walls has stucco and seems to have been painted, but little be seen today. It is difficult to tell the height of the ceiling, but a window to room #12 to the southeast of the kitchen is high on the wall. High on he east wall of the kitchen a portion of the wall seems to have fallen away. Whether this was at one time a lararium or a window or neither is uncertain.

column14: None
column21: In the north corner of the northeast wall is a latrine. It is on a southeast/northwest axis. The floor on the northwest slopes to the southeast where a terracotta amphora has been embedded in a masonry platform which serves as a seat. The floor of the latrine was made of terracotta. It is difficult to determine if the southeast and west walls extended high enough to provide any privacy. Though the exterior walls have been stuccoed and painted, no evidence remains.

column14: None
column21: Flooring is black & white tessarae. Outer boarder is black tessarae with a regular linear symmetrical pattern of white tessarae. Counter boarder on the outside is a reverse swastika with a flora pattern of one stem and leaves in each corner. Inside this is a large circle with eight pie triangles inserted with diamonds. It is believed that the circular central pattern with the square boarders indicated a pattern for a couch arrangement.

column14: None
column21: The dining room is located in the southeast corner of the house. One enters the dining room from the west from the atrium (2). The room is rectangular in shape one a northwest/southeast axis. On the south wall there is a window to room #7. On the east wall there is a small window to the street. To the northwest of this window is a small but deep rectangular niche which could have been either a lamp niche or perhaps a lararium. The floor is indeterminate, as is the ceiling. High above and just to the southeast of the window in the east wall looks to have been either another window or a light well. It is now walled up (in antiquity?) In the southeast corner of the east wall there may have been another window, rectangular in shape, although it may just be a damaged wall. The east, south and west walls have remains of plaster with no paint or decoration remaining.

column14: 2631 to the northeast, 2624 & 2623 to the southwest
column16: 2631 to the northeast, 2624 & 2623 to the soutwest
column21: Large shallow plastered water basin along the northeast edge of the garden. At the base of the north edge of the basin is a terracotta drain. At the base of the northeast edge are two terracotta drains, draining into the cistern (2631) that abuts the basin to the northeast. On the southeast corner a narrow plastered channel runs from the basin through the adjoining wall, under the stairs and continues to a terracotta water channel with masonry supports that extends along the wall to the east and gradually slopes upwards to the east.

column14: Abuts directly to water basin (2630) to the west.
column16: Abutts directly to water basin (2630) to the west.
column21: Circular masonry cistern head with plastered interior and exterior facings. In the western interior face, there is a downspout from the terracotta drain in the water basin (2630).

column14: Room (2) to the WestKitchen (3) to WestRoom (4) to SW
column15: Room (2) to the WestKitchen (3) to WestRoom (4) to SW
column21: One enters the counter room from a large doorway to the Southeast onto the street to the Northeast after you enter the room as reconstructed, is an S-shaped counter containing three dolia and a hearth. To the Northwest of the counter is the entrance to room 2. To the West is the kitchen (3). To the Southwest is the entrance to room 4. The floor is cocciopesto. The walls were stuccoed and painted, however, the decoration is indistinct. On the Nortest wall is a lararium. On the Southeast wall in the S corner is a rectangular window. Height of the ceiling is indistinct although as reconstructed it may have been considerable. In the South corner of the Southwest wall there seems to have been constructed a niche running at least to the height f the window of the Southeast wall.

column14: (2634) lararium to N
column21: The S-shaped counter begins in the East corner of the doorway. The narrow first arm (without dolia) is on a SE/NW  axis. The second arm, quite wide, lies on a WE/SW axis and contains two dolia. The third arm is on a roughly East West axis and contains one dolium and a hearth on the West end. As reconstructed the masonry counter is in two levels. The one dolium and hearth on the third are is slightly lower than the first and second arms. The surface of all the arms may have been made up of broken tiles (maybe marble or limestone). The walls, small remains of painted stucco remain; color red. On arm three in the area of the hearth there seems to be a step to the SW of the hearth.

column14: Counter (2633) to the south
column21: The niche lararium is located on the northeast wall to the north of the counter. It was stuccoed but no decoration remains. The base of the lararium was made of a single thick tile. The top is vaulted.

column14: Room 1 to SE
column21: Rectangular room, NE-SW axis, plastered floor with cistern in the western corner, in the center of the SW wall there is a base of a restored square wide with traces of plastered base inserted into blocked plastered doorway. In the center of the plastered window, that ?? Towards the exterior to the East. In the Easter corner of the room there is a hodzoutal recess. In the center of the SE wall there is a large doorway to the counter room. Plaster survives on all 4 walls. Black lower register, white upper register, red trim, traces of earlier plaster on the Eastern door frame. High restored ceiling.

column14: Counter room (1) to East, Dining room () to South.
column15: Counter room (1) to East, Dining room () to South.
column21: We enter the kitchen 2636 from the counter room to the SE. We see a rectangular room, the floor packed  earth, the walls are restored and there is a restored ceiling over the kitchen, dinging room and counter room. One half of the floor is concrete. On our right there is a large cooking platform with carefully laid tiles. What we see today is a lower interlocking and a higher level of tiles. We may have a stone shelf in the corner. There is a door with a big stone lintel to a preparation room (5). On the west corner is a circular opening. To the left of this well is a lararium. No paint remains, The west wall of the kitchen show signs of plaster painted red.

column14: Cistern (2638) to West, lararium (2640) to West
column16: Cistern (2638) to West, lararium (2640) to West
column21: There is a large cooking platform wit carefully laid tiles. What we see today is a lower, a intermediate and a a higher level of tiles. We may have a stone shelf in the corner.

column14: Lararium (2640) above to South, Cooking platform (2637) to East
column16: Lararium (2640) above to South, Cooking platorm (2637) to East
column21: We see a well. It has a large platform around the circular opening. Some evidence of platot Rom?. No sign of paint or decoration.

column14: room 1 to the East
column21: Enter room from East off counter room (1) to a large rectangular (SE/NW axis) dining room. The floor is cocciopesto. All four walls are in place (heavily reconstructed) with high restored ceiling. High SE wall a large rectangular window. On the floor are two large modern wooden platforms and one concrete slab. On top of all these looks like are wall frescos facing downward. The main door on East wall is half-full length and N is a ledge about 3 feet high. On walls is a  deep rd bottom panel up s bordered top and bottom by white stencil border with red green. Colors that remain are yellow, black, deep red, and white. Next panel up is yellow bordered with red and white stencil. The borders above in yellow and red border and white stencil.

column14: Cooking platform (2637) to East, Cistern (2638) Below
column16: Cooking platform (2637) to East, Cistern (2638) Below
column21: On the left wall there is a lararium. No painting remain. Tiles serve as the floor shelf of the niche.

column14: preparation room 2642 to NE
column21: We enter this dining room from a very wide and high doorway, its shape is rectangular and is on a SE/NW axis. This room has some examples of tesserae laid in concrete, most of it is gone. There is plaster and painting examples on all of the walls but they are not very well preserved.  All of the walls are completely restored to a high restored ceiling. The back wall shows a panel painted black. The next level at the back is red and the east and west walls are yellow panels. The most interesting painting remains on the East and West walls. There is a border divided into rectagulars, they are blue turkeys, deep red and rllow and repeated. On these panels there are small stenciled flowers. The flowers are cream and deep red. Above this elaborate border is a smal lrectangular panel with blue turkies background, a triangular base and a very tall slender colou. At the same level of the rectangular panels are larger panels of deep red, yellow and black. No other painting can be seen.

column14: Room 6 is to the west,  rooms 7 and 8 to the East, room 3 to the South
column15: Room 6 is to the west,  rooms 7 and 8 to the East, room 3 to the South
column21: High large rectangular room, NW/SE axis. Cistern in center of the roome 2642, larger areas of plaster survive in N, NW, NE of the room. Red lower register white above. In N corner of the room is a impluvium with drain in N corner and Southern face. In the center of the East wall, plastered cistern head 2644. Doorway to store room and in East corner, lower steps to stairs to floor above. In the center of the South wall are 2 masonry supports for preparation platform 2643. At the western end of the South wall, a doorway with stone threshold and placing for door and modern lintel to room 3. the West wall is a wide opening into dining room 6. Earth floor.

column14: 2644 to the North
column21: 2 restored high masonry supports for a preparation platform. No traces of platform itself survive. Stands against the center South wall.

column14: 2643 to the South, 2642 to the Southwest
column16: 2643 to the South, 2642 to the Southwest
column21: High, plastered cistern head that abars directly against the East wall of the room. The interior, exterior and lip are plastered. The North and South interior faces both contain blocked holes in plaster, perhaps for drains into the cistern. However, no drains are visible on the exterior faces.

column14: room 8 to South, Room 5 to West
column15: room 8 to South, Room 5 to West
column21: Rectangular room, NW/SE axis, Earth floor, upper courses of walls restored, modern ceiling. In Northern end of East wall, 2 recesses. The first, is a rectangular going thru the wall blocked by rubble the other is circular. In East, West and South walls fragments of undecorated plaster survive. At the Southern end of West wall there is a plastered doorway with a stone threshold with door placing for door and modern lintel. At western end of Southern door placing and modern lintel, to room 8 that contains latrine.

column14: Atrium (#1) to the east.
column21: From the atrium, one enters into the large doorway on the eastern wall, two steps up into a large rectangular shaped dining room on a southwest/northeast axis. The floor is pounded dirt. The northeast and northwest walls are restored to the ceiling level. The southwest and southeast walls are in place above modern lintels and a window. The western wall at the southeast corner has a large rectangular window. The walls are mostly completely devoid of any plaster or painted surfaces. On the west wall to the corner of the room there is a large rectangular cupboard niche. Evidence of plaster on the sides and back, but no sign of color. Signs of red plaster from an earlier phase of decoration exists in the east corner of the northeast wall.

column14: None
column21: On the west wall to the corner of the room is a large rectangular cupboard niche.  Evidence of plaster on the sides and back but no sign of color.

column14: Room 1 to North East
column21: Kitchen lies on the West side of the house.  One enters the kitchen through a doorway from Room 1 to the North East.  Room is rectangular in shape on a West East/South West axis.  Just inside the room, abutting the North East walls is a cooking platform.  In the West corner is the opening to a well or cistern.  In the South corner of the South West wall is a rectangular niche which may have held a cupboard.  Floor is cocciopesto.  Walls were stuccoed and painted though decoration is indeterminate.  Ceiling height (modern) is indeterminate.

column14: 2650 Cistern to West
column21: Cooking platform lies in the East corner abutting the North East and South West walls.  The South West end of the cooking platform has broken away.  The platform was composed of rubble and may have had a surface in stucco.  No sign of decoration remains if there had been any.

column14: 2649 (Cooking Platform) to East
column21: The well is located in the West corner abutting the South West and North West walls. The low wall defining the well is rounded.  The well is made of rubble.  Any evidence of stucco and decoration has disappeared.  Waterproof (opus signinum) remains on interior well walls.

column14: Room 1 to South WestRoom 3 to North East
column15: Room 1 to South WestRoom 3 to North East
column21: The kitchen lies to the North East of the atrium (1) of entrance 8.  One enters the kitchen from a doorway from the South corner.  Just to the North West and abutting the West wall is a low cooking platform.  In the North West corner are the foundations for the steps leading to the upper floor and the large, open rectangular space where the stairs would have been.  In the North corner, abutting the North West walls is a water basin.  In the East corner is the doorway to room 3.  The floor is indeterminate.  The walls were stuccoed and probably decorated though no paint remains.  On the North West wall is a rectangular window retaining a portion of the iron grate.  To the North East of the window is a round hole extending to the outside street.  Above the window are the remains of post holes indicating the height of the ceiling.  The room is rectangular in shape on a North West/South East axis.

column14: 2653 to the south
column21: The water basin is located in the north corner abutting the northwest and northeast walls. Very little remains beyond the foundation. Rectangular in shape in a northwest/southeast axis.

column14: 2652 to the north
column21: The cooking platform lies just inside the room from the doorway from the atrium (1) abutting the southwest wall. Made of rubble as reconstructed. It is low with a surface of tiles and lacks any evidence of stucco or paint.

column14: Garden (8) to the south.
column21: One enters the dining room from a large unexcavated garden area (8) to a rectangular shaped dining room through a large doorway from the southeast wall. The room runs on a northwest/southeast axis. A large tile threshold with a cistern with a single stone cover.
