There are walls restored on a high level, no ceiling and the floor is pounded dirt and weeds. On the southeast corner is a low rectangular window that looks into room #10. On the west wall evidence or plaster and a couch niche can be seen. The lower panels appears to be a cream/gray color with traces of red. The next panel is cream with red lines. The other walls show minimal traces of plaster and no paint. The wide doorway might indicate a pleasant garden scene.

column14: None
column21: The niches are plastered,  traces of red paint remain. The niche is found in the northwest corner of the room

column14: None
column21: (Atrium) In the western corner of the atrium between rooms 9 and 10 there is a cooking platform with a level tile top, no lip and no fuel arch.

column14: None
column21: We enter the atrium through a fauces with a Tuscan impluvium and a restored compluvium. There is sign of plaster on the walls and the roof is beautifully restored. The floor is pounded dirt. We see a small bedroom, an ala (8), another bedroom (7) a passageway (6) with an entrance to room 14 next to a impressive tablinum (5). There is another bedroom (4) and another bedroom (3). On the eastern wall there are two large stones, their purpose is unknown. In the western corner of the atrium between rooms 9 and 10 there is a reconstructed cooking platform (2656) with a level tile surface, no lip and no fuel arch.

column14: Atrium (2) to the east.
column21: A rectangular room with a northwest/southeast axis. Restored ceiling; plaster floor obscured by earth. High in the north and east walls, there is a small rectangular window through to the cubiculum. In the east corner, there is a high plastered doorway to the atrium. Poorly preserved stone threshold, modern lintel. Plaster survives on all four walls with a red lower register and white above on the east, north and west walls. In the center of the southeast wall there is a large blocked plastered window from an earlier phase. At the north end of the west wall there is a couch niche (2659).

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: None
column21: Plastered rectangular couch niche. Plaster survives throughout, red in color with no other visible decorations. In the center of the niche is a high plastered bench. The floor of the niche is obscured by earth.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: Andron (6) to the northeast, Room #7 to the northwest.
column15: Andron (6) to the northeast, Room #7 to the northwest.
column21: Dining room (14) is located to the south of the atrium. One enters the dining room from the andron (16) from the northeast. The large dining room is rectangular in shape on a southeast/northwest axis. In the northwest wall in the west corner is a doorway to a bedroom (7). In the northwest wall in the north corner there is a tall narrow recess reaching to the ceiling. The floor is cocciopesto. The original height of the ceiling in indeterminate with modern construction but was probably considerable. The walls were stuccoed and painted apparently in fourth style, though details are hard to determine. In the south corner of the southeast wall is a round hole in mid-height, most likely not ancient. In the north corner of the northwest wall there is a narrow niche from floor to ceiling of unknown purpose.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: None
column21: A large rectangular garden, now containing vines. Excavated by Jashemski (copy notes from Jashemski AJA article). Square water basin (2662) in the north corner. The orchard running from the water basin to the south and east walls. Two large vegetable gardens (21 root cavities) in the north garden. Most of the lower garden was planted in vines. The lack of cavities for stakes indicates the vines were probably less than two years old. 29 terracotta planting pots. In the southeast corner of the garden there is a door to entrance #6.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: None
column21: Square masonry water basin with a plastered internal face. The base is obscured by vegetation. A water channel (2663) extends along the east wall and along the wall to the south.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: Basin (2662) to the west.
column21: A water channel lined with opus signinum extends along the north wall to the east of the basin (2662). The channel forms a "T" with the arm extending to the south. The end of this arm is no longer extant. The east arm is obscured. At the junction of the channel to the north wall and to the basin, plaster survives.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol., pg 954-955

column14: Room 2 to the south.
column21: The counter room is located to the N side of the house, opening into the street. One enters the shop through a wide entrance on the N wall. On the E wall there was a counter (no longer extant). In the SE corner of the S wall is the entrance to Room 2. The floor is cocciopesto in bad condition. The walls were plastered and painted, though no decoration remains. On the W and S walls still remains evidence of molding. The height (original) of the ceiling is indeterminate. The threshold of the door on the N wall is heavily damaged, but that of the doorway in the S wall shows evidence that the door could be closed off. Modern reconstruction.

column14: None
column21: NEGATIVE FEATURE: Eschebach reports a built podium

column14: Room 3 to the south; Room 2 to the southwest.
column15: Room 3 to the south; Room 2 to the southwest.
column21: Triclinium 4 is located in the northeast corner of the house. One enters the room from the southwest from Room 2. The room is rectangular in shape on a north/south axis. The floor is cocciopesto. On the south wall is a large window looking into Peristyle 3. The walls were stuccoed and painted in perhaps the Fourth Style. It is difficult to tell. The ceiling was vaulted as evidenced by the plaster and post holes on the north wall. In the NW corner is a couch niche. Ceiling has been reconstructed at a greater height than vaulting.

column14: None
column21: On the southwest corner of the west wall in a couch niche curved inward is a gradual niche, stuccoed and painted.

column14: Room 2 to the north.
column21: Triclinium 18 is located in the southeast corner of the house. One enters the room from the area of Peristyle 2 to the north. The room is roughly rectangular in shape on a northwest/southeast axis. The floor is cocciopesto. Above the doorway on the north wall is a window. The wall is covered with plastic and painted in probably Fourth Style. The original height of the ceiling is uncertain, but was apparently quite high. Ceiling has been reconstructed.

column14: None
column21: Cooking platform is located in the northeast end of the northwest wing of Room 2. The cooking platform abuts the northeast wall and is on a northwest/southeast axis (roughly). The cooking platform is divided into three unequal parts from south to north. The two south most sections are defined by a tall lip. The north section seems to be an extension of the cooking platform, as it is smaller, sits atop the threshold of Room 3 and does not have a lip on its north end (as reconstructed). The central and south sections are supported by brick foundations that provide a rectangular storage space beneath. The surface of all three sections is of broken tiles (as reconstructed). The foundations of the cooking platform may have been stuccoed in antiquity, but none remains.

column14: None
column21: Square masonry water basin restored. No internal or external facing. Base obscured by vegetation.

column14: Atrium 2 to the northeast; Storeroom 8 to east.
column15: Atrium 2 to the northeast; Storeroom 8 to east.
column21: Enter this storeroom from the Atrium 2 from the northeast through a very high modern lintel. Has a shallow two-step door sill. Is a rectangular room with a east/west axis. The floor is pounded dirt. On the northwest wall there is evidence of two connected storage bins. The walls are second story height with a restored ceiling. Large stair foundations are in the southwest corner (two stairs, landing, two stairs turning left). On the east wall is the doorway to the second floor storage noted in Room 7. Traces of plaster remain on the northeast, northwest, and southwest walls. Some paint, largely faded, remains on the southwest wall.

column14: None
column21: These two connected loins are constituted of stone rubble. The front walls are lower than the back walls (two feet and three feet in back). Bins are in the northwest corner of room. The dividing and end walls were probably sloped. Is largely deteriorated otherwise. The back and northeast wall end of the bins are plastered which allows the size and shape of the bins to be determined.

column14: Storeroom 8 to the northwest; Atrium 2 to the east.
column15: Storeroom 8 to the northwest; Atrium 2 to the east.
column21: Room is to the southwest of main entrance. Enter this large storeroom off of Atrium 2 through a wide door and somewhat low lintel. Floor is pounded dirt. Rectangular room on an east/west axis. There is a bump in over half the northwest wall. Behind the bump is a latrine accessed from Storeroom 8. There are two high small rectangular windows in the southeast wall. Traces of plaster remain in south corner beginning two feet out from the south corner is a recessed horizontal niche about three feet off of the floor and about two inches high. Half of this large storeroom on the north side shows a reconstructed floor of seven floor beams about one foot apart. This second floor area provides good storage for produce. It can be reached through the next Storeroom 8 via stairs. This is the closest room to the produce garden. Modern ceiling reconstruction about twenty-five-thirty feet in total height. Modern scaffolding in south corner.

column14: None
column21: About two feet away from south corner is a recessed shelf niche about three feet off the floor and two inches high. It extends about four feet. Plaster remains on all three sides of the niche. Niche is about one inch deep.

column14: None
column21: Long rectangular bench composed of two pieces of limestone. To the west of the entrance of shop two attaches to the House of the Ship Europa.

column14: None
column21: Long rectangular bench composed of a single block of limestone to the east of the entrance of Shop 2 attached to the House of the Ship Europa.

column14: On the north side - Rooms 1, 3, 4, 11, 12, 13. On the south side -Rooms 6, 15, 18. On the west side - Rooms 5, 7, 8, 9.
column15: On the north side - Rooms 1, 3, 4, 11, 12, 13. On the south side -Rooms 6, 15, 18. On the west side - Rooms 5, 7, 8, 9.
column21: Room 2 is a corridor that runs on the three sides of peristyle 5; north, west, and south sides. On the north side, Room 2 has entrances to Rooms 1, 3, 4, 11, 12, 13. On the west side there are openings to 5, 7, 8, and 9. On the south side, there are openings to 6, 15, 18. On the south, west, and north sides, windows formed by a pluteus, connecting the columns of Peristyle 5, overlook the garden.

column14: Garden 15 to the west.
column21: Is southwest from main entrance. Rectangular room with a northeast/southwest axis. Floor obscured with earth. Walls extensively restored. Modern ceiling. In the center of the north wall is a plastered window that narrows to north and has a modern lintel. In the center of the east wall are two steps up to low doorway to street with stone steps with placing for door and modern lintel. At the south end of the west wall there is a doorway to Garden 15 which has a store threshold with placing for the door and modern lintel. High in the north corner there is a restored plaster fragment (undecorated).

column14: Peristyle (11) to the east.
column21: The dining hall is located in the south corner of the house to the west of the peristyle. One enters the dining hall directly from the peristyle through a doorway in the northeast corner. The dining hall is rectangular in shape on a southeast/northwest axis. The east wall appears to have had a large window looking onto the peristyle to the east. The floor is indeterminate but appears to have been of a beaten cement. The walls were probably decorated in antiquity but nothing remains except small portions of stucco. High on the west wall is a small window. High in the northeast corner at the doorway is a small niche that may have served for lighting.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Storage room (6) to southeast.
column21: Entered through a very low doorway. There's discernible sign of plastering on northwest wall.  There is no ceiling.  Floor obscured by lapilli.  Room is rectangular in shape and has a northwest by southeast axis.  On northwest wall there is a large cooking platform, with a rear shelf.  There is a tiled surface.  Next to cooking counter is water basin lined with waterproof cement.  On southeast corner is latrine.  At the southwest entrance to the left there is a modern blocked doorway.  There are six joist holes in the southeast wall for second floor.  Contiguous to storage room (6).

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: None
column21: Low door to large and irregular horticultural space on southeast wall of peristyle.  Triclinium (masonry) one half way on west side of garden.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Peristyle (11) to the west.
column21: The dining room lies to the east of the peristyle roughly half the way down. One enters the dining room from the west through a wide doorway. The room is roughly square. High on the west wall near the southwest corner is a window looking on to the peristyle. The dining room was probably decorated in antiquity, although plaster remains, very little color is discernible. In the northwest corner of the room are some amphorae and amphora fragments, but it is doubtful that they belong to the room.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Kitchen (5) to the northwest; Storeroom (7) to the northeast; Anteroom (4) to the south.
column15: Kitchen (5) to the northwest; Storeroom (7) to the northeast; Anteroom (4) to the south.
column21: Storeroom 6 is entered from anteroom 4 to the corner of peristyle 11. The storeroom is square and provided with one window on the northeast wall two meters high. The room enjoins kitchen 5 to the northwest and storeroom 7 to the northeast. There is evidence of plaster on the northeast and southeast walls. No evidence of a ceiling but on the northeast wall you can see 7 joist holes which suggest a second floor. The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Storeroom (6) to the northeast; anteroom (4) to the northwest; Room (8) to the southeast.
column15: Storeroom (6) to the northeast; anteroom (4) to the northwest; Room (8) to the southeast.
column21: Storeroom 7 is a square room and is entered from anteroom 4 to the northern corner of peristyle 11. A small oblong window is pierced into the northeastern wall. In the southeast corner of the northeast wall there is evidence of a rectangular slab framed by the edge on one side. The function of this structure is uncertain. The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Water basin (2687) to southwest; Latrine (2686) to southeast.
column16: Water basin (2687) to southwest; Latrine (2686) to southeast.
column21: Large cooking platform in northwest corner.  It has an irregular tiled surface.  It has no front lip.  Most importantly, no storage.  It has a long rear shelf.  Rectangular running along southwest wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Cooking platform (2685) to northwest;  Water basin (2687) to northwest.
column16: Cooking platform (2685) to northwest;  Water basin (2687) to northwest.
column21: Latrine across from water basin in southeast corner.  Two recesses remaining for seating material.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Cooking platform (2685) to northwest.2686 - Latrine  to SE
column16: Cooking platform (2685) to northwest.2686 - Latrine  to SE
column21: Rectangular water basin lined with waterproof cement along the southwest wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: None
column21: The masonry triclinium lays of the west side of the horticultural. The triclinium abuts the wall and fauces to the east. The right couch on the northwest side is fitted into the corner and abuts the west wall and the north end of the north wall that projects from the west wall. The left end couch does not abut the west wall. The left north middle couch abuts the west such that there is a narrow path behind the triclinium that extends almost to the right couch. The couches slope back from the inside. On the inside edge of each couch is built-up to form a ridge. The ridge on the right hand couch beginning at the point where the middle couch meets it turns slightly to the northwest direction where it continues into the west wall. The ridge then continue to the north and then to the east at the east end of the right hand couch. The path behind the triclinium does not extend completely to the right couch, but is blocked by a rectangular structure attached to the middle and end of the right couch. The right and middle couch are slightly higher than the left couch. The triclinium surface is of cement with crushed terracotta. The sides were covered with plaster and were probably decorated. Some red paint remains on the end of the right couch.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 978-979

column14: Atrium (5) to the northwest;  Room (3) to the north.
column15: Atrium (5) to the northwest;  Room (3) to the north.
column21: Dining room (4) lays in the southeast corner of the house.  The door opens in the northwest end of the northwest wall and steps down by one step.  The rectangular room extends along the north/south axis.  In the middle of the west wall a large square window opens onto  water structure of atrium (5).   The walls of the dining room are painted in the 3rd style, with black band supporting large rectangular panels which are framed by red narrow bands.  In between the bands are yellow vegetable stems.  In the middle of the white panels are painted figurative panels.  The only ones left are on the east wall.  They represent two animals (quadrupeds) on the side square panel and two landscaped motifs in the middle of the medallion.  On the upper part of the wall runs a large wide white band framed by yellow frames.  The floor is covered by concrete, but  it shows traces of red painting along the threshold.  Up to the south wall is a small opening.  Along the long walls there is evidence of joist openings (5 left on the northeast wall, 6 on the opposite wall).  Ceiling is of modern construction.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 998

column14: Dining room (4) to the southeast.
column21: A large rectangular room.  No ceiling.  Lapilli on the floor.  In the southeast corner is an aedicula lararium.  Next to this is a staircase to the second floor.  At the northwestern end is a water feature.  Adjacent to this is a dining room.  On the west is a storage room.  The south entrance opens onto a vestibule.  To the west of the vestibule is a small cubiculum.  Another small cubiculum is to the east with a north facing entrance from the atrium.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 998

column14: None
column21: In the east corner of the atrium is an aedicular rectangular shrine.  The east wall shows a genius holding a cornucopia filled with wheat and presenting a patera offering of food to a crested snake.  On an offering table there is a spouted receptacle with a handle ("teapot").  We cannot identify the offered food, but it is light brown and white.  A togaed figure has his head covered.  On the southern aspect of the lararium there is a Minerva figure.  Spear and shield in left hand.  The right hand is extended over an altar.  Around the top of the aedicular triangle there is a red and blue stuccoed pattern in the approximate shape of repeated clover leaves peaked by a single white lily shape.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 998

column14: Corridor (6) along the NW wall of the dining tablinum.  T corridor ends onto space (8) which opens into dining room (9) hortus (11).
column15: Corridor (6) along the NW wall of the dining tablineum.  T corridor ends onto space (8) which opens into dining room (9) hortus (11).
column21: Dining Tablinum is located on the fauces/atrium axis to the southwest. The square room has a large opening entrance off the atrium and a big low window on the opposite wall.  The window faces the Hortus behind.  The dining tablinum doesn't show any evidence of floor covering as it is all lapilli.Along the southwest side of the dining tablinum run a low wall sloping down onto a partly preserved pillar on the northwest side of he entrance.  However the s corner of the southeast wall shows traces of a higher wall abutting the back wall.  On the northeast side of the entrance is framed by a high pillar  is contiguous to the wall with entrance to room 4.

column14: Hortus (11) to west.
column21: The dining room is located on the east side of garden.  One enters dining room from west through fairly wide doorway the room is rectangular in shape on an east/west axis.  The floor is plaster.  On the south wall near the southwest corner is a large window overlooking the garden.  As extant the southern half of the floor remains covered.  Whether unexcavated or whether recovered after excavation is unknown.  All walls were stuccoed and elaborately painted in the third style - much of which remains.  The framing of large window is also decorated with painting.

column14: Room (5) to the southwest
column21: The kitchen is located in the northeast corner of the house. One enter the kitchen through a doorway in the southwest corner. The room is roughly square in shape. The height of the ceiling I indeterminate. The flooring is indeterminate. The walls were plastered, of which a little bit remains, but no decoration is extant. Against the east wall, running between the north and south wall is a combination cooking platform and cleaning area.

column14: Water feature (2708) to the southeast.
column21: The cooking platform is located along the east wall beginning in the northeast corner. It lies on a northwest-southeast axis. Beneath the cooking area is an arched storage area. The surface of the cooking platform has a layer of tile and a front lip. As extant there is only a small part of the lip remaining to the southeast. The façade of the cooking platform shows no evidence for plastering.

column14: Cooking platform (2707) to the northwest.
column21: The water feature lies to the southeast of the cooking platform, abuts the north and east walls, and lies at a level lower than the surface of the cooking platform. The water feature is divided into two parts. To the northwest is a niche, possibly for the storage of some sort of water container. The northwest wall of the niche is shared with the southeast corner of the cooking platform and rises above the cooking platform to an indeterminate height. To the southeast of the niche is a tiled surface that slopes down and toward the back wall where there is a drainage hole in the wall that extends to the outside street. The anterior tile has a high lip. The anterior tile in front of the niche may also at one time have had a similar lip. To the front of the water feature and at a lower level there seem to be remains of a step.

column14: Kitchen (6) to the east, anteroom (5) to the east, open space (3) to the southeast.
column15: Kitchen (6) to the east, anteroom (5) to the east, open space (3) to the southeast.
column21: The L-shaped store room (4) is entered from anteroom (5) which leads into kitchen (6) to the east and open space (3) (atrium) to the southwest. The southeast side of the room ends on to a block of stone which probably supported a flight of stairs leading up to a second story. Above the modern wooden bean over the entrance is a rectangular opening. Most of the walls are covered with plaster. Above the window next to the entrance door there is evidence of red painting.

column14: Atrium (2) to west.
column21: One enters the room from a large doorway in the western corner with post and lintel stone threshold without evidence of door. Rectangular room with northeast-southwest axis. The floor is lapilli. There is no ceiling. Slight evidence of late plaster on the walls. There is evidence of black plaster on lower register of south corner of southwest wall.

column14: Room (1) to the northwest.
column21: The kitchen is located just inside the doorway to the house, to the south. One enters the kitchen through a small doorway from the northwest. In the north corner is a hearth, and a latrine takes up the entire back of the room to the southeast. On the northeast wall was a window which seems to have been walled up in modern times. The height of the ceiling is indeterminate. The nature of the floor is indeterminate. The walls were covered with stucco but no decoration remains. The room is rectangular on a southeast-northwest axis.

column14: Latrine (2713) to the southeast.
column21: A small hearth lies in the north corner of the kitchen. It seems to have been square in shape although the present state of preservation is poor.

column14: Hearth (2712) to the northwest.
column21: The latrine lies to the southeast portion of the kitchen and extends between the northeast and southwest walls. The entrance to the latrine is through small door on the west side. The floor of the latrine is composed of two tiles with lips which slope to the northeast, where there seems to be a drainage hole in the southeast east wall leading to the street. The height of the wall to the southeast of the entrance doorway is indeterminate.

column14: Corridor (5) to the west; room (4) and kitchen (3) to the north.
column15: Corridor (5) to the west; room (4) and kitchen (3) to the north.
column21: The dining room (6) lies in the southeast corner of the house and is entered from open space (1) via corridor (5) to the west. The room is square and shows a large opening on to the street along the northeast wall, but this looks late or of modern construction. Up on the south wall in the southwest corner is a pseudo-rectangular niche whose function is not certain. The nature of the flooring is indeterminate: the floor is currently covered with lapilli and sand. No traces of ceiling remain.

column14: None
column21: The couch niche is built into the north corner of the northwest wall. It is about one meter long and about 50 centimeters high. There are no traces of either plaster or decoration.

column14: Room (4) to the southeast; Atrium (2) to the southwest.
column15: Room (4) to the southeast; Atrium (2) to the southwest.
column21: The triclinium is located at the front of the house in the north corner.  One enters the room from the southwest.  The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest to northeast axis.  There is a doorway in the south corner leading to room 4.  The height of the room is indeterminate, but judged from the stucco on the northeast wall it was vaulted.  The walls are stuccoed and elaborately painted in the 4th style with central panels on the southeast, northeast and northwest walls.  In  the east corner along the southeast wall is a couch niche with low ridge to support the dining couch.  The floor is entirely of beaten cement with a simple design of white marble tesserae surrounding a central square panel of blocks of colored marble.  In the west corner of the northwest wall abutting the northwest and southwest walls is a low hearth.  High on the northwest wall are two windows.  One near the northeast corner and the other toward the northwest corner.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1028-29

column14: Couch niche (2718) to the east.
column21: In the west corner abutting the southwest and northwest walls is a low hearth.  As extant there is a little evidence for stucco façade.  The original height is indeterminate.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1028-29

column14: Hearth (2717) to the west.
column21: In the east corner along the southeast wall is a couch niche.  Inside the niche there is a projecting shelf that comes into the room in the same place as the wall.  The superior aspect of the niche is curved inward from top to bottom.  The low projection does not extend the full width of the niche, but is centered within it.  The niche and projection are stuccoed and painted to conform with the wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1028-29

column14: Dining room (3) to the northwest; space (2) to the southwest; corridor (5) to the southeast.
column15: Dining room (3) to the northwest; space (2) to the southwest; corridor (5) to the southeast.
column21: Serving (4) shows two entrances. The one to the southwest opens on to space (2). The other leads into dining room (3) to the northwest. The small, square room was probably painted as plaster on the western and northern aspects suggests. There are also traces of red painting along the southwest wall framing the entrance and the lower part of the southeast wall. The floor is of beaten cement. Ceiling no longer extant. In the north wall there is evidence of three irregular holes resembling joist holes. Their true function is, however, uncertain.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1028-29

column14: Hallway (5) to the north.
column21: We enter the kitchen from hallway (5) through a doorway in the southeast wall. Wider than usual doorway. Floor lapilli. No evidence of plaster. Ceiling is not in place. It is a square room. On the northeast corner there is evidence of a masonry platform. On the southwest wall presents a strange rectangular opening with evidence of a drain at the bottom. Above this opening there is evidence of a place for a shelf. Opening is walled up but leads to a toilet. Hallway also leads to a toilet. The northwest hallway leads to an atrium. We have three deep slots, probably for shelves, on the southeast wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1028-29

column14: The cooking platform (2724) to the southwest.
column16: The cooking platform (2724) to the southwest.
column21: The latrine is located to the southeast of the doorway. The floor is on a higher level than that of the kitchen and of room 2. In the east wall there evidence for construction to support the seat. Inserted in the wall above the seat is an arched niche. The walls seem to be stuccoed and possibly painted. The surface of the floor is made up of paving slabs in cement. There is a southwest wall to the latrine that separates it from the cooking platform. The height of the wall is indeterminate.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.

column21: The lararium niche is encircled by yellow with border of 10 large flowers and 23 buds. Back shows genius sacrificing to an altar holding petera. Copper receptacle with food. The genius is holding a cornucopia, wearing a toga. He is accompanied by attendant. The back wall and edge of altar is bordered with red burgundy color. The ledge on bottom has two burgundy green stars underneath.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.

column14: Pool (2734) to the southwest; cooking platform (2736) to the northeast; water basin (2739) to the southwest; hearth (2734)  to the east.
column16: Pool (2734) to the southwest; cooking platform (2736) to the northeast; water basin (2739) to the southwest; hearth (2734)  to the east.
column21: Triclinium is located to the south of the stairs leading up to the second floor. Constructed of masonry the three couches are approximately of the same length. To the front of the left couch, running the entire width is a step. The interior of all three couches have a series of shallow arched niches, six in the left couch, four in the middle couch, five in the right couch. The left and middle couch have a rim running around the edge. The right couch has a rim on the northwest side but a low wall on the northeast side. In the center of the couches is a rectangular table on a northeast/southwest axis. The northeast end of the table is defined by two projections with an open end. Underneath the table is an opening to what appears to be a cistern. The surface of the couches appear to be modern reconstruction. The table was apparently covered with masonry of which a little remains. In the southwest corner, next to but not connected with the left couch is a shallow rectangular water trough parallel with the left couch.

column14: None
column21: In the northeast wall there is evidence of masonry support for cooking platform.  On southwest wall is masonry support for cooking platform.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1029-29

column14: Room (4) to the northeast; space (2) to the northwest;  kitchen (2723) to the southwest
column15: Room (4) to the northeast; space (2) to the northwest;  kitchen (2723) to the southwest
column21: Storeroom (5) opens onto space (2) to the northwest.  Adjoining the entrance to the northeast is a rectangular window with a shelf sloping down outwards.  On the stone threshold there is a small circular hole for closing the door and a rectangular hole for pivoting the door.  The walls are mostly covered with red painting.  The southeast and northeast walls show holes of different shapes and sizes; perhaps for supporting shelves?  On the southwest wall there is a built-in semicircular niche.  Above this niche is the modern wooden stairs leading up to a second story.  The modern ceiling of this storeroom to the west side supports the floor of the above mezzanine.  The axis of this small rectangular room is northwest-northeast.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.

column14: Stairs (11) to the south; peristyle (1) to the northeast
column15: Stairs (11) to the south; peristyle (1) to the northeast
column21: Dining room (10) opens onto the northeast porticus of peristyle (1).  The room has not been excavated and has been blocked by modern wall.  However, the large entrance and location which offers the best view out towards the peristyle (1) suggest the function of unexcavated space as the main dining room.  There is just a small fragment of red painting along the northwest wall framing the entrance door.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.

column14: Dining room (2727) to the west; cubiculum/dining room to the south; garden to the east.
column15: Dining room (2727) to the west; cubiculum/dining room to the south; garden to the east.
column21: Colonnaded hallway to peristyle garden.  With northwest entrance, two southwest entrances and one southeast door to cubiculum/dining room with lararium above.  On southwest are four columns with a balustrade and arches spring from columns. On southwest wall to the west of the first southwest door about six feet up is a lararium with ledge.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. 1038-1039

column14: All three dolia (2757, 2758, 2759) to the southeast; cistern and puteal (2760) ; altar (2765) to the south.
column16: All three dolia (2757, 2758, 2759) to the southeast; cistern and puteal (2760) ; altar (2765) to the south.
column21: A large rectangular vat with low walls, on a southwest/northwest axis, blocks entrance to Room 4 from the northwest.  The southwest wall of the room forms the southwest wall of the vat.  The exterior walls of the vat were plastered and painted.  The interior walls and the floor were covered with opus signinum.  There was also an ovolo which seals the area where the walls and floor meet to prevent leakage.  In the south corner at floor level is a drain to drain the vat. A second drain, at the floor level in the southeast wall, appears to drain into the cistern.  The vat may have held water, perhaps used in preparing the picked grapes for crushing in Room 2.

column14: Dolia (2758,2759) to the northeast; altar (2765) to the southeast; vat (2756) to the northwest; cistern to the north.
column16: Dolia (2758,2759) to the northeast; altar (2765) to the southeast; vat (2756) to the northwest; cistern to the north.
column21: This dolium lies along the southeast wall and is the most southwest of the three.  It is a typical dolium with a thick rim, partially embedded in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2757) to the southwest; dolium (2759) to the northeast; cistern (2760) to the north; vat (2756) to the northwest.
column16: Dolium (2757) to the southwest; dolium (2759) to the northeast; cistern (2760) to the north; vat (2756) to the northwest.
column21: This dolium lies along the southeast wall, to the northeast of dolium (2757)  and to the southeast of dolium (2759).  This is a typical dolium with a thick rim, partially embedded in the ground.

column14: Dolia (2757 and 2758) to the southwest; cistern (2760) to the northwest; vat (2756) to the northwest; altar (2765) to the southwest.
column16: Dolia (2757 and 2758) to the southwest; cistern (2760) to the northwest; vat (2756) to the northwest; altar (2765) to the southwest.
column21: This dolium is located along the southeast wall to the northeast of dolium (2758).  The lip of the dolium is heavily damaged but seems to conform to the shape of the other two dolia ( 2757 and 2758).

column14: Fauces (1) to the southeast.
column21: The room is located to the northwest of the entrance.  One enters the room from the northeast through a tall doorway.  The room is rectangle in shape on a northeast/southwest axis.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is rather tall and slopes downward from northeast to southwest.  The floor is of a cement inlaid with broken pieces of white, red, and orange marble, and basalt. There seems to be in the center, a rectangular panel of marble inlay. The lowest register has a black background; in the foreground are plants and birds.  The middle register, the tallest, is a series of rectangular panels in various colors: red, orange, and green alternating.  The upper register has a white background, two vertical bands separating a series of paintings, all food related.  Just above the third, top register molding, the stucco seems to pitch inward (southeast wall) perhaps to create a barrel vault.  In the south corner is a niche for a couch.  On the northwest wall is a window cut into the wall such that it would have destroyed much of the painting that was situated between features 2839 and 2840.  Nothing of this painting remains.

column14: Painting (2836) above; paintings (2834, 2835) to the east; paintings (2837, 2838) to the southwest, paintings (2839, 2840) to the northwest.
column16: Painting (2836) above; paintings (2834, 2835) to the east; paintings (2837, 2838) to the southwest, paintings (2839, 2840) to the northwest.
column21: The single couch niche is located on the southeast wall in the south corner of the room.  The niche slopes sharply, back and down, where it meets the couch support.  The niche and stucco are painted to blend with the design of the low register.

column14: Painting (2835) to the southwest.
column21: On the east corner of the southeast wall is a painting showing four pomegranates, one of which has been cut to show the interior.  The center two pomegranates sit on a box; in the background are branches.  The painting is framed by a thin red line all set within a rectangular panel, bordered on top, bottom and northeast sides by a wider red band.  The southwest border is a vertical green band.

column14: Painting (2834) to the northeast; painting (2836) to the southwest.
column16: Painting (2834) to the northeast; painting (2836) to the southwest.
column21: On the southeast wall, in the center, is a painting showing dates.  The background is indistinguishable, perhaps a bowl.  The painting is framed by a thin red line all set within a rectangular panel defined on the top and bottom by continuous red lines and by the double vertical bands on the northeast and southwest.

column14: Painting (2835) to the northeast; painting (2837) to the west.
column16: Painting (2835) to the northeast; painting (2837) to the west.
column21: On the southeast wall in the south corner is a painting showing a dead pig.  The pig lies on its back, feet straight up.  The red paint along the stomach may indicate it had been gutted.  A spear lies on the chest of the pig between his two front legs.  The painting is framed by a thin red line all set within a rectangular panel defined on top and bottom by the continuous red lines and by the double vertical lines to the northeast and a red vertical line on the southwest.

column14: Painting (2836) to the east; painting (2838) to the west.
column16: Painting (2836) to the east; painting (2838) to the west.
column21: On the southwest wall in the south corner there is a painting.  To the left is a duck.  To the right lying on a box is a basket of fruit, to the right of which appear to be either baskets or vessels of other fruits.  The painting is framed by a thin red line all set within a rectangular panel defined on top and bottom with a continuous red line.  It is framed on the left by a vertical red line and on the right by two vertical green lines.

column14: Painting (2837) to the south; painting (2839) to the northwest.
column16: Painting (2837) to the south; painting (2839) to the northwest.
column21: On the southwest wall, west corner, is a painting.  To the right is a large fish, perhaps a mullet, lying on its back.  To the left is a box on which lie other seafoods.  On the top right of the box is another fish (perhaps a mullet). That fish may be leaning on another fish, though the painting is indistinct.  On the top left are two squid.  The painting is framed by a thin red line, all set within a rectangular panel defined on the top and bottom by continuous red lines.  It is framed on the left by two vertical green lines, and on the right by a vertical red line in the corner.

column14: Vat (2756) to the northwest; dolium (2759) to the south-southeast.
column16: Vat (2756) to the northwest; dolium (2759) to the south-southeast.
column21: The cistern lies to the southeast of the vat such that the opening (pluteus) partially impinges into the southeast wall of the vat.  As extant today, a terracotta puteal covers the entrance to the cistern.

column14: Three dolia (2757, 2758, 2759) to the northeast; vat (2756) to the northwest; cistern with puteal (2760) to the northeast.
column16: Three dolia (2757, 2758, 2759) to the northeast; vat (2756) to the northwest; cistern with puteal (2760) to the northeast.
column21: In the south corner, abutting the southeast and the southwest walls, is a low stone structure that may have been an altar.

column14: Rooms 12, 13, and 14 lie to the north of Room 15. The other three sides of the room are bounded by streets.
column15: Rooms 12, 13, and 14 lie to the north of Room 15. The other three sides of the room are bounded by streets.
column21: This large rectangular room is on a roughly north/south axis.  It contains a masonry couch triclinium in the middle of the room situated slightly to the west.  It is planted with modern olive and fruit trees and grapevines.  Along the eastern wall appears a small rectangular recess which seems to have contained a flight of stairs but the overgrown vegetation doesn't allow us to go beyond this as an hypothesis.  The surrounding walls have been heavily reconstructed in modern times and vary in height.  The south and east walls are restored to one plus stories high.  The east wall varies between over one story to the east to waist high in the west.  At the base of the southern wall runs a low bench-like structure which seems to have been used for supporting the entire wall.  Along the northern wall, to the northeast, there are traces of red and yellow painting.  The is a small rectangular niche in the northeast corner of the eastern wall about 1.5 meters above the ground.  In the northeast corner of the northern wall there are four joist holes about two meters above the ground.  On the eastern wall there is also a high rectangular window.  Along the western wall towards the kitchen there are traces of red and yellow painting on the lower part of the wall.  Near the kitchen there is also a large built-in shallow semicircular niche.  It has a narrow ledge and there are traces of plaster.  South of the niche is a large rectangular stone that juts out of the wall and is about two meters above the ground, the function of which is uncertain.  There is a recessed area to the east of the entrance of Room 5 which, according to the floor plan was actually a doorway to Room 2.  Today it is blocked up.  According to the floor plan there are stairs in the southern end of the eastern wall. The stairs no longer exist.  In the southeast corner today there is a small glass building showing thirteen plaster casts of victims of the 79 A.D. eruption (men, women, children).  According to modern literature the bodies were found in Room 15.

The masonry couch triclinium is in the middle of Room 15 and is situated slightly to the west in the room.  It is U-shaped with the eastern couch about 50 centimeters longer than the western couch.  The inner walls of the couch are decorated with ground-level semicircular niches (five on the eastern couch, three on the southern couch, three on the western couch) for storing plates.  Along the outside of the couches runs a low bench.  In the middle of the southern couch and in the corner of the southern and eastern couches were pillars.  The pillar in the southern couch is the only one remaining.  The benches on the eastern and western couches continue out and enjoin a large rectangular structure.  They are slightly higher than the benches connected to the triclinium couches.  The large sunken rectangular structure contains an embedded pillar in the middle of the southern side.  This pillar may have supported  a table which suggests the idea that the whole area may have been used as a garden.  Today the masonry triclinium is shaded by a vine pergola.

column14: Room 1 (2762) to the north.
column21: Large, rectangular open space with single gate in north-northeast corner. When originally excavated, there were 128 root cavities found - currently there are 132 in number of modern planted vines. There is evidence of four actual dolia with depressions indicating two more. In 1972, near dolia, was found "GA Scombr(i) scavrt/Ex officina scaruri" and a garum container. Broad paving  rectangular stones surrounds the current vines growing on site. The room has a northeast to southwest axis.

column14: Dolium (2749) to the southeast
column21: Dolium 2748 lies in the eat corner of the vineyard (room 5). It is parallel with the northeast wall and is seated into the ground.

column14: Dolium (2748) to the northwest; Dolia (2750) to the southeast.
column16: Dolium (2748) to the northwest; Dolia (2750) to the southeast.
column21: Dolium 2749 is in the east corner of the vineyard (room 5), in between dolia (2748) and (2750) parallel to the northeast wall, It is seated in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2749); Dolium (2751)
column21: Dolium 2750 is in the east corner of the vineyard (room 5) at the end of a row of three and parallel to the northeast wall. It is seated in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2752); Dolium (2750)
column21: Dolium 2751 is in the east corner of the vineyard (room 5) at the end of a row of four; parallel to the southeast wall. It is seated in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2753); Dolium (2751)
column21: Dolium 2752 is in the east corner of the vineyard (room 5) at the inner row of four; parallel to the southeast wall. It is seated in the ground.

column14: Dolium (2752); Dolium (2754)
column21: Dolium 2753 is in the east corner of the vineyard (room 5) in a row of four dolia; parallel to the southeast wall. The dolium is seated in the ground.

column14: None
column21: Negative feature sheet. Dolium no longer extant. Eschebach mentions seven buried dolia in the southeast in an L shape.

column14: Vineyard (5) to the southwest; Processing room (2) to the southeast.
column15: Vineyard (5) to the southwest; Processing room (2) to the southeast.
column21: Room 1 is rectangular on a northwest/southeast axis. Room 1 is entered through a large entrance as wide as the room to the northwest. Two pairs of semi-pilasters leaning against the northwestern and southwestern walls seem to divide this large room into three spaces. In the southeastern corner at the back, close to the entrance of processing room there is evidence of stairs leading up to a missing story. What is left today is a low step and a high platform which would have supported the stairs. In the western corner of the southwestern wall in the entrance into the vineyard (room 5) with the embedded dolia. On the same wall between the two pilasters there is what appears to have been a door. On the top is covered with a line of bricks supporting what looks like the opening but is difficult to discern the function. Because of the location of this room connecting the vineyard and processing room, the use of room 1 must be somehow associated with the production and processing of grapes. With comparison to all the traditions still surviving in Southern Italy, this space could be used for storing the agricultural tools. In some periods of the year the front part could be temporarily used for selling surplus wine and serving a glass of wine to the passersby. The ceiling is no longer extant but the walls are quite well preserved almost to full height of the first floor. The floor is now covered with lapilli. No plaster is extant. Along the southwestern wall, next to the last pilaster to the southern corner is a long, narrow indentation with a tiled bottom and stuccoed interior with an indeterminate function.

Room 2 is entered from room 1 to the northwest. It's a rectangular room along a northwest/southeast axis. The northeastern wall is almost entirely preserved in its height while the opposite wall (southwestern) is about two meters high with two separate brick pillars embedded in the wall dividing the wall into thirds. Up on the southeastern wall there are four irregularly shaped joist holes. In the southeastern corner of the room a modern post supporting a modern roof in the adjoining building (I.20.4). The floor is completely obscured by lapilli. No plaster or other decoration extant. Close to the entrance along the southwestern wall there is evidence of one embedded dolium. Eschebach mentioned two dolia being in this room.

column14: None
column21: Midway in the southwestern wall is the remains of a dolium. Today it is just 1/3 of the rim of an embedded terracotta dolium. The visible rim is about 5 to 8 centimeters high.

column14: Processing room (4) to three southeast; Room (3) to north; Room (10) to west.
column15: Processing room (4) to three southeast; Room (3) to north; Room (10) to west.
column21: One enters the storage room from a large doorway off the vestibule from a large northwest high entrance. We see in the southeast area a large processing room with a 10 inch high three sided vat. The floor is rubble and lapilli. It is a rectangular room with a southwest / northeast axis. The walls are interesting showing early tufa to late Roman construction and is empty of features with the exception of a rectangular built up area in the eastern corner about 7 inches high. Opus signinum is how it is lined (or cocciopesto). Ceiling is no longer extant. Evidence of stucco on northwest wall survives.

column14: None
column21: In the eastern corner of room 2 is a two sided stomping vat. The other two sides are parts of the structure (walls). This square area slopes to a drain which ends in a tank. The containment tank has been attached to an old wall and is a buried containment terra cotta vessel or tank. The vat is lined with a low wall about ten inches high. The new wall (lip) closest to container is rounded. The other ten inch line is tile.

column14: Peristyle (6) to the southeast; dining room (2699) to the south; and hortus (5) to the northwest.
column15: Peristyle (6) to the southeast; dining room (2699) to the south; and hortus (5) to the northwest.
column21: Dining room (10) is entered from a doorway in the SE corner along the northeast porticus (19) of peristyle (6).  The square dining room is provided with two windows.  The smaller one opens onto the  middle of the southwest wall.  It is square, about 3 meters high.  The other window on the opposite side is much bigger and faces onto the peristyle.  This window is in line with the entrance door.  The threshold of then door is decorated with octagonal pattern of tangent squares framed by white tesserae on cocciopesto.  The geometric composition may have been repeated on the floor, as some traces along the northeast wall suggest.   However, the floor is completely covered by a thick layer of soil and rubble.  Up on the northwest wall there is evidence of one joist opening.  There are a lot of fragments of plaster to suggest there was once painting on the walls.

column14: Peristyle (11) to the northeast; dining room (2696) to the northwest; space (2) to the southeast.
column15: Peristyle (11) to the northeast; dining room (2696) to the northwest; space (2) to the southeast.
column21: Dining room (11) lays off the northwest patio (19) of peristyle (6).  It is entered from a large opening into the northwest side of the northeast wall.  The high adjoining northwest wall is quite well preserved, while the other 3 walls are just 1 meter high now.  The large room is rectangular along the northwest/southeast axis.  The floor is covered with lapilli, which makes it difficult to ascertain the floor covering type.  A pile of large cocciopesto fragments lay along the southeast wall, but we don't know if they belong to this room.  Ceiling no longer extant.

The hearth is located in the northwest corner abutting the northwest and southwest walls.  The hearth is rectangular in shape on a roughly northeast to southwest axis.  The top of the hearth is layered with red tiles which seem to show some evidence of burning.

column14: Room (6) to the south.
column21: Entering the dining room through large southwestern entrance with marble threshold with holes for a door.  Rectangular room with a north/south axis.  Room had high lintel and posts (as reconstructed).  Floor is lower than threshold.  The floor retains no mosaic work.  Walls go to second floor.  On the southeast wall there is a rectangular window opening to the street on the second floor.  No ancient ceiling.  Currently protected by modern cover.  Walls show late plaster, apparently third style.  From the center of the room the view to atrium impluvium is partially blocked by a pilaster of tufa block and brick alternating courses.  The room overlooks atrium with impluvium, which is next to large entrance vestibule.  There are no features.

column14: Room 3 to northwest; Room 6 to southwest.
column15: Room 3 to northwest; Room 6 to southwest.
column21: In the south corner of the house.  One enters the room from the northwest.  Roughly square in shape.  The walls were plastered in antiquity.  The base of the walls where they meet with the floors are sealed with plaster ovolo.  This has led to identification of the room as a press room.  The height of the room is indeterminate, though as reconstructed the roof slopes from east to west.  The room itself is higher than the hallway (room #3) to the north.  In the northwest corner at the base of the wall is a drain to the outside into room #6.  Today the floor of the doorway is open to the outside.  In antiquity the ovolo may have run across the doorway.  The walls may have been painted (probably red).

column14: Cupboard niche (2701) to the southeast; Shelf niche (2702) to the southeast; Cupboard niche  (2703) to the southeast; Amphora (2705) to the South
column16: Cupboard niche (2701) to the southeast; Shelf niche (2702) to the southeast; Cupboard niche  (2703) to the southeast; Amphora (2705) to the South
column21: Amphora in northeast corner within large arched niche filled with lapilli seen through break in amphora.  Modern concrete supports in situ Amphora.

column14: Shelf niche (2702) to the north; amphora (2704) to the northwest; cupboard niche (2703); cupboard niche (2701) to the northwest
column16: Shelf niche (2702) to the north; amphora (2704) to the northwest; cupboard niche (2703); cupboard niche (2701) to the northwest
column21: in southwest corner evidence of an on site amphora.  The shape  of the amphora can be seen in full.  There is a large fragment of amphora remaining.  The wall behind amphora S wall shows green & red fourth style.  The bottom course shows red above amphora are two levels of molding.

column14: Processing rooms (3) to the east; Entrance to the north; cellar to the southeast.
column15: Processing rooms (3) to the east; Entrance to the north; cellar to the southeast.
column21: Space 2 is accessible from the southwestern side of entrance 1. This huge space includes a number of features. Stone stairs to the northwest leading up to a missing story, a masonry couch triclinium with two enjoined water structures at the back (to the west) a cooking platform opposite the masonry couch to the northeast, a cellar to the southeast along the perimeter wall of the structure. The remaining space to the south is today planted as a vineyard. Along the northwest wall a small entrance connects space two with the enjoined lamps workshop; however the two structures seem not to be related to the same building. The space between the entrance and the masonry couch triclinium to the southwest wall with the pathways running along the vines are paved with regularly shaped blocks.

column14: Agricultural area (2732) to the west; Processing room (2738) to the northwest.
column15: Agricultural area (2732) to the west; Processing room (2738) to the northwest.
column21: Located along the northeast wall, about a third of the way down from the southeast wall of room 3, is an underground wine cellar.  The entrance to the cellar is defined by a low wall on an east/west axis and is a lower level than the level of the vineyard.  One descends the stairs from the east.  Approx. eight steps down the steps turn at a right angle towards the southwest.  At the southeast end running the entire width of the cellar is a low wall that together with the cellar walls create a deep vat.  About one fourth of the way from the entrance of he cellar is the remains of the wall.  The walls of the cellar were lined with opus signinum.  The ceiling of the cellar is vaulted its entire length interrupted only in the front middle and back by the three vent holes.  Near the midpoint of the southwest wall is a large opening into a cavity of unknown use.  It may have been merely where the wall has caved in as it may have been covered by the plaster of the wall.  At the bottom of the stairs the cellar opens to the southeast and runs in a northwest/southeast direction.  The cellar appears to run all of the way or almost so to the southeast wall of the vineyard (room 2)  There appears to be three openings to the cellar in the floor of the vineyard to allow light and air into the cellar and evacuate gases from the fermenting wine.

column14: Room (2) is to the northeast; room (15) is to the southeast; The street is to the southwest; Room (9) is to the northwest (according to the floor plan, but today is walled.)
column15: Room (2) is to the northeast; room (15) is to the southeast; The street is to the southwest; Room (9) is to the northwest (according to the floor plan, but today is walled.)
column21: The kitchen (5) is entered by one step up from the southeast through what looks like today a large entrance. The room is rectangular on a southeast / northwest axis. The northwest and southwestern walls have preserved their height up to the first floor. About one meter high on the southwestern wall there is evidence of three joist holes the function of which is not certain (they are too low to support a second story) Another joist hole appears on the southwestern wall in the corner joining the northwest wall. However this hole is about one and a half meters from the ground. On the area of the southwestern wall are traces of red painting which do not appear on the other walls. The floor is completely covered by lapilli and wild vegetation. The kitchen contains a latrine in the northern corner and a cooking platform in the southern corner. Ceiling is no longer extant. Modern hoses are being stored in the room today.

column14: Latrine (2769) to the north.
column21: The structure is in the southern corner of the kitchen and leans against the southwestern wall. It is a large square structure the top of which is covered by large tiles. In the southwestern corner there are remains of a high stone support which appears semi circular in shape. There is evidence that a similar stone support is in the northwestern corner of the structure. The tiled top slopes to a drain in the southwestern wall. Adjoining the northwestern side of the structure is a low square stone platform whose function is uncertain as it is completely covered by debris. Because of the lack of other examples of this structure type it is arguable that the tiled feature might have been used as a cleaning platform and the adjoining low platform is in fact a cooking platform. However it is also possible that the higher part of the structure functions as both a cooking and cleaning platform which leaves open the question of the lower platform.

column14: Cooking platform (2768) to the south.
column21: The latrine lays in the northern corner of Room 5. It is completely covered by lapilli, vegetation and modern plastic hoses. However the southeastern stone edge is still visible. No drain is extant due to vegetation/lapilli layer.

column14: Room (5) to the southeast is a peristyle and a wide corridor.
column15: Room (5) to the southeast is a peristyle and a wide corridor.
column21: One enters the dining room with a marble threshold through a large wide door. This is a rectangular dining room with a northwest / southeast axis. The floor is plastered but tesserae are not visible. On the entrance wall (southeast) no plaster remains. On all three remaining walls we see good evidence of Fourth Style painting. The bottom zone is divided into burgundy rectangles. The walls have burgundy, ivory, yellow with Third Style perspective that Vitruvius would not like. The ceiling is modern which indicates there was no ceiling after the eruption. On the northwest corner there is a brick engaged column that would have been covered in plaster. The northeast wall near the corner shows evidence of an earlier door. You could see a peristyle from the dining room.
column53: BW: exterior and three interior walls; CS: exterior and three interior walls; Dig: exterior and three interior walls

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column14: None
column21: The horticultural space is located in the southeast part of the property. The northeast, southeast and southwest boundaries are defined by high masonry walls. In the center is a masonry triclinium. To the southwest of the masonry triclinium is an altar (2793). Along the southwest wall about four feet from ground level are a series of openings into the wall, function unknown.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column14: Altar (2793) to the southwest.
column21: The masonry triclinium is located in the center of the horticultural area, Room 5 (2791). The triclinium faces to the southwest. The left couch is slightly longer than the right one. Around the interior edge of all three couches is a raised lip. All three couches slope slightly down from the inside out. The interior walls of the couches contain niches for storage; four niches in the right couch, three in the middle couch and five in the left couch. In the center of the couches is a large rectangular masonry table lying on a northeast / southwest axis. The table according to Jashemski had a variegated marble top, no longer extant. As extant, the exterior of the couches and table lack any plaster. As reconstructed, the surface of the couches is made of a hard cement with fragments of terra cotta.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column14: Masonry triclinium (2792) to the northeast.
column21: To the southwest of the triclinium, which faces it , is a low altar, square in shape and on a northwest / southeast axis. As extant there is no sign of stucco or decoration.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column14: Space (2) to the south; corridor (5) to the northwest
column15: Space (2) to the south; corridor (5) to the northwest
column21: Dining room (8) lies in the eastern corner of the hotel. The large entrance faces a semicircular stone structure at the back of space (2). On the opposite wall is a large square window opening onto courtyard (13). To the west of the entrance remain traces of red painting on the wall. They also appear on the northeast wall. The floor is today covered by lapilli. The ceiling is gone. To the eastern side of the entrance are remains of the ancient wall, made of terracotta slabs. The dining room is rectangular and along a southwest/northeast axis.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. ,1028-1029

column14: Entrance 1 to the east; Space 2 to the west and south.
column15: Entrance 1 to the east; Space 2 to the west and south.
column21: Room 3 is located to the southwest of entrance 1 and opens onto space 2 to the west.  The room is today closed by a modern locked door which allow us to give a full description of the space inside.  However, from some space holes at the entrance it's possible to see a low wall at the back.  This wall could surround a tank for processing grapes since PPM describes a grape pressing structure in front of the masonry couch triclinium.

column14: Masonry triclinium (2733) to the north; pool (2735) to the southwest; cooking platform (2736) to the north; hearth (2734) to the northeast.
column16: Masonry triclinium (2733) to the north; pool (2735) to the southwest; cooking platform (2736) to the north; hearth (2734) to the northeast.
column21: In the southwest corner, next to but not connected with the left couch is a shallow rectangular water trough parallel with the left couch. The trough is a single piece of stone that has been hollowed out.

At the southeast end of the underground wine cellar running the entire width of the cellar is a wall approx. one half the height of the room that together with the walls create a deep vat.  The walls of the vat are lined with opus signinum so as to prevent leakage.  The vat is approx. square in shape.

column14: Processing room (2761) to the northwest; Room 5 near north corner; Room 6 near east corner; Room 13 is to the southeast.
column15: Processing room (2761) to the northwest; Room 5 near north corner; Room 6 near east corner; Room 13 is to the southeast.
column21: The processing is approached from the  northwest room 2. The room is rectangular in shape on a southwest/northeast axis. Most of the southwest part of the room  is taken up by a vat parallel to the axis of the room. To the southeast of the vat area are three large dolia partially embedded. In the south corner is a stone structure probably an altar. Near the north corner is a doorway to room 5. In the east corner is a doorway to room 6. In the east corner of the southeast wall is a doorway to room 13. Height of walls are indeterminate, as is the floor. Between the southeast wall of the vat and the most northeast dolium is an opening to a cistern protected by a puteal.

Room 1 opens to the northwest by descending a flight of two steps. The rectangular room is on a northwest/southeast axis. Two thirds down the room to the southwest is a masonry couch triclinium. Above the middle couch to the south there are two semicircular niches. The top niche which is larger than the smaller niche; it has a shelf and shows traces of white painting on the upper curve of the niche. This suggests that the niche was probably used as a lararium. The other smaller niche which is about 70 centimeters above the middle couch is deeper than the larger niche above the ground. Perhaps it was used to hold lamps. To the south of the larger niche is evidence of a walled up window. On the same wall to the west there is another large niche resting on the ground. There are traces of yellow paint on the southeast wall and red painting on the eastern corner of the northeast wall and in the northern corner of the northeast wall. On the north and east and southwest walls there is evidence of plaster. In the northern corner of the northeast wall there is a U-shaped frame of a window that was blocked up. On the southwestern wall there are irregularly shaped holes located in different points. The function of these joist like holes is unknown. The walls have been heavily reconstructed to the first floor height. The floor is now covered with overgrown vegetation, however Jashemski argues that the area was planted with olive trees and possibly vines because traces of wine were found in the dolia. The ceiling is no longer extant. The dolia were found in the eastern corner of the room. Today in the southern corner is an unburied dolium but there is no evidence if it was there in antiquity.

column14: The large cupboard niche (2774) to the northwest;  A lararium (2775) to the southwest; Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column16: The large cupboard niche (2774) to the northwest;  A lararium (2775) to the southwest; Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column21: On a southwest area in the room we see a masonry triclinium.  The triclinium has a left side, a top middle and a right side.  There is a two-piece table/mensa in the rectangular open space.  The dining slope is very apparent but there is no painting remaining on the benches, but there is evidence of plaster on the right bench.  The top couch is narrow, perhaps too narrow for reclining.  Looking at the wall (behind the garden triclinium) on the west of the triclinium there remains a patch of yellow plaster next to a large cupboard recessed niche.

column14: Triclinium ( 2773) to the southeast; Lararium ( 2775) on the same wall to the southeast. Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column16: Triclinium ( 2773) to the southeast; Lararium ( 2775) on the same wall to the southeast. Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column21: On the southeast wall is a large curved cupboard niche. On the back wall there is evident yellow paint stucco inside. This could have contained cooking/eating/drinking utensils.

column14: Triclinium (2773) to the northeast;  Large cupboard niche (2774) on same wall to the northeast;  Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column16: Triclinium (2773) to the northeast;  Large cupboard niche (2774) on same wall to the northeast;  Two dolia (2776, 2777) to the east.
column21: The lararium lies above the triclinium (2773) on the southwest wall.  The lararium has aedicular shape with a ledge.  It's a good size.  On the north side of the lararium there is ivory colored paint placed with strong touches of red and pink apparent.  Perhaps this replicates the scattering of roses we've seen on other lararia.  The lararium is not centered over the triclinium but is slightly south of the center.  Next to the lararium on the west is a rectangular window.  Beneath the window and lararium a curved opening probably for a lamp.

column14: Painting (2838) to the southwest; painting (2840) to the north.
column16: Painting (2838) to the southwest; painting (2840) to the north.
column21: On the northwest wall in the west corner is a painting of four bunches of grapes, two of which have branches attached.  The painting is framed by a thin red line, all set within the rectangular panel defined on the top and bottom by a continuous red line.  It is framed on the left by a vertical red line and on the right by two vertical green lines.

column14: Painting (2839) to the southwest.
column21: On the north corner of the northwest wall is a painting.  To the left is a green parrot.  To the right, sitting on a box are four apples.  One has been cut and three seem to have twigs and leaves attached.  The painting is framed by a thin red line, all set within the rectangular panel defined on top and bottom by a continuous red line.  It is framed on the left by two vertical green lines and on the right by a vertical red line in the north corner.

column14: Fauces (1) to the southwest; dining hall (2843) to the southeast; room 9 to the southeast; rooms 4,7 and 8 to the northeast; room 5 to the northwest.
column15: Fauces (1) to the southwest; dining hall (2843) to the southeast; room 9 to the southeast; rooms 4,7 and 8 to the northeast; room 5 to the northwest.
column21: Room 3 is a large peristyle.  The central courtyard of this peristyle may be divided into two unequally sized spaces by two larger pilasters which show a rarely decorative feature:  two semicircular semi-columns enjoining two square semi-pillars.  In the modern description of this open area these two pilasters are said to have supported a pergola shading the northeastern section of the courtyard.  On the northwest wall there is evidence of plaster.  The courtyard of the peristyle is framed by bricked columns resting on a low wall.  The northeast section of the courtyard which is said to be covered by a pergola contains the altar for sacrifice.  On the top of the northwest and southwest walls are rows of joist holes.  The nine remaining holes on the northwestern wall are equidistant and could have supported the roof of the peristyle porticus.  The eight remaining joist holes on the southwestern wall are more irregular in shape and distance between each other.  (The southwestern section of room 3 has been recorded in a Minority Report as Room 15.  See Minority Report for more detail.)  The central open space of the peristyle is covered by vegetation (bushes, trees, and grass) while the surrounding porticus is covered with lapilli.  The area containing the altar faces the main entrance to 2.1.12 (room 1).
Negative feature sheet.  Identified as a dining room based on the location, size, and wall paintings.  Back of the room is filled, walled, and terraced.

column14: Space (2) on the northwest; kitchen (4) on the south.
column15: Space (2) on the northwest; kitchen (4) on the south.
column21: Dining room (5) shows a double entrance.  The bigger one opens onto space (2) to the southwest.  This entrance was closed by a door, as the stone threshold and the three door jams on it show.  The rectangular room is on a northeast/southwest axis.  The walls were decorated with 4th style painting.  The lower part of the walls were painted with a black register.  This register on the northeast wall shows traces of green, white and yellow plants.  On the same wall, above the black zone, is a green and yellow band framing the middle part of the wall.  No trace of painting has survived except two red bands which were used as frames.  On the other part of the wall runs a frieze framed by marble molding which continues running onto the two adjoining walls.  The walls are preserved in their height but the wooden ceiling is of modern construction.  There are a few traces of cocciopesto floor by the main entrance. On the southern corner is a smaller door opening onto the kitchen (4).

column14: None
column21: In the north corner of the northeast wall there is a built-in niche which was used for inserting the couch.  This feature was covered by a layer of plaster which is preserved only on the upper part.  Along the lower part is a stone structure (like a low platform) which is interrupted by the adjoining northeast wall.

column14: Corridor (three) to the southeast; peristyle (six) to the south west; kitchen-latrine to the north.
column15: Corridor (three) to the southeast; peristyle (six) to the south west; kitchen-latrine to the north.
column21: Dining room 8 is entered from the east corner of the southeast wall corridor three which connects open spaces two and six on either side of the room. The  rectangular room lies along the northeastern/southwestern axis.  The southwestern side of the dining room was pierced by a large window looking out onto the peristyle which is ornamented with a pool.  The corners of this pool are occupied by columns which are not in situ any longer.  The room is covered by a modern wooden roof sloping down towards the peristyle.  The floor was decorated with opus signinum (orthogonal grid pattern of white squared tesserae).

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1071-1072

column14: Atrium (2) to the northeast; dining room (8) to the east; peristyle (6) to the south.
column15: Atrium (2) to the northeast; dining room (8) to the east; peristyle (6) to the south.
column21: Kitchen (9) lies in the western corner of atrium area two.  The room is not accessible today because of a modern locked door.  It is being used as a store room.  However, on the western side are the remains of a cooking platform and a possible latrine that are visible.  This is confirmed also in the description of the house by Eschebach and in PPM.  On the wall opposite the entrance door is a small rectangular window looking out on peristyle six.  A modern wooden roof is sloping down southwards.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1071-1072

column14: Room 2 to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen lies in the southwest part of the house. One enters the kitchen through a door in the northeast corner from the east. The floor is at a level lower than room 2. To the southeast is a latrine and abutting the latrine to the southwest is a cooking platform. The walls are stuccoed and somewhat elaborately decorated. The layout of the kitchen is indeterminate. The floor seems to be of a beaten cement. High on the southwest wall above the cooking platform there are two openings that may have been windows in antiquity.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.

column14: Latrine (2125) to the northeast.
column21: The cooking platform is located in the south corner abutting the southeast and southwest walls. There is an arched storage area beneath which had a shelf raised above the floor by approximately 6 inches. The surface of the cooking platform is divided into two parts. On the northeast side there is flat surface made up of flat stones embedded in cement with a lip along the southeast wall whose surface slopes toward the front. The southwest portion of the cooking platform, and the larger part, is built up higher than the first part. It is possible that the entire cooking surface had been built up and that the northeast portion has fallen away. A wall on the northeast side separates the cooking platform from the latrine. The walls were stuccoed but no evidence of painting remains.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol.  1038-1039.
