column14: Cooking platform (2736) to west; triclinium (2733) to southwest; water basin (2739) to southwest; water pool (2735) to southwest.
column16: Cooking platform (2736) to west; triclinium (2733) to southwest; water basin (2739) to southwest; water pool (2735) to southwest.
column21: The raised edge of the square hearth is covered by convex red tiles on the southern, eastern and western sides.  From the northern corner of the hearth runs a low stone bench along the northwestern wall of processing room (3). The hearth lies in the northeast corner between the north wall of processing room (3) and the east perimeter wall of space (2) off the street.

column14: Atrium/reception (2) to west
column21: We enter kitchen through a door in western corner of the atrium/reception area.  This is a narrow rectangular space on a northwest/southeast axis.  This is a kitchen with elaborate decorations.  Perhaps open to public.  Floor is lapilli.  Newly plastered with lower register of yellow.  Upper register of white.  Southeast wall show red stenciling on sides and pale green color in areas.  Cornice molding on southeast wall.  The reason for kitchen designation is presence of two arched niches.  No ceiling.  In the room between the two arches is a place for cupboard niche higher tan both arched storage niches.  Amphora were left in situ.  Ceiling no longer extant.

column14: Shelf Niche (2702) to the southeast; Amphora (2704) to the northwest; Cupboard niche (2703) to the southeast; Amphora (2705) to south.
column16: Shelf Niche (2702) to the southeast;Amphora (2704) to the northwest; Cupboard niche (2703) to the southeast; Amphora (2705) to south.
column21: The large arched cupboard plastered with red & yellow with amphora in situ.  Lower level stenciling.

column14: Cupboard (2701) to the northwest; Amphora (2704) to the northwest; Amphora (2705) to the southwest; Cupboard (2703) to the southeast
column16: Cupboard (2701) to the northwest; Amphora (2704) to the northwest; Amphoria (2705) to the southwest;Cupboard (2703) to the southeast
column21: Shelf Niche.  Post and lintel shelf niche with 3 clearly indicated indentation for shelves.  The niche shows new plaster yellow and white and cream.

column14: shelf niche (2702) to the northwest; Cupboard  (2701)to the northwest; Amphora (2705) to the southwest; Amphora (2704) to the northwest
column16: shelf niche (2702) to the northwest; Cupboard  (2701)to the northwest;Amphora (2705) to the southwest; Amphoria (2704) to the northwest
column21: Southeast arched niche.  It is plastered without detail of other niches.  This only shows cream beige plaster.  This storage niche received little attention.

column14: Peristyle (6) to the southwest; Bedroom (8) to the southeast
column15: Peristyle (6) to the southwest; Bedroom (8) to the southeast
column21: Dining room (9) lies in the northeast corner of house to the east of the peristyle.  One enters the dining room from through a doorway in the southeast corner.  The room is rectangular in shape on a roughly northeast to southwest orientation.  The height of the ceiling is indeterminate.  The floor is of cocciopesto with multicolored stones with a simple mosaic surrounding a centered panel.  The walls are painted in 4th style.  In the center of each wall is a panel.  The last preserved panel is on the southeast wall.  The southwest wall has a large window that opens onto the peristyle (6).  In the northwest corner, abutting the northwest and southwest wall, is a low hearth.

column14: Room 2 to SE; Storeroom (2801) to the SE
column15: Room 2 to SE; Storeroom (2801) to the SE
column21: One enters the room from the NW through a large doorway; most of the doorway on the northeast is blocked by the counter. The room is roughly square in shape. The northeastern part of the room is taken up by the L-shaped counter. High on the southwestern wall in the southern corner is a lararium. The walls of the room were stuccoed and painted, as indicated by remains on the southwestern wall. The floor is indeterminate. The height of the ceiling is reconstructed. In the southern corner of the southeastern wall is a large doorway leading to Room 2. In the eastern corner of the southeastern wall is a large window looking into the storeroom, (Room 3 (2801)).

column14: None
column21: A low bench (for dining?) abuts the northeastern wall, southwest of the entrance of the shop. The bench is rectangular in shape on a southwest/northeast axis. As reconstructed, the surface of the bench is square tiles. There is no evidence of stucco or decoration.

column14: Lararium (2804) to the south
column21: The L-shaped counter is located in the northeast part of the room, slightly inside. The short arm to the northwest runs parallel to the sidewalk on a northeast/southwest axis. On the northeast end of the short arm there is a step shelf, which has three steps. The top two steps extend to the northwest wall of the shop. The bottom step extends only to the exterior side of the short arm. All three steps extend into the exterior of the shop to the southeast, beyond the interior wall of the short arm. The long arm, perpendicular to the short arm, extends about 3/4 of the way into the interior of the shop on a northwest/southeast axis. Embedded in the long arm, just before it meets the short arm, is a small dolium. At the base on the exterior, (northwest and southwest) sides of the L-shaped counter appears to be a step on a higher level than the floor. At the southeast end of the long arm is a hearth, the width of which is wider than that of the long arm. The hearth is roughly rectangular in shape, on a northwest/southeast axis. The floor of the hearth is higher than that of the room. The cooking platform is defined by a U-shaped construction opening to the southeast. As extant, the cooking platform is on a slightly lower level than the long arm. The L-shaped counter was stuccoed and painted red. There is no evidence of color and decoration on the hearth. The step shelves are constructed of cement and brick, while the surface of the L-shaped counter employs fragments of tile and stone rubble. On the interior face of the short arm of the north corner, below the step shelves, is a recess that may have supported a dolium.

column14: Storage Room (2801) to the northwest; Dining Room (2802) to the northeast, Hall (2) to the southwest
column15: Storage Room (2801) to the northwest; Dining Room (2802) to the northeast, Hall (2) to the southwest
column21: We enter the rectangular kitchen from a southwestern door. The floor is cement and broken tesserae, and the floor to the northern side of the cooking platform becomes soil. There is evidence of plaster on the southeastern wall, which is painted white with signs of red. The kitchen is open in the southwest to the hallway (2) where it opens with a huge window to the street. The cooking platform is unusual in that it has two components: the southwestern wall component is lower and has a tiled top; the northeastern component is higher and wider with a tiled top. Over the soil portion, next to the platform on the northeast wall is a small, indented, oblong niche which was probably for a lamp. There is no ceiling or window over the platform; the street window in the hall would have provided ventilation.

column14: None
column21: The feature in this kitchen that identifies the space is the cooking platform, which is located against the southeast wall. The platform is unusual in that it has two components: the southeast wall component is lower and has a tiled top; the northeast component joins the southeast component and is higher and wider, with a tiled surface.

column14: Counter room (2796) to the southwest; Hallway (2) to the southwest; Kitchen (2799) to the southeast
column15: Counter room (2796) to the southwest; Hallway (2) to the southwest; Kitchen (2799) to the southeast
column21: We enter the square storage room from the southwest, through a very small entrance from the hallway (2) which connects the counter room (2796) and the kitchen (2799). On the northwest wall there is a very large window to the counter room. The storeroom shows some plaster on the northeast and southeast walls and there is evidence of floor with some broken tesserae.

column14: Room 2 (corridor) to the west; Room 6 (dining room) to southeast; Room 4 (kitchen) to the west
column15: Room 2 (corridor) to the west; Room 6 (dining room) to southeast; Room 4 (kitchen) to the west
column21: Room five is a square room which opens from Room 2 (corridor) to the west and faces the entrance (2.1.13). The northwestern wall was decorated with paintings, of which some traces of red and yellow are extant. On the opposite wall to the southeast is the door and window which open to Room 6 (garden). The floor is covered with packed earth, under which there is evidence of cocciopesto. Further traces of red paint also appear on the lower zone of the northeastern and southeastern walls, while plaster covers the southern corner. To the east of the large window there is another window which is smaller and has a shelf that is covered with tiles. The ceiling is no longer extant. The northwest and northeast walls are preserved to the first floor height. Up to the northwestern wall is a square joist hole, roofed by a large tile, the function of which is difficult to ascertain. The large opening and location of this room, from which the street was visible (through the entrance), and the large window to the west along the same wall, make it likely that the room was used for public dining.

column14: Room 5 (dining room) to the north; Room 2 (corridor) to the northwest
column15: Room 5 (dining room) to the north; Room 2 (corridor) to the northwest
column21: Room 6 is entered from the western corner of the northwestern wall. The step by the entrance adjoins a large square stone slab, under which there runs an L-shaped water channel. The long side of the water channel runs along the entire length of the northwest wall, while the shorter section runs on the corner of the southwestern wall and is provided with a drain hole opening off the street. To the north of the entrance on the northwestern wall is a large window that looks out onto Room 5, (dining room). Below the window, the entire wall is covered with plaster and some traces of white painting. More traces of painting appear on the southern corner of the southeastern wall: A red band which could have framed a panel. Fragments of plaster are visible on the southeastern and northeastern walls. On the southwestern wall, next to the water channel, there is a cistern which is now covered by two stone blocks. The southern corner of the room is delimited by an L-shaped low wall. This was probably a covered room, as a row of 16 joist holes are on the southwest wall. They may have supported the ceiling of this room. Eschebach describes this space as a storeroom, (repositorium) though its location in a large area, the paintings, and the possible arrangement of a garden with the water channel, suggest that the walled space may have been used as a dining room with a nice vista onto the garden. High up in the southeastern wall, above the longer wall, delimiting the dining room is a glass window which appears to be modern. The ground is covered in vegetation. In the southern corner of the southeastern wall there is evidence of a door which was walled up and covered with painting. The southeastern wall is preserved at a two-story height, while the southwestern wall is preserved at a one-story height. In the southeastern wall there is a stone block supporting an upright stone block that juts out from the wall. It is difficult to ascertain the function of this.

column14: None
column21: High on the southwestern wall, in the southern corner, is a small lararium. On page 85, Eschebach reports that the lararium was dedicated to Venus, and contained a gold pseudo-alabaster statue of Venus.

column14: Room 2 (Atrium) to the southeast; Storeroom (2817) to the south; Room 1 (Fauces) to the northeast
column15: Room 2 (Atrium) to the southeast; Storeroom (2817) to the south; Room 1 (Fauces) to the northeast
column21: The square counter room is entered from the street, (through a large entrance to the northwest) over a step which is now approximately 30 cm high. The stone threshold shows the door guide. The room has one more entrance to the southeast. The smaller door connects the shop with the atrium of the house (2.2.2). On the southwestern wall is a large rectangular window which looks out onto a side street. To the south of this window is a storeroom (17). To the southwest of the entrance into the atrium is a flight of stairs which leads up to a missing second floor. Four stone steps are extant. On the northeastern wall is a lararium (2816). On the opposite side, in the western corner of the room, is the L-shaped counter (2815). On the western corner of the shop are traces of red painting. More evidence of painting is visible on the northwestern wall near the entrance door. The northern sections of the northwestern and northeastern walls are preserved to the second story. There is evidence of two joist holes and plaster in the northern corner of the northeastern wall. The southeastern and southwestern walls have been restored to the first story level. The ceiling is no longer extant and the floor is covered with lapilli.

column14: Lararium (2816) to the east
column21: The L-shaped counter, which has been heavily restored, runs from the western corner of the room. It contains two embedded dolia on the northeastern/longer counter. The dolium in the northern corner is mostly preserved with is partly high, thick rim. The presence of the southern dolium is only suggested by the hole.

column14: A water feature and garden (room 6) is to the southwest.  Room 4 (hallway) is to the southwest.  Room 5 (dining room) is to the northeast.
column15: A water feature and garden (room 6) is to the southewest.  Room 4 (hallway) is to the southwest.  Room 5 (dining room) is to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is at the southeast corner of the building. We enter the kitchen from the northwest through the small hallway (Room 6) around a garden.  There is no evidence of a door.  The floor is covered with lapilli.  The southeast wall shows some evidence of plaster.  The northeast wall has been heavily reconstructed. There is no ceiling.  On the southeast wall we see a water drain which runs into a water feature around the garden.  On the northwest wall we see remains of a masonry support for a cooking platform.  Any form of a platform is missing.  Next to the masonry support to the northeast are sings of a wall which separates the platform from the latrine.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Masonry supports for a cooking platform (2779) are to the northwest.
column16: Masonry supprots for a cooking platform (2779) are to the northwest.
column21: The floor between the cooking platform and the latrine shows demarcation by a threshold in terra cotta on a northeast/southeast axis.  One enters to a slightly sloping floor of a latrine.  The latrine shows two masonry supports for the seat.  You can see the drain on the northeast wall at the floor going outside.  The latrine is located in the northeast corner of the room.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room 2 is to the northwest.  Room 6 is to the southwest. Room 7 is to the southeast.  Room 4 is to the west.
column15: Room 2 is to the northwest.  Room 6 is to the southwest. Room 7 is to the southeast.  Room 4 is to the west.
column21: Room 5 is located in the eastern corner of the northeast side of the entrance (1.21.3).  It is entered through two doors.  The taller door to the northwest opens into Room 2.  The door to the southwest opens into Room 6 (courtyard).  This rectangular room extends along a northwest/southeast axis.  The dining room may be divided into two spaces.  The smaller space is by the northwest entrance. The larger space lays on a few centimeters high platform.  The step up to the larger space is decorated with the base of a column in the northern corner. The walls were painted as there are traces of white and red painting on the southwestern and northeastern walls.  The larger painted fragment on the south western wall shows rectangular panels framed by a red band and separated from each other by a band containing a row of white "v" shaped symbols.  On the northeastern wall is a rectangular window about two meters from the ground which looks out onto the street.  On the northeastern wall, below the window, five rows of bricks run along the entire wall.  The walls have been preserved to the first story level.  The ceiling is non-extant. The floor is covered with lapilli.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room 2 (Preparation Room 2787) is to the northwest.  The garden/water feature (room 6) is to the southeast. The hallway (Room 4) is to the northeast.
column15: Room 2 (Preparation Room 2787) is to the northwest.  The garden/water feature (room 6) is to the southeast. The hallway (Room 4) is to the northeast.
column21: We enter this dining room from the northwest from the preparation room (2787) through a large and high doorway.  It is a square room with a very large window in the southeast wall to the garden/water area.  It is contiguous to a hallway (Room 4) that ends with a kitchen.  The floor is covered with lapilli.  Of the four walls of the dining room, the north wall shows third style decorations in Pompeiian red and ivory and the lowest zone is a peach color with Pompeiian red splatters throughout all areas of the lower zone.  There is no ceiling.  The west wall has minimal plaster and the south wall has a huge window.  The window is surrounded by a peach and Pompeiian red frame.  The east wall again shows the splatter on the lower zone.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: None
column21: The counter is in the northwest part of the room.  It is rectangular in shape and lies roughly on a northeast/southwest axis.  As extant today, only the foundation remains.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: None
column21: In the west end of Room 10 is an L-shaped bench.  The long arm, rectangular in shape, lies on a roughly north/south axis and abuts the west wall.  The short arm, abutting the south wall lies on a roughly east/west axis.  The east end of the short arm extends slightly beyond the entrance to the counter room (Room 9)(2783). The exterior of the L-shaped bench was in antiquity covered in stucco and probably painted (traces remain) but the top surface is indeterminate.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room 4 (dining room) is to the northwest.  Room 7 (processing room) is to the south.  Room 2 (fauces) is to the west.  Room 5 (vineyard) is to the south/southeast.
column15: Room 4 (dining room) is to the northwest.  Room 7 (processing room) is to the south.  Room 2 (fauces) is to the west.  Room 5 (vineyard) is to the south/southeast.
column21: As the excavation has not been fully carried out, Room 6 will be described as a large single unit, although scattered traces of walls show that this space was divided into smaller spaces.  In fact, on the northwestern side, opposite Room 4 (dining room), there is evidence of a low wall framed by five columns which seem to belong to the peristyle.  A number of huge dolia have been found in this space; however, as they are mostly not embedded it is difficult to locate them to a specific space.  Three medium sized dolia rest on the ground to the northwest.  They are mostly well preserved.  The rim of two dolia are half preserved.  In the middle of what appears to be the central courtyard of the peristyle (close to the northwest colonnade wall) there is evidence of a huge embedded dolium but only the base of the dolium is preserved.  In the southwestern corner six big dolia are mostly embedded in the construction of a modern wall above which are some casts of victims on display.  For what is visible today they are in very good condition.  Two dolia still show their huge rims.  More dolia are visible in the eastern corner; however, as they are in a fragmented state it is difficult to ascertain if they were embedded (like the small fragments in the middle of this corner suggest) or resting against the wall (like two broken halves of dolia appear today).  The northeastern wall of this corner shows traces of painting on the lower zone while a low wall in the eastern side suggests the perimeter of this space.  This L-shaped space of this entire room is situated on a northwest/northeast axis.  The two walls bounding this room to the northeast and southwest are preserved to first story height.  The northeast wall is framed by supporting pillars and shows some traces of painting.  Three of the dolia show signs of repair along the bodies of the containers.  It is debatable if they are modern or ancient repairs.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column14: Supports for a wooden platform (2745) to the southwest.
column16: Supports for a wooden platform (2745) to the southwest.
column21: The latrine lies in the north corner of the northwest wall, leaving a small space between its southwest wall and the northwest masonry support for the wooden platform (2745).  The southwest wall of the latrine is taller than the northwest masonry support of the wooden platform.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1071-1072

column14: Room 5 (2791) is to the southeast.
column21: The processing room lies in the middle of the structure approximately one half way between the entrance to the house and the garden though not on a direct axis with the entrance.  One enters the room from the southeast.  If this is as is supposed, a room for treading or pressing grapes (torcularium), there would not have been a door per se but probably wooden steps.  The room is rectangular in shape, on a southwest/northeast axis.  The floor has not been excavated, nor can the original height of the walls be determined.  The walls were stuccoed and appear to be painted, probably red.  The floor level was above the level of the room to the southeast (Room 5 - 2791).  The identification of the room as a processing room is based on the construction of a masonry foundation for a terracotta vessel located on the outside of the southeast wall.  A lead pipe, still in situ, drained the liquid (must) from the room into the terracotta vessel (small dolium) embedded in the masonry and floor.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1092

column21: This dining room is rectangular and has a marble threshold. There was a door on the south wall. Post and lintel door. Black and white tesserae on the floor. Large window on east wall. South wall has robber hole. Nicely decorated in the third or fourth style. There is an arched ceiling.

column14: The latrine (2870) is to the northeast.
column16: The latrine (2870) is to the northeast.
column21: This masonry support for a cooking platform is on the northwest wall with space for plenty of storage between the two supports. This would have had a marble or wooden platform that does not exist.  The northern (second) support abuts a short wall that would separate the support from the latrine.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room 10 (serving room) is to the northwest. Room 2 (prep room) is to the south.
column15: Room 10 (serving room) is to the northwest. Room 2 (prep room) is to the south.
column21: One enters the counter room from room 10 (serving room) to the northwest.  The counter, parallel with room 10 (serving room), takes up much of the doorway.  Access to Room 9 is in the northeast part of the entrance.  The room is roughly square and has a doorway to Room 2 (prep room) in the middle of the south wall. The walls were stuccoed and painted in a simple design.  The height of the ceiling is indeterminate.  The floor seems to be of a beaten cement.  The counter falls on a northeast/southwest axis, the southwest end abutting the west corner of the southwestern wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: L-shaped bench ( 2785) to west.
column21: At the east end of room ten abutting the south and east walls is a rectangular bench on a roughly east/west axis. The exterior of the bench was in antiquity covered in stucco and probably painted but the top surface is indeterminate.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room 9 (shop) (2783) is to the northwest.  Room 1 (fauces) is to the northwest.  Room 4 (corridor) is to the southwest.  Room 8 (dining room)(2782) is to the southwest.    Room 5 (dining room) (2781) is to the southeast. Room 3 is to the north.
column15: Room 9 (shop) (2783) is to the northwest.  Room 1 (fauces) is to the northwest.  Room 4 (corridor) is to the southwest.  Room 8 (dining room)(2782) is to the southwest.    Room 5 (dining room) (2781) is to the southeast. Room 3 is to the north.
column21: Room 2 is entered from Room 1 (fauces) and Room 9 (shop) both of which are to the northwest.  The main axis of this irregularly rectangular room is southwest/northeast.  The walls were painted as traces of plaster and red painting shows on the walls.  On the northeastern wall there are five rectangular joist holes running above five rows of bricks that run the length of the wall.  On the top of the same wall is a rectangular window which lies about one third of a meter above the joist holes.  Today the floor is covered by lapilli.  The large room contains, in the northern corner, four stone stairs leading up to a missing floor.  On the eastern corner is an irregularly shaped pile of stones leaning against the wall, the function of which is unknown.  The room also contains a hearth (2788) on the northwestern side.  This feature leads us to define this space as a preparation room though the big size suggests that this space could have been used for purposes other than cooking.  The ceiling is non-extant.  There appears to be a blocked door and a blocked window (above the door) on the southwestern wall.  The walls exist to the first floor height.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column21: The hearth leans against the northwestern wall of room two. It is situated between the entrances into room nine (shop) and room one ( fauces). It is a U-shaped brick structure in the middle of which is a hole for the fire. The open end of the U FACES South. The top layer of the hearth is tiled.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Counter room nine (2783) to the south, room one to the south.
column15: Counterroom nine (2783) to the south, room one to the south.
column21: The serving room is rectangular in shape and on an roughly east/west axis across the full width of the north part of the house and extends into the street. The serving room, as is the rest of the house, is a lower level than the outside street. One enters room ten from the north by way of a step on axis with entrance four. In the west end is an L-shaped bench (2785), the long arm abuts the west wall while the short arm abuts the south wall and extends slightly beyond the entrance to counter room (2793) to the east. At the east end of the room abutting the south and east wall is a rectangular bench (2786) on an east/west axis. The interior walls of the room including benches and step were once covered with stucco and were probably painted ( traces remain).  There is no indication that the northeast and west walls extended beyond a few inches of the level of the street. Floor is indeterminate.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1086

column14: Room eight to the southwest, room 16 to the southeast (2813)
column15: Room eight to the southwest, room 16 to the southeast (2813)
column21: The triclinium is located behind and to the northeast of the atrium. The room is roughly square and has two entrances.: one from the southwest, the second larger one from the southeast. The latter overlooks the large fountain. The floor appears to originally have been of a smooth beaten cement.  A lower ceiling has been reconstructed such that it covers the northeast side of the room. In antiquity and as reconstructed today, the entire room had a ceiling a little higher than the lower one. In the center of the anterior façade of the lower ceiling, in stucco, was a small arch. In the north corner, the lower two thirds of the northwest wall has been so constructed as to connect directly with the northeast wall thereby covering the north corner. The walls were stuccoed and elaborately painted. On all four walls the lower zone is painted to represent a series of large panels of colored marble. The upper zone is difficult to describe as very little remains. Above the lower zone on all four walls is a light green band decorated with figures of soldiers and a cart; Achilles and the Trojan war including Achilles dragging the body of Hector. Above this band is a much larger band showing large human figures depicting Hercules and his expedition against Laomedon.

The biclinium lies on the northeast end of room 16 (2813). The couches lie on the northwest and southeast sides of the euripus which extends back to the aedicular fountain. Each couch slopes back and down from the euripus. The left couch has on its southwest and southeast sides a lip. The right couch has a lip on its southwest and northwest sides. The euripus extends to the southwest to just in front of the zoothecula. The walls of the euripus were painted in blue.  The aedicular fountain at the back is composed of two columns in front with Corinthian capitals supporting tympaneum. The back part is a large niche. At the bottom is a base perhaps for a statue. The niche is decorated to appear as a rocky façade with a design in dark blue arula and red tesserae at the top of which are sea creatures. On the back wall on either side of the fountain  is a painting in red with flowers at the base. A large panel painting on the right to the southeast is of Thisbe and Pyramus. The panel painting on the left or to the northwest is of Narcissus. The Euripus which extends to the southwest is bordered in marble and was probably opened to the sky in antiquity. Columns on the northwest side impinge upon this marble border. Two small bridges cross the Euripes, one just in front of the biclinium, and the second in front of the doorway to the triclinium (2811) to the northwest.

column14: Counter (2815) is to the West.
column21: On the northeastern wall of room is a large rectangular niche. The walls are plastered and the shelf shows traces of cocciopesto. The niche was probably used as a lararium as the Pompeian shops are usually provided with this kind of religious feature.

column14: Latrine (2746) to the northeast.
column21: In the west corner of the northwest wall of the kitchen are two masonry supports for a wooden platform, probably for cooking or food preparation.  The west support abuts the southwest wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 1071-1072

column14: Room two to the southwest.
column21: The triclinium is located in the northeast side of the atrium, room two, on axis with the impluvium. One enters the triclinium from the southwest through a tall doorway.  The room is rectangular in shape on a southeast/northwest axis. The threshold to the room is at a higher level than the floor of the atrium and the floor of the triclinium. A modern ceiling is constructed in such a way that it pitches steeply from the southwest to the northeast with six modern openings. As reconstructed there appears to have been two large windows on each of three sides: the southeast, northeast, and northwest. The walls were plastered and decorated in the fourth style, much of which remains. The floor, though heavily damaged, seems to be decorated of a beaten cement and stones.

44 embedded amphorae were found along the eastern edge of the garden. Della Corte and Spinazzola mentioned as reference but no citation provided. Spinazzola states that the amphorae were used for storing wine. Della Corte, by contrast argues that they were used as water containers for the worship of Isis.

column14: Room 4 to the northwest; Room 6 to the south; Room 7 to the southwest
column15: Room 4 to the northwest; Room 6 to the south; Room 7 to the southwest
column21: Room 5 is square and is entered from room 4 to the northwest. Opposite the entrance on the southeastern wall is a window looking out onto room 6. The window ledge is tiled. In the northern corner of the room beginning about 50 centimeters off the ground is a recess about 50 centimeters wide and 50 centimeters deep. The walls of this recess along with the four walls of the room show evidence of plaster. The room is preserved to the first floor height. Lapilli covers the ground. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Room 4 to the northwest; Room 5 to the northeast; Room 6 to the southeast
column15: Room 4 to the northwest; Room 5 to the northeast; Room 6 to the southeast
column21: The rectangular room is situated on a northwest/southeast axis. It is entered from the northwest by room 4 and opens onto room 6 to the southeast. The walls are preserved to the first story. No plaster is extant. The floor is covered with cocciopesto. The kitchen shows evidence of a cooking platform to the southwest and a lararium to the southeast. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Lararium (2831) to the northeast
column21: One 20 centimeter high stone structure juts out from the southwest wall almost in the middle of the room. To the west of this jutting stone structure there remains a low base which is as long as and is parallel to the stone structure. The two structures may have supported a platform for cooking. The floor between the two framing supports shows patches of cocciopesto.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Cooking Platform (2830) to the southwest.
column21: The lararium is a small, semicircular niche pierced into the middle of the northeastern wall of the kitchen. The inner walk of the niche shows traces of red painting. At the base of the niche is a large, tiled ledge that juts out from the wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: None
column21: The square stone altar is about one meter high and 2/3 of a meter wide. The altar is in the central court of the Room 3 towards the northern corner. The stone alter is interspersed with long rectangular bricks. The altar is placed on a straight axis between the fauces and Room 4 (where the priest probably started the ceremony).

column8: Turcan, R., ‘Sabazios à Pompéi’ in Ercolano 1738-1988. 25 Anni di ricerca archeologica (Rome, 1993) 499-512.
Pace, R., ‘Il Complesso dei Riti Magici a Pompei II, 1, I, 1-2’ in Rivista di Studi Pompeiani 8 (1997) 73-98.
Pace, R., ‘Il Complesso dei Riti Magici a Pompei II, 1, I, 1-2’ in Rivista di Studi Pompeiani 8 (1997) 73-98.
Laforge-Charles, M-O., ‘Le “complexe des rites magiques” et le culte de Sabazios à Pompéi’ in Contributi di Archeologia Vesuviana II (L’Erma di Bretschneider, 2006)161-184.

column14: Room 3 to the northwest; Room 14 to the southwest; Room 11 to the southeast; Room 9 to the northeast.
column15: Room 3 to the northwest; Room 14 to the southwest; Room 11 to the southeast; Room 9 to the northeast.
column21: Room 10 is entered by one step down from two entrances located on opposite sides directly facing each other to the northwest and southeast. It is a long rectangular room which is along a northeast/southwest axis. The area is divided in two differently sized spaces. The longer side to the northeast lays on a platform about twenty centimeters above the lower, shorter side. This space, which was used to hold dining couches, is floored with an octagonal grid of white marble poised squares. What is left today is seven rows of poised squares. The three walls (northwest, northeast, southeast) have plaster fragments with small traces of red and black painting. They are preserved to the first floor height. The ceiling is not extant, but a modern reconstruction is present. The lower section of Room 10, which lies to the southwest of the couch area is more open space as it contains two entrances; one to the northwest and one to the southeast. The room has a very large square window looking out on to Room 11 to the southwest. The step to the platform of the dining area was painted in black and red but today only small fragments remain. The walls were also decorated. The southern section of the southeastern wall shows a large white panel divided by slightly recessed red bands. On the opposite wall, to the northwest, there are again traces of white painted panels with slightly recessed red bands. The lower register was divided into two bands of different colors: black and red. On the western wall in the southwestern corner there is evidence of a blocked door which has traces of plaster at the bottom. The walls are preserved to the first story. The floor is made of cocciopesto with some white marble poset squares inserted in the middle of the room toward the large window. However, as this area is accessed by a raised wooden platform it is not possible to discern if this decoration continues. The ceiling of today in Room 10 is covered by a modern wooden roof supported by four corner posts situated in each corner of the couch area with two more placed outside the walls of the room as the southwestern end.

column21: Room 13 is entered from Room 11 to the northeast. A square pillar to the southwest seems to divide the cooking area from the adjoining Room 14 (courtyard). Opposite the pillar, to the northeast, is a very large square window looking out onto Space 11. The area contains a cooking platform to the southeast which extends along the whole length of the wall. The walls appear to have been reconstructed. The pillar suggests the presence of some kind of roofing which doesn't exist any longer. Because of its location, the kitchen was easily accessible from a number of rooms (Room 10, 11, 14). Through Room 14, the kitchen could have been entered by a door from the street (2.1.11) There is evidence of stucco and painting on the southern corner of the southeastern wall over the end of the cooking platform.

column21: Minority Report: We enter this long space for religious banquets from the southwest. It is currently a roofed area. Floor is lapilli. There are high walls on the northwest side. The northeast opens to an altar and a dining room, The southeast wall has a door to the large dining hall. There is also a rectangular lararium niche. In the west corner of the space we find dining room (Room 2). The space is bordered by two rounded and rectangular columns. Four columns also were within the space; two on either side (south and north) and was part of a colonnade.

column15: Sacred Space (2841) to the southwest; Room 6 to the northwest; Room 7 to the southeast.
column21: Minority Report: This is a sanctuary with a large dining room. We enter the room from the southwest behind the altar and altar space. We see a threshold of one half foot with evidence of a door. There is marble and terracotta emblema on the floor. The northeast wall has a storage platform. This platform could be used as a dining bench or as an altar. Two pitchers were found on the platform as well as a sacrificing tool, the hand of Sabatius. The northeast wall, southeast entrance and northwest entrance show plastered walls in red and yellow. The northwestern side of the dining room extends into an open rectangular room which shows red and yellow 3rd style painting with red and white stencil work. The southeast wall has a door opening to a room and an other southwest door opening to the sacred alter space.

column14: Dining Room (2871) to the northwest; Dining Room (2824) to the southwest; Dining Garden (2825) to the southeast; Room 8 to the southwest.
column15: Dining Room (2871) to the northwest; Dining Room (2824) to the southwest; Dining Garden (2825) to the southeast; Room 8 to the southwest.
column21: One enters the room from the northwest through Room 8. The room is rectangular in shape on a northeast/southwest axis. The southeast side of the room is defined by a series of pillars, eight in number, on axis. The northeast end of the room is defined by the biclinium with fountain. The southwest end is delimited by the zoothecula (possible dining room). The northwest side is defined by a wall painted to represent three large windows looking on to an expanse containing wild animals (paradeisoi). On the northwest side abutting on the euripus is a series of columns supporting a roof, creating a covered colonnade. In the center is a long rectangular euripus on axis running from just in front of the zoothecula all the way to the biclinium between the two couches. The area between the pillars and the columns was probably unroofed in antiquity. Two small bridges cross the euripus, just in front of the doorway to the triclinium (2871). To the southeast of the second bridge is the platform forming the front part of a large fountain overlooking the sunken garden. The floor is of beaten cement.

column21: Room 17 open at the back of Room 15 to the south. It is a small rectangular room along a southwest/northeast axis. Excavation reports mention stairs to the southwest of the entrance but what is visible today is only crumbled foundation sloping down to the northeast. The heavily restored walls (south east and southwest) preserved to the first story. The northwestern wall of the storeroom has been reconstructed to about two meters high. The ceiling is no longer extant. The floor is covered with lapilli. No evidence of plaster remains

column14: None
column21: The high bench, approximately 50 centimeters high) runs along the northwest wall of the shop (2.1.1) off the street. The top of the bench is tiled. Because of it close proximity to the shop the bench was probably used by the customers of the same shop; however the bench continues along the northeastern wall of the fauces of the house (2.2.2). It is an L shaped bench overall. Another bench is situated on the opposite (northeast) wall. Both the L-shaped bench to the northeast were used by the clients awaiting to greet the master of the house during the morning ritual salutatio. Once the ritual was completed, the same benches may have been used by the customers of the adjoining shop.

column14: Atrium to the south; Passage entry to the southwest; Room with oven to the east.
column15: Atrium to the south; Passage entry to the southwest; Romm with oven to the east.
column21: Minority Report: This shop is reported by many people, including Eschebach to be a popina, which is a term for a food shop. It has a large entrance to the northwest with evidence of the ability for closure. There is a large step up. Eschebach reports the remains of an imprint of a wooden counter. We see a lapilli floor. The shop has been decorated with red paint on the walls in Pompeiian red. The room is open to the sky. On the southeastern corner there is evidence of a cubiculum with door opening to it at the southeast corner of the shop. On the southeast wall, center, there is a water basin feature. The owner of the shop was Athictus, as shown in two programata (CIL IV 7523, 7545). We have a lararium on the northeast wall; a rectangular shrine with a ledge and cream background with red border in stencils. On the southeast wall, two steps up to a small door. We see a contiguous room with a highly unusual oven. On the southeast wall there is an opening to the atrium to the house and to the east of the opening there are stairs to a second floor. The southwest wall has a rectangular lararium, high up, with a ledge although no paint or plaster remain. There are four niches, plastered and arched, above the lararium. This shop has an entrance (2.2.3) to the street, but this project combines this shop with structure of house as entrance to house (2.2.2).

The southeastern wall behind has stucco painted red.

column14: Peristyle to the north; cubiculum to the northwest; biclinium room to the northeast; garden to the southeast.
column15: Peristyle to the north; cubiculum to the northwest; biclinium room to the northeast; garden to the southeast.
column21: We enter this elegant dining room from the south corner of the peristyle. There is an engaged column in the south wall. We can also enter the dining room from the northeastern end of the biclinium room, From the vantage of the door to the biclinium room (long passage biclinium with water feature). We see an intact wall with concrete. We see 4th style decorations on all walls. The ceiling is in place and we see nine coffers and four of them are framed recesses bordered on red. Besides the two doorways, which have lovely views, we can see on the east wall a low rectangular window overlooking the garden. There is a platform before the garden. The bottom zone of the paintings are black with green stencils with gryphons. The next zone has a central panel on the southwestern wall that has been removed. On either side of all the panels are elongated, painted Vitruvian style columns. The top zone has a variety of immortals with attributes evident.

column8: Richardson, L., ‘Water Triclinia and Biclinia in Pompeii’ in R. I. Curtis (ed.) Studia Pompeiana & Classica in honor of Wilhelmina F. Jashemski (New Rochelle, 1988) 307.

column14: Room 16 to the northwest; Bounded on the remaining three sides by streets.
column15: Room 16 to the northwest; Bounded on the remaining three sides by streets.
column21: The extensive rectangular garden runs along the northwest/southeast axis. It is divided into halves by a long euripius which is decorated with an elegant fountain in the middle of the garden and a basin just southeast of the elegant fountain. The elegant fountain is covered by a pergola supported by four small brick columns. The basin is divided into  four unequally sized parts which is decorated by a small temple structure: Four short columns support a vaulted arch finally decorated with white vegetable motifs on a red background. The northwestern portion of the euripius is ornamented with a semicircular vaulted niche supported by four little steps. In the middle of this painted niche is a hole for spouting water. The informative panel says that "The fruit trees... were there in antiquity. The root holes of these original trees were found... There was a double row of smaller trees, which scholars at the time identified as quince and pomegranate trees. The garden was restored again more recently, planting beds of iris and acanthus along the edges...". The walls are heavily restored to a first floor height. The garden is accessible from the house through stairs on either side of the porticus in Room 16.  A street entrance (posticum 2.2.5) is situated at the opposite side of the space. This door gives easy access to the nearby amphitheater. This entrance into the garden is framed by a row of brink columns which support modern wooden beams. Excavation records mention the evidence for a masonry triclinium (2826) and amphorae (2827) which are no longer extant.

column8: Richardson, L., ‘Water Triclinia and Biclinia in Pompeii’ in R. I. Curtis (ed.) Studia Pompeiana & Classica in honor of Wilhelmina F. Jashemski (New Rochelle, 1988) 307.

column14: Room 15 (2807) to the southeast.
column21: One enters the counter room through entrance 6 to the northwest. The entrance is wide with approximately one half on the northeast being blocked by the counter. The entrance way has a stone threshold behind which the counter sits. The room is roughly square in shape with the counter taking up most of the northeast part. The service area behind the counter is on a higher level than the rest of the room. The floor of the counter room is at a lower level than Room 15 (2807) to the southeast. The height of the walls is indeterminate. The floor seems to have been made of stucco and fragments of terracotta and stone. As extant, there is no evidence for stucco on the walls.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: None
column21: The L shaped counter sits in the northeast part of the room. The short arm, without embedded amphora, sits just inside the threshold and lies on a southwest/northeast axis. The short arm ends just before the northeast end of the opening to the shop thereby leaving about a two foot opening between the northeast end of the short arm and the northeast wall of the room. The long arm joins the short arm at a right angle and runs on a northwest/southeast axis into the interior of the room about 80% of the depth of the room, At the southeast end of the long arm is a hearth which open to the northeast. as reconstructed the surface of the L-shaped counter is made of cement and fragments of white, gray and red marbles. The L-shaped counter shows no evidence plaster or decoration. The service area is on a higher level than the floor of the room and runs in a semicircular direction from the east corner of the hearth to the northeast wall about a foot from the southeast wall.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Counter room (2810) to the northwest; Garden (2808) to the southeast
column15: Counter room (2810) to the northwest; Garden (2808) to the southeast
column21: We enter this dining room from the northwest door from the counter room (2805) selling food and drink. There is one threshold 2 1/2 inches up from the shop floor and another raised threshold matches the floor of the dining room. The floor is concrete and terracotta fragments. In the north corner we see two steps that would have to curve to the northeast wall. There is a wide doorway to the garden (2808) on the southeast wall next to it. To the south is a window and there is little remaining of the southeast wall. The southwest wall is intact with a quarter showing plaster. The northwest wall in the corner shows the small portion of red and cream plaster. The northwest wall to the counter room is about half missing.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Dining room (2810) to the northwest; Rooms 8 and 12 to the southwest; The street to the northeast.
column15: Dining room (2810) to the northwest; Rooms 8 and 12 to the southwest; The street to the northeast.
column21: Room 11 is a large rectangular space oriented on a northwest/southeast axis. It is entered by a posticum to the northeast but it could also have been entered from shops Room 9 (2.1.5) and shops Room 14 (2.1.6) and through dining rooms 10 (2810) and 15 (2807) respectively. This space was once used as a passageway for carts to the possible stables (Room 12 and 13) to the southwest. The large opening of the posticum was partly walled later on. This space could be described as a generic courtyard, a definition that is preferable to the "garden" mentioned by Eschebach. In this space a number of amphorae were found but in the previous description of this area there is no mention of the extant location. The courtyard is framed by two large entrances to the southwest (the one to space 12; the other to space 8) and two more entrances to the northwest (Rooms 10 and 15). each of the entrances to Room 10 and 15 is also adjoined by a large window to the west of each doorway. Above each entrance to 12 and 8 is a large rectangular window. The walls to the southwest and northwest are mostly preserved in their first floor height, while the southeast and northwest are today two meters high. The floor is covered with vegetation and a bush is in the center of the room.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column21: Negative Feature: 30 wine amphorae; with the inscription "QTR" The location of the amphorae is not specified.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column14: Garden (2808) to the southeast; Shop to the northwest.
column15: Garden (2808) to the southeast; Shop to the northwest.
column21: Entering the dining room from the northwest through a shop that has a wide opening to the street. We are unprepared to say what happened within this shop. This dining room is square and has  a wide and high doorway on the northwest with a clearly defined threshold to the dining room. The threshold raises the floor about two inches above the unknown shop floor. The floor is concrete and tesserae. In the north corner there is a large staircase with three large steps apparent and the stairs have evidence of continuing up on the northeast wall. On the northeast wall you see large portions of 4th style painting. The lower register is black, middle zone is yellow, red and white/cream. On the southeastern wall there is a large entrance doorway to the garden almost duplicated in width to the garden windows. The 4th style painting continues on this wall with lower zone black and middle red and cream and yellow with stenciling. On the southwest wall, the 4th style painting continues the same colors. On the top zone appears to be a small architectural rectangular scenic painting. On the northwest wall that opens to the shop, the 4th style painting continues. This room is currently roofed with modern wooden ceiling. It is a comfortable room with cool breezes. There are no features evident except for painting a stairs.

column8: Pugliese, Pompei Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. , 5-6

column21: According to Eschebach, an ara compitalis lay to the right of entrance 2.4.1.  Nothing remains today, except perhaps the rock foundation.

column14: Building (2) to the northwest.
column21: The large vineyard lies to the north-northwest of the amphitheater.   One can enter the vineyard from a doorway (posticum) on the southeast side wall.  The vineyard shape is defined by a wall on all four sides; just inside the entrance  to the to the east is a masonry triclinium (2950).  In the northwest corner is a preparation building (2), where the grapes were crushed and the wine made.  To the southeast of the building and abutting it is another masonry triclinium (2951).  Today, the vineyard has been replanted, following the pattern of ancient roots discovered and plotted by Wilhelmina Jashemski.  According to Jashemski, in antiquity there were over 2000 vines arranged in rows.  In addition, there were 58 trees (probably fruit and nut trees).

column14: Masonry triclinium (2951) to the west.
column21: We enter a large vineyard (Foro Boario) at II V, formerly II VIII, through a columned aedicular lintel which duplicates the entrances of the palestra to the south east.  As we enter, we see rows of grapevines propped up by wooden supports and a double (wide) lane (north-south path) separating the vines on the west from the vines on the east.  Immediately to the south east, against the wall, we see an outdoor masonry triclinium.  Jashemski reports this triclinium at 1.medius 485 cm; 1.imus and 1.summus 450 cm;  table 60 cm x 130 cm.  The 3 corners - 2 to the north and one to the east - have poles that support a pergola that has a grapevine.

column14: Northwest corner of 2949 Masonry triclinium (2950) to the east.
column21: There is a u-shaped masonry triclinium facing north-northeast.  There are masonry couches with traces of plaster on the internal face with no extant description.  The surface is obscured by vegetation, however, there are possible traces of opus signinum.  The southeastern area slopes sharply to the external side.  Against the northwestern arm is a rectangular platform that has been added, with traces of an opus signinum surface.  Between the arms of the couches is a rectangular table of which the surface has not survived.  The walls to the west and south bear traces of plaster in which two registers are discernible.  Five amphora were reported by Jashemski along the extant face of the lectus summus.  She identifies these as supports for a pergola.  They are no longer extant.  A modern pergola has been planted.

column14: Cooking platform (2928) to the south.
column21: A water basin is attached to the northeast corner of the cooking platform.  All that is apparent is the bottom part of the dolium.

Entering from northeast door of the atrium, there is a marble threshold.  The room is rectangular with an east-west axis.  The floor is in good shape with black and white tessera.  What is unique about the floor, it is raised on the north and east sides covering about a third of the room.  The first step on the rise is marble.  Northwest is a huge window overlooking the peristyle with a small window above to the east.  Another large window with a smaller above looking at the orchard.  All four walls retain half of their decorations, bottom dado red with green plants.  The walls are divided into sections with red paint, architectural elements and beautiful blue paint.  Upper part has dragons, porpoises (leaping), griffon.  There have been many pictures removed.  The ceiling is a modern reconstruction.

Along the northeast wall of the impluvium (18) is a dining tabularium with a very large entrance.  A large modern cardboard rectangle, either a cover for the impluvium or a covering  for a floor mosaic in the center of the floor in the next room (18).  In the northeast wall is a large rectangular window with a small window above it to the orchard beyond.  The floor features white tessera with black borders.  There is some evidence of painting - the lower register black with yellow and red above - but little remains.  The ceiling is modern reconstruction.  The southeast wall is mostly missing in the center.

column14: Room 37 is contiguous to the peristyle to the north (room 39); a small unnumbered space to the west ( also discernible on to the peristyle); room 38 to the south and rooms 27 and 36 to the east.
column21: A large dining room with three entries. The dining room looks north on to the peristyle with fountain and piscina. On the north wall is the longest entry. Red and yellow plaster survives at the northwest corner and at the north east corner. All of the walls in this room survive only to the first story. The lintel is not original on the north wall. On the east wall in the north east corner is a service entry. At the south east corner on the east wall is a second service entry; the lintel has been restored. In the south east corner and along the east wall the plaster survives but the color is indiscernible. The south wall survives to a low height with the remains of plaster (which is red and yellow) in the south west corner. The west wall survives also only to a low height but is covered in plaster with red and yellow dado still surviving on the lower register. The floor is covered with mesh - possible mosaic beneath.

column14: Room 43 is contiguous to room 44 and 45 to north room 42 to the east, corridor 52 to the south and the peristyle (39) to the west.
column21: The dining room has two entrances with the larger opening west on to the peristyle and fountain. A smaller opening is located on the north wall in the north west corner: this is a service entry. On the north wall plaster survives on the lower register and in the north west corner. The wall has had a good amount of reconstruction and conservation work done on it. Colors are not discernible. On the east wall is a small window located in the center of the wall at the ceiling. The wall painting is better preserved and three registers are discernible. It appears that the wall paintings are of the third style with red and yellow on the bottom register and black, red and yellow in the middle register. The base of an architectural can be seen - possibly a column or pilaster base, above which a canopy is visible, scratched into the plaster. To the left of the column base (in the painting) is possibly a herm or podium but the wall painting is sadly damaged. The upper register is visible only in small amounts but on the east wall only red and black bandings can be seen. The south wall has been heavily restored with only the middle register surviving. In the south west corner of the west wall the lower register is partly visible in black and yellow/white; and the upper register is in black, red, yellow and white panels. The west wall is badly damaged with only plaster surviving at the south west end of the west wall. The ceiling has been restored. The floor is covered with modern archaeological materials. The lintel on the west wall is restored.

column14: Room 47 is contiguous to room 48 to the west; room 39 (peristyle and fountains) to the south and room 46 to the east. North of room 47 is the exterior property wall.
column21: This large dining hall looks south on to the peristyle garden and fountain. It has a single large entry at the south end and there are three arcoated niches with semi-curricular tops in which a stucco shell has been created. On the west wall the arcoated niche is present in the middle of the wall; the wall is decorated with red and yellow and black plaster in large panels. The room filled with archaeological equipment and therefore not entirely visible. The niche in the middle of the west wall was painted with blues and greens whilst the upper semicircular area contains a large seashell in stucco with a stucco banding beneath. The upper area of the niche is painted in reds and whites. On the west wall near the south entrance to the room are two emblema scenes but the southern most has been removed while the second is in bad condition. It is possible to see an upper register of yellow banding on the wall painting. On the north wall plaster survives only on the lower register in yellows and reds in the northwest corner. Again the arcoated niche is in the center of the wall and is as described fort he west wall: however the stucco work banding beneath the shell is better preserved with possible details of bead and reel decorations visible. On the east wall the plaster is much better preserved and three registers are visible in whites, yellows, reds and black. The semicircular niche is again in the middle of the east wall but is badly preserved. The wall paintings are fourth style in this room. Around the arcoated niche on the east wall it is possible to see the remains of a marble sill at the south east corner and the remains of a pilaster surround on the lower half of the arcoated niche.
column53: Roll change at 4. Note digital 6, col 34,B+W 34 surplus shot

column14: room 4 to the west.
column21: Rectangular room, northwest southeast axis. The northwest wall is no longer extent, doorway in the center of the south east wall opens to vineyard (1). Above the door is a modern lintel and two rectangular joist holes. Above is a modern roof. All three extent walls preserve traces of plaster , red lower register with white above. The north east wall is extensively restored, but preserves a trace of molded top above which is a modern pillar roof. Step up in the north west, with single step to higher level floor to the northwest. The base of the south east wall, in the east corner, a terracotta drain, drains out from the processing room to the vineyard. Stone stepped threshold to the doorway in the south west wall. In the north corner of base of what was the north east wall is the terracotta out pipe into the processing room. The floor is earth, into which are embedded two lines, against either length wall are five submerged dolia (2954), in total 10. The south west wall features a large poorly preserved window into the press room (4) with modern lintel. Below window is low rectangular step or bench. Extending west to the end of south west wall, along it, is raised plastered, narrow channel. At the west end is a drain into the adjoining room. Above, approximately two feet, the channel, a long horizontal facing has been cut into the plaster wall. Parts of four roof tiles are still extent in this placing to provide a sloping cover, protecting the channel below. In the external face of the channel, three lead pipes, the fourth is no longer extent, drain from the channel into the dolium below. The channel was used to drain the must from the vat of the press room (4) into the preparation room and dolia. Channel feature number 2957

column14: Room 41 to the E.
column21: Square sales room, opening N/NW to the street. Undecorated plaster on S/SE wall, with blocked door way from earlier phase. Rectangular recess adjoining the counter at N end of E wall. Doorway in the center of E wall to room 41 blocked in the modern period. Floor is obscured. A stove is recorded in SW corner, but is no longer present (Ruddell.) In the S end of E wall are holes for floor joists. Counter (2913) is in the center of the room facing the street.

Poorly preserved U-shaped counter of which only the lower courses survive in the North of the room, facing the street to the North/Northeast.  Adjoins a rectangular plastered recessed storage cupboard niche in the wall to the BE. Ruddell refers to a dolium, but nothing is visible.

column14: Peristyle 42 to Southwest; room 47 to Northeast; Southeast to swimming pool (48); storeroom 46 in Northwest corner.
column21: Large L-shaped room, with wide doorway North/Northwest to street. Stepped threshold, most of the doorway faces a large L-shaped counter (2913) the extends to center of the room. Floor is obscured in the center of the E wall is a doorway with tufa stepped threshold to room 47. To the South is a stepped doorway to swimming pool and base for stairs to floor above. In the Southwest, center of the wall, there is a plastered buttress against the wall. And in West corner of the Southwest wall, a square modern window into peristyle (42),  In the high end of the Southwest wall are 3 rectangles for joists. High in the Northeast wall are holes for joists or possibly shelving and a square plastered window into kitchen 47A with modern lintel.  Modern wooden lintel over entrance to the street.  In Northeast corner, a stepped platform. On the Northeast and Southwest wall are extensive surviving plaster, black lower register with vegetation and with red and yellow alternating panels above that register. Decoration plaster continues along wall of storeroom 46 to Southeast.

Large L-shaped counter, facing street to the Northwest. Counter surface is restored marble, with one in situ dolium on the internal Southeast half.  At the end of the Southeast arm is a rectangular marble based recess with plaster drain for liquid. The Northwest arm of the counter, facing the street, is enlarged by an addition of a rectangular sales area facing the street.  The Western end of Northwest arm is a stepped sales display area with six plastered steps.  Below steps is a square recessed storage area, fronted by a large rectangular step and a smaller rectangular plaster step painted black against the Southwest wall of the room.  Few traces of plaster survive on the base of the front of the Southeast arm of the counter with traces of red paint.

column14: Room 47A to Northwest, Room 45 to Southeast.
column21: Large rectangular dining room, Southwest and Northeast axis. Traces of plastered floor survive against triclinium (2928) and benches (2917) and Northeast and Southwest walls.  Doorway with modern lintel and tufa stepped threshold in Southeast wall to room 45.  Room 47A inserted into the Northwest corner of the room. In center of Northeast wall, a blocked plastered doorway to 51, modern lintel.  The wall above this is restored with 2 thresholds (?) and one blocked doorway in the floor above.  Along base of Northeast wall, is a gutter, constructed of roof tiles that drains into street to the North via a terracotta pipe.  The adjoining plaster floor is contiguous with the facing of couch 2918.  The Northwest wall survives only to half its height (?) with undecorated plaster.  In the corner of Northwest wall, a drain runs from the down slope of dining couch 2918 out to the street to the North.  Southeast wall with undecorated plaster throughout and molded top, leaving a large high opening out to the garden.  The roof and supporting pillars above are modern.  Southwest wall has undecorated plaster with 2 rectangular holes for shelves (?)   Plastered window with modern lintel high in Southwest corner.  Rectangular joist hole in center of the wall for the floor above.  The wall above is modern

column14: Masonry triclinium to Northwest (2918)
column21: Masonry dining bench extending along Southeast and East walls of room 47.  Benches have 2 arms extending Northwest to the center of the room.  Between the arms of the benches are two square masonry tables of opus signinum work.  The benches and tables are plastered throughout in red.  The plaster is contiguous with that of the adjoining floor.  The couches are too narrow for reclining and must have been used by seated diners. The surface of the Western most of the two tables is broken away and the plaster facing of the arms of the benches has collapsed in places. There appears to have been extensive modern restoration.

column14: dining benches (2917/ to SE
column21: Large "U"-shaped masonry dining couch, sloping out to N/NW/W/NE.  The couch is plastered throughout with opus signinum on upper surface.  The couch plaster is painted red throughout.  Between the arms of the couch is a solid masonry circular table, plastered and painted red.  The W corner of the couch slopes down to a drainage channel through the wall to the street to the N.

column14: Door to S/SE to Room 47.
column21: Rectangular kitchen, NW/SE axis.  Doorway in SE to Room 47, square plaster window with modern lintel high in SW wall to Room 45.  Traces of undecorated plaster in NE/SW walls, two holes at the N and S ends of W wall for joists match to holes opposite on the E wall. At the S end of E wall are 2 smaller holes for shelves?  Along SW wall, starting in the S corner, is a large rectangular masonry preparation platform (2920) that abuts directly to cooking platform (2920) to the NW.  The floor is obscured.  Modern roof.

column14: Preparation platform 2921
column21: Large square cooking platform in NW corner of the room (47A), large recessed storage, partially filled with debris and earth.  Surface of platform is plastered and a large plastered partition extends south across the platform, dividing the platform in two.  The half of the platform to the W of this partition is raised above the level of the surface of the rest of the platform.  There is a buttress lip along the N wall (placing for a grill?)

column14: Room 25 to NW
column21: Enter the room from the southeast side of room 25.  We go through a small room, then SE into the dining room.  There is a marble threshold which is broken into two pieces.  The mosaic floor is gone. On the NE wall is a large window overlooking the orchard.  Centered directly above the large window is a smaller window.  On the SE wall is another set of windows, duplicating the east wall.  They also look onto the orchard.  The N wall shows evidence of red wall painting with a black dado along the bottom edge.  The room was roofed in modern times.

column14: Atrium 18 to NE and SERoom 5 to NW
column21: Room 22 lies to the NW of Atrium 18.  One enters the room from the E.  In the  SW corner is a doorway into Atrium 18.  There is a doorway to the NW into Room 5.  In the N corner is a cistern.  Constructed into the N corner of the NW wall is a rectangular shaped vaulted storage space.  The floor is of beaten cement. The walls were stuccoed and painted.

column14: Corridor to Atrium 18 to NW
column21: Rectangular room NW/SE axis.  NW wall has a poorly preserved doorway at W end opening to corridor and atrium 18.  Above this door is a square plaster internal window.  There is extensive first style decoration with red border and yellow or white background.  On the NE wall undecorated plaster survives with placing for shelf supports.  High in the center of SE wall is a window with a modern lintel and undecorated plaster. The SW wall has undecorated plaster and placing for shelf support.  There is a poorly preserved window at S end which might be collapse.  Also a poorly preserved door at W end of S wall which might indicate collapse.  The upper courses of the walls are restored and the floor is obscured by earth, debris and vegetation.

column14: Room 29 to SW
column21: This rectangular storeroom is on a NW/SE axis.  The wall in the W corner of the room is collapsed.  Traces of plaster decoration, red borders with yellow background, fragments of black lower register, on the lower walls, exist on the NW wall.  The NE wall has no extent decoration,; however, holes exist for shelves and floor joists for a second floor.  The doorway at the N end of the NE wall could be collapse.  Window at the E end of the NE wall could also be collapse.  There is a window high in the SE wall with modern wooden lintel, and a doorway in the center of the SW wall to kitchen 29.  The floor is obscured by earth and in the SW corner there are floor joists into the adjoining kitchen.

column14: to the cooking platform 2928 to N and latrine 2943 to SW to the east.  Basin 2929 to N
column21: When facing the cooking platform on the South wall there is evidence of a quarter circle basin on the R back corner of the platform.  It shows evidence of a cutout drain to provide water to the contiguous latrine.  It is connected to the shelf on the back of the cooking platform.

column14: to the cooking platform 2928 and water feature, basin, 2942 to the East
column21: A five foot wall partially separates the cooking platform from the latrine.  The entrance is SE of the corridor on the NW.  The SW wall shows four narrow windows to the street.  The latrine receives water from the cooking platform side to the E.  The latrine slopes to the SE.

column14: counter 2913 to the SW
column21: In the N corner of NE wall is a rectangular niche on a vertical axis.  Probably used to accommodate a wooden cupboard.  As extent, there is no sign of plaster or decoration.

column14: fish pond 2937 to W
column21: There are alternating semicircular and rectangular bays (alcoves) ten in all "which contained raised planting beds.  The semicircular bays were covered with pumice and each had a band of Egyptian blue along the sides and top.  The central bay had four bands of Egyptian blue."(p87) The location of these bays overlooks the fishponds; they all directly face the marble summer triclinium.  The area of the bays is shaded by an elaborate pergola (in 2011) laden with green grapes.  I think these bays could have been used by large or small dining groups.  One person could lie down, or two people could sit and be served with a portable table.The five rectangular bays show no pumice or Egyptian blue tessera.  They are all stripped and are being prepared for redecoration.  The fifth bay from the N aligns with the marble summer triclinium.  This is the "central bay" to which Jashemski refers.

column14: Peristyle garden 3 to NW
column21: Excavations in 1951-52 were unpublished but Jashemski refers to soil contours of rectangular planting beds.  Maiuri suggests that cabbage was grown here.  Jashemski also refers to four basins and a cistern.Large rectangular garden area occupies the south and east of the insula enclosing the property.  The baths are to the west and north.  The walls are extensively restored.  In the center of the southeast wall there is a gate to the amphitheater.  The exterior wall of the atrium complex 18 has extensive traces of Pompeian first style.  Two doorways open to the garden peristyle.  The western door has a threshold with three steps and the eastern has two restored side walls of which only the lower course is preserved.  Immediately south is a large, poorly preserved masonry platform.  The eastern quarter of the platform contains an inserted rectangular basin.  No traces of interior lining survive (one of the basins referred to by Jashemski?)  Immediately NE is a modern cover of the Fontina aqueduct.  Against the N wall to the S of the bath latrine, is a circular cistern surmounted by a lead water pipe.  To the east of the latrine there is the rectangular masonry base of a water basin.  Traces of plaster survive on the internal and external surfaces.  The south external wall of the atrium complex 18 contains joist holes.  Their purpose is unclear.  Two ancient tree roots survive.  The modern garden is planted with pear, apple and pomegranate trees.

column14: NW to room 45
column21: Small square room added in final phase into the large shop room 45.  Floor is obscured and N and W walls survive to only half height.  The E & S walls contains 2 square windows, both plastered and with modern lintels (Decoration or discoloration to plaster to window in E wall).  Doorway to Room 45 in N end of NW wall without threshold.  Plaster survives on all 4 walls, continuing the decorative scheme of room 45, with black lower register, and alternating red and yellow panels above.

column14: Atrium 2 to the south.  Latrine 10 and preparation room 9 to the north.  Kitchen 54 to the east.
column21: Dining room 5 opens to the north off atrium 2. This room is oriented southeast/northwest.  it shows a very large entrance leading into a rectangular space which is divided into 2 unequally-sized parts by a low wall running east-west direction for half of the length of the room.  It is not clear how the small space (B) at the back could have been used, as it is not possible to define the original height of the dividing wall.  Was it low enough for supporting, for example, lamps or statuettes?  Or was it high so that two separate spaces were created?  The northeastern wall of the room doesn't run parallel to the opposite wall, since it is interrupted by a L-shaped wall against which the above-mentioned low wall rests.  The three preserved walls are approximately 1.8 meters high with some traces of reconstruction.  The floor today is covered with lapilli.  Traces of wall plaster are visible in the northern corner of the room and onto the northeastern corner of the L-shaped wall.  A square stone platform is placed on the northwestern side of space B (it's function is not certain).  A pile of broken terracotta bricks lays in the northwestern corner of the room next to the square stone.

column14: Vat 18 to the northwest.  Space 15 to the southwest and the street to the east.
column21: Room 16 is entered from room 18 to the northwest.  On the threshold is a rectangular stone.  The small square room is delimited by a mostly collapsed wall to the northwest (wall that delimits the adjoining vat), two preserved walls to the north and northeast and a wall to the south which was probably pierced by a large window looking out onto space 15.  Large sections of red plaster are visible on the north and northeastern walls.  On the northeastern wall is a  medium-sized rectangular window on the top and traces of another window are also visible on the top of the northern wall.  The floor shows  a few traces of mosaic decoration (white tesserae on a pinkish background) close to the doorway.  The orientation of the room is northwest/southeast.

column14: Corridor 20 to the west.  Processing room 16 to the south and room 19 to the north.
