column21: Processing room 18 is entered from corridor 20 to the east.  The rectangular space is occupied by a vat at the back opposite the entrance.  The room is oriented southwest/northeast.

column14: Space 18 to the west. Processing room 16 to the south.
column21: The vat in processing room 18 is a very deep rectangular space delimited by mostly preserved walls to the north and northwest.  The western wall is preserved for 75 centimeters.  At the bottom, in the middle, is a semicircular  opening for drainage.  The interior walls of the vat are covered with cocciopesto.  At the bottom of the western wall and part of the adjoining northern wall and in the southeastern corner  the walls protrude inward.  Evidence of another drain is visible in the bottom of the eastern wall.  However, as the vat is hardly accessible because of its' depth, it is not possible to ascertain whether it is an ancient drain or a modern opening.  It is difficult to specify what could have been processed in this vat.

column14: Corridor 49 to the south and storeroom 24 to the southeast and cubiculum 23 to the east.  At the back of storeroom 22 to the north is atrium 27.
column21: Store room 22 is entered from corridor 49 to the southeast.  It is a long, narrow space oriented southwest/northeast.  In the western corner is a low square platform with a raised edge to the east side.  This probably supported a flight of stairs leading up to the missing upper floor.  Space 22 under the supposed flight of stairs could have been used for storage.  Today a large rectangular block of stone occupies the whole width of the room in the middle.  This stone doesn't look like it belongs to the storeroom.  The walls are all preserved in their entire height.  Larger fragments of plaster (a few traces of faded red color) are evident along the northwestern wall.   The floor is covered with soil and lapilli and it is a little higher than the adjoining storeroom 24.

column14: Storeroom 22 to the north. Cubiculum 23 to the northeast. Space 25 to the southeast and corridor 49 to the south.
column21: Storeroom 24 is a very small square space delimited by continuous large rectangular and low blocks of stones along the northwestern and southeastern sides.  On the eastern side runs a wall which is approximately 40 centimeters high in the direction southeast/northwest.  On the southeastern side a wall, which is today preserved at height of two meters.  In the southern corner, where the southwestern wall and the southeastern wall are interrupted is an irregularly shaped stone block which forms the paving floor of the adjoining corridor 49 and steps down into the central space of storeroom 24.  Because of the badly preserved condition of the whole area, it is not possible to ascertain whether the room was entered from the southern corner as is possible today. The  floor shows evidence of paving stones.  The southwestern wall includes a group of terracotta tiles which runs along the whole height of the wall.  This row of tiles seems to appear like part of a frame of a larger opening. In fact, a farther row of terracotta tiles runs perpendicular to the previous one at approximately two meters high.  It is evident that a very large door opened onto the adjoining cubiculum 23, but it was blocked in at a later stage.

column14: To the southwest of kitchen 54 and to the northwest of corridor 28.
column21: The cooking platform rests against the southwestern wall of kitchen 54.  The preserved structure is approximately 40-50 centimeters high and shows an irregular shape.  In fact, while the southeast and southwest edges run parallel to the adjoining walls, the northeastern edge is slightly diagonal in relation to the corridor 28 leading into latrine 10 to the northwest.  The front edge to the northeast curves to form a convex shape.  The top of the cooking platform is covered with irregularly shaped terracotta tiles for almost the entire length of the structure.

column14: "corridor" 7 to the southeast, "consider" 28 to the northeast, store room 8 to the northwest.
column21: Kitchen 54 is entered from corridor 28 to the northeast and corridor 7 to the southeast.  It's a small rectangular space which is mostly occupied by the cooking platform to northwest.  There is no evidence of a doorway both onto corridor 28 and corridor 7.  It seems likely that what is numbered space 7 in the house plan are all referring to is part of the kitchen 54,  which would have been entered from the eastern corner of corridor 49.

column14: Corridor 28 (with the adjoining kitchen 54) to the east/southeast.  Preparation room 9 to the southwest and space 38 - triclinium 37 to the northeast.  To the northwest is building 6-1-4.
column21: Preparation room 8 is a small rectangular room oriented northeast/southwest.  It is entered from corridor 28 to the southeast.  the floor is covered with lapilli and overgrown vegetation.  The walls to the southeast, northwest and southwest are preserved for almost 2 meters.  The northeastern wall shows a few traces of plaster.  the southeastern side of the doorway is framed by about a 70 centimeters high wall.  Because of its small size next to the kitchen, the room could have been used for food preparation.

column14: Corridor 28 (with the adjoining kitchen 54) to the east/southeast.  Preparation room 8 to the northeast and latrine 10 to the southwest.
column21: Room 9 is a larger rectangular space oriented southwest/northeast.  on the threshold of the entrance to the southeast is a block of gray stone which look like volcanic origin.  This block which is about 20 centimeters high steps down onto the adjoining corridor 28.  The walls to the southwest, northwest, and southeast are well-preserved and about 1.70 meters high.  The northeastern wall is about 30 centimeters ? than the other 3 walls.  In the southeastern corner about 2 meters high a pilaster frames a doorway of the connecting preparation rooms 8 and 9.  The floor is covered with lapilli and overgrown vegetation.

column14: Room 12 and room 7 plus room 4 to the northwest.
column21: The garden takes up the entire southeast of the property.  One enters the garden from the northwest through room 7.  The shape of the garden is roughly square although in the north corner it extends along the north east side of the house for a short distance.  On the northeast wall is a large aediculate lararium, in front of which is a small altar.In the northwest corner is a small rectangular pool whose axis is east/west.  The garden is surrounded on all sides by a tall wall.  The interior of this wall and the exterior of the southeast wall of the house is stuccoed and painted.  A small portion of which is still extant in the northwest corner.  On the exterior of the southeast wall of the house is a low masonry bench running parallel to the southeast wall from its northeast end.  Just before it reaches the southwest end it stops.  The rest of the distance to the doorway of room 7 was taken up by a small dolium.  To the southwest of the doorway inside the garden, sitting on a masonry base, bordered with stone is a large dolium.  to the southwest of the dolium is a doorway opening to the northwest to room 4.  From the doorway to room 7 toward the southeast into the garden was a paved walkway about a quarter of the way into the garden, to the southwest of the walkway is the remains of a column base.  If there were a matching column to the north, it is no longer extant.Paralleling the southeast wall of the house is a stone walkway.  On its southwest and northeast ends the walkway turns 90 degrees to the southeast.  The walkway on the southwest end parallels the northwest wall until it reaches to the south east wall.  There appears to have been two rooms, one behind the other in the southwest corner.  In the rooms only a small portion remains.  The walkway on the northeast end runs southeast until it reaches the southeast end of the masonry triclinium where it turns at 90 degree to the southwest and extends to where it meets the central walkway.

column14: Garden 13 to the southeast.
column21: One approaches the triclinium from the southwest by way of corridor 6.  The entrance to the room itself is from the north corner from corridor 6.  The dining room is rectangular in shape, on the southwest/northeast axis.  The floor is a beaten concrete fragments of white and blue marble randomly dispersed.  The room was stuccoed and painted as extant along the bottom of the southeast wall.  it appears to show some sort of vegetation.  in the center of the southeast wall is a large window looking onto garden number 13.  the heights of the walls are indeterminate.  If there was a window in the northeast wall, it's no longer extant.

column14: Triclinium 2963 to the west
column21: The altar is constructed of stone and is rectangular.  Behind we see and aediculum large shrine attached to the garden wall.  It has 4 large roof tiles with a triangular pediment below.  the pediment shows white plastering.  This shrine has a column in each corner.  To the side of the opening there is brickwork.  The wall is opened behind the columns.  There are shelves on both sides of the post and lintel entrance to the shrine.  The back of the shrine shows white plaster.  Near the shrine was a marble statuette of Hercules and two terracotta votive offerings - a slender female, winged figure and a small, draped figure with traces of red on the drapery.

column14: altar (2962) to the east
column21: There are two ways into the garden with paved paths.   The dining area is on a cement platform, sloped to the sides so water could flow off for cleaning.  (1, medius 4.40m; imus 4.00m; summus 3.80 m, table between the couches 1.00x1.67 m)The south end of the rectangular table has a semicircular cutoff at the south end.  the south end of the triclinium shows a pattern of natural stone with white, square shaped tessera.  Nearby Jashemski reports the findings of a human skeleton, five gold coins, two gold finger rings, a strigil and seven medical instruments.  To the Southeast of the dining triclinium is a place for a hearth.  It has 3 stone sides and is paved in the center.  Today there is a splendid pergola shading the dining area.  Holes for timber were apparent.
Broken catillus, no visible Meta.  Two broken halves of a hand mill were found in Rooms 8 & 10.

column14: Triclinium, masonry (2890) to Northwest.
column21: Near the imus of triclinium is a smashed dolium half.
On South side of triclinium we can no longer see a shallow basin which collected rainwater from the couch of triclinium.

column14: Room 14 is the SW.
column21: Rectangular room, NW/SE axis.  Floor obscured by lapilli and vegetation, especially at the SE end.  No decoration.  Undecorated cement restoration on SE wall.  Wide doorway at West end of the SW wall.  No threshold visible.  Catillus (2893) in N end of the room. The base and a neck rim of amphorae were found in the floor of the room, no in situ, dressel 2/4 rim.

column14: Room 2 is contiguous with Room 1 to the south, Room 5 to the southeast and in the west of Room 6.
column21: A dining room with entrance in the West wall in the southwest corner.  There are two niches in this room (6032 and 6033).  The north wall has red and yellow plaster surviving a the bottom and a band of stucco work at the top of the wall.  The east wall has a large niche (6032) cut into the wall in the north east corner running to the south.  The doorway in the east wall has a threshold in place with  pivot marks and a stop join surviving;  it is of volcanic stone.  In the southeast corner of the east wall , red plaster survives.  The south wall is plastered with red plaster but has suffered a collapse.   The west wall has suffered a severe collapse but in the northwest corner is a niche (6033).  Small traces of plaster remain in the south end of the niche.  The floor is covered with lapilli.  There are signs of modern conservation in the pointing of the walls.

The niche is a rectangular niche cut into the east wall.  The niche has been inserted later into the structure and the construction of the niche has reused roof tegulae.  A relieving arch has b een put in the wall to take the stress of the wall above the niche.  Red plaster survives at the bottom of the north and south end of the niche.  Most of the plaster is gone.
The niche is a rectangular niche in the northeast corner of the room.  A small amount of red and white plaster survives a the bottom of the southwest corner of the niche.

column14: Atrium 4 to the southwest, tablinum 6 to the southeast, space 8 to the northeast.
column21: Use existing description.

column14: Kitchen 10 adjoins room 9 to the southwest and garden area to the south.
column21: Use existing description.

column14: Corridor (14) to the southeast.
column21: One enters the room through a doorway in the south corner.  A low wall abutting against the southeast wall running southeast to northwest separates  the front part of the room from the cooking platform.  One approaches the cooking platform through a break in the low wall at the southwest end.  As extant the walls show little sign of plaster, primarily at the base of the northeast wall.  No evidence of decoration remains.  The floor and the height of the walls are indeterminate.

The cooking platform is against the southeast wall of the kitchen and runs northeast/southwest.  The surface of the platform on its northeast as extant was made up of a single roof tile.  The southwest surface is not extant, but may have been another roof tile.  Beneath the northeast roof tile is a storage area.  The cooking platform, including the storage area, rests upon the foundation that rises about a foot above floor level.

column14: Room 6 to  the south.  Long, narrow space 7 to the North.  Atrium 4 to the east.
column21: Not required.

column14: Corridor 2 is to the north.
column21: A rectangular room, northwest/southeast axis.  Large opening doorway looking northeast.  No visible threshold.  Low masonry base of fully preserved wall (?) at the east end of northeast wall.  Doorway at the north end of the northwest wall opens to corridor  3.  DPM plan and Eschebach plan does not have a doorway in the northeast wall.  No visible facing to the walls.  Floor level is raised above that of rooms to northeast.  Garden to the west is above the floor level of this room.  The floor is obscured by the earth, vegetation, and debris.

column14: Contiguous to hallway 6 to northwest.
column21: One enters the triclinium (7) from a doorway in the north corner.  The room is rectangular in shape, with southwest/northeast axis.  Though not extant today, early excavations show a small pillar, rectangular, abutting the southeast wall, on line with northeast end of the west wall.  Neither  the floor nor the height of the walls are determinable.  Walls shown no evidence of plaster today.

column14: Latrine (2907) to the  southwest.
column21: Cooking platform in the east corner of the room.  The only extant part is the poorly preserved northwest wall support of the original surface.

column14: Dolium 16-2894 to south east
column21: Triclinium - rectangular table which had receding semicircle cut into its east end. Couches faced with opus signinum and show evidence of having been painted red. The top of the table was inlaid with marble, the center circular, the others square. There is no evidence of a small table attached to the north wall (as described in Jashemski). The triclinium is currently under a blue tarpaulin.Medius 4.60m; imus 4.65m; summus 3.75mRectangular table 2.00 x 1.45m

column14: Hallway 6 to north
column21: One enters the kitchen (7) through a low door by way of hallway (6) from northwest. The room is rectangular in shape on a northwest-southeast axis. Wall in south corner juts into room by about 18 inches. There may have been a window in the south corner opening into room 10. The southwest wall of kitchen is an addition which may have cut room 10. Evidence for this is painted plaster on southeast wall where southwest wall abuts. No other paint is on the walls. The height of the room is indeterminate as is the door. Eschebach indicates on his map that a platform (cooking) was located on the northwest wall. No evidence of this platform exists today.

column14: Room 8 is west of room 4, south of room 10, south east of 12, east of room 9 and west of room 7
column21: Dining room with entrance from the west wall in southwest corner, window opening on to corridor and peristyle on the east wall in the southeast corner. The dining room is visible from the main entrance at 10 through the atrium. There is a closed doorway with marble threshold on the south wall in the southeast corner. North wall has remains of white plaster with red bands in the northeast corner. This plaster continues on the east wall to the window. On the south wall white plaster remains at the bottom of the wall. Some conservation has been carried out to the wall at the southeast end. The floor is badly degraded but would have been crushed stone embedded in plaster or cement. The doorway to the dining room on the west wall is the highest preserved wall but the lintel has been restored.

column14: Room 10 to the west. Corridor 12 to the north. Space 19 to the east. Corridor 21 and room 27 to the south.
column21: See feature number 11

column14: Back entrance 17 to the west, space 19 and corridor 20 to the south
column21: Kitchen 18 is entered from corridor 12 to the west and corridor 20 to the southwest. It is a small square room which is provided with a large preparation platform against the north wall. Adjoining the preparation platform is a latrine to the west. The preserved walls on the eastern, western and northern sides are approximately 2 m high; roof is missing. The floor is now covered with lapilli, with no trace of original paving. Traces of plaster are visible on the lower zone of the western wall. A small rectangular window opens on the top of the northern wall above the preparation platform.

column14: Room 10 (and the latrine) is east of room 9 and north of room 11 and its adjacent corridor (unnumbered)
column21: The latrine is located in the southeast corner. The latrine is in a very badly degraded state. Two niches survive for the plank. 1 in the south wall and 1 in the east wall. The floor is cocciopesto. The floor is collapsing in the southeast corner.

Jashemski- Page 221There was a triclinium (medius 4.60 m, imus and summus 3.20 m) attached to the south wall.  On sides of triclinium, which were finished with painted plaster, two amorini were painted on a red background.  The one on right trying to ward off a pheasant that attempts to peck at a bunch of grapes held by the amorino, the other amorino drinking from a bowl while pushing back an animal, perhaps a leopard.  Triclinium table, rectangular in shape with an incurving semicircle in front (1.40 x 0.90 m), had a top decorated with circles, squares and triangles of colored marble.
Eschebach 389-390
Eschebach 389-390

column14: Garden 6 to SW hallway 2 to SE.
column21: One enters the dining room hallway 2 through a small door in the SE corner.  The room is rectangular in shape on a SW-NE axis.  In the center of the SW wall is a doorway leading into garden 6.  The floor and the height of the walls are indeterminate.  The walls were plastered but only little remains today.  No decoration is extant.Post-earthquake rectangular pillar effectively creates a rectangular recess between the low wall on the NW wall and the SW wall.

column14: Corridor 2 to the NW.
column21: Square room, doorway at the N end of NW wall.  The floor is raised above level of the floor of the adjoining corridor.  Original floor surface survives on the W half of the room and consists of terra cotta files sloping S to latrine (2907) in the SE corner of the room. In E corner of the room there is a cooking platform (2906) of which only one masonry supporting wall survives.  Walls of the room are poorly preserved, with no surviving finish.  The thresh hold in front of the room is poorly preserved, so it is not possible to determine if the raised level of the floor is by steps.

column14: cooking platform 2920 to the north.
column21: Rectangular masonry preparation [platform, no storage; poorly preserved plaster surface.  Against SW wall there is a thick buttressed lip with plastered top.

column14: Room 2 to the northeast
column21: The vaulted triclinium is situated along the middle of the southwest side of the peristyle.  One enters the triclinium from the northeast through the wide doorway that extends almost the width of the opening.  A wide but shallow rectangular space precedes the triclinium whose dining couches take up the rest of the space within the room.  In the middle of the southwest wall above the ten steps that rise up and back into the wall, the steps appear to descend through a large rectangular opening constructed as if to reflect a cave.   At the top of the stairs is an opening that penetrates through the wall.  The lower portion of the walls of the room, the floor and most of the triclinium couch is covered with marble.  On the southwest wall on either side of the stairs is a semicircular niche.  On the southeast and northwest walls is a rectangular niche.  High on the southwest wall above the stairs is a large rectangular window on a vertical axis.  The southwest wall still retains the marble facing from the level of the triclinium couch up to the level of the first step of the staircase.  The southeast and northwest walls also had a similar marble facade only a little of which still remains.  From the top level of the marble facade and upward, the walls were painted with various scenes.  Still extant is the western corner of the northwest wall and the north corner of the northwest wall.  A small portion also remains on the southeast wall.  The interior of the northeast wall on either side of the entrance appears to have lacked the marble facade.  As reconstructed, the ceiling has a barrel vault.

The triclinium composed of three couches takes up most of the room in which it lies.  It is on axis with the room and faces out almost full width through a room (2) and a garden (3), with the fish pool.  The only portion of the triclinium not covered in marble are the top surface of the couches.  The marble front facade of the northeast ends of the left and right couch rises slightly higher than the level of the couches creating a small lip.  To the front and at a lower level of the three couches is a platform for food dishes.  The rectangular space between the couches functions as part of the water display.  The rectangular space extends to a depth below the level of the floor of the room and slopes southwest to the northeast.  At the base of the southwest end of the central area is a semicircular hole for water flowing from the stairs above to enter.  Water flows down the sloped floor of the central area where it exits through a semicircular hole at the northeast end flowing and then under the floor and out to the garden. As excavated, there appears to have been a narrow space between the triclinium couches and the wall on the northwest, southwest, and southeast sides.

On the northwest wall above the level of the rectangular niche are the remains of painted decoration.  In the west corner, one is able to detect a bunch of grapes; to the north is a seascape showing what appears to be a large crocodile above which is a boat with three individuals.  Farther to the north a large individual is shown from the waist up, and behind him there appears to be another boat.

column14: rooms 23 and 24 to the east, and room 22 to the northwest
column21: We enter the old atrium from a northwest entrance.  There is a marble impluvium and a beautiful reconstructed compluvium.  On the north wall is a 4th style wall painting (2926) and an apparent cornice.  The floor is white and black mosaic tesserae.  At the northwest entrance of the atrium are three marble steps.  There are entrances to a dining room and a dining tablinum on the northeast wall and a third door leading to a corridor.  On the southeast wall are two doors.  On the southwest wall are three doors.  The southwest and the northwest doors lead up to small rooms, and the west door leads to a blocked fauces.  Along the north wall is the main entrance to the atrium and two doors lead to a storeroom (22).

The northwest wall has fourth style painting with a black dado, green leaves, and red central space.  Above the cornice are two pomegranates and the bottom third of a basket.  A fish is hanging from the basket.  A golden apple is below the basket.

column14: Room (17) to the north and room (28) to the east.
column21: The room is on a northwest/southeast axis.  We enter from entrance (10) from the southwest.  The entrance floor is soil.  To the south, there is a toilet enclosure with four slotted windows.  There is an additional window on the south side of the toilet.  The toilet is separated from the kitchen by a plastered wall.  Moving to the second large part of the area, there is a large cooking platform.  The cooking platform area has a roof The third part of the complex was probably used for storage.  There is a window over the cooking platform.  In the third area, there are two large high windows. There is a highwall separating the work area from a hallway to the old atrium.  There is a large window in the wall to the adjoining room.

column14: Water feature, basin (2929) to the north.
column21: The cooking platform runs the entire length of the southeast wall with two recessed, arched niches underneath for storage of wood, coal, or kitchen equipment.  There is evidence of tiles on the top of the cooking platform.  The wall is plastered in this area, and there is a window above the cooking platform.

column14: To the southwest are rooms (4, 7, 8, 6, 9, 10, 13, 14)   To the northwest is atrium (1).  To the north is the bath suite (36).  to the southeast is dining room (23) and adjoining open area.
column21: Peristyle (3) occupies a long rectangular space which is oriented northwest/southeast.  The center fishpond is surrounded by a row of slender pilasters.  On the northeast/southwest and southeast sides.  Today the area is planted with small trees and bushes.  In the past it could have been used as either an ornamental garden or vegetable garden.  On the southeast side of the peristyle, the pilasters rest on the paved porticus which is covered today by a sloping roof.  On the other side of the same row of pilasters, a channel runs along the edge of the central area.  On the southeast and northeast side, on the contrary, the pilasters are resting directly on the natural ground and today support a pergola with vines.  The northeast wall of the peristyle is articulated with alternating semicircular and square niches.  On the bottom of each of the niches is a platform slightly raised above the surrounding areas.  The walls of most of the niches are decorated with what appears to be reddish crushed stone framed by a thin blue band.  On the southwest porticus are sixteen slender pilasters with Corinthian capitals.  The pilasters are decorated with channel-like ornamentation which is interrupted half way up with rectangular panels on all four sides.  The pair of central pilasters facing the entrance of the triclinium (8) are approximately 30 centimeters higher than the other pilasters.  On the opposite porticus (southeast/northeast), the pilasters are completely enclosed in modern wooden supports.

column14: Cistern (2935) to the south.
column21: In the north corner of the room a rectangularly shaped vaulted space is constructed into the northwest wall.  In the northwest wall of the storage space appears to be three (3) sockets to accommodate wooden beams.  No evidence of stucco or painting remains.

column14: Storage space (2934) to the north.
column21: In the north corner of the room is a cistern.  A stone puteal defines the central opening.

The fish pond is a long rectangular structure which covers the entire central area of the peristyle (3).  It is ornamented with alternating semicircular and square niches on the northeast and southwest sides.  At about 20 centimeters above the ground is a rectangular slab of stone which divides the space of all the niches vertically into two irregularly high spaces.  The lower area could be used as fish receptacles above which could be used as support for statues.  Dividing the fish pond in quarters are three arches of bricks each supporting a rectangular marble slab which could be used as a walkway to traverse the fishpond. The interior walls of the fishponds are pierced with three drains which are placed in different sections and heights.  A large fragment of plaster is visible on the northwest wall.

column14: contiguous with room (6) to the southeast, room (14) to the southwest, and room (2) to the northeast
column21: One enters the room from the northeast.  The room is square in shape with a door on the east corner of the southeast wall and the south corner of the window on a vertical axis.  In the center of the southwest wall is a large semicircular niche;  on the southeast and northwest walls are rectangular niches.  On the southwest wall between the semicircular niche and the west corner appears to be a rectangular light well that penetrates the wall at an oblique angle.  the opening into  the room is much larger than the hole that penetrates the room (14?).  All four walls are covered with fourth style wall painting.  The floor is in opus signinum and fragments of brick.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is quite high.

column14: Contiguous to room (14) to the southwest, room (10) to the northwest, and room (2) to the northeast.
column21: One enters the room from the northeast.  The room is rectangular on a southwest/northeast axis with a door on the south corner of the southwest wall and the north corner of the northwest wall.  High on the southwest wall is a large rectangular window on vertical axis.  In the center of the southwest wall is a large semicircular niche.  Still extant at the top is a stucco decoration in the shape of a seashell.  On the southeast and northwest walls are rectangular niches.  On the southwest wall between the semicircular niche and the west corner  appears to be a rectangular light well which penetrates the wall at an oblique angle.  the opening into the room is much larger than the hole that penetrates the room (14?).  All four walls are covered with fourth style wall painting.  The floor is in opus signinum and fragments of brick.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is quite high.

column14: Room (4), the dining garden is to the north.
column21: Visitors entering from the Nocera gate will see the first door to the north of the gate.  There is a high step to enter the doorway.  One enters that small room just inside the entrance.  On the north is a large space which leads to the garden/peristyle.  On the southeast wall is an oven.  On the west wall there is a locked modern door. The floor is pounded concrete.  There are two small high windows on the southwest wall placed diagonally.  The higher window is to the south of the lower window.  There is a remnant of plaster on the southwest wall below the windows.  The ceiling is of modern reconstruction.

The east wall contains a beehive oven on a picium.  When looking at the cooking oven, one first sees a raised platform to the north next to the beehive oven.  This provides space for preparation.  This podium extends beneath the beehive oven but does not extend all the way to the wall.  The oven has a post and basalt surface.  At the top of the beehive there is a mantle type platform around and above the beehive.  there is a large recessed arch above the platform over the beehive oven.

column14: Room (1) to the southwest.  Room (5) to the northwest.
column21: The dining garden takes up most of the northeast part of the property.  One enters the dining room from the southwest through the kitchen (1).  The garden is essentially rectangular in shape on a northeast/southwest axis.  In the south corner, the garden extends more to the southwest.  High on the southwest wall is a narrow window opening onto the street. A staircase to the second floor abuts the southwest wall in the exterior of the east wall of room (1). To the east of the stairway, at the third step level, there is a small hearth. To the north there is a doorway to room (5).  There are remains of eleven planting rows still visible along the northwest wall, running from the west end of the room (5) towards the north along the north wall. In the center of the garden a few meters northeast of room (1) was a well or cistern. The walls on all sides lack plaster except for a small amount on the southeast wall.  It appears to have been painted.  On the southeast wall, roughly on axis with room (5), there is a remnant of a wall extending into the garden.  To the north of this wall and abutting it are the remains of a platform, the smooth surface of which is composed of plaster and fragments of terracotta.  The function is unknown.  Eschebach suggests that it was perhaps a latrine.

column14: Dining garden room (4) to the southeast.
column21: Rectangular raised floor and lower course of walls on this structure are extensively restored.  There is no visible decoration on the floor.  The room is on a northeast/southwest axis.  The only surviving wall to the northwest is extensively restored.  Eschebach says that this was a room with two windows.  There are no traces of these remains.  There is no visible threshold.  There is a large couch niche (2969) on the northwest wall.

There is a long couch niche along the northwest wall of the room extending from the northeast corner of the room.  Two couch podia are inserted into the niche.  Traces of undecorated plaster survive on the face of the larger - westernmost- podium, and along the junction of the podium to the wall behind.  Traces of plaster also survive on the vertical end faces.  The smaller - easternmost- podium has traces of undecorated plaster on the face and vertical end faces.  Undecorated plaster survives on both the east and west ends of the niche.

column14: (2966)  below the lararium
column21: Earlier excavators report a lararium in this room.  This recessed arch may be the lararium.  In the niche are roof tiles, the neck of an amphora, and a gutter tile.

column14: Hearth (2972) to the south.
column21: Along the north wall to the east of room (5) is a series of eleven planting rows on a north/south axis and abutting the north wall.  The rows extend into the garden to the south and end on line with the south end of room (5).

column14: Planting rows (2971) to the north.
column21: To the south of the stairway at the level of the third step is a small hearth.  The hearth is roughly rectangular in shape on a north/south axis.  In antiquity the sides and probably the top were stuccoed and painted.  Remnants appear on all four sides.

column14: Triclinium ( 2994) to the southwest lararium to the northwest.
column21: The preparation platform abuts the Northwest Wall and the low wall to the southwest that divides it from triclinium 2994.  The platforms rectangular in shape on a southwest/northwest axis.  There is evidence for a stucco covering but none for painting.  However, the low wall to which it abuts on the southwest shows evidence of stucco and red paints. The platform sits on a floor raised above the level of the floor raised above the level of the floor of the room. The floor on which the platform sits was covered by covered by beaten cement.

column14: Triclinium (2998) to the southwest prep platform (3000)to this North west.
column21: Abut in the southeast wall to the northeast of the imus of the triclinium ( 2993) is a rectangularly shaped preparation platform on a southwest/northeast axis.  The surface mean the southeast walls seems to be higher than the rest of the surface but this maybe a result of the preservation. The platform was stuccoed but there is no sign of painting.

column14: Count yard 16 to the south room 18 to the south west, postium 20 to the south east and room 22 to the north east.
column21: Room 19 is the longest dining room of this domestic building. Oriented to the south west to the north east, the room is entered from a narrow entrance doorway at the south end of the southwest wall. On the threshold lies three shapeless blocks of stone.  Along the same wall at the point where it converges with the southeast wall is a column which today only two blocks remain. This column is partially imbedded and forms decorative corner on the outside of the room. Because of the room's very bad condition nothing much is visible today in terms of decorative layers. However the fragments of red paining on the northeast wall and the existence today of a modern protective tarp on the one section of lapilli covered floor ( tarp which likely covers an excavated fragments of mosaic floor) give the idea for the ancient decorated of the room for dining.

column14: The dining room is located east of room 12 and room 13, north of corridor 11, and the atrium, room 7 and east of room 6.
column21: The dining room is entered off the atrium ( room 7) and is entered from a small doorway located on the southwest corner and the south wall. The room is in a poor state of repair with low walls and plaster does not survive except for a small amount of yellow plaster in the north east corner. The rectangular dining room is on a north east south west axis,  Traces of mosaic flooring remain in the northeast corner and consists of red cocciopesto and white tesserae inserted to create a geometric pattern. The rectangular detail located in the northwest corner of the plan and mentioned on the original sheet description 26 does not survive.

column14: The room number 9 is continuous to corridor 11 to the north, room number 15 to the east, room number 10 to the south and room number 7, atrium to the west.
column21: The dining tablinum is located east of the atrium and  is directly visible from the property entrance. The room is on a north east/ southwest axis and is a poor state in general, some restoration to the masonry has occurred  Some traces of an original mosaic floor in red cocciopesto with white tessarae inserted to created geometric patterning. The entry to the dining tablinum is a wider entry on the west wall but no decoration survives. The north wall of the room has the remains of first style wall painting in yellows and reds as well as molding running the upper negiates of the room and fragments of dentil decoration remain. The east wall has suffered a collapse and remains only to a low height with red and yellow wall paining in the north east corner. The south wall has also suffered a collapse and no decoration survives. the ceiling is not present.

column14: Shop 1 to the southwest, open space 5 to the northwest and room 7 to the northeast.
column21: Dining room 6 is accessed from open space 5 to the north through large central entrance. With orientation to the north west and south east , the large rectangular room is in a very bad state of preservation. All of the walls are approximately one meter in height today. The only evidence for wall painting appears in the corner between the northwest and northeast walls. The floor is today covered with Lapilli and piece of rubble and also molded rubbish.

column14: Kitchen 10 to East, space 4 to West, space 8 to South.
column21: Previous sheet 1273 including kitchen with out stone roomThe small rectangular room 11 is accessible from kitchen 10 to the east.Note: on the database this space is considered as part of the kitchen 10; however the dividing wall to the east against the cooking platform clearly delineates the space from the adjoining area.The orientation of the room is east west to north south. The walls show large fragments of plaster, particularly the southern wall is completely  covered with red paint. The wall is more damaged and shows traces of a possible window to the southwest. The floor is today entirely covered with lapilli. Given the large size of the kitchen, which could include also space for the preparation of food (especially in the area delimited by the cooking platform to the west and latrine to the east. Space 11 is likely to have been used for storage.

Rectangular masonry cooking platform along the southeast wall of the room overlies earlier first style decoration. Tile and plaster surface survives in places with possible low molded lip. In the south corner are the masonry and plaster supports for a grill. The fire pit is filled with debris.Attributes: grillCitations: ESCHEBACH 99-100; PPM 329;JASHEMSKI 1979 176-177
Sodo refers to a dining scene painted in this room.  Location in room unknown.  Not possible to enter room.

Low rectangular masonry platform with broad tile rim around the entire platform, square on the outside border surrounding an elliptical opening.  The base of the elliptical opening is masonry.  Placing for charcoal or brazier.  The platform is against the northeast wall, sited between the north corner and the window to Room 9.

column14: Corridor (5)  to southwest.
column21: We enter this garden from corridor 5 to the northeast.  At the end of this corridor we see a wall.  About a third of the wall is preserved with full-sized amphorae.  To the northwest of this wall there is a latrine.  There is a southeast entrance to a rectangular garden.  The walls of the garden are high.

column14: Dining Room 15 to the northwest.
column21: The niche is inserted into the southeast wall of Dining Room 15 at approximately 1.4 meters above the floor.  It is a trapezoidal shape and its walls are covered with plaster.  The back wall shows two small circular holes which are on the some axis and about 40 centimeters apart from each other.  The function of these holes is difficult to ascertain- maybe for supporting hooks?  On the bottom of the niche is a well-preserved marble shelf at the front edge.  The back area of the shelf is covered with lapilli.

column14: Corridor 18 to the south.  Storeroom 14 to the northeast and Room 12 to the southwest.
column21: This sheet replaces #1264.Kitchen 13 is entered through Corridor 18 to the southern corner.  It is a small rectangular room oriented southeast/northwest.  The only totally preserved wall it to the northwest.  On the same wall is a long rectangular window above the cooking platform.  This looks out into Dining Room 11 of the house at 6,2,27.  The floor is covered with lapilli.

column14: Kitchen 13 to northeast.
column21: The cooking platform rests against the southwest wall of Kitchen 13.  This wall is almost all gone.  The long rectangular top surface shows very few remains of terra cotta tiles on the western half.  On the eastern section the tiles are covered by a thin layer of grayish porous material.  Underneath the surface is a large, semicircular opening for the storage.  The outer arch of the storage space is supported by a row of vertical terra cotta tiles.

column14: Kitchen 13 to southwest.  Kitchen 8 and Preparation Room 7 of the house at 6,2,27.
column21: This replaces sheet #1266Storeroom 14 is accessible from Kitchen 13 to the south.  The orientation is southwest/northeast.  It is a small rectangular room the southeast corner of which is occupied by the termination of the southwest wall of the adjoining Kitchen 13.  The layout of this wall termination does create a recess on the northwest side of the storeroom.  The delimiting walls of the room are preserved at varying heights and the floor is covered with lapilli and a sloping pile of building debris in the northwest corner.

column14: Corridor 3 the the southeast.  Atrium 5 to the southwest and the street to the northeast.
column21: This replaces sheet #45Room 4 is a long rectangular room oriented northeast/southwest.  It is entered from a medium-sized door of Atrium 5 to the southwest.  The preserved condition of this room is very bad due to the collapse of the dividing wall between Room 4 and Corridor 3.  Also, the northeast wall  flanking the street is also collapsed.  The floor is covered with high piles of rubble and scattered large stone blocks.  The northwest wall, which contains the niche for the couch, is the only wall which appears less damaged.  It shows large fragments of white, blue and red painted plaster, but they also appear on the southwest wall framing the door and what is left of the southeast wall.  The remaining northeast wall shows evidence of a square opening which likely was a window looking out on the adjoining street.

column14: Dining Room 4 to the south.
column21: The niche for the insertion of the dining couch in recessed into the northwest wall of the Dining room 4.  It is approximately 1 meter high.  The back wall is partially plastered in red.  Based on evidence visible today the northeast side wall of the niche continues into the northeast wall of the Dining Room.  At the southwest side wall of the niche, on the contrary, the recessed area is fully evident in the northwest wall

column14: The niche in Room 2 is located in the west corner of the room on the northwest wall.  Northwest of the couch niche 1600.
column21: A rectangular cupboard niche is located in the northwest was at the west end of the room.  This niche has been created by closing up a doorway between Rooms 4 and 1.  The original  height of the niche is not discernible.  Yellow plaster survives on the southwest and northeast walls of the niche with red banding in the corners.  The full height of the niche is not discernible.

Inside the northeast and southeast walls is a gutter surfaced with a waterproofed  stucco.  The gutter beginning in the north corner runs northwest/southeast until it reaches the east corner  where it turns at a right angle towards the southwest.  In the south corner it empties into a drain located beneath the large puteal. In the east corner to the west of the gutter is a construction of unknown use that slopes strongly from west to east, opening towards the gutter.

In the south/southeast corner of the garden there is a raised area.  Eschebach reported an open air triclinium. In 2011 the area is obviously higher than the rest of the garden. There is a  large tree where there might have been a table.

column14: Preparation platform 3003 is southwest.
column21: On the northwest side of the pillar in the north west wall below a painting of a garland are 2 cornucopia in a heraldic placement flanking an elaborate caduceus. At the top of each cornucopia is a lid on each side of which are items by food, such as cherries, perhaps figs, pomegranates and eggs? Each cornucopia is similarly decorated.

column14: mill/oven room 1 to northwest
column21: Space 2 is a very large rectangular room which is oriented northwest to southeast.  The floor of the room, which today is covered with vegetation and lapilli, is about 5 cm above the adjoining mil/oven room. The threshold is covered by one rectangular slab of volcanic material, which shows a fracture. The walls are not completely preserved to the northeast and northwest, while the walls have been restored to the southwest and northwest in their entire height. A number of holes of different size, shape and height appear on these restored walls, but at this stage, following modern construction, it is difficult to assess their function. The processing room contains a latrine and preparation platform.

column14: to south of room 2 which contains latrine to the north
column21: The preparation platform lies in the corner between the southeast and southwest walls. It is in very bad condition today. What is left is a low structure sloping down toward the middle of the room. The top is covered with moss with very few fragments of terracotta.

column14: Room one (1) is contiguous to room four (4) in the east and room two (2) to the south.
column21: The mill oven room is access from the southwest stress side entrance and is on a northwest east to southwest axis. The large rectangular room contains three mills and a single meta, and a large beehive oven and water feature - other. The west area of the room is entered through a wide entrance with a threshold containing a shutter channel and out of hours entry door typical of commercial properties. Immediately southeast of the threshold is an entry to room two (2) processing room with a volcanic stone threshold. The three mills are aligned to the northwest side of the room with the first mill closest to the west corner and the other two mills located northeast of the first. The third mills is located in the enter of the room. Surrounding each mills are paving stones used by animals for turning the mills. Small buttresses or short walls are located in the middle of the room with one on the northwest wall and one on the southwest wall. Southwest of this buttress on the southeast wall is located a meta, possibly not in its original position. In the east end of room one (1) is located the oven in the north corner along the northeast wall and a doorway on the northeast wall in the east corner. Partially obscuring the doorway on the north east wall is a masonry platform for stairs which includes a reused threshold stone at the base. The doorway on the northeast wall contains a segmented threshold in stone and a modern wooden lintel, immediately above which are three round beam holes and a window. The water feature is-other is located in the north corner in front of the oven. The ancient floors of the mill oven floor are obscured by lapilli with exception to the volcanic stones surrounding the mills. The property has received extensive restoration especially the pastry walls shared with the property 6-2-4 which was bombed in WW II. Trace of plaster survive in the northeast end of room one(1) on the the northeast wall and the southeast wall but the colors and decoration are not discernible. A small window is located at the top of the southeast wall, in the middle. There are four beam holes present on the southeast wall, one at the upper floor at the southeast end of the wall, one at the ground floor level of the south wall, the middle of the wall, two (2) at the southwest wall, one at ground level and one at upper floor level. There are three beam holes located on the northwest wall, one north of the most northeasterly mill, one in the middle of the wall between middle and most northeasterly mills, and one behind the middle mill.

column14: The oven (6083) is located in the north corner of room mill-oven room (6082) is contiguous to (6084) water, other.
column21: House of Sallust. A beehive oven with chimney is located in the north corner of the mill oven room. The mill oven room is located northeast of the property entrance. The oven is visible from the street. The oven has received extensive restoration to both the oven and the chimney. The northwest opening of the oven consists of a large arch leading into a forecourt area with passthrough northeast of which is the entry into the oven which could be closed off with a door. Beneath the large arch is a small archway for fuel storage and or ash waste. The passthrough is accessed from the southeast side of the oven front beneath a semi-arched opening. The floor of the passthrough and the forecourt area are covered with bricks and the same is located on the floor in the archway. No decoration or plastering survives on the front of the oven. The oven chimney is located above the forecourt area of the oven for smoke to rise out of the property area. The chimney of the oven has been heavily restored where it consists of masonry construction with a terra cotta exhaust pipe at the top. The rectangular opening at the beehive oven area consists of volcanic stone leading into a floor paved with terra cotta bipedales and the interior of the beehive oven remains intact.

column14: The water feature is located northwest of the oven 6083, in the northeast corner of room one (1), and is east of the mill 6085.
column21: Water feature other (6084) is circular in shape with flat walls on the body and a handle located on south side of the vessel which probably replicated on the opposite side but has broken off. The interior of the water feature appears to be bowl shaped but is obscured by lapilli. The water feature is constructed of volcanic stone and is likely to be located in its original position in the north corner of the room in front of the oven.

column14: The mill 6085 is contiguous with mill 6086 to the west and the oven 6083 to the east.
column21: Mill 6085 is the most northeast of the three mills within the mill oven room. The mills is surrounded by volcanic paving stones. The mills base is circular but has been restored. No lead covering remains. A partial catillus is seated upon a meta, both of which are constructed in volcanic stone. The typical two holes for the turning apparatus survives in the catillus but no metal survives.

column14: The mill 6086 is located east of mill 6085 north of meta 6088 and west of mill 6087.
column21: The middle mill is located between the most easterly and most westerly wall surrounded by volcanic stone paving. The base of the mill is circular and has been restored. The meta of the mill is located on top of the mill base but the catillus is missing. The meta is constructed from volcanic stone.

column14: The mill 6087 is contiguous to mill 6086 to the east and entry to the property to the west.
column21: The mill 6087 is located in the northeast corner of the room, northeast of the threshold and west of mill 6086. The mill is surrounded by volcanic paving stones and is circular in shape and has been restored. The meta is located on top of the mill base but no catillus survives. The meta is constructed of volcanic stone.

column14: Mill 6088 is located south of mills 6086 and 6086 and is located in the southeast corner of the western most half of room one.
column21: The mill 6088 is a meta stone which is not in situ and is located in the southeast corner of the western half of room one (1) and was possibly part of a small hand rotary mill. The meta is circular in shape with an opening in the center at the top for the mill furniture. The meta is approximately 60 cm in height.

column14: mill room 3 to southwest with oven to northwest
column21: Storeroom 4 is entered from a very narrow corridor to the southwest between a flight of stairs and the oven. The orientation of this room is southwest to northeast. The threshold is marked by a block of volcanic stone which is about 30 cm high above the floor of the adjoining corridor, while the top of the stone is on the level of the storeroom. The floor is today covered with lapilli. The walls are preserved at different heights. The northwest wall contains a rectangular recess which is about 25 cm deep. Because of the location next to the oven and mill room, the room might have been used for storing wheat or bakery products.

column14: to the south room 3 which contains preparation platform on the opposite side
column21: The latrine is in the northern corner of the room. What is hardly visible today are two shapeless stone fragments, which slope down toward the middle of the room and frame a rectangular space which is now covered with lapilli. On the top of the framing fragment toward the northwest wall is a large terra cotta tile with high edges above which a modern drain pipe running along the northeast wall to its entire height.

column14: Rooms 14 and 6 are to the south.
column21: Casa del triclinio all'aperto. Large garden occupying the remainder of the insula to the northwest of the house. The garden is planted with grape vines. Trace of plaster survive along the south wall of the garden on either side of the doorway to room six (6). Red lower register. Pressing tank and dolium (3045) lie to the southwest of the entrance to six (6). In the southwest corner of the garden are the remains of two internal walls that only survive at the junction with the southwest wall. The exterior walls of the garden are extensively restored. In the southwest corner there is a large pile of earthen and ceramic debris. Against the west wall there is the poorly preserved remaining reside of a wall surviving only where it abuts the west wall. Eschebach shows several poorly preserved rooms in this area of the garden. Immediately to the northwest are the remains of a small square room with access to the east. Plastered steps up to the floor of the room and the two masonry supports for a latrine against the wall. In the northwest corner there is a poorly preserved masonry altar (3046)  and a deep rectangular cistern directly in the western corner of the garden. One rectangular window in the west wall above the cisterns and two plastered windows. Entrance six in the east wall opens out to the street and the palestra in the southeast corner. There is a blocked doorway with modern lintel opening east to the street. High step and narrow doorway to storeroom 14. Eschebach calls the cistern at the northwest corner a piscina. Jashemski says that it was probably originally planted with vines.

column14: Rooms (4) and (7) are to the southwest.
column21: This rectangular garden has a northeast/southwest axis contiguous with dining garden (4) to the southwest and kitchen (7) to the southeast. In the southwest corner water feature (2980) extends into the garden a square basin and drain from the floor above. Undecorated plaster is present in south corner of the room. In the east corner there is a square plastered water basin into which a terra cotta pipe drains through the wall to the east The exterior face of the basin is plastered with yellow paint. In the west corner there are traces of plaster decoration on two registers. Altar and lararium  niche (2982)  in the west corner. East floor Jashemski does not refer to any aspect of the garden.

Rectangular tufa altar with lipped and sculptured top. The northeast and south sides are undecorated. The west side is decorated with a club carved in relief. The altar abuts directly against the northeast wall in the garden. Above the altar is an arched recessed lararium niche. Undecorated plaster survives. Four holes have been cut into the plaster floor in the niche. Three of the holes abut directly against the rear wall. In front and below the niche a tile has been embedded, extending out in front of the altar. The tile is plastered. No trace of decoration.

There is a large rectangular masonry cooking platform running along the entirety of the northwest wall on east/northwest and west southwest axis. The platform is a tiled surface preserved throughout. At the west/southwest end there is a low step down in the surface of the platform to a semi circular tile and plaster water basin that extends into the adjoining southwest wall. At the base of the basin a small terra cotta pipe drains through the southwest wall to the room to the southwest. In the northwest corner of the platform directly adjoining the basin there is a square masonry oven. Super structure has been restored. Interior semi circular cooking chamber constructed of tile and masonry upper courses. masonry modern construction? The base of the cooking chamber is tiled.

column14: Garden (6) to the southeast.
column21: The rectangular room is on a northeast/southwest axis. A doorway is in the east corner with modern lintel. The northeast wall is extensively restored. Traces of undecorated plaster on the northwest wall. There is a hole in the west end of the southwest wall through to adjoining room. The southwest wall is restored. The southeast wall is restored. The opus signinum floor throughout is partially obscured by moss.  There is an opus signinum threshold as well. The large masonry cooking platform and hearth extend along the entire northwest wall (2984). A Base of a poorly preserved semi circular feature is in the south  corner of the room and the  Function is unknown.

column14: Horticultural (10) to the north east, room (6) to the south west.
column21: We enter from the south west; to the east there is a high step to a food shop. WE walked into a space that was once an atrium; it has now two benches, triclinium masonry (U-shaped). Then we see to the east an elaborated first style painting and a large entrance to a dining tablinum. We then pass an open air rectangular garden area with a northwest/southeast axis. There is a medium size door  with a high large threshold. To the north there is a large entrance to a horticultural area. This space is a large room with four U-shaped benches triclinium masonry benches. Three of these have tables. There are open spaces separating each pair of benches. there are high walls both sides of the neighbors. In the east wall that separates the garden there is a high lararium niche. There is a possibility of an even higher up lararium in this wall but it doesn't have the supporting brick. The floor of this room is lapilli. In the entrance to the horticultural space there is a brick demarcation in the floor.

column14: The cooking platform is located along the south west wall of room 8, the kitchen, south west of the arched niche located in the kitchen space.
column21: The cooking platform is a small rectangular platform along the southwest wall abutting the north wall with an arched fuel storage niche beneath. The platform is in poor condition and the arched opening has begun to collapse. Because of the condition it is not possible to know what exactly the surface is covered with. A marble sill has been inserted into the floor within the arched opening.

column14: 2990 bench triclinium masonry to the northwest; 2989, to the north bench triclinium masonry; 2987 bench triclinium masonry to the northeast
column21: Running along the neighboring wall to the south east there is a free standing bench triclinium masonry. It has a large rectangular table in the middle. In an effort to understand it we had eighteen staff members comfortably seated on these benches. Between this bench and the next bench triclinium there is a small pillar. (remains)

column14: Bench triclinium masonry: to the south west 2988; to the northwest 2989; to the west 2990
column21: Replicate almost exactly the 2988 feature. One side of the triclinium bench opens to the room; the other is connected to the neighbors wall to the northwest and the other ruins along the wall to the horticultural space. The end of the bench connected to the horticultural wall shows concrete and bricks.

column14: Porticus of peristyle 22 to northeast, rooms 10 and 11 to the northwest.
column21: Dining Room 31 is oriented northeast to southwest.  The large rectangular room is entered from the southwest porticus of peristyle 22 through a large entrance, which is framed on either side by Doric columns which abut the masonry walls on each side.  These columns are mostly painted with red colors and the lentil of the entrance door, which is almost 4 meters high.  The floor is paved with a coarse earthen material.  The southeast wall shows traces of painting.  On the opposite side, the northwest wall, shows a rectangular recess close to the entrance.  The whole room has been completely reconstructed in modern times.  The entrance is fenced and inside scaffolding is being used to support the walls and ceiling.  On the three walls two pairs of square openings aligned centrally.  Because of their position (not very high from floor), it is not possible to ascertain their function.

column14: The preparation platform is located northeast of the counter and in the middle of room 2
column21: The preparation platform is an irregular shape located in the middle of the room behind the counter.  It consists of two heights indicative of seats or storage.  Platform has been heavily restored with a marble fragment surface and traces of plaster remaining.  The north face of the masonry platform is the side with the lowered surface at the northeast end of the north segment.  Traces of the wall plaster are present here.  The east face of the platform consists of two heights because of the shelf/possible seat, and the south face segment is significantly shorter than the total length of the north face.  The west face of the platform has been fashioned with a right angle inserted (see drawings and photograph.).

column14: benches triclinium masonry: to the southwest #2990; to the south #2988; to the southeast #2987
column21: It is a u-shaped bench triclinium (masonry) with a smaller center table.  the side goes along the horticultural space, the medius is engaged to the wall to northwest and the imus is free standing but connects to the northwest wall.  there is a center table.

column14: Bench triclinium masonry: to the south #2988; to the southeast #2987; to the east #2989
column21: It has one bench opened to the room, one bench along the northwest wall and a bench attached to the preparation room wall.  This u-shaped bench triclinium does not have an extant central table.

column14: Atrium 2 is to the west.
column21: Square tablinum opening out southwest to the atrium.  Restored threshold opus signinum pavement with large numbers of white limestone? inclusions.  In the center of the northeast there is a large low open window looking out to the small garden/courtyard.  Modern lintel on the window in the west entrance.  Modern rood.  First style decoration in white, green, red, and yellow survives extensively.  Traces of plaster molding on the northwest, southwest and northeast walls.  The upper register on the northwest/northeast walls may indicate a false ceiling.  High in the northwest door jamb is a rectangular slot.  However, this slot is not matched by a slot on the opposite jamb.

column14: Room 2, dining room, is located south of the property entrance and corridor  room 1 and east of rooms 3 and 4.
column21: A rectangular dining room on a northwest/southeast axis with an entry on the southwest wall at the north corner of the room.  On the northwest wall is a rectangular niche in a closed up door way in which white plaster remains.  On the northwest wall at the north end are the remains of red plaster.  The northeast wall has the remains of backing plaster in several places and a couch niche 6100 with red plaster inside the niche.  The southwest wall of the room has traces of red paint in the middle of wall.  The southwest wall survives to a very low height.  The room does not survive in a very good condition.  The floor is covered with lapilli and there is no indication of a ceiling left on the walls due to poor conservation.

column14: The niche 6100 is located in the east corner of the room 2 (6099 - Dining Room)
column21: The bench/couch niche is located in the east corner of the room along the northeast wall.  The niche is approximately 50 cm in height and has been recessed into the wall and the red painted plaster interior survives.  Some conservation has been applied.

column14: Room 7 is contiguous to Room 8, the kitchen, to the northwest, Room 6 to the north and room 3 to the east.
column21: The preparation room is a rectangular room off the kitchen room 8 and also accessible from the corridor room 6.  The room survives in poor condition with the remains of the plaster present south corner of the southwest wall (no discernible color).  The southwest wall has the remains of red plaster and close to the entry to the kitchen is a channel cut into the floor for waste disposal.  Traces of plaster remain on the northwest wall.  The floor is covered with lapilli and the walls are at low height with exception to the southeast wall which survives to about 2.5 m with 2 beam holes inserted at east end of southeast wall and approximately 2 m and 2.25m height.

column14: to the SE Kitchen 19
column21: The rectangular cooking platform rests against the N end of the structure aligned with the NE entry to the room.  The opposite short side is in line (on axis) with the semi-column framing the protruding northern section of the NW wall.  The preserved cooking platform appears badly damaged.  The top is covered today with rubble; it slopes down toward the interior of the kitchen.  The SW and SE borders of the platform show fragments of plaster.

column14: Kitchen 19 to NE, dining room 17 to SE, L-shaped garden area 21 to NW and room 28 to SW.
column21: Storeroom 20 is a square room oriented NW by SE.  The eastern end of the NE wall frames the door entrance which is about 1.8 meters high.  On the threshold is evidence of a channel for a sliding door.  The floor paving is compacted earth.  The walls to the SE, the SW and NW are heavily reconstructed in modern times; they show large fragments of plaster.  On the SW wall at about 2.2 meters above the floor are two square openings which appear to be in line with the two square holes on the opposite wall above the entrance.  The holes would hold beams. The NW wall is pierced with a very small opening at about 2.3 meters above the floor and a large rectangular window at approximately 1.4 meters above the floor.  To the W the window is framed by a semi-column which protrudes into the room.  The storeroom today is covered by a roof which is a completely modern reconstruction.  Although the large window and the column make the room an elegant space.  The direct connection with adjoining kitchen suggests the possibility that the room was somehow related to the activity performed in the kitchen.  Given the large size of the kitchen, food could have been prepared and cooked in the kitchen 19 and stored in room 20.

column14: Porticus 18 and kitchen 19 to SW, posticum of 30 to SE
column21: This sheet replaces previous Sheet 1135.Garden 21 is an L-shaped open area with orientation NE/SW.  The corner between the NW and SW walls is occupied by a masonry triclinium.  The floor is today covered by overgrown vegetation.  Along the NW side a colonnade porticus is supported by four columns and a pillar.  The columns frame a low wall which delineates a water channel running along the entire L-shaped section;  however, it is interrupted in the corner which joins the two sides.  In the corner between the NE and SE wall there are two platforms of different heights, the function of which is not certain.  The NE wall shows traces of plaster on its entire length.  Against this wall and very close to the masonry triclinium rests a square pilaster which is about 40 cm high.  The NW wall above the masonry triclinium is entirely preserved; it is decorated with red plaster and at approximately 2.5 meters high two small rectangular openings appear on either side of a rectangular window looking out on the adjoining property.  This section of the wall continues running to the SW but it is not well preserved.  It shows traces of plaster.  The area delineated b y this wall contains two wells which are today covered/protected by a fence.  At the end of this area next to the triclinium is a small structure which appears that could have been used as a support.  The garden area delineated by the colonnade porticus is today ornamented with planters and a vine-covered pergola.

column14: Feature 3000 preparation platform to SWTriclinium 2994 to SWTriclinium 2993 to S
column21: On the N wall as we stand in an area adjacent to the summous of the masonry bench triclinium we see a small raised podium on the floor and we see an aedicular lararium niche.  Beige white plaster is still apparent on the back on half sides and the floor.

column14: Kitchen 7 to the SW, courtyard 6 to the SE and dining room 9 to the NE
column21: Storeroom 8 is entered from courtyard 6 from the SE.  The small squarish room is delineated by walls which are mostly preserved.  The NW and the NE walls show large fragments of plaster.  Today the floor is covered mostly with lapilli and moss on the top of concrete paving.  Against the NE wall and along its entire length rests a long narrow bench like structure.  It is approximately 25 cm high above the ground and 45 cm wide.  This structure may have been used for supporting food containers or other items designed for storage of food and/or drink.  In the corner between the SE and SW walls is a rectangular block of stone which could also have been used for support.  It is a few centimeters higher than the supporting structure on the opposite side.  On the opposite corner between between the SE and NW walls appears shapeless stone feature which seems to be attached to the adjoining supporting structure.  Because of its damaged condition it is difficult to ascertain its function.  As a whole, the size of the room, the wide entrance door, the supporting structure and the proximity to the kitchen suggest the possibility that the room was used for storing food or drink.

column14: Room 1 and 3 to SW.Andron 4 to NETablinum 12 to NE
column21: One enters room 2 from the SW by way of room 1.  The room was originally an atrium but at some point was converted into a dining room with two bench masonry triclinia.  One triclinium lies on the SE side and the other on the NW.  To the NE of the SE triclinium is a dining tablinum, room 12.  To the SW of the NW triclinium is room 3.  Room 3 seems to be a bedroom converted to contain a latrine in the W corner.  To the NE of the NW triclinium is a small preparation platform separated from the triclinium by a small low wall.  On the NE wall above the preparation platform is a lararium.  Walls of the room were stuccoed and painted but little sign of the painting remains.  The floor is indeterminate. To the NE on axis with the entrance to the room is the andron 4 leading to the back of the house.

column14: Triclinium 2993 to NWPreparation platform 3000 to NE
column21: On the SE side of the atrium is a masonry bench triclinium facing o the NE.  The imus abuts and parallels to the SE wall and the medius abuts and parallels the SW wall.  The summus extends towards the NE into the room.  In the middle of the benches is a rectangular -shaped table on a SW/NE axis.  As extant neither the benches nor the table show evidence of stucco or painting.  On the NE end of the imus there is a low platform possibly used for placing a container of some sort.

column14: Triclinium 2993 to SEPreparation platform 3000 to NE
column21: On the NE side of the dining room is a masonry bench triclinium opening to the SE.  The imus abuts and parallels the SW wall and the medius the NW wall.  The summus extends into the room to the SE.  In the middle of the benches is a large rectangular masonry table on a SW/NE axis.  In the N corner where the medius and summus meet both abut a low wall.  As reconstructed the summus appears at a slightly lower level than the medius but this may not have been the case in antiquity.  As extant neither the benches nor the table show evidence of stucco or painting.

column14: Room (12) and room (7) plus room (4) to the northwest.
column21: The garden takes up the entire southeast of the property.  One enters the garden from the northwest through room (7).  The shape of the garden is roughly square although in the north corner it extends along the north east side of the house for a short distance.  On the northeast wall is a large aediculate lararium, in front of which is a small altar.In the northwest corner is a small rectangular pool whose axis is east/west.  The garden is surrounded on all sides by a tall wall.  The interior of this wall and the exterior of the southeast wall of the house is stuccoed and painted.  A small portion of which is still extant in the northwest corner.  On the exterior of the southeast wall of the house is a low masonry bench running parallel to the southeast wall from its northeast end.  Just before it reaches the southwest end it stops.  The rest of the distance to the doorway of room 7 was taken up by a small dolium.  To the southwest of the doorway inside the garden, sitting on a masonry base, bordered with stone is a large dolium.  to the southwest of the dolium is a doorway opening to the northwest to room 4.  From the doorway to room (7) toward the southeast into the garden was a paved walkway about a quarter of the way into the garden, to the southwest of the walkway is the remains of a column base.  If there were a matching column to the north, it is no longer extant.Paralleling the southeast wall of the house is a stone walkway.  On its southwest and northeast ends the walkway turns 90 degrees to the southeast.  The walkway on the southwest end parallels the northwest wall until it reaches to the south east wall.  There appears to have been two rooms, one behind the other in the southwest corner.  In the rooms only a small portion remains.  The walkway on the northeast end runs southeast until it reaches the southeast end of the masonry triclinium where it turns at 90 degree to the southwest and extends to where it meets the central walkway.

column14: Room 15 is contiguous to the peristyle (8) to the west and Room 16 to the north.
column21: This replaces sheet #32.The dining room is on a northwest/southeast axis and is entered off the small garden from the west.  A second door is located on the north wall in the northwest corner.  The north wall has suffered a collapse over the doorway in the northwest corner.  Plaster with white and red paint can be seen in the northwest corner.  The rest of the north wall is covered in plaster but the colors are not visible.  The east wall is entirely covered in plaster although the southeast corner has lost some of this.  There are two holes located on the east wall, one at the northeast end and the other at the southeast end.  These are located approximately 2 meters up the wall.  The south wall is covered in plaster  but no colors are discernible and there is a beam hole located in the southwest corner approximately 1.7 meters up the wall.  The floor has the remains of black and white mosaic tesserae although it is mostly destroyed.  The west wall contains the large opening onto the garden in the middle of the wall. A marble threshold is present inn this entrance with door pivots at both the south and north ends.

column14: Posticum 16 to the south.  Store room 12 to the west.
column21: This sheet replaces sheet #30.Kitchen 13 is entered from posticum 16 to the south.  The medium-sized rectangular room is oriented northwest/southeast.  It contains a cooking platform on the eastern side of the space. It also includes a latrine(14)  to the north of the cooking platform.  The northern and western walls are preserved to about 2.30 centimeters high.  On the top of the northern  wall above the cooking platform is evidence of five rows of rectangular terracotta tiles which are interrupted in the middle with what looks like a window.  On the small wall a farther window opens to the northern end.  It is about 1.7 centimeters above the ground.  On the northern wall is a large fragment of plaster was a few traces of red color.  The eastern side of the southern wall rests against the pillar-like door frame of the back entrance(21).  This wall which is not well-preserved slopes down towards the entrance into the kitchen.
column53: Photo board shows incorrect feature number.

column14: On the eastern side of Kitchen 13.  Latrine to the north.
column21: This replace sheet #1253.Cooking platform is a large structure in the southeastern corner of kitchen (13).  The surface is covered with large irregularly-shaped terracotta tiles.
