Along the eastern and northern sides the edges are raised a few centimeters  above the central area.  They are delimited on the exterior sides by a row of vertical terracotta tiles.  At the bottom of the exterior side of the cooking platform to the south are two deep semicircular niches which were used as ovens.  The oven to the north next to the latrine is blocked by the structure supporting the platform.  The cooking platform is oriented to south/north-east/west.
column53: Photo board shows incorrect feature number.

column14: Cooking platform (6061) to the south.  Room 12 to the west.  Room 16 to the south.
column21: This sheet replaces sheet #31The latrine is located within the kitchen(13), recessed into a niche in the northeast corner of the space.  Above the latrine is a rectangular window beneath which the latrine was located on the east wall in the northeast corner and is on an east/west axis.  Little survives of the latrine.  No seat niches or marks in the wall plaster can be discerned.  No plaster survives in this area at all.

column14: Room 13 to the east.  Room 16 to the south.  Room 11 to the west.
column21: This replaces sheet #1254.Room 12 is a store room on a northwest/southeast axis of the kitchen (13).  An entry from the kitchen into the store room is present on the east wall of the store room at the southeast end.  The north wall has suffered a collapse and survives to only about 1 meter in height.  The east wall has suffered collapse and survives at its' highest point to approximately 1/2 meters.  The south wall has the remains of plaster within a recessed area of a closed doorway.  The color is not discernible.  Traces of plaster also survive at the southwest corner.  The west wall has suffered a collapse at the southwest end.  No plaster is visible.  The floor is not visible.

column14: Three couches to the southwest, northwest and northeast.  Garden to the southeast.
column21: The fountain stands in the middle of the masonry triclinium.  The fountain, which is somewhat cylindrical, flares out to a wider base where it rests on a marble-covered floor.  This floor, along with the fountain, is delineated by a marble band on all four sides.  At the bottom of the southwest marble band, almost in the middle, is evidence of a drain pipe.  The location of this pipe at the bottom of the marble recessed floor, along with the hole piercing the top center of the fountain, suggests that the whole central area of the masonry triclinium was decorated with a fountain in the middle of a rectangular pool.  However, as it is not possible to verify the water system of this area, the high marble structure which has been described as a fountain might have been used as a support for a table instead.

column14: Room 6 to the north.  Room 7 to the east.  Room 4 to the south.  Room 2 to the west.
column21: This small room may have acted as a small passageway between rooms 4 (counter room) , room 7 (dining other) and room 6 (store room ), but may have also been used for drinking and eating goods for sale from the counter room.  The room is on a north/south axis with the main entry way on the south wall onto the atrium, with secondary walls on east, west and north walls.  From the counter room, rooms number 5 and 7 are visible.  On the south was is a large doorway with the remains of plaster in the southeast corner, otherwise no plaster on this wall.  On the west wall towards the southwest end is a small marrow doorway.  No plaster remains on this wall.  On the north wall a doorway is located on the west end.  No traces of plaster survive on this wall.  On the east wall a door is located a door is located on the southeast end, and traces of plaster with traces of yellow pigment.  The walls and ceiling of this room have been heavily reconstructed.   The lintels are of modern concrete construction.  The floor appears to be of basic plaster construction.  Traces remain at the southwest end of room between doorways on the west and south walls.  A marble threshold is present in the south doorway.

column14: Preparation room to the east.
column21: One enters the press room from the north through the wide door.  The walls were stuccoed and painted, but little remains.  In the east wall near the southeast corner is a large window overlooking the processing room (3).  The floor is made of opus signinum and slopes slightly south to north so that the grape juice flows into the rectangular vat located in the northeast corner of the room.  The vat has a central wall dividing the vat into 2 unequal parts.  The entire west part of the room is taken up by the horizontal beam press (not extant).  A low wall runs north/south along the side of the vat for approximately four to five feet beyond the south end of the vat, at which point it turns sharply west and extends to the west wall.

column14: Channel 2957 to the northwest.
column21: Ten dolia arranged in two lines of five along the northeast/southwest sides of the room.  The dolia are embedded to the depth of the base of the rim.  The rim survives on four of the dolia of the northeast side and four of the dolia on the southwest side.  Several of the dolia have been repaired in antiquity with lead joints.  On the northeast line, the second dolium to the south is stamped - "ROTIC.SC(?)."  The third dolium to the south has an illegible rectangular stamp.  On the southwest line, the second dolium from the south is stamped - "EROTIC. . ." .  Both dolia then appear to be manufactured by the same person or workshop.

column14: Treading vat? to the east
column21: The horizontal beam press is no longer extant, but the holes for its parts remain. A square hole  for the pier is located at the back and is used to anchor the south end of the beam.  In front on the north side of the low wall that runs east to west are two holes to support the beams that anchor the north end of the beam.  To the north of and located between those holes is a larger hole, square in shape, into which a weight could fit to help add pressure to the beam as it squeezes the grapes placed in a basket beneath the beam to the rear.

column14: Olive/grape press (2955) to the south.
column21: The rectangular plastered vat is embedded into the floor in the north corner of the room. Above the vat on the north and east walls, there is a placing for an unidentified lid or cover.  Remains of a partition wall, poorly preserved, divide the vat in two.  At the base of the east wall, there is a small terra cotta out pipe that drains through the wall into channel(2957) in processing room (3). In the northeast corner of the east wall, a large semicircular recess from the vat into the wall may be from collapse.

column14: Dolia (2954) to the east.
column21: The wine channel is narrow, raised, and plastered and runs along the southwest wall of the room from the northwest.  At the west end there is a drain from the vat in the pressroom (4).  In the external face of the channel, three lead pipes (the fourth of which is no longer visible,) drain into the adjoining dolia.  The channel was used to drain the wine from the press room.

column14: Room (8) to the west
column21: One enters the triclinium (9) from the hallway (8) to the west.  The room is rectangular in shape on a northeast/southwest axis.  The doorway is rather wide.  In the northwest wall near the entrance is a niche for a cupboard.  In the north and east corners, near floor level,  are couch niches.  The east niche is longer than the north niche.  The walls show evidence of having been plastered, but no paint survives.  In AD 79, the niches in the east and north walls had been plastered over.  Evidence for this in both cases is the surviving plaster.  The floor is indeterminate, as is the height of the walls.

column14: Room (8) to the northeast
column21: This space has been determined to have been a dining garden.  One enters from the northeast doorway and passes a low wall on the northeast.  In the southwest corner there is a masonry triclinium.  Signs of a wall to the northwest are apparent.  There is a long high southwest wall with two small window vents.  There is also evidence of a dolium water spout.  The southwest wall has two buttresses.  In front of the wall are two cement covered cisterns.  In between is a modern cement covered well (?).  "Spano reports between the south wall and the rest of the space filled high with soil.  He reports that the longitudinal furrows indicated a kitchen garden.  The east wall is tall and takes a dog leg turn and runs to the north.  There are small cavities for pergola post in front of the triclinium."  Ellis indicates a small, connecting pool in the northwest corner of the room to (8), (7),  and (10).  Along the south wall, the ground is raised perhaps indicating the furrows described by Spano.
Eschebach pp. 389-90.

column14: Corridor (14) to the northwest.
column21: The room is rectangular and runs along a northeast/southwest axis.  There is a wide doorway at the northeast end of the northwest wall. No visible threshold survives, and the northeast and southeast walls are extensively restored.  The southwest wall is almost completely modern.  The floor is completely obscured by earth and vegetation.  Some structural debris is in the northeast corner.  There is an opening at the west end of the northwest wall which is modern collapse.

column14: Corridor (8) to the northeast.
column21: One enters the space from a long corridor to the northeast. On the northwest a long wall separates the space from the other section of the structure.  At the top of the wall there is white plaster.  Three/fourths of the way up, the south wall of the gladiator barracks is visible.  There is a small northwest wall quadrant that backs up to the barracks.  A southwest wall also backs up to the barracks.  The south wall is adjacent to the triclinium dining garden (2889) in (8.7.6.).  The south wall ends in line with the neighbor's triclinium.  There is an east wall which connects to the south wall and separates an unroofed space.  The area in one spot shows a peach plaster along the bottom of the northwest wall.  A garden is reported along the north wall and southwest wall in an L-shape and communicates with the garden triclinium area in the adjoining property.

column14: Room (8) to the northwest
column21: The room is small and square with an entrance at the east end of the north wall.  The floor is obscured by lapilli, and there is no extant wall decoration.  The north and west walls are preserved to a foot and a half.  Eschebach refers to a cistern identified as a pile of rubble and the adjoining west wall in room (8).  Eschebach refers to a non extant lararium (2899) and a cooking platform (2900)

column14: Back entrance (17) to the west, space (19) and corridor (20) to the south.
column21: Kitchen (18) is entered from corridor (12) to the west, and corridor (20) to the southwest.  It is a small square room which is provided with a large preparation platform against the north wall.  Adjoining the preparation platform is a latrine to the west.  The preserved walls on the eastern, western,k and northern sides are approximately two meters high.  The roof is missing.  The floor is now covered with lapilli with no trace of the original paving.  Traces of plaster are visible on the lower zone of the western wall.  A small rectangular window opens on the top of the northern wall above the preparation platform.

column14: The preparation platform is south of room (17) which has entrance (23) in it.  It is east of corridor (20) and east of room (19).
column21: The masonry preparation platform has a top surface constructed of broken bricks.  There are no fuel arched beneath.  A small window is directly above the preparation platform.  The platform is located on the east wall in the southeast corner of the room abutting the south wall.  The latrine (6030) is located to the north of the cooking platform and the two are divided by a wall.

column14: Courtyard (12) to the southwest.
column21: Dining room (13) is entered from the courtyard (12) to the southeast.  It is a medium-sized rectangular room oriented southeast/northwest.  The threshold is framed by a marble rectangular stone to the northeast.  Evidence shows of the opening for the bolt to be inserted.  To the southwest of the threshold a low rectangular piece of stone leans against the southwest wall of the doorway frame.  The floor is paved with a polychrome mosaic which is badly preserved.  What is visible today is a u-shaped section which contains irregularly-shaped marble panels of white, pink, red, and black, on a white background.  This section is framed by a large white band and two black thinner bands. In the middle of the floor is a larger rectangular panel which is framed by a two-strand guilloche in red, yellow, white, and black. The decorative motif in the middle is completely destroyed.  On the northeastern side, the floor slopes down toward a pipe pierced at the bottom of the wall.  The walls of this very well-preserved room are decorated with fourth style painting.  The lower zone in black motifs:  the ones best preserved show female figures holding trays.  On either side of this figurative panel is a vase framed by a garland.  The middle zone contains three large rectangular panels containing in the middl figurative emblema.  The only best-preserved ones are on the northwestern wall. They represent from left, a semi-naked boy riding a horse, a female figure with traces of a child and a man, and a similar semi-naked boy on a horse.  Fragments of architectural structure are evident on the border framing the panel in the northwestern and southeastern corners.  in the upper zone, individually-placed female figures decorate, but in this section, the wall painting is badly decayed.  On the top of the upper zone runs a stucco cornice which is only partly preserved along the northwest and northeast walls. On the very top of the northwestern and southeastern walls below the reconstructed roof are two large rectangular windows.
column53: Overview of room (6057) with detailed shots of center (6057-1), left lower wall (6057-2),left upper wall (6057-3), right lower wall (6057-4), left lower wall (6057-5).

column14: Vineyard to the northwest and palestra to the southwest.
column21: The open space between the amphitheater to the southeast and the vineyard to the northwest was probably denoted at least partially to the sale and the consumption of food and drink.  The basis for this conclusion derives from the painting "Riot in the amphitheater" presently located in the archeological museum in Naples.  The painting, while it shows men fighting, also shows what are clearly temporary structures, tents or awnings used for the sale of items.  That food could have been served in these temporary structures is strengthened by the fact that the vineyard to the northwest had a triclinium just inside the wall that no doubt served spectators.  Although the painting shows only the space described above, there could have been temporary structures in the area between the amphitheater and the palestra to the southwest.

column14: Street to the northwest and southwest, back entrance/living space 2 to the southeast and space of 6.2.2 to the northeast.
column21: (Replaces sheet 21)Counter room 1 is entered directly from the street to the northeast through a doorway which is about 70 centimeters wide.  The large square room is oriented northeast/southeast.  The central area of the room is occupied by an L-shaped counter.   Opposite the counter in the southern corner is the entrance into room 2 which was used also as a back entrance.  The floor is covered with lapilli.  The preserved walls are mostly reconstructed today.  On the southwestern wall are large fragments of plaster.  On the corner between the southwestern and northwestern wall the section is built with terra cotta bricks.  The same structural material appears on the eastern side of the southeastern wall opening onto room 2.  On the northeastern wall are fragments of pinkish plaster, of a lararium 1.40 centimeters above the ground floor, and a small square opening at the bottom leading onto the adjoining space of 6.2.2.  Along the northwestern side of the counter room are the entrance and the counter.  On either side are large blocks of tufa.

column14: The counter room is contiguous to rooms 2 and 3 to the east of the property and south of room 4 within 6.2.2, accessed by the passthrough from room 1.
column21: (Replaces sheet 21)The counter is u-shaped with 6 recessed dolia; a hearth is located at the east end with a support for cooking apparatus above, level with the counter surface.  The counter has been heavily restored, with the marble segments repainted in their original positions.  However, on the south arm of the counter, towards the east end, the marble segments do not survive.  The hearth has also been heavily restored.  The rim of only 1 dolium survives on the northeast arm of the wall, and the bodies of 2 dolia are visible in the interior of the counter shape.  The bodies of the 6 dolia are still visible despite not having rims.  The interiors of the dolia are filled with lapilli.  The hearth located at the east end of the south arm of the counter is slightly offset in alignment.  Because the hearth has been heavily restored it is difficult to be certain if this is the original slate.  The base of the hearth survives with cocciopesto and broken tegula comprising the floor of the hearth.  Signs of burning are present within the hearth.  The marble segments on the top of the counter consist of giallo antico, cipollino, luna, black africanus, red porphey.

column14: The lararium is contiguous to the counter in room 1 and the low opening/passthrough between rooms 1 and 4.
column21: (Replaces sheet 21)The lararium is rectangular and recessed into the middle of the north wall and adjacent to the north arm of the counter.  The lararium is covered in white plaster with green bands in the corners.  However, the rest of the wall painting is not discernible.  The sill and the top of the lararium are not present.

column14: Room (7) contiguous to (6) to the north;  (8) to the east;  (4) to the south;  room (5) to the west.
column21: This dining room other opens out into the atrium on a north-south axis with a large opening on the south wall.  A second doorway is located in the southwest corner of the west wall.  A small window is atop the north wall.  Yellow, red and white painted plaster is present on all the walls but but does not have scenes on the walls.  A molding was present on top of the walls, and traces remain today, but the ceiling is a modern reconstructed one.  The lintels are modern concrete.  The threshold on the south wall is marble and indicates bifold doors.  The ancient floor is not visible.  The room is located northeast of the primary entrance and was accessed from the counter room (2) through room (5) to the east of room (7).

column14: Porticos 18 to northeast, Dining room 17 to the southeast, and store room 20 to the southwest.
column21: Kitchen 19 is a square room oriented northeast by southwest.  The larger entrance from porticos 18 to the northeast does not show any trace of the threshold.  At the northern edge of the entrance (to the right) and aligned with the opening is the cooking platform.  In the southwest corner of the room  along the bottom of the southwest wall runs what looks like a rim, slightly raised above the floor.  At the "rim" on the western wall seems to be a semicircular small opening which could have held a drain pipe.   The whole corner may have been occupied by a latrine, but the evidence is too poor to support this suggestion.  The room shows traces of a coarse earthen floor.  The walls on the southwest, northwest and the southeast sides have been heavily reconstructed, along with the roof.  On the southwest wall, at approximately 2.2 meters above the floor, are two square holes which could have supported the beams of a roof.   On the north end of the northwest wall a section is framed by a semi-column.  This section protrudes into the room and shows traces of red painting.

column14: northwest to room (45).
column21: This small square room was added in final phase into the large shop room (45). The floor is obscured and north and west walls survive to only half height.  The east and south walls contain 2 square windows, both plastered and with modern lintels (Decoration or discoloration to plaster to window in east wall).  Doorway to Room (45) in north end of northwest wall without threshold.  Plaster survives on all 4 walls, continuing the decorative scheme of room (45), with black lower register, and alternating red and yellow panels above.

column14: Room 2 is contiguous to Room 4 (atrium) and room 5 (dining other) to the east. It is also contiguous to Room 1 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room on a NE/SW axis with main shop entry to the west and a large opening to the fauces on the south as well as a large opening onto the atrium to the east and a small opening onto the dining other to the east.  Within the room is a large U-shaped counter with a small hearth; 6 dolia have been inserted into the counter.  A preparation platform is situated in the middle of the room behind the counter.  Both counter and preparation platform are covered in marble and have been reconstructed.  The property was bombed in WW II and has been heavily reconstructed.  No wall plaster survives.  The west entry to the counter room contains a marble threshold (3 segments).  The original floor is not visible and the  ceiling has been reconstructed.

column14: The counter is located in room 2 at the South, Southeast and Southwest ends and is contiguous to the preparation platform to the Northeast.
column21: The U-shaped counter, located within the counter room contains 6 dolia of which 2 are inserted into the west arm opening to the street, and 4 on the south arm opening to the fauces 1, with a small hearth jutting out off the south arm.  The counter is constructed of masonry with a marble top.  On the west arm the exterior face of the counter is also covered with marble fragments.  The counter as a whole has received extensive restoration efforts, but it is still possible to note that the marble has been reused here, possibly a sill. This consists of various types of marble. On the west arm, two dolia are present with rims missing, and the east side of the west arm has collapsed so that it is possible to see a roof tile (modern) inserted into the masonry.  The four dolia located on the south arm are also missing rims, but within each hole fragments of terracotta dolia are visible.  The small hearth located at the east arm's end is a small U-shaped insertion into the counter.   A terracotta surface of the counter is visible inside the hearth.

column14: Garden 21 is to the South.
column21: Previous sheet #1135Masonry triclinium in space 21 is a U-shaped structure with the northeast side shorter than the opposite side to the southwest. Facing southeast, the masonry triclinium occupies the corner between the northwest and southwest walls of the garden.  The couches are covered by a thick layer of cocciopesto on the very top surface. The inner sides of the couches are occupied by a rectangular band of which the inner edge is delineated by a row or band of vertical terracotta tiles.  This band, which is about 30 cm wide, was probably used for resting plates.  This same band on the Southwest couch also forms the top of semicircular receptacle which is underneath.  Both the outer and inner sides of the three couches show traces of plaster.  The central area is occupied by four bands covered with marble which frame the fountain in the middle.  The northeast couch, whose top, covered with cocciopesto, is mostly preserved, does not slope outward as much as the adjoining couches.  As the northeast couch is directly attached to the wall, it is not clear how the area was shaded or protected from the elements.

column14: Room 6 (storeroom) is located at the Northwest end of the property with rooms 5 and 7 to the South, and the L-shaped peristyle garden to the Northeast (room 21) and room 30 to the East.
column21: The storeroom is oriented East-West with an entry from the Southwest corner on the South wall and is located Northeast of the primary entrance.  The condition of the room is poor and has been heavily reconstructed.  The floor is not visible and the ceiling is reconstructed.  A window is located in the center of the North wall, at the top, but not at full ceiling height.  Immediately below the window is a possible drain to the adjacent property to the North.  Four beam holes are located on the North wall; two at Northwest end, one in center, and one at East end.  A beam hole (modern?) is located at ceiling level of the East wall with a corresponding beam hole (modern?) at the ceiling level of the West wall.  In the South wall traces of plaster survive from the Southwest corner to the middle of the wall - the color is indiscernible and the plaster is in poor condition.  The entry at the Southwest end of the South wall has the lintel restored.  There are 2 beam holes present.  The top of the wall is at the Southwest end.  The West wall is possible window or collapse.  At the upper part of the wall, 4 beam holes are present: 2 at the South west end and 2 at the Northwest end.

column14: Back entrance (17) to the west, space (19) and corridor (20) to the south.
column21: Kitchen (18) is entered from corridor (12) to the west, and corridor (20) to the southwest.  It is a small square room which is provided with a large preparation platform against the north wall.  Adjoining the preparation platform is a latrine to the west.  The preserved walls on the eastern, western,k and northern sides are approximately two meters high.  The roof is missing.  The floor is now covered with lapilli with no trace of the original paving.  Traces of plaster are visible on the lower zone of the western wall.  A small rectangular window opens on the top of the northern wall above the preparation platform.

column14: The preparation platform is south of room (17) which has entrance (23) in it.  It is east of corridor (20) and east of room (19).
column21: The masonry preparation platform has a top surface constructed of broken bricks.  There are no fuel arched beneath.  A small window is directly above the preparation platform.  The platform is located on the east wall in the southeast corner of the room abutting the south wall.  The latrine (6030) is located to the north of the cooking platform and the two are divided by a wall.

column14: Room 7 to the southwest.
column21: We enter this dining garden from rooms 7 at the end of this commercial structure.  The three walls of the garden are high and show evidence of being heavily reconstructed.  The southwest wall has a large window to a tablinum which once allowed the tablinum to look at the garden.  On the southeast wall we see signs of painted plastered and an opening to a latrine.  Half of the northeast wall is taken by a dining triclinium.  The dining area has a column that is plastered and introduces a wall that separates he dining room area from the garden.  On the northwest wall we see holes that once could have held timber wood.  There is a very large cement root of a big tree close to the northwest wall.  there are 5 small trees lined up at the center of the garden and two trees to the south of the garden.

When excavated forty-three amphorae of various types were found placed on and around the triclinium including dr.1 wine amphora, golbular oil amphora (will check type) as well a third broad-mouthed form with pointed handles (will check type) . Large quantities of amphorae are stored in the area of the atrium and tablinum of the property.

The masonry triclinium is located in the northeast part of the garden.  Each of the three couches abuts a wall.  In the south corner of the  southeast wall and embedded in the wall is a column made of tiles stuccoed and painted. The northwest wall is an extension of the northwest wall of the garden. The couches were stuccoed and on the interior faces of the couches was a series of erotic Nilotic scenes.  On the interior of the summus still extant are pygmies.  On the northwest wall near the north corner are the remains of a garden painting.  The surface of the couches slopes down toward the walls.  In the center of the couches is a large rectangular masonry table on a southwest/northeast axis.  The table was plastered but no evidence of painting remains.  The triclinium appears to have been roofed.

column14: the cooking platform is located along the southwest wall of room (8), kitchen, southwest of the arched niche located in the kitchen space.
column21: The cooking platform is a small rectangular platform along the southwest wall abutting the north wall with an arched fuel storage niche beneath.  The platform is in poor condition  and it is not possible to know what exactly the surface is covered with.  A marble sill has been inserted into the floor within the arched opening.

column14: Room (2). dining room, is located south of the property entrance and corridor room (1) and east of rooms (3) and (4).
column21: A rectangular dining room lies on a northwest /southeast axis with an entry on the southwest wall at the north corner of the room.  On the northwest wall is a rectangular niche in a closed up doorway in which white plaster remains.  On the northwest wall at the north end are the remains of red plaster.  The northeast wall has the remains of backing plaster in several places and a couch niche (6100) with red plaster inside the niche.  The southwest wall of the room has traces of red paint in the  middle of the wall.  The southwest wall survives to a very low height.  the room does not survive in a very good condition.  The floor is covered with lapilli and there is no indication of a ceiling left on the walls due to poor conservation.

column14: the niche (6100) is located in the east corner of the room (2) (6099-dining room).
column21: The bench/couch niche is located on the east corner of the room along the northeast wall.  The niche is approximately 50 centimeters in height and has been recessed into the wall and the red painted plaster interior survives.  Some conservation has been applied.

column14: Room (7) is contiguous to room (8), the kitchen to the northwest, room (6) to the north and room (3) to the east.
column21: The preparation room is a rectangular room off the kitchen room (8) and is also accessible from the corridor room (6).   The room survives in poor condition with the remains of the plaster present in the south corner of the southwest wall (no discernible color).  The southwest wall has the remains of red plaster and close to the entry to the kitchen is a channel cut into the floor for waste disposal.  Traces of plaster remain on the northwest wall. the floor is covered with lapilli and the walls are at a low height with exception of the southeast wall which survives to about 2.5 meters with two beam holes inserted at the east end of the southeast wall and approximately two meters and 2.25 meters in height.

column14: Cooking platform to the southwest.
column21: The latrine is inserted in kitchen (7) opposite the entrance into the room to the northwest, which today is blocked by a low rubble pile.  In this very badly preserved space, the floor is covered with thick soil and stones.  The walls show significant deterioration to the northeast and southeast.

column14: Garden (15) to the northwest.
column21: The storeroom is entered from the garden from the northwest.  the room is rectangular in shape on a northwest/southeast axis.  Neither the type of the floor nor the height of the floor is determinable.  Approximately 40% of the southeast part of the floor has been raised.  the surface of this portion is made of cement with stones embedded.  This floor runs the entire width from the southwest to the northeast.  The walls were stuccoed and painted of which little remains.

column14: Dining couch to the northwest.
column21: This large rectangular pressing vat runs on an northwest/southeast axis.  The masonry walls with opus signinum top are contiguous with the opus signinum lining of the tank.  The tank is filled with earth and vegetation.  The southeast end of the tank abuts directly against the exterior wall of the peristyle garden.  Against the southeast corner is an intact partially submerged dolium.  A puteal has been added to the rim of the dolium encircling the east and south sides constructed of tile and surfaced with opus signinum.

column14: Triclinium 3043 is  is to the east.
column21: The altar is a rectangular masonry structure against the west wall.  There is no exterior facing that survives.  The surface is modern restoration.

One enters the triclinium  from corridor (5) by way of a small doorway in the west corner.  Most of the room is taken up by a masonry triclinium.  There probably was not a ceiling to the room hence open-air.  The floor is at a lower level than corridor (10), and is of beaten cement with fragments of terra cotta.  The lower part of the southwest, southeast, and northeast walls have a lower register in red and on top a black band.  the upper register is unknown because the plaster is no longer extant or the paint is gone.  The northwest wall is defined by a low wall in the center of which is a tall painted rectangular column on a southwest/northeast axis.  Its placement is slightly off-center to the northeast in relation to the triclinium.In the west corner abutting the southwest wall is a rectangular platform on a northwest/southeast axis.  In the middle of the southwest wall is a large window opening onto room (10). most likely into a cistern in Room (2). In the west corner to the southeast of the platform, there is a drain in a southwest direction that seems to lead under room (10). Along the base of the southwest wall is a gutter that leads from this drain towards the southeast where in the south corner a drain leads to the outside of the house. The floor southeast to the northeast such that rain water would flow southeast to northwest.  The rectangular column in the northwest wall is pointed on all four sides.  At the top on all four sides is a garland  On the southeast side clearly visible to diners is a large human figure garlanded man with a right hand raised holding some sort of staff in his left hand  and appearing to be walking.  On the southwest side is another human figure seemingly standing on a pedestal.  His dress is foreign (eastern), and he is holding up the lower portion of his tunic with both hands, displaying his erect phallus.  On the northeast side just below the garland are two figures.  Below the garland is a lyre. Below the lyre is a large black bird standing on a cage.  On the northwest side below the garland are two cornucopia flanking what appears to be a caduceus.

column14: Platform 3003 to the west.
column21: The masonry triclinium open northwest and takes up most of the dining room as extant. The surface is no longer extant but was probably plastered and painted as is implied by plaster on the exterior sides.  The interior sides of each couch contains two storage niches for a total of six.  In the center of the three couches appears to be the remnants of a table.

In the west corner of the room is a rectangular masonry preparation platform on northwest/southeast axis.  The surface was composed of pieces of terra cotta and marble and probably stuccoed as some stucco still survives on the northeast side.

column14: Room (1) to the southwest; room (11) to the south; room (3) to the west; room (4) to the north; room (5) to the northeast.
column21: We enter this home from the southwest  through the 7th doorway from the Nocera Gate.  The wide entrance shows signs of plastered walls. We see a large rectangular room probably a previous atrium. In the center there is an impluvium with a puteal moved to the center of the impluvium.  The room lies on a northwest/southeast axis.  On the west wall a wide and tall room with a threshold.  The northwest wall has a red bottom zone.  The northeast wall has two tall door openings.  On the north corner there is a high window with an arched top.  Looking at the compluvium, which has an incredibly small opening, the masonry around it shows designs.  In the east corner, there is a cooking platform. On the southeast wall there is an entrance with a tall door with a double window.  In 2011, this room is used for storage of small terra cotta materials and amphorae.

In the corner of room (2) we see a large cooking platform.  A large dolium was left next to the west end of the platform.  There is a red bottom zone throughout the room with a black large border which continues over this platform.  A lip is discernible on the  south side (a small portion).  There are two masonry struts probably to hold a grill.

column14: Corridor (5) to the northwest.
column21: This is a rectangular room on a northwest/southeast axis. The plaster floor has been preserved throughout.  In the center of the northwest wall there is a doorway with a modern lintel and no defined threshold. In the center of the northeast wall, there is a large window looking northeast to room (9). Extensive modern restoration is apparent in addition to the modern lintel. Third style painting survives extensively with white panels with green trim and garlands. Green and yellow architectural  elements and black lower register are present.  The figurative and landscape center pieces survive on the southwest wall, including a depiction of tropheum.  High in the northwest and north, molding and the molding for a vaulted ceiling survive,  above which is a placing for joists.  They match two surviving joist holes in the south corner.  In the northwest corner the plaster continues above the height of these joists, indicating a false ceiling. The room is modern.  There is a cooking platform (3007) against the northeast wall.

column14: Atrium (2) is to the northeast.
column21: This is a rectangular room on northwest/southeast axis.  The doorway with modern lintel is in the north corner opening to the atrium (2).  The roof is modern.  In the center of the northeast wall there are two high rectangular windows separated by a stone pillar.  The square hole in the center of the pillar matches a similar hole in the east jamb.  The room is currently used as a storeroom for finds and it was not possible to enter.  The floor appears to be solid.  The walls have plaster in some places. Sodo says that the room was decorated and white panels and that there was a scene of a colloquy.

A large square niche inserted into the wall of the insula is present at the crossroads.  There are traces of plaster which survive on the sides and top rear.  There are no visible decorations, and the niche is arched and the external face of the arch is finished with a brick arch and tile lip.  The niche is two feet above the street level.  There are traces of plaster with red paint surviving at the base of the wall.  the masonry base of the niche is poorly preserved and covered by earth, but may have originally been painted.

column14: Room (1) to the southeast.
column21: The counter room is located to the northwest of room (1).  One enters the counter room from the southeast through a doorway. The smooth floor is slightly lower than that of room (1) and is made of plaster with terra cotta fragments.  The walls were stuccoed and painted with remnants on all four walls.  The ancient ceiling is not extant, but the height appears to be determined by the remnants in the northeast and northwest corner of a molding in plaster.  In the southwest wall is a large doorway opening onto the sidewalk and street.  The function of the room is defined by the L-shaped counter, one arm of which begins on the northwest wall and runs parallel to the street.  Midway in the doorway, the counter turns at a 90 degree angle to the northeast and ends approximately two and a half feet from the northeast wall.

The function of the room is defined by the L-shaped counter, one arm of which begins on the northwest wall and runs parallel to the street.  Midway in the large doorway the counter turns on a 90 degree angle to the northeast and ends approximately two and a half feet from the northeast wall. In the west corner on the northwest end of the counter is a display counter with four steps.  Underneath the counter is an arched opening for storage.  At the northeast end of the arm running northeast/southwest is a large hearth opening towards the northeast.  The hearth extends above the height of the counter and is wider than the width of the counter arm.  The northwest and southeast arms of the hearth extends towards the northeast wall for approximately 18 inches.  Inside the hearth is a low shelf. Extending beyond the raised portion of the hearth is a platform.  this platform also forms the floor of the hearth.  The exterior of the counter including the hearth and step shelves was covered with plaster and painted red, parts of which are still extant.

column14: Other garden (8) to the northeast;  kitchen (7) the southeast; room 5 to the southwest.
column21: This structure is located at the second  north entrance from the Nocera gate.  We enter and pass a northwest room.  There is a storage room to the south.  Continuing,  another northwest room was probably used for food storage or preparation.   This space is a garden dining peristyle.  As we look at the northwest wall, we see a plastered surface behind the triclinium;  it is an orange and red wall.  Facing west, there is a window to the preparation room.  The northwest wall is high.  A third of the space is utilized by a triclinium.  The space is delineated by a clear stone narrow border which separates the dining garden peristyle and the garden with the altar.

Along the west wall there is an elaborated garden triclinium.  The masonry triclinium (1. medius 360m; 1 imus 285, 1 summus 230 - Jashemski).  There is a rectangular table at the foot of the imus (.65 x .69m).  There is a circular table between the benches (.50 m in diameter).  There is a pergola abundantly displaying grapes.  This triclinium back wall shows orange and red painting.

column14: Dining garden (4) to the to the northwest.  Other garden (8) is to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is located to the southeast of the open air triclinium.  There is no way of separating the northeast/southwest axis along the southeast wall.  No part of the kitchen has a ceiling.  At the southwest end between the stairs to the southwest and the cooking platform to the northeast is the latrine.  To the northeast of the latrine is the cooking platform with dual storage areas beneath.  To the northeast of the cooking platform is the water feature.  The water feature is not connected to the cooking platform.  The floor is indeterminate.  The southeast wall was stuccoed or probably painted, although no paint remains.

column14: Cooking platform (2979) to the northeast; water feature (2980) to the northeast.
column21: The latrine is at the southwest end between the stairs to the southwest end and the cooking platform to the northeast.  There is no evidence of a roof.  The walls were stuccoed, although no sign of paint remains.  The floor slopes from the northeast to the southwest and joins in the west corner a gutter that runs southeast/northwest all the way to the northwest wall of the house.

column14: Latrine (2978) to the southwest.  Water feature (2980) to the northeast.
column21: To the northeast of the latrine is the cooking platform.  The cooking platform is constructed of masonry.  Above the platform on the back wall are the remains of plaster, but no paint remains.  The cooking platform is bordered on the southwest and northeast by a wall the height of which is unknown.  The cooking platform has two semicircular storage spaces that extend to the floor.  The surface of the cooking platform is made up of a cement and fragments of stone but with large pieces of terra cotta embedded in no discernible pattern.

column14: Cooking platform (2979) is to the southwest.  Latrine (2978) to the southwest.
column21: There is a rectangular masonry platform on northeast/southwest axis with an elliptical extension to the northwest extending along the southeast wall of room (7) and (8). A circular wellhead is inserted into the center of the platform.  The plaster lining base is obscured by earth.  Adjoining the well to the east is a square plaster-lined basin.  A narrow drain runs on the basin down into the adjoining well.  A terra cotta pipe drains into the basin from the garden to the northeast. Undecorated plaster survives on the exterior face to the northeast.  A terra cotta drain survives against the southeast wall of the basin into which runs a placing for a terra cotta down pipe from the floor above.

column14: Room 10 to the northeast. Room 5 to the northwest.
column21: One enters the triclinium from room 5, through a door in the northeast wall. The triclinium is rectangular in shape on a northwest southeast axis. On the northeast wall is a large window opening into garden 10 The floor is beaten cement with fragments of white and bluish stones. The paintings on all 4 walls are 4th style. The lower register is a combination of plants, amphorae, and outdoor scenes of animals and humans. In the central register are a series of large rectangular frames around either square mythological scenes, floating winged figures (erates?) or small, rectangular frames around birds. The picture on the southeast wall is Venus fishing. On the southwest wall in Europa and the bull. The upper register has garlands and stylized architectural drawings. On the northwest wall, however are still extant 3 fish. The corresponding area of the southeast wall may also have been food-related but is too damaged to be sure. Although the ceiling is not extant, portions of plaster in the east corner indicate the ceiling was fairly low. In addition, the extant plaster  from the northwest and southeast ends indicate the ceiling sloped from southwest to northeast.

column14: Garden 10 to the southeast
column21: Rectangular room southwest/northeast axis. First style decoration survives on the northwest and southwest walls. The west corner of the room has been isolated as a separate room entered from the southeast  by the construction of partition walls. The partition walls abut directly against the first style plaster decoration indicating their posterior construction. Fragmentary floor of opus signinum with traces of geometric decoration in white tesserae, against the southeast wall. In the center of the southeast wall there is a doorway with modern lintel to Room 10. The southeast and northeast walls are extensively restored and the roof is modern. Cooking platform (3026) in the north corner. Latrine (3025) in the north corner.

column14: To the west, cistern 3027, preparation platform 3028 and fish pond 3030. Cistern 3031 and water feature 3033.
column21: Large, U-shaped dining couch facing southwest finished with opus signinum and plaster. The surface of the couches has been extensively restored. There is a low wall restored at the end of lectus summus and imus. The exterior yellow-painted plaster, interior and front plaster blue background with wide red borders, possible traces of red figures. Similar coloring has been seen of Nilotic landscapes on other garden triclinia. Between the arms of the couches there is a plaster circular table with marble top. The floor between couches and in front is opus signinum with large marble inserts. In front of the northern arm there is a terracotta cistern head (3027) and in front of the southern arm a preparation platform (3028).

column14: The room number 10 is contiguous to room 9 to the west and the exterior of the property to the east of room 10 The feature 2998 is located in the southwest corner of room 10
column21: The horticultural space at the northeast end of the property is a large, square space on an east west axis with an opening to the room on the west wall. Within the room in the southwest corner are two masonry tanks with a dividing wall between them (Feature 2998) near to which is a small, masonry square structure and in the southeast corner is a latrine separated from the horticultural space by a low wall. There is a wide opening on the west wall to the horticultural space with the remains of a small threshold. On the north wall two beam holes, one at the northwest end and one at the northeast end; the remains of plaster can be found at the northeast end of the wall but the color doesn't remain. The east wall has a beam hole located in the northeast corner and the wall has been restored in recent years. The latrine is located in the southeast corner and is entered from the north. On the south wall is a single beam hole within the latrine space. No sign of the floor or surfaces within the garden remain and the room is in a poor state of preservation.

Square masonry tank in the southwest corner of room 10. Divided into two by masonry partition wall. The walls are extensively restored. No traces of exterior finish no trace of lining survives in either tank. The bases of both tanks are obscured by lapilli. Eschebach says that these are fish tanks.

column14: Atrium 4 to the southeast
column21: Rectangular room, east/northeast - west/southwest axis. Plaster floor subsided to the center of the room. Doorway in the east corner of the southeast wall with stepped threshold to atrium. Modern lintel. Traces of plaster on all four walls. The northwest wall has two registers, white above. Large locked doorway or recess at the eastern end of the southeast wall. In front is a low plastered step facing the southeast corner of the room. Against  the southeast wall is cooking platform (3020). To the east of the cooking platform there is ceramic debris including a roof tile, the lower body of an amphora and the base of a dolium. In the northwest corner of the room, divided from the remainder by an undecorated partition was/is a latrine (3019). In the north corner of the room is a large masonry podium with two plastered steps leading to wooden stairs to the floor above (no longer extant). The upper sections of all four walls are modern restoration and the roof is modern also.

column14: Cooking platform (3020) to the southeast.
column21: Latrine is in the west/northwest corner of the room separated from the remainder of the room by an undecorated partition wall that abuts directly against the undecorated plaster in the northwest wall indicating that the partition wall is a subsequent addition. The latrine is entered from the south/southeast over a stepped threshold. The floor is plastered and slopes towards the latrine drain in the north/northwest. The drain is filled with earth and debris. U-shaped bench along the north/northwest wall is plastered over a tile surface. The U encircles the seat and drain area. The bench continues into an arched recess in the west wall.

column14: Latrine (3019) is to the northeast
column21: Cooking platform along the southeast wall. Two well-preserved masonry supports for a no longer extant surface. The eastern support abuts directly against the undecorated plaster of the southeast wall indicating its subsequent construction. The original floor is poorly preserved.

column14: Rooms 5 and 10 to the southeast.
column21: Square room with doorway south to corridor 5. No defined threshold. Modern lintel. To the east corner of the southeast wall adjoining the doorway is a small square window looking out to Room 10. Modern lintel. Traces of undecorated plaster survive on either side of the doorway. Plaster floor preserved in places. Southeast wall preserves extensive traces of lararium painting (3013). Upper half of the walls is modern restoration with modern roof.

Extensive painting along the entirety of the west/southwest wall. Plain plaster on which a lararium scene has been painted. From south, garlands above with lar depicted below with raised right hand, left hand pointing downwards but only preserved in fragments. Facing poorly preserved picture of lar of which only right arm and part of head survive. The lar is facing a tripod around which is an encircling snake. Garlands continue to the west corner with a third figure with raised left hand holding a cornucopia. In the west corner a fragment of red grapes.

column14: Lararium to the north, water feature to the northeast and southeast
column21: The masonry cooking platform lies in the west corner of the room abutting the northwest and southwest walls. The platform is in a southwest/northeast axis. The platform has two superimposed arched processes. The lower and taller one was probably for storage, the upper for cooking. Both recesses were stuccoed, but probably unpainted. The floor of the cooking platform was also stuccoed. Above the cooking platform had been inserted three tiles creating a slight lip on top of which is further masonry construction. The exterior of the cooking platform on its northeast/southeast sides were stuccoed but probably not painted. The entire cooking platform seems to have been inserted into the west corner after the garden painting had been done since the painting seems to continue behind the cooking platform.

column14: Room 3 is to the west
column21: Rectangular room southeast/northwest axis. Doorway in the west corner of the southwest wall stepping up to to room 3. F plastered floor preserved throughout. The southwest northwest and northeast walls preserve first style decorations with extensive surviving architectural molding and yellow lower register. High in the northwest corner modern (?) opening through the wall in to adjoining property. Cooking platform (3041) occupies the entirety of the southeast wall. Traces of red marble finish survive on the wall plaster in the southeast corner. The roof is modern.

column14: Altar 3046 to the south; Triclinium 3043 to the Southeast
column21: Deep rectangular cistern in the northwest corner of the garden directly against the exterior walls. Base is obscured by vegetation. No visible finish in the exterior face. Low masonry lip around all 4 sides.

column14: Fishpond to the east. Triclinium tot eh northeast. Water feature to the south.
column21: In the west corner of the garden to the southeast of the kitchen is a well. The aboveground structure is topped by a rectangular piece of volcanic stone. Depth is indeterminate. The well head, except the top stone, seems to have been stuccoed and possibly painted.

High on the northwest wall in the upper register are 3 fish. The fish to the right (northeast) is perhaps a red mullet. The 2 to the left (southwest) appear silver or bluish in color (probably can be identified by an expert). The fish appears to be lying on a table but the ground line is not flat.

We enter the elegant dining room, rectangular with a northwest/southeast axis, via a large opening from the southeast. The shortest of the three dining room doors on the peristyle garden. There is a concrete threshold. In 2011, there is a 2X3 foot platform for dramatic presentations. there are speakers. There is a small door on the southwest leading to the next dining room (38). the floor is concrete at this time, any other decoration has disappeared. This is a dining room, has a barrel vault over two thirds of the room and a flat higher ceiling over the other third. Half of the barrel vault shows frescoes. This elegant dado stage with flowers and plants (and birds) is excellent fourth style, the second region continues with primarily black with columns , red and gold and cinnabar and continues to the third register. There is molding where the top wall zone meets the ceiling and where the barrel vault meets the ceiling.

column14: floor below to southeast painting # 3077 to northeast.
column21: High on the northwest wall in the tympanium formed by the vaulting of the ceiling is a painting. In the center is a rectangular box on top of which sits a bronze tray, oval in shape. On the tray appears to be various food items.; on the right perhaps, a large fig. On the left my be a glass cup. The items in the center cannot be distinguished.

column14: floor below southwest painting 3058 to northwest
column21: On northeast wall in the upper register is an Eros appearing to walk from left to right, balancing a second Eros on the right, the Erotes flanking a herm with a tragic mask. The Eros on the left carries a basket containing fruit.
along northeast wall of portico was a storage chest, no longer existent. Its shape and size are unknown.

column14: Chests 3061, 3062, 3063 to northwest. paintings 3055, 3055, 3056 above on wall.
column21: An upright storage chest, rectangular in shape, placed against the northeast wall. Present today is its plaster cast. It appears to have been made of wood.

column14: chest #3063 to northwest, chests 3061 and 3060 to southeast. Paintings 3056 and 3055 above.
column21: An upright storage chest, rectangular in shape, placed on northwest-southeast axis against the northeast wall. Present today is its plaster cast. It appears to have been made of wood. Two decorative bronze pieces remain on the southwest side.

column14: chest 3062 and 3063 to northwest, chest 3060 to southeast. Paintings 3055, 3056, 3057 on wall above.
column21: An upright storage chest, rectangular in shape , placed on northwest- southeast axis against northeast wall. Present today is its plaster cast. It appears to have been made of wood, but the corners of which seem to have had ivory bars running vertical. Today a bronze decorative piece and the remains of an iron locks appear on the southwest side. the lid appears to be in the open position. There also appears to be evidence of a shelf on the inside. ON the southwest side (front) is a vertical ivory bar which may have served as part of a doorway to gain access to the box under the shelf without opening the top.

column14: chest 3062, 3061, 3060 tot eh southeast painting 3057, 3056, 3055 above.
column21: An upright storage chest, rectangular in shape, placed on northwest-southeast axis against the northeast wall. Present today is a plaster cast. It appears to have been made of wood with a metal band around the center.

column14: painting (3057) to the north, painting (3055) to the south, 3061, 3063, 3062, 3060 to the west (below)
column21: Vignette of two red fish to the north. 3 further fish are shown hanging in the background. The two red fish appear to be mullet, the 3 hanging fish are silver in color (perch?). The identification of all fish is uncertain.

column14: Cooking platform to southwest. Water feature to the southeast.
column21: The small niche lararium lies in the northwest wall at the level of and to the northeast of the upper portion of the cooking platform. The floor of the lararium is made from tiles and as extant protrudes slightly into the area of the room to the southeast. The interior of the lararium still contains a white stucco but no evidence of paint. The floor of the lararium that extends into the room is wider than the width of the lararium.

column14: Garden 15 to the northwest.
column21: The kitchen is defined as as an open-air garden located in the northwest part of the house in which hallway 5 leading to the garden to the northwest forms two sides. One enters the kitchen from hallway 5 through a small doorway in the north corner. The northeast and southeast is defined by a low wall separating the kitchen garden from hallway 5. In the southeast and northeast walls and in the east corner is a column. In the south corner is a rectangular pillar on a northeast-southwest axis. The columns and pillars support the modern, reconstructed roof covering hallway 5. Embedded in the southeast wall between the central column and rectangular pillar is a puteal covering the mouth of a cistern. In the west corner abutting the northwest and southwest walls is a tall cooking platform defined by superimposed arches. In the northwest wall to the northeast of the cooking platform is a small niche lararium. The floor is indeterminate. The low wall and columns were stuccoed and painted, the southwest walls still showing signs of a garden painting. In the east corner to the west of the gutter is a construction of unknown use that slopes slightly from west to east, opening  toward the gutter.

column14: Room 5 to the west. Room 7 to the northwest.
column21: Large rectangular room east-northeast/west-southwest. Opus signinum floor. Modern roof. Large areas of plaster survive on the southwest and southeast walls with red panels. Possible black panels, Xenia(?). Doorway in the northwest corner, no threshold, modern lintel, to Room 7. In the center of the northwest wall is a doorway to peristyle 5. Modern lintel. Preserved threshold with placings for doors. Red plaster survives on the internal face of the doorjamb. Modern roof.

column14: In the center triclinium 3024, and fish pools 3030 lie in the middle of the furrows. Water feature in the southwest.
column21: Garden 10 contains 16 furrows: 7 to northwest of the pool, 9 to the southeast, used for growing trees of various kinds such as hazelnut, peach, plum, and apricot. On each side a small pathway running southeast-northwest separates the furrows into 2 groups.

column14: Triclinium to the northeast. Furrows to the northwest and southeast. Well to the west. Water feature to the southwest.
column21: In the southwest of triclinium 3024 is a rectangular fish pond on a northeast-southeast axis. The pond is quite deep and as extant no longer shows evidence of stucco.

column14: Contiguous other features: Altar (3046) to the west.
column21: The triclinium is an elaborate masonry triclinium with pergola and two mosaic fountains. The triclinium is located in the northwest corner of the Dining Garden Peristyle. It faces east. The medius is 4.5m, immus 4.2 and summis 3.55 (Jashemski). At the end of the summus one can see a white painted stucco. The bottom part shows the typical painted garden fence and the top part is gone. There is a large rectangular center table with a pipe coming up out of the center. This triclinium shows 13 aedicular arched recesses. The triclinium shows the typical slopes. There is a wall surrounding the south, west, and north sides of the triclinium. Jashemski shows this wall as a low masonry wall with space for plants. There are four round columns, one at each corner, that would have supported a pergola. There is evidence of stucco on the west column. To the northeast and southeast in front of the triclinium are two large ornate fountains. The dominant tesserae colors are white, deep blue, light blue, coral, and green. At the back of each fountain are stairs that go to the top. Jashemski reports that Stephano DeCaro that the steps led to the reservoirs. The fountains are almost duplicates of each other. The north facade will be described. It has a large niche in a rectangular block that has a pediment at the top. There is a rectangular pool area in front of each fountain. The large arched niche contains a smaller niche with a protruding marble shelf. The north fountain still contains a center water pipe coming up through the bottom. The interior niche contains shells with outlining in green and red tesserae, Both fountains, beneath the small niche, show two ducks and two fish. At the top of the large niche is a flying swan, clearly 4th style. At the middle zone of the fountain are two green jumping dolphins. The shells are everywhere on the facade, probably modern restoration. The north water fountain contains a small circular marble table, which may or may not have been there originally. On the east facade of the north fountain we see remains of a garden painting with evidence of a garden fence done in pink and gold, and a large crater outlined above the fence. On the west side of the facade we see the fence again. The large crater outlined in yellow shows blue water within the crater. Remnants of the same garden painting are evident on the south fountain but are less visible. The fountains are covered by a plastic roof. The triclinium is uncovered.

column14: FN 3077, wall painting, to northeastFN 3058, wall painting, to northwest.
column21: The design of the mosaic floor is simple, made up of beaten cement with fine terracotta fragments. A design is formed by small pieces of white marble. The entrance is a crosshatched band going in a northwest direction. The next section is wide, made up of marble fragments in columns. After a small band lacking any marble fragments, followed immediately by a band of the same width with marble fragments in squares with different designs. The rest of the floor to northwest wall has in the center a large square design made up of many squares of geometric design. This large square serves as the focal point, around which the dining couches would be arranged. Surrounding the central square, lined up in rows, are a series of 4 marble fragments, each forming flowers. The floor, where the benches would be placed, seems to sloped back towards the walls.

column14: Peristyle 31 southeastDining rooms E (39) , W (37)
column21: One enters the dining room from the peristyle to the southeast. The room is rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis. In the east corner there is a low doorway to room 39. In the south corner there is a doorway to room 37. The floor as extant slopes slightly on axis southeast to northwest. The floor is a beaten cement, simply decorated with small pieces of white marble. To the northwest the mosaic design is a large square, serving to define the location of the dining couches. The walls and ceilings are decorated in the 4th style. The southeast ceiling, taking up almost a fourth of the room, has three sections. The southwest and northeast sections are arched on a southeast-northwest axis. The center is rectangular in shape on a southeast-northwest axis. The center is rectangular in shape on southeast-northwest axis. The rest of the ceiling to the northwest is at a lower height, and is barrel-vaulted on a southwest-northeast axis. The doorway from the southeast is very wide, extending to almost entire width of room.

The floor contains a floor mosaic done in a couch pattern. The flooring material is dark green and is inlaid with large pieces of a variety of marble. The marble inlay includes numidian giallo antico and pavonazetto with the emphasis of the marble pieces in the center.

column14: Room 31 is to the southeast. Room 36 is to the west.
column21: We enter the dining hall from the peristyle (3054) which was located to the south. There is a marble threshold and an extremely large entrance way. This dining hall is rectangular and is oriented on a northwest-southeast axis. As reconstructed, the first barrel vault is in place over the back 3/4 of the ceiling. The south corner of the ceiling is higher and flat. There is a floor mosaic (3069) in the triclinium couch pattern. There are seven pieces of reproduction furniture using modern components. All the wood is natural and modern. There are four 3-legged tables with lions'-heads feet. The room to the northeast shows a cast of a heavy door which shows a room to the northeast. On the walls there is a black dado interspersed with yellow and red columns on the bottom. Puti and ladies are represented above the dado and there is a middle zone of a dramatic punishment of Dirce who was]forcefully led to hear death tied to a bull. The middle zone has columns interspersed with beautiful female winged figures. In all but one section, color still remains --  Green (4th style) and patches of green and red. At the northwest wall there is a very high window with a modern block, open to peristyle. At the southeast there is another rectangular window. The wall suggests it was made taller and more impressive.

column14: Paintings (3056, 3057 ) to the north.Chests (3060, 3061q, 3062, 3063) to the west, below.
column21: Vignette of red grapes spilling from an overturned basket. A bird (owl?) is shown flying above.

column14: 3056 is to the east and 3062 to southwest. Chests 3062, 3063, 3061, 3060 below.
column21: Rectangular vignette, blue upper, brown lower. In the center is a poorly preserved image of fish on a platter (?). Brown border along bottom edge - table?

column14: Room 5 is to the south. Room 19 is to the west.
column21: Northwest of the lararium, and on the same wall, is a rectangular kitchen. The doorway is protected with Plexiglas. The floor slopes southwest. On the east wall, there is a round window and on a sloped roof is a shaped terracotta cooking vent. Room has a northwest-southeast axis. Doorway has a modern lintel and no discernible threshold.

column14: Latrine (3025) to the west.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform in the north corner extending along the northwest wall.  The platform abuts first style decoration on the northwest wall.  Two large masonry supports with undecorated plaster facing support a platform with terra cotta lip formed of roof tiles and tile surface.  The platform is modern restoration from 1984.  Opus signinum floor beneath.

column14: Triclinium 3024 to the east.  Fishpond 3030 to the west.  Water feature (3033) to the west.  Cistern (3031) to the west.
column21: Circular plastered cistern filled with debris surmounted by a circular terra cotta well.  Head with decorated lip consisting of incised lines and circular embossed elements.  In front of the lectus imus of couch 3024.

column14: Cistern (3027) to north, couch 3024 to the east, fish pond 3030 to the west, water feature (3033) to the west, cistern to the west (3031).
column21: Square tile and masonry platform with plaster finish.  Traces of the decoration survive on the northern face and appear to continue the scheme of the adjoining triclinium with unidentifiable red features on a blue background.  A circular marble element is inserted into the plaster decoration.  The plaster on the east face is contiguous with that of the adjoining couch.  The plaster does not survive on the west face.  The surface is modern cement.  It abuts the lectus summus (southern arm) of couch 3024 to the east.

column14: Furrows to the northeast.  Fish pond to the northeast.  Triclinium to the northeast.  Well to the north.
column21: Water feature made up of gutter and fountain lies to the northeast of and parallel to the southwest wall of the house on a southeast northwest axis.  The gutter is divided into 2 unequal parts by the doorway leading into room 5 to the southwest.  The northwest portion, the longest in length, of the gutter has on its northwest end  a rectangular basin of unknown function.  The portion of the gutter lying to the southeast of the door has at its southeast end what appears to be a fountain with a lead pipe rising vertically in the center.  Underneath the fountain lies a drain for the gutter.  The interior of the gutter is faced with a waterproof stucco opus signinum.

column14: Relationship unknown  -  not excavated.
column21: Garden area to the northeast of the insula.  The perimeter of the garden has not been identified.  Wall to the southeast.  Eschebach says there is a cistern, dolium and open air triclinium under a vine pergola.  Used for vine cultivation with olive and fig trees in the corners.  Drain into unexcavated house to the southwest.

column14: 3050  Preparation platform to the west.
column21: In this space we see the stone masonry remains of an open air triclinium.  The imus medeus summus are apparent.  I see no plaster.  A triclinium slope is discernible and can still be seen.  It is contiguous with the preparation platform.  This space is well within the city walls.  The triclinium imus is north, the medeus is east and the sumus is south.

column14: Triclinium (3049) to the east.
column21: Preparation platform is located to the west of the summus couch of the triclinium.  As extant the couch has pretty much lost its form although in antiquity it was probably rectangular or square.  Because of the deteriorated condition of the platform it is not possible to determine if it had been plastered and painted.

column14: Andron (26) to east, dining hall (35) to west, (25) to the southeast, (32) to the south , (33) to the south, (34) to the southwest.
column21: The peristyle lies in northwest part of the house.  One enters the peristyle from andron (86) in the east corner.  The peristyle is rectangular in shape on a northwest - southeast axis.  On northwest side in the west corner is dining hall (35).  To the northeast next to dining hall are rooms 36 and 37.  To northeast of these rooms is triclinium 38.  In north corner is dining room 39.  In north corner of northeast wall is a door that has been closed up in antiquity.    On southeast side in east corner is andron 26.  To the southwest is room 25, followed by 32, then rooms 33 and 34 in the south corner.  In the center is a rectangular open peristyle on a northeast - southwest axis and is defined by doric columns, 3 on the northwest side, 4 on northeast side, 2 on southeast side.  The southwest wall has 5 engaged columns, for a total of 14 columns.  The garden area in the center has, on northwest, northeast and southeast sides, a stone gutter.  The southeast gutter has a drain hole in south corner of southwest wall.  On southwest side, running northwest-southeast, is a walkway made up of 2 rows of flat stones running the width of the garden.  Jashemski (1979) found evidence that the garden contained citron, fig and olive trees.  The columns support a roof, creating a covered portico on the northwest, northeast and southeast sides.  High on walls of all 4 sides, covered by the portico, is a series of paintings of different subjects.  Below on the second register is a series of large rectangular sections, with small vignettes in the center.  The lowest register on all 4 sides bears paint but no figured representation.  Around the portico at roof level on the northwest and northeast sides are gutters with lion head spouts.  Those on the southeast side appear to be modern.  Columns, with exception of 3 on southwest side, are painted gold on the lower half and white on the upper part.

column14: Contiguous to room #4, which is to the northeast.
column21: Entrance to Dining room is at the south end of northeast wall.  Dining room identification is based on location in house and size of room.  Walls are stone with masonry door jams.  Traces of stucco remain, particularly on southeast wall.  Two layers of plaster remain at northeast wall.  Floor is not visible.

column14: The room is contiguous to the atrium (4) to the southeast
column21: We enter the room from the southeast from the atrium.  The room is along a northeast-southwest axis. On the northeast wall, east corner there is a large lararium with a recess above it. Original plaster exists on all 4 walls with traces of red, white and yellow paint.  On the northwest and southwest wall approximately 2.5 meters high are traces of plaster molding. The walls are high, the height is indeterminate, but we see evidence of painting on the second story west corner with blue and gold paint.  The floor is obscured with lapilli.  The width of the entrance doors seems to have been narrowed in antiquity. There are seven beam holes on the northwest wall above the molding and plaster, and just over the door way on opposite sides of northeast and southwest walls are large holes possibly for floor joists.

column14: Northwest of Room 4
column21: On the far east end of the northeast wall is an arched deep recess to the floor.  The back of the lararium has no discernible plaster.  There is decoration on the top of the arch and curved to 1/3 to 1/2 down the east side.  The decoration is third - fourth style, white plaster with yellow/green balls, tendrils, leaves.  At the top of the arch is a square surrounding aqua frame. Within the frame is a red indiscernible  scene/face. Three fourths of the way down on the east side are signs of a shelf support.  Below this are signs of roughening of the plaster in preparation for repainting.  There is modern graffiti on the upper east wall.
column74: 012/013 indicated to be deleted on feature sheet.

column14: Room (  ) to the southeast
column21: We enter the property from the southeastern entrance. This space is difficult to interpret due to an open channel running through the property on a northeast/southwest axis.  This space would have been appropriate and abundant for outside dining.  In this space there is evidence of a large masonry triclinium with a table. At the foot of the right triclinium platform there is evidence of a platform that could have been for serving food or used for children or freed men.  The property (space) borders a house located on the southeastern side beyond the channel.  The southeastern wall is interrupted by a low door on the street of the Palestra. The northwest part of the wall, surrounding the space, shows some evidence of plaster.  This is an area where large trees grew based on ancient sources.

column14: none
column21: Standing in a central portion of the northwest wall of the space we see the top three rows of stone forming an outdoor masonry triclinium. There are two layers of stone forming a circular large inner table. The triclinium shows the usual slope.  At the feet of the right couch arm there is evidence of a stone platform, square in shape it could have been used for food service or a space for eating for children or freed men.  There is a possibility that future excavation would show further depth in the triclinium and the platform. In 2010 the outdoor triclinium was located in a cool tree studded area.
This dolium was located to the northwest of the other dolium, 2777.  As extant the cavity is present but no remains of the dolium itself.
The missing dolium lay to the southeast of dolium 2776.  Today its location is identified only through a depression in the ground.
On the Eschebach plan of the house a cooking platform seems to appear at the back of the room along the north west wall.Eschebach defines the room as a kitchen.

column14: Atrium is to the south east
column21: Square room with door way to atrium in the south east corner.  There is a modern lintel, and an ancient threshold in the west corner.  There is a rectangular window to storeroom thirty.  There is a modern roof, plaster floor and decorative plaster survives on the walls.  The room is inaccessible and the walls are not visible as it is used as a finds store by the custodian.  Traces of red painted plaster in the south west corner.  Recess for cupboard in the north west, finds of glass and ceramic vessels and amphora suggest its used as a storeroom.

column14: Atrium fifteen to the west
column21: Rectangular room north east/south west axis.  Holes for 2 sets of shelves in the north west and north west walls.  The room contains amphora.  Presence of the shelves and amphora indicate this room was used for storage; however traces of early decoration survive.  The walls have undecorated white plaster; however traces of first style decoration and architectural molding survives on the north west and south east walls.  Plaster floor with geometric pattern in tessera.  The room is accessed from the south west level of the floor in the adjoining atrium.  In the south corner there is a rectangular plaster window or collapse into room eleven.  Roof is modern.
