column14: Atrium fifteen is to the west
column21: Rectangular room north west/ south east axis.  Opus signinum floor with low stepped threshold to atrium fifteen in the west.  Modern roof.  Doorway to atrium in the south west corner with modern lintel and plaster surviving on the internal faces of the door jambs.  In the north west corner there is a large window with plaster upon the jambs and bases.  The southern jamb preserves a circular indentation in plaster.  Modern lintel.  Undecorated plaster survives on all four walls.  Two square holes for shelves survive in the south west corner and the center of the north west wall.  The lines for the intervening shelves are preserved in the plaster on all four walls.  The room was found to contain ceramic vessels, 2 lamps and amphora.

column14: atrium fifteen to the south west
column21: Rectangular room north east/south west axis opening south west to atrium fifteen.  Stone stepped threshold to the atrium.  Modern lintel to doorway.  Modern roof and plaster floor.  In the east wall there is a blocked rectangular window or recess.  Undercoated plastic survives on the north west, north east and south east walls with holes for shelves.  In the north west corner there is a rectangular plastered recess or blocked doorway with modern lintel.

Two square hole for shelves survive at the west end of the north west wall.  The north east section of the wall does not preserve the placings.  Two further supports for shelves are useable on the east wall.

Square holes for two sets of shelves survive in west corner in the north west wall.  Contiguous with these holes are the lines of two tiers of shelving cut into the plaster decoration of the wall.  Shelves ran along the north west and south east walls of the room.

Square holes for two tiers of shelves survive on the north east, south east and north west walls.  Two holes survive at each end of the north west wall and the north east wall whilst only one hole survives in the south east corner.  Two holes survive in the south corner.

column14: Masonry couch triclinium (2733) to the northeast. Cooking platform (2736) lo the northeast hearth (2734) to north water basin (2739) to northeast.
column21: Two adjoining water structures lay at the back of masonry couch triclinium to the southwestern side of Space 2. The smaller water structure to the northeast is quasi-square and is delineated by about fifty centimeter high wall. In the eastern corner there are two small rectangular stone structures, the function of which is unclear. The floor is covered by vegetation but stone covering is visible in some parts (especially in the southern corner and by the eastern wall).The bigger water structure lies to the southwest of the smaller tank (northeastern wall of larger water structure is the southwestern wall of the smaller tank). The water feature is rectangular with the northwestern wall, slightly running outward toward the northwestern corner (angled slightly). The floor is covered with vegetation.

column14: Masonry couch triclinium (2733) is to the southwest. Water pool (2735) to southwest. Water basin (2739) to south. Hearth (2734) to east.
column21: The cooking platform is situated to the south of entrance 1. The semicircular built-in structure on the lower level faces the western couch of the masonry triclinium. The vault is covered with bricks as well as the outward semicircular vault of the opening. The three walls inside are covered with plaster. The platform, on top, shows a pattern of irregularly shaped and colored tiles.
column53: 102/36 Reshoot Black and White Roll 3, Frame 3103/23 Reshoot Color Roll 4, Frame 2

column14: Cooking platform (2906) is to the northeast.
column21: Latrine recessed into the southeast wall of the room. The rear of the latrine has a steeply sloping terra cotta tile draining into channel below. The channel is completely filled. The terra cotta tile of the floor drains into the latrine.

column14: Dining room (4-2908) to southeast and room 1 to the north
column21: Entry from Shop 14 from the kitchen is to south in corridor. General condition is bad. No ceiling or walls. Floor shows indication of rocks and stone. Without walls there are no windows. It has a wall foundation on east and south only. The cooking platform indicated by Eschebach's map.

column14: Southwest of dining room.
column21: We entered the large entrance at southeast side into Counter Room. A second entrance is on the southwest side. The room is oriented northwest/southeast. The shop is located facing the street with a fountain to the southwest. Evidence of paved floor. Evidence of two layers of fresco with red paint on outer layer. On the northeast wall is a lararium. The northwest wall has a large door out through the eastern side and three steps of a staircase are present at the west side. Northwest wall is preserved to a height above ceramic lined holes floor beams of second floor. Northwest wall is stone and brick. Southwest wall with doorway to the street; northwest side is brickwork with fresco, and the south side of the doorway is masonry with cut recess and shaped counter is projecting from the eastern wall.

column14: Counter room (1) to the southeast
column21: We enter the room from a doorway on the southeast wall. This small room has been determined dining-other due to its location which is northwest of the counter room. Entrance 16. The orientation of the room runs along a northwest-southeast axis. The general condition of the room is poor; however, every wall on all four signs of plaster which is original. Evidence on the southwest wall and the northwest wall suggest that the room had been replastered. There are colors on the lower register of red and white painted plaster and stenciled work in yellow and red. The floor is covered with lapilli and ash. The ceiling is absent and the entrance door is notably high. Above the doorway on the southeast wall are four beam holes which were used for support of the second story.

column14: Counter on east and southwest
column21: In the Counter Room, we find the lararium on the northeast wall behind the counter. It is a small arched recess approximately 1.5 meters from the floor. Some remains of the original plaster still remain along the arch. The structure appears to be original. The width is approximately 20 centimeters. The depth is approximately 10 centimeters. Red and white paint survives on the north side.

column14: Southwest of lararium on northeast wall
column21: L-shaped counter facing southeast and southwest entrances. Southwest portion of the counter has two cut dolia which are notably shallow. The base of the counter is preserved stonework and the counter top is modern restoration in marble pieces, with a piece at northwest end with what appears to be a modern inscription(?). Southeast exterior side has preserved traces of fresco with red paint.

column14: The latrine is contiguous to room 17 at the North; room 19 at the West and corridor 20 at the West.
column21: A one seater latrine located in the Northeast corner of room 18 adjacent to a dividing wall located beside the preparation platform. The latrine is masonry construction with a limestone seat.  At the rear of the latrine seat is an opening for waste disposal; the front of the latrine is also opened. The East wall in the Northeast corner is of masonry construction but appears to have had a waste disposal pipe inserted indicating it serve both an upper floor and the latrine in room 18.

column14: Fauces ( 1) to Northeast; store room 2872 to Southeast, room 9 to the Northwest.
column21: The dining room is located in the Northwest part of the house. One enters the room from a doorway in the East corner of the Northeast wall. The room is rectangular in shape on Southeast/ Northwest axis. In the South corner of the room is a doorway leading to a storage area under the stairs. As extant neither the height of the room nor type of floor is determinate. Stucco and remains of painting are extant on all four walls.

column14: Dining room (2871) to Northwest; dining room (2873) to the Southeast.
column21: The entrance to the store room is located in the South corner of the dining room (2871). The height would have been determined by the scope of the ancient stairs. The room is rectangular in shape on a Northeast/Southwest axis. Plaster on the Northwest and Southeast walls with red paint remaining, indicates that the room was decorated in antiquity.

column14: Room 4 is to the Northeast. Room 20 is to the Northwest.
column21: Room 7 is accessible from the Northeast from room #4. The entrance extends along the whole width of the room. The square room walls were painted: there are traces of red painting on the Northwest and Southwest walls along with plaster fragments on the same wall. The floor is covered with vegetation, debris, and heaps of soil. In the Northwest corner toward the entrance rests a 30 centimeter high block of stone which doesn't appear on the floor plan of the building. It probably doesn't belong to the room. The Northwest and Southwest walls are preserved to 2 meters.  The Southeast wall is preserved to the four meters high roof which is difficult to discern if it is ancient or modern.  The ceiling is not extant.

column14: Room 10 is to the Northeast. Room 12 is to the Southeast. Room 15 is to the Northeast.
column21: Room 11 is entered from the Northeast corner of room 15. It is a small rectangular room on a Northwest/Southeast axis. The Northeast and Southeast walls are mostly collapsed. The Northwest/Southwest walls are preserved to a a second story height. The roof is not extant. These walls show joist like holes scattered along the walls. The Southwest walls shows large fragments of plaster. The floor is with a thick layer of vegetation, debris and two large heaps of soil to the Northwest and Southeast. The room contains a lararium in the Southwest wall and 2 possible platforms (cooking and preparation) along the Northwest wall.
According to Eschebach's floor plan room 11  was provided with what looks like a cooking platform along the Northwest wall, as the lararium suggests the function of the room as a kitchen.
According to Eschebach's floor plan room 11 was provided with what looks like a preparation platform along the Northwest wall, as the lararium suggests the function of the room as kitchen.

column14: Room 15 is to the Northeast. Room 11 is to the Southwest.
column21: Room 10  is entered from Northeast off room 14. The room has another opening; a large low window looking out onto room 15. The rectangular room is on a Northeast/Southwest axis. The Northwest and Southwest walls show traces of red painting and large fragments of plaster. They are also largely collapsed. The southern section  of the Southwest wall is largely collapsed. The Southeast wall (with the window) is mostly covered with dead vines. The ceiling is non-extant. The walls framing the entrance to the Northeast exist now only as small blocks of stone resting on a heap of soil in the northern corner of the room. The floor is covered with overgrown vegetation and heaps of soil.

column14: Peristyle #19 is to the southeast.
column21: Rectangular room northeast/southwest axis.  The floor is opus signinum with marble inclusions and central rosette consisting of a pattern of circles in white tesserae, around which the couches would have been placed.  There is a modern roof.  The doorway to the peristyle in the southeast corner has plastered jambs, modern lintel and placings for the door in the threshold.  The threshold is contiguous with the remainder of the room.  The large window in the center of the southeast wall looking out to the peristyle has a modern lintel.  There is a narrow rectangular window in the northeast corner.  A large square section of painting has been removed in east corner.  Third style decoration survives throughout, red on the lower register and white panels above.  Unidentifiable scema survive on the southwest, northwest and northeast walls, alternating with circular rosettes of animals that survive on the southwest and northwest walls.  There are various ceramic and glass vessels and metal artifacts and animal bones found.  Allison calls it fourth style, but there is little or no architectural imagery or perspective visible and color palette is limited.

It is a low rectangular plastered platform against the earlier second style painting of the east wall.  The platform is surmounted by a high plastered terra cotta lip on all three sides and a matching support in the center of the platform.  The lip and support will have supported two grills and fire placings.  There is a gap in the lip on the southeast corner to clear out the ashes.  Traces of white plaster survive.

column14: Lararium #3076 is to the south.
column21: The platform is L shaped against the southwest and northwest walls, abutting the northeast wall in the kitchen and there is a lip against two edges.  There are storage areas in two sections underneath the platform for fuel for the hibachi-style burner.  On the modern plastic protectors that hang in the doorway and prevent entrance, the conservators identified kitchen implements.  These are, listed from top to bottom, iron triangular shaped hibachi-style stand for food receptacles; a casserole dish on display on the stand with a convex space and flared rim; a terra cotta basin with spout; the stems or bottoms of amphorae for light grinding; a circular shaped weight; and thin wall jug with anthropoid features.

As part of the kitchen area, we see a beautiful lararium.  We see two-thirds of a semicircular water holder.  There is a red cinnabar border of approximately five foot by six foot.  It is cream in color with an unknown rectangle in the center.  We see gardens, lares (possible Augustus with a cornucopia).  There are two sedate lares with their tunics, shawls, brown skin, black hair holding rhytons and situla (cups).  There is indication of wine being poured from the rhyton to the situla on each lares figure.  The northwest lar seems feminine in her features?  In the center of the ground line, there is an offering on the altar which attracts the snake with some red flames and perhaps the outline of an egg.  The snake's head is above the altar and it's tail is in the lower east corner.  In the lower southwest, there are two figures.  The figure nearest the altar wears a red palea, covering head and shoulders and blue underneath. She offers a patera with both hands.  The figure on the southwest is taller and could be the ancestor, master of the house or Augustus holding a cornucopia with a conical object and two pieces of fruit.  The central figures are approximately one half the size of the lares.  On the ground line, knee level of the lar, we see a small figure with dual Pan pipes and on the other side there is probably a slave holding a platter in one hand and one or two fish in the other.  Below the ground line, the features and details of the snake become more intricate.  There are undulating plants beneath the altar, including a couple of irises.  There are other leaves and iris plants in the cinnibar and lighter orange with much green foliage.

column14: The atrium, room 2, is located to the northeast.  Room 5 is to the southeast.
column21: The dining hall is located in the west corner of the house.  One enters the room from the atrium from the northeast.  The room is rectangular in shape and is on a southwest/northeast axis.  There is a large doorway to room 5 on the southeast wall.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is very tall.  The floor is entirely in black and white mosaic.  A simple design runs around the periphery, while the interior appears to be white tesserae.  Stucco remains on each of the walls although the the paint has disappeared.
column53: video team leader: Adina and Lilly

column14: The peristyle, room 5, is to the. west.
column21: Dining room 7 lies on the northeast side of the house opposite the north corner of the peristyle, room 5.  The room is rectangular in shape on a roughly northeast/southwest axis.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is quite tall and the floor is of a beaten cement of terra cotta fragments and large irregular shaped pieces of marble.  One enters the room through a wide door from the southwest.  The walls are covered in stucco and richly painted in fourth style.  The northwest and southeast walls have large panels with a central rectangular panel, probably of mythological scenes.  The small panel on the southwest wall is missing.

column14: Fountain (6024) to the southeast; well (6023) to the northwest.
column21: The shrine sits directly behind the fountain and is connected to the south wall of the well.  As extant it is a block.  it is a crossroads shrine.  Eschebach reports that Nazois has a drawing of the shrine.  Some evidence of white stucco/paint exists on the west side.

column14: Latrine 14 is contained in the northeast corner of room 15.  The south wall abuts room 16. There are trace remains leading to room 13.
column21: Midway down the east/west axis of the house is room 11, a large rectangular dining room.  The access to the dining room is a doorway at the northwest corner of the north wall.  The room was frescoed.  Traces of red paint remain.  Construction of the north wall consists of eight courses of brick with opus incertum above.  The door threshold in the north wall, west end, is of tufa stone with a channel for the door so the door opened to room 11.  There are no windows in the room. The room identification is based on size, shape, and view towards garden (9) through the doorway.  The axis of the room is east/west.

column14: Latrine 14 is contained in the northeast corner of room 15.  The south wall abuts room 16.  There are trace remains leading to room 13.
column21: Room 15 kitchen is located near the northeast corner of the house.  The kitchen contains a cooking platform on the east wall and a latrine in a small room immediately adjacent to the north of it.  The kitchen is l-shaped, with a doorway in the southwest corner.  No evidence of windows outlets remain, although at this point a ceramic pipe appearing to come from an upper level is visible over the cooking platform.There is no trace of plaster on the kitchen walls and the floor appears to be lapilli.  The latrine is entered by a door on a northeast abutting wall off the l-shaped room.  There is plaster along some of the north and east latrine walls,  and the latrine floor is cocciopesto.  However, this appears to go on the side of the building only.

column14: Room 23, 24, 25, 26 and 27 are to the east.  Rooms 16, 17, and 12 are to the north and rooms 19, 20, and 21 are to the west.
column21: The  rectangular atrium is located along a north/south axis.  From entrance 19 to the east Eschebach says there was a mosaic impluvium that is shown on the plan; however no trace remains (2012). In the southeast corner there is a rectangular preparation  platform (6156).  Traces of plaster floor survive in the southwest corner of the south wall, and in the center of the west wall against the entrance to room 19.  Traces of plaster may survive in front of the preparation platform.  Stone thresholds may survive for doorway (room 23), and fauces (room 25)on the kitchen side.  In the northwest corner three masonry steps lead up to room 12.  The remainder of the floor is obscured by lapilli.  Undecorated plaster with upper and lower register survives on the south wall.

column14: 3 to the north
column21: Rectangular room, northwest axis, floor obscured by lapilli. Traces of undecorated plaster in southeast corner. Wide open doorway in west wall to the street outside. Stepped threshold with placings for door. Doorway in the east end of the north wall provides access to the atrium of entrance 5. There are no files recorded in Eschebach nor any indication of food and drink however Nina identifies this as a taberna.

column14: Room is at south east end of house directly entered off of street Via Della Fullonica. Storeroom 12 is completely within the room and the southwest doorway opens to pergola 9.
column21: Entered from doorway 21 at rear end of house. The kitchen is on a northeast/southwest axis. In the center of the room, abutting  the north wall to store room 12 are two masonry supports for a cooking platform. At the northeast end of the room adjacent to both storeroom 12 and the exterior door is a latrine which gives the room an "L" shape. There is a raised threshold in doorway 21, and a window above the latrine opening out into the street. Little plaster remains on the walls giving no evidence of decoration. Areas of the wall show signs of modern repair. Floor slopes to street outside door 21 but is rubble.
column74: Cindy. Mosaic on wall in the latrine area approximately 3 1/2 meters above latrine. See comments for feature 6135

column14: Bordered on northwest by masonry support 6136.
column21: Latrine is immediately adjacent to exterior southeast wall of the house and is part of room 10 (kitchen). Identified as narrow space with sloping floor, with window immediately above. No masonry remains or wall decoration.

column14: Atrium is to the East. West wall runs along the street.
column21: A large rectangular dining room with the entrance doorway West of the atrium. The room is on a North/South axis. Plaster remains on 3 walls but entirely not on the West wall. Plaster is red and orange in color. No decoration schema can be readily determined, although North wall appears to have red and yellow blocks. Entrance to the dining room is on the Southeast corner of the East wall and extremely tall, about 4 meters high. There are numerous metal repair clamps along the North and East walls. Slight stenciling is found along the lowest south wall plaster. On the East wall, North corner of the room, there is a cutout niche (covered) that is approximately 30 centimeters deep, 2.5 meters wide, that appears to run to the height of the ceiling.The floor is covered with lapilli.The door jamb contains two insets on each. The lower is circular 10 centimeters across and 20 centimeters deep. The upper two are rectangular and across from each other.

A floor-to-ceiling covered niche is located on the North corner of the East wall.The niche extends approximately half of the total wall distance beginning at the North corner to the door. The interior is covered with red and yellow plaster with remains of red paint. The niche appears to have extended from floor to ceiling. Cupboard niche designation was determined based upon recently work by P. Allison. Minor metal repair 'wings' appear along mortar line repair on the lower right area.

column14: Rooms contiguous to garden room 40 to the North, to the ala number 8 to the West; to the South is the tablinum number 6. Room number 39 is to the East.
column21: This large near-square dining room is entered by one of two doorways on the West wall. The axis of the room is North/South. The North wall of the room contains both a tile-lined niche, approximately 190 centimeters from the ground, and the large window faces garden room 40. Window sill height is 60 centimeters from the ground and about 250 centimeters wide. Minimal plaster remains on the North, East, and South wall. West wall between the door frames appears to be anciently reconstructed. Some pieces of black and white stone tile tesserae are found in the rubble of the room and maybe evidence of a previous mosaic tile floor. Neither entrance way has evidence of door sill or jamb. There is a high inset in the South wall, West end. On the West wall, the South door jamb is made of lime-or tufa stone blocks. East and North walls show opus reticulatum along the lower course between the plaster.

column14: Room is bordered on the garden room number 40, on the East by ala 8, to the West by room 5, and to the South by atrium 4.
column21: Rectangular dining room located East of the ala. The window and room face garden room 40 to the North. The room has a North/South alignment, with a doorway with a marble threshold to the North, East wall. Room has paint remaining on three walls only, excepting the East wall. Plaster colors extant are red and yellow and some traces of white border on the yellow plaster on the South wall. The floor is rubble, mostly lapilli. However, some white and black tesserae (rare)  remain. There is a large window located waist height from the ground. The room also has a marble door jamb with placings for attachments of a double door. There are circular pivot holes.

column14: To the North is hallway 38. To the East is room 36. To the South is the next structure. To the West is the passageway (andron) leaving to atrium number 4.
column21: The room under the stairs is identified as a kitchen by Eschebach, although no evidence remains. Because of the presence of a latrine, we agree with Eschebach. The room is located on a passthrough between the two halves of the house. The room is rectangular on a North-South axis. On the East side of the room, all evidence is located. To the North are the remains of a staircase going East, then North to the upstairs, and under that staircase we suggest the cooking took place in an arched alcove. Next to the alcove is where the latrine is located on the South and East corner of the room. There is some plaster evidence on the four walls. The lower register was painted red. The upper register appears to be painted white. Plaster evidence appears under the stairs in the archway. The floor is rubble. No windows are apparent.

column14: To the North is hallway 38. To the East is room 36. To the South is the next structure. To the West is the passageway (andron) leading to atrium 4.
column21: This is a small space walled off from the identified cooking area to the South wall of room 37. The space is approximately 50 by 70 centimeters. The walls are covered in plaster in red paint up to about 1.5 meters. The floor is rubble. On the East wall of the latrine, about 1.6 meters from the floor, is a horizontal volcanic stone and possible opening.

column14: 26, 27, 28 to the North. 40, to the Northwest. 29 to the East. 33, 34, 35, 36, to the south. 38 to the Southwest.
column21: This is a large open area, opening to the East with a wide doorway to the East opening to the street, at entrance 22, possibly for the use of carts. To the South the area opens to a series of small rooms, possibly used as stables. To the North of the doorway is a possible latrine. In the center of the room are stairs going North to the floor above. To the West of the base of the stairs is a preparation platform (6116). Beneath the stairs is a water basin. (6117)  In the Northeast corner and North are the doorways to three dining rooms. In the Northwest the room opens to the garden and a small tiled latrine. Adjoining the latrine is a doorway to a store room. (26) And out-of-situ marble cistern head is in the room. The floor isobscured by lapilli. In the Southwest corner is a narrow corridor leading to theatrium area.

column14: 6117 is to the North.
column21: This is a low rectangular masonry preparation platform with modern cement reinforcement which abuts directly onto the West base of the stairs which rise  to the North. It is approximately 170 centimeters long from East to West, 25 centimeters high and 1.20 meters long on the North/South axis.

column14: 6116 is to the South.
column21: This is a deep square basin in an arched recess beneath the stairs, open only to the West. Access is restricted by a low plastered wall. The basin is lined throughout with opus signinum, and there is not apparent exit/ingress for water.

column14: 30 to the South.
column21: This is a large square room. The floor is obscured by lapilli. High on the North wall are the placing for six floor joists: restoration has obscured a possible seventh. Plaster survives on all walls with a red lower register and white above. High on the south end of the West wall is a single floor joist.In the center of the South wall there is a low plastered window, facing the garden, that has been subsequently filled in. Against the doorway in the southwest corner is a cooking platform, number 6119.

column14: Room 15 is in northwest corner of the structure, enter directly off the northwest corner of atrium 5 with kitchen room 3 immediately to the south and cubiculi 14 to the east.
column21: Large rectangular dining room on northeast/southwest axis along northern wall of house, west corner. Entrance to room is a medium-sized doorway in southeast corner. View to the doorway is through a columned atrium.  Walls are heavily plastered with bright red paint on the lower register and possibly white or yellow above.  Some traces of yellow border design on the red. No windows are obvious.  Floor is rubble.  South door jam contains inset for door closure. Deliberate blind opening approximately 240 cm above ground level in center of north wall.

column14: Room 3 is located at the front entrance of the structure to the north of the vestibule rooms 1 and 2. It is located to the west of atrium of 5 and to the south of dining room 15.
column21: Square room to the north of doorway 4 opens off entryway to the house. Kitchen contains a long masonry platform the width of the north-wall with two-third of surface tile and the other northeast one-third contains masonry cooking hearth with supports. A rounded tile lip runs the length of the platform. To the southwest of the cooking platform are two masonry supports of either side of the sewer opening to the street. Above the opening is a ceramic pipe feeding into the sewer from the higher level.  A window is located immediately above the cooking platform on west wall. Another window is located on the east wall close to the entrance.  Walls appear to have some remnants of utilitarian plaster, with red dado along west wall to approximately one meter. Floor is rubble.  Rough cut hole above cooking hearth area along north wall at approximately 4 meter elevation. Possible blocked up doorway where east wall meets cooking hearth, as evidence as limestone jambs, bits of plaster.

column14: Covers full length of northwest wall of room 3. Latrine is about 20 cm to the south of the platform along the west wall.
column21: Masonry cooking platform which runs the length of the north wall of kitchen room 3.  Platform is about 50 cm high (see drawing) and has a lip of  rounded tiles running the full length.  There is a tiled surface on the southwest two-thirds of the surface of the platform.  Remaining one-third to the northeast is untiled masonry with cooking supports.  Cooking platform has a medium sized window above on the northwest part of the west wall opening to the street. Portions of cooking platform appear to be reconstructed.

column14: On west wall of room 3 about 20 cm south of cooking platform. (6129).
column21: Latrine created with two masonry supports attached to the west wall of room 3. Supports are approximately 30 cm high forming U-shape with space below opening to a below sidewalk sewer in street outside. Above the latrine is evidence of a ceramic pipe which appears to run through the wall from a space above.  Latrine is unusual in that it sits openly in the kitchen about 20 cm to the south of the cooking platform. Condition is such that reconstruction may be possible although firmly attached to wall. Floor of latrine bottom slopes sharply to the street sewer. Area above latrine has been cut away through plaster to reveal piping.  Area around latrine was plastered red to about 1 meter, white above.

column14: Room 10 is located at back of house northwest of garden area (8 and 9). Store room 11 on north wall with stairs above it.  Tablinum is to the south and atrium and room 12 are to the west.
column21: Large square room overlooking garden area (9). Identified as a dining room by large doorway with lava stone threshold with view to garden to northeast. Little plaster remains to determine wall decoration. A small store room opens up on the northwest wall which utilizes the space under a stairway.  Lapilli floor. Several stones remains in threshold.  Door attachment recesses remains in door jamb.
column74: CindyComments: Small piece of plaster wall found in rubble clearly shows white and red. Plaster piece is approximately 3 cm x 3 cm.

column14: Opens to the northwest of room 10. Room 12 is to the southwest. Staircase in room 8 is immediately to the northeast.
column21: Small space off dining room number 10 situated north of dining room. Store room is southwest/northeast and is rectangular.  There is a low doorway for access. Walls show evidence of plaster including what appears to be First Style tan, orange and red painting on southwest wall. Space is approximately 300 x 100 cm. Door height is approximately 150 cm. Floor is rubble. There are no windows. The space is under stairs that rise from room 8.

column14: Back of cooking platform is on east wall of kitchen, room 15.  The north wall of the cooking platform abuts latrine room 14 and the south end of the platform is on the kitchen wall that abuts room 16.
column21: Cooking platform extends across entire width of room 15 on its' eastern most wall adjacent to the Via della Fullonica. Cooking platform is rectangular and waist high (approximately 90 cm) with arched open storage below. In the open storage area are seen remains of a plastered floor.  Cooking platform is masonry with a brick arch and has a rounded terracotta lip across the front top surface.  A low (approximately 10 cm high) 25 cm square limestone block may be seen along the south wall, approximately 50 cm from the cooking platform.

column14: none
column21: A rectangular masonry platform inserted into the southeast corner of the atrium.  The platform rests against plaster to the wall to the south.  Poorly preserved rubble structure, however fragments of in situ tiles surface as well as loose tiles originally from the tile surface of the platform are visible.

column14: "Other" Atrium 18 lies to the south, room 12 is to the west, room 16 is to the east, and room 13 is to the north.
column21: Dining room 17 opens at the south end to secondary (other) atrium 18. Very little plaster remains in the walls.  There are no windows.  Room is almost square and is identified as a dining room because of the wide doorway that open almost across the entirety of the southern wall onto atrium 18.  No floor remains. The entire structure was previously excavated pre-79AD levels. Threshold had clay tiles across the front.

column14: Contiguous to the south wall of storeroom 12 and directly southwest of latrine (6135)  centrally located along north wall of room 10(kitchen).
column21: In kitchen room 10 are two attached-to-wall masonry supports identified as being for a cooking surface.  The northwestern support is worn down to just a few centimeters from ground level.  The northeastern support appears to be intact (possibly some reconstruction).  See drawing for measurements.

column14: Immediately to the northwest is dining room 15.  Northeast wall abuts street Vicolo della Fullonica.  Southeast wall abuts kitchen room 10 and storeroom 12.  Southwest opens to peristyle 9.
column21: Large rectangular room opening up onto peristyle 9.  Room axis is northeast/southwest.  Large double-doored doorway with tufa stone threshold opened onto peristyle.  Immediately to the west of the main entrance way is another smaller doorway leading to adjoining dining room 15. Walls show evidence of high fresco decoration which Eschebach calls Fourth Style, although it is no longer visible.  The floor has areas of cocciopesto.

column14: Room 14 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room east-west axis wide open doorway opens to pseudoperistyle garden to the west.  Narrow doorway in southest end of the south wall with modern lintel opens to adjoining dining room 14.  Cocciopesto floor survives throughout with larger marble inserts of various colors.  In the center of the room is a square of marble inserts surrounded by a border of black and white tesserae that marks the position of the dining couches(6142).  Wall painting survives on all four walls with red lower register, yellow panels above.  Poorly preserved central rosettes on the north, east and south sides of the room.  Eschebach says this is Fourth Style.

column14: 6142 mosaic and 6141 painting to the southwest.
column21: Central circular rosette in the south wall of the room poorly preserved.Possible fish depicted diving (?) down in the center of the image.
column74: Cindy.Comment-to the east of central rosette is a better preserved smaller rosette depicting seated figure with blue background.

column14: West wall is on the street Vicolo di Modesto. South door opens to entry way 1. East wall abuts rooms 3 and 4. northeast wall is shared with neighboring. property VI.5.7.
column21: Entered immediately to the north/east off street entrance 8. Room appears, by masonry supports to be divided in thirds, the rear third being the latrine, the front 2/3 being kitchen. Kitchen is a narrow rectangular room on a north/south axis. The northeast 1/3 of room contains a latrine draining to the street. Two deliberate holes are inserted into east wall across from latrine south wall.

column14: Located on the west wall in southwest 2/3 of the room. Latrine (6149) is about 50 cm. to the north.
column21: A pair of masonry supports are located in the west wall of the kitchen (room 2) immediately off the west doorway to entryway (room 1). Supports are low (see sketch for dimensions). With the southern of the pair appearing to be missing about half of its length. The northeastern-most support appears to be full length. Space between the two supports is about 60 cm.

column14: Located in kitchen (2) along the northwest walls. Masonry platform supports area to the northwest and is bounded by the kitchen to the south.
column21: Located in the northwest area of the room, the latrine is defined by a sloping floor, masonry support and a niche in the wall for the insertion of a seat. The niche in the wall turns the corner from the southwest to northwest walls and ends at its masonry support about 1/3 of the way down the wall. Latrine is raised from the kitchen floor by about 10 cm. Walls are of plain masonry. Floor is currently covered with plastic which indicates previous archaeological work and protects terracotta slabs. There is no sign of windows. There are two man made holes in the east wall suggesting attachments.

column14: Atrium 6 lies to the west, room 11 to the east.
column21: Rectangular room, east west axis. Doorway in the center of the east and west walls opening to atrium 6 to the west end parallel to the east. An obvious addition to the southwest of the west wall was made in antiquity, narrowing the west doorway. No extant decoration on walls. Floor obscured by lapilli. Eschebach identifies this as a dining room (as did the PI in 2001)However, note the through way of the two doors.

column14: Garden to the east.
column21: This is a rectangular room, east west axis. Doorway in east wall opens to the garden to the east. An earlier doorway leading west had been blocked. No extant decoration on the walls, floor obscured by lapilli. Piece of remaining masonry in northeast door sill suggests the door must have opened into room if a door existed.

column14: Mosaic 6142 and painting 6140 a and b to south,  paintings 6139 a and b to north.
column21: Square central image poorly preserved on middle of east wall. A large central fish is still clearly visible.

column14: Garden to the west. Storeroom 3 to the north. Triclinium 6 to northeastern corner.
column21: Open air triclinium 6 lies on the northwest side of the hotel. It included U shaped masonry couch. According to Fiorelli and Jashemski, the dining space was shaded by pergola; but there is no evidence to support their statement. The triclinium faces the entrance 2 to the south. The very badly preserved conditions do not allow us to define any type of possible decoration of this dining space, except for traces of painted red and possible green painting along the northwestern wall.
column74: No video information on Feature Sheet

column21: The masonry couch in the open air triclinium is U shaped with the central area facing southeast. The 3 couches slope down outwards. In the northern corner between the eastern and northwestern couch is a high buttress that makes an incomplete triclinium couch. This structure does not show any trace of painting nor the usual ledge around the inner sides. The eastern corner of the northeastern couch adjoins triclinium 6 so close that one had to step over this couch in order to get to corridor 5.
column74: No video information on this Feature Sheet.

column14: Dining garden 2 to the west; corridor 5 to the southeast and kitchen 4 to the northeast.
column21: Storeroom 3 opens to the northwest.  Opposite corridor 5 is a small square room whose western and northwest walls are mostly preserved in their height.
column74: No video information on this Feature Sheet.

column14: Room 5 to southeast.
column21: The kitchen is located in the north corner of the house.  One enters the kitchen from Room 5 from the southeast. The room is roughly square. There is a little platform abutting the southeast, southwest and northwest walls. On the northwest wall in the north corner is a large niche lararium.  Below the lararium on the floor a short distance from the northwest wall is a construction that may have been a hearth or altar.  The room was plastered and painted a red color. On the northeast wall just outside the entrance to the kitchen is a lararium. The height of the room and the type of floor are indeterminate.
column74: No video information on this Feature Sheet.

column14: Hearth to the southeast. Preparation platform to the south and southwest.
column21: On the northwest wall in the north corner is the niche lararium. The interior is stuccoed and painted. On the back wall is a painting showing the Deity "Abundance" reclining on a bed (according to Fiorelli).
column74: No video information on this Feature Sheet.

column14: Hearth and Lararium to the north.
column21: On the east wall just outside the doorway to the kitchen is the niche lararium.  The interior was painted though the decoration is unknown because the back wall is not extant.
column74: No video information on this Feature Sheet.

column21: This is the house of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. In the north corner of the northwest wall is a small couch niche which is approximately 1 and 1/2 meters in length and runs on a northeast southwest axis. No evidence of paint.

This is the house of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. We enter the preparation room from the northeast. There is a marble threshold containing holes for door posts. The door is narrow but high. Red, yellow and white painted plaster survives on the southeast portion of the entrance. Painted plaster survives on all four walls, but the room is poorly preserved. The floor is covered with lapilli. On the southwest wall are two vertical parallel groups of holes. On the south are three holes and on the west are four holes which correspond with the exception of the lowest one on the west side. On the west corner of the northwest wall is feature 3135, a lararium, which is approximately 1 and 1/2 meters from the ground. Above the lararium is evidence of molding which corresponds to a small extant portion of intricate cornice on the southeast upper wall. The height of the ceiling is indeterminate.

This is the house of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This is a small square lararium on the west end of the northwest wall, approximately 1 to 1 and a 1/2 meters from the ground. It is approximately 50 centimeters wide and 20 centimeters deep. Poorly preserved plaster is extant on the middle portion on the northeast side with no evidence of paint.

This is the house of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. Room 14 runs along a southeast axis. One enters the dinning room one of two ways: from the northwest one gains access through the main entrance off the peristyle. The small service entrance maybe accessed from the north side of the northeast wall. Plaster exists on all four walls. There is evidence of blue, red and gold paint. The floor is obscured with debris. The height of the walls is indeterminate. There is no ceiling.

This is the house of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. We enter this dining hall from the southeast across a marble threshold to floor of opus signinum. This large rectangular room has a decorated northwest wall with evidence of plaster remaining on three walls and the entrance side walls. No evidence of bearing support for ceiling. No roof now exists. On northwest wall we see third style wall covering which includes Hercules in red toga contemplating seven nymphs engaged in music making. Two of the nymphs each hold a lyre. Garden fences and small shield as border 1 meter from floor. We appreciate the care taken with the paintings' portion and sense of mystery and something special happening. This northwest fresco is thankfully protected by a 6 foot overhang. On the south portion of the southwest wall approximately 2 meters above the floor is a framed portrait of one couple, male/female, (14 inches by 14 inches). The male face shows features and expression. The woman shows only two eyes and part of the hair. The painting has a blue background. The picture is protected by tile overhang.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. You enter the L-shaped kitchen from the south. The longer portion of the room is on a northeast/ southeast axis. In the western corner of the southwest wall is a bench. On the northeast wall is a large cooking platform (3139) which is in poor condition. Centered over the cooking platform is a large window to the street. On either side of the large window are two smaller windows. There are remains of a low plastered bench along the northwest wall with a small drain embedded at the most northwest corner. A small patch of plaster remains on the northwest wall approximately a meter from the ground. Adjoining the cooking platform along the northeast wall (north side) there remains plaster painted in yellow with red above. On the east portion of the southeast wall is a large window connecting room 19 to room 20. The walls are extant to the first story. The floor is obscured with lapilli and debris. On the west side of the southwest wall there is a small recess with a lip whose function is unknown.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. The large cooking plate form which is in poor repair has a raised ledge on the northwest side. It has a tiled surface. It is about 0.8 meters high. it is located under a large window.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. We enter this dining room from the southwest over a volcanic threshold which contains grooves for a security door. The lintel is reconstructed. The small room is square and is on northeast southwest axis. Plaster is apparent on all four walls with remains of cornice molding on the northeast, southeast and southwest walls. There is some evidence of red, yellow, white and blue paint. There is a high window opposite the door on the northeast wall. The floor is obscured with lapilli. Walls are extant to the first floor. There is no roof. In the east corner of the northeast and southeast walls we see remnants of gold and red border stenciling and blue paint. Room could been vaulted, based on molding remains.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. We enter the rectangular dining room from atrium 26 from the southeast. We cross a white marble threshold which has post holes and tracks. There is a high modern lintel and plaster on both sides of the door jam with evidence of red and white paint. The room runs along a northeast southwest axis. In antiquity it appears that the walls were painted with a reddish color framed by darker red panels and stenciling. Evidence is most prominent on the northwest wall. However all four walls suggest the same motifs. On the southwest wall is a large window which gives view to a large peristyle of the Corinthian style. In the corner of the southwest- northwest walls there remains a pillar constructed of brick covered with painted plaster to match the walls and extending to first story level. In the north portion of the northwest wall is a large deep niche (3149). The walls are in disrepair; however they reach first story height. The floor is obscured with lapilli and there is no ceiling.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. One enters this L-shaped room from the long end (southeast) with a northwest southeast axis. Immediately on the northeast wall is a large cooking platform above which is a small narrowing window to the street. Centered along the northeast wall there are four holes which suggest support for shelving. A second window on this northeast wall is higher and wider than the first. The northeast wall curves eventually forming the northwest wall of the room. Within this curve, adjacent to the aforementioned window, is a modern lintel which has apparently replaced an arch contiguous to the large oven(3150). This structure along with the curved wall forms an irregular space which could have been used for kneading. The area did not receive a separate designation as a room due to the lack of a pass through to the oven. The major portion of the northwest wall is the large oven which projects directly into the space. Another archway which adjoins the northwest wall and extends to the southwest of the short end of the L-shape provides entrance to the remaining spaces which are also designated by smaller arches. The large, low, wide arch (3144) on the southeast wall possibly for grain storage is plastered. The arch which is the southwest most portion of the room houses a well (3152) and has a hole above in the arch itself for passage of water. On the northwest wall just north of the well is entrance to room 29. There is a large water basin north of the oven. The archway and oven wall are mostly brick and volcanic. The height of walls appear to be preserved to first story height and the floors obscured with lapilli and broken bricks. There is no ceiling extant.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This a cooking platform. It abuts the partition on its southeast side which separates it from the latrine (3153). The cooking platform is a low stone feature without outer surfaces preserved. The northeast side wall is devoid of outer surface. A series of four hole across the northeast wall provided shelving above the platform. There is a small vertical window in the northeast wall above the platform.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This is a vaulted storage niche. It is located directly south of the oven. This niche is barrel vaulted. it has a plaster floor. The walls and vault are also plastered with vestiges of red paint. The exterior face is arched brick and stone work.
Poorly preserved square base of a rubble cooking platform inserted against the plaster of the south wall of the dining room.

column14: Room is in northeast corner of the whole structure. To the southwest is dining room 27, to the south east is dining room 29, and due south through the doorway is room 30, an open area for carts.
column21: Large rectangular room at northeast corner of the  property.  Axis of the room is north northwest by southeast.  Little plaster remains on any of the walls.  Four joists on the east wall and approximately ten holes, evidence of a second story.  With opus quadratum above, incertum below (no wall).  Three small high windows located directly below the joists in the northeast wall.  Access to the room was provided by a small doorway on the south wall and the southwest corner.  Room was identified as a dining room because of (1) the size, (2) view through small doorway led to a large open area, and (30) floor is lapilli and weed.

This is a roughly rectangular shaped dining room, and axis is east west.  Identified by size and location as a dining room.  Plaster evidence on walls shows the same red-below-white pattern as we have seen elsewhere in the service-type quarters of this house.  The west wall appears to be a modern reconstruction for the most part.  A narrow doorway is located on the west wall.  The floor is rubble.  No windows evident.  Small niche in center of north wall approximately 2.10 high.  Two rectangularly-shaped blocks situated at the bottom center of the east wall.  Surrounded by single lentil all set amid irregularly shaped stones.
column74: CindyFloor is lapilli rather than rubble.

column21: A floor to ceiling cupboard niche is located on the north corner of the east wall.  The niche extends approximately half of the total length of the wall, beginning at the north corner to the door.  The interior is covered with red and yellow plaster with the remains of red paint.  The niche appears to have extended from floor to ceiling.  Covered niche designation was determined upon recent work by P. Allison.  Minor (ancient?) metal repair 'wings' appear along mortar line.  Repair in lower right area.

Small space walled off from identified cooking area to the southeast wall of the room 37.  Space is approximately 50 x 70 cm (see drawing).  Walls are covered in plaster with red paint up to about 1.5 m.  Floor is rubble. On east wall of latrine approximately 1.6 m from floor is horizontal volcanic stone and a possible opening.

column14: Water storage (6023) to the northwest and crossroads shrine (6025) to northwest
column21: Between Via _______ and Via ______ at the tip of the triangle is a public fountain.  It is rectangular.  The block that distinguishes the location is devoid of a distinguishing feature pattern.  There is a step on the southwestern side.  Inside the fountain is a drain in the southeast side which empties onto the street.  Stones (large and irregular basalt) are located (3) out of (4) corners.  The north corner is missing a stone.  These were to avoid traffic damage.  In the center of the southeast side is a channel for overflow.  Indentations of metal clamps that held the sides of the fountain together are still visible.

The low preparation platform abuts completely the southeast and southwest walls. It extends a small distance along the northwest wall. It appears that the platform was stuccoed, but there is no evidence of decoration.

column14: Room 1 is to the southeast.
column21: Dining room 6 is located in the back of the house abutting the northeast wall. One enters the room from the southeast. The room is roughly square in shape. The height of the ceiling and the construction of the floor are indeterminate. As extant the floor has been excavated down below the original level of the room. The walls lack any evidence of plaster.

column14: Lararium is to the northwest. The preparation platform is to the south.
column21: The hearth is located near the northern corner of the room. It is square in shape, but the original height is indeterminate.

column14: Atrium 15 is to the northwest.
column21: The square bedroom is converted for use as a store room/kitchen in its final phase. The doorway in the north corner with plastered jambs, modern lintel to atrium 15. A stone threshold preserves the placing for a door. The floor is opus signinum with decoration in the northeast half of the room consisting of flowers in white and black tesserae surrounding a geometric pattern in white tesserae. The southwest corner of the floor has been removed to place a cupboard. The adjoining walls are undecorated. On the remaining walls are preserved throughout early 2nd Style with red and yellow panels, architectural motifs and two ramnant, equine figures in the southeast corner . Undecorated plaster survives above on the northeast wall. A modern roof in the north corner. A rectangular recess has been inserted into the wall with modern restoration. Traces of undecorated plaster survive overlying the floor in the northeast and southeast. Cooking platform (3074) is against the northeast wall. The room contained 3 cupboards and was used for storage and  cooking in its final phase. A section of painting has been removed from the western corner of the room.

column14: Other features: Paintings 6141 (a & b) are to northwest, 6140 (a & b) to southeast.Other rooms: Peristyle 9 is to southwest. Dining room 14 is to southeast.
column21: Rectangular mosaic insert with marble insets into the cocciopesto floor. Border of black and white tesserae surrounding multicolored marble inserts into cocciopesto. Surrounding hexagonal hole for table base or mosaic emblemata or a similar feature. The feature is placed so that the dining couches can be arranged around the northwest, northeast, and southeast sides. A small doorway leads southeast to dining room 14, while doorway with double doors to the southwest looks out onto peristyle 15.

A floor-to-ceiling covered niche is located on the north corner of the east wall. The niche stems approximately half of the total wall distance beginning at the north corner, to the door. The interior is covered with red and yellow plaster with remains of red paint.  The niche appears to have extended from floor to ceiling. Cupboard niche designation was determined based upon recent works by T. Allison. Minor (ancient?) Metal repair "wings" appear along mortar line repair in lower right area.

column14: Kitchen 28 (3142) to the south east.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. The entrance on the southeast has a small low doorway. When you enter from the southeast going northwest you immediately see a rectangular opening to the oven entrance on the east end on the northeast wall. The floor is lapilli the walls are mud and rubble with low grade concrete coating on parts of the wall. The ceiling has the barrel vault. There is a skylight opening on the northwest end of the barrel vaulted ceiling. To our surprise we found a catillus ( round upper mill stone). The lava catillus  is in the north corner. There are no mills in this kitchen. Why is the top of the mill found here? Betty Jo speculates this was once a bakery, but the usual 3 to 4 mills were removed to provide more space. There is no sign of a kneading machine in this house.

column14: Room 25 is to the northeast and can b accessed through a small doorway.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. Entering through to a very large dining hall from the southeast past an old peristyle with nine columns and two engaged columns that are on the next house wall. The outside entrance of the room is wide and formally decorated with plaster molded to copy marble slabs in a a second style form. There is no discernible threshold. The floor shows some evidence of a white marble chipped floor adjacent to the northwest, northeast and east corner. No ceiling is evident. On the walls is a second layer of concrete with finish coat of paint. In the east corner there is a small low doorway with a low lintel that provides egress to room twenty five. The doorway is through the northeast wall and has a basalt threshold. No dining dining features are evident except for the scale of the room and its location. The location provides a view of the ancient peristyle. On the peristyle columns there is evidence of red paint and doric capitols.

column14: This dining hall is contiguous to 24 to the southwest and opens to the peristyle court 23 to the south east. There is a stairway in room 23 which located outside the eastern corner of 25.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This is a dining hall on a northwest southeast axis. There is a wide entrance on the southeast side and small doorway on the end of the southwest wall connecting to dining hall 24. The floor of this hall was cocciopesto with stone threshold. The walls of this hall are decorated with frescos in a first painting style. Alternating panels of red, yellow and green are divided by yellow borders, which are delineated  in raised plaster. This first style decoration has a dado and wide band and the rectangular panels of the medium zone. The upper zone is also divided into rectangular panels. This room is on axial alignment with the primary entrance. Overall this room has excellent preservation on the northwest and southwest walls. The roof is reconstructed as a sloping roof.

column14: Beehive oven 3150 to the northwest.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. The large water basin is located in front and to the north of the oven. The water basin is made out of stone covered with cocciopesto lining. The basin features two handles (bassos). The depth of the basin cannot be determined because of the soil and ash filling approximately half of the vessel.

House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. In the northeastern corner of the northwest wall running on a southwest-northeast axis, is a deep couch niche which is approximately one meter in length fifty centimeters high fifteen centimeters deep. The support is modern. There is no evidence of paint.

column14: Water basin feature 28-3148
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. The work area is called a kitchen but is unique because it includes a large enclosed oven with evidence of a large preparation room and a possible kneading area. The oven is good shape and shows no evidence of restoration. The attributes associated with the oven are the water basin, the preparation room and the possible kneading room. There are no mills, or though there is a catillus in the preparation room to the southwest of the oven and a catillus in the peristyle. The large enclosed oven has a projecting brick faced arch which accompanies a rectangular ash pit and a rectangular opening. There is no iron grill to cover the baking entrance. The interior of the beehive oven features a square shaped recess that currently does not go through to the southwest wall. There are basalt stones framing the oven opening and basalt stones supporting the arch over the oven entrance facade and a basalt floor in the entrance to the oven and inside the oven. To our surprise we see a small arched opening to the northeast of the oven with no floor at the base of the arch, but has a floor at the base of the oven. The small arched opening to the northeast of the oven opening requires additional study. In the oven there is a passage way to the preparation room.

column14: Atrium 26 to the southwest.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. We enter this small square dining room, which has a high narrow doorway, from the southwest. There is a white marble threshold with post holes and a modern lintel above. There is a small bit of painted red plaster on both sides of the door jam. All four walls show evidence of a lower red painted plaster register above which is white paint showing remains of gold stenciling and red and green paint which created borders for decorative panels.  There is a window centered high in the northeast wall. The walls are preserved to first story height and on the northeast wall in the north corner maybe evidence of molding. In general the room is in disrepair. The floor is lapilli and pile of modern tiles. There is ceiling extant and the view from within the room looking southwest is directly into the impluvium in the atrium and the peristyle.

column14: This well is located to the west of the storage niche.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This is a well. It is within a niche with a vaulted ceiling which is pierced by a round whole directly above the well. The hole is capped at the upper level by a stone well head. The well is plaster lined. There appears to be a drain at the northeast side. The well head is well cut stone. The niche is plastered . No paint is preserved. The archway of the well niche is stone vousoirs.

column14: The latrine is contiguous to the cooking platform 3143 to the northwest.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This small rectangular room is the latrine. It is located directly north of the kitchen door. It is aligned on a northeast southwest axis. There is a stone threshold. No other flooring is visible. The northeast wall has a low stone platform going from the north corner going half way across the wall. This supported the toilet seat. Cuttings in the southeast wall supporting the other side of the seat. The east corner of the northeast wall has a cut drain at the base of the wall. The walls of stone work preserving only small areas of plaster. The northeast wall has small high vertical window. The northwest side is preserved on to the height of a low partition, approximately one meter but an indentation in the northeast wall suggests it may have been twice as high.

column14: Atrium 26 to the northwest and dining room 34 to the north.
column21: House of CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This tiny room runs along a northwest southeast axis. It is rectangular in shape and appears to be a preparation room. There is a modern lintel. The lower register is plaster painted red on all three walls and the upper register is painted white plaster. On the east side of the northeast wall there are two small holes probably used to support a shelf.  The walls are preserved almost to a first story height. One large hole exists on the white plaster of the southwest wall. The floor is obscured with lapilli and pumice.

column14: northwest of the cooking platform 3139
column21: House CC Cuspii Pansa and Proculus. This feature is a latrine. It is located at the north corner of the kitchen 19. There is a low partition which separates the latrine from the cooking platform to the southeast. No flooring is visible. The remains of a low L-shaped platform remains along the northeast and the northwest walls. The east portion of the northeast wall preserves yellow and red fresco above the low platform. The northeast wall has a rectangular window. The northeast wall has cuttings in the north corner for support of the seat. A drain is visible along the northwest wall. The walls are poorly preserved with only minor traces of stucco. The north wall is ashlar masonry. There is also one ashlar block on the northwest wall. The wall above the ashlar block is poorly preserved. The low L-shaped platform remains along the northwest and northeast wall preserves a section of its plastered surface on its southeast side.

column14: Room 1 is to the southwest.
column21: We enter this tiny square kitchen which lies at the northeast end of the shop from the southwest. There are a half/cooking platform, shelves and a latrine in the room, the former two on the southeast and northeast walls. Support holes fort he latrine are in the west corner along the northwest and southwest walls. The walls are plastered and painted red in the first register. High the southeast wall just over the shelves is a round opening and high on the northeast wall in the center is a window which is a light aperture as well as a vent for smoke. The walls on the northwest, northeast and southeast sides extend to the second story height and on the southwest wall above the door way the wall is lower, however it still extends above the first story level. The floor is obscured but seems to have been cement in antiquity. The threshold, which is still intact, is a step made of volcanic rock. Eschebach reports that in the kitchen there is a graffitto: "carmina communemne arma virumque ceno tro." The graffitto is not visible today. If this shop, as evidence suggested were bronze and iron workshop this passage from Virgil's Aeneid is befitting.

column14: The latrine is to the west.
column21: The hearth and shelf structure runs along a northeast southwest axis and the short arm abuts the northeast wall and the long arm abuts the southeast wall. On the northeast end we find a cooking platform which is small and almost square with a terracotta cooking surface which is partitioned on the southwest end and adjoins the remaining shelf. Underneath the cooking platform is an arched opening for kindling and is plastered on the southeast wall. The other portions of the structure are volcanic rock and the shelves, which are badly deteriorated today, extend the approximate distance along the southeast wall on the southwest end on the structure.

column14: Hearth and shelves 3195 on the northeast and south east walls.
column21: Two deep recesses which form a "V" at the corner of the northwest and southwest walls appear to have been supports for a latrine. Each recess is approximately ten centimeters deep and ten centimeters high. Each is twenty to twenty five centimeters in length.

column14: Storage area 21-3165 to the east.
column21: The kitchen is entered from the northeast from the portico. The kitchen has a mud floor. The walls show signs of minimal plaster. The entire room is roofed by a large barrel vault. You are struck by the coolness of the kitchen. The kitchen is of a good size but suitable for a house this size. The kitchen has an elaborate large cooking platform on the southwest wall abutting the southeast and southwest walls. Above the cooking platform is a smoke hole and a sky light opening. The sky light opening above the southeast wall. There is a mid height northwest southeast wall separating a latrine from the cooking platform area. Above the latrine is a sky light opening in the southeast wall at ceiling level that has been blocked in antiquity. The cooking are is very spacious. On the northwest wall near the entrance is a rectangular block of stone abutting the wall. The low block of stone may have served as a preparation platform.

column14: Latrine 3164 to the northeast.
column21: The cooking platform is on the south end of the southwest wall. The cooking platform is large and has two recesses for wood or charcoal. The room has a barrel vault ceiling. The cooking platform abuts on the southwest wall which features a small skylight opening on the southeast wall above the platform. The platform has a small portion of front lip. The platform features rear shelf from the wall. The platform back abuts on the southwest wall. The platform features a tiled surface. There is no roasting pit.

column14: Dining room 5 to the northwest, atrium, and room 3 to the south east.
column21: We enter this dining room from the atrium on the north corner of the northeast wall through a narrow passage way over a white marble threshold with tracks for doors. A second access is a lower doorway on the northwest wall which leads to the dining room. Evidence of painted plaster is on northwest, southwest and southeast walls. On the southwest wall at the south end is evidence of yellow paint which has been covered in antiquity with plaster perhaps for redecoration. There are couch niches: a small one on the northeast wall just inside the doorway and much larger longer one which extends from approximately the middle to the south end of the southwest wall. the floor is obscured with lapilli however the doorway in the northwest wall suggests a cocciopesto floor in antiquity. There is no ceiling and walls are preserved to approximately first level height.

column14: Room 6 to the northwest. The atrium to the northeast and room 4 to the south east.
column21: This is a small dining room one can enter from the atrium from the northeast through a very tall doorway with a marble threshold with cuttings for double doors. The flooring was cocciopesto with white tesserae. Both the southeast and northwest walls have doorways have doorways on their northeast ends. These are both low doorways. The door on the northwest wall connects to the formal dining room 6. The floor of room 5 is at a slightly lower level. All four walls preserve most of their frescoed surface. Crown molding remains in part on both the northwest and southeast walls. The wall decoration preserves shadowy traces of painting which suggests that this room matched room 6. The only difference is that these frescos go up to the ceiling level.

column14: The atrium to the northeast and the small dining room 5 on the south east side.
column21: This is a formal dining room. The principal entrance is from the northeast from the atrium. The entrance is the full width of the room. Engaged pillars flank the opening and the lintels are supported by two Ionic columns. The front pillars were refurbished with one or two layers of thick plaster which extended the pillars beyond the surface of the walls. While we now carved scenic capitols these may have been covered over as well. On each of these capitols the northeast faces have been intentionally damaged, where essential motifs have been removed and the little side columns remain intact.   The inner sides each preserve a figural scene. The one on the north corner depicts a relief of a Pan and a Meanad.  The eastern corner capitol depicts a seated figure perhaps of Dionysus with a fully clothed female figure standing behind him. The floor of this room was cocciopesto and oddly covered over the bases of the columns. The three walls all preserve their final frescos. The plaster is very thick and at least two layers are discernible. The tree walls also preserve and elaborate molded cornice with dentil decoration. Except for a short door connecting the dining room to a smaller dining room to southeast, the three walls of this room preserve third style wall paintings. These have white backgrounds. The dado is divided into small rectangular panels with small rectangles alternating with large ones. The small ones have shields with fillets. The mid section preserves the vertical lines dividing large panels but no other details are visible. These dividing lines are in red and yellow, some with highly ornate decoration. The upper panel just below the cornice molding shows delicate birds in red paint in small rectangular panels alternating with large rectangular panels containing red griffins flanked by stylized tree motifs and delicate red branches. The remaining fresco plaster preserves no paint except in the west corner. The upper walls preserve beam holes on the northwest wall and southeast wall.

column14: Room 19 is to the south. Room 27 atrium is to the west.
column21: One enters this rectangular dining room which runs on a northwest southeast axis from the southwest. There is a marble threshold with tracks for secured doors. The height of the southwest wall is indeterminate. The northwest and northeast walls and east side of southeast wall are preserved to the first floor. The northwest wall shows indication of reconstruction marked by terracotta tiles below which some plaster survives. In the eastern corner of the room on the northeast and southeast wall faces traces of plaster survive. The floor is covered with lapilli. No ceiling is present.

column14: Kitchen 20 to the south. Dining room 26 to the south east.
column21: This large rectangular garden is to the northwest of the portico and is surrounded by high walls on the northeast and southwest and low wall on the northwest which contains four steps up to a higher level for what Jashemski denotes as a flower garden. On the southwest wall there five beam holes on the upper register and five beam holes approximately halfway up the wall on the west end. High in the middle portion of the wall is a deep rectangular window. Two holes are on the southwest wall to the south. On the northeast wall there is one visible hole high in the wall. Jashemski and others describe furrows as excavated in 1865. Today some depressions are extant suggesting the furrows run in a northeast southwest pattern. In the south portion of the garden near the southwest wall are a cistern cover or puteal. Today the garden is covered with grass and bay laurel bushes surround the perimeter, five each on the southwest and northeast and three on the northwest wall. This garden runs on a northwest and southeast axis. On the east corner of the northeast wall a rose bush grows.

column14: Peristyle to the northeast, stairway on the northwest, dining room 6-3160 on the south east.
column21: The store room is entered from the northeast from the peristyle through a very high linteled doorway. The door threshold indicates the door could have been locked. The floor has a small patch of cocciopesto in the north corner. The walls are plastered and painted white. The corners of the room all feature red paint. We identified this as a food and drink storage room because of the evidence of shelf support holes in all four walls. The support holes are at two levels. There are eight holes at the lower level and seven holes at the lower level. We have small oval shaped opening on the southwest wall located well above the top shelf support holes. The opening provides light and ventilation. The wall extends to the second story and has rafter strut holes on the northwest and southeast walls. The holes indicate there was a high ceiling but there is no other evidence of a ceiling. The shelving is evident in the indentations in the plaster above the shelf struts. On the northeast wall the width of the shelves is evident in the impression in the plaster (width approximately five centimeters). On the southwest wall there is a stain that runs from the opening on the southwest wall to the floor.

column14: Room 2 and 3 to the northeast.
column21: The shop is opposite the Stabian Baths, with an altar to the south. The sidewalk is very wide. The stop is a step up from ashlar masonry which shows a door indentation across counter space indoor entrance. A large U-shaped counter is immediately apparent on the southeast wall. The flooring is lapilli. There is no roof or windows. Doorway (large) to a dining room and preparation room are to the northeast. The wall on the southeast is painted with holes for two layers of shelving. Height of walls are extant ti first floor. You can see three holes for top shelf and three holes for bottom. Southeast wall is propped up with scaffolding.

column14: Counter room (1) to the southwest; processing room (3) to the northwest.
column21: A large rectangular dining room runs on a northwest/southeast axis and we enter it from the southwest, which is northeast of the counter room (1). The southeast and northeast walls are preserved to a second story height, while the wall on the northwest slopes from the northeast to the southwest and is lower. Evidence on all walls suggest panels of red and yellow on the lower register and painted white plaster with evidence of some stenciling on the northeast, southeast, and northwest walls. The floor is obscured by lapilli and debris. There is a recess on the northeast wall which suggests a blocked window in antiquity which had been plastered for unknown use. The large doorway from the southwest contains a partial wall on the south side made of brick and covered with plaster painted red. We can see directly into the counter room and possibly into the street from this the doorway.

column14: Room 1 is directly toward the southwest side of this room. Room 3 is to the southeast side.
column21: This is a narrow, rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis for food processing. The entrance to the room was a door on the southwest wall. Only a small cutting in the masonry at the south corner indicates a door. This room is aligned with the front entrance. Flooring is not visible. The southwest wall is not preserved. The northwest and northeast walls are preserved to a great height, but the southeast wall is very poorly preserved. The northwest, northeast, southeast walls preserved plaster coating with fresco visible on northeast and southeast walls. Although poorly preserved, there are traces of red paint.
