Feature number 3185, a low vat, is located along the northwest wall.

column14: Shelf (3186) to the northwest.
column21: At entrance to the shop, you can see a U-shaped counter. The entrance to the counter is on the northeast side. The counter arm on the southeast side has 3 dolia. A heavy layer of concrete covers the U-shaped counter. The southwest arm faces the street. The arm on the northwest side contains 2 dolia but are aligned by stone and brick. The counter is restored. The height is approximately 1 meter. Each arm is approximately 2 meters long.

This feature is a stone vat. It is located on the northwest wall and is a long, narrow rectangular form. This is very poorly preserved. At the northwest side, it abuts the wall and has two horizontal cuts in the wall toward its west corner. The walls of the vat remain along the southwest, southeast, and northeast sides and a low brick and tile surface remains at the northeast end of the vat. The ceramic tiles are embedded in plaster and were covered with a plaster having a terracotta matrix.

column14: Counter (3184) is to the southeast.
column21: This feature consists of 2 large, high steps (brick and rock) which run along a northwest/southeast axis and join in the west corner of the southwest wall upon entering the room (1). The portion which runs along the northwest wall consists of 2 volcanic stones which join from the wall, the most northern of which shows evidence of a metal fastening.  The surface suggests that the entire structure was plastered in antiquity.

We enter shop by stepping up from pavement on Via Stabiana, one shop away from the corner of Via Abbondanza. The entrance is a wide door. The threshold is one step up from the sidewalk. Southeast wall is resplendent with a penis and a scrotum in a rectangular frame at shop lintel, height. The outside walls are brick interspersed with opus reticulatum. On the northwest side of the doorway entrance is a quern. There is a ceiling to floor recess on the northeast wall, approximately 1 meter wide. At northwest of entrance is a cooking platform, which is relatively tall. To southeast of entrance is a feature-preparation platform. It is the same height of the cooking platform. The floor is lapilli-covered. Plaster on the northwest wall corner has red paint and darker paint. No windows or ceiling in this room.  The shop is on the northeast side of the street.

column14: Cooking platform 3173 to the northwest.
column21: This is a rectangular preparation platform. It is located along the south half of the southwest wall to the south of the entrance.  This platform is constructed of stone and preserves the remains of a plaster top.

column14: Preparation 3172 to the northwest.
column21: We enter from the southwest and immediately to the northwest is a structure for cooking which consists of two U-shaped segments. This is an unusual structure in that on the southwest side we border the entrance and form the southwest and longer segment. Within this structure, we find a raised tufa stepped like portion which is approximately 20 centimeter high and 30 centimeter deep. On the western corner of the structure is a short pillar which may provide support for a grill. The northeast segment of the structure is a narrow pit/grill and consists of the middle partition to the extreme northeast end of the platform. Bottom of this second tufa segment is the same height and runs parallel to the step portion of the southwest segment.  The innermost face of this structure on the northeast is thick and contains some pieces of terracotta tiles on the surface. The long arm which runs southwest/northeast also contains several terracotta tiles on the surface.

Lararium is located in the east corner in this atrium which is southeast of the atrium entrance. It is a large square aedicular shrine. The platform rests on a base approximately 1.5 meters from ground. Base is topped with a double band of decorative stucco molding and the two sides of the base are frescoed with red paint on a white background, preserving what may be paintings of an aedicular shrine on each side. The west corner supports a column, doric in style, with yellow and red marbleizing paint. North and south corners have pillars topped with double rows of stuccoed moldings and abaci. Molded cornices above and both sides have pediments that are also plastered mold decorated. The interior of the lararium preserves a curved back platform in the southeast wall. This brick with fresco coverings and paintings appear to be 3rd Style. White upper structure is brick, the base is mixed brickwork and stonework, including an area with exposed opus reticulatum on the southwest side.

column14: Peristyle portico to the northwest (5).  Dining room to north (7) -2862).
column21: This is a minority report.  We enter the dining room from the southeast end of the peristyle portico.  It is the final room along the portico in that direction.  The threshold is marble.  It has a red painted western door entrance in the lower section.  We have the same black pavement with white tessera.  This is a square room with a large window overlooking a peristyle garden.  The window is on the southwest wall.  All 4 walls show recent repainting.  The lower zone is black with a plant motif.  The room's second painted zone shows two pictures, one on the northeast wall, the other on the southeast wall.  The northeast wall picture is faded while the southeast wall picture shows Venus and cupid and a male figure.  The central zone is blue.  On the southeast wall panel to the left we have amorini.  The two blue central zone panels framing the window on the southwest wall show amorini.  The dining room has a typical barrel vault.  There is evidence of a top white zone with architectural features and a peacock.

column14: Dining room (2861) to the northwest; dining room (2862) to the southeast; peristyle portico (5) to the southwest
column21: This a minority report.  We enter this storeroom from the southwest over a threshold which shows evidence of a door with locks.  It is a long rectangular storeroom on a northeast/southwest axis.  The floor is now covered with dirt which covers a white tessera floor.  The 4 walls show much evidence of plastering in cream/white with no designs.  The northwest wall has 4 definite square shelf holes that would have held 2 shelves, one above the other about a half meter apart.  The southeast wall has an identical shelf arrangement at the northwest wall, with 4 definite shelf holes.  This is a high room with possibly modern tile ceiling.
The triangular area between Via ____ and Via _____ there is an arched stone structure with one window type opening.  This is a public well behind a public fountain and a bakery.

column14: Saccellum (2881) to the northeast; room (14) to the northwest.
column21: We enter the horticultural space from the northeast.  (See Jashemski's description)  The north corner holds the saccellum and the northwest wall leads to a two-step entrance of an open garden and a single room structure.  The wall of the maritime Venus fresco in 2. 3.3 forms the remainder of the northwest wall.  The southwest wall is high with vegetation growth.  In front of the wall in the southwest corner is a possible casting of plant root.   The whole southwest corner is covered with modern tree cuttings to make way for modern vineyard.  The modern vineyard contains 293 staked vines.  The southeast corner contains an entrance for modern farm equipment.  It may indicate a large entrance in antiquity.

column14: Cooking platform (2875) and preparation platform (2876) to the northwest.
column21: The lararium is located on the southwest wall of room 11.  It is semicircular, almost 10 centimeters deep.  The walls are partly covered with a thin layer of plaster behind which was another painted surface which was covered with dados of green and red paint on a white background.  The arched vault was covered with a terracotta border which was later covered by the plaster revetting the entire wall of the room.  The ledge is deteriorated but shows some plaster along the inner ledge.

column14: Sacellum to northwest (17).
column21: We enter the horticultural area from the northeast, immediately coming to a lararium niche on the wall northwest of the entrance.  On the northwest wall rebuilt to a second floor we see an entrance approached by four steps and a large threshold.  The threshold is of pounded stone and a high window wall above the door on the second floor.  We look in through a locked gated door.  The room is square with walls in place one and a half floor high.  The first thing we see is an alter with customary scrolls (lips) of the platform top.  The lips are northeast and southwest.  The alter shows plaster without painting.  Behind the center alter is a podium which is higher than the alter.  The podium is divided into three sections by masonry struts and two columns.  On the northeast and southwest walls at about eight foot level there is evidence of molding with a top ledge.  The panel walls show faint yellow and white paint.  The podiums northwest section may have once held a painting.  There is a round section removed.  The central and most important part of the podium may show an indicular frame.  There is no painted evidence what gods were worshipped.  Custodi have placed two platforms of four sections of laid out broken wall fragments.  If they are restored and replaced, we may have more information.

column14: Room 3 to southwest.
column21: The room is located in the north corner of house.  One enters the room from northwest through entrance #5.  In the south corner of the room is the door to room 3.  Eschebach's map shows a U-shaped counter in the north corner of the room.  Nothing remains today.  Neither the height of the room or type of floor can be determined, covering no longer extant.  No stucco remains on the walls.  Floor is obscured by vegetation.
Reference: Eschebach 1993, 90-1. Eschebach: A U shaped counter once laid in the North corner of the room. The counter opens to Northeast where the salesman stood.

column14: Altar in South (2886).
column21: Behind the center altar is a podium which is higher than the altar. The podium is divided into three sections by masonry struts and two columns. The podium's Northwest section may have once held a painting. There is a round section removed. The central and most important part of the podium may show an idicular frame. There is no painted evidence of what gods were worshipped.

column14: Podium in Northwest (2885)
column21: The altar in the sacellum has the customary scrolls (lips) of the platform top. The lips are Northwest and Southeast. The altar shows plaster without painting.

column14: none listed.
column21: The western part of the room contains a floor of lava basalt blocks. The large mill room contains four mills of varying size and degrees of completeness. A pebble base is seen for all four mills. One mill has only a rubble foundation; two mills have a meta on top. The meta is solid and made of hard porous lava. One mill is complete. We see a lava catillus of hourglass shape with square sockets in place on top of the meta. This mill also has a circular metal fitting to catch the flour. On the North wall there is a door to a storage room. On the North oven wall, there is a deep niche. On the North wall of work area is a portion of plastered area painted white and deep red--27 turquoise tesserae survive- in the form of a snake (?). As in most bakeries there is very little space around the mills for the animals to move. Perhaps the horse in the stable was not used in this work area. On the North wall close to the entrance to the storage room is a plastered niche. In both corners of the East wall are embedded amphorae making the access of the animal even more difficult.

column14: Kneading machine (3084) to East; water basin (3082) to South;  water basin (3083) to the North; kneading basin (3085) to the Northeast; mills (3086, 7, 8, 9) to Northwest.
column21: As we face this large work area we will describe the ovens of the baker first. On the Southwest wall we see an elaborate oven of masonry faced with bricks. Mortar is of lime and sand in this oven. A beehive shaped baking mound was encased in a smoke chamber to enhance heat efficiency.  The oven is bricked to the ceiling. The inner beehive is enclosed. Standing on top of construction stairs we see that the beehive portion of the oven has just the open space and vent at the front of the beehive.  This is a rare chance to see the top of an oven. The whole of the mound structure  was laid on a brick base. The bottom course of the mound is wider and has hard stones to resist blows from shovels. The oven opening is rectangular. The South part of the oven has a large rectangular pass through open space to the preparation room. Beneath the lava stones is a small rectangular area usually used to hold kindling, dried brush wood, bark of flax plant, or charcoal. This is probably an ash pit for raking out the ashes. As we look at the brick lined arch to the oven we see a rectangular recessed area which probably contained a phallus/penis. On the North face of the oven is a rectangular niche. In front is a water basin on each side. There is no oven door extant.

column14: Oven (3081) to the southwest; basin (3082) to the northwest; kneading basin (3085) to the north; kneading machine (3084) to the northeast
column21: To the northeast of the southwest corner of the oven (3081) appears to be a meta flipped over onto its top and encased in masonry all abutting the oven (3081).  The hole in the top of the meta has been sealed with tile and plaster.  The use is unknown, but may have been for water or perhaps fuel for the fire or ashes.

column14: Oven (3081) to the southwest; mills (3086, 7, 8, 9) to the west; water basins (3082, 2083) to the southwest; kneading basin (3085) to the northwest.
column21: We see a round lava stone container; the metal socket is in place.  This allowed the machine to knead dough.  The vertical shaft is not in place that would have turned the arms;  still to be seen are round holes on the sides for wooden shafts which could be turned by men or animals to pull and push the dough.

column14: Oven (3081) to the southwest; mills (3086, 7, 8, 9) to the west; water basins (3083, 82) to the southwest; kneading machine (3084) to the southeast
column21: In the middle northeast wall is an interesting reuse of two catilli or mills.  The first is cemented to the wall, the second worn catillus is cemented to the first and to the ground.  The one on the wall is lined with plaster/cement.  The second more worn catillus is lined with perfectly fitted terracotta.

column14: Oven (3081) to southeast; mill (3087) to the southwest; mill (3088) to the west; mill (3089) to the northwest; kneading basin (3085) to the east; kneading machine (3084) to the southeast; water basins (3082, 3083) to the southeast.
column21: Mill (3086) is only a rubble base.

column14: Mill (3088) to the west; mill (3086) to the northeast; mill (3082, 3083) to the east; kneading basin (3085) to the east; kneading machine (3084) to the southeast
column21: Mill (3087) has a rubble foundation; meta of hard porous lava is in place, plastered surface surrounding.

column14: Mill (3087) to the southeast; mill (3086) to the southeast; mill (3089) to the northeast; kneading basin (3085) to the east; kneading machine (3084) to the southeast; water basins (3082, 3083) to the east.
column21: Mill (3088) is complete.  It has a rubble foundation, a lava catillus of hourglass shape with square sockets in place on top of the meta.  This mill also has a circular metal fitting to catch the flour.

column14: Mill (3088) to the southwest; mill (3086) to the east; mill (3087) to the southeast; oven (3081) to the southeast; water basins (3082, 3083) to the southeast; kneading basin (3085) to the east; kneading machine (3084) to the east.
column21: Mill (3089) has a rubble foundation and a meta in place made of solid porous lava; only fragmentary evidence of plaster surround.
See feature sheet 3-3090 for full record.  This sheet provides video documentation number only.  Needs to be reconciled.

column14: Contiguous to room (5) to the south.
column21: The stable is located on the east side of the house.  The room is rectangular in shape on a north/south axis.  It is approached by two entrances:  An east entrance opening on to the street and a south entrance onto hallway (5).  High on the east wall to the north of the street entrance is a window opening onto the street.  The roof of the stable is in line with the top of the window based on beam holes in the east wall.  In the southeast corner there appears to be the remains of a water trough.  The room was originally stuccoed but there is no sign of decoration.  Still present are the skeletal remains of (5) equids - whether horse, mule or donkey is unknown.  Along the west wall appears to be plaster casts of trees or posts which may have been used to tie up the animals.  At the head of the equid found in the northwest corner there is an upside down terracotta pot.  When found, one equid lay in the northeast corner, one in the northwest corner, two in the middle of the room, and one at the entrance to the east doorway.

column14: Mill-oven room (3) to the northeast.
column21: This is a rectangular room on a northwest/southeast axis.  There is a doorway (no distinct threshold) in the north corner to the mill room (3).  On the north, east and west walls undecorated plaster survives.  In the center of the east wall a red bordered vignette depicts Venus flanked by two eroti.  In the north corner there is a rectangular window to the oven through which the loaves would have been passed for baking.  In the center of the southeast wall there is a window to the street.  Animal bones lie in the floor against the west wall beaten earth floor.  In the center of the room are three stone blocks for preparation platform (3093).

column14: None listed
column21: There are three stone bases for the preparation platform along the central axis of the room used for mixing the dough prior to placing the bread in the adjoining oven.  Each of the stone blocks preserves architectural molding indicating reuse from a different structure.  There are no other features in the room. There is access to oven (3081) via the window in the north corner of the room.

column14: Mill room (3080) to the northwest.  Room (2) to the northeast.
column21: We enter this bakery/restaurant from a door in the southeast - a large entrance.  As we look into the room we see a square bread sales room.  In the north corner are steps to the upper floors.  Red painting is above the first step and plastered first two steps.  The floor is plastered mud.  No roof is extant.  In 2011 steel scaffolding fills the room.  A door on the eastern corner is low and perhaps to a bedroom.  This sales room has full vision of a wonderful bakery oven.   As we walk through the large entrance we see the work area of the baker/miller.  This is a rectangular room with a northeast/southwest axes.

column14: Mill room (3) is to the west.
column21: This rectangular room is situated on a northwest/southeast axis.  It has a plaster floor.  Plaster decoration survives on all four walls.  There is a smooth red lower register, coarse white upper register.  Only the lower course survives in the southeast wall.  The doorway to the mill room is in the center of the southwest wall with a plaster door jam and modern lintel.  There is a rectangular window high in the northwest wall with a modern lintel.  Placings for floor joists survive high in the northwest and west walls above which is the decoration of the floor above.

column14: Mill room (3) is to the southeast
column21: This is a rectangular room situated on a northeast/southwest axis.  The floor us obscured by lapilli.  In the center of the southeast wall is a doorway with a stepped threshold to the mill room (3).  Plaster decoration survives in the west corner with first style decoration.  Along the northwest corner of the room is a bench (3098) and in the east corner of the room is a vat (3099).  In 2011, the room is filled with metal stairs and scaffolding.

column14: Vat (3099) is to the southeast.
column21: A rectangular masonry bench runs along the entire northwestern wall of the room.  It has a plastered surface surviving in place and abuts directly against the plaster on the northwest wall of the room.

column14: Bench (3098) is to the north.
column21: There is a square plastered vat inserted into the floor in the east corner of the room.  The vat is filled with lapilli.

column14: Room (11) to the north.
column21: The cooking platform takes up about 90% of the room.  The platform abuts the southeast, northeast and southwest walls.  The surface was made up of terracotta tiles.  The northwest edge of the surface has a large lip across the entire width from northeast to southwest.  In the south corner there is today a large hole through which one is able to see that the platform is not solid.  The space underneath the platform is empty.

column14: Contiguous with room (11) to the southwest.
column21: One enters the dining room through a door on the south corner.  The room is rectangular in shape on a northwest to southeast axis.  The floor on a level higher is of beaten cement in a simple repetitive mosaic design of small pieces of white marble.  The window now appearing on the southeast wall is probably modern.  The height of the roof is unknown.  All four walls were stuccoed and painted in the fourth style.  On the southwest, northwest and northeast walls, in the center between thin decorative columns is a rectangular painting with black backgrounds each showing a motif of drinking parties.  There may have been another on the southeast wall where the window is located.  The other panels of the room have in their centers floating figures with red backgrounds.  Below the panels on all four sides in the lower register is an alternating pattern of triangles painted in black.

column14: Floor below.  Painting (3105) to the northwest.  Painting (3105) to the northeast.
column21: On the southwest wall in the center of a large panel formed by two thin decorated columns, is a rectangular painting on a northwest to southeast axis showing a scene from a drinking party (Greek symposium?).  Four individuals, two men and two women, lie on couches.  To the left of and behind the couch stands a woman with her head covered by a scarf, holding a cup in her right hand.  She seems to be supported by a slave behind her.  Behind appears to be a doorway.  This woman may either be herself drunk and supported by a slave, or she may be a matron astonished by what she sees having just entered the room.  The center couple recline on their left elbows; both gesture towards the veiled woman.  The man, however, looks toward the couple to his left.  The male member of this couple gestures with his right had towards the veiled woman.  The female reaches out with her right hand and removes the lid from a glass cup on the table belonging to the other couple.  Each couch has its separate tripod table.  The table to the left is more delicate and appears to have feet shaped like deer hooves.  The other table is shorter, thicker and heavier with feet shaped like lion paws.  Both tables support cups and ladles.

column14: Floor below; (3103) to the southwest; (3105) to the northeast.
column21: On the northwest wall in the center of a large panel formed by two thin decorated columns is a rectangular painting on a southwest to northeast axis showing a scene from a drinking party (Greek symposium?).  The diners recline on couches beneath a large awning or perhaps tent - one couple per couch.  Between the two couches is a tripod table on which sits a cup and ladle.  To the right a slave pours water or wine into a large bowl.  The couple on the right recline on their left elbows, the male gestures towards his right.  The woman holds a drinking cup.  The couple on the second couch exchange akiss.  To the left appears to be two servants, both facing away from the couples.  One servant drinks from a cup.  Behind the couch is another standing, possibly a slave.

column14: Floor below; painting (3104) to the northwest; painting (3103) to the southwest.
column21: On the northeast wall in the center of a large panel formed by two thin decorated columns, is a rectangular painting on a northwest to southeast axis showing a scene from a drinking party (Greek symposium?).  Four individuals, two men and two women, lie on a couch.  A servant stands to the upper right.  In front of the couch is a tripod table with small drinking cups.  On the left a man reclines holding in his left hand a drinking cup; his right hand reaches out to get a rhyton offered by the seminude female.  To their left is a second couple, the male of which has already passed out from drinking.

column14: There is a garden (number?) to the northeast. There is an atrium (number?) to the southeast.
column21: This is a dining room with a southwest/northeast axis. The main entrance is on the northeast side and is a wide opening with a view to the garden. there is a small door at the eastern end of the southeast wall. no flooring is visible. All walls preserve remains of frescoes in Pompeiian fourth style. A decorated black dado surrounds the room with a horizontal line of fruit and other decorative patterns. The frescoes on the side half of the southeast wall preserve a large yellow panel to the southern corner and with a large winged victory in the center and with a small cow above. Above this yellow panel is a square panel with a window view of the architecture beyond. The panels to the east of this have an architectural scene of a doorway below a panel of more architecture. Above the doorway are three shields. The frescoes on the southwest wall are best preserved along the bottom and sides. The side panels above the dado each show a large yellow panel with a concave edged blue rectangle. Within the rectangles portrait tondos are evident. On the northwest wall, the bottom and sides of the frescoes are preserved. A large central panel may have been removed. The western half of this wall preserves a painted niche (3190). Also on the western end of the wall is a yellow panel with a winged figure with three dead ducks suspended below (3192). At the northern end of the northwest wall the fresco includes fruit (possibly grapes) from a basket, a boar, and three dead ducks suspended with ribbon. A second niche is on the south end of the southeast wall (3193). The niches extend the room for couches. High on the northwest and southeast walls is a raised plaster molding. There is a lot of modern restoration along the edges of the frescoes.

column14: The atrium (2) is to the southwest.
column21: We enter this room from the west from the atrium, through a relatively wide door with a moderately high lintel. We move to the small rectangular kitchen avoiding a short northwest wall. the floor is lapilli and dirt. The walls show minimal signs of red  plaster.  The southwest wall shows plaster painted white with two red stripes and a window for the smoke to escape. There is no roof but there are indications of post holes for a roof. The post holes do not match as far as height. Previous reports state that there is a latrine here. We could not find evidence of a latrine.
In the east corner, we see a fairly square pile of rubble. This is undoubtedly the remnants of a cooking platform. The window in the southwest wall supports this conclusion.

column14: A painting (3192) is above. A painting (3191) is to the north. Niche (3193) is to the southeast.
column21: On the western half of the northwest wall is a painted niche. The painting at the northern half of the niche is a mythological scene on a black background. A goddess (?) enthroned on a wheeled cart is pulled by two goats. A figure behind her follows with arms outstretched and a heavy male figure is in front of her. The goddess appears to be holding a drinking cup in her left hand.

column14: Niche (3190) and painting (3192) are to the west. Niche (3193) is to the south.
column21: At the northern end of the northwest wall, the fresco is well-preserved. The panel closest to the north corner preserves the traces of a winged figure on a yellow background. To the west of this panel, is an architectural design featuring a doorway with three shields with faces above. A band above the three shields shows food including fruit from a basket and a boar. On the small column on the north side of the painting window opening is a mask at the top and three dead ducks suspended with ribbon. Other animals appear in this panel including a bird on a ledge and a leopard perched on the roof. To the north corner is an upper panel with a seated female feeding a peacock.

column14: Niche (3190) is below. A painting is to the northwest. Niche (3193) is to the southeast.
column21: On the western end of the northwest wall is a yellow panel with a winged figure. Above is a window scene with a female figure feeding a peacock. What is left of the next section shows a continuation of the architecture outside the window. A mask motif is at the top of  the column and three dead ducks are suspended below.

column14: Niche (3190) is to the northwest. Painting (3192) is to the northwest. Painting (3191) is to the north.
column21: On the southern end of the southeast wall is a niche. Plaster with black paint survives on all walls.

column14: The mill room is contiguous with rooms 1, 4 and 5.
column21: The western part of the room contains a floor of lava / basalt blocks. The large mill room contains four mills of varying size and degrees of completeness. A rubble base is seen for all mills. One mill has only a rubble foundation, two mills have a meta on top. The meta is solid and made of hard porous lava. One mill is complete. We see a lava catillus of hourglass shape with square sockets in place on top of the meta. This mill also has a circular metal fitting to catch the flour. On the north wall there is a door to a storage room. On the north oven wall there is a door to a storage room and a deep niche. On the north wall of the work area is a portion of plastered area painted white and deep red - 27 turquoise tesserae survive - in the form of a snake? As in most bakeries there is very little space around the mills for the animals to move - perhaps the horse in the stable was not used in this work area. On the north wall close to the entrance to the storage room is a plastered niche. In both corners of the east wall are embedded amphorae making the access of the animal even more difficult.

column14: Oven (3081) to the south west, mill (3086) to the north west, kneading basin (3085) to the north east, water basin (3083) to the south east, kneading machine (3084) to the east.
column21: To the north east of the north west corner of the ovens is a small stone basin, at one time encased in masonry, all abutting the oven. The interior has been cut in a cone shape and lined in plaster. On the interior west wall is a hole also lined with plaster. The use of the basin is unknown but may have been used for water.

column14: Room 11 to the north.
column21: The kitchen is approached from room 11 to the north. The room is roughly rectangular in shape on a south eat to north west axis. The room is quite small as most of it is taken up by the cooking platform. To the north west are stairs to the upper level. The walls were plastered but no sign of paint remains except on the north west facing of the cooking platform. The ceiling of the kitchen is indeterminate, if there was one.

column14: Room 9 to the northwest, room 6 is to the west.
column21: The prep room (8) is a rectangular room situated on a north west/ south east  axis. It has a plastered floor. It has an open entrance to the north west with no defined doorway. The west wall has two square plastered interior windows to the courtyard to the west. In the center of the west wall there is a placing for a down pipe from the floor above. In the south east corner is a rectangular hole has been cut into the floor against which on the east wall is a placing for an arched feature which has been cut into the undecorated plaster. Also on the east wall are three square joists for shelves (?) above which are the joist holes for the floor above. In the center of the north east wall is water feature 3107 which drains east through the wall. The channel of 3107 continues along the east wall to the north where it passes through the partition wall that isolates latrine (3108) from the remainder of the room. In the center of the northern half of the room is a cistern and water channel (3107). A low restored ceiling overlies the northern half of the room preserving the original collapsed beams and floor of the room above.

A U-shaped drain runs along the east wall from the latrine to drain through the east wall. The second arm of the drain runs diagonally across the room to the north west where it joins a terra cotta pipe and outflow from the water feature in room 6. The two arms of the water feature enclose  water cistern with a puteal consisting of a reused catillus that has been refinished with plaster. A marble puteal as been subsequently placed over the whole.

column14: Water feature 3107 to the south
column21: In the north east corner of the room, separated from the remainder of the room by a partial wall is a latrine with a plastered floor sloping east into a drain (3107) against the east wall of the room. The drain undercuts the seat of the latrine and the base of the partition wall at its junction with the east wall of the room. There is a masonry and tile seat of the latrine with a plaster lip and facing. The latrine drains through a tiled channel sloping east through the wall to a cistern outside to the east. Placings for a wooden seat survive in the north east and south west walls. There is a low ceiling, a modern restoration of the original.

column14: Room 11 to the south east
column21: One enters the small dining room through a doorway in the south east. The floor is on a higher level than room 11 to the south east requiring a step. It is of beaten cement with no discernible decoration. The room itself is rectangular in shape on a south east  to north west axis. The walls are painted and stuccoed in, essentially, Third Style. The ceiling is vaulted on a south east to north west axis. In the north corner are the remains of what may have been a small cupboard abutting the north west and north east walls.

column14: Room 11 to the east.
column21: One enters the small dining room through a doorway in the east corner. As wit dining room 12 next door, one must step up from room 11 at least one step. The floor is of beaten cement with no sign of decoration. As extant, the floor seems to have a high point in the middle creating a slope towards all four walls, possibly due to the eruption. The room is rectangular in shape on a north east to south west axis. The ceiling is barrel vaulted running south east to north west. The walls are stuccoed and painted in the Fourth Style. On the north east wall is a niche lararium

column14: Atrium (3) to the northeast.
column21: We enter the dining room from the northeast. The room runs along a northeast- southwest axis. There are two modern windows high on the southwest wall. There is a door on the south corner of the southeast wall to the adjoining room. The entire room is of modern use and decoration for the custodii. The only thing which is original is the step from the atrium into the room (northeast).

column14: Northeast is room (7), (8) and (9); northwest (3) and (4); southeast (1).
column21: From the street we enter the atrium Tuscan style displuviate through a long vestibulum facing northwest. As we look into the atrium, which runs along a northwest/southeast axis, we see an impluvium in disrepair with a broken marble cistern cover on the northwest side. The room is rectangular. The general condition of the room is poor, however some plaster remains on all walls. In the east corner of the room is a lararium which is highly decorated. There is evidence of red paint on the wall with a white lower register on all the walls. Over the lararium the paint is well preserved in third style displaying reds and yellows with intricate stenciling in gold and possibly a bird atop a standard. Plaster symbolizing faux columns is extant next to the entrances to the adjoining rooms on the northwest and southeast. The ceiling is high but indeterminate. The floor is covered with lapilli. There are doorways on all walls except the southwest wall which adjoins the neighboring property. High on the northeast wall near the east corner appears to be small window into a small dining room (9). There is a large window on the north end of the northeast wall which allows a view into the atrium from the dining room (7).
From atrium walk east into room past the lararium to the south.

column14: Room 2 to the east.
column21: This is a dining room. The entrance is located at the eastern corner of southeastern wall. The room is rectangular, oriented southwest. On the northeastern wall a window looks out from the eastern corner to the peristyle court. Couches were located at the southwest side of the room along the northwestern wall, southwestern wall, southeastern wall. Plaster preserves the shallow niche for a couch along the southeast wall. The walls are in very poor condition with only small traces of plaster. No point is preserved. The flooring is not visible.

column14: Room 5 is to the south east
column21: There is well preserved stairwell to the southeast of the entrance. We enter the room from the portico from the southeast. southeast of the portico is a garden. The portico has five brown columns at the corners. Garden is mentioned to point attractive view from the dining room. No ceiling remains. It was a room with a high ceiling. The floor is lapilli. The room is rectangular shaped. The entrance is as wide as the room. On the southwestern wall there is evidence of a very long niche for a dining couch. There is plaster 'yellow-red-white' on the southwestern wall. The west corner shows the common red paint. The northwestern wall shows a red lower register with white stenciling and a yellow band. The northeastern wall has a a red lower register with a minimal evidence of a white dado with yellow plaster. There are no windows.

This is a small dining room. The entrance is the entire width of the northwestern wall. This had a moderately high doorway. The lintel over the door space supported six beams to the southeastern wall to form a low ceiling. The walls are in poor condition,but preserve plaster and fresco decoration on northeast and southwest wall. On the southwest wall a decorative plaster molding is also preserved. A fine red line is visible below the plaster molding. The entrance is flanked with small projections that are pillar-like and preserve fresco with paint visible on the lower portion. On the southeast wall three poles supported a low shelf.

column14: Room 11 is to south east. Room 4 is to northwest.
column21: We enter the atrium from the southwest. We are on the northwest/southeast axis. The atrium is Tuscan style. The impluvium is made of twelve or. forte en volcanic stones and is ancient. The atrium was plastered in antiquity. and painted with red lower register and white upper register. On the southwest wall, west side, remains evidence of a cooking platform. The height of the wall on the southwest, southeast and northeast appear to support a second story. The north end of the northeast wall and the northwest wall height is lower. The floor is obscured by lapilli. No ceiling is extant.

column14: n/a
column21: This feature is the remains of the couch niche. Fine plaster preserves the concave space located at the south end of the southeast wall.

column14: Rooms 7 and 9 are to the north.  Room 8 is to the east.  Room 3 is to the west.
column21: A rectangular room (courtyard) situated on a northwest/southwest axis with low plastered walls along the northwest and southwest.  There are large plastered drains/troughs along the interior face of the low walls and larger plastered drains/troughs along the northeast and southeast walls.  The floor of the courtyard is plastered.  In the northeast wall there are two square plastered windows to the east.  The southeast wall has undecorated plaster and a window with a modern, restored lintel.  The southern corner of the room is separated from the remainder by a partition wall.  The space is of uncertain use but is decorated with red panels with a lower register of plants on a red background.  There are small mythical (?) xenia with an architectural molding above.  Two feline rampant on either side of a vessel with fruit on either side.  There is a vaulted ceiling.  The use of this space is unclear (possible ritual use?).  The low wall on the southwest side of the room is recessed from the wall creating a narrow rectangular area containing altar (3112) abutting the southwestern wall of the room.  Along the southwest wall are two lararium scenes: one earlier scene of two lares and one or two other figures over lying the altar and snakes has been replaced with a more elaborate lararium painting with two registers; a lower register altar with pine cone with two snakes, one on either side of the altar.  The upper register has twelve Olympian deities.  In the north corner a lead pipe as well as a plastered drain drains fro the water feature to the east where it joins feature 3107.  In the north corner there is also a doorway with a modern lintel and a threshold with placement of door which leads top the stable (room 9).  In the northwest wall there is a square window with traces of a plaster jam and a modern lintel looking it to the adjacent triclinium (room 10).  In the west corner is a steep threshold through a plastered doorway into the mill room (room 3) with modern lintel.  The room opens directly to the latrine (3108) to the north.

This feature is a small, square plastered altar.  The plaster is contiguous with that of the wall and floor.  The surface of the altar is formed by a roof tile with overlying plaster in red (?).  The altar abuts directly against and midway against the west wall of the room and the two lararium paintings.  There are two lararium paintings: one from an earlier phase with two registers.  The upper register has two lares and two (?) other figures with altar and snakes low.  A second later painting has two snakes on either side of an altar with twelve Olympian deities above.

In the north corner of the room abutting the northwest and northeast walls are the plaster remains of a wooden cupboard.  The cupboard is too deteriorated to determine any details except that is was probably rectangular in shape but one cannot determine the axis.

column14: There is a floor below.  Painting 3115 is to the southwest.
column21: High on the center of the northeast wall is a niche lararium.  The interior and exterior were covered with plaster and painted.  There is no sign of any figures in the painting.  The shelf of the lararium extended into the room to the southwest.

column14: Painting contiguous to the room below.  Lararium (3114) is to the northeast.
column21: On the northwest wall in the highest register, where the wall begins to pitch to form the barrel-vault, is an upright rectangular panel, framing a small round shallow basket but appears to be hanging by strings from the upper part of the frame.  The string is tied with a bow to the basket handle.  In the basket are eight pieces of fruit, perhaps cherries.

column14: The painting is contiguous to the floor below.  Painting 3104 is to the northwest.  Painting 2105 is to the southeast.
column21: In the north corner of the northeast wall, in the center of a large panel framed by the north corner and the slender decorated column to the southeast is a flirting female figure.  In her right hand she holds a platter on which are various fruits, which kinds are indistinguishable.

column14: The painting is contiguous to the floor below.  Painting 3105 is to the northeast.  Painting 3103 is to the northwest.
column21: In the second panel to the southeast of painting 3105, framed by a slender column to the northwest and a large decorated band to the southeast, is a floating figure of Mercury holding a rabbit by the legs in his right hand.

column14: Room 11 has garden 9 on its north wall, room 7 on its west wall, room 12 at the east wall and an adjoining property on the south wall.
column21: Midway down the east-west axis of the house is room 11, a large rectangular dining room.  Access to the dining room is a doorway at the northwest corner of the north wall.  The room was frescoed.  Traces of red paint remain.  Construction of the north wall consists of eight courses of brick with opus incertum above.  The door threshold in the west end of the north wall is of tufa stone with a channel for the door, so the door opened into room 11.  There are no windows in the room.  Room identification is based upon size, shape, and view towards garden 9 through the doorway.  The axis of the room is east-west.

The remains of a cooking platform which is in poor condition and today piled rubble and tiles cover the west end.  The feature runs along a northwest-southeast axis on the southwest wall of the atrium.  At its highest point the structure appears to have been approximately 20 centimeters high.

The couch is on the southwest wall.  At the top on the south side of the niche there is a space for a triclinium knob.  It has white plaster with a double red line at the west corner.  The niche is very apparent in the room.

column14: All the rooms of the property are to he west and north of the garden.
column21: Space 2 is a large horticultural area that encompasses the bulk of an earlier property.  Cubiculi surround along the northwest and north sides of the garden.  In the southwest corner there is a small dolium against the north cubiculi with a large water cistern and three rectangular features of uncertain use.  To the south of the water feature there is a cistern head.  Jashemski (page 127) says this was used for viticulture with flowers.  Planting beds were visible at that time.  Traces of painting with red lower register and yellow panels and no longer visible central image survives in the center of the south wall of the garden.  Several indentations in the southwest corner of the garden may mark subterranean features such as dolia.  Eschebach reports  11 amphorae in this house with the inscriptions LYMPHAE.

column14: Garden space (room 14) is to the southwest.  Corridor (room 18) is to the northeast.
column21: We enter this small dining room from the northwest through a low doorway.  There is a pounded pavement with a mixture of stone.  This small square dining room has a window in the southwest wall overlooking a garden space (room 14).  There is evidence of plaster on all the walls.  There is no ceiling.  The window and doorway are reinforced in modern times.  The doorway looks out into a doorway (room 18).

column14: Atrium (room 1) is to the northeast.  Room 5 is to the southeast.
column21: The dining hall is located in the west corner part of the house.  One enters the room from the atrium from the northeast.  The room is rectangular in shape and is on a southwest/northeast axis.  On the southeast wall is a large doorway to room 5.  As reconstructed, the ceiling is very tall.  The floor is entirely in black and white mosaic.  A simple design runs around the periphery, while the interior appears to be white tessarae.  Stucco remains on each of the walls, although the painting has disappeared.

column14: The atrium (room 2) is to the west.  Storeroom (2866) is to the southeast.  The peristyle portico (room 5) is to the southwest.
column21: We enter a rectangular dining room from an entrance doorway off the atrium  in the northwest corner of the room.  The southwest wall is largely opened as a window to the peristyle portion.  The floor shows evidence of a white tessarae pattern.  The northwest wall has no remaining paint.  The northeast wall has a red lower zone with plants.  Above are two panels in white framed with yellow stencil bordered in red.  A tondo is visible on each panel.  The left northwest border is a male with a piercing look whilst on the right (northeast) the border is not clearly discernible.  On the southeast wall we have a red lower zone, and a middle zone with three panels.  The middle panel has garlands on a white background with columns in frames of green and red.  The center panel fresco is not discernible.  The left and right panels have cupids.  The southwest wall is partially a window with no paint on the walls.  The threshold of the atrium on the southwest corner of the northwest wall has third and fourth style painting on the wall.  The rectangular room has corners on a north/south axis and an east/west axis.

column14: The peristyle (room 5) is to the northeast.
column21: The kitchen is located in the south corner of the peristyle (room 5). The room is rectangular in shape and is on a southeast/northwest axis.  One enters the room from a doorway in the north corner.  In the south corner of the room is the masonry foundation for stairs to the upper floor.  On the northeast wall is a lararium.  Abutting the southwest wall to the northwest of the stairs are the rubble remains of a possible cooking platform.  As reconstructed the ceiling is missing.  The type of floor is indeterminate.  The wall was originally stucco but no sign of painting remains.

column14: There is a lararium (2867) to the northeast.
column21: Abutting the southwest wall to the northwest of the stairs are the rubble remains of a possible cooking platform. The platform appears to be rectangular in shape and is located on a northwest/southeast axis.

column14: Two water basins (3219 and 3218) and lararium (3233) are to the southwest.
column21: The oven is on the northeast wall.  This oven was made more heat efficient by encasing the baking mound in a smoke chamber.  It is bricked to the ceiling.  The smoke escaped through a vent on the front wall of this encasing.  This oven is unique due to the huge area below the oven available for the storage of charcoal/wood.  The structure is laid on a stone base.  The lowest corner of the mound is wider and composed of hard stone to resist blows from shovels.  The oven opening is faced with lava stones.  Quote, "Bakers, Bakeshops and Bread..."  Mayeske.  For more description of the features and their purposes see page 41.  On the front arch of the oven, Warsher reports a grotesque mask of terracotta.  We see only the remains of the figure's mane where the mask was.  There is also a carved phallus on the arch, a common atropeic feature on ovens.  In the encasing there is a passthrough on the southeast side.  A recessed rectangular opening on the southwest side of the mill accesses this passthrough.  A second passthrough on the northwest side connects to a preparation room (3201).

column14: To the north is the preparation room (3209).  To the northwest is a latrine (3205).  There are six holes in the curb outside the external doorway.  The stable (3200) and mill room (3199) are to the southeast.
column21: We enter the room from the mill room from the southeast.  This is an elaborate oven room with a massive enclosed oven to the northeast and two water basins are along the southwest wall (3219 and 3218).  There is a lararium (3233) in the southwest wall.  The northwest wall has a doorway (to room 8) which leads to the street.  See Mayeske, page 41, "Bread, Bakeshops) sic.  The side space opened to a passage to another room.

column14: The stable (room 10) is to the northeast.  The oven room (6) is to the northwest. Storeroom (2) is to the southwest.
column21: There is no roof. The southeast wall is approximately five meters tall and has three windows. There is evidence of a small indentation for an oil lamp and a rectangular one for a lararium. This area has a mud and lapilli floor except for examples of paving stones placed around the mills, which are placed basins.  We see one basin and meta, a catillus next to it, a strange meta consisting of one lava stone and one basin, and a complete but damaged mill consisting of meta, catillus and basin. These are placed along the southeast wall.  There is also a kneading basin along the same wall.  This room abuts a stable room which is on the northeast wall.  There is a cistern on the northwest wall. There is a lava water basin on the northwest wall.

column14: The mill room (3199) is to the southwest.  Oven room (3198) is to the northwest.
column21: The stable is a raised area now covered with vegetation, which runs along a northwest/southeast axis and is approximately ten meters in length and four to five meters in width.  The entrance is on the west corner of a low southwest, irregular, partitioning wall contiguous to the mill room to the southwest (room 6).  The southwest wall is approximately fifty centimeters high.  On the side of the mill room and on the inside of the stable is ten centimeters high.  On the northwest, northeast, and southeast the walls are to the first story height and beyond.  On the northwest wall the plaster survives.  In the northeast wall in the east portion a few pieces of plaster with red paint survive, with evidence of remodeling in antiquity.  A rhomboidal window in the south corner of the southeast wall allows light.  In the north corner of the northeast wall a window appears to have been blocked in antiquity.  There is a broken dolium in the east corner of the stable.  There is no threshold extant and the floor appears to be sloped at the doorway, however, there is a large square volcanic rock on the west corner of the entrance.

column14: The oven room (3198) is to the south/southeast.  Hall (room 8) is to the southwest.  The northwest parallels and is contiguous to the street.
column21: We enter the preparation room from room 8 to the southwest through a low door.  The room is along a northwest/southeast axis.  Evidence of painted plaster exists on the northeast, northwest and southwest walls.  All walls are preserved above a first story height with evidence of beam holes high on the northwest wall and one high on the south portion of the southeast wall.  Five other holes indicate possible shelf support on the lower portion of the northwest wall.  In the north corner of the room is an L-shaped preparation platform, the long arm of which runs along a northwest/southeast axis abutting the northeast wall.  The short arm runs along a northeast/southwest axis and abuts the northwest wall.  The height of the platform is approximately one meter.  The floor is covered with lapilli, which however, portion of hydraulic cement are visible.  A major feature of a contiguous room shares the southeast wall on the lower portion on the south end: the passthrough into the oven (3197) in room 6.
column74: No video information provided for this feature sheet.

column14: The preparation room 2 is to the northeast.
column21: One enters the counter room from the street to the southwest.  There is a high step from the sidewalk and a threshold made of volcanic rocks (three large and one small).  There is a deep groove running the length of the doorway and holes for door posts and one small piece of metal.  The shape of room is determined by the partition indicators on the north and east corners.  In antiquity the room appears to have been plastered and painted red and white.  Immediately inside the door is an l-shaped counter, the long arm runs on a northeast/southwest axis. The short arm, which parallels the street, is on a northwest/southeast axis, and abuts the brick column of the outer wall on it south end with a large pile of hardened rubble in the inner corner of that space today.  The northwest and southeast walls are primarily extant to just under a first story level.  Against the eastern of the southeast wall are the remains of two dolia (3209 (southwest) and 3210 (northeast).  Reports indicate that a third dolium was extant to the southwest previously.  The surface of the counter is marble pieces which are probably of ancient reconstruction.  The floor is covered with lapilli.

column14: Room 2 to northwest.
column21: From atrium walk east into the room past the lararium to the south.  Doorway is average width, approximately one meter.  It is very high, approximately four meters.  The room is a rectangular dining room, close to the primary entrance of the structure.  Orientation is northwest/southeast.  There is no ceiling.  Each of the four walls shows patches of plaster.  The remains of the northwest wall shows evidence of Third Style paintings with red, yellow and orange.  The floor is lapilli.  The northeast walls show two windows that are now barred.  This entrance faces the impluvium.

column14: Room 2 to the southwest.
column21: From atrium, southeast side, enter a doorway of average width, approximately one meter, without a lintel.  We determined this is a dining room because of the repurposing of the old house to an inn/hotel.  The room is close to the southeast entrance of the inn oriented northeast/southwest.  General condition shows very little plaster.  The floor is soil and missing ceiling.   Based on the presence of a large window on the southwest wall facing the atrium, and impluvium, we interpret  this as a dining room.

column14: Room 4 is contiguous to the west of the atrium(2) and Room(12) in the northwest.
column21: We enter storeroom(4) from the southeast.  The room is on a northwest/southeast axis off the atrium(2).  The room lies off the west corner of the atrium.  The general condition of the room, relatively speaking, is fair.  White painted plaster is extant on all walls.  There are six holes on the southwest and four holes on the northwest walls, and five holes on the northeast wall which suggest beams for shelving or storage.  The height of the doorways is approximately four meters, and the ceiling is high, but indeterminate.  The floor is obscured with lapilli.  There is a white marble threshold at the entrance and it appears to house grooves for secure closure.

column14: To the northwest is a columned garden and water feature(Room 11).  To the southwest a hallway and steps (no room number).
column21: We enter this tiny dining area from the northeast (a la Pliny, a diata, a dining and reclining room prevalent in larger villas).  It is a small rectangular northeast/southwest oriented room.  Present condition of the space shows no plaster, lapilli floor and no ceiling.  Central door on northern wall permits a good view of a garden and water feature.  We can see nine fluted Doric columns surrounding the garden/pool.

column14: This room is contiguous  to Room 11 and Room 2.  Room 2 is a step down from Room 12.
column21: This is a dining room with two entrances flanking the east corner.  The door on the southeast wall is low, with a marble threshold.  The doorway on the northeast wall is tall and is missing a threshold.  This rectangular room also has a window through the northeast wall.  The view from this window overlooks the contiguous water feature and the peristyle  beyond it.  The interior of the room is decorated with frescos.  The paint on the dado is the best preserved and reveals rectangular and diamond patterns.  The flooring is not visible.  Decorative plaster molding is preserved on three quarters of the walls, above the frescos.  On the northwest and southeast walls there are arched pediments above the straight molding.  These are the ends of a barrel-vaulted ceiling.  The south corner above the arched molding on the southeast wall preserves a small section of fresco.  This may predate the vaulted ceiling.  The upper part of the existing northeast wall is cut with an unidentifiable small niche cutting into the ceiling vault.  The upper remains of the southwest wall have eleven rectangular holes for ceiling/upper story support beams.
column74: Keep both. Retake.see LK's addition on retake, not in original script.

column14: Cooking platform area #20 - 3157 to the southwest storage room #3165 to the northeast.
column21: The latrine is located in the kitchen, which is entered from the portico from the northeast. We note again the temperature in the barrel vaulted kitchen is cool. We turn to the southeast and we see  a large area with a wall that is a bit higher than the cooking platform (approximately 1.30 meters). The latrine is bordered with a high northwest/southeast wall separating it from the cooking platform area. There is a ceiling height wall on the northeast side of the latrine that separates it from the storage area. The latrine floor is mud.  On the northeast wall are two widely spaced struts that would have supported a wooden seat, that would have seated more than one individual. There is a skylight on the southeast wall opening which has been blocked in antiquity. The latrine is are is large and extends to the middle of the barrel vault in the room.  The ceiling above the toilet area features an oval ceramic pipe abutting onto the northeast wall. The pipe in the ceiling aligns with the end of the toilet struts and was probably used for collecting water.

column14: Kitchen # 20-3156 to the west.
column21: The storeroom is entered from the northwest from the kitchen thru a low doorway. The dirt floor slopes upwards from the entrance.  The walls show signs of ancient plaster. We see amphora to move water on the southwest wall. The location indicates this was a food and drink storage room. The ceiling of the room currently extends to the second floor.

column14: A second cliche niche (3167) to the northeast.
column21: A niche in the southwest wall extends along a northwest - southeast axis and occupies approximately two thirds of the wall. In antiquity there appears to have been at least two layers of plaster and paint in bright yellow is exposed where the top layer is missing.

column14: A second couch niche (3166) to the southwest.
column21: This niche on the northeast wall is square. with no evidence of paint or plaster.

column14: Contiguous to rooms 14 to the southeast, room 12 to the southwest.
column21: One enters the square dining hall from one of two accesses; from the southeast one enters from the atrium thru a large tall door over a white marble threshold with tracking on both sides for a door.  Opposite the door on the northwest wall is a large window which looks onto the peristyle and garden. Access from the southwest thru a lower wider doorway adjoins the tablinum.  The threshold from this access was once a large darker slab of marble from which a large portion is missing. The lintel seems to be modern reconstruction.  The room itself is in poor condition.  Plaster is evident on all walls. On the northwest and southeast walls, molded ornate cornices give evidence of a vaulted ceiling, three possibly four layers of plaster suggest redecoration or remodeling in antiquity. Traces of red, yellow and white paint are evident, and on the northwest and southeast walls are decorative panels which mirror each other in approximate location;  the figures on the southeast wall are indiscernible, but appears to be a man and woman and on the northwest wall a single male figure can be seen. The floor is deteriorating, but is constructed of white tesserae.  On the northwest - northeast and southeast walls high above the cornice are beam holes for a second story support.  The is non extant.

column14: Portico (southwest), window of an elegant dining room, southeast, and the horticultural area (northwest).
column21: The dining room is entered from the southwest from the portico. The dining room entry is wide but very low and unpresupposing. The floor is lapilli.  The is no evidence of a worked floor.  The room is almost square in plan.  The walls have small areas of white plaster. There is a large window opening on the northwest wall that provides a view of the hortis area.  There is no ceiling. This suggests to us this is an eating area for slaves.  In 2012, there is a pile of stones and bits of floors in the south corner, piled up the wall to about 1.5 meters high.

column14: Paintings 6141 to north. 6140 to south.
column21: Square mosaic insert to the cocciopesto flooring in the room. Border of black and white tesserae surrounding multicolored marble inserts into cocciopesto. Surrounding circular hole for table base or similar feature. This feature is placed so that the dining couches can be arranged around the north, east and south sides.

We enter the latrine from the oven room six from the southeast. This is a small narrow latrine with a few terracotta tiles on the floor. The north wall is approximately 1m high and adjoins a room which was for stairs. The gradient of the northeast suggests that the height of the room would be determined by the height of the stair. Evidence of plaster is extant on the southwest, northeast walls. The drain is not determined, however there may be a hole in the north corner.

This dolium, which is approximately 50-60 am high, is cylindrical and tapers in to a large, wide protruding lip at its height. There are chips along the northwest side of the lip and the dolium if filled with volcanic debris, otherwise the dolium appears to be in good in repair. in antiquity the dolium probably touched the southeast wall. The construction material is red terracotta.

This dolium lies to the northeast of dolium 3209 and abuts the protruding column which forms the northeast/ southeast definition of the room. The dolium is approximately 50-60 cm high it is cylindrical, the upper portion tapers and narrows into a large wide protruding lip at its height. The northwest half of the lip is missing and the dolium is filled with volcanic debris and lapilli. The construction maternal is red terracotta. The letters N.A are inscribed on the northwest face, however these may not from antiquity.
Mayeske:1971 Dolium not extant. Evidence from earlier studies Mayeske,1971 suggest that a third dolium was south of dolia 3209 and 3210 in antiquity.

Raised preparation platform is approximately one meter high and approximately 2m long and runs along the northwest / southeast axis. The long arm about the northeast wall of room 9 and the short arm which runs along a northeast/ southwest axis about the northwest wall for approximately 50 cm. The counter is constructed of volcanic rock.

column14: store room (2) is to south east. Room 4 is to the northeast.
column21: We enter the room from the storeroom (2) from the southeast, or from room 4 from the northeast. All walls are low and show evidence of plaster painted red and yellow. The room is basically square but runs along a northwest/ southeast axis. In the east corner of the room abutting the northeast and south walls is a low preparation platform (3224). There is a large stone which may or may have been used in the room, located parallel to the southwest wall. The floor is obscured with lapilli.

column14: Completely located within Room 10 the North wall abuts Room 12.
column21: Completely located on the north side of Room 10 (kitchen) very small rectangular room has a northeast /southwest axis.  Small entryway in southwest corner. No remaining decoration. No windows or floor.

column14: Cooking platform to the SW (2867).
column21: In the center of the NE wall we have an oval shaped lararium. It shows no ledge, no painting but is plastered. platform is formed of tile with plaster

column14: (11) to the southwest, west (17).
column21: We enter the dining room which lies off the peristyle(11) to the southwest. The room has a northeast /southwest axis. There is a large doorway with a volcanic threshold which allows a view to the garden. On either side of this threshold are white stones for placement of door posts. A small doorway just inside the room on the west side of the northwest wall provides access to stairs, an andron, and the peristyle.  Red painted plaster survives on the lowest abutment of the door on the northwest and southeast facings and also on the west side of the southwest wall at the lowest portion. On the northwest wall there is evidence of yellow paint; traces of red over niche feature 3133. A larger a painted portion covers most of the extant northeast wall, primarily in white paint with traces of yellow and red pattern. The floor which is now obscured with dirt and overgrowth is cocciopesto, and bits of white tesserae. The southeast wall is volcanic. The height of the ceiling is indeterminate.

column14: Counter room to the southwest. Preparation to the northwest, room 5 to the northeast.
column21: The axis of this room is southwest/northeast. Entering the room from the southwest one goes through a wide opening almost the entire width of the space. The northwest wall may have also been open. The 2 corners of the room along the southeast wall are brick pillar construction. The corners of the northwest wall are constructed of stone. Five folio (3211 to 3215)are embedded along southeast wall and there is a square cistern (3217) on the northwest wall just south of a doorway into room 3. Along the northwest wall at the north of the doorway into room 3, there are the remains of a stairway. Remains of fresco remain on southwest wall (door pillars). Plaster and paint are also on the northwest and southeast walls.  Yellow paint can be seen on both and red painted bands Re visible on the northwest walls. No flooring is visible. Preservation is overall very poor. Two rows of three square holes run horizontally high above the Delia along the southeast all. These were for shelves.

column14: Room 1 is to the west.
column21: This is an almost square room. The doorway is at the north end of the west wall and has a stone threshold with a placing for doors, opening inwards. The southern half of the west wall has a large, low window looking west to room 1. The floor is obscured by lapilli. Fragments of plaster are found in the northeast, southwest, center of the north wall and high in the south wall. No extant decorations. Each wall shows signs of restoration.
column53: BW, color and digital are all A&B

column14: The mill is southeast of three other mills in the room. There is a platform with a kneading basin and cistern head at the west wall of the room.
column21: The mill is in the southeast quadrant of the room. It is a reconstructed mill with a stone base, meta-stone and catillus top. The catillus is cracked and missing 40% of its structure. There is evidence of repairs in antiquity. The collecting surface is parged modern concrete.

column14: The mill is one of four and is in the northeast corner of the room.
column21: The mill is in the northeast corner of the room. The platform/base is reconstructed (modern). The meta is extant as is the catillus. There is no cracking or signs of repair in antiquity. The mill is one of four in the room and is closest to the easterly entrance.

column14: The mill is one of four in the room. It is on the northern edge of the room/space.
column21: The mill has a modern reconstructed base and meta extant. The meta is cracked through longitudinally on the east face. The collecting surface is parged modern concrete and there is no catillus.

column14: The mill is one of four in the room. It is the mill closest to the oven, the kneading base and the cistern head.
column21: The mill platform base is a modern reconstruction with a parged modern concrete collection surface. The meta is extant with no cracks or missing material. There is no catillus.

column14: The cistern (6212) is directly to the south and south of the cistern is the kneading basin (6211).
column21: A masonry rectangular platform with curved north end against the west wall of the room. It is partly preserved with a modern cement surface.

column14: The cistern (6212) is directly to the north next to which is the preparation platform (6210).
column21: A circular basin inserted into a masonry platform consisting of a partially restored terracotta bowl used in conjunction with an adjoining cistern and preparation platform for the preparation of bread. The lip of the platform/ basin is partially restored in cement.

column14: The cistern is placed directly adjacent to the kneading basin (6211) to the south and the preparation platform (6210) to the north.
column21: A circular stone cistern mouth partially covered by an arched plaster recess in the west wall. The cistern is filled with debris.
column53: A full shot of features (6010), (6011) and (6012) and the numbers are roll  BW 4/33 and color 4/33 and digital 16

column14: The mill room is to the north, the oven to the west, a different property to the south and the street is to the east.
column21: The preparation room's long axis is venally west east.The room is entered through the north wall at the northwest corner over a stone threshold. The threshold is carved to indicate door panels such that one could secure the room.The west wall has a pass through of opus mixtum to the oven platform/mouth of oven. The west wall is prominently of opus incertum with very little white plaster extant at its southerly edge.The south wall of opus incertum with some white plaster extant in a low red plaster register half a meter tall. On the eastern edge of the south wall are found four, possibly five, supports for two, possibly three, shelves.Five pock hole sexist in the south wall that do not seem to be shelf supports or shrines but would seem to be a deteriorated wall construction.The east wall has a window to the street with a sill two meters high. The wall is opus incertum with the upper third in opus mixtum, probably reconstructed in antiquity. There is some white plaster extant.The north wall is of opus incertum with opus mixtum at the entrance opening. There is some white plaster extant.The floor is stone marble with vegetation. On the west wall are what appear to be three beam pockets, possibly for stair supports. The special configuration of the room, does not support these being for a staircase.

column14: Dolia (negative feature 3220, 3209 and 3210 are to the south east.
column21: The counter is basically 'L' shaped with a slight intrusion of a square edge into the west corner. The short arm of the counter,which runs parallel to the street along a northwest/southeast axis , is approximately 2m long. It provides a defining barrier for the south portion of the southeast side of the room. The longer arm which runs along the northwest / southeast axis is approximately 3m long and delineating the division of space in the middle of the room. The counter appears to have been reconstructed after 62 AD and the surface consists of black, gray, white and travertine pieces of marble and cement. The counter is approximately 1m high on the southeast wall. Abutting the counter is a pile of rubble, however a small fragment of counter plaster, painted red, appears at the bottom It cannot be discerned whether this rubble was a portion of the counter or not. The southwest face of the counter consists of rich colors (white, red, green and gray) where the marble is still present. There are 4 white marble slabs along the bottom. There are approximately 10 imprints for missing pieces. The face of the northwest outer wall of the counter contains only foundation material. Plaster appears on both arms of the interior side.

column14: It is next to (east) of a catillus (3220) which is out of place. Mills (3227 3207) and kneading basin (3222) to the northeast. Water basin (3225) and cistern (3216) to the northwest.
column21: You see the rubble basin with a meta on top. There is no sign of a metal sheath. This mill is closer to the southeast wall however the animal could have still moved around it. It is in the southern corner of the room.

column14: kneading basin (3222) is to the east. A meta and basin (3227), catillus (3226) and meta and basin (3206) are to the southwest. Water basin (3225) and cistern (3216) to the west.
column21: This complete mill is in a good location with the exception that the kneading basin has been moved into the eastern corner. It sits along the southeast wall. The basin does not show a sheath. The meta needs some repair. The catillus is missing two thirds of its top walls.The height of he meta is taller than normal, specifically the distance between the bottom edge of the catillus and the top edge of the basin which is approximately 0.5m.
Eschebach 397/398Mayeske Dissertation 127-129Eschebach and Mayeske report a mill in the northwest side of the mill room. No remains are extant.

column14: Dolia (3212,3213, 3214, and 3215) to the northeast. Cistern 3217 to the northwest.
column21: This is a very large ceramic vessel. The lower wall slightly flares from the flat bottom. The shoulder is carinated. The rim flares and turns inward for a flat horizontal lip with a wide opening. The dolium is intact and complete except for small chips in the rim. It has undergone conservation seemingly in ancient times with a plaster coating on one third of the rim (which may be a concrete replacement part). There is a visible patch across the rim. This patch is a fine pink plaster. The interior is filled with lapilli and not visible. The dolium is half embedded in the southeast wall in the southern corner of the room.

column14: This dolium is second from the south corner in the line of 5 dolia along the south east wall. (3214 and 3215 to the northeast, 3212 and 3211 to the southwest) Cistern 3217 to the northwest.
column21: This is a dolium. It is a very large ceramic vessel. The lower wall slightly flares from the flat bottom. The shoulder is carinated. The rim flares and turns inward for a flat horizontal lip and wide opening. It is almost complete although it is cracked in pieces on the southern side and the rim is broken and missing several sections. This rim has undergone extensive repairs. At least seven cracks have been repaired with metal staples covered with a pink plaster. One section is replaced in concrete and is badly broken missing all of the lip. There is an inscription on the flat edge of the rim at the west side. This is not clearly legible although it appears to be a numeric designation for the capacity of the vessel. This dolium is half embedded in the southeast wall. The interior is filled with lapilli and not visible.

column14: This is the third dolium from the southern corner. Dolia (3212 and 3211) to the southwest, dolia (3214 an 3215) to the northeast. Cistern 3217 to the northwest.
column21: This is a very large ceramic vessel. The lower wall rises almost vertically from the flat bottom. The shoulder is carinated. The rim flares and turns inward for a flat horizontal lip with a wide opening. The upper portion including the shoulder to the rim is broken and missing several pieces. Approximately one third of rim survives. No extant repairs are visible. The interior is filled with lapilli and not visible. The dolium is half embedded in the southeast wall.

column14: This is the fourth dolium from the south corner. Dolium 3215 to the northeast. dolia 3213, 3212 and 3211 to the southwest. Cistern 3217 to the northwest
column21: This is a very large ceramic vessel. The lower wall rises almost vertically from the flat bottom. The shoulder is carinated. The rim is missing.
