The dolium is similar to dolium 3213 to the southwest. There are at least two large cracks but the body is complete. Some of the shoulder and all of the rim are missing. The interior is filled with lapilli and not visible. The dolium is half embedded in the southeast wall.

column14: All the rooms of the property are to the west and north of the garden.
column21: Large horticultural area that encompasses the bulk of an earlier property. Cubiculi survive along the west and north sides of the garden. Near the southwest corner there is a small dolium. Against the north cubiculi is a large water cistern and three rectangular features of uncertain use. To the south of the water feature there is a cistern head. Jashemski p. 127 says this was used for viticulture and flowers. Planting beds were visible at that time. Traces of painting with red lower register and yellow panels and no longer visible central image survives in the center of the south wall of the garden. Several indentations in the southwest corner of the garden may mark subterranean features such as dolia. Eschebach reports eleven amphorae in this house with the inscription 'LYMPHAE'

column14: Entryway 1 to the southwest. Vicolo de Modesto to the west. Adjoining property 6.5.6 to the northeast. Room 4 and garden 2 to the southwest.
column21: A rectangular room to the northwest of the entryway opens off the garden area which is to the northeast. Room access is southeast corner of the east wall. In the northwest corner of the room is a plastered niche in the lower part of the wall. Niche is fully plastered but other walls show only slight evidence of plastering. There is a dirt floor and no windows.

column14: In the northwest corner of the room. Abuts Vicolo de Modesto to northwest.
column21: Niche cut into wall of room in the northwest corner. The niche is approximately waist high by roughly 80 cm wide (see drawing for detailed measures). The niche is fully plastered.

The feature is a large rectangular plastered water cistern. The plaster survives throughout and it is deep. In the center of the base of the south wall a square hole extends south. The cistern is not accessible as the basin is full of water. It has a stepped lip. Two terracotta lined channels run at the top of the south wall. The southeast channel drains to the cistern. To the west there is a rectangular feature of uncertain use. The cistern will originally have had to be covered as it blocks access to room 7 to the north

column14: The street is to the south. Tablinum or exedra is to the north on an axis with the street entrance. Also, rooms 3 and 4 are to the north and to the east and west are other structures.
column21: Room and structure is generally oriented north and south. The primary entrance to the room is from the street on the south. The entrance threshold is raised and curved for security door panels. The room contains two catilli with no metae or base platforms. There is minimal red plaster extant on the south wall. There is a small window sill 1.5 m. above plaster on south wall. The floor is of heavy black volcanic stones. In the southeast corner is a terracotta drain from the story above. The upper story is not extant

column14: One of two mills in the room
column21: Mill is on the west side of the room. The platform and base are not extant. Catillus remains but it is not in situ.

column14: One of two mills in the room.
column21: The mill is on the east side of the room. The platform and base are not extant. The catillus remains but it is not in situ.
column53: BW 16 re-shoot; Color 15 re-shoot; digital 25 re-shoot

column14: Preparation room is to the west. Ala/corridor is to the east. Oven room is to the north.
column21: The room's long axis is generally north/south. The cistern head and basin are on the west wall. The primary entrance to the room is from the south. The wall extant is almost one meter high and may have been a low wall in antiquity. There is an entrance to the oven room to the north wall. The floor is of stone rubble. Minimal plaster remains.

column14: Connected to basin and low wall of preparation room.
column21: The cistern head is on the west wall of the room and is made of terracotta. Modern tuck-pointing is evident. The cistern opening is filled with stones. The terracotta head is cracked and missing pieces which are not extant. The cistern head's structure is physically connected to the base structure in the low wall.

column14: Physically connected to preparation wall and to the cistern.
column21: This feature is assumed to be a basin because of its location in the structure and its contiguous relationship to the cistern and preparation room. Opus signinum is not visible but is likely present. The basin is partially full of stone rubble and may not be fully excavated.

column14: Room 5 is to the south. Preparation room is to the east. Processing room is to the north. Another structure/property is to the west.
column21: The room's primary axis is north/south with two half meter diameter windows on the north wall. One of these windows/pass throughs' sill height is one meter. The other is roughly two meters. There is a high window on the south wall with a sill roughly 2.5 m. high. Room is entered at the southeast corner over a raised threshold. Ten centimeter drain tile is extant in the southwest corner of the room. Minimal plaster is extant on north, west and south walls. One meter dolium is in the room but is not in situ. Floor is stone rubble. Likely opus signinum in northwest corner of the room.

column14: Room 8 to the west, room 9 to the south
column21: This is an L-shaped room with a north-south axis. The northern arm of the room is taken up with oven (6191). To the east and wets of the oven are two small recesses of uncertain use. The western recess has a stepped threshold. The eastern is full of volcanic debris with three floor joists high in the north wall. By the entrance to the eastern recess are the fragments of a dolium. Along the eastern side of the room there  are two rectangular brick/tile columns aligning with the doorway of the center of the south wall. Only the base of the northern of the two columns. Between the two columns in the center of the room is the kneading machine (6192). The floor is obscured by lapilli. The west wall is continuous with room 8 and preserves part of the vaulted ceiling. There is no extant wall decoration.

column14: Oven 6191 to the north.
column21: Circular volcanic stone machine with the base of the metal blade survives in the bottom.  Four holes remain in the face of the face of the basin.
column74: No video information for this feature sheet.

column14: 6192 to the south
column21: Large beehive oven with well-preserved brick beehive. Partial collapse obscures the base of the oven. The external face has modern cement restoration. The external face has modern cement restoration. The oven is accessed through the square opening facing south. Along the southern face of the oven is a wide masonry bench with tile and stone surface, with signs of modern restoration. To the west of the oven front is a stone square column.

column14: Room 7 to the northeast.
column21: This is a rectangular room with a north - south axis with doorway to the north end of the east wall. The north wall only survives in its lower course. The floor is obscured by lapilli and unexcavated volcanic debris. Plaster survives on the west wall with possible yellow color extending up the wall into the lower courses of a vaulted ceiling. Extensive plaster in south wall containing two circular plaster windows opening to room 6.

column14: The south and west walls of the room abut the corner of Via del Vesuvio and Vicolo di Modesto. East wall of room abuts corridor 1. North wall of room abuts atrium 4.
column21: Opening directly to the street, counter room 7 is located in the southwest corner of property VI.5.13 and is entered through address VI.5.12. Internal access to the counter room is located on the west corner of the north wall opening to atrium 4. The counter room is rectangular with a north/south axis. A masonry counter with stepped shelves and a hearth is located in the southeast half of the room. Counter appears to be heavily reconstructed. Walls show evidence of plastering and there is a high window on the west wall opening onto the street, Via del Vesuvio.
column53: BW Shot A & B; digital Shot A & B

column14: The counter is located in the south east quarter of room 7. The shorter end of the l-shaped counter faces Vicolo del Modesto. The longer side broadens on the hearth on the northwest corner and is approximately 200 cm. from the west wall of the room.
column21: This L-shaped masonry counter faces Vicolo del Modesto on the south. Counter has two stepped shelves on the south eats corner and a deep brick-lined hearth on its northern most end. The counter widens at the hearth.

column14: The tablinum is to the north.  The mill room (11) is to the northeast.
column21: (We have the description and photograph from 2001, but the only drawing is an elevation.)  (We also need a floor plan.) (The original feature is #143.)  This rectangular room is on a north/south axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Extensive, undecorated plaster survives on the south wall.  In the north wall there is a doorway with a modern lintel and stepped threshold opening north to an earlier tablinum.  At the north end of the east wall there is a door with a stone threshold to the mill room (11).   The threshold has multiple placings for a door.  South of this doorway, in the east wall, there is a square opening for the passing through of bread to the oven room (room 11).  Fragments of decorated plaster survives in the southeast corner with a black lower register and red above.

column14: The atrium is to the north.  Room 8 is to the east.
column21: This rectangular room is on a north/south axis.  At the west end of the north wall there is a doorway opening north to the atrium with a stone stepped threshold.  The threshold preserves placing for a door. The floor is obscured by lapilli.  There is undecorated plaster on the south wall and on the southwest corner.

column14: The street is to the east.  The kitchen is to the west.  The mill room is to the south.  A differing property/structure is to the north.
column21: The long axis of the room is generally east to west with a water trough running the entire length of the north rubble.  The floor is of stone rubble.  The east wall is of opus mixtum and contains an entrance from the street.  That entrance has a stone threshold carved such that panels/doors could be used to secure the room.  One steps down into the room from the threshold.  The north wall is of opus incertum and opus mixture at the entrance opening.  The north wall has evidence of repairs, both modern and from antiquity.  The west wall is of opus incertum and is interrupted by a water basin/passthrough of modern reconstruction.  Some opus signinum is extant. The south wall is of opus incertum with opus mixtum at the entrance to the mill room.  This entrance has a stone threshold carved to indicate two pivot points such that one could secure the room. Plaster is not extant in the room.  The room is a stable because of size, trough, and its proximity to the mill room.

column14: There is a water basin in the west wall of the room, just south of the trough.
column21: The trough runs axially east to west and is engaged with the north and west walls.  It physically abuts the street entrance opening and stands nineteen centimeters above the stone threshold.  Some opus signinum is extant.  There is evidence of modern reconstruction on the trough.

column14: A differing property/structure is to the south and east.  Room 6 is to the north.  The andron and cubiculi are to the west.
column21: The room's primary axis is north/south because of the door in the north wall.  One steps up over a stone threshold into the room.  All walls are modern and heavily reconstructed with tuck pointing.  No plaster is extant.  The walls are of opus incertum.This is a kitchen with a latrine because of Eschebach's analysis, small finds, location and orientation within the structure  The floor is of stone rubble.

column14: A differing property is to the north.  A salesroom is to the west.  An andron is to the south.  A cubiculi is to the east.
column21: The room's long axis is west to east with a direct view to the street.  Its primary entrance is through the west wall which is of brick and opus latericium.  The south wall is of opus incertum, modern tuck pointing restoration is evident.  Some plaster is extant.  The color and pattern are unclear because of the elements.  The east wall is of opus incertum with a secondary entrance of brick and opus mixtum.  There are likely two steps up to exit the dining room through this opening.  Three beam pockets are visible for a non-extant second floor.  The north wall is opus incertum with evidence of modern reconstruction.  There is a small piece of plaster and it is likely a red color.  The floor is of stone rubble.  This is a dining tablinum because of its view, orientation, and finds in the structure.

column14: Rooms 2, 3, and 4 are to the east.
column21: This is a rectangular room on a east/west axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Fragments of plaster survive in the northeast and northwest corners of the room.  It is pink in color?  The entire west side consists of a wide open doorway to the street with a partially preserved stone threshold stepping down to the street to the west.  The threshold preserves placings for a door.  In the north end of the east wall there is a doorway to the dining tablinum (room 2).  In the center of the east wall there is a lararium (6225) directly in front of which is a cistern (6227).  The southern half f the east walls opens directly to the rear of the property.

column14: Cistern (6227) is directly in front of the lararium to the west.
column21: This is an arched lararium niche with plaster surviving on the interior face.  There is no visible decoration.
Neapolis says that there was an oven, lararium, amphora, and cistern in the workshop.  The lararium and cistern are still extant, however the oven and amphora are no longer extant.  (Eschebach, 164).
column53: This is a negative feature, therefore there is no photo.

column14: The cistern is directly in front of a lararium (6225) to the east.
column21: The feature is a tufa, circular cistern mouth.  The cistern is filled with debris.

column14: A differing structure/property is to the north and east.  Rooms 2 and 3 (cubicula) are to the south and the street is to the west.
column21: The room's primary axis is west to east and entered from the street over a raised stone threshold.   Carving in the stone threshold is not evident.  The north wall is opus incertum with the upper two-thirds of modern construction.  The lower corner of the north wall has a passthrough slot to the property to the north and does not appear to be from antiquity.  The west wall is of opus incertum. Tufa ashlar blocks are at the entrance and appear to be all modern reconstruction.  The south wall is of opus incertum from antiquity with modern tuck pointing.  The east wall is of opus incertum.  The top two-thirds of the wall appears to be modern reconstruction.  Minimal plaster is extant in the northeast corner of the room.  The color is red.  The floor is stone rubble.  There is a heavily reconstructed platform (6234) is in the northeast corner of the room.

column14: The platform is the only platform in the room; however Eschebach mentions, but does not locate, a latrine.
column21: The platform abuts the north and east walls and is heavily reconstructed in modern times.  The platform can be viewed directly from the street entrance. Wall plaster on the east wall predates the platform.  Plaster runs contiguously between the wall and the platform.  This condition is not evident on the north wall.

column14: The southwest wall abuts a peristyle (2).  The northeast wall abuts a storeroom (15).  The southeast wall abuts a passageway (11) and the northwest wall abuts the adjoining property (6.5.9).
column21: This is a small rectangular room with a stone threshold with indentations for door pivots.  The north and west walls were plastered and the floor is lapilli.  The doorway is entered from a passageway (11) on the south side of the room.  The room is on a northeast/southwest axis.

column14: The north wall abuts the adjoining property (6.5.9).  The northeast wall abuts a dining room (14).  The east wall abuts a passageway (11).  The southwest wall abuts a storeroom (16).
column21: This is a small rectangular room with a stone threshold with indentations for door pivots.  The southeast and north walls were plastered and the floor is lapilli.  The doorway enters from a passageway (11) on the south wall.  The room is on a northeast/southwest axis.

column14: The corner of the southwest wall it is immediately adjacent to the northwest wall of dining room 14.
column21: The rectangular niche is cut out on the lower portion of the southwest wall immediately abutting the northwest wall.  The niche is approximately one hundred fifty centimeters wide by fifty centimeters high.  No decoration is present any longer.

column14: The open doorway, located to the southeast, opens to a garden (12).  The southwest wall abuts a storeroom (15).  The northeast wall opens to a dining room (13).  The northwest wall abuts the adjoining property (6.5.9).
column21: This is a large rectangular space opening to a garden (12) on the southeast.  In the middle of the wall is a doorway to another dining room (13).  A single couch niche is located on the northwest corner in the southwest wall.  On the northwest section of the south wall no plaster remains; however, there are traces of a white mosaic floor.  The axis of the room is northeast/southwest.

column14: Painting (3262) to the east; mills (3265, 3266, 3267) below.
column21: This feature is a small detail located on the north side of the barrel vault.  A small rectangular frame in red paint with a red line within it encloses a white panel.  This small panel is painted green in the center and shows a small bird eating two cherries with their stems.

column14: Room 2 to the south; pseudoperistyle to the east.
column21: We enter dining room 3 from the southeast.  The room, which is slightly rectangular, runs along a northwest/southeast axis.  On the north, west, and south walls we find remains of painted plaster which was yellow and possibly white in antiquity.  In the west corner of the room where the north and west walls converge, pieces of plaster cornice which have been molded and decorated with blue and red paint and ornate pattern, show a division of upper and lower wall space.  In the same area we find evidence of red borders which run parallel and perpendicular to the cornice.  The walls have been restored to first story height as have the ceiling and floor.  Modern equipment and decoration fill the room. There is a hearth and sink on the south and east side.  High in the west wall is a small tiny window and centered on the east wall is a modern window which looks into the garden in the pseudoperistyle.  The entrance to the room has modern doors which can be locked and both windows have shutters and screens as well.

column14: The main entrance is contiguous  to the corridor (5) to the west. Dining room (9-3260) is to the north.  Room 11 is to the south.
column21: This is a dining room.  It is on the northwest/southeast axis.  One enters the room from the west side through a very large arched opening.  The ceiling is barrel vaulted.  The flooring is not visible.  There are opposing doorways at the west end of the north and south walls.  Frescoes remain on the north, south, and east walls.  The vault is also frescoed.  Features 3262 and 3254 are paintings in the wall and vault.  Features 3265, 3266, and 3267 sit along the north wall.  About 50% of the frescoes remain.  The west half of the vault has been conserved.  The wall paintings are in the Fourth Style with plaster relief molding at the springing of the vault on the north and south walls and across the east wall.  The door to room 11 is blocked with modern construction.

column14: Corridor 5 to the south; dining room (14-3257) to the east; dining room (16-3259) to the west.
column21: This room opens off the corridor (5).  There is a marble threshold to the door.  Masonry struts abut the window which seems the same size as that in dining room 14, but this window has a marble sill.  This room is currently barricaded with a wooden slot door.  Through this can be seen a room similar to 14 with red, black, and yellow paint.   There is a sizable wooden shelf and a mound of tubs and buckets covered by plastic and a large pile of sand covering about one quarter of the room.

column14: Stairway (with 10 steps and a landing) to the west; dining room (15-3258) to the east.
column21: Dining Room 16 is also off corridor 5 and has a partial door frame.  Three rubble walls are extant but no plaster.  The floor is mud.  An improvised shower and a modern sink are present.  This room is square and a similar size to dining rooms 14 and 15.  This room, like dining rooms 14 and 15, has a view of the garden.

column14: Dining Room (10-3256) to the south.
column21: This rectangular dining room lies along a northeast/southwest axis and is entered from the southern corner from dining room 10.  In the west wall near the entrance is a low window which gives a view into the pseudoperistyle.  The window is approximately one meter wide and 80 centimeters high.  Plaster remains can be seen on all four walls, however these are only small fragments.  High on the north wall are nine beam holes however these are not found on the corresponding south wall.  In the north corner of the west wall is a slight right angle which juts into the space.  The  ceiling is not extant.  The floor is obscured with vegetation and rubble.

column14: Latrine 6 to the west and andron 5 to the south.
column21: We enter room 7 which is a small kitchen with a large cooking platform from a door in the southeast end of a south wall from andron (5).  The axis of the room is northwest/southeast.  On the adjoining corner of the southeast of the room is the entrance to the latrine.  The doorways to the kitchen and adjoining latrine are low.  Occupying the entire east wall is a cooking platform which fits in between the north, east, and south walls and extends into the room approximately one meter in width, ending just before the entrance.  There is a large stone structure abutting the east wall from the northeast corner and extending midway where it appears to have been broken.  It is approximately one meter high and 20 centimeters deep.  The walls of stone are preserved above first story high with reconstruction.  No ceiling is extant.  The floor is obscured with moss and lapilli.

column14: Room 2 to the south, Room 3 to the west .
column21: Square sales room with wide open doorway to street to the east.  Stone-stepped threshold, with placing for door.  The northern half of the doorway is blocked by the base of a heavily restored L-shaped counter.  Plaster survives on the north wall with red lower register, white upper.  Along the wall extending from the east are seven holes, five of which are positioned to support two rows of shelves.  At the west end of the north wall there is a square plastered niche with modern lintel.  No decoration is visible.  The west wall has a wide window through to room three and at the south end of the west wall is a wide doorway to three.  Against the south wall there is a base for stairs to the floor above accessed  from entrance 24.  There is a doorway in the south wall to room 2.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: Niche 6205 is to the northwest.
column21: This is a L-shaped counter with a short arm facing the street to the east.  Masonry body with rectangular plastered recess in the center of the long arm.  Cement surface is extensively restored.

column14: The niche shares the room with the counter and is visible from the street.
column21: The niche is in the north wall of the counter room, in the northwest corner of said room. It is roughly 1.5 m. to the niche sill. Significant modern restoration and reconstruction is evident in the opus incertum wall. The niche has a modern wooden lintel. Plaster extant. Likely restoration and possibly not in situ. Plaster appears to have been red and white. Niche bisects the lower and upper plaster registers of the north wall.

column14: Room 2 (storeroom)  is to the north.  The street is to the west.  A differing  structure/property is to the south.  Room 3 is to the east.
column21: The salesroom is entered from the street through the west wall.  The entrance has a stone threshold carved to indicate one could secure the room with doors/panels.  The floor is stone rubble.  The short west wall is of brick.  South wall is of opus incertum with brick coining at westerly edge of the wall.  Plaster is extant and likely a lower register in red.  There are eight beam pockets along the south wall for a second story that is not extant.  There is a stair/platform in the southeast  corner of the room.  There is evidence of modern tuck pointing on the south wall.  The east  wall is of opus incertum with a  two-stepped entrance to Room 3.  The entrance to Room 3 is of opus mixtum.  There is one beam pocket extant on the east wall.  There is minimal plaster extant.  There is  a low register in red.  The north wall is of opus mixtum and it has a door opening north to storeroom 6219.  This is a salesroom because of street frontage, a wine press found in Room 3 and size.

column14: This dolium fragment is contiguous to dolium 3214 which is on the southeast side of the wall. this maybe the 5th dolium from the south corner. Dolia (3214, 3213, 3212 and 3211) to the southwest.  cistern (3217) to the northwest.
column21: This is a fragment of a column embedded in fill along the southeast wall at the east corner of the room. No diagnostic features are visible. We cannot determine if this is in situ.

column14: The water basin is to the north. Kneading basin (3222) and mills (3207, 3227,3226 and 3206) to the southeast.
column21: This is a rectangular opening to a cistern with no cover evident. It is the north corner. It is heavily restored.

This is a square stone constructed structure. Traces of fine plaster coating are visible on the interior of the southwest side and along the bottom of the northwest side. A large underground opening is visible at the northeast and southeast bottom. This stone feature abuts the earlier plastered and painted northwest wall which is visible along the northeast side of the cistern (interior). The northwest side of the cistern was probably lower then the other sides.

column14: Water basin 3219 and lararium 3233 to the northwest; oven 3197 to the northeast.
column21: This water basin is located in southwest wall immediately south of the entrance to room 4. It is embedded in a stone platform. The form of this platform is rounded on its northeast side. The embedded ceramic vessel appears to be a wide mouth jar with a side flaring to flat lip. This vessel is complete except for a small chip in the rim. Ancient repairs are seen on 4 large cracks. Two of these repairs have visible metal staples and all have buff colored fine plaster covering. Most of the vessel is not visible because it is filled with gravel. The platform is topped with plaster and stands almost a meter high.

column14: Water basin 3218 to the SE; oven 3197 to the northeast ; Lararium 3233 above
column21: This water basin is located along the southwest wall immediately north to the doorway to room 4. It is embedded in a stone platform. The form of this platform is rounded in its northeast side. The embedded ceramic vessel appears to be a wide - mouth jar with a side flaring to a flat lip. Only two small fragments of the vessel are preserved. These may have broken prior to the eruption and were not repaired. Most of the vessel is not visible because it is filled with gravel. This stands about a half a meter high.

column14: Room 3 is to the northeast, Room  2 is to the east.
column21: Rectangular room - N/S axis. The floor is obscured by Lapilli. Traces of undecorated plaster on the south and west walls. In the center of the west wall there is a wide doorway with stepped stone threshold to the street to the west. In the northwest corner there is a masonry base with two proceeding steps for stairs to the floor above. Room 1 is contiguous with room 3 forming an L enclosing room 2 to the southeast. Room 2 is accessed through a doorway to the east. In the southeast corner is cooking a platform 6232. In the south wall behind the platform there is a terracotta drain from an upper floor above.

Square masonry cooking platform with partially preserved masonry and cement surface in the southeast corner of the room. In the wall to the south of the platform there is a terracotta downpipe from the floor above.

Rectangular arched couch niche. The lower part of the niche is contiguous with the wall. At the base of the niche at the southern end there is a collapsed hole into the wall. Plastered decoration survives of yellow and red bands and red trim on a white background. It's in the southern end of the east wall. The brick courses at the base of the niche are inserted into an earlier recess as they rest against an earlier plaster layer. No decoration is visible on the earlier plaster.

column14: Lararium is in the kit hen containing two platforms
column21: The lararium is in the north wall, and would have been visible from the kitchen's primary entrance from the southeast corner of the room. It is roughly two meters from the floor to the sill of the lararium. north wall and lararium are of modern reconstruction. The surrounding plaster is extant. the color is not discernible due to the elements.

column14: Contiguous to the west is the peristyle garden. To the north, east, and south is another structure /property.
column21: The overall structure is oriented generally in N/S axis. The dining room is northeast of the primary structure entrance. The room is oriented with its entrance facing west toward the peristyle. there is a rectangular window high on the north wall. The window sill is roughly 3.2 meters high. Plaster remains on the north, south, east and west walls with white over red paint, likely 4th style. The floor is a black tesserae set into white stone In a diamond shaped geometric pattern. Extant at the west threshold entry to the room. There are no signs of doors in only the singular high - placed window, mentioned above.

column14: The room is contiguous to the peristyle garden on the south. To the east is the repositories and anti room. To the north is another structure / property, situated to the west is room 10.
column21: The dining tablinum is oriented generally on a N/S axis. The room can be viewed directly from the structures primary south entrance and through the peristyle garden and from the street. North, east and west walls are of Opus Incertum with evidence of reconstruction and a 1976 reconstruction plaque is in the north wall. Some plaster is extant in the northeast and northwest corners or the room. Room's primary entrance is on the south wall with a secondary entrance in the southeast corner of the room. No sign of windows, jams or threshold.

column14: A cooking platform (6160) is to the north.
column21: This is a latrine with a  drain across the southern end of the room.  The drain is filled with earth.  The floor of tiles and opus signinum slopes south to the drain.  In the southwest corner there is a recess into the wall and against the floor level there is a terracotta down pipe draining through the west wall to the street beyond.

column14: A latrine (6159) is located to the south.
column21: The rectangular cooking platform is inserted against the plaster in the northwest corner of the room.  It is a masonry platform with a tile surface and arched recess beneath.  At the north end there is a masonry step against the north wall abutting directly to a plastered buttress in the northwest corner of the room.  Against the south end a low square platform has been added with a modern (?) cement surface.

column14: The peristyle (2) is to the north.
column21: This is a rectangular room on an east/west axis.  The doorway in the center of the north wall opens from the peristyle (2).  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  No extant wall decoration remains.

column14: The peristyle (2) is to the north.
column21: This is a square room.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  The doorway in the northeast wall leads to the peristyle (2) and has a stone threshold.  There is a possible blocked doorway from an earlier phase in the west wall.  The north wall is a later addition as it lies against the yellow and red plaster of earlier phase at the junction of the north and east walls.  Plaster with traces of yellow paint survives on the south and north walls.

column14: The peristyle (2) is to the north.
column21: This rectangular room is on an east/west axis and has a doorway in the northwest corner leading to the peristyle (2).  A matching door is in the eastern half of the north wall.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Plaster survives on the west and south walls with red trim.  The east wall is an addition as it abuts the plaster in the south wall.

column14: A corridor (8) is to the north
column21: The rectangular room is on a north/south axis.  The doorway in the center of the north wall opens to a corridor (8).  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Fragmentary plaster is on the south wall but has no visible decoration.  There is a small plastered recess in the northeast corner, subsequently blocked.

column14: The corridor (8) is to the west.
column21: This rectangular room is on an east/west axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  There is a plastered doorway with red paint in the north end of the west wall.  In the center of the north wall a wide window looks out to the garden (12).  Plaster decoration survives on all four walls with attending red, white and yellow panels, and white above - fourth style (?).   High in the south wall parts of plaster cornice are visible.

column14: The northeast wall abuts to the garden (12).  The southeast wall abuts a corridor (8.  The southwest wall abuts the peristyle (2).  The northwest wall abuts a passage (11).
column21: This is a square dining room opening to the northeast off of the peristyle (2).  A secondary entrance is located in the southwest corner of the northwest wall.  Another secondary entrance is located in the northeast corner of the southwest wall.  The doorway opening to the peristyle has a stone threshold.  The other two accesses have no evidence of thresholds remaining.  The room was fully plastered with some remains of fresco paintings in shades of red and black.  The floor is lapilli.  No windows are evident.

column14: The southwest wall opens to dining room 14.  The remaining three walls abut other structure addresses.
column21: This rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis opens off the northeast wall of dining room 14.  The doorway provides a view of the garden (12).  The walls have some remains of plaster, but very little.  There are no windows and no remains of flooring.

column14: A peristyle (2) is to the east.
column21: This is an L-shaped room with a north/south axis.  The longest arm of the room consists of a tiled latrine sloping south to a drain beneath the latrine.  The drain is filled with earth.  In the southwest corner there is a tile recess extending from the latrine into the wall.  At the base of the center of the west wall, almost at the junction of the latrine and cooking platform, there is a terracotta down pipe that drains through the wall to the street to the west.  As well as tiles, the floor is covered with a fragmentary preserved layer of opus signinum.  The northern half of the west wall consists of a cooking platform (6160).  The floor of the east arm is obscured by lapilli.  The doorway opens east to a peristyle (2).  Traces of undecorated plaster survive on the north wall and plaster extends beyond the southeast corner suggesting the south wall may be a later addition.  Above the platform in the west wall there is a small window to the street.

column14: The north and west walls abut adjacent property.  The south wall abuts room 11.  To the east is room 13 and corridor 10.
column21: At the far north end of the house (6.7.7) is located a rectangular kitchen that contains on its west wall a cooking platform (6282) with a built up hearth above.  The walls were plastered plastered and there is the possibility of a high window in the southwest corner of the wall.  The room is on an east/west axis.  The floor is rubble.

Spanning the west wall of the kitchen (12) is a brick cooking platform with a cement top, probably reconstructed.  On the north end of the top, spanning about one third of the total top distance is a built up hearth with arched wood storage underneath.  The hearth is a a cube shape also made of terracotta brick with a cement top.  The platform appears to have been heavily restored.

column14: The atrium (4) is to the south.
column21: This is a square room. The south wall is absent to allow an opening to the atrium to the south.  Only the lower courses of the north, east and west walls survive, with modern restoration.  The bulk of the north wall consists of a wide, low window looking into the garden to the north.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Against the center of the west wall there is a modern or restored square basin or pit (?) with a tile and cement lip.  The function and date is unclear.

column14: Room 5 is to west.
column21: This is a square room with a doorway at the south end of the west wall to room 5.  It has a modern lintel.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  The south and west walls show signs of restoration.  Undecorated plaster survives on all four walls, but most extensively on the north and east walls.  High in the east wall there is a square plater window opening to the street.  In the south wall are two poorly preserved holes for shelves (?).  There are also several randomly spaces holes in the north wall.  Eschebach identifies this a as a kitchen.

column14: The south and west walls of the room abut adjoining properties.  The east wall abuts the Vicolo della Fullonica.  The north wall abuts rooms 2 and 7.
column21: To the south of entrance 1, one enters dining room (6) off of the atrium (2).  The room is rectangular with an east/west axis, and is entered in the northwest corner.  The room is in a fairly ruined state with reconstructed walls on the north side.  There is little plaster remaining on the walls, but enough to prove the room was fully plastered at one time.  The floor is dirt and lapilli.  No windows are evident. An indentation niche in the northeast corner of the north wall may have been a couch niche, but the wall has had so much reconstruction that is it not possible to identify it as such.

column14: Room 1 is to the north.
column21: This is a square room.  The wide doorway to the atrium (1) takes up almost the entire north wall.  Only the lower courses of the wall survive with modern restoration.  The floor is obscured by lapilli, debris, and weeds.  The adjoining room (8) to the west is possibly a latrine and the function of room 7 is also unclear.  Both rooms 7 & 8 are filled with debris.  Eschebach says there is a kitchen and a latrine, but there is no visible evidence.

column14: North and west doors are contiguous to adjoining properties. South wall is contiguous to rooms 1 and 5. East wall is contiguous to spaces 2 and 3.
column21: To the northwest of entrance seven of Vicolo della Fullonica is a large rectangular room with two doorways. One leads to the south (atrium 1), the other leading to the east into a passageway (2). No door sill evidence remains. On the east wall is a large window, just above waist height, that opens to room 3. Plaster remains on the west wall at the bottom. Other then that the wall are bare opus incertum. No flooring remains. A little bit of red plaster remains in the northeast corner of the room.

column14: Room 20 to north.
column21: The kitchen is a small rectangular room with a north/south axis directly to the south of entrance 1. Lower courses of the walls survive with extensive modern restoration. The floor is obscured by lapilli. The adjoining room 25 to the southeast contains a latrine under the stairs, accessed from entrance 2.

column14: Room opens to the west to atrium 20 and to the south to space 22. The north and east walls abut neighboring properties.
column21: From doorway 1 we walk through atrium 20 in a west direction to enter dining room 21. The dining room is a large rectangular room on an east/west axis. The north wall appears to have been divided into two rooms in a previous time by a jut in the center of the wall. Plaster remains in rough condition on all walls and in some places it is possible to see an earlier decorative scheme of red lines on white plaster. The AD 79 plaster is evident in two places on the south wall where it supersedes the previous plaster. It appears the room was painted orange-red in some areas in AD 79. The access to the room is by two doorways, one shorter on the southwest corner of the south wall and a taller doorway opening to atrium 20 on the west wall. A large almost floor height window opens on that same wall to the tetrastyle in the atrium giving the diners a view of that. There is another window above providing additional light. The south wall also shows previous room division by a recessed angle leading to the doorway. The floor is lapilli.
column53: BW Shot A B CColor Shot A B CDigital Shot A B C

column14: Garden 14 is to the north. Dining room 18 is to the west.
column21: This is a square room with a side doorway to the garden at the west end of the north wall, with a marble threshold and placing for a door. The remainder of the north wall consists of a low open window looking over the garden. Traces of plaster survive on the base of the window. At the north end of the west wall there is a doorway to dining room 18 with a modern lintel and no preserved threshold. The partially preserved floor consists of marble chips inserted into cocciopesto. The ceiling of the room is modern restoration. Extensive 4th Style decoration exists on the south and west walls. Fragments of 4th Style decoration survive on the west wall. The central images survive on the south and east walls and are identified by Bianco as hermaphrodites.

column14: To the south is room 20 near entrance 6.7.1. To the west is corridor 19. To the east is dining room 16 as well as adjoining property.
column21: Entering to the south of the peristyle garden, one enters a very large rectangular room with a north/south axis. The room is divided into two sections by juts in the wall midway down the long sides. A small doorway to an adjoining room is located on the northeast corner of the east wall. The larger opening is on the north wall and almost spans the width of the room. Marble door sills are evident on the two sides of the doorways with cutouts for door hardware. Painted plaster, although faded and ruined, appears on all walls. There are two very high windows on the south and east walls. There are shards of mosaic tiles on the floor amidst the rubble. Tile, along the east and west walls, appears in two places to have had a black border, that would have run around the walls, on white ground.

column14: The porticus entrance 27 is north. Shop (entrance 29) is southwest.
column21: This is a small kitchen. There is an entrance at the east corner of the northeast wall. There is another entrance at the south corner of the southwest wall to the shop. The floor is not visible. The walls are in poor states of preservation with only some plaster in a few places remaining. There is a small window in the northwest wall. Only traces remain of a cooking platform (3237) along the northeast wall. The latrine (3238) is located near the north corner of the northwest wall. Four sections of ceramic pipes are visible in the northwest wall.

column14: Room 9 is to the northwest and room 7 is to the northeast.
column21: We enter this small square dining room from the northeast through a relatively low doorway. Evidence of plaster with 3rd Style wall painting is extant on all four walls and is best preserved on the northwest and southwest walls. On the north corner of the northwest wall is a large window between two pillars which were integrated into the wall in antiquity. High on the northwest wall, west end, is a small square window which is enclosed in what appears to have been an arch in antiquity but was blocked in. These windows provided light and air circulation, the larger providing a view into the garden. The ceiling is high, with concrete beams and terracotta tiles with plaster, which appears to be reconstruction. The floor is indeterminate but may have been beaten cement. The axis is northeast/southwest.

column14: The primary entrance to the shop-house is to the northwest. The kitchen is to the southwest. The garden is to the south. A blocked room to the south east is locked and contains modern equipment. The position suggests it is a cubiculum.
column21: We walk into the dining hall in the north corner of the structure from the southwest. There are signs of a marble threshold at the entrance. The entrance is large, old ashlar blocks. The lintels are modern concrete as are the rest of the lintels in the shop-house. It is a dining hall based on its large size and placement. The entrance is very wide. The floor is partial mosaic, which is white tesserae with a black tesserae border. All walls are in place but reconstructed. It has a reconstructed concrete ceiling. The walls show minimal plaster with no color. The dining room views a reported altar which is nearly gone. We can see a portion of the external street corner arch from the dining room. The south side of the southeast wall shows a narrow but high doorway with a threshold which is blocked with a modern grate.

column14: Room 5 is to the south east.
column21: This small room lies along a northwest/ southeast axis, and lies under a steep flight of stairs to the southwest. The room is vaulted and is approximately three meters high and is plastered and evidence suggests some red paint. In the northwest wall on the west corner is a skewed rhomboidal shaped opening which is plastered and leads into the adjoining room which is now used for modern lawn or maintenance equipment. Above the window is a hole which corresponds to one in the north corner of this same wall (northwest) and underneath this level are other small holes which indicate perhaps the location of small nails or hooks. On the southwest and northeast walls are similar random holes both in the plaster and in the surface from which plaster has been vacated. The floor is covered in dirt and debris. The doorway which fills the southeast wall is not extremely high.

column14: Cooking platform 3239 is to the north.
column21: The latrine in kitchen 10 is in the west corner of the northwest wall. Evidence for the structure is supported by the four large terracotta pipes which appear to come from the second floor. On the southwest wall which runs from the northwest to the southeast evidence of plaster remains as well as on the northwest wall near the drain. A small window to the north on the northwest wall opens to the street near entrance 27. The floor is obscured by ash and debris however some rock appears to have made a channel.

column14: Latrine 3238 to the southwest
column21: This is a cooking platform. Only slight traces of this platform remain including the southeast end where an outer edge can be seen abutting the northeast wall.

column14: room 4 is to the north.  Room 5 is to the west.
column21: This is a rectangular room with an eat/west axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  A doorway with modern lintel and fragments of a plastered threshold in the center of the west wall leads to garden 5.  on the north face of the door jamb, there is undecorated plaster.  At the west end of the north wall there is a doorway with modern lintel to latrine 4.  At the east end of the north wall, a small window opens into the latrine.  High in the center of the east wall there is a window with modern lintel that opens to the street.  Traces of undecorated plaster are on the north, south, and west walls.  There is a low masonry cooking platform, feature 6200, in the center of the north wall.

column14: N/A
column21: This is a low masonry platform.  It has a poorly preserved cement surface with tile fragments.  It stands against the north wall of the room with a window high on the east wall opening to the street to provide ventilation.

column14: North and west are differing structures/properties.  To the south is the atrium and likely a tablinum.  To the east is a cubiculi.
column21: The dining room's primary axis runs primarily east to west.  Its doorway is in the southeast corner which is northwest of the structure's primary entrance.  Embedded in the south wall is an Etruscan column whose placement has no bearing on the dining room usage.  One third of the column's drums, capital and echinus have been honed/removed so that the column would have been buried in the wall and not visible from this room in antiquity.  High on the west wall are seven beam pockets with plaster evidence of a barrel-vaulted plaster ceiling or exedra.  Plaster is extant on all the walls.  The lower register is red and the upper register is white plaster.  The upper register on the north wall  is capped with a cornice relief.  The room is entered from a raised black lava stone threshold.  The floor is of stone rubble.  The south wall, west end, contains a large couch niche.  Modern restoration has divided the niche in two.  The niche is painted in non-discernible red figuring on a yellow ochre background.  The south wall contains a window with a sill three meters above the floor.  The window was closed by modern restoration/stabilization effort.  This is a dining room because of its size and niche.  A meta is inside the entryway and is not in situ.

column14: The feature is in the southwest corner of the room.
column21: The couch niche is in the southwest corner of the dining room.  Yellow ochre and red plaster are extant.  The niche is large as compared to other dining room niches we have seen/observed.

column14: Atrium 4 is to the south.
column21: This is a large square room with a wide doorway to atrium 4 at the south.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Plaster survives extensively on the north and east  walls and in places on the south and west walls.  Fourth style painting with red and yellow panels is seen with a white upper register with architectural motifs.  Molded plaster cornices survive on the north wall and in traces on the east wall.  Above the cornice on the north wall is the placing for a floor joist.  High on the east wall ate placings for 8 floor joists.  Above these on the north and east walls are plaster from the floor above.

column14: Fauces 1 is to the west.
column21: This kitchen is a rectangular room with a north/south axis.  The doorway is in the center of the west wall with a modern lintel.  The floor is obscured by lapilli and structural debris.  Plaster survives on the north, south, and west walls.  High in the west end of the north wall is a window (or perhaps collapse?).  In the center of the south wall is a rectangular plastered window tapering south to the street outside.  In the southeast corner, the placement for a downpipe survives together for possible placing of a latrine seat.  The area of the drain below is filled with debris.  In the northeast corner there is a rectangular cooking platform.

column14: the latrine (6177 is to the south.
column21: This is a rectangular solid masonry platform with modern cement surface in the northeast corner of the room.

column14: Cooking platform (6176) is to the north.
column21: The drain is in the southeast corner, but is filled with debris.  Above the drain in the east wall. there is the placing for the seat.  In the southeast corner a downpipe drains into the drain beneath.

column14: Room 20 is to the north.
column21: this is a small rectangular room with a north/south axis and is directly to the south of the entrance 1.  The lower course of the walls survive with extensive modern restoration.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  The adjoining room 25 is to the southeast and contains a latrine under the stairs accessed from entrance 2.

column14: Atrium 2 is to the south.
column21: This is a square room with a wide doorway in the south wall opening to atrium 2.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  On the center of the north wall there is a square window with a modern lintel with traces of plaster on the base of the window.  Plaster survives on the north, east, and the north end of the west wall with red decoration.

column14: none
column21: Open to the west from space 1, room 7 is defined as a kitchen based upon a large masonry cooking platform in its southwest corner.  Two identified dining rooms open off this space on the north and west.  The east of the room is completely open to space 1.  There do not appear to be any windows in the room.  A couple holes at eye level on the south wall may have held shelf supports.  No plaster remains on what appear to be heavily reconstructed walls.  The floor is lapilli.  The kitchen is divided from space 1 by pillars of opus vittatum and opus catercium.  The rest of the walls are opus incertum.  Eschebach recorded a lararium in this area but it is no longer present.

column14: None
column21: A masonry platform with a large arched storage below is located in the southwest corner of room 7.  The platform is attached to the west and south walls and is rectangular in shape.  The top shows remnants of tile surface and the arch is made of brick.  The platform stands at approximately waist height in the room.
According to Eschebach a lararium was located in this area, but is no longer present.

column14: Room 1 to the north
column21: A rectangular room on an east/west axis with a doorway to room 1 out the west end of the north wall with stone threshold and modern lintel.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Only the lower course of the south wall survives.  The north, east, and west walls show signs of extensive restoration.  On the south, north, and east walls there are fragments of plaster with no visible decoration.  In the southwest corner there is a low plastered preparation platform (6297).

column14: The north and east walls are adjacent to the street and adjoining property.  The south wall abuts latrine 2 and space 1.  The west wall abuts dining room 4.
column21: Located to the north off entrance 15, this is a rectangular room on a north/south axis.  Plaster remains on the walls.  The doorway is wide, looking onto common area 1.  Doorway has a tufa sill.  High up on the west wall are two holes that may have been used for ceiling beams.  Floor is lapilli.

column14: North wall abuts the adjoining property.  The east wall abuts dining room 3 and the west wall abuts dining room 5.  The south wall is contiguous to space 1.
column21: Dining room 4 is entered to the north of space 1 and is a fairly square large room.  Paint and plaster remain on some of the walls.  Doorway is on the south wall and is quite wide with a tufa door sill.  Above the door is a small square window.  On the east and west walls of the room are located two large holes on each which are paired across from each other and probably held a beam at ceiling height.  In addition, ten smaller holes are located on the north wall where joists for an upper story would have been positioned.  Lower down at eye height on the north and east walls today are two other indentations that may simply be fallen brick but may also be noteworthy.  Floor is lapilli.

column14: North wall abuts the adjoining property.  The east wall abuts dining room 4 and the west wall abuts dining room 6.  The south wall is contiguous to space 1.
column21: The third in a series of large square rooms opening off of space 1, dining room 5 has a larger sized doorway on the south wall.  The room does not have a door sill and just has a lapilli floor.  Above the door is located a small square window for light.  On the east and west walls of the room are located two large holes on each which are paired across from each other and probably held a beam at ceiling height.  In addition, 11 smaller holes are located on the north wall where joists for an upper story would have been positioned.  The east and west walls show painted plaster remains.

column14: North and west walls abut the adjoining property.  The east wall abuts dining room 5.  The south wall abuts kitchen 7.
column21: Entered by a low doorway in the south wall from kitchen 7, dining room 6 is rectangular and is on an east/west axis.  This room was identified as a dining room because of its larger size.  Three upper story beam holes are seen in the north wall with one more possibility for a beam hole in the west wall at about the same height.  The west wall appears to have had a doorway that was closed up and plastered over in antiquity.  Remains of plaster are predominately found on that west wall.  Floor is lapilli.  There are no windows visible today in the room.  In the northeast corner of the room where the two walls join together, currently there are, at ceiling height, three larger sized tufa blocks stacked one on top of the other with an indentation above.  This could be either an upper floor beam support or simply fallen masonry.

column14: North, south and west walls abut the adjoining property.  The east wall abuts  kitchen 7.
column21: A small room accessed next to the cooking platform in room 7, dining room 8 has been identified by a niche in the west wall.  The room has plaster on its north wall and the plaster carries onto an indentation above the couch niche which could have been a lamp rest or a lararium.  The room is mostly square with a lapilli floor and no windows.  There is a tufa and tile door sill extant.

column14: Room 1 is to the north.
column21: This is a rectangular room with a north/south axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli.  Along the east wall are stairs to the floor above, beneath which is an arched cupboard space.  The room opens to room 1 to the north with a low wall and the square platform of water feature 6295 at the junction of the two rooms.  Undecorated plaster survives on the south wall.  On the west wall there is white plaster with dark lower register with lararium 6298.

column14: Lararium 6298 and niche 6296 are to the south.
column21: This is a square masonry platform with modern cement pointing.  There is a terracotta tile and brick surface into which is inserted a circular basin.  The basin has modern cement restoration and no visible lining.  Eschebach identifies this as a kettle.  The base of the basin is obscured by debris.

column14: Room 4 to North, 2 and 3 to the East.
column21: Rectangular room north-south axis. Floor is obscured by lapilli. In the center of the west wall. There is a wide doorway with fragmentary stoned threshold opening to the street outside.  At the southern end of the west wall there is a smaller doorway with stepped threshold which Eschebach says led to stairs.  In the southern half of the east wall there is a doorway to to store room 3.  At the northern end of the east wall there is a stone stop threshold to storeroom and there are 3 pierce-through holes along the east wall, possibly for a shelf.  2.  High in the center of the east wall there is a window open to storeroom 2 . In center of north wall, there's doorway to mill/oven room 4.

column14: Room 1 is to the west.
column21: A rectangular  room north / south axis. Floor obscured by lapilli.  Undercoated plaster survives on east, west and south walls.  Traces of 2 registers survives in northeast corners. At the west end of the south wall there is a blocked plastered doorway. In the center of the west wall, there is a high square window through to Room 1.  At the north end of the west wall, there is a doorway with stone stepped threshold to salesroom 1.  In the west wall there are 3 holes which pierce through to room 1.  There are 3 holes piercing thru the wall completely and a 4th neither in line nor piercing thru on the north wall.  There are 6 randomly placed holes in the east wall.  These holes on the west and north walls may have supported shelves.

column14: A differing property / structure is to north and east.  The street is to the west. The mill room is to the south and the oven abuts the room to the southeast.
column21: The room's primary access is from north to south and is entered from the south from the mill room via 2 doorways.  Floor is of stone and lapilli rubble.  North wall is of opus incertum with evidence of significant modern reconstruction.  A small bit of plaster is extant in the northeast.  The color is likely red, but faded due to the elements.The west wall is of opus incertum with a handful of tufa blocks with heavy reconstruction in modern times.  Very little plaster is extant, likely first style of white and red color.  The south wall is opus incertum.The east wall is opus incertum and shows evidence of several phases of modern reconstruction. East wall contains preparation pass-thru opening to the front of the oven.  Eschebach references a stair directly west of the pass-thru opening. Evidence for this is not extant. Along the east wall is 1/3 of a mill catillus, fragment not in situ and does not match the 3 surviving mills.  Along the west wall is a low incertum edifice, possibly a wall or preparation platform base.  No windows are extant.
column53: a & b (7 & 6 wrong) on B& W and color. (16 & 15 wrong) on Digital.

column14: To the north is the preparation room.  To the west is the street.  To the south are the sales and preparation rooms.  To the east is a differing property/structure.
column21: Room's primary access is from south to north.  The primary entrance is from the salesroom on the south. The east wall is of opus incertum, some plaster is extant.  Color is not evident due to the elements.  However, a register/relief/datum exists which matches that found on the west wall of the preparation room. The north wall is of opus incertum and opus latericium. West wall is of opus incertum with a lararium at its south end.  Very little plaster is extant, likely of red color. South wall is of opus incertum with 3 beam pockets that extend through the wall to theadjacent storeroom #1.  These could be for shelf supports and less likely forventilation.  Wall has evidence of repair/reconstruction in antiquity and modern time  Floor is of black lava pavement stones.  East wall has 2 masonry supports.  There are 3 mills and a cistern head in this room.  In the northeast corner is a kneading basin.

column14: Mill is south and east of the oven, kneading basin and masonry supports.
column21: This mill is in the southeast corner of the room.  The stone base is of modern reconstruction with a concrete parged collection surface.  Meta and catillus are intact.  Top lip of (W) catillus is fractured and missing.

column14: Just inside the primary (south) entrance of the room.  It's axially due east of the lararium in the west wall.  One of 3 extant mills.
column21: The mill is roughly centered in the south edge of the room.  The base is of modern reconstruction/repair.  Material collection surface has been parged with modern concrete.  Meta and catillus are extant.  Catillus is damaged and missing 40%.  There is no evidence of repair in antiquity.

column14: One of 3 mills and is closest to the oven face.  Directly south of the preparation platform 6242.
column21: One of 3 mills in the room.  Base is of modern reconstruction/repair with a concrete parged material collection surface.  Meta and catillus are extant.  The top of the catillus is damaged.  There is no evidence of repair in antiquity.

column14: Preparation platform abuts the oven and its masonry banding is not contiguous with that of the oven.
column21: The preparation platform and surface is heavily reconstructed post antiquity.  2 basins exist with no terracotta vessels extant.  Preparation platform is rectilinear with an easterly and westerly wing wall or bump-out.  This form is atypical to what we commonly see in Pompeii.  This form is likely a misinterpretation by modern restoration.

column14: The preparation platform is to the west of the oven mouth.
column21: Beehive oven is of opus latericium with opus incertum surround.  Passthrough from the preparation room is west of the oven mouth.  There is no postbaking passthrough to the east through the front face of the oven.  Eschebach references a terracotta medallion above the oven mouth with phallic symbol and inscription which are not extant; only the niche remains.  There is no high ventilation openings/vents evident.  They were likely filled/covered post antiquity.  Between the oven mouth and preparation room passthrough there is located a vertical opening through the top of the structure.  This may be a chimney or flue.

column14: Basin is directly east of the oven mouth and north of the masonry platform supports.
column21: Kneading basin is of black tufa, located in northeast corner of room in front of oven.  It was damaged in antiquity with 3 iron repairs evident. The 3 pieces associated with this repair are not extant.  Opus signinum is present.  Distinctive wear is noted on the wedge and the inside of the basin lip.

column14: Supports are directly south of the kneading basin and along the east side of the room.
column21: Two low masonry supports are bonded with the east wall.  Supports and east wall have evidence of modern tuck-pointing.

column14: Cistern 6247, mill 6240, 6241,6239, masonry support 6245.  Kneading basin 6244, oven 6243, preparation platform 6242 to the east.
column21: Large, shallow arched recess at the south end of the west wall.  The base of the lararium is not preserved.  Undecorated plaster with modern restoration survives throughout.

column14: Lararium 6246 to the southwest, mill 6241, 6240, 6239, masonry support 6245, kneading basin 6244, oven 6243, preparation platform 6242 to the east.
column21: Square tufa base for a circular cistern head.  Cistern is filled with earth and a small cone shaped stone, not in situ, has been placed in the opening.

column14: Room 10 to east.
column21: A rectangular room faced west-east axis. Doorway in the southern end of the east wall with stepped threshold and modern lintel. Floor is obscured by lapilli . No extant wall decoration. two small holes in north wall of uncertain use. Third hole blocked. Cooking platform 6181 in northeast corner of room. Northwest corner of room w/ latrine 6182 is separated for the remainder of room by a partitioned wall.

column14: 6182 to the west.
column21: Rectangular cooking platform against the east end of the north wall. The platform abuts directly against plastered wall to the east arched recessed storage beneath. tiled cooking surface partially preserved.

column14: 6181 to the west.
column21: A latrine separated from remainder of room by a partitioned wall. the latrine is entered by a stepped threshold with tiled surface that slopes into the drain to the north. the drain is filled by debris. on the northeast and west sides are the masonry supports for a seat and in the east wall there is the placing for the wooden seat inserted into the face of the wall.

column14: Mills (3265, 3266, 3267) to the W; painting (3254) to the west.
column21: This feature is the painted area beneath the barrel vault on the east wall. A large rooster is painted facing the center area from the north corner and is shown eating grapes. To the north of this rooster is a basket of pomegranates. Another  pomegranate is located toward the south side of the painting. there are also other objects that cannot be identified but may have to do with food.

The large cooking platform occupies the length of the east wall and abuts the north and south walls. It extends west into the room just short of the entrance. it is approximately 1m deep and 40 cm high. At the back of the structure is an upright stone structure which is approximately 1m high and 20 cm deep. It abuts the northeast wall for the northeast corner and extends midway across the back of the platform. it appears to have been broken. tiny fragments of plaster are visible at the broken portion. moss and debris cover both structures however, a few terracotta tiles remain on both upper and lower surfaces.

column14: Kitchen (3261) room 7 is to the north and dining room (3260) room 9 is south and room 5 is to the south.
column21: We enter the long rectangular preparation room, which lies south of the kitchen, from the west. The room likes along a northeast/southwest axis. The walls are high and have been restored at some point. Only a small few fragments of plaster remain. On both long walls (north and south) we find nine beam holes for support. The floor is obscured with vegetation and marble slabs as well as random building materials in the back of the room. The ceiling in non extant.

column14: It is contiguous to two other catilli (3266, 3267) along the north wall of room 10.
column21: This is a Catillus. It is broken along the rim. It is black basalt. It is not in situ.

column14: It sits between features 3265 and 3267. Two other catilli along the north wall.
column21: This is a Catillus in poor condition with portions of both ends missing. It is black basalt. It is not in situ.

column14: Two other catilli sit next to this one (3265 and 3266) along the north wall.
column21: This is a Catillus in poor condition with both ends broken. It is black basalt. It is not in situ.

column14: Adjoins corridor 5 to the north; Rooms 11, 12 and 13 to which there no access, to the south; Dining Room (3256) to the NW; Dining room (3258) to the west.
column21: We enter room 14 from 'corridor' 5. Room 14 is southeast if the 'corridor'. There is a marble threshold. The doorway is topped with a modern concrete lintel and is medium height. The room is a Roman square room and the floor is a mixture of mud and Lapilli. The wall which opens to the corridor holds a large window overlooking the garden and corridor. the window is closed to 2/3 height with a corrugated iron sheet. Two of the vaults show plaster with white and red paint. There is a modern ceiling. This room contains paint, boards, concrete, tubing for use of custodians.

column14: The northwest walls abut the adjoining property. The south wall abuts room (5). The doorway opens to space (3).
column21: At the far northwest corner of the house is a small rectangular room. The room is extremely narrow. There was a low ceiling as evidenced by a series of holes at  a height of approximately at six and half feet along the two long walls. The room is orientated in a east west direction. Plaster is present on the lower half of the three walls. The doorway to space 3 constitutes the fourth wall. There are no windows. The floor is rubble. The room has been identified as a kitchen solely based upon Eschebach's description.

column14: Room 8 to the west.
column21: This is a rectangular room on an east/ west axis. The floor is obscured by lapilli and extensive debris. All four wall show signs of restorations. At the north end of the west wall there is a small doorway with no visible threshold. In the center of the east wall there is a square window with a modern lintel looking into the street to the east. Above the window are facings for floor above or possible modern restoration. The north wall, east wall and east corner of south wall have white plaster with a red trim surviving at the east end of the north wall. Wall collapse at the north end of the east wall reveals a terracotta down pipe which drains out to the street.

column14: Atrium (3249) to the southwest and room 6 to the northeast.
column21: This dining room is a square room with a northeast/ southwest axis. The entrance is on the southwest wall and is a wide opening. No threshold or flooring is visible. In general the walls are poorly preserved with plaster repairing on the southwest , northwest and northeast walls. The construction of the southwest wall at the south corner is opus vittatum. The southeast wall has used ceramic and brick mixed into the stonework. There is a fairly large window in the northeast wall with a view to space (6). There is an arched recess (niche 3241) in the northern corner of the northwest wall.

column14: None
column21: This recessed space or niche is located in the northwest wall in the southern corner. The space is 1.5 meters wide, 1.5 meters tall and 20 centimeters deep. The vousoirs are visible on the northwest side of the arch. Wall plaster is preserved on the southern half of the arch, including the interior of the arch, otherwise the rough stone is visible.

column14: The viridarium (6) is to the west/ southwest, the atrium (3241) is to the southwest.
column21: We enter the kitchen in the west from the viridarium or from the southwest via the atrium. The L- shaped room runs along a northwest / southeast axis and is in poor condition. There are traces of plaster on the northeast wall. There are four or five holes above this plaster for an unknown purpose. On the north corner of the northeast wall is a partial wall approximately 2 meters long on a northwest / southeast axis abutting the northeast wall. The height is approximately 1.5 meters in the middle and its function is unclear. On the east corner of the northeast and the southeast walls is what appears to be the remains of the latrine (3247) with the northwest portion on a northeast / southwest axis which is approximately 1 meter in length. On the southwest wall is an indentation which runs along northwest / southeast axis the length of the wall and is approximately 50 centimeters high. This would suggest delineation  of a cooking platform. The walls are to a second story height. The floor is obscured by lapilli and vegetation.

column14: Catillus (3244) to the south.
column21: This is a minimal catillus; less than a fourth of this catillus remains. It sits in the south corner about one third of a meter from the southeast wall.

column14: A minimal catillus sits to the north.
column21: This partial catillus sits in the south corner of the shop. It was either moved or blown in here; more likely it was moved.

column14: NA
column21: Two thirds of a catillus sits in the southwest entrance from room (1). It is not in situ.

column14: The latrine (3247) to the east.
column21: The evidence for a cooking platform is suggested by an indentation on the southwest wall which runs along a northwest / southeast axis and is approximately 50 centimeters from the floor and 1.5 meters long.

column14: Cooking platform (3246) to the west.
column21: Evidence for a latrine is suggested in the east corner of the kitchen. The structure runs along a northeast / southwest axis and at its highest point, which is the northwest partition boundary, is approximately 50 centimeters high eroding to nothing at the west end. The structure abuts the northeast wall and in antiquity probably joined the southeast wall as well. Within this structure are two low parallel pilings of terracotta probably used to support a seat. A small fragment of plaster remains on the northwest face of the structure. The structure is in disrepair.

column14: Atrium (3249) sits to the northeast.
column21: There is a large entrance to the shop on the southwest side from the Via Stabiana. It is a roman square room. The threshold is high with no signs of flaking. There are two catilli in the south corner on a lapilli floor. There is a smaller doorway on the northeast wall. The height of the wall is not ceiling height. There is evidence of pink plaster on all four walls.

column14: The shop room 1 (3248) is to the southwest the dining room 3 (3240) is to the northeast. A hallway is to the northeast.
column21: We enter the atrium in the southwest from the shop (3248) and look through to the hallway which is to the east. The southwest entrance is blocked by an out of place catillus. The floor is uneven lapilli. The walls are over 3 meters high with minimal plaster which is pink.

column14: A different structure property to the east and north. The street is to the west, salesroom is to the south.
column21: The room is entered from the salesroom to the south on the south wall. The south wall is of opus mixtum. Some plaster is extant. The color is unclear due to the elements. Wall is of brick coining of opus incertum. There is a rectangular window to the street and is centered in the room with a sill two meters high. There is no plaster extant. The color pattern is unclear due to the elements. The north wall has brick coining of opus incertum. There is some plaster extant, likely white. Seven-beam pockets are visible for the second store, which is non-extant. The east wall is of opus incertum and opus mixtum at the entrance opening. Centered on the wall half meter high is a recess whose identification is unclear but could be shrine/lararium. The floor is of stone rubble. The east wall has a recess in the bricks at the level of the pockets on the north wall. Modern tuck painting is evident on the north, west, east walls.

column14: Room 1 to the west.
column21: A rectangular room north-south axis. Floor obscured by lapilli. Undecorated plaster survives on the south wall, the southwest corner, the northeast corner, the base of the north wall and northeast corner. In the north wall at the east end there is a poorly preserved window looking into atrium of VI-3-3, In the center of the north wall there is a small square hole. At the north end of the east wall there is a possible window of collapse? High in the center of south wall is a poorly preserved window. In the northern half of the west wall there is a doorway opening down to the salesroom to the west. The threshold consists of two masonry steps going down to the level of the sales room. There are no signs of a physical door in this place.
PAH1 3, 26 remains a wine press CF Eschebach 162'

column14: Room 2 (Storeroom) is to the north. The street is to the west. A different structure/property is to the south. Room 3 is to the east.
column21: The salesroom is entered from the street through the west wall. The entrance has a store threshold carried to indicate one could secure the room with doors/panels. The floor is of stone rubble. West wall is opus incertum with brick coining at westerly edge of the wall. Plaster is extant and likely a lower register in red. There are eight beam pockets along the south wall for a second story that is not extant. There is a stair/platform in the southeast  corner of the room. There is evidence of modern tuck pointing on the south wall. The east wall is of opus incertum with a two-stepped entrance to Room 3. The entrance to Room 3 is of opus mixtum. There is one beam pocket extant on the east wall. There is minimal plaster extant. There is possibly a low register in red.
