The north wall is of opus mixtum and it has a door opening north to Storeroom 6219. This is a salesroom because of street frontage, a wine press found in Room 3 and size.

column14: Room 4 to the north, Room 8 is to the east, Room 6 is to the west.
column21: A rectangular room east/west axis. At the east of north wall there is doorway to Atrium 4 with stone threshold. The threshold preserves placing for a door. At the north end of the east wall there is a doorway to Room 8 with stone threshold. in the center of the west wall there is a doorway to Room 6. The floor is obscured by lapilli. On the south wall there is extensive preserved plaster with dark lower register, red and yellow panels above. High in wall a fragment of molded cornice survives. The door jambs in the doors in the north and east walls contain recesses for bars or locking mechanism for the door?

column14: Kitchen's west wall abuts Room 8. The opening on the north abuts space 13 and passageway 11. The south and east walls abut adjoining property.
column21: One enters room 12 off andron 11 passing through room -3 to the north. The kitchen is rectangular on an east-west axis. On the western end of the room is found latrine (feature 6267) and on the east end of Room is cooking platform (6266). The room is divided between the two by a short divider wall. Some plaster remains on the walls and post holes on the south wall provide evidence of an upper story. On the east wall up high is an opening that may have been a window. No flooring remains.

column14: the cooking platform is east of  latrine (6267) in the southwest end of kitchen (12).
column21: on the south wall of kitchen (12) running between the east wall and the wall dividing the room from the latrine is a largely reconstructed masonry cooking platform. current surface appears to be plain asphalt and masonry is flush to the floor with no storage below. Cooking platform is about knee high from the floor, perhaps a bit higher.

column14: The latrine is in the southwest end of room 12 immediately adjacent to the wall separating it from cooking platform 6266 to the east.
column21: Latrine is a square area on the southwest end of room 12. identification is solely based upon Eschebach as there are no remains of a tile floor or drain. some plaster remains on the walls.

column14: the south wall abuts peristyle 14. The west wall and doorway abut kitchen 17. The north and east walls abut adjoining property.
column21: store room 16 is accessed directly from kitchen 17 to its west. the doorway is narrow. the space is rectangular on an east west axis. plaster remains on the south wall where we also see a pair of linteled windows looking onto peristyle 14. Above the second window and to its south are three holes which may have held beams for an upper story. The floor is rubble. The lower window is the larger of the two and begins at about chest height on a five foot six inch person. The second window is smaller and although higher than the top lintel of the lower window, is located diagonally t o the upper right when facing that wall inside the room.

column14: The west wall is adjacent to the street. The north and west walls attach to adjoining properties. Storeroom 16 enters to the east. Peristyle garden 14 and walkway 15 are to the south.
column21: At the northwest rear end of house 6 lies  a kitchen which includes a cooking platform and latrine. The kitchen is entered by a doorway off of peristyle walkway 15 to the south. The room is slightly L-shaped with a  cooking platform immediately  on the west wall upon entering. The latrine occupies the northwest corner of the room. The walls are plain with no plaster remaining. no windows are evident. a pipe from an upper story is visible above the latrine. Some terracotta tiles on the floor denote the area of the latrine. At this time the rest of the floor is rubble.

column14: The latrine is located in the northwest corner of room 17 immediately to the north of the cooking platform 6271.
column21: Currently open area at the northwest end of room 17, latrine is identified by terracotta floor tile sloping down towards the cooking platform to the south. Additional evidence within the west wall of the latrine is a terracotta drain pipe that runs within the west wall directly above the latrine. The latrine would be located on the west street wall of the room and would have drained out to  the street, although no evidence  of a drain in the floor remains.

column14: The platform is approximately 2 feet from the doorway of room 17 stretching along the west wall towards latrine 6270 at the north.
column21: A rectangular platform is located immediately within the doorway of room 17 along the west wall. Solid masonry construction makes up the cooking platform with no open storage spaces. The top may have been tiled at one time because there are scraps of terracotta material remaining. The platform is about knee height and about 5 feet long.

column14: The dining room is to the south of atrium (8) and room 6 is to the southeast. Room 14 is to the west and the dining room abuts adjoining properties on the north and east.
column21: This very large rectangular room is entered by a southern doorway that opens to atrium 8. The room is on a north south axis and has a very large window opening on the west wall looking at peristyle 14. Painting and plaster remains on all walls to a degree. On the east wall is a protected painting of Hercules which gives the house its name.  No other features are evident and the floor is lapilli and weeds.  A marble threshold with indentations for door attachments is well-preserved.  Close to window on west wall a brick column surrounded by masonry shows evidence of a previous room design.  There is a slight straight wall indentation running from that column about two feet to the south at about six feet high.

column14: To the north is an adjacent property in addition to storeroom 16.  Room 15 wraps the room on the south and west, and on the south is also located tablinum 13.  Dining room 7 is to the east.
column21: The peristyle garden is located to the north of atrium 8 and tablinum 13.  This rectangular garden is on the east/west axis and contains a built lararium on the northeast corner.  On the south and west sides of the garden are the remains of 3 columns with a low wall between.  On the north wall is a pair of windows opening to storeroom 16.  On the east wall is a large window opening to dining room 7, and although no longer present, a low wall in the tablinum 13 probably also contained a window.  The walls in the lararium were plastered.

column14: Atrium 4 is situated to the East. Peristyle 26 is situated to the North.
column21: This is a small dining room. This room is on a NE/SW axis. The room is in fair condition. The floor and walls are preserved. The ceiling is reconstructed. There is an entrance to the room in the northern corner of the NE wall. This doorway opens to the atrium and has a white marble threshold. Another door is located in the western corner of the NW wall. This door opens to the peristyle. A large window is located on the Northern half of the NW wall. The floor is a black overall pattern with a double band of white around the perimeter. In more patterning on this floor, it's not visible due to the accumulation of heavy dirt. The walls are in fair condition with a great deal of painting intact. These walls appear to be third style. There is a red dad with patterns containing figures and mythological creatures. The central zone is predominantly pale blue with fanciful architectural designs and garlands and putti. The upper zone reveals delicate architecture and birds, putti and a central goddess. The Southwest wall has a small window, located near the center; just below the ceiling.

column14: This space is S.W. of the dining rooms (28) and (29). It is located N.W. of the atrium
column21: This rectangular peristyle garden is aligned on a NE/SW axis. This is surrounded by 24 stucco covered columns between which Jashemski noted a wooden fence between the columns. The fluted columns are red on the bottom and white on the top (6 x 8). A narrow channel is enclosed by the columns. In the center, there is a large fountain pool. This is basically rectangular with alternating rectangles and semi-circular recesses. The walls of the pool are painted blue. The top surface is capped with white marble. In the center of the pool is a column supporting a column base which was part of a fountain. At the SW end of the pool water cascaded down from 7 marble steps, located adjacent to the S.E. side of the stepped fountain is a deep square tank which Jashemski suggested may hold fish while the pool was being cleaned or used to cool drinks. A similar yet smaller and more shallow tank is located just N.E. of the eastern corner of the peristyle garden. A puteo is located between the last columns at the Eastern end of the S.E. row.

column14: To the central inside columned area of room 26.
column21: This is a fountain pool. This is basically rectangular with alternating rectangles and semi-circular recesses. The walls of the pool are painted blue. the top surface is capped with white marble. In the center of the pool is a column supporting a column base which was part of a fountain. At the S.W. end of the pool water, that is cascading down from 7 marble steps. Adjacent to the S.E. side of the stepped fountain is a deep square tank which Jashemksi suggested may hold fish while the pool was being cleaned or used to cool drinks.

column14: This dining room opens to a significant spectacular view, looking on to the fish pond. The peristyle garden #26 is located to the West.
column21: The room has a large formal entrance to the Southwest, that is the width of the entire room. The entrance is made of thin marble, seen at ground level with a mosaic floor. The mosaic floor, situated at the entrance has a black geometric design, with a white background. The floor is white tesserae, in the dining area with a black border on 4 sides. The interior to the dining area contains ten individual columns. The two columns, seen at the entrance appear to be attached to large round pilasters.. The fluted columns hold an arch with pseudo ionic columns with traces of yellow paint. Each of the ten individual columns sits on a square base. The square bases are painted with traces of first style in yellow architectural design. At the top of the columns, there is a second level of continuous architrove. the columns define an interior dining area with separate corridors, situated on the North and South sides. the 2 columns situated at the back of the room are centered to the entrance.  There is a varying different geometric mosaic with a white and black pattern seen between the columns. When facing into the dining room, the wall is directly to the right. There are 3 registars. On the bottom register, there are 5 distinct patterns of red paint. The panels on the end are red painted in white is a laurel border possibly of marine life, with a matching panel situated on the other end of the wall.  Next, the two interior side panels are possibly of Dionysis. the statues are sitting on a painted raised platform. The center panel is sacro-idyllic landscape with traces of blue, yellow and white on the background.  The middle register is badly damaged and faded and mainly yellow; it consists of 3 large panels separated by painted architectural of 4th style. The center, damaged top register contains figures. On the left are birds and the center and side panels contain masks and flying figures.  The rear wall is badly damaged and the painting is identical to the wall located on the right sides. The large center panel is too badly damaged to be identified. The wall situated to the left, upon entering the dining room, it's badly damaged and appears to be decorated the same, as the wall situated to the right.  On the entrance, there are semi-attached columns painted the colors of red and yellow. The one situated on the left has a metal curtain hook. The ceiling is reconstructed.

column14: To room 30, situated to the North and room 2840, to the Southeast. Southwest peristyle # 26.
column21: Room 29 lies Northeast of the peristyle. It is a large rectangular room on a Northeast-Southwest axis. A white marble threshold borders the black and white tesserae, which makes up the mosaic floor. Just beyond the marble is the edge of the floor, which has a pattern of black and white lines enveloping white figures in groups of 4, which resemble arched white figures forming black arches in between. Approximately two feet between the geometric pattern of hexagonal mosaic, seen in black detail. Is is bordered by white tessearae on 4 sides. Plaster painted in second style occurs on all 4 walls, with most being on the Southeast and Northeast walls. On the lower register, in the Northern corner is a black panel which features a cloaked male, resting on the figure of a bull. This pattern of black is contiguous with the Northeast wall, which depicts other figures, 2 of which are reclining and one central figure, who is squatting and appears to be holding the doorway above him. At the Eastern corner of the Southeast wall, a figure, possibly representing Venus, appears to be resting on a dolphin. The only other shape that can be clearly seen onthe lower register is a large vessel. There is a slight outline of a figure onthe South end of the Southeast wall, however no details remain. On each of the panels that containlefelike figures, there are small framed flowers on the left and right sides. The upper register was painted red in panels, which were framed by painted columns extending through both registers. The center panel, at the Northeast wall appears to have had a square or rectangular painting, the outline of which is visible. The other fine panels of red have blue backgrounds and remnants winged figures. On the Northeast wall, above the left and right panels are white squares. The ceiling is modern, as is the high lintel.

column14: Opening to north and off atrium 7
column21: Dining room on north/south axis. Entered over stone threshold from atrium 7. No ceiling. Overgrown floor. Plaster remains on all 4 walls. On the north wall there is a white lower register with a red band across the top. The north west wall appears to be divided into two panels, with traces of red, yellow an blue paint.  But style of decoration is impossible to tell. The north/east and east walls appear to have the same style of decoration, with the lowest register in red and the upper wall with no real defined color remaining on the plaster.  The South wall continues the decoration with traces of bright red and white paint remaining over darker red in the lower register. The west wall shows evidence of more elaborate painting on the lower register which looks to be  center frieze bordered by red lines that look like ribbons over black paint. A central panel bordered by architectural  detail appears above, but designs is indistinguishable. I see no windows, only a large doorway for a view. Three gaps in the masonry that resemble post roles may have been original on the east wall.

column14: Atrium 7 is to the north.
column21: Rectangular room E/W axis. Floor obscured by earth and vegetation.  The West and off the north wall, there is a doorway to the atrium with a basalt stepped threshold.   At the west end of the south wall, there is a doorway to the area beneath the stairs from entrance 18. At the south end of the west wall, there is a plastered window that narrows to the room to the west and the circular hole (modern collapse?). There are traces of undecorated plaster surviving on the west wall.  At the base of the west wall, there is a water basin (6451).  Directly to the north of the basin, there is a terracotta downpipe embedded in the wall from the floor above. Undecorated plaster survives on the north wall, and high on the wall are placings for a floor above.  Plaster survives on the east wall with a pink hue.  In the center of the east wall, there is a square window looking out at the street outside.  At the north end of the east wall, there is a square hole and at the south end of the east wall, there are 3 small holes of an uncertain function. At the base of the east wall, are masonry supports (6449). The south wall has extensive modern restoration.

column14: Atrium 7 to the south.
column21: Retangular room on an east/west axis in heavily bombed out area. N and W walls are reconstructed, with traces of white and red plaster.   Room is entered from wide doorway in southwall from atrium 7. East wall only exists partially. There is no ceiling and the floor is over grown. there are possible traces of red and yellow paint remaining in a very rustic condition. There is a very small remnant of a stone threshold in the doorway.

column14: 6449 is to the East.
column21: Rectangular masonry base of a water feature. Fragments survive of a tiled surface. Against the extension of the basin to the north is a terracottta downipe.  At the junction of the southern end of the basement and the west wall there is a hole for a drain?

column14: 6451 is to the west.
column21: Two masonry supports against the east wall of the room. Plaster facing  survives on the northern face of the northern platform contiguous with the plaster on the east wall. Fragments of the same plaster survives at the southern face.  The southern masonry support consists of a single stone block and there is no extant plaster. in front of the block, traces of a base of the support are visible on the floor. No evidence for the table survives.

column14: Rooms 5 & 6 to the North. Corridor 8 to the east.
column21: Kitche is entered from corridor 8 tot he E and is located in the SW corner of the house. In the SE  corner of the room is a cooking platform #6439. South wall is partial reconstruction with traces of plaster, no paint remains. West wall is reconstructed.  Opus incertum, no plaster. to the north, there are two openings to rooms 6 and 5. Doorways are rubble.  Plaster evidence exists only on the NW corner. Water feature #6440 sits in the NW corner of the room. No ceiling. Floor is lapilli. Room is on a E/W axis.

column14: Room is contiguous to and entered fro room 13 to the east
column21: Room is entered at the North West corner of room 13. No threshold remains Floor is covered with lapilli and debris. there is no ceiling. North wall is badly damaged with traces of reconstruction and no traces of reconstruction and no traces of plaster. South west wall is badly damaged with some reconstruction and traces of plaster. A large opening appears to and may have been an opening prior to 19 A.D. North East walls are badly damaged and facing the wall to the left is the door opening.

Room has no ceiling or roof. Floor obscured by lapilli. Entrance is on south east all of House of the Labyrinth (6.11.10) off corridor 51. Whole house at 6.11.8 is in northwest side of the House of the Labyrinth, directly behind the bakery. On the northwest wall of room 2, on the right, there were stairs leading off the main corridor into atrium 5. The section of northwest wall is located under a stairwell. Damaged and some reconstruction with some plaster and traces of paint, very faded colour. In the wall under the stairwell there is a round post hole and a large recessed rectangular niche with traces of plaster. High up on wall there are traces of two post holes. Facing the wall to the left a wall projects north approximately one third into the room, behind which is a latrine (6425) On south west wall which is and has damaged no plaster or paint, there is a rectangular window above head level. Facing wall on left side, above cooking platform is a rectangular opening. Low on that wall is a round hole. Facing the south east wall in the lower right corner there are traces of a cooking platform (6426) On the wall is a trace of plaster but no paint. High up on the wall appears a row of post holes of uneven sizes. At the level of the doorway there are five post holes, possibly round. Other round holes appear in the wall. There is a large entrance along the north east wall. There are no remains.

column14: Latrine is in room.
column21: On the north west corner of room 2, enclosed with a wall projection is a latrine. There is some plaster and traces of faint red paint on two of the walls. Evidence in corner of a possible bench for a seat, badly damaged, and evidence of a possible tiled floor with slightly raised entrance.

column14: It is in opposite corner from latrine.
column21: Located on the south west wall side in the corner are traces of a cooking platform of stone and rubble.

column14: atrium 5 to the west
column21: Rectangular room, east west axis, floor obscured by lapilli throughout. White plaster fragments survive on east wall, north east corner and north west corner. At the base of the north west corner there are traces of two layers of plaster of earlier decoration with red plaster and black overline. In the centre of the west wall there is a doorway with no visible threshold to atrium.

column14: Atrium 2 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room, north south axis. Bombed out. Poorly preserved north, east and west walls. Pinkish hue on plaster on east and west wall with traces of a central rosette and architectural details in the east wall. Yellow trim and rosette in the west wall. Floor obscured by debris. According to Warscher the painting of Isis and Io referred to by Bonucci and now in the Naples museum (inv 9555) may have come from this room. Warscher suggests that the presence of a painting of Isis in a low status inn indicates that it was used by worshippers of isis. The large quantities of cooking utensils found throughout the house supports its identification as an inn.

column14: Atrium 2 to the south
column21: Rectangular room east west axis. Bombed. Filled with earth, no visible floor, no south or west wall. According to Forelli the kitchen contained stairs to floor above, latrine 6339 and cooking platform 6338.

column14: north of room 37, room 35 to east, atrium 2 to the southeast
column21: No longer extant cooking platform against the north wall of the kitchen described by Warscher. Warscher's photograph shows arched storage recess beneath and tiled surface.
No longer extant latrine described by Fiorelli.

column14: South of Atrium 2
column21: Bombed out and filled with debris. Warscher identifies this as a possible dining room. Overlooking a garden according to Jashemski.

column14: Room 7 to the north
column21: One enters the storage room from the northeast. This room runs along a northwest/southeast axis. It is located under the stairs and it is a irregular room in that there is a large threshold like step up and down to a lower level under the stairs. On the northwest side of this lower part the ceiling of this room angles at 45 degrees under modern stairs. There is a modern lintel which delineates the angled space. This portion of the room appears to have been plastered with cement and is obscured with ash on the floor. The upper and main portion of the store room contains four holes, two above two lower, probably for shelf support. This holes are in a plastered, nicely painted wall of orange and white with red vertical lines. There are red borders that form panels. The ceiling in this portion of the room is formed by modern stairs, forming a flat roof. On the south wall is a large window or light well which has a modern wooden lintel inserted and lined with lead. It is about 3 x 3 feet (100 x 100 cm approx.). There is a portion of a small partition on the west side of the northwest wall. Today large pieces of plaster and marble are on hte floor in a pile. Note, on the northwest wall, there is a gap in the plaster, which may have indicated an enclosure and another one above the partition on the southeast wall.

column14: Room 8 to the southwest
column21: We enter the kitchen from a door on the southeast wall. Abutting the southeast wall and north wall is a large cooking platform with two arched recesses underneath. The outer facing of the front (South) is made of brick which was faced with plaster painted red as evidenced on the lower southern corner. Also the northern face of the platform is still also entirely faced with red plaster. The cooking platform is in relatively good repair. The floor surrounding the cooking platform creates an "L" for the remaining space which would allow greater access to the platform surface. Underneath the moss covered floor seems to be beaten cement which continues under both recesses and covers most of the room. All walls are preserved to a second story height. On the northern wall are two hole approximately 5 feet (150 cm) from the ground on either end of the wall, which probably provided shelf support. Traces of red painted plaster covers all the wall on the northeast and southwest. beam holes appear high, four on the northeast, eight on the southwest. On the northeast wall above these holes is one much larger hole. On southeast wall there is a square window with a wooden lintel and plastered sill. There is no ceiling extant. A modern wooden lintel is over the doorway.

The cooking platform appears to be in relatively good condition. It runs along the northwest/southeast axis. This is a large cooking platform approximately six feet in length (180 cm), five feet deep (150 cm) and three feet high (90 cm). The surface of the cooking platform is covered in moss however terra cotta tiles form the surface beneath. The platform itself seems to be made of stones, brick and mortar, the front of which can be seen on the southwest face. There are two concreted arched recesses for wood storage. Plaster painted red is evident on both southwest and northwest faces. The platform abuts the northeast and southeast walls. There is evidence of a lip along the three sides which was made of lava stone covered with terra cotta roof tiles. Most of the northwest face is covered with painted red plaster.

column14: Space is southwest of the impluvium and in the atrium (2). Room 19 is to the northwest. Room 18 is to the southwest
column21: This house is domestic. This is a dining space opening from the atrium (ala). This ala, or wings, on the southwest mirrors an ala across the atrium on the northeast side. This space is in poor condition with reconstruction of the upper walls. This space is walled on three sides and still has a great deal of plaster and paint on the lower portions. The painting is either third or fourth style. The central zone preserves rectangular spaces and on the southwest walls one can see roundels which presumably would have contained portraits. This same wall also has two large restored holes which may have been for tunneling in. Up a molding remains in part on all three walls. Joist holes go across the entire length of the southwest wall. The floor is white mosaic with black bands around the periphery.

column14: This space is to the northeast of the atrium. Room 3 is to the northwest. Room 4 is to the south.
column21: This is an open space off of the atrium (2) which is to the southwest. The three walls enclosing this space are in poor condition with very little paint still visible above the dado which is red with stenciled decoration. The upper walls are reconstructed. the mosaic floor remains in about two thirds of the space. It is white with black bands around the periphery. No ceiling remains. On the northwest wall there is a doorway to room three.

column14: This room is to the northwest of peristyle area 10. It is southeast of room 7 and to the northeast to room 9.
column21: This is a dining room, one enters through door at the southeast side of the room. The room is almost square. It is in fair condition, although none of the finished floor is preserved. The door jams are crumbling. The walls are preserved to a very high level with full style painting decoration. A large square tableaux has been removed from the center of the northwest wall. Although conserved and patched, two tunnel holes are evident on the northwest wall. The southeast wall on the east side of the door has a tall vertical cut through its center. The northeast wall bulges out above the dado and the dado is slightly concave forming a long couch niche (3893). This room has been conserved with a roof and the upper walls are also restored. Large tableaux are painted on the northeast and southwest walls. The southwest one seems to depict a female holding a helmet, seated with another figure holding a shield. Two putti holding a greave. On the northwest wall there is also a seated female and a warrior holding a large shield. These frescoes maybe Achilles themes.

column14: This room is in the southeast section of the house. It is southwest of corridor 12 and northeast of room 18.
column21: This is a large dining room. It is positioned at the back of the house with alignment to the front entrance (2), gives a sense of great formality. This large space used for dining or meeting gave its occupants a view to the peristyle garden (10) and to the tablinium, atrium and entrance. The room is now in poor condition, no flooring is visible, no ceiling remains. The walls remain to great height in some sections but no paint can be seen on the plastered surfaces. In addition to the very wide opening in the center of the northwest wall a small door opens onto corridor (12) in the northern corner of the room along the northeast wall.

column14: Hallway 19 to the west and dining room 15 to the east.
column21: The kitchen runs along a northwest/southeast axis and we enter from the fauces to the street (door 22) on the southwest. We enter this room from the northwest through a low partition wall on the southwest. Immediately on the northwest wall as we enter is a lararium which is painted in full style and contains a small altar. Today the lararium is covered with a protective awning. This kitchen is unusual because it contains an enormous archway adjoining the northeast and southwest walls, rising to a second story height at its apex. The facing of the arch as we enter forms the southeast portion of the lararium with painting and is plastered on the street side. Abutting the partition wall on the west corner of the northwest wall is a cooking platform which runs about half the length of this partitioning wall and includes the bottom of the arch. It continues for approximately 6 feet (180 cm) more along the southwest wall. Next to this cooking platform further southeast appears to be an arched drain into the street. The remainder of the room contains rubble on the east corner with roofing tiles and different rocks piled high.On the southwest wall, high above the cooking platform, is a small light well to the street and another on the southeastern most portion of the wall at the same height. Under the latter are six large joist support holes. Other holes appear on this wall but could be from dislodged stones. The largest of these may have been for an oil lamp in the center of the southwest wall. There is no ceiling extant. Plaster is evident on all walls but there is no evidence of paint.

column14: Contiguous with feature 3887 (lararium) to northeast.
column21: This long cooking platform runs approximately 8 feet (240 cm) along the southwest wall on a northwest/southeast axis. The northwest portion abuts the partition which delineates the room from the street entrance (22). The platform is made of lava rock and mortar. It appears to have been plastered in antiquity as evidenced on the lower north face. This platform is low although the height could be raised with lapilli and/or the surface could be missing a layer or two. On the east end of the northeast face is a poorly preserved arched recess. The unusual feature of this platform is its inclusion of the base of an arch which is build into the wall and covered with original plaster. Therefore a small section of the southwestern abutment incorporates the jutting arch. This platform is poorly preserved.

column14: Contiguous to feature 3886 (cooking platform) to the southwest.
column21: The lararium takes up  a portion of the northeast wall, and the southeast face of the archway which is incorporated into the room. there is a small alter which is in situ and joins both walls in the eastern corner. There is painting in the whole lararium and alter, which appears to be fourth style surrounded by a red border and containing approximately 5 lares and a faint water plant painting. A garland is visible at the top of the northeast painting. Plaster garlands which are in poor shape are on the northwest and southwest faces of the alter. Plaster molding surrounds the bottom of the alter. Today a tile has been inserted into the wall in an effort to protect the lararium. Situated directly above are two raised lips along the top of the alter.

column14: To the northeast of corridor 12 and northwest of room 14.
column21: This is a small rectangular storage room. It is on northwest/southeast axis. One enters from the corridor (12) through a doorway on the southwest wall. This room is in very poor condition. No floors are visible. No ceiling remains. The walls are rumbling and no plaster remains. A pile of rocks from crumbling wall is in the northern corner.

column14: This room is in the eastern most corner of the house. Room 13 is to the northwest. Room 15 is to the southwest and corridor 12 is to the northwest of the doorway.
column21: This is a small rectangular storage room, in the eastern corner of the house. This is on a northeast/southwest axis. One enters from the western corner through a door on the northwest wall. The room is in poor condition. No floor is visible. The ceiling does not remain however 7 joist holes remain along the top of the southeast wall. There is rough rough plaster on all the walls. No painted surface exists. All walls are of greying colour.

column14: Room 2 (atrium) to the east.
column21: This room runs along a northwest/southeast axis and is open to the atrium. Only three partial walls exist. The southwest wall is preserved or reconstructed to a second storey height and contains 6 beam holes. This wall is constructed with alternating sections of opus signinum and brick work. On the northwest wall we find some plaster which appears to have been decorated in antiquity. It is unremarkable now. The floor is obscured with lapili. The is no ceiling extant. There are 3 levels of brickwork on the southwest wall. One level at 3 and a half feet (105 cm), a second at 7 and a half feet (210 cm) and the third level much higher above. The first levels of brickwork extend to the southeast wall.

column14: Thisr oom is to the northwest of room 11. The door opens to the atrium (2). Space 8, the tablinium lies to the southwest.
column21: This is a medium size dining room, almost square. One enters via a doorway through the western corner of the northwest wall where there is a stone threshold flanked by two pieces of white marble. Door post cuttings can be seen on all piece of the threshold. The room is in poor condition. The floor can be seen in some areas and is cocciopesto with lines of white tesserae. Plaster is preserved on all four walls, however very little painting remains. No ceiling remains. While one would have a view through the door to the atrium, there are no other doors or views.

column14: Room 2 (atrium) to the west.
column21: We enter room 5 from the atrium which is to the southwest through an open space with a large modern lintel. There are 3 walls ( northwest, northeast, southeast). Each have remnants of plaster and some sort of border which is indiscernible today. High on the southeast wall is a window type opening to room 6. The floor is obscured with lapili and there is no ceiling extant. There appears to be a possible niche along the southeast wall.

column14: This niche is the entire length of the northeast wall of this room.
column21: This feature is a couch niche which extends the full length of the northeast wall of the dining room. It is approximately the same height as the dado. It is three black panels. The wall above is somewhat irregular in its present condition. The niche is about 6 inches ( 15 cm) deep.

column14: Directly across from another cooking platform 6367 in the room.  To the northwest of latrine 6368.
column21: Feature 6366 is a large cooking platform attached to north wall.  it is rectangular in shape with an arched recessed area underneath.  Tile remains on top surface of cooking platform.

column14: Opposite cooking platform 6366.  It is on the south wall to the west of latrine 6368.
column21: feature 6367 is a very large cooking platform with the remaining of flat top surface.  Facing platform to the left is a raised edge.  The remainder of a raised rim.  Below platform is a large arched recessed area.

column14: On the east wall at opposite end of the doorway that goes to the street.  East of cooking platform 6367 and southeast of cooking platform 6366.
column21: Latrine 6368 is on south wall in the eastern corner.  Latrine appears to be in close relationship to cooking platform and what may be an arched recess to a sewer (?)

column14: This room opens completely west to a portico facing a planted area, small garden, with a planting wall surrounding it #34.
column21: Dining room.  The west side is completely open to planted peristyle 34.  No ceiling.  Floor is damaged, with traces of conglomerate floor with pattern of white tesserae.  North wall is badly damaged with traces of plaster with red and yellow paint.  The east wall, rear wall, is badly damaged, with fragments of plaster.  The south wall has no plaster remaining, is badly damaged.  On the floor facing the dining room on the far right is the possible opening of round shaped stone on the floor with circular opening nearby, evidence of underground cavity.

column14: Direct view onto atrium 25.
column21: Room entered from atrium 25.  Room is on northeast side of  atrium looking toward atrium to the southwest.  Entrance is impressive two step marble threshold with evidence of door jambs on each step.  No evidence of ceiling or room.  Floor is rubble and dirt.  North wall of room is badly damaged.  Traces of plaster with a yellow white pigment with molding and a recessed area running half of the also with traces of plater and painting with possible platform.  Facing the wall to the right is evidence of deeper recess, maybe a cupboard niche with traces of plaster and paint.  See feature 6371.  Rear wall on the east side is badly damaged.  Wall on south side is badly damaged with traces of plaster with wall paint of red and yellow, possibly three registers.  Wall to the west, the right side of doorway entrance is badly damaged.

column14: In northeast corner of room in north wall.
column21: On the far northeast corner of the room.  A recessed area cupboard niche with evidence of a shelf.  Damaged but with plaster and traces of yellow and red paint.

column14: E is to the west and B is to the south.
column21: A rectangular room  with an east west axis, arched ceiling.  The floor  is obscured throughout by earth and debris.  The doorway in the west wall has a modern lintel.  the doorway at the west end of the south wall has a has a modern lintel.  The thresholds of both doors are obscured .  Situated on the west wall is an opening, a collapse at the top of the roof?  High in the east wall at the junction with the ceiling is an opening to the street level.  This area is weak and close to collapse.  In the center of the east wall there is a low plastered partition wall extending into the center of the room.  Cooking platform 6373 is in the northwest corner.  Lararium 6376 is in the northeast corner.  There are remnants of plaster on the south wall with no visible decorations.  Any sign of a latrine is obscured by debris.

column14: Lararium 6374 is to  the northeast.
column21: A long rectangular cooking platform, masonry, with no visible storage, extends along the north wall from the west wall.  The western half of the top is obscured by earth and debris.  The eastern half has collapsed, revealing fragments of a plastered or tile lip and surface.  The eastern face is plastered, with no visible decoration.

column14: Platform 6373 to the west.
column21: Square masonry altar with a plastered face.  There is a plastered lip surface above, abutting the north wall of the room  Above the altar on the wall is a poorly preserved lararium painting on a white background.  From the west there is a partially preserved painting of a lare with cornucopia and with a yellow tunic.  Legs of a smaller figure, a camillus; the arm, head and shoulders of a figure in a toga performing a sacrifice on an altar with indeterminate painted figures.  The face and arms of a lare facing the scene, with a cornucopia forming a pair with the lare to the west.  Above the scene are green garlands hanging above.

column14: Contiguous entrance to storeroom H is on the west wall to the side.
column21: Floor is rubble and dirt.  Vaulted ceiling.  All walls are damaged, reconstructed, with traces of white plaster.  Entrance is on the south.

column14: Entrance from store room G on south.
column21: Enter from corridor with entrance on east wall.  Enter from store room G on south wall.  Floor is rubble and dirt.  Vaulted ceiling.  All walls, north, south, east and west are damaged, with traces of white plaster.  Considerable debris present at south wall entrance.

Entered from underground corridor.   Entrance is on the east wall.  A second door leads to another subterranean storage area (H) with a door on the  north wall.  This is a subterranean storage area with a pounded dirt floor, arched ceiling.  The wall to the east is damaged badly, maybe some plaster.  There is a large rectangular hole in the wall near the door and near corner with south wall.  South wall is badly damaged, with a small rectangular opening at top center of vaulted ceiling and a round small hole at west side.  Also a small opening exists in the ceiling.  West wall is badly damaged.  Trace of plaster.  North wall has door into room H.  Badly damaged, reconstructed, with a small rectangular hole at top.

column14: Hallway (7) to the west
column21: We enter this kitchen from Hallway 7. There is no discernible threshold and a very low entrance. There is a northwest/southeast axis for a long rectangular space. On the northeast wall we see a low cooking platform (3853). On the northwest wall we see a low lararium, deep niche with some orange paint remaining. On the northeast wall above the platform we see three large square post holes and a partly filled in lararium. No post holes are visible on the opposite wall. Further on the northeast wall to the southeast we see two large round post holes (?). On the center of the northeast wall you see a large patch of red painted plaster and the remains of a partition wall placed in front of the plaster. The southeast wall shows red plaster. The west wall has remains of a stair and the landing above. It was plastered but no color remains.

column14: lararium (3855) to northwest
column21: The cooking platform (3853) is a low rectangular one. The top was leveled. No front lip is present. On the northeast corner there is a large stone abutting the edge as build in protection. Above the rectangular platform are three large post holes ( perhaps for a protective awning ). Above the northeast corner is a partly filled lararium which may be used as a lamp niche. There are two storage areas under the platform. The north corner is square and the northeast storage is oval. On the northwest wall is another feature - a deep lararium niche.

column14: Corridor 7 to the northwestDining room 9 to northeast
column21: From the northwest we enter this large dining room over a lava stone threshold. The room is somewhat irregular in shape due to the fact that the doorway entrance on the north extends into the room approximately three and a half feet (105 cms) and is formed from a brick column face with painted plaster. The corresponding door jam is a brick column which abuts the southwest wall between corridor 7 and only protrudes into the room approximately 6 inches ( 15 cms). It is faced with painted plaster. The axis of the room, which is mostly rectangular, is northeast/southwest. The large doorway divides the vista onto the peristyle garden to the northwest. Alternating red and yellow panels are divided by architectural white and stenciled outlines transcoursing all three registers with the bottom and top being a continuous white panel. Evidence of a water plant exists on the south portion of the northwest wall indicating 4th style. High in the center of the southeast wall is a circular window which is plastered. Above the window is an intricate molding of plants and shells. A remnant is seen on the southwest wall. Four open joist holes appear high on the southwest wall above the molding area. There is a 5th but covered joist hole. The walls are preserved beyond a first story height with the northeast wall being the exception. The floor is obscured with vegetation and lapilli. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: Cooking platform (3853) to southeast
column21: This lararium is on the low zone of the wall. The floor is shaped - a roof tile is serving as the floor of the lararium. The curved edges face upright. The lararium is plastered with signs of coral paint.

column14: Atrium (2) to the southwestRoom 4 to the northwestRoom 6 to the southeast
column21: The store room is a small rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis. We enter the store room from an opened doorway in the southwest. The three walls on the northwest, northeast and southeast each contain plaster with evidence of yellow and red painting. There are 6 support holes  (3 each) to support two shelves on the northeast wall. The lowest row is approximately four feet (120 cm) above the ground. The higher is approximately two and a half to three feet ( 75 to 90 cm) above the lower. On the northwest wall are two holes at the same height as the upper shelf holes, while there is only one on the southeast wall. The walls are preserved to a second story height. There is no roof extant. The floor is obscured with lapilli and debris. The doorway of the northwest wall appears to be a plastered column which juts out into the room for about three inches ( 8 cm).

column14: The room is to the southwest of area 7 and to the southeast of the garden area
column21: This is a small cubiculum. It is orientated on a southwest/northeast axis and is rectangular in plan. There is a door on the northwest wall through which one enters from the peristyle ( area 7). There is a window on the southeast wall towards the eastern half of the wall. The window is presently shuttered and the doorway has a locked, barred door. From the doorway we can see the southeast, southwest and northwest walls depict exotic scenes with pygmies thus giving the house its name. The northwest wall painting (3858) is a nilotic scene with pygmies and a crocodile surrounded by wildlife scenes, architecture with towers and pygmies carrying baskets of food. These are second style paintings. Above the paintings the southeast and northwest walls preserve their upper molding. No molding remains on the southwest wall which was arched for a vaulted ceiling. The room is in fair condition, the flooring is not visible, the original ceiling is not extant however is covered with a modern roof.
column27: locked - measurements approximate as measured outside walls

column14: These features are on the northwestern wall to the northwest of room 36 to the west from the doorway to this room.
column21: This is a second style wall painting. A section of the painting shows a walled structure with towers at the corners. To the bottom of this section there is a pygmy carrying two vessels on a stick over his shoulders, these may contain food or water. This is in the center of the northwest wall. The lower right side of the same wall has a little pygmy holding sticks and is about to become crocodile food.

column14: Room 33 to the southwest and hallway 7 to the northwest.
column21: We enter this dining room from the northwest over a lava stone threshold. There is a modern wooden lintel. The door is not extremely high but not too low. On the northeast portion of the doorway there is thick white plaster. On all walls we find evidence over lower register with golden yellow stenciling and a white upper register which had stencil work. High on the southeast and northwest walls there is patterned plaster and traces of red paint are faint on each fanlike flower. On the north corner of the northwest/southeast walls is an approximately two foot (60 cm) wide indentation which is where the original northeast wall stood. However there is now a southeast facing which juts out into the room about two foot (60 cm) forming the new face for a northeast wall. In other words, there is a small alcove in this corner. High in the center of the southeast wall is a small rectangular window which still contains plaster. High on the northwest wall above the doorway is a beam hole. The painting of a water plant low on the western side of the northwest wall indicates that the room was probably in the fourth style. The floor is covered with lapilli. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: Southwest of area 7 surrounding the peristyle.Southwest of room 5 and northwest of room 8 (the kitchen).
column21: This is a dining room or a possible tablinum. It is a rectangular room on a northwest/southeast axis. There is a door on the southwest wall in the western corner. One enters the room from area 7 which surrounds the peristyle. There is a window on the southwest wall towards the middle of the room. This could be considered another doorway. This room is in very poor condition. The rubble walls have been heavily reconstructed. Plaster is preserved in parts of each of the four walls, however no paint survives. The floor is not visible and the ceiling no longer survives.

column14: Rooms 40 and 39 to the east.Rooms 37 and 36 to the west.Room 32 to the south.
column21: Square room, wide open doorway center of south wall with marble step threshold and placings for a door.  In the east and west corner of the south wall are small doorways with same step threshold and placings for doors.  Opening south to peristyle 32.  At the south end of the east wall there is a doorway with marble threshold, with placings for door and modern lintel.  At the north end of the east wall is a doorway to bedroom 39 with marble threshold, placing for doors and modern lintel.  At the southern end of west wall a doorway with marble threshold, placing for doors and modern lintel.  At the north end of the west wall, doorway to room 37, marble threshold, placing for door and modern lintel.  White mosaic floor survives throughout with black border with black border with a marble central diamond-patterned rosette.  Extending along the north, west and east walls are ten Corinthian columns constructed of brick and plaster contiguous with the columns and extending along the southern face of the room to form a border for the entire room is a mosaic pattern in white, yellow, red, green and black tesserae in a 3-D geometric pattern.  Extensive plaster decoration survives on the north, east and west walls, with second, third style decoration of architectural elements and theatrical mask.  Ceiling reconstructed.

column14: Room 34 is to the east.Peristyle 32 is to the south.
column21: Rectangular room, north-south axis, opening south to peristyle (32).  Southern doorway has marble threshold and placing for doors. At the south end  of east wall there is a doorway with step threshold and modern lintel.  Mosaic floor survives throughout, separated into two halves by border of geometric swastika in black and white tesserae.  The southern half consists of opus signinum with pattern of flowers in black and white tesserae and white border.  The northern half of the room is opus signinum with flowers in black and white tesserae, black border.  In the center forming a rosette around which the couches were arranged is a square pattern of alternating black and white tesserae enclosed by borders of white and black.  Extensive plaster survives on north, east and west walls, decorated in first style with alternating yellow, white and red panels.  At the top of the walls in the north half of  the room  there are traces of plaster molded cornices and on the north wall plaster molded vaulted ceiling.  The ceiling is modern restoration.   At the north end of the east wall there is a rectangular window, modern lintel, looking  into bedroom 35.  This may be modern?

column14: The entrance from portico 32 south.  A side entrance from room 33 east.  Room 35 to the north.
column21: Entrance from large peristyle (32) and the room is located on the northwest side of the peristyle.  Large entrance opening.  Standing in the room one looks out on the peristyle garden.  It is a very large room.  Threshold is marble with one short step.  The room is roofed with a reconstructed ceiling.  The exterior of the entrance is plastered with traces of yellow paint.  The  upper walls are reconstructed.  The floor has a geometric patterned mosaic in polychrome.  Fragments of mosaic floor remain.  Southwest wall has traces of plaster and painted in third style, very faint, with three registers in yellow and red and possibly white.  Facing the wall, there is an entrance of the left side to room 33 to the southwest.  There are three post holes above the doorway entrance and two post holes directly above two of them.  Northwest wall has an entrance on far left to a cubiculum.  There is plaster and traces of painting with three registers of red, yellow and white paint.  The southeast wall is damaged and reconstructed, with plaster and painting with very faint traces of yellow, red, and white paint in three registers that are possibly  third style.  Facing that wall in lower right corner attached to southeast wall and entrance wall is a low rim, perhaps a water feature.  Above, near the ceiling, is trace of molding.  Southeast wall reconstructed with yellow and red plaster.  There is a small cubicula that is entered from the northwest corner by an opening from this room.  Above lintell centered at entrance way is a hole.

column14: Entrance is off corridor 30 to the east.Southwest doorway opens to room 27.
column21: Room is entered from hallway 30 on the northeast wall of kitchen.  There is another entrance on the southeast wall from room 27.  There is no roof and the floor is obscured by lapilli.  There are seven features identified in this room  The entrance on northeast  wall, viewed from the interior is damaged and reconstructed with some faint traces of reddish color in plaster.  At the stone threshold there is one step down from corridor 30 with evidence of a door jamb.  Facing the southeast wall to the lower right side is feature 6405, a preparation platform.  Above the doorway and preparation platform and to the right of the doorway is a round hole.  In the northeast corner of the room is a cooking platform (6401).  There is a lararium (6403) on the southeast wall to the left of the doorway.  Facing the southwest wall we see damage and reconstruction with a trace of plaster and faint red paint.  Facing the wall to the lower right on the floor is evidence of a latrine (6404) (with a stone projection that may have held a shelf), with drainage on the floor under the wall to the right.  Facing the wall about in the middle is an arched recessed niche, high up.  It is connected to a pipe opening, allowing running water to reach the floor level water feature (6406).  The recessed niche is above feature 6405 called a preparation platform.  The pipe-like opening has one side and is open on the other side.  It is a long narrow recessed space.  The northwest wall is damaged and reconstructed, with no trace of plaster.  Facing the wall, there is a long, large cooking platform with a restored tile surface.  Facing the wall to the left there is construction with possible evidence of a latrine.  Facing the wall to the right is a recessed area from floor to ceiling that possibly held a furnace for the baths.  There are seven features in the room.  There is apparent water from possible pipe through niche into basin below.

column14: To the  north of 6405, 6406, 6404, 6402.  6403 is on southeast wall above.
column21: On northeast wall, facing the entrance to the left to corridor 30, there is a cooking platform.  Brick and stone with traces of plaster on both sides.  It abuts northeast and southeast walls in the corner.  No traces of tile surface, concrete only.

column14: 6401, 6403 to the east.6404, 6422 to the south.6405 to the southeast.
column21: A very large cooking platform exists on northwest wall with a tile surface.  Reconstructed, at least in part.  Facing the platform there is no evidence of a rim.  Facing the wall to the left is latrine 6404.

column14: Next to and above the cooking platform 6401.  6405, 6406, 6422 to south.  6402, 6404 to the southeast.
column21: On southeast wall there  is a lararium in the kitchen next to the cooking platform, according to Boyce page 51.  The lararium on the back wall was painted with a portrait of the genius.  The niche is rectangular.  According to Boyce, there is a small masonry alter.  Today there is no altar and the painting cannot be seen or identified.  There are traces of plaster and very faint traces of yellow and red.

column14: Water feature 6406 and preparation platform 6405 to southeast.Cooking platform 6402 to northwest.  6401 and 6403 to the north.
column21: Facing the southwest wall to the right is a latrine.  Few remains. Masonry projection which may have held a seat.  Plaster on lower level and ground slopes downward to a drain below the wall.  It is adjacent to the water feature and cooking platform on northwest wall.

column14: Water feature 6406 and 6422 and 6404 to the northwest.  6401 and 6403 to the east.  6402 to the west.
column21: In the southwest corner of the room a raised preparation platform is of masonry and stone surfaces, somewhat obscured.  it is in the corner along two walls, with curved wall out into kitchen and next to doorway from room 27 and next to water feature 6406.

column14: Preparation platform 6405 to the east.  Water feature 6422 above.  Cooking platform 6401 and lararium 6403 to the north.  Cooking platform 6402 and latrine 6404 to the west.
column21: On the floor on the southwest wall is a round opening in a square stone, raised shape, very low platform that perhaps goes to cistern or is deep basin for water.  It is adjacent to a preparation platform and directly below niche that connects to a water pipe.

column14: Rooms 43 and 30 to the south.  Room 47 to the northwest.  Room 49 to the north.
column21: L-shaped room  with north-south axis,  facing oven 6417 to the north.  In the southeast corner is a doorway with a stone threshold to a corridor (30) with placings for a door.  In the center of the south wall is a doorway to stairs with modern lintel and a doorway with modern lintel to bath room 43.  The west wall preserves signs of extensive restoration.  The northwest corner encloses processing room 47, accessed through a doorway in the northwest corner with no visible threshold and modern lintel.  South of the doorway is a small square window with modern lintel opening to processing room 47.  Immediately southeast of the oven is water basin 6416.  Along the east wall, extending north of the oven is a corridor (51).  Along the east wall are four kneading basins 6412-6415.  The floor of the northern half of the room is covered by lapilli.  The floor of the southern half of the room is basalt paving slabs enclosing mills 6408-6410.   In the southeastern corner a gap in the basalt paving reveals the presence of a fourth, no longer extant, mill.  Undecorated plaster survives on the south, north and east walls.  In the southeast corner is lararium painting 6411 and adjoining platform 6423 and water basin 6421.  At the south end of the west wall, a wide block doorway basalt threshold.  Against the base of the wall are two marble fragments and a section of  a tufa column shaft.
Circular masonry support with poorly preserved surface and modern cement.  Basalt meta in situ on the base.

column14: 6412, 6413, 6414, 6415, 6416 and 6417 are to the north.6411, 6421 are to the south.6405 is to the west.
column21: Circular masonry base for mill.  Plastered exterior survives in places.  Modern restoration.  Basalt catillus and meta survives in situ on the base.

Circular masonry support for  a mill, poorly preserved surface4.  Moedern cement on exterior face.  Neither the catillus nor the meta survive, although a fragment of a basalt catillus lies on the base.

Lararium  painting.  A white background with garlands above.  From the south there is an unidentifiable figure.  A lare facing north with his rhyton in his left hand.  The other lare is not extent.  A child standing next to a female figure with a staff.  The lower half of the  painting is completely destroyed.  Above preparation platform 6423 and water basin 6421.

column14: 6413, 6414, 6415,6416 and 6417 to the north.6409, 6408, 6411 and 6421 are all to the south.
column21: Wide shallow terracotta kneading basin with iron ties indicating repair in antiquity.  Contiguous with 6413 to the north.  The basin is embedded into a masonry plaster support.

A wide terracotta shallow kneading basin with iron ties indicating repair in antiquity.  The basin is embedded into a masonry plaster support.  It is contiguous with terracotta basin 6412 to the south and abuts 6414 to the north.
Shallow plastered kneading basin on top of plastered masonry.  Support contiguous to kneading basin 6415 to the north.  The terracotta kneading basin 6413 abuts directly to the south.

column14: Corridor (11), and a dining room (8), overlooking a garden (7), situated on the East wall.
column21: We enter kitchen 9, at the rear of the house. We have a narrow low doorway to the kitchen. The floor is lapilli. There is one tiny patch of plaster in this L shaped kitchen. The ceiling posts are low, under 2 meters, in the long arm of the L and they are found on both long walls. The short arm of the L or the base of the L with the cooking platform seems to be unroofed. There is a good sized cooking platform in the Southwest with an arch for firewood or charcoal or pots and pans. There is some evidence for a latrine in the Southwest corner of the short arm of the L, at the end of the cooking platform.

column14: Not applicable
column21: The cooking platform has no hint of a front lip but evidence of a side lip is present. The archway below is partially filled with lapilli and could have served as storage.

column14: Corridor (11) is to the South; peristyle (7) is to the East
column21: This small rectangular room lies along a Northwest, Southeast axis. It is in complete disrepair. We enter from the Southern corridor (11) through a low doorway. To the Southeast in the corner, abutting the East and South walls, is a low piece of masonry. It appears that this room had been remodeled in antiquity due to the filling of a large space which was then surfaced with plaster and painted red and white with panels which were completed before the masonry was placed in the corner. There are traces of another column; celadon, and yellow remain within the filled space reaching to the peristyle centered in the East wall. There, is a small window whose bottom lip is broken. The walls are preserved to a first storey height and no ceiling is extant. The floor is obscured with lapilli and vegetation.  There is a hole on the North wall for an unknown purpose and this wall seems to have been plastered. 3 or 4 times in antiquity. he is about 1.5 meters above the floor.

column14: This room is contiguous to Room 2. The atrium is situated to the West
column21: This is a dining room. It is a rectangular space with a North/South axis. the entrance is on the West side, near the Northwest corner. This is a tall doorway with a basalt threshold and asphalt construction. a round cutting is on each end, for the door frame.All 4 walls retain plaster and fresco. The condition of the fresco is very poor. Only traces of red paint can be seen in the mid-sections of the wall.The N and S walls preserve thin arched mouldings with beam holes above (2 on the North wall and 6 located on the South wall), suggesting the room was vaulted. The walls are all opus incertum. The floors are cocciopesto. There is a window opening to the atrium in the West wall.

One enters the dining room over a threshold constructed of volcanic rocks. The room is basically squre and is located around a NE/SW axis. Evidence of 4th style painting is apparent on all walls. Yellow, red, white and green colors survive. The panels are delineated with stenciling and 3-D views on the NW and SE walls and below the large window on the N.E. wall which looks into the garden (  ). In the East corner, the wall juts out slightly and receeds back into the S.E. wall at a smoothed right angle which looks like a faux column which has been decorated. The lower register of the walls was painted white with red borders and framing of sorts of various flowers. the Afore-mentioned middle panels contain both architectural and stenciled segments and vague facial cameos can be discerned with 5 circular outlines that are visible, and perhaps a 6th, at a 1.5m level on the 4 walls. the upper register of the walls were decorated in antiquity with both a lower plaster cornice and an upper highly decorative moulding. The portion between the 2 moulding sections were painted with red borders and evidence on the N.W. wall indicates a blue stripe as well. The ceiling was painted in antiquity as is evidenced with extant red paint in the S.W. corner. Above the upper cornice on the S.E. wall are 6 holes for support while only 2 can be seen on the N.W. wall. The ceiling has been restored above the ancient level. The floor appears to have been cement and contained chips of white marble and red rock. In the East corner, today, remains a portion of a column base or capital.The lower register on the West and South of the S.W. wall may have been black in color.
column74: Image type is 66 by Ann Pernchief

column14: The room is contiguous to Room 5, to the N.W.. The room is contiguous to room 2, situated to the S.W..
column21: The scavi sign reads: Taberna C. Catius Scithus. However, inside it appears to be a dining place. You can enter from the road via a privacy entrance situated at the South end of a Southeast wall. The floor is made up of lapilli and pounded dirt. There is no ceiling. The Southwest wall is made of stone and cement, with a portion of plaster. The South corner shows a tiny vertical slice of red paint. (In the high zone, there is a recess for a light source) There are 3 walls in the Northwest. The Western segment appears to be a prep and fish pond rooms. the middle wall contains a lararium. A close look at the interior back wall of the lararium, seems to indicate a graphite sketch. There is red paint, in evidence, on the back wall. Situated beneath, is a rectangular altar. A door to the North opens to a storeroom. The final third of the Northwest wall encloses the storeroom.  The Northeast wall shows the 3 plaster layers of evidence. The bottom layer is grayish white in color. A 2nd thin layer is a red Pompei color. The top layer is a beige/light coral color. 3 beam holes are approximately 8 feet off the ground, and indicates some kind of covering. The S.W.  shows no comparable beam holes.

column14: #3760 is to the south (directly underneath 3759).
column21: On the northeast wall, the semicircular lararium shows at least two plaster layers.  the only indication of art work is at rear top.  One phallus centrally positioned, tip of phallus on top layer.  It is about halfway up the wall.

column14: Room 1 is to the southeast.Corridor (room 2) is to the southwest.
column21: This is a storage room.  There is a single entrance at the western end of the southeast wall.  This room is square, on a northwest/southeast axis.  It is in poor condition.  The floor is not visible.  There is no ceiling extant.  The walls are preserved to between eight-twelve feet in height.  The southwest wall has a low window at the south end.  North of this window are two cupboards (3753 and 3752).  The walls have some remaining plaster, particularly on the lower five feet of the wall.  There is a horizontal etched line dividing the plaster from the wall above.  On the northwest wall at about ten feet high is a horizontal groove shallowly out in the stone.

column14: #3753 is to the north.
column21: In the southwest wall there is a cupboard located in the middle of the wall.  This is a cupboard about 10 to 12 inches in depth.  It retains most of its plaster covering.  The etched seam continues through these cupboards.  Two small cut holes are at the base of  the back wall and appear to be deliberate.  Small bracket holes are aligned toward the front of the cupboard on both sides, suggesting shelf supports.  The back wall  preserves a series of small holes.  The northern most one still containing the metal fitting.  One horizontal line of these holes is about halfway up the cupboard and a second group of lines up approximately a foot above these.  This is in poor condition with restoration at the top.

In the southwest wall there is a cupboard located in the north corner.  The cupboard is about 10 to 12 inches deep.  Some plaster still remains within the cupboard.  Two bracket holes remain with a bit of metal in the lower one.  This in in poor condition with restoration at the top.

column14: The room is northwest of corridor 2.  This room lies to the southeast of room 4.
column21: This room is a narrow corridor aligned northwest-southeast along the southwest side of the house.  There is an entrance at the southeast end, as well as a passage to the next room (4) at the northwest.  A large stone vat (3755) is located along the southwest wall occupying the northern portion of the room.  This room is in  poor condition.  The walls are only preserved to about nine feet in height.  Very little plaster remains over the  rough cut stone and mortar.  No finished flooring is visible, no roofing remains.  The vat suggests that this area held life fish or was used for processing related to the activity in room 4.

column14: Room 4 is to the northwest.  Room 2 is to the southeast.
column21: This is a vat.  It is about 6 ft long by 3 ft wide and is preserved to about 18 inches in height.  There is some smooth plaster.  Preserved on the southwest wall of the vat that which may be hydrolic plaster.  the bottom surface of this is not visible and the walls are rough cut stone and mortar.  This is in poor condition.  This vat may have been a fish tank.

column14: This room is northwest of room 3754.
column21: Room 4 is a processing room which is on a northwest-southeast axis, northwest of the structure's entrance.  The room is irregular in shape due to features which complicate the space.  An interesting room a vat feature 3759 fills the entire width of the back (northwest) wall and protrudes into the room in approximately one-third of the space.  On the southwestern wall a preparation platform delineates the remaining portion of the room and is about 3 feet high.  On the southeastern side of the vat on the south corner between the preparation platform and an indentation for enabling feet to get closer to the vat, lies a structure which probably held a dolium.  The height of the room is indeterminate; however, all walls except the wall between the cooking platform and the vat in room 3 are preserved to an almost second story height.  The floors are obscured with lapilli and devbris and no ceiling is extant.

column14: Contiguous to dolium holder 3758 and to vat 3759 in room 4.
column21: This preparation platform extends along the southwest wall of room 4 and abuts the wall which provides the boundary for vat 3759.  It is approximately 3 feet high at its highest point and 3 feet deep.  However, the depth at the western end decreases to approximately 2 feet as it is interrupted by the space for feature 3758.  The structure is made of a mixture of stone, mostly volcanic and terra cotta on the surface.  The surface is missing on the western half.  On the surface of the prep platform is a nearly crescent shaped rock structure extending from the back wall to the middle of the preparation surface.  An indentation which mirrors the structure abuts the southeast wall, which delineates the space between rooms 3 and 4 and rises to approximately 6 feet from the floor.

column14: Contiguous to vat 3759 and to platform 3757.
column21: This feature appears to have been a support to hold a dolium or basin.  It is low and abuts feature 3759 (the vat) and 3757 (preparation platform).  Although it is broken off it appears to have been one height in antiquity and was lined with cement, which was painted red.  it intrudes into the space of the platform which is next to 3759.

column14: Contiguous to dolium holder 3758 and other preparation platform 3757.
column21: This vat extends the width of room 4 along the northwest wall.  it is deeper than the floor level of room 4.  There is waterproofed cement painted red which extends approximately 3 feet in height on the back wall and on the southwest and southeast walls.  It is preserved to a lower height and is irregular.  On the northeast wall there is no evidence of paint, only cement, with a hole in the middle.  The southeast wall is made of rubble and mortar and the finished opening is no longer extant.  One patch of red waterproofed cement exists on the face of the protruding wall off the southwest wall and the height is consistent with the delineation  of red inside the vat.  It should be noted that with the proximity to the adjacent structures and with commentary from Eschebach that this may have been a latrine before it was repurposed.  An indentation for a large pipe runs from the ground to the top of the surviving southwest wall.  The floor of the vat is obscured with lapilli and debris.  Walls are preserved to a high but indeterminate height.  No covering exists above.  On the exterior portion of the vat on the eastern region is a terra cotta tile which provides an indentation for feet.

column14: Lararium 3759 above on northwest wall.
column21: A square altar, small, is directly below lararium.  The altar was faced with fired beige/light coral plaster, which appears in several places on the room's walls.

column14: Kitchen 4 to the northeast and atrium 3 to the northwest.
column21: This dining garden lies at the southeast of the entrance.  It is in very poor condition as it is filled with ash, debris and vegetation.  There is no doorway today; however, on the north corner on the raised entrance is a piece of white marble with an indentation which indicates some sort of closure.  A short brick northwest wall exists in the western corner.  Southwest and southeast walls exist; however, the room is otherwise completely open.  In antiquity there was probably a small wall on the northeast which separated the garden from kitchen.

column14: The southeast wall is contiguous to house 5.  The southwest wall is contiguous to the dining garden (room 5).
column21: This area of the house was the kitchen.  It is the eastern back corner of the house, extending along the southeast wall.  This narrow rectangular space is along a southeast/northwest axis.  The only remaining walls are the southeast and northeast walls.  There is a step down to room 3 (the atrium) and the opening to the dining garden (room 5) reveals no walls at present.  The condition is poor.  The remaining walls have no plaster.  Cement flooring is visible in front of the niche-shelf (3826) along the northeast wall.  The southeast wall is heavily reconstructed at the upper portion, with a roof tile serving as a drain pipe from an opening that drops into the south corner of the room.  There is no ceiling visible.

column14: It is along the northeast wall of the house.  Latrine (3825) is to the south.
column21: This is a niche-shelf.  It is a recessed area about 1 foot deep and about 4 feet wide.  The height can not be determined since the wall has not been preserved to its full extent.  There are traces of plaster on the southeast side of the niche.  Otherwise it is just rubble and ashlar masonry of the wall.  No evidence of shelf holes or brackets remains.  At the upper level of the northeast wall two cross section pieces of column drum are reused in this all.

column14: Contiguous to the atrium (4) and to the entrance hallway (1).
column21: We enter this dining room from the atrium.  There is a stone basalt threshold.  This is a rectangular room with a north/south axis.  The floor is pounded mud.  Today we see pounded mud and lapilli.  There are a few sections that show cement.  On the east wall, a section is covered with plaster.  The north wall has on the high zone signs of a window and beneath this window there seems to have once been a pipe (?).  There are also traces of a red border.  On the west wall we see one/third plaster.  There are faint indications of a red border on one part of the wall and yellow rectangle.  On the south wall we see plaster that is undecorated.  The plastered remnants on three walls are held in place by modern metal butterfly hooks.  We see no sign of a roof.

column14: This room is to the northwest of space 9 (courtyard).  It is northeast of the entranceway (1) fauces and to space 11.
column21: This space is a kitchen.  It is an L-shaped room.  All generally on a northwest/southeast alignment.  One enters this space through a doorway from the central courtyard (4), and enters the southeast section of the room towards the southern corner of the room.  Looking into this space from the doorway one sees the L-shaped area to the right extending toward the northern corner of the house.  From the doorway looking toward the right one sees three large blocks in situ which probably formed a cooking platform (3822).  This room is in poor condition.  The northwest wall preserves painted plaster (yellow) which extends across the northern corner slightly on to the northeast wall.  This plaster is mostly at the bottom 4 feet of the wall.  However, another patch of plaster is located about 6 to 9 feet above this and reveals a clear horizontal ridge.  The partition wall to room 11 is preserved between 3 and 4 feet in height.  The other interior walls are from 3 to 7 feet.  A high window in the center of the northwest wall may have provided light to the space.  No floors are visible.  No ceiling exists.  Although there is one joist hole in the northern corner of the northwest wall.

column14: These three blocks are in the northeast third of the southeast rectangular section of the L-shaped room.
column21: This feature appears to be a three part base to a working/cooking platform.  The three large blocks line up along the northeastern side  of the space.  The eastern most block is aligned with the walls of the room; however, the other two blocks are turned at a slight angle.  It is assumed that these blocks formed a table top support.

column14: Contiguous to a hallway (2) and a preparation room (4) and to a street.
