column21: We are entering from a nice sidewalk.  On the wall on the east there is a sign that says Taverna Q. Sallustius Inventus.  We step up to an entrance to a large food shop.  We look straight ahead to a north wall with a large opening to a preparation room (4) and another opening to a hall (2).  The east wall is rubble, with a pipe on the southeast corner.  There are little patches of plaster on this wall.  There is a rectangular podium-shaped platform.  It is made of concrete and roof times, with an unknown usage.  On the west wall we see a vat (3818) with remains of opus signinum and connected to it is a long rectangular preparation platform (3817).  The floor is pounded mud and lapilli.  There is no ceiling.

column14: This room is to the northwest of room 1 and to the northeast of room 2.  This room is southeast of room 9 from bakery of Papirius Sabinus.
column21: This is a small square preparation room.  One steps up from the sales room (1) and enters this room through a doorway on the south half of the southeast wall.  This room is in very poor condition.  No flooring is visible.  No ceiling remains.  All walls preserve some plaster but no longer reveal any paint.  Along the northwest wall two square cuttings pierce this wall to room 9 in bakery of Papirius Sabinus.  A vertical cutting approximately 4 feet long is seen in the southwest wall near the south corner. The eastern door jamb has three pairs of deep drilled holes.  According to Kevin Hill, the northwest wall may be mostly modern reconsruction.

column14: Room 1 to the southeast and room 3 to the northeast.
column21: The room is on a northwest/southeast axis and is narrow and actually contains part of the corridor the the back of the structure.  The room contains a vat (3819) in the southern corner of the southwest wall.  In the west corner of the room there is a portion of a terra cotta pipe from above and a drain common to the northwest wall.  The room is sloped towards the street.  Only fragments of plaster appear on the southeast and southwest walls.  The northwest wall is faced with brick.  There is a piece of plaster low on the northeast and a deep groove in the northeast wall toward the entrance of the room.  The floor is obscured with lapilli and debris.  The walls are of indeterminate height, but high on the southwest and northwest walls.  The ceiling is not extant.

column14: Vat (3818) to the northeast.
column21: Connected to the vat (3818) is a long rectangular preparation platform.l

column14: Prep platform (3817).
column21: On the west wall of this salesroom is a possible fish tank 4.  It is rectangular and is partially coated with opus signinum.  It is about knee high.

column14: none
column21: Small, quasi-rectangular vat is low and abuts the southeast and southwest walls of the room for approximately 3 feet on the southwest and to the doorway on the southeast.  The northwest end is slightly irregular and angles toward the back of the room.  Hydraulic plaster and opus signinum coat and form the vat.  At its highest point it is approximately 2 feet up from the ground.  Much volcanic debris fills the bottom of the vat.

column14: Atrium 7 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room on an east/west axis in heavily bombed out area.  North and west walls are reconstructed, with traces of white and red plaster.  Room is entered from wide doorway in south wall from atrium 7.  East wall only exists partially.  There is no ceiling and the floor is over grown.  There are possible traces of red and yellow paint remaining in a very rustic condition.  There is a very small remnant of a stone threshold in the doorway.

column14: 6449  is to the east.
column21: Rectangular masonry base of a water feature.  Fragments survive of a tiled surface.  Against the exterior of the basin to the north is a terra cotta down pipe.  At the junction of the southern end by the basement and the west wall there is a hole for a drain (?).

column14: East of latrine 6502.
column21: This platform consists of a bricked arch with storage beneath and a tiled surface.  The west and east end of the cooking platform show traces of plaster and the west end is directly attached to latrine 6502.  These two features are located at the west end of the south wall of kitchen room 2 (6501).

column14: In room 2 (6503) west of cooking platform 6501.
column21: At the west end of cooking platform 6501, cut into the south masonry wall is a semicircular niche for a latrine.  Niche shows remnants of plaster and slots for a top lintel, as well as lower down for seat placement.  Ground surface is obscured by soil and debris.

column14: West of sales room 1.
column21: The kitchen is a rectangular room completely open on its east end from sales room 1.  Room is on an east-west axis and a second door at the west end provides access to the adjoining property 6-8-9.  Door is on the northwest end of the west wall and there  is a stone threshold with a step up.  Door has a reconstructed lintel.  Immediately to the left of the door is access to latrine 6502.  West wall shows traces of plaster in the corner where it abuts the north wall.  The reconstructed north wall has a pinkish-toned plaster near its west end.  There is no wall to the east.   South wall is heavily reconstructed and contains cooking platform 6501, as well as latrine niche.  About one meter above the cooking platform is a hole in the masonry.  Floor is obscured by dirt and gravel.  No ceiling exists.

column14: Opening to street to the east.  Kitchen 6502 to the west.
column21: Sales room 1 is rectangular.  It is on a north-south axis.  The east wall consists of entrances 12 and 13, separated by a brick column.  Both entrances have thresholds of stone and are a small step up from the sidewalk.  The brick pillar shows evidence at its west midpoint that the room was apparently divided in two at some pint.  The north wall is heavily reconstructed, but contains two holes that may have held a shelf at one point.  The northwest corner of the room is open to kitchen 2.  The quoining of the threshold consists of brick layers and continues into an all masonry opus concertum wall, again, reconstructed. In the center of the masonry portion of the west wall is a hole, roughly triangular in shape, that may have been a lamp niche or possibly a very small lararium.  The south wall is identical to that of the west, but with a potential hole for a floor joist high up.  There is no ceiling and the floor is obscured by dirt and lapilli.

column14: The entrance to corridor number 21 is to the North
column21: This room is entered from a doorway on the North wall from corridor number 21. There is no roof and the floor is rubble. The Eastern wall is badly damaged. The facing wall on the lower left, there are traces of plaster with very faded paint.  On the North wall, the facing wall situated on the right side is a doorway entrance. It is a badly damaged, it's reconstructed in the far left corner. There are traces of plaster with light yellow paint. Up high, there is a possible round post hole.    Whe West wall is badly damaged, the facing wall on the right side, shows traces pf plaster. The square window is high up in almost the center of the wall. The South wall is badly damaged. There are large areas of plaster with faint traces of paint. Six possible post holes are seen, when facing on the upper left side.

column14: Room 12 is located to the East. Room 5 is located to the West. Room 10 is located to the South
column21: The room is rectangular and is situated on an E/W axis; it is bombed out. The floor is obscured by earth. Only the Northeast corner walls and the South and Southwest corner walls have survived. Some plaster survives on the South wall with no visible decoration. The doorway at the West end of the South wall leads to the tablinum. There is plaster on the North wall with no visible decoration. Dr. Jashemski says this is a dining room, looking over the garden that is situated to the East.

column14: The room contains 2 cooking platforms and a latrine and an arched opening at floor level in the corner of the East wallThere is a large entrance on the West side that opens at the corridor (40) and there is a smaller entrance situated to the East; it enters the street. (Vicolo del Fauno)
column21: This is a large sized Kitchen room. The kitchen is located on the Northeast side of the house at ground level. There are 2 entrances. There is 1 entrance on the street side. You can enter directly into the kitchen from the street. The rear entrance, rooms 6, 9 and 12, then proceed into the kitchen. The entrance from the street ha 2 post holes and evidence of a door. The other entrance is taller from the interior of the house corridor, that leads from the small garden. There is no ceiling or roof remaining and the floor is made up of dirt and debris.The North wall is badly damaged and reconstructed with some traces of yellow paint or mold. It has a round recessed area situated high up that is blocked in now. On the North wall situated on the left side is a large hearth to be discussed (6366) cooking platform.The East wall, the facing wall (entrance 12 from the street), there is a damaged wall with traces of plaster. The construction in the lower part of the wall suggests the presence of a sewer. On the East wall, high up there is a square or rectangular opening that is damaged at the top. The S. Wall is badly damaged, it is the facing wall on the left side (6568). There is a latrine located next to a cooking platform running the length of the wall. On the West wall, facing the wall on the far right is the large door, that is an entrance to the interior of the house, it is badly damaged!

column14: Room 8 to the east, room 6 to the south
column21: Rectangular room, east/west axis. Floor obscured by lapilli. North wall survives with evidence of restoration but no visible plaster. Against the north wall  extending from the west wall is cooking platform 6386. In the north west corner adjoining the platform and on the west wall are traces of plaster with a red or pink colour. The west and south walls survive only in the lower courses. In the centre of the south wall is a doorway to 6 with a stoned threshold and placing for a door. The southeast corner of the room is obscured by debris partially covering latrine 6387 and water feature 6388 in the centre of the east wall. At the north end of the east wall is a doorway to room 8 with a stone threshold and a placing for a door.

column14: Latrine 6387 and water feature 6388 are to the east
column21: Rectangular masonry cooking platform extending along the north wall from the west. The southern and eastern half is collapsed but the surface survives in the north west. Plastered surface contiguous with the plaster on the north and west walls. No visible lip or storage.

column14: water feature 6388 to the north, cooking platform 6386 to the west
column21: Latrine is in the south east corner of the room. Latrine itself is obscured by lapilli and debris. In the east wall behind the latrine is a terracotta down pipe inserted into a plastered recess in the wall. The plaster continues along the face of the wall behind the latrine. Directly against the latrine to the north is the masonry support of the water feature 6388.

column14: Latrine 6387 to the south, cooking platform 6386 to the west
column21: Masonry and tile base forms a semi-circular water basin. The base of the basin is obscured by lapilli and debris but the upper course is visible revealing plaster lining that abuts directly on to the plaster of the adjoining east wall. Latrine 6387 abuts directly against the tile and masonry wall of the feature enclosing the plastered basin. Not enough of the exterior face of the wall survives to determine whether it was plastered or finished in any other way.

column14: corridor 1, corridor 6
column21: There are two entrances. One is from entrance 5 corridor 1 on the southwest side through a corridor and the other entrance is on the northeast side 6. No roof. No floor. According to Jashemski this establishment was badly damaged in the earthquake of 62 CE. The rubble was removed at that time and the entire area was planted. The southwest wall is badly damaged, no traces of paint or plaster and partly reconstructed. The south wall is badly damaged with some reconstruction, in the southeastern corner of the room there are traces of a lower wall perhaps defining a space. On the northeast wall a lower wall projects into the room. An entrance from house 15 at corridor 6 has a wall that is badly damaged with faint traces of plaster. The northwest wall is damaged and has been rebuilt. Facing the wall on the right hand side are traces of painting, lower register, faint red and upper, faint yellow. On the southwest wall - facing the entrance at 5 there is a triclinium.

column14: Northwest corner of horticultural space
column21: Masonry support for the face of a masonry triclinium. Only the lower course survives with no indication of the couch surface. The external face of the northern arm preserves traces of red plaster. Jashemski says that this triclinium came from an earlier phase prior to the earthquake of 62 CE after which debris filling the room was cleared and the remainder of the area turned over to horticultural use.

In the fourth feature on the lower level, the ground is black in an arched rectangle. There is a serving tray with a brown casserole (?) surmounted by two pieces of food (?) and a pomegranate in the foreground.

column14: room 26 to the south
column21: Subterranean storeroom under room 32 is accessed to the south y stairs from    peristyle 26. Narrow rectangular room, east/west axis. All walls are plastered with no visible decoration. Recess in the centre of the west wall may be a collapse. Plastered vaulted ceiling. An L-shaped cooking platform is found along the north and west wall. Plastered floor throughout, partially obscured by earth and debris.

column14: north end of storeroom
column21: L-shaped preparation platform along the west and south walls. Masonry with plastered surface.

column14: corridor to the east, room 18 abuts to the south, stairs 20 abut to the north
column21: A rectangular room with a north/south axis. Accessed from a corridor east running the length of the house. The dimensions and layout of the room are unclear as it is completely filled with debris. In the west wall there are two arches abutting the wall. Beneath the northern arch are the rubble remains of cooking platform 6358. Amongst the debris against the south wall is a carrot-shaped amphora and a fragmentary dolium.

column14: against the west wall
column21: Remains of a masonry cooking platform obscured by debris. Boyce and Warscher show this to be a cooking platform. Boyce also refers to a no longer extant lararium.

column14: large opening to dining room 30 to the west, possible opening to corridor to the east.
column21: This preparation room has two entrances. The one to the west is a large entrance to dining room 30, to the east side no wall remains but it must have opened to the corridor to the east. No ceiling remains, the floor is obscured by lapilli. The room is L-shaped with five features related to a bakery placed (at the time of recent excavation) near the north wall of the room. The walls and partial walls on the west, south and north sides are badly damaged and reconstructed. Traces of plaster show on the south and west walls - possibly white. As one enters from room 30 the wall to the right is badly damaged and reconstructed and shows traces of white paint (?) in the lower and middle register. There is a lamp niche on the far left high up on the wall facing west, badly damaged. There are traces of plaster and white paint and a possible post hole high in the centre of the wall. In the lower right corner in a vertical row there are 3 square post holes with evidence of a wooden plank in the middle hole. Directly opposite 3 similar square holes are found on the wall of the corridor. The south wall is mostly destroyed and there are no traces. the corridor to the east is the exterior wall to the street (east) The west entrance to room 30 is a reconstruction with a modern wooden lintel. High impressions in plaster running across the opening may reflect the ancient roof line.

column14: near the north wall, scattered, not in situ
column21: Feature 6360 is a rotary hand mill. 5 round stone bases and parts of mills (not in situ) 4 have square cutout openings one, smaller, has a roundish opening cut in the top.

Boyce 49-50 describes a lararium painting tht is no longer extant. In the centre is a blue omphalos, around which coils a huge scaly serpent with crest and beard and , on each side of it, stands a Lar clad in bright violet Phrygian cap, blue sleeveless tunic and red pallium which flies out behind his head, and holding rhyton and situla. Each Lar stands between two laurel trees. Across the top of the painting is stretched a heavy garland.

column14: entrance on the west goes directly to atrium 7
column21: The entrance is facing west off atrium 4. No visible remains of ceiling. Floor obscured by lapilli. Traces of plaster remain on the entrance opening with red and yellow paint but it is very damaged. The wall to the north is damaged and there is some reconstruction. Plaster with traces of paint remains - a lower red dado with border, a large middle register and an upper register (?) - faded red and yellow on wall. The wall to the east is badly damaged - there are traces of red plaster on both corners at the lower level. The wall to the south shows traces of plaster in two registers, red paint and possibly the remains of a third border. 5 round post holes are high on the wall. Ancient metal clamps are in situ in the lower register and in the middle of the wall to the west - badly damaged traces of plaster and red paint. Facing wall to the the left is a recessed area with a modern wooden lintel. There are traces of plaster with yellow and red paint and an opening at window level to the adjacent room 7.

column14: Room 14 is to the south
column21: Large rectangular room. East west axis. Floor obscured by lapilli throughout. Doorway in the center of the south wall to 14. No visible threshold. Blocked doorway from earlier phase at the west end of the south wall. Fragments of plaster survive on the south wall. Extensive fragments of plaster on the north wall with pink hue. Plaster survives extensively on the east wall divided into two sections but with no discernible decorations. At the top of the east wall a painted plaster cornice with red trim survives along the entire edge of the east wall indicating that this had a high ceiling (no ceiling extant). At the east end of the south wall there are two holes into the wall. The function is unclear. Maybe collapsed and plastered over.

column14: Kitchen is entered from room 12 to the eastDownshaft in wall of the kitchen is unusual.
column21: Entrance on North East floor is dirt-debris and weeds. No ceiling to room. Entrance is badly damaged. No sign of entrance hall.North west wall is badly damaged, evidence of 3 post holes high on wall. Facing the wall to the left  at eye level there is a lararium, recessed niche. Traces of plaster and paint on wall, presumably a lararium painting. South West wall is badly damaged with traces of plaster. Facing the wall on right side a recessed area leads to a vertical shaft to space above. Inside the shaft evidence of plaster in situ.South east wall badly damaged with traces of plaster. Facing the wall on upper right there is a small niche for possibly a lamp?Evidence of a second floor with traces of plaster and painting above kitchen.

column14: Lararium is located in room 13. On the north west corner on the north wall.
column21: On north wall, facing the south east wall of room 13, to the left is an arched recessed niche-lararium. Traces of a ledge, traces of plaster and some point exist. Surrounding the niche on wall there are traces of plaster + painting presumably a lararium painting survive. Very faded.

column14: To the south east of water feature 6440
column21: Its located in the South East of the kitchen (6438). The masonry cooking platform has arched underneath storage and a tiled hearth surface

column14: To the north west of feature 6439 cooking platform
column21: Reconstructed concrete cistern head square exterior, round interior, approximately 2 feet high. Located in the north west corner of kitchen room 7.

column14: Room 3 is to the east and room 8 is to the south
column21: Rectangular room east /west axis. All four walls are poorly preserved with no traces of decoration and has modern restoration. Floor is obscured by lapilli and rubble. At the east end of the south wall there is a doorway with a stone stepped threshold. At the north end of the east wall there is a doorway with a stone stepped threshold.

column14: Contiguous to cooking platform 3907 to the SW.
column21: The latrine runs along the NE and the SE walls of the kitchen.  There is a small step up from the kitchen into this area. In the eastern corner of the NE wall, is a badly broken terracotta  pipe.  Oddly, there is a painted plaster area in the latrine with red and gold portions.  The SW portion of the latrine is delineated by  the NE cooking platform support which runs approximately half the distance of the space toward the NW wall. There is a small lightwell high on the SE wall above the latrine. There are no tiles evident today.

column14: Contiguous to atrium (2) to the NE an fore room 7 to the SE.
column21: this large dining hall is in extremely poor condition. We enter through an enormous opening to the atrium (6) from the NE or a much smaller doorway on the E corner of the  room from the fore room. Traces of paint and plaster are  too faded and broken to precisely determine; however on the western side of the NW wall  we find evidence to suggest 2nd style.  There is a low yellow dado at the bottom followed by a register that is now white but could have been black with simple ornamentation, one red and one gold diamond spaced apart. Then a border of red separates the next area which forms panels.  Some column figures and a man looking over his shoulder are the only discernible features. The room would have been approximately 2 stories high as indicated by plaster on the eastern corner of the SE wall.  Traces of coccio pesto with tesserae which may have formed a pattern earlier are obscured by moss, vegetation, and debris. There is a large marble threshold separating this room from the atrium. Modern mantles and wood supports are in the door in the eastern corner. *Note, it appears like 3 (even though the third on the NW wall has had much plaster removed) large central paintings on each wall have been deliverately removed.  No ceiling is extant.

column14: Contiguous to corridor 11 to the SW and corridor 10 to the SE. Contiguous to dining 15 to the SW and 17 to the NE.
column21: one enters th dining room 16 through a large open doorway from corridor 11 or corridor 10. There is no lintel nor threshold.  Therre is concrete or cement plaster on most walls in large fragments.  There is a low pass-through on a tiny southwest remnant of a doorway which appears to have been added to an already plastered thick doorjam.  The floor is covered with rubble, terracotta tiles and debris. The only decoration visible is on the inner face of the SE doorjamb in the east corner (red and white paint).  A small piece of yellow painted plaster shows through the concrete plaster of the south corner of the SW wall.  Eleven poorly preserved beam holes with terracotta tiles are high on the  NW wall.  A tunneling hole appears on the SW wall in the center.  There is no ceiling extant, but there is an indication of a second story.

column14: Contiguous with corridor 10 to the SE and tablinum 19 to the NE.
column21: One enters dining room 17 from corridor 10 to the SE or the tablinum 19 to the NE.  The large entrance to the SE contains broken marble threshold fragments  which  indicate placements at the door or pivot.  This opening provides a focal point intto the large impluvium in the atrium where there was  a fountain. There is a large section which is indented into the stone on the NE wall of the threshold.  Tough badly preserved, the floor was caccio pesto with white tesserae running diagonally forming diamonds with little black centered four petalled white flowers in the center of each. The painting  on the walls is faint, but traces of red white and yellow can be seen on all four walls and faint outlines of green and red stenciling can be seen in at least 2 of the corners.  One the SE and NW walls, faint columns garlanded in red can be seen above the the red dado and on the NW wall white impressions outline small birds holding garlands in their beaks decorating the red and white column.  This room was probably decorated in 3rd or 4th style.  Poorly preserved molding at the SW end of the room where the three walls meet provide an indication of the ceiling above which there was a vault on the SW and 7 beam holes above the arch.   There is no ceiling extant but the western corner indicates 2 storeys. The floor is obscured with rubble and debris.

column14: This room is to the NE to the tablinum (19). This room forms the northern most corner of the house.  The dieta (20) is just further east along the northeast wall.
column21: This is the dining room. it is a rectangular space on a SW/NE axis. One enters this room from a wide doorway in the center of the SE wall from the tablinum 19.  The room is in very poor condition.  The walls have had very little reconstruction.  There is plaster on all 4 sides of the room.  Some of have early conservation but the NW wall is crumbling.  Although it is difficult to determine the style of painting there is a low red dado with large panels above.  In the center of the NW and NE walls, one can still make out trces of rondelles. No flooring is visible. There is no ceiling remaining. The NE wall is the best preserved. There is a small high window above the horizontal cornice.  This is within a molded arch.  In the north corner of the NW wall, there is a small low couch niche (3906). This niche is the height of the dado and also painted red.   Like the rest of the dado, it is decorated with a delicate motif: in the niches there is also painted the hind legs and tail of the animal.

column14: Contiguous to fore room 4 to the NE.
column21: one enters dining room 5 from a door on the NE wall.  The doorway has modern supports and is in bad condition.  Plaster remains on both sides of the doorway as we enter into the room. The floor, though obscured, appears to be coccio pesto.  Wall paintings have been removed from the center of the SE, SW,and NW walls.  The painting style is indiscernable, however, may have 3rd  or 4th according to traces on the NW wall.  It appears there were red panels above a low dado which looks black or white.  There are two windows inthe room, each high and  supported with wood and metal inserts.  One is on the SW and the other on the SE wall.  There is a ledge just over the windows which continues the full length of each wall which would indicate a second floor.  Additionally, eight joist holes high on the NE wall support a second storey idea as well as another higher window above those.  No ceiling is extant.  There are three holes spaced vertically on the SE wall aligned with the southern most portion of the window on the SE wall, and on the western most border of the window above is one whole of the same height and shape on the SW wall.  It is an after thought but should be noted that each of the aforementioned windows angle to let light into the room.

column14: This room is located northwest of dining hall (6) it opens to space 9 leading to the atrium (8).
column21: This is a small dining room.  it is rectangular with a northeast southwest axis.  One enters the room through a doorway from space 9.  The doorway forms the eastern half of the wall. The doorway forms the eastern half of the wall.  The northern half of this wall is n very poor condition and is made from a red volcanic stone.  The room is in very poor condition.  Coccio pesto flooring can be seen near the doorway.;  The northwest , southwest and northwest walls still have some painted plaster, however, large central tableaux have been cut out from these walls.  The painted decoration preserves traces of a high dado and large panels above.  This room  has had various attempts at conservation, including metal butterfly  clamps on the southwest, southeast and northwest walls.  No ceiling remains, the upper portion of the southwest wall is red volcanic stone.

column14: atrium 2 to the south
column21: We enter dining room4 from the atrium to the southwest. The room is square and is north of the street entrance. An outline of an old threshold remains and the floor appears to have been cement with cocciopesto material mixed. The painting in the room has a low white or black dado which contains some stencilled patterns in gold - with a bird on the northwesternmost section. Alternating large panels (possibly fourth style) of red and yellow occur on the northwest, northeast and southeast walls, separated by white portions which appear to have features of architectural motifs which extend from lower through middle to top registers. The moulding,  which is decorated with dart and thistle, exists in fragments on all three walls about two feet above the highest register. The lintel is modern and concrete. Six large square beam holes are high on the northwest and southeast walls. Plaster survives to a second storey height on northeast and southeast. No ceiling extant.

column14: Atrium 2 to the south
column21: Room 21, which is slightly smaller than the corresponding room across the atrium, mirrors the artwork with respect to panel designs. However the lower register appears to have been painted black. We enter this room through the open wall southwest of the atrium and entrance from the street. There is no threshold outlined. The floor appears to have been cement. The painting in the room has a low black dado which contains some stencilled patterns in gold. Alternating large panels, possibly fourth style, of red and yellow occur on the northwest, southwest and southeast walls, separated by portions of white which appear to have features of architectural motifs which extend from lower through middle to top registers. The moulding, which is decorated in floral designs, appears to have been painted red and blue alternately and exists on all three walls - full length on the southwest wall, in patches on the northwest wall and approximately half the length of the northeast wall. The lintel is modern and concrete.

column14: kitchen 10 to the northwest, dining garden 13 to the northeast
column21: This is a storeroom. It is a  rectangular shaped room on a northeast/southwest axis. One can enter this space from the dining garden 13 at the southwest wall or from the kitchen 10 at the south corner of the southeast wall. A tall deep cupboard 3851 is located to the west of the doorway 8. It is separated from the rest of the storeroom by a partition all the way to the ceiling. The storeroom itself is in very poor condition. Cement floors are visible in the north corner. Plaster remains on all four walls. No painting is discernible. No ceilings remain, however, four joist holes are preserved in the northeast wall and one in the partition wall to the southwest wall. There is a small high window in the northeast wall and a large square window in the northwest wall which may have been above the ceiling of this room.

column14: storeroom 17 to the north, dining garden 13 to the south
column21: Walking into this storeroom, north of us is a stairway to the second floor. We see a plastered rectangular storeroom on a north/south axis. On the west wall we see three post holes for shelves. The north wall has some plaster left and four post holes  for a ceiling. On the east wall we see a low doorway to storeroom 18. This storeroom is under the stairway. The floor is pounded earth with some lapilli. This room would have had a ceiling.

column14: located in the westernmost corner of room 9 directly opposite the door to kitchen 10
column21: This is a cupboard located in the western corner of storage room 9. This appears to be about two feet deep, three feet wide and goes up to the ceiling. Holes in the northwest wall remain for shelving. Some pkaster remains over the rubble structure. Condition is poor. No floor can be seen.

column14: storeroom 17 to the east, dining garden 13 to the south
column21: This is a small storeroom which is located under the stairs leading to the second floor. It is a rectangular room with a north/south axis. There are some signs of plaster on the north and east walls, but nothing on the west. The stairs are gone. The floor is pounded earth on some lapilli. This room was roofed by the stairs. There is a doorway on the west wall leading to storeroom 17.

column14: room 2 to the west
column21: Square room. Floor obscured by lapilli throughout. Wide doorway in the east wall opening to the street. Basalt stepped threshold with placings for a sliding door. Fragments of plaster on the south wall with a pinkish hue. High in the south wall there are two holes for floor joists between which, in the lower part, there is a restored doorway. At the southwest corner there is a rectangular base for stairs to the floor above. In the centre of the wet wall there is a basalt stepped threshold to the preparation room 2. High at the east end of the north wall there is a shallow square plastered recess. Above this, there are two holes for floor joists. In the centre of the room is a catillus 6499.

column14: There is a salesroom 1, located to the East, and cubiculum 3 to the West
column21: A squarish room with an east/west axis. Room is entered from salesroom 1 to the east and provides access to cubiculum 3 to the west. There is a plastered lararium with a terracotta shelf on the west wall. On the southwest corner of the west wall red plaster trace remains. North wall is solid masonry. The east wall is reconstructed to waist height with a stone threshold for the doorway and a mound of stacked tiles which could be the remains of a staircase to the upper floor or the remains of a hearth (per Eschebach). South wall is reconstructed masonry. West wall has its own step up to the cubiculum. Floor is obscured by lapilli. No ceiling remains.
A catillus is in the middle of the room towards the northern corner. Excavation reports record that it is in situ. No extant meta, present.
Plastered arch lararium is situated high up on west wall of preparation room 2. A terracotta base protrudes from the bottom. No paintings remain.

column14: This room is to the south west of entrance 16 it is directly south east of the cubliculum (bordello) (room 25).
column21: This is a preparation room. It is a rectangular space on a north east/ south west axis. There are 2 doorways on the north east wall. One enters this room from the atrium just to the west of entrance 16. Evidence for storage and preparation remain in this room including a dolium and a square cutting in the south corner of the room. The room is in poor condition. The flooring is not visible. No ceiling remains. There is some plaster on the south east wall. There are several cuttings in the north west wall going horizontally at about five feet as well as three others in the north corner.

column14: Contiguous with rooms 24 and 25 to the west, 22 and 23 to the east, a corridor to the north and the street entrance 16 is to the south.
column21: This is a large Tuscan atrium which is north of street entrance 16. Its in a state of disrepair with vegetation obscuring the floor and an outline of an impluvium which has small plaster fragment which is painted black, red and white in the centre of its north west lowest portion. The structure which is gated and locked has a lava stone step up threshold from the street. On the south west wall are three doorways to adjoining rooms. The first is low and small. The second and third are the same height. All have modern wooden lintels surrounded by lead. The third doorway, which is almost in the centre of the wall also has lava stone threshold which is grounded. Today there is a locked wooden door which closes off the adjoining private bordello, with exotic pictures. Just north west of this third door is a square blocked window with brick and mortar, however a beautiful white marble windowsill is in situ and another lead and wood modern lintel has been inserted. Above the third door and the small window there is a large opening which is now roofed to protect the next room from sun and water and weather. In the extreme north west corner at the bottom is a fragment of plaster painted dark yellow. In the wall which adjoins the next corridor (north west) is a doorway with modern wooden and lead lintel. To the north east is a large room abutting the north east and south east walls is a preparation platform which is in a bad state of repair. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: This room is to the north west of dining room  22, it is on the north east side of the atrium. The north east wall is exterior wall to the street.
column21: This is a dining room. One enters through the doorway in the centre of the south east wall. There is a stone threshold. This door is about 1/3 the width of the wall. The room is rectangular on a south west/ south east axis. The room is in poor condition, no flooring is visible. The north west, south west and north east walls are preserved to a great height. There is a high window to the street on the north west wall, a conserved area may have been a tunnel in the centre of the wall (??). two holes cut through to the entrance way on the wall probably held beams on the other side. Two small square holes on the upper section of this wall may have held a ceiling. No ceiling remains.

column14: This room is north east of the atrium (20). It is south east of dining room 21.
column21: The space is a dining area. It opens on the south west side to the atrium (20) which was used as a preparation area. This area of the house is associated with entrance 16 and is the commercial area of this house. This dining room as well as room 21 appear to have served as commercial dining areas which may have been associated with a bordello. This room is rectangular with a north east/south west axis. The door on the south west is almost the entire length of the room. A doorway on the north west wall opens the middle 1/3 of the wall to the dining room beyond. The condition of this room is very poor. No flooring is visible. Small areas of plaster are preserved on the south east, north east and north west walls. Red painted bands can be seen on the corners and the dado areas of the walls. A painted tableau seems to have been removed from the centre of the north east wall. A high window is located in the centre of the north east wall. No ceiling remains.

column14: Contiguous to atrium 13 to the south east.
column21: This large dining room runs along a north east/south west axis, almost. One enters the dining room through a large doorway which has a large portion of a wide lava stone threshold in situ. There is a deep groove on the south west side of the entrance and a ledge of the same height on the north east side, however there is no lintel. The room gives the feeling of space in that it is high with no evidence of beam holes. The walls (south east wall in particular) rises beyond a second storey height. Red painted plaster with panels delineated by stencilling is faint but evident on all walls. It appears that some painted plaster or paintings have been removed intentionally from the centres of the north west and north east walls and possibly the south east wall at the doorway, on the east side. there was a lower register of dado which had a filigree design alternating with panels of water plants. In the centre of those with the stencilling, there were circular medallions of some sort. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: Contiguous to corridor 11 to the south west and to dining room 26 to the south east and atrium 13 to the north west.
column21: There are two entrances to dining hall (3917), one on the south west wall. At the western end is a smaller passageway from the atrium. There is a broken marble threshold with a door pivot hole and a wall which separates the corridor to the peristyle and the atrium. The second opening is 10-12 feet wide and is to the south west. It provides a vista of the peristyle garden. This entrance has a small broken white marble threshold which delineates the room and the western side of the wall is broken, while the southern door facing rises approximately 13 feet. No traces of painted plaster survive, however on the north east wall, approximately 10 feet from the ground are two holes which may have been for some kind of support, and on the south east wall there are three holes, approximately five feet from the ground. White tesserae are scattered among vegetation and ash, and there appears to have been some which may have been stained black.

column14: This room is to the north east of corridor 11. It is south east of dining room 32 and is north east of preparation room 27.
column21: This large dining room is entered through a large doorway from corridor 11. The room is rectangular with a north east/south west axis. The room is in poor condition, however much of the coccio pesto floor remains with assorted coloured stones embedded throughout. A small door in the southern corner along the south east wall enters to the adjacent preparation room (27). There is no plaster or paint on remaining on the walls. No ceiling remains. In spite of this poor condition, the view of the peristyle gives this room a sense of luxury.

column14: Contiguous to atrium 2 to the NW.
column21: This kitchen which is in a state of disrepair is to the NE of entrance 18.  There is a narrow doorway on the NW wall which is supported by modern boards and metal supports.   there appears to have been a lava stone threshold.  There is plaster on the NE NW and SW walls.  The plaster on the NE wall appears to have had a lower golden register and a red border and this would now be part of the latrine wall.  There is a  small step up into the latrine which then is bordered byh a cooking platform support which extends from the SE wall toward the NW into approximately into the midpoint of the room.  A large  broken drain pipe made of  terra cotta is situated in the wall toward the eastern corner.  There  are two small light wells on the SE wall with the one above the latrine having a much smaller opening to the street.  The one over the cooking platform is square in shape.  Both have modern wooden lintels inserted.  On this same wall are four large holes which are below the window height, and one smaller beam hole approximately  window level.  The cooking platform supports jut into the room  from the SE.  The first to the NE  as was mentioned  also forms the latrine's barrier and the second abuts the SE and SW walls.  On the SW wall running along the length of the cooking platform support is a deep thick groove which may have housed a shelf.  The floor is obscured with rubble and vegetation.  The SE wall shows a groove and building material indicating a second storey height.  There is no ceiling extant.

column14: This room is to the southwest of dining room 7 and southeast of corridors 13 and 11.
column21: This is a large prep room, one enters from the northwest wall  at the northern corner. The room is on a southwest/northeast axis and is rectangular.  There is a low door and a slight step up into this room.  Due to it's proximity to the service corridor (11) this appears to be a prep or storage room.  This room is in very poor condition.  The southwest wall is quite tall with a small high window for light.  Presently this wall is braced with wood and metal supports.  There is some plaster on each f the walls, however, no paint remains.  the floor iis not visible.  The ceiling no longer remains.

column14: Contiguous to dining room 26 to the northwest and corridor 11 to the southwesst.
column21: This small nearly square preparation room runs along a northwest/southeast axis and has two doorways with marble thresholds and modern wooden and lead lintels.  The thresholds have placements for small door pivots.  The doorway on the northwest wall adjoins dining room 26 and the doorway on the southwest leads to the peristyle corridor (11).  The common area of the two doors is formed by a column of brick between them at the western corner.  The floor was of mixed pavement cement.  Today there are two pieces of a column in the east corner, and in the south corner, some broken drain tiles.  The floor is obscured with vegetation and debris.  The northeast wall contains a large window into the next room, which is roofed.  All walls, except the northwest, are high.  There is no ceiling extant.

column14: The kitchen is adjacent to the stairwell at its northwest side.  The southeast wall is an exterior wall to the street.  Preparation room 31 is the the southwest.
column21: This rectangular space is a kitchen.  One enters this room from a doorway in the western corner of the northwest wall.  an "L" shaped platform (3921) goes from the northern doorjamb to the north corner of the room and then makes a right angle to the east corner of the room.  Near the center of the southeast wall are traces of another platform.  The room is in very poor condition.  At present the southwest wall is braced with metal and wood supports.  The walls are in poor condition, however, some plaster remains on the northwest and southeast walls.  The flooring is not visible and no ceiling remains.

column14: This platform is the the northeast and northwest of a small platform (3927).
column21: This cooking platform is along the northwest and northeast walls of the kitchen and is "L" shaped.  The section of this platform along the northwest wall is about 3.5 feet deep and about 2.5 feet high.  There is an arched storage space for firewood below this section.  Remains of ceramic tile can be seen on the upper surface.  At the northern corner of the room the platform turns to the east, it is the same height bas the other section, but only about 1.5 feet deep.  It goes continues at this depth for about 3 feet and then the section at the eastern corner of the room is only about a foot deep.

column14: Of Computer
column21: In the Vicolo dei Termo at an intersection region 9.4 and 9.5 and 9.6 and 9.3, a corner of a house or houses that has not been excavated.  At the outside of the new central baths, which were unfinished at the time of the eruption is a crossroad shrine. This consists of an aedicular niche, made of brick with an apparent ledge and beneath it is an altar.

column14: None stated.
column21: The alter is a one stone block waist high that protrudes from the wall and it is beneath a shaped bk niche. A circular hole appears halfway up the front of the block.

column14: The opening to the North off of atrium 7.
column21: This is a Dining room situated on a N/S axis. One can enter over a stone threshold from atrium no. 7. There is no ceiling, there is an over grown floor. Plaster remains on all 4 walls. On the North wall, there is a white lower register with a red band across the top. The NW wall appears to be divided into 2 panels, with traces of: red, yellow and blue paint remaining over darker red in the lower register. The West wall shows evidence of more elaborate painting on the lowest register which looks to be a center frieze bordered by red lines that look like ribbons, over black paint. A central panel bordered architectural detail appears above, but the design is undestinguishable. I see no windows, only a large doorway for a view. There are 3 gaps in the masonry that resemble post holes and they may have been original on the East wall.

column14: Contiguous to counter room 2 and store room 3 to the North and a street situated to the South
column21: The counter room sits on an E/W axis, with the South end opening directly to via DeFortuna. 2 large counters, one rectangular, one v shaped are located on two short ends of the room. There is a t shaped brick column like small wall dividing the room from entrances 6-8-7 and 6-8-8. There is no ceiling, the floor is lapilli. The North end of the room is delineated by another short brick L shaped columnar structure. Attached to the end of counter 6460. The West wall is masonry with only a fragment of plaster remaining. At the South end of counter 6460, is a narrow concrete bench attached just inside entrance door 6-8-7. At entrance 6-8-8, there is a threshold for a door to close off the counter room from the street.

column14: Bench 6461 & counter 6460 to the West. Dolia 6459 is situated to the North
column21: This "U" shaped counter runs along the East wall of room 1, with the bottom of the "U" facing via di Fortuna. There are 6 openings for dolia in the tiled surface. The interior base of the counter is masonry with traces of plaster. The surface is tiled in marble. Only 1 of the dolia has an extant lip (that in the SE corner). At the outside end of the "U", on the Southwest end, is an indentation for a hearth, rectangluar in shape. At the North end of the eastern "U", against the wall is dolia(6459). The exterior of the counter is all tiled in marble. The counter is a reconstruction.

column14: To the North of counter (6458). To the East of the Counter (6460) and bench (6461)
column21: This is a broken clay dolium partially built into the N end of the counter (6458). Dolium is short and squat round in shape. Narrowing at the neck and flaring to a wide lip. The lip is cracked on the West side, with another break in the same area lower down. The Dolium is filled with lapilli.

column14: Bench (6461) situated to the South.Counter (6458) and dolium (6459) to the East
column21: A tiled, masonry counter has 4 insets for dokia. The counter is located on the West wall of the room with a street side bench (6461) directly attached to the U shaped counter is the East and counter room 2 situated to the North. The counter is reconstructed, and made of masonry with a tiled ceramic top.

column14: Room 7 is to the east.  Room 12 is to the south and west.
column21: This large rectangular room has two entrances, one from the atrium to the east, one from area 12 to the south.  It also appears to have had, on its western wall, a very large window facing the garden.  The room is on an east/west axis.  The room has no ceiling.  The floor appears to be a combination of opus signinum and what may be modern concrete.  Some of the floor is rubble, but area appears to be well covered by flooring.  Starting on the east wall, the threshold in the southeastern corner is a step up. All four walls contain a fairly large amount of plaster.  The lowest register shows evidence of red paint on the north, west, and south walls, but may have been black on the east wall.  The upper register shows evidence of division into panels, with white, red, and blue paint still remaining.  About in the center of the north and south walls, a false plaster column with blue paint and striped lines appears as an element of architectural interest.  The only wall that shows evidence of second story joist holes (4 to 5) is the north wall.  Under the window of the west wall is a remnant of a brick column that implies that this wall may have been a later addition.  The southwest entrance is faced with brick with a spacing for a lintel up above.

column14: 18 and 19 to the south.  15 and 16 to the east.
column21: This is a rectangular room with an east/west axis.  The floor is obscured by earth and lapilli throughout.  All four wall are extensively restored.  On the east wall there are two doorways to rooms 15 and 16.  There is no visible threshold and there are modern lintels.  High in the eastern half of the south wall there are five restored rectangular holes for floor joists.  In the western half of the south wall there are two doorways to 18 and 19 with modern lintels.  Doorway 19 has no visible threshold.  Doorway 18 on the center of the wall has a basalt threshold.  In the center of the west wall.  The threshold continues underneath the cooking platform to the north.  Cooking platform 6491 extends along the north wall from the northwest corner.  Two square brick columns are inverted into the north wall.  Between the columns are two rectangular openings for windows.

column14: In the northwest corner along the north wall.
column21: This is a long rectangular masonry cooking platform with extensive restoration.   The surface does not survive.  In the center there is an arched tiled recess for storage.  In the base of the south face and and east face there are traces of plaster.  Fragments of plaster survive inside the recess and in the northwest corner traces of plaster survive at the junction of the north and west walls.

column14: Peristyle 14 to south
column21: Rectangular room. north south axis opening from a narrow corridor which continues to south to peristyle 14. Vaulted concrete ceiling with the placing for the planking throughout. Partially preserved tile floor in the south, east and north half of room. Slopes north drain into the sewer that extends along the north wall. At the north end of the west wall are the placings for a seat and a step that would have extended to a square masonry platform and step in the northeast corner.  As the masonry step and platform are the same height as the seat and the step in the west wall we would suggest that they are part of the latrine rather than a separate feature. There are no visible cooking features in the room but its position in the house, dimensions and latrine suggest possible function as a kitchen. No visible threshold. Modern lintel above. In the southeast corner the surviving section of floor has a raised ribbing running parallel to the east wall approximately 5 cm from the wall.

column14: 37 to the south
column21: Narrow rectangular room. north south axis opening south to corridor 37. Floor obscured by lapilli throughout. No visible threshold. No visible decoration or finish on the north, east and west walls. All three walls have extensive restoration. At the base of the east wall there is a load bearing arch to cover a drain (?) beneath. Against the center of the east wall there is a small square tile and cement base. The upper two thirds of the east wall are restored including three small holes equidistant along the wall. The two southern most holes extend through the wall to the street. High in the center of the wall there is a rectangular window through the wall to the street. To the east with plaster interior faces and tile lintel narrowing   to the east. There are no cooking features in this room. Its identification as a kitchen is based on te dimensions and the presence of a water supply.

column14: Peristyle garden 14/15 to south
column21: Rectangular room, north south axis. Floor obscured by lapilli throughout. Wide open doorway in south wall to peristyle . marble threshold with placing for door. Plaster survives on north, east, and west walls. East and west walls extensive decoration survives. Third style(?). Black lower register with yellow trim with alternating with alternating red and yellow above, separated by white borders. Traces of plaster molded cornice survive on the northern half of west wall with plaster decoration continuing above. Fragment of cornice on southern end of west wall.

column14: Atrium 5 to the east.Portico 14 and garden 15 to the west
column21: One enters the room from the north end at east wall. Room axis is east west. The threshold is of marble. There are door jambs on either side. One then ascends to marble steps to a raised floor that is obscured by lapilli. On the north wall there are remnants of painted plaster. There is a lower register with very faint traces; above which there is a narrow red border. Then a mid register carrying 3 panels painted in yellow and red. The style cannot be discerned. Above this there are traces of paint that may be an upper register. The western wall has a large formal entrance that looks out looks out on to the garden and peristyle. On either side of the entrance there is red and yellow painted plaster. The threshold is raised and appears to be of marble. Cuttings in the surface of the threshold are present for door jambs. On the south wall there are traces of painted plaster similar to those on the north wall but better preserved. There are three panels visible in a middle register that may be third style. Above the painted area there are fragments of a plaster ceiling molding. The east wall shows traces of painted plaster similar to elsewhere but poorly preserved. A nice view of the impressive household shrine.

column14: ALA (9) to the east, room 13 to the West.
column21: Room axis is East/West. One enters the room from the east. The threshold is of stone and raised. There are cuttings for door jams. The east wall shows traces of painting. There is a lower register in red with a thin white border. Above this there is a yellow register. The north wall has better preserved painted plaster. Four registers are visible. The lower register is red as elsewhere. The registers above are yellow. There are two large yellow panels whose style is indiscernible. There are traces of plaster molding high on the wall. The West wall has a large opening looking out on the portico (14) and the garden (15). There are traces of painted plaster similar to the other walls. The south wall carries better preserved painted plaster and molding, similar to the North wall. View of portico (14), garden (15), lararium through the opening in the West wall.

column14: Portico (14) and garden (15) to the South.Room (25) to the North.
column21: Room axis is North/South. One enters the room from the North side of the portico (14) to the south. The entrance is large and formal with a marble threshold. The floor is obscured by lapilli. The east wall is poorly preserved. A few traces of yellow paint remain. There may be a post hole high at the northern end. The North wall is poorly preserved. No traces of paint are visible. There is a large opening waist high on axis with the entrance that may be reconstructed. The West wall is badly damaged. Little plaster and no painting is visible. The South wall on either side of the entrance is poorly preserved. There are patches of adherent plaster at the lower extremes.

column14: Garden peristyle (31/39) to the West, and atrium (41) to the North.
column21: Rectangular room, East/West axis. Floor obscured throughout by lapilli. North/East/West walls survive only in the lower courses with extensive modern restoration. At the West end of the North wall there is a narrow doorway with stone threshold with placements for door. Wide doorway in the West wall, overlooking the garden, and stone threshold with placing for shutters. South wall survives to a higher level with signs of collapse and modern restoration. At the East end of South wall there is couch niche 6315.

Long rectangular couch niche along the eastern half of the south wall. The dimensions of the niche are poorly preserved due to collapse and modern restoration. At the east and west ends the plaster of the niche survives on teh interior, red color.

column14: Against the North wall.
column21: Partially preserved tile floor slopes North to drain into the sewer that extends along the north wall. At the North end of the West wall are placements for a seat and a step that would have extended over the sewer. The seat and step extend to a square masonry platform and step in the North/East corner. as the masonry step and platform are the same height as the seat and step in the West wall, we would suggest that they are apart rather than a separate feature.

column14: Rooms one, two, and three are to the East. Rooms five, six and seven are to the West.
column21: Rectangular room North/South axis. The floor obscured by earth and vegetation throughout. In the east wall there are three doorways to cubiculi (2) and (3) and fauces. And in the West wall there are three doorways to cubiculum (5) corridor (7) and dining room (6). All four walls are plaster but there is no visible decoration. High in the North wall there are 9 holes for floor joists. The placements survive at the North end of the East and west walls. In the Northeast corner of the room there is a cooking platform (6443).

column14: South/East corner of the room.
column21: Square masonry platform in the South/East corner of the room. The surface does not survive. No recess storage.

column14: Room (4) to the East.
column21: Rectangular room on an East/West axis. There is no ceiling. Floor is obscured by overgrowth. Doorway is located in the Southeast corner, opening to atrium room (4). The threshold was stone but little remains. All four walls show remnants of plaster, pinkish-red in color. No windows are evident, but a probably reconstructed opening leads to the adjoining property at 6-11-17

column14: In Southeast corner of room.
column21: There is an arched masonry cooking platform stretching along the East wall into the Southeastern corner of the room. The surface of the platform is nonextant, although the masonry arch for underneath storage is still present. Pieces of clay on the top suggest the surface may have been tilted.

column14: To the south of room (8)
column21: The kitchen is a small rectangular room in the Southwest corner of the property. There is a cooking platform (6445) in the Southeast corner of the room. The walls are ruined. No ceiling remains. The floor is overgrown. Trace evidence of plaster on the South wall. There is one brick on the South wall that appears to have two rusty metal attachments on it. Access to the kitchen would be from room (8).

column14: (9),(10) and (11) to the East.(7) and (12) to the West.
column21: A rectangular atrium- North South axis. Along the east side from the North there is a doorway to a small room - cubiculum (11), fauces and small room - cubiculum (9). The South wall survives with extensive plaster; pink upper register and white lower register. The West wall plaster survives in fragments with pink color. The wall is divided into two by a corridor leading to the rear of the property. In the southern half there is a locked doorway with signs of modern restoration or that the doorway has been blocked in the modern era. High at the North wall there is a low stone step, perhaps for stairs extending along the north wall. Fragments of plaster on the North wall, pink lower register and white above. In the north east corner of the room there are fragments of plaster from earlier phases with red plaster overlaid by black plaster. In the north west corner of the room there is a cooking platorm (6392). Floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.

column14: Northwest corner of atrium.
column21: Poorly preserved cooking platform is the Northwest corner of the atrium with arched storage recess beneath and tiled surface. Western masonry support abutts the plaster on the West wall and survives to the height of the tiled surface. Only the base survives to indicate the location of the Eastern support. The floor is obscured by lapilli.

column14: Room (1) to the North.
column21: Rectangular room; North South axis. The north wall survives only at ground level but consisted of a central pillar separating two doorways to the east and west. No visible thresholds. High in the South wall there is a chimney with a tiled lintel sloping up to the exterior beneath which along the south wall would have been a cooking platform of which no trace remains. The western third of the room was divided from the rest of the room by a plastered partitioned well. The floor in this area of the room was tiled and sloped down to the latrine (6394). High in the South wall there is plaster with no visible decoration and a circular hole - modern collapsed. No plaster on east and west walls. The eastern two thirds is obscured by lapilli.
column53: Add unassigned feature shot chimney: B/W- 12Color- 12Digital- 6

column14: Southwest corner.
column21: Latrine with masonry step. The floor to the North of the step is tiled draining down to the latrine to the South. The hole beneath the stone step allows drainage into the drain/sewer. The sewer is filled with earth. Square recess in the wall to the west of the drain above which is a second rectangular recess supporting a seat. The latrine is separated from eh rest of the room with a plastered partition wall. However, this does not survive to sufficient height to show any placing for the seat.

column14: Plan shows opening to room 12 workroom to the north.
column21: This tenuously defined room in a heavily bombed out area of the workshop is on the south side of the house.  There is only a roughly reconstruct east and reconstructed south wall to the room.  South wall has remnants of red plaster in the southeast corner of the room.  There is a clay pipe descending in the wall from the upper story which suggests the presence of a latrine.  there is also in the southeast corner a fixed pile of rubble that suggests a cooking platform (6433).  Boyce tells us that there was a lararium painting near the cooking platform.  No ceiling, no floor.  On the south wall to the west of the drain pipe are three low holes that may represent shelf placements and three higher holes that would hold joists for an upper level.  In the southwest corner of the south wall is another hole that appears to go quite some distance into the wall at head height.

column14: In southeast corner of room.
column21: In the southeast corner of the room is a masonry platform.  Short end is attached to south wall.  Drainpipe coming from floor above is located next to this platform.  No top surface.  Only masonry remains.

column14: Atrium (5) is to the east.
column21: Rectangular room.  East-west axis.  Wide doorway in the east wall to atrium (5).  No visible threshold.  Floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.  On the north wall there is extensive first style plaster with plain plaster beneath.  On the west wall there is extensive first style plaster with yellow base.  High in the center of the wall there is a square plastered window.  On the south wall there is plaster decorated red borders going down.  The difference in styles between the north, west and south walls suggests that it was redecorated.  At the west end of the south wall there is a blocked plastered couch niche.  At the west end of the north wall there is a second plastered couch niche (6435).    At the top of the north wall there is a plastered cornice for the ceiling.  On the southeast corner there is a red painted wave pattern and yellow trim.

column14: In the northwest corner of the dining room.
column21: Long rectangular couch niche blocked by rubble and modern restoration.  The niche extends along the north wall from the junction with the west wall to the center of the north wall.  Plaster survives on the interior face and on the base to support the couch there is no visible decoration.  It is not clear if this was used in the final phase or if the refill is modern.  The couch may have been plastered in its final phase.

column14: Tablinum (7) to the south.
column21: Dining room is on an east-west axis, with the door opening off of tablinum (7) to the south.  There is no ceiling.  Floor is lapilli with no sign of extant threshold in the doorway.  Room is identified as a dining room by its large size and the fact that it has two windows, one looking at at the atrium, one looking at the garden behind.  Looking at the north wall, one finds remnants of red and white plaster.  In the middle of the north wall there is also evidence of a ceiling cornice molding in white.  Wall is heavily reconstructed, with two holes above plaster level which could have held joists for an upper story.  Turning right and facing the east wall, again heavily reconstructed, you can see just a trace of the white cornice molding at ceiling height.  In the southeast corner of the room, still on the east wall, is a very small square window with a reconstructed lintel.  Directly below the window is the best preserved plaster in the room, showing a bright red lower register with a light pink plaster above.  The south wall, which contains the door, is ruin and reconstruction.  The west wall is the same.
Boyce described a fragmentary painting of the lares above the cooking platform.  No evidence remaining.

column14: This room is entered from room 1 to the south.
column21: Entering the house to the east into area one, to the left is the entrance to room five.  Entrance faces south.  Badly damaged, under roughly five feet of rubble and debris.  On the east side there is a wall, badly damaged with no traces of plaster or paint.  The interior north wall is badly damaged, with traces of plaster and paint high up on wall.  Reconstruction visible on north wall.  Possible post holes.  On the west wall basically nothing is left, very badly damaged.  Possible projection from wall.  Wall on the south had entrance.  Possible evidence of wall, few blocks remain.  No floor visible, covered by rubble.  No ceiling.

Our fourth feature on the lower level, the ground is black in an arched rectangle.  There is a serving tray with a brown casserole surrounded by two pieces of food and a pomegranate in the foreground.

column14: Room 26 to the south.
column21: Subterranean storeroom under room 32.  Accessed to south by stairs from peristyle 26.  Narrow rectangular room on east-west axis.  All walls are plastered with no visible decoration.  Recess in center of northwest wall-collapse?  Plastered vaulted ceiling.  L-shaped cooking platform (6356) along the north and west wall.  Plastered floor throughout, partially obscured by earth and debris.

column14: North end of storeroom.
column21: L-shaped preparation platform along the west and south walls.  Masonry with plastered surface.

column14: large opening to dining room 30 to west.  Possible opening to corridor to east.
column21: Preparation room has two entrances.  One to the west is large entrance into room 30 dining room.  To east side no wall remains, but may have opened to corridor to east.  Corridor is on east.  No ceiling remains.  Floor obscured by lapilli.  Room is L-shaped with five features related to a bakery placed (at time of excavation-recent) near the north wall of room.  Partial walls on west, south, north sides, badly damaged and reconstructed.  Traces of plaster on south and west portions of wall-possibly white.  As one enters from room 30, wall to the right is badly damaged, reconstructed.  Traces of white paint-possibly lower and mid register.  Lamp niche on far left high up wall perpendicular-facing west- badly damaged, with traces of plater and white paint.  Possible post hold high in center of wall.  Lower right corner in a vertica row there are three square post holes with evidence of wooden plank in middle hole.  Directly opposite are three similar square holes on the wall of the corridor.  The south wall is mostly destroyed, no traces.   Corridor to east is exterior wall to street (east).  North wall is damaged and reconstructed, with modern wooden lintel high.  Impressions in plaster running across the opening may reflect the ancient roof line.

column14: against west wall
column21: Remains of a masonry cooking platform, obscured by debris. Boyce and Warscher show this to be a cooking platform. Boyce also refers to a no longer extant lararium.

column14: corridor to the east, room 18 abuts to the south, stairs 20 abut to the north
column21: A rectangular room, north/south axis. Accessed from a corridor, east, running the length of the house. The dimensions and layout of the room are unclear as it is completely filled with debris. In the west wall there are two arches abutting the wall. Beneath the northern arch are the rubble remains of cooking platform 6358. Amongst the debris against the south wall is a carrot-shaped amphora and a fragmentary dolium.

column14: near north wall, scattered across room - not in situ
column21: 6360 rotary hand mills, five round stone bases, parts of mills, not in situ, four have square cut out openings, one smaller has roundish opening cut in top

Boyce 49-50 Lararium painting no longer extant. In the centre is a blue omphalos, around which coils a huge scaly serpent with crest and beard, and on eachside of it stands a Lar clad in bright violet Phrygian cap, blue sleeveless tunic and red pallium which flies out behind his head, and holding rhyton and situla. Each Lar stands between two laurel trees. Across the top of the painting is stretched a heavy garland.

column14: entrance on west goes directly to atrium 4
column21: Entrance: facing west off southwest side of atrium 4 - no visible remains of ceiling - floor obscured by lapilli - traces of plaster on entrance opening with red and yellow paint - very damaged. Wall to north damaged, some reconstruction- plaster with traces of paint - lower red dado with border - large mid register - maybe upper register - not much remains - faded red and yellow on wall. Wall to east badly damaged - trace of red plaster on both corners lower level. Wall to south - traces of plaster - two registers - red paint possibly remains of third border. Five round post holes high on wall - ancient metal clamps in situ in lower register and mid. Wall to west badly damaged - traces of plaster and red paint. Facing wall to left is recessed area with a modern wooden lintel. There are traces of plaster with yellow and red paint - opening - window level to adjacent room - cubiculum 7

column14: garden 7 and fountain 8 are to the east, cubiculum to the west
column21: We climb two steps from the atrium 3 to a small corridor 4. To the east are the remains of a garden wall fountain with water. To the west is a cubiculum 5. To the north is a medium sized doorway to a dining room. One enters the room from a narrow doorway in the south corner of the west wall. The floor is now mud but at the entrance is a concrete mixture. This is a typical Roman square room. There are walls to a modern ceiling and a concrete lintel. On the southeast wall is a large window opening to the garden topped with a concrete lintel. A portion of this room can be seen from the entrance. The window is set low and is high and emphasizes the garden view. All four walls show evidence of third style painting - yellow, white and red with a red dado indicating a re-design at some point. No features are evident in this room. Remnants of a corner cornice and a cornice between the window and the door.

column14: There is a latrine 9 at the east side of the room separated by a stone and ashlar wall. A shopfront 11 is to the west. An atrium (room 3 of House 7) is to the north.
column21: This is the kitchen. The room is aligned on a northeast/southwest axis. It is a narrow rectangular room with an entrance from the front shop at the west. This entrance is a very low doorway at the south corner of the west wall. There is a second low doorway in the north wall. There are windows in the north and west walls (one in each wall) In the west corner of the room is feature 3253, a cooking platform. The flooring is not visible. The walls are in a poor state of preservation but extant to the height of two storeys. Only the west and south walls preserve plaster. There is no roof. There are two tall arched niches in the south wall, west end. These are filled with ceramic tile and mortar with the insertion of ceramic pipes.

On the west end of the north wall in room 10,the kitchen, lies a low platform. The remains of this platform lie along a northeast/southwest axis. This platform abuts the north and west walls and a south delineation which runs parallel to the entrance and walk space in the kitchen. This delineation appears to be the south end of the cooking platform. The south wall is approximately 20 cm high and 1 m long. The east wall is not extant, there is no surface remaining however lapilli and broken tiles obscure the space.

column14: oven room 2 to north, property VI.6.3 to the west, Via delle Terme to south, Vicolo della Fullonica to the east.
column21: A square sales room located on the corner of Via delle Terme and Vicolo della Fullonica. The room has two large entrances from the sidewalk, one facing each street. At the northeast end of the room restored remains of a staircase are located. On the west wall, we can see holes that imply shelving was present. There are approximately four slots in the wall for shelving. In addition on the large granite corner blocks, evidence remains of two holes at the top which may have supported wood beams for a second storey and lower down at door level either a shelf or door attachment are also present on both sides. There are two holes which appear to have supported square beams and two which appear to have supported wood shelving on the east wall. There is no plaster remaining o walls which are of opus reticulatum. No floor remains, although the bakery appears to e a step up from the street. No windows are present.

column14: room 1 to the south, room 3 to the west
column21: L-shaped room with the arm north/south and the base east/west. The room extends around a northwest side of a no longer extant oven. The floor is obscured by lapilli. Only the lower courses of the walls survive with extensive restoration. In the north end of the west wall is a doorway to room 3 with a partially preserved stone threshold. At the western end of the south wall is a doorway to the salesroom 1.
Eschebach p 174 identifies this property as a bakery and the plan shows an oven. No traces remain.

column14: entrance 31 and room number 3 to the southwest
column21: This is a kitchen. It is aligned on a northeast/southwest axis and is rectangular in shape. The doorway is at the south corner of the southwest wall. There is a stone threshold. The floor in the kitchen is not visible. The south wall is brick and stone at the lower half (opus vitatem) The northeast, southeast and northwest walls are stone construction. These three walls were frescoed, with only small areas of plaster surviving. A cooking platform (3229) extends along the entire northeast wall. A latrine is located at the western corner. There is a small rectangular window in the northwest wall. Eight holes, mostly square, pierce through the northwest wall in a line roughly above the window height. To the north of the window, two holes are cut into the wall. A hole pierces through the northwest wall about a metre above the latrine. A deep hole is cut into the southwest wall near the west corner.

column14: dolium 3231 sits in situ on the north corner of cooking platform 3229. Latrine 3230 is west/southwest
column21: The cooking platform runs along a northwest/southeast axis and fills the entire wall on the northeast end of the room. The platform is approximately 40 cm high and 50 cm deep. The surface is obscured by moss and lapilli.

column14: dolium 3231 and cooking platform 3229 to the northeast
column21: This is a latrine in the west corner of the kitchen. It is placed within a small arched apse which is cut into the northwest wall. The seat extends outward along the southwest wall.
