The apse may have been faced with ceramic pieces one of which remains in situ. The drain cuts under the northwest wall.

column14: Cooking platform 3229 beneath. A latrine 3230 to the west.
column21: Situated in the north corner of room 4 on top of cooking platform 3229 between the northwest and northeast walls are the remains of a dolium which is small and made of terracotta. The shape appears to be cylindrical but only fragments remain. The height is indeterminate.

column14: atrium 2 is north
column21: One walks into this small dining room through a doorway in the north corner. The evidence we use is positional. The doorway is wide and the floor is lapilli. There is no ceiling. The walls are stone and brick. There are no signs of roof posts but we do see evidence of a ceiling (post holes) in the front room to the northwest. No windows are evident. The room looks into the atrium 2 to the north which also leads us to believe it is a dining room. There is one small patch of plaster on the southwest wall but no paint. In the south corner we see a square platform bout one third of a metre square.

column14: atrium 2 to the north, garden 6 to the south
column21: We enter the dining room 5 from a small entrance in the north wall from atrium 2. The room is rectangular and lies along a northeast/ southwest axis. The north and east walls are preserved to a second storey height while the south wall, which contains a large opening providing a view into the peristyle, is approximately two metres high on the west end and 2.5 to 3 metres high at the east end. The west wall is slightly lower that the north and east. Remnants of painted plaster remain on all four walls in red, yellow and white. An odd finding, high on the west wall, is a portion of ancient glass window pane, in situ, placed horizontally and perpendicular to the wall - perhaps an ancient shelf? The floor was cement with fragments of marble. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: room 10 is to the south, room 15 to the west
column21: We enter this dining room from room 10 through a very wie doorway with the remnants of a marble threshold. This typical Roman rectangular dining room has walls with about one third remnants of plaster. A good sized door to the west opens onto the tablinum 15 and through to the atrium 2. We see seven post holes and a high window in the north wall. This dining room, if we look out the broad entrance, overlooks a garden across room 10. Probably the final use of room 10 was as a large bronze workplace however.

column14: room 2 to the south
column21: We enter this food and drink shop - other over an ashlar threshold from the sidewalk. An interesting metal remnant is left in the threshold. The room is a good sized serving room. The major identifiable feature is a large cooking platform in the west wall. There is some plaster remaining on the north wall.

This good looking cooking platform has a small remaining front lip. A good recessed storage area is present. We see a small round window. We are surprised to see about one third of a large arch from the north wall over the cooking platform. Several tiles remain on the platform.

column14: Via Stabiana to the west, north corner of 9.1.1. and 9.2.12, feature is across the street and west of 9.1.34
column21: Stone kerbs are above the street (which is not named on Eschebach). We see painted cement and a street shrine. It can be seen as a short aedicula shrine and was decorated in antiquity. Eschebach reports a painting of two snakes alongside the altar and a basket of offerings above. The paintings are no longer extant though the whole lower portion of the wall is painted pinkish-white

column14: Latrine 7 lies to the south, corridor 5 lies to the west
column21: This is the kitchen. It is a square space on a raised platform one step up from corridor 5. It is on an east/west axis. The rubble remains of a cooking platform (3274) are in the southeast corner. The north and east walls are stone construction with traces of  plaster. The south wall is a partition between this room and the latrine (7) There is no west wall. No flooring is visible. It is all in a very poor state of preservation.
This feature may have been a cooking platform. It is in the south east corner of room 6. Presently this is just a pile of rubble.

column14: peristyle 8 to the east
column21: Rectangular room east/west axis. Wide doorway in the centre of the west wall overlooking the garden peristyle. Marble threshold with placings for the door. Modern lintel and ceiling.Mosaic paving survives throughout with white tesserae, black border and square central rosette consisting of geometric patterns and circles with images of ducks and marine life. Extensive decoration survives on all four walls. Third style decoration throughout with black lower register with architectural details, gardens and birds. Red panel above with architectural details, animals and seahorses. Yellow panels above divided by architectural borders with inserted figures and images. The centre of the south wall the (?) of cherubs. In the centre of the east wall are Theseus and Ariadne watched by Athena. In the centre of the north wall are Artemis and Callisto. On the north wall the upper register survives with further mythic scenes depicting Venus and Adonis, cupids, Leda and Tyndareus. In the northeast corner is a painting 6456.

column14: room 8 to the west
column21: This is a narrow room on an east/west axis. Entered from the west from room 8. The room is divided in half by a masonry arch. The doorway is a step up from the peristyle, with a concrete lintel indicating restoration. There is no ceiling. Floor today is covered in dirt but may have been tiled. Entering the room we see a concrete base for a cistern. Immediately to the right in the southwest corner is latrine 6455. Above the latrine and door on the west wall is evidence of a past roof line (a channel with inserts cut out of the masonry) On the northwest end of the wall, below the channel is a square post hole. No plaster remains. The south wall is heavily reconstructed, with two post holes on each side of the dividing arch. On the east wall is located cooking platform 6454 with a small square window above. The north wall contains three post holes, two to the west and one to the east of the arch. The easternmost  hole is above the cooking platform. There is probably one more hole next to the arch obscured by modern reconstruction. Wall has some faded pinkish painted plaster remaining. On the north and south walls close to the cooking platform are four or five small round holes which may have held shelves or hooks.

column14: to the east of latrine 6455
column21: This cooking platform is heavily reconstructed. It fills the east side of the room extending from the north to the south wall. Made of masonry construction. There is arched storage below. The platform has a lip and a tiled surface. On the front of the platform is a small round hole near the top left as you face it.

column14: to the west of cooking platform 6454
column21: Latrine is located in the southwest corner of the kitchen. It is divided from the cistern on the floor by a masonry wall. No trace of tiled floor remains but walls show evidence of a seat placing on thw west and south. Floor appears to slope and the space is narrow.

column14: north east corner
column21: north end of the east wall contains a figure of a partially clothed nymph. In her left hand she is holding a branch with cherries. In her right hand a platter/bowl containing cherries.

column14: atrium 2 is to the west, room 15 to the south
column21: We walk into this good sized dining room from the west from the atrium 2 which is separated from the street by the vestibule. We see another short doorway to this room obviously for slaves. Today we see an added concrete block to frame the doorway with modern wood. This is laid upon the ancient threshold. As we enter the room we see three layers of plaster, the last painted white with red touches. Traces of original floor cementicum (?) are inlaid with marble pieces. Today this room has a huge ugly modern table covered with a tarp and unusable boxes. Underneath this is a rectangular marble tiled floor design mostly greyish white marble. The central coloured marble feature in the floor (which would not have been covered by dining benches) contains feature tiles of red and white marble. Two windows are present in the room. Protective wood awnings well above eye level are present over painted areas on three walls. All that can now be seen on the west covered picture may be a deer. A large chunk has been randomly cut out near signs of a dark turquoise sky (?) with a red frame. The lower dado is black and shows green plant forms as in fourth style. The protective awning on the north wall has no painting evident though the dado and its plants remain. We wish to note that Eschebach reported that this painting was of Bellerophon or Theseus, fighting Amazons, but they were depicted wearing Roman armour. The east wall contains the two high windows either side of the protective awning. The red frame of the painting and some blue can be seen but the picture has been randomly removed. Yellow and white squares can be seen in this wall. There is a modern ceiling.

The cooking platform lies at the west end of the kitchen and consists of two separate structures which abut the west and south corners of the kitchen. The wall which is in between shows evidence of plaster painted red in antiquity as does the wall behind the western structure. The floor plan indicates that the two were connected in a U shape, however these two appear to be individual. The structure is in disrepair, each side consisting of a pile of stones with no visible surface and at their highest points about 50 cm. Each pile runs along a northeast/southwest axis on the west side of the room.

column14: storeroom 9 to the west, rooms 10 and 11 to the south
column21: The kitchen is a long narrow room which lies parallel, on a northeast/southwest axis, to the garden 12 on the north and to room 9 to the west and rooms 10 and 11 on the south. At the southwest end of the kitchen is a cooking platform or a food preparation structure. high above this structure in the wall is a circular window. The garden wall, which defines the north boundary of the room, has remnants of red painted plaster. The east wall contains doorways into the aforementioned contiguous rooms. There is no ceiling extant and the floor is covered with vegetation. In the southwest corner above the platform is a curved painted portion of the wall (niche?)

column14: atrium 2 at its east side, the garden portico 6 is to the west, the passage 4 lies to the south
column21: This is a tablinum/dining room. It is roughly on an east/west axis. This rectangular room has wide openings through both the east and west walls. Due to its location between the atrium and the garden portico it has been identified as a tablinum and dining room. This is in a very poor state of preservation with the stone walls preserved only below the ceiling level. Brickwork flanks the doorway on the western side. All walls retain the remnants of their plaster covering with traces of fresco. The dado is visible in some places and seems to be a third or fourth style painting. On the north wall there is a small section of blue painted panel just above the dado. The midsection is divided into large panels with wide red borders on the north and south walls and blue or green borders on the west wall. No flooring is visible. There is opus signinum visible only in the threshold on the east entrance. There is also a small piece of marble threshold in the east entrance with a cutting for a door.

column14: posticium 18 to the north, kitchen 3270) to the west
column21: We enter the storeroom from the west through the posticium 18. The room is square on a southeast/northwest axis. The threshold appears to have been just volcanic rock. The doorway, which has basically completely deteriorated, has a cut edge on the east side. The western portion is all but missing. Traces of red painted plaster appear on the east, south and west walls. On the east wall are two or three holes for shelf support. On the south wall is a rectangular small window, above which are five indentations which appear to have been for second storey support. On the west wall there is one hole. There is also a hole for an unknown reason from which something has been removed. It is about two m high in the southeast corner and today we can see to the outside through this hole. The east and south walls are preserved up to the second storey. The west wall is not as high and the north wall, where we enter, is only about two m at its highest. No ceiling is extant and the floor is obscured with rubble and vegetation.
Small shallow plastered kneading basin in the top of a masonry plastered support contiguous with basin 6414 to the south. The basin now contains part of a catillus of a no longer in situ mill.
Circular basalt basin directly against the oven 6417 to the north. Used to contain water for the preparation of bread. Conical interior with no visible lining.

Circular beehive oven. Well preserved tiled floor. Brick interior face preserved throughout with tiled superstructure. Basalt stoke hole. In front of the oven there is a basalt and tiled platform with openings to the east and west. In front of the platform is the arched facade to the oven facing south to the mill room. Traces of a strip of iron on the basalt stone in front of the stokehole.

column14: room 45 to the east
column21: A rectangular room, north/south axis, floor obscured by lapilli throughout. Plaster survives on all four walls with red lower register, white above. At the north end of the east wall are signs of redecoration with undercoat exposed beneath the later layer of red plaster. High at the north end of the east wall are three holes for floor joists. A further hole is in the centre of the east wall and matches four holes in the west wall. In the centre of the west wall there is a window to the street with modern lintel. High in the west wall above the north wall there is a restored window with a modern lintel. In the centre of the east wall there is a door with a modern lintel and no visible threshold to mill room 45. To the north of the doorway there is a rectangular opening to the oven with modern lintel serving as a baking area to the oven. To the south there is a small square opening in the wall with modern lintel looking into the mill room. In the centre of the west wall and in the north wall there are shelves 6420. Against the west wall there is the shaft of a tufa column and in the centre of the southern half of the room there is a kneading machine 6419.

column14: 6420 is to the north
column21: Circular basalt kneading machine. At the base of the basin there is the placing for a partly preserved iron blade of a kneading machine. In the east and west sides of the basin there are two holes in each and in the north and south side there is a single hole in each. Beneath the hole in the north face there is a small indentation in the external face of the basin.

column14: 6419 to the south
column21: In the centre of the west wall are three square holes to support three layers of shelves. At the end of the north wall there are four holes and at the west end of the north wall there are two surviving holes that would have originally supported four tiers of shelves. No shelves are visible on the south and east walls.

Opus signinum base of the water basin is directly against the east wall of the room. Only the base survives and there is no trace of the walls. The basin abuts directly against preparation platform 6423 to the north. At the base of the northeast corner of the basin continuing beneath the conjunction of 6423 and the east wall is a lead pipe draining from the basin.

column14: above the circular basin or cistern 6406 on floor and next to long cylindrical opening where pipe may have been. To west of 6404, 6402, 6401
column21: There is a small arched recessed niche on the north west wall, directly above a water feature on the floor. Facing the niche, from the corner of the walls, to the right a pipe comes in that terminates in the niche. The pipe runs to the next room from the arched niche to the northwest wall. We speculate that running water came into the niche which had a spout and water fell into the circular opening of the water feature 6406 below, thereby providing running water to the kitchen. No trace of the pipe remains.
Rectangular masonry platform with no discernible surface or exterior finish. Abuts directly against water basin 6421 to the south.

column14: atrium 19 to the north
column21: Rectangular room, east/west axis, with doorway at the west end of the north wall with marble threshold and placings for a gate. Immediately to the east of the doorway is water basin 6429. Against the west wall are stairs to the floor below. The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout. Extensive plaster survives on the north, east and south walls with a pinkish hue. At the east end of the north wall are two holes for floor joists matching holes in the south wall. High in the eastern half of the south wall are two windows that narrow to the street to the south. In the centre of the south wall is cooking platform 6430. Directly abutting the platform to the west is the masonry base of a partition wall.

column14: cooking platform 6430 to the south
column21: Square masonry platform above which there is a plaster lined basin abutting directly to the corner of the north wall. The south side of the basin does not survive. The west side of the basin and its plaster face survive at the junction of the north and west walls. Plaster lined base of the basin is partly obscured by debris.

column14: water basin 6429 to the north
column21: Low rectangular platform against the centre of the south wall. Masonry with fragments of a tile surface. No visible storage or lip. Abuts directly against the south wall. To the west of the platform are the fragments of a partition wall only the base of which survives.

column14: atrium 9 to the south
column21: Rectangular room on an east/west axis. Doorway at the east end of the south wall opens to atrium 9. Marble threshold with placings for a door. Fragments of a mosaic floor survive along the north wall and most extensively in the northeast corner with a white interior enclosed by a black border. There are wide modern windows in the south, west and north walls - it is not clear if these existed in antiquity. Fragments of plaster survive on the east wall nd adjoining corners as well as the northwest and southwest corners. The plaster is red in colour with traces of borders but the colour is not discernible. Two tall rectangular blocked windows (?) in the east wall.

column14: southwest corner of room 2 adjoins street to the south, wall between rooms 1 and 2 to the west.
column21: Entering from entrance 6.4.10, immediately to the east is kitchen 2. On the southwest corner are two waist high masonry supports with an approximate gap of 2 feet between them, both attached at their short end to the south wall. One is attached by its length to the west wall of the kitchen. The easternmost of the pair appears to have a sight L-shape with the bottom of the L attached to the south wall.

column14: atrium 4 to the south
column21: Rectangular room, north/south axis. The entire south wall is absent to provide access to atrium 4. The floor is obscured by lapilli. The north, east and west walls are extremely restored. At the base of the north end of the wet wall there is a couch niche 6259. Trace of undecorated plaster on west wall.

Low arched niche only partly visible above the lapilli that cover the floor. Traces of red painted plaster survive on the interior of the niche. The niche is located at the north end of the west wall.

column14: the street is to the south, adjoining property to east, north is cubiculum 8 and atrium 9
column21: The structure and room's primary access is north/south. The room is entered from the northwest corner of the north wall.  Plaster is extant on north, south, east and west walls. Unsure of fresco style. Window on the south wall with sill 1.5 m above the floor - looks out on the vicolo. Floor is stone rubble. North, south and west walls are opus mixtum. This is a dining room because of its size and the view to the atrium 9.

column14: to the south are ala 10 and atrium 9, to the east is the vicolo, to the north is the kitchen 14, to the west is the tablinum 12
column21: The room is entered from the southwest and is oriented primarily north/south. All four walls have plaster extant, likely fourth style. The lowest register is primarily red. The middle register is yellow ochre in color. These are panelised with painted frames, topped with a plaster sigma relief with some garland/ribbon painted detail extant. The yop register is a yellow ochre topped by a plaster cornice with floral relief. East wall has a window - sill, situated 2 m above the stone rubble floor. This is a dining room because of the size, decor and view south to the atrium. Modern reconstruction is evident on the west wall. Walls are partially capped with modern terracotta tiles. The north, south and west walls are opus mixtum. Doorway shows no threshold or evidence of a door having been in place.

column14: room 15 to the west
column21: This is a square room with a doorway in the centre of the west wall with a modern lintel and no threshold. The floor is obscured by lapilli. There is undecorated plaster on all four walls. High in the centre of the east wall is a large window opening to the street, with a modern lintel. Three quarters of the east wall beneath the window is taken up by a large rectangular cooking platform 6197. In the southeast corner there is a latrine 6198.

column14: latrine 6198 to the south
column21: This is a rctangular cooking platform with tiled surface and two arched recesses. Above in the east wall is a large window to the street. Fragmets of undecorated plaster survive on the northern and southern ends of the face.

column14: cooking platform 6197 to the north
column21: This is a narrow alcove between the cooking platform and the south wall in the southeast corner of the room. The floor is completely obscured by lapilli. Possible tile masonry lip at the base of the east wall above which there is a terracotta pipe draining to the street outside. As any drain or floor is completely obscured by lapilli its identification as a latrine is based on location and the drain.

column14: the complete mill 3207, meta and basin 3227, catillus 3226 are all to the southwest
column21: Mayeske did not report the presence of this feature behind the completed mill in 1971. Today about one third of the bottom is missing and there are three holes for wood posts. A central post is used to turn the interior workings. It is in the east corner. It could have been worked in this location it is one inch away from the southeast wall and the northeast wall. it is about 1 m tall. Three holes are evident - one is partially broken where the bottom is missing.

This is a square structure which takes up the east corner of the room betwen entrances to rooms 2 and 4. This platform is low and made of volcanic stone and abuts the northeast and southeast walls. The platform is approximately 50 cm high and 60 cm wide and deep.

column14: cistern 3216 to the south, kneading basin 3222, mills 3207, 3227, 3226, 3206 to the southeast
column21: This cylindrical tufa water basin is in the north corner. It has a crack but is otherwise in good condition. it is approximately 1 m tall. It abuts the northwest and northeast walls which are plastered and painted yellow.

column14: meta and basin 3206 to the southwest;  meta 3227, mill 3207 and kneading basin 3222 to the northeast; water basin 3225 and cistern 3216 to the northwest
column21: This is a catillus in the usual hourglass formation. It is labelled with engraved letters or numbers. It is located on the ground against the southeast wall. It is in good condition.

column14: mill 3207 and kneading basin 3222 to the northeast; catillus 3226 and mill 3206 to the southwest; water basin 3225 and cistern 3216 to the northwest
column21: A solid lava block is shaped for a base as a meta. We see paving stones around this feature. There is no catillus. It is approximately 30 cm from the southeast wall which is confusing as there is no space for ananimal to walk around it.

column14: water basin 3129 is directly below it on the southwest wall, oven 3197 is to the northeast; water cistern 3218 is to the southeast.
column21: The lararium is on the southwest wall about one and a half metres from the ground. It is plastered and is above the water basin 3129.

column14: street to west, rooms 13 to the northwest and 14 to the north
column21: Rectangular room, north/south axis, floor obscured by lapilli and weeds. Walls have signs of extensive restoration. Across the north wall are stairs to the floor above accessed from entrance 1 to the northwest. In the centre of the west wall is a wide open door with a step to the street outside. In the centre of the east wall is a wide doorway to 14. In the southwest corner is a masonry support for a preparation platform 6124. In the southeast corner is a cooking platform 6123.

column14: 6124 to the west
column21: Rectangular cooking platform with tiled surface preserved throughout. Arched recess storage area beneath. In the southeast corner there is a tile hearth, partially preserved, and showing a brick stamp.

column14: salesroom 12 to east; entered from area 10 on the northeast and to the northwest of room 5 and to the southeast of rooms 14 nd 15.
column21: Small square room immediately to the east of salesroom 12. No decoration on walls. Door opening is from a small area on the northeast wall. No floor remains.

column14: room 30 to the south
column21: Square room with doorway in centre of south wall to room 30. Floor is obscured by lapilli. Plaster survives on all four walls with red lower register and white above. High at the south end of the east wall are holes for three floor joists for the floor above. Against the north wall are four large rectangular buttresses possibly supporting storage. They are plastered with red lower register and white above contiguous to the plaster on the adjoining walls.

column14: atrium 2 to the west
column21: This is a small dining room. It is n a northwest/southeast axis. There are two entrances. One can enter through a narrow door from the fauces at the southeast corner of the room  or through a wider door on the west wall from the atrium. There is a window in the west wall. The surface of the floor is not visible. Two small slit windows are on the upper east wall. A couch niche 3285 is adjacent to the small door in the south wall. Traces of plaster remain on the walls and decorative first style mouded panels are preserved n the north and east walls. There are three levels of cornice moulding at the upper portion of the wall.

This hearth in atrium 2 is square and approximately one metre by one metre and 30 cm high. It is located about 40 cm from the entrance to room 7 and one metre from the southeastern corner of the atrium. It is made of volcanic rock and plaster remains on the surface. Itabuts the east wall.

column14: dining room 3276 to the northeast
column21: We enter the large Tuscan style atrium from the northeast fauces to the street. Just off centre from this entrance are the remains of an impluvium made of opus signinum which appears to have been square. The room is in disrepair. It runs along a northeast/southwest axis. On the eastern corner of the impluvium is a large, ancient cistern cover and to the east of this cistern cover, abutting the eastern portion of the east wall is a square hearth which is approximately one metre square and 3o cm high. The placement of the hearth is between the entrance to room 7 and the corner of the atrium. Evidence of plaster painted red remains on aspects of all the walls.  In the south wall are doorways with the tablinum in the middle formed by ashlar blocks of sarno stone covered with plaster. The height of the walls, in most places is above the first storey level. On the western end of the north wall are two lararia the smaller one lower, the larger being more visible and higher. There is a window and a doorway on the north corner of the west wall to room 8. The floor is obscured with lapilli and vegetation. The ceiling is not extant.

column14: dining room 3288 to the north, garden 11 to the west.
column21: We walk through corridor 8 and turn south into a corridor to the furthest triclinium. We enter via a lava threshold into a good sized dining room. This dining room has a broad door overlooking the colonnaded garden. Earlier reports identify a window on the south wall - no longer extant. On the north wall is a good sized bench niche. The floor is modern lapilli. On the north wall is a narrow doorway to the adjoining dining room 3280. The separating wall is just waist high. On all of the walls are small patches of cement and plaster and some red and yellow paint.

column14: adjoins dining room 12 (3279) and overooks the colonnaded garden 11 and is alongside corridor 8 to the north
column21: We enter this larger dining room from the west from a narrow corridor off garden 11 to a no longer extant entrance. The floor is lapilli and rubble. There is little plaster or paint in this room except for a patch on the north wall. Here we can see the ubiquitous white/yellow so common in this insula. The adjoining dining room 12 (3279) is connected by a narrow doorway to the south wall.
On the north wall of dining room 12 there is a niche backing on to the east wall. It is a moderate size with a minimal indentation. It has been plastered and painted red.

column14: andron 8 to the south,
column21: This is the kitchen. Its alignment is east/west. One enters from the andron 8 through a door in the south wall at the southwest corner of the room. There are two preparation platforms - 3283 is in the northwest corner, platform 3284 is along the full length of the eastern wall. The stone walls have no plaster remaining. The floor is not visible. the walls are preserved only to a low height.

column14: west of preparation platform 3284, directly opposite the entrance
column21: This is a rectangular stone preparation platform. There is a square level with a ceramic surface and then the platform steps up at the eastern end to a higher surface. This is in poor condition and located at the northwest corner of the kitchen.

column14: preparation platform 3283 lies to the west
column21: This is an L-shaped stone preparation platform. It is preserved only to a very low height. It is located in the north and east walls and is in very poor condition.
This niche is a low couch niche identifiable by a small concavity in the lower portion of the wall. Some plaster remains on the surface.

column14: corridor 13 to the south
column21: Room axis is east/west. One enters through a large formal entrance from corridor 13. The floor is obscured by lapilli over most of its surface but an area on the southern side is covered by patterned marble mosaic floor containing several colours. The room has undergone several renovations (at least two) in antiquity and wall painting from two phases is visible in different plaster layers. The north wall is badly damaged. In the lower register there are traces of an original painting with overlying renovation. Behind the original plaster there is evidence of tile. Colours of the renovated layer are yellow, red and green. On the west wall the tile continues. The wall is badly damaged. There are traces of red, blue and green painted plaster on the outer layer. High on the walls there are traces of plaster moulding. Above this is a circular opening. The south wall is badly damaged. There is no tile. There is evidence of two plaster layers as elsewhere. The east wall on either side of the entrance is also badly damaged. Traces of two layers of painted plaster remain on the northeast section. There is no tile. There is a marble table in the centre of the room that may be in its original position.

column14: room 17to the north; room 20 to the east
column21: Rectangular room, east/west axis. Doorway with stone stepped threshold and modern lintel in the centre of the north wall to rooms 17 and 18. At the south end of the east wall there is a doorway with stone threshold and modern lintel to room 20 to the east. Plaster survives in the north corner of the east wall adjoining lararium 6326 in the north wall, pink in colour. The upper corner of all four walls are modern restorations. High on the east wall there is a blocked doorway or window. Above the lararium in the east wall there is a recess for a sloping roof (modern?) Plaster survives in fragments along the north wall; ink lower register, white above. In the centre of the north wall there is a low partition wall with modern restoration. In the northwest corner there is latrine 6328. To the south of the latrine there is a partition wall that separates the latrine from cooking platform 6327 inthe southwest corner. Undecorated plaster fragments survive in the west wall. A window high in the centre of the west wall partially survives. Plaster survives in the south wall with pink lower register. In the centre of the south wall there is a small recess - for a candle or similar? Floor is obscured by lapilli although beaten earth/masonry floor survives in the west half of the room.

column14: in northeast corner, 6329, 6334 to the south; 6328, 6327 to the west; 6335 to the southwest
column21: Arched, plastered lararium niche with moulded edge. White plaster with burgundy trim. On northeast wall of the kitchen 16. Burgundy extends to ledge. White plastered background with traces of original figures. Below the ledge is the remains of a painted lararium with burgundy border, badly damaged. Traces of a serpent in red and yellow on right side. Yellow figure discernible on left side. According to Boyce p 167, on the back wall of the niche was painted a genius holding in his right hand a patera over a flaming altar, a painted Lar and a coiled snake with a beard facing the altar

column14: 6328 to the north; 6335, 6329, 6326 to the east
column21: Large masonry L-shaped cooking platform in the southwest corner of the room. The longer arm abuts the west wall of the room. The exterior faces of the platform are faced with undecorated plaster. The surface is lined with cement - modern restoration. The platform is separated from latrine 6328 to the north by a partition wall.

column14: 6327, 6335 to the south; 6334, 6329, 6326 to the east
column21: Latrine located in the northwest corner of the kitchen. Separated from cooking platform 6327 to the south by a partition wall. The floor is separated from the rest of the room by a step up. Tile floor survives throughout and slopes down to the west to a drain that extends through the wall to the west. On either side of the drain abutting the west wall are two masonry supports for the seat. The form of the supports is: two low supports for a step that extends into a recess in the south wall. Plaster survives on the north, west and south walls with pink colouring on the south and west walls. Plastered moulding survives at the base of the south wall.

column14: 6326 to the north; 6334 to the south; 6335, 6327, 6328 to the west
column21: Small tufa altar. Moulded base and lip with a scroll decoration with recessed top. No inscription. The rear face is undecorated.

column14: room 18 to the west; room 16 to the south
column21: Rectangular room with a north/south axis. Originally a single room with 18 but subsequently separated by a partition wall (west) containing doorway to 18. Doorway in the south wall to kitchen 16 with stone step threshold and a modern lintel. Plaster survives on the east wall and the northeast corner where it is pink in colour. Plastered moulding survives at the base of the north wall at its junction with the west wall. High in the north wall between rooms 17 and 18 there is a window to the garden with a modern lintel. At the top of the wall there is a possible window in the second storey. At the east end of the north wall there is preparation platform 6331. Floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.
Rectangular stone preparation platform with modern cement extending from the east corner along the north wall.

column14: room 17 to the east
column21: Rectangular room with a north/south axis. Originally a single room with 17 to the east separated by poorly preserved and extensively restored partition wall containing a doorway into the room. No visible threshold. Floor is obscured by lapilli throughout. Plaster survives on the northwest walls, pink in colour. Plaster moulding survives at the base of the north wall at the junction with the east wall. In the centre of the north wall, between rooms 17 and 18 there is a window into the garden with a modern lintel. Above the window in the western half of the north wall are four holes for floor joists for the second storey. Above the window is a possible window in the second storey. In the southwest corner, extending from the corner to the middle of the room is a latrine consisting of two stone supports between which the floor slopes to a central drain. The drain is filled with lapilli, no trace of the seat survives. In front of the east support is a square basalt block containing a square hole to support a no longer extant feature.

column14: garden 24 to the south; room 26 to the west
column21: One enters the garden containing the outdoor dining room from the south. The garden and dining room are on a north/south axis. The floor shows evidence of white tesserae that presumably form part of a mosaic floor. Only a small area of white tesserae remain in the northwest corner. The entrance into the dining garden was possibly raised. There are fragments of marble floor at the perimeter. To the north are two columns semi-attached to the north wall. They show attached fragments of blue-green marble. Four further column remains are to the west and east - two on each side - the two on the west are reconstructed. The garden dining room was covered but the nature of the roof is indeterminate. On the east side the dining garden was open to a space that may have been planted. To the north there is a wall. Very little plaster or painting remains - a very small fragment in the northwest corner shows traces of red paint. At roof height there are four square post holes. There is evidence of a pedimental roof above, the nature of which is quite uncertain. The edges of the roof may have been supported by columns. There are three niches in the north wall - traces of marble remain in them. The central niche is apse-shaped. The two on either side are rectangular. To the west the ding room opens to a covered colonnade. Off the colonnade to the northwest there are three marble steps leading to a painted room (26) Clearly visible from the garden dining room was a mosaic on the west wall of the colonnade (Achilles disguised as a woman) To the south of the garden dining room a circular pool and fountain would be visible.

column14: 6329, 6326 to the north; 6328, 6327, 6335 to the west
column21: This feature is a conical hand quern. The rim is partially preserved. Possibly not in situ.

column14: 6334,6329,6326 to the east; 6327 to the west; 6328 to the north.
column21: This feature is a fragment of a rotary hand mill. Possibly not in situ.

column14: room 3 to the north
column21: Large rectangular room, north/south axis. Floor obscured by lapilli and earth. The south wall consists of a wide open doorway to the street to the south with fragmentary stone threshold. In the centre of the west wall is a wide doorway to the street to the west with a fragmentary stone threshold. At the north end of the wets wall there is a doorway with a stone stepped threshold which Eschebach says accessed stairs to the floor above. At the west end of the north wall a terracotta downpipe is embedded into the wall and drains out through a square hole at the base of the wall. In the west wall there are two holes for shelves. Undecorated plaster is on the north wall and in the southeast and southwest walls. Several small holes for 3 to 4 sets of shelves are located along the east wall.

column14: tablinum 7 to the north, kitchen 10 to the east, storage room 17 to the west
column21: We nter this dining garden from a tablinum 7 which is open. The garden is a rectangle. Immediately to the west wall is a stairway and a low entrance to a storage room 3849 with a low door to a good sized storage area under the stairs. This west wall also shows two cubicula. Eschebach reports that there was a large animal painting on the south wall. There is also a very high lararium or lamp holding area on this wall. It is arched and has a shelf. The dining grden is paved with some opus sectile appearing. The garden is contained by a low wall with four columns showing red plaster at the bottom. Within this wall is a large masonry summer triclinium 3842. We see a round table with six arched niches at the base. The lectus immus has an extension that Mau says is for children, but could also be a miniature serving platform. Within the low wall and around the triclinium is pounded mud. This dining garden is certainly open to the sky. The east wall shows some red plaster on the lowest level, and the entrance to the kitchen is also on this wall.
This large outdoor triclinium, with a table in the middle is medius 4.10 m; immus 3.86 m; summus 3.12 m. It is a mixture of stones and brick as is the table

column14: room 13 to the west, room 12 to the south, room 9 to the north
column21: One enters the kitchen from the northwest from an andron 7 or from the street entrance doorway on the northeast (9.5.13). The space is delineated on the northwest and southeast by remnants of walls or partitions and the edge of the street entrance. Surrounding walls extend to second storey height. Evidence of some plaster remains above the cooking platform which abuts approximately half of the northwest wall and half of the northeast wall. The kitchen platform is about two and a half feet from the ground and is poorly preserved, but intact. There is no ceiling extant. The floor is covered with vegetation and debris.

The cooking platform is composed of rubble and mortar. Traces of plaster can be seen on the southwest face low on the western corner which abuts the northwest wall. The surface is obscured but it appears that some reconstruction cement runs around the edges. The structure is located in the north corner of the room with the longer edge streetside, abutting both northeast and northwest walls. The structure is approximately three feet high and deep and four feet long.

column14: room 20 to southeast, tablinum 7 to the southwest
column21: This is a rectangular dining room aligned on a northeast/southwest axis. One enters through a doorway with a white marble threshold, in the northern corner of the room. Directly opposite the door on the southeast wall there is a large window looking out to the peristyle 13. The condition of this room is fair. A cement floor is visible only in parts. The ceiling no longer remains. There is heavy reconstruction including the lintels, upper walls and a corrugated roof. The four walls preserve a good deal of painted plaster and parts of cornice moulding can be seen on the top of each wall. The southwest wall has its moulding preserved across the entire wall with horizontal mouldings in the corner stepping up into the centre to an arched central section. Although the paint in this room is not well preserved one can still see a dado decorated with intricate yellow bands. The central zone seems to be fourth style with large panels enclosed by red borders. The upper zone only faintly presents what may be fourth style open areas. Along the wall there is a large hole - now filled in - that may be a robber's hole.

column14: Sales room (1) to the north, Preparation room (9) to the southeast, Hallway (4) to the southwest.
column21: This square mill room has a typical bakery floor around the rubble bases of basalt stones. Away from the bases, the floor is pounded mud and lapilli. On the north walls is the entrance to sales room (1). The east wall is built to the second floor. The west wall shows three large piers. The first large opening leads to preparation room (9), the second to hallway four and the third is a small wall and a space for storing grain. Behind the west wall rises to a second floor and shows little plaster. The rubble blocks are an appropriate size for the mill bases, so there is probably little reconstruction. At the south opening is a complete mill but the catillus is probably not original to this meta. On the west wall we see a broken catillus and a carved basin.

column14: Mill (3862) to the north, mill (3865) to the southeast.
column21: This rubble base has some damage. It is surrounded by lava stones.

column14: Base (3864) to the east, base (3862) to the south.
column21: The first rubble base shows damage to one third of the structure. It is surrounded by lava stones.

column14: Mill base (3863) to the west, mill base (3865) to the south.
column21: Base 3864 is quite complete and surrounded by lava stones.

column14: Mill base (3862) to the northwest, mill base (3864) to the north.
column21: Base 3865 holds a meta and catillus. The catillus appears to be too small to grind effectively.

column14: This room is contiguous to room (8) on the southeast and the preparation room (3) to the north and room (5) to the northwest.
column21: We enter the oven room from the northwest. The oven room runs along a northeast/southwest axis with the oven filling two thirds of the room and this includes the oven surround. the room is vaulted over the oven until it is bisected by passageways on the northwest and southeast. In the southwest corner of the room is a large water pipe which flows into a large dolium basin that abuts northwest and southwest walls. On the southeast side of this well preserved basin appears to have been a second basin in the same mounting. Plaster painted red is evident along the pipe on the southwest wall and behind the second basin. A pile of rubble is in the southeast corner of the room next to the northeast/southeast walls. On the northwest wall is a passthrough from the preparation room to the northwest. The opening is the width of a large terra cotta drain tile and is approximately as high as the length of a drain tile. The oven abuts a wall in this vaulted room which was painted in antiquity on both the northwest and southeast walls which suggests that the room was repurposed in antiquity.

column14: It's contiguous to feature (3876) (basin) to the southwest.
column21: This oven is a large beehive oven. It takes up two thirds of the room space of room (6). The oven appears to be in good shape, and was placed in the room, which had previously been plastered. From the ground level the oven structure extends vertically about six feet above which the ceiling is vaulted for six additional feet. The ledge of the oven is composed of lava stones which lie low from the ground. Four or five pieces of terra cotta remain on top of this ledge on the southwest and west. A large passthrough from room (3) to the northwest is lined with a terra cotta drain tile. The opening to the oven is composed of lava stones, which appear to be three stones. The inside of the oven is covered with ash on the bottom, but the spaces around, which form the inside of the brick oven appear to be in good shape. There appears to be a stone slab under the ash towards the eastern corner. The central circular top of the oven on the exterior is in place. Two holes which can't be observed from inside this oven seem to be venting on the southeast wall into room (8). There are some holes on the southeast and northwest walls toward the north end, but the function is unknown. Modern structural supports for ceiling in wall are in front of the oven today.

column14: Street, and mill room (3861) to the south.
column21: We enter this bakery from door (4). There are stones demarcating the entrance from a wide sidewalk of mud and lapilli. The rectangular shop room with walls to a second floor. On the north wall is a rectangular window and on the lower zone is some orange plaster. The east wall also has orange plaster on the lower zone. The south wall has some remaining orange plaster and a door in the northwest corner leading to the mill room (3861). The floor is covered by lapilli. There is no ceiling.

column14: This room is to the northwest of the oven (room 6). It is southeast of prep room (9).
column21: This is a preparation room, it is aligned on a southeast northwest axis. One enters through a doorway on the middle of the northwest wall. This rectangular room is in very poor condition. Plaster remains on the northwest, southwest and northeast walls. No painted decoration survives. The floor is not visible. The ceiling is non extant, however, rows of joist holes remain in both the northeast and southwest walls. A large, heavy kneading basin is in situ in the center of the room (3871). A lead lined catillus coverted to a basin is located in the west corner (3870). A pass through (3873) to the oven cuts through the southeast wall in the south corner. A niche cupboard is located in the southeast wall just east of the pass through (3872).

column14: This feature is in the northwest corner of the room. It is west of the keading basin (3871) in the center of the room. It is across the room from the oven pass through.
column21: This lead lined basin is a reused catillus which has been placed upside down. The bottom coating of lead is intact. Above this a mortar and ceramic tile coating went up the side of the basin. The area behind the basin is not excavated.

column14: The kneading basin lies central in the room. Other-basin lies to the northwest.
column21: This basalt kneading basin is very wide, only one place is visible on the side for the wood or metal fittings. The bottom of the basin shows a round plug for the fittings of the inner machinery.

column14: This niche cupboard is directly east of the oven pass through (3873). It is southeast of the kneading basin located in the center of the room (3871)
column21: This niche cupboard is in the southeast wall of prep room three. It is in the center of the wall and is a deep rectangular space. There are drilled channels that supported three shelves. This has been reconstructed with a wooden top and a re-plastered back surface.

column14: Adjacent in the south wall to niche-cupboard (3872)
column21: This oven pass through is on the south wall of the preparation room leading to the front of the oven (3867). It has a floor made of a roof tile sloping to enable easy access to the baker at the front of the oven (3867).

column14: This room is located to the southeast of the mill room. It is northwest of prep room (3).
column21: This is a preparation room. It is a square room. There is a wide opening at the northwest side of the room to the mill room. There is a small doorway on the southeast side of the room to another prep room (room 3). The northwest wall is left open with brick and stonework piers at the north and west corners. The southeast wall is also brick and stone masonry up to the height of the doorway lentil. Above the height of the lentil is a rubble mortar wall, the same as northeast and southwest walls. Some plaster remains on the southwest wall, no paint remains. The floors are not visible, however, the paving stones of the mill room extend to the inner side of the north corner pier. A basin fashioned from a catillus is located in the western corner of the room (3874). This room is in very poor condition.

column14: This basin is in the western corner of the room, and is just to the south of the doorway from the mill room (2).
column21: This basin is a re used catillus which is placed upside down in the western corner of the room. It may have held a ceramic basin. There is also the remains of a large ceramic basin which may have been placed in the catillus. This catillus seems to be leveled with a large stone beneath it. The western corner behind the basin is not excavated.

column14: It is contiguous to the oven (3867) to the northeast.
column21: This water feature which is located along the southwest wall of the oven room is a rubble and mortar structure which apparently held two basins. The western most is a dolium which is surrounded by the support and remains in relatively good shape with the exception of a crack. n the western corner is also a large terra cotta water pipe which was added in antiquity to flow into the basin, probably from a second story. It is surrounded by brick and mortar behind which pre existing plaster, painted red, is evident. The second basin which is now in pieces lies to the southeast of the first basin. Only an outline on the northwest face of the support indicates its location in antiquity. Plaster remains on the wall. Behind this basin, the support, and the pile of rubble is the southeast wall on the southwestern side of the passageway through room six.

column14: Contiguous to room (6) to the northwest.
column21: This processing room is entered from the oven room which is to the northwest. The room is in a state of disrepair, but runs along the northeast/southwest axis. On the northeast wall is evidence of a vaulted ceiling and on the southeast a low wall appears to be added in antiquity to repurpose the room. Small patches of plaster are evident. The floor is obscured with rubble and debris and on the northwest wall there appear two holes that may vent the oven. There is no ceiling extant.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest and northwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the southwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the northwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the northwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the northwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

Due to its proximity with the as yet uncompleted Central Baths, it is probable that this shop, one of eleven which surround the Central Baths of insula 4, was a large food and drink shop. It is entered by one step up through an open store front from the northwest. The floor is rubble. The reconstructed walls are extant to a first floor level. There is no remaining plaster.

column14: street is to south, preparation room 2 (6500) to the north
column21: Sales room is entered from the street to the south and, on its north/south axis, has a central doorway opening to preparation room 2. Entry and doorway sides are of brick, remainder of walls are of opus incertum. There are only faint traces of plaster on the walls. On the west wall one finds eight existing post holes for shelf 6509. The bottom of the wall shows some areas that are impressions of dolia or other objects which were there in the past. The north wall has two post holes, one in the brick to the west one higher up in the masonry to the east. The east wall has six shelf/post holes and one tiny square window to the street next to it. Floor is obscured by dirt and lapilli. Streetside entrance has a stone threshold with door placements. There is no ceiling. Large dolium 6507 is embedded in the southwest corner of the room. Eschebach suggests this was an olive oil shop.

column14: sale room 1 to the south
column21: Squarish room 2 opens to the north to salesroom 1. The doorway is narrow with reconstructed brick facing on both sides. The west wall is opus incertum with two high post holes near the north and south ends. At the southwest end are the remains of an embedded dolium 6508. The north wall contains slight traces of painted plaster (red and white?) The east wall has three brick structures at its current top, which may have been windows opening to the street to the east. There are two post holes, one at window height, one slightly lower. A brick arch in the masonry at floor level provided structural support. In the south east corner of the room are three stone steps. The south wall is masonry with faint plaster trace and brick facing around the doorway. There are two joist holes in that wall, one on either side of the door. Floor is obscured by lapilli. No ceiling remains. Eschebach says that this was an olive oil distributor.

column14: south of shelves 6509
column21: A large round dolium is located in the southwest corner of salesroom 1. Dolium has a crack along the bottom and several chips around its top lip. A metal attachment (not repair) is visible on its north side. Dolium is filled with lapilli and dirt. It may have been embedded in its spot.
Trace remains of a clay dolium are found in the southwest corner of preparation room 2. Eschebach suggests that a water basin was also present in the vicinity.

column14: all north of 6507 dolium
column21: The northeast and west walls contain a series of post holes indicating the presence of display shelves around this shop. The west wall contains pairs of four and the east wall has two regularly spaced pairs. Another four holes are scattered with no regular patterns throughout the shop.
Eschebach pp 184-185 refers to a second dolium in room 2 that is no longer extant.

column14: contiguous to storeroom 31 to the northeast and latrine 33 to the southwest. Corridor 28 is to the northwest
column21: This rectangular storeroom runs along a northeast/southwest axis. One enters from the northwest. The room is in a total state of disrepair with piled rocks, rubble and vegetation obscuring the floor. There is a large portion of the southeast wall missing, from which one can see the street. Some red painted plaster remains on this wall in the east corner. There is no ceiling extant.

column14: contiguous to storeroom 30, to the southwest and to kitchen 29 to the northeast and corridor 28 to the northwest.
column21: This small storeroom runs along a northwest/southeast axis. One enters from the northwest. The room is in a total state of disrepair with piled rubble, rocks and debris. There is a large portion of the southeast wall missing from which we can see the street. Some red painted plaster remains on the same wall next to the hole. There are some pieces of support high on the northeast wall. There is no ceiling extant. The room is approximately four feet wide.

column14: southeast of room 20's central displuvium
column21: This preparation/cooking platform is approximately five feet long along the southeast wall and on the northeast wall approximately three feet deep. Today this platform is in a state of disrepair and is covered with debris and vegetation and is made of rubble and mortar. At its highest point, it is approximately three feet high and is in the corner.

column14: to the east of basin 3926
column21: This is a small dolium. It is located about midway across the southeast wall. It is partially submerged (about two thirds) below ground level and stands at a sight angle. This is complete except for several small chips missing from the rim.

column14: to southwest of dolium 3925, in the southern corner of the room
column21: This is the remains of a rectanguar basin in the south corner of the room. It is in very poor condition. It is visible to about six inches in depth and seems to have had ceramic tile lining along the northwest edge. The use of this basin cannot be determined.

column14: lies along the southeast wall opposite the L-shaped platform.
column21: Only the lower courses of a small platform remain, this forms a rectangle sticking outward from the centre of the southeast wall. The nature of this platform cannot be ascertained from the scanty remains

column14: counter 6460 to north, counter 6458 to dolium 6459 to east.
column21: Low cement bench/step directly inside entrance 6.8.7 sits at the south end of the masonry counter 6460. Bench runs the width of counter.

column14: runs across east wall of room 2, mortar 6465 to east
column21: A large rectangular masonry counter takes up the entire east end of counter room 2. Two large round dolia are embedded into the counter. Dolia have a wide lip and are embedded in a tile surface. Counter is reconstructed of terracotta covered tiles on the top and masonry construction below. Dolia are filled with rubble.

column14: north of counter room 1, west of storeroom 3, north of corridor 4
column21: Room 2 is on a north/south axis immediately to the north of counter room 6460 and west of storeroom 3 (6464). There is a north opening to corridor 4. North wall is part of counter 6468. Northwest corner is brick wall. West wall is opus incertum with counter 6462 running the entire length. South wall is brick, simply dividing off the space from counter room 1 (6457) East part of room is open to corridor 4 and storeroom 3. There is no ceiling. Floor is obscured by lapilli and dirt. Located in the room is a stone object which the tour guide describes as a phallic symbol. Its use is undetermined. At the far eastern end of the room is mortar 6465.

column14: north of counter room 1
column21: Opening directly from counter room 1, this is a small rectangular storeroom on a north/south axis. There is no ceiling. Floor is of obscured by dirt and lapilli. Walls are opus incertum and heavily reconstructed. There is no wall in the south end of this room. On the east, the wall contains a plastered niche housing remnants of a terracotta drainpipe. Remnants of plaster also remain on north wall. Dolium 6466 appears to be embedded in the northeast corner of the room in front of the niche. Currently a stray meta sits in the centre of the room.

column14: to east of counter 6462
column21: Standing about a metre high, the mortar appears to be embedded in the lapilli floor. It is made of waterproof concrete and two iron hardware pieces show repair of cracks on the top surface. The shape is cylindrical, tapering towards the floor. It has two protuberances across from each other that are shaped like an upside down 'U' which may have been handles. Mortar is currently filled with lapilli.

column14: sits in northeast corner of room 3 (6464)
column21: Round terracotta dolium is embedded into the earth in the northeast corner of  room 3 (6464) Visible portion of the dolium stands about knee high and tapers to a neck with a flared lip. On the lip is a metal attachment which may have connected a lid to the lower part. A round stone piece currently sits inside the dolium and may have been the lid to a similar feature.

column14: dining room 8 to north, corridor 4 to the east, counter room 2 to the south
column21: Rectangular room on a north/south axis. The preparation room is entered from room 8 to the north of corridor 4 to the east. Bricked columns and pillars delineate the entrances. There is a stone threshold to corridor 4. Floor is obscured by lapilli. Only the west wall is at full height. The east wall is knee high. At the south end of the room is located counter 6468. The room has no ceiling. A misplaced meta is located in this room. in front of the counter in the southwest corner is a red coloured tiled pad.

column14: to the east of water feature 6473
column21: Rectangular counter delineates south wall of room 5 (6467) Counter contains one dolium, water feature 6473 and a hearth. Pot is located centrally in the eastern two thirds of the counter. With rectangular opening for the hearth contiguous to the north. One corner of the counter fits around a brick entrance pillar to room 5. The exterior eastern and southern edges of the counter are covered in brick where they face rooms 4 and 2

column14: It is adjacent to room 6 (N.E.)
column21: We enter this kitchen from room 6 on the S.E. wall. The room is contiguous to a room filled with roof tiles to the N.E. with signs of a roof. On the N.W. wall is a toilet. The floor is of pounded soil and lapilli. The space appears to be unroofed with 3 walls undecorated plaster and one-half of the wall on the N.E. with no plaster being evident. The low wall on the Northeast indicates a large opening to the room.On the Northwest wall, there is a toilet and it is adjacent to a large cooking platform. In the South corner is a small oven. On the S.E. wall, there is a covered well. The investigator was  surprised to see such a structurally significant kitchen adjacent to the decorated room off the atrium. Perhaps, the well dictated this placement.

column14: The cooking platform is contiguous to the oven located in the South corner (3706) and the well located to the Southeast (3707)
column21: On the Northwest wall, there is an arched recess for storage situated below the cooking platform used for storing supplies. A second arched recess area is located beneath the oven under the southwest part of the platform. Both  recessed areas have cement floors. The surface is tiled. No rims are extant and no lips are extant. The recess located under the oven in the South corner of the room, possibly contained charcoal and wood.
column74: Done by Fran Capo & Lisa Wernick

column14: There is a platform, extending from this oven (3706), situated along the Northwest wall. There is a stone slab, covering a well (3707) located immediately Southwest of this oven.
column21: This is a miniature beehive oven located on the Southwest portion of platform 3705, located in the kitchen. It has a square opening, to the kitchen. It is constructed of mortar and cut stone slabs. It is constructed of mortar and cut stone slabs. The base is cut stone.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leaders are Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: Situated next to the oven (3706) and cooking platform (3705) which are situated on the S.W. wall.
column21: On the floor situated by the Southeast wall of the kitchen, is a large rectangular stone with a 3 sided metal barrier, covering a well. This is ideally located for a kitchen
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: The toilet is contiguous with the cooking platform (3705)
column21: A toilet situated on the Northwest wall is adjacent to a large cooking platform. A ceramic, vertical pipe system is visible, running from floor 2 to floor 1. The drain to the street is situated below the pipe. The ceramic fill, supports the toilet seat for two persons.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo & Lisa Wernick

column14: With room #35
column21: From the entrance, go to the S.E.. Enter the large atrium with a shallow impluvium with two channels. Situated directly beneath the impluvium is a slightly raised dining tablinum with an elaborate fountain, situated behind it. Enter, the large square dining room. There is a black and white tesserae, with interlocking white capital. I's outlined in black on diagonal to room- double black tesserae border, on the entire floor. There is a large white marble threshold eating room, #35. Room 75 is remarkable because of the wooden reconstructed ceiling.   On the N.W. wall, we see a very large window with a marble sill and a very high zone. Two windows, on the S.E. high zone are currently shuttered. All 4 walls, show painted plaster, likely completed 62 centimeters in 'deep' perspective. There is dado, divided by a stenciled band of the middle zone. The Dado shows a yellow background with 10 large black rectangles. The middle zone has stencils, dividing the space into sections; mostly with a red and yellow background. A double Greek key stencil demarcates the top and bottom of the middle zone. The high zone has lost most of its plaster. On the S.E. wall, at the high zone, a faint red border is evident. 5 small and 2 large sections have been removed.
column53: Lee Payne is the team leader
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: This is room 3, there is an atrium situated to the N.W., dining hall. Room 29, opens to the N.E. and room 33 is on the other side of the S.W. wall.
column21: This is a dining room. There is a N.W. - S.E. axis. One enters the room along the N.W. side. There is a marble threshold, that rises from the atrium. On the N.E. wall, is a broad doorway with a marble threshold, leading into the dining hall, space 29. This marble threshold has post holes for doors. This room is well preserved. The tesselated floor shows a black geometric pattern on white  tesserae. The 3 walls preserve 4th style painting. 7 picture panels have been removed. The high square window is located in the center of the S.E. wall, this goes up to the ceiling. There is a restored wooden ceiling, situated directly beneath the window. This is feature 3711, which is a small fresco of a lobster.
column53: Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column21: The 4th style painting decoration of this room includes large yellow panels in the central zone. Above this wall, the painting depicts open spaces with figures enclosed in delicately framed rectangles. 2 of these figures flank the feature which is a depiction of a large lobster against a blue background. It is located on the S.E. wall, situated just below the window.
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo.

column14: This room is to the N.E. of the atrium (3); thedining hall (29) is to the S.E., the fountain court (27) is to the N.E. and the stairway is to the N.W.
column21: This space is a tablinum which may have also served as a dining area. It is axially aligned with the principle entrance, which is (#5) and one enters from the atrium at the S.W. of this room. The entrance is one step up from the atrium onto a marble threshold. This threshold extends the entire length of the S.W. side of the room. The N.E. side of the room is bordered with a short retaining wall capped with white marble at the level of the fountain terrace. Both the N.W. and S.E. walls are intact and each has a central rectangular area where a painting has been removed. The walls are in poor condition; plaster remains with some traces of paint and traces of a horizontal ceiling molding remains on each wall. The retaining wall on the N.E. side is missing nearly all it's plaster, only preserving some in the lower N. corner. Preserved in the stone work of the wall is a terra cotta pipe near the E. end of the wall. There is no ceiling. The floor is well preserved, and it is the outstanding aspect of this room. It's a black and white tessellated floor pattern which surrounds a central square in opus sectile. There is a square towards the center of the N.E. wall that is possibly a cistern cover. The mosaic pattern with 3 broad bands of white along the N.W., N.E. and S.E. edges of the room suggest the placement of couches in a triclinium.

column14: It is contiguous to room 10, situated to the S.W. and 27 to the S.E..  Anything unusual - there is a central rectangular panel missing on the N.W. wall. It's been said, it's in the Naples museum and contained writing implements, an inkwell and the name of "Marcus Lucretius."
column21: This small diaeta runs along a N.E.-S.W. axis and looks onto garden no. 27. There is no existing decoration on the floor, which appears to be beaten cement. The S.E. portion has no wall and the S.W.,N.W. and N.E. walls located on the interior contain plaster painted in 4th style, with panels of pompeian yellow and red seen along the lower register and white with architectural features seen above. Figures such as faces, stenciling, and columns are faint but visible. The ceiling is made of modern wood.
column53: The Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: On the floor plan by Esch, it is contiguous to room 21 situated to the S.W. and room 22 to the East, and 12 is to the West
column21: This dining room runs along a N.W.-S.E. axis and is located N.E. of the entrance to the house. The room is poorly preserved. There is a small entrance on the N.W. side of the S.W. wall and a large doorway, which is completely open on the S.W. wall and provides a look into the garden, situated just beyond the passageway. The floor appears to have been black pavement with white tesserae sprinkle about, and is now covered with debris and overgrowth and two column pieces. Evidence of painted plaster remains on all 4 walls, of primarily the colors of red and yellow. The N.W. and S.E. walls  have been capped with terra cotta tiles in modern times, and the N.E. wall, which is the highest wall, is not capped but appears to have been repaired and partially reconstructed at some point in time. There is no ceiling extant.  As an aside, it appears that 3 medallions or circular panels have been removed from the Eastern end of the Northwest wall and the East and South ends of the Southeast wall, approximately 1.5 meters from the floor level.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: It is contiguous to room 24, situated to the West.
column21: This large rectangular dining room runs along a N.W.-S.E. axis. We enter from the doorway in the N.E. wall over a marble threshold and through a doorway that was plastered and painted red on the N.W. wall and as we enter the room, most of the wall is open to the garden on the N.W. side. The N.E. wall is approximately 3 feet high at the entrance and rises to an indeterminate height on thence S.E.. Evidence of plaster exists on all walls. The floor is poorly preserved but evidence shows a patterned mosaic floor of black and white tesserae. However, the design in the middle, does not exist.  High on the S.W. wall are 2 beam holes, one situated above the other. There are traces of red and yellow paint scattered about. On the N.W. floor, there appears to be inlay that mimics the threshold. There is no extant ceiling, however, there are tiles on the N.W. wall, seen at the North end.
column53: The Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernicki

column14: Room 6 (Hallway) situated to the Southeast. Room 7(kitchen) is situated to the S.W..
column21: Enter from room 6, Hallway. One enters the room from a doorway, on the South end of the S.E. wall. There is a rectangular storage room with a compacted floor of dirt and lapilli stone. 2 walls have indications of plaster with indicators and preparation for repairing. There are post holes, present, for a relatively low ceiling. The N.W. 2/3 wall is extant to 2 feet high and the West 1/3 of the wall is 10 feet high.  It could serve as a pass through to the kitchen. In 2013, the room is filled with roof tiles and 1 large piece of particle board. The room is situated on a N.W./S.E. axis.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Room 15 is to the S.E. and vestibule 17 is to the N.E.. The S.W. and N.W. walls are exterior walls.
column21: This is a small dining room that is located directly Southwest of the vestibule 17, at the entrance, #24. One enters from a door, from the atrium, 15 into the Eastern corner of the room. This doorway is cut into the S.E. wall. The room is in very poor condition with only traces of plaster covering ushlar masonry and stone walls. No paint survives. The walls are preserved to about 7-10 feet in height and there is no ceiling. The floors are only preserved to a cement layer. The S.E. wall has a self niche, # 16-3718 and a couch niche # 16-3719.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: 3719 is located to the South, at floor level, along the same wall.
