column21: There is a small rectangular area for storage, containing an indentation for a shelf on the East end of the SouthEast wall. The inside of this recess contains plaster, that's painted red.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne.
column74: Video team leaders are Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: 3718 is located to the North, at a higher level along the same wall.
column21: In the South corner of the S.E. wall is a low arched niche, which is approximately 1.5 to 2 feet in height, situated underneath the arch. The concrete rubble is in a mass. Plaster is evident on the wall, surrounding it.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Video taken by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: Feature 3721 is to the N.E.  Feature 3724 is to the East
column21: This feature # 3720 is a rubble mortar basin for the mill. The top is smoothed with cement and the structure sits just inside entrance #12, situated to the East. It is the Western most of the 3 basin structures aligned to the S.E. wall in this room. The structure is approximately 1.5 feet high on the exterior at it's highest point and is circular in shape. The inner height is slightly less. The width of the ring surface, from the outer portion to the inner portion is approximately 8 inches, like the rim of a tire. The center is filled with rubble and debris
column53: Photo team leader if Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lee Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Feature 3723 is to the N.E. of the mill Feature 3724 is to the S.W. Feature 3720 is to the South
column21: This feature number, 3721 is a rubble and mortar basin for a mill. The top is smoothed with cement and the structure sits between 2 other mill basins that are aligned with the S.E. wall. The structure is approximately 1.5 feet high on the exterior, at it's highest point and is circular. The inner height is slightly less. The width of the ring surface from the outer portion to the inner portion is approximately 8 inches, similar to the size of a rim of a tire. The center is filled with rubble and debris.
column53: The photo team is led by Lee Payne
column74: Video done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Feature 3723 is located to the N.E.  Feature 3721 is located to the S.E.
column21: This feature number 3722 is a rubble and mortar basin for the mill. The top is smoothed with cement and the structure sits just North-Northwest of the 3 basins, that are aligned with the S.E. wall. The basin is near the Northern corner of the N.W. wall. The structure is approximately 1.5 feet high on the exterior at it's highest point, and it is circular. The inner height is slightly less. The width of the ring surface from the outer portion to the inner portion, is approximately 8 inches, appearing like the rim of a tire. The center contains rubble and debris.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernicke & Fran Capo

column14: Feature 3722 is situated to the West  Feature 3724 is situated to the Southwest
column21: This feature number 3723 is a rubble and mortar basin for the mill. The top is smoothed with cement and it is the Eastern most of the 3 mill basin structures aligned with the Southeast wall. The structure is approximately 1.5 feet high on the exterior at it's highest point and it is circular. The inner height is slightly less. The width of the ring surface from the outer portion to the inner portion is approximately 8 inches, like the rim of a tire. The center contains rubble and debris.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Taken by Lisa Wernicke and Fran Capo

column14: It is contiguous to mill base 3721 to the N.E. and mill base 3720 to the N.W.
column21: There is a small lararium situated approximately 5 feet from the ground on the Southeast wall in the mill room. The height from the bottom to the top of the lararium is approximately 1.5 feet and the width is approximately .1 foot. The top is arched and it is approximately 6-8 inches deep, at the bottom. There is evidence of plaster painted light yellow containing plants with green leaves and red berries. There is a broken lip/edge which protrudes along the bottom.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column21: Enter this room from a doorway in the Southern end of the Southwest wall. The L shaped room is on a Northeast S.W. axis. There is an entrance to the street on the S.E. wall. We see a large bakery work room. A second entrance #12 from the via degli Augostli (street) is on the South end of the Southeast wall. The walls are up to a second story height. There is no roof. A lararium is on the Southeast wall. There is evidence of plaster on the Northeast and S.E. walls. A beehive oven occupies a central spot in the bakery's Northeastern part of the room. A storeroom  to the Northeast and an animal stall located to the N.E. flank the baking latrine space. 4 mills and 4 catilli are extant. A 6 foot high wall bisects a small portion of the N.W. side of the room, on it are traces of red plaster. Adjacent to this wall, to the North are 3 steps leading up to room 10(garden).
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: It stands at the Western corner of the oven. It is S.E. of catillus 3738 and South of the doorway to the prep room (#6).
column21: This is a mill/catillas of local stone. It is almost complete, missing several fragments from the upper portion/rim. The square opening for the beanhole is within an articulated block. The condition is fair. This catillas is standing upside down but may be in situ.
column53: The photo team lead is Lee Payne
column74: Performed by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: This is S.E. of catillus, 3726
column21: This is a mill/catillus of local stone. It is almost complete, missing several small fragments from the upper portion/rim. The square opening for the beam hole is within an articulated block. The condition is good. The catillus is standing upside down at the Southern corner of the oven.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernicke and Fran Capo

column14: This is N.W. of the pillar and S.W., across the room from the oven.
column21: This is a mill/catillus made of local stone. It is almost completely missing, there are several small fragments from the upper rim/portion and base. The form of this has the fittings block extends from the rim to the base. The rim preserves the notch in the center of the fitting block. The condition is good!.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo.

column14: This is presently located just S.W. of the oven (3730) opening. It is just N.W. of 3727.
column21: This is a quern. This small hand mill is almost complete and is only missing about one-eighth of it, broken from one side. This is a round object with a convex upper surface with a round hole in the middle. This is local stone.
column53: Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Feature 3726 is in front of the oven, to the S.W.  Feature 3727 is in the front of the oven to the S.W.  Feature 3729 is in front of the oven to the S.W.
column21: The central feature of Room 8 is the great oven. There is arched brick in the outer opening. As we approach the enclosed beehive oven, there is a large basalt stone opening, into the oven; the floor of which is laid with lava stones. The basalt stone demarcates a floor space under the oven, for ashes. On the North side of the oven, there is no typical opening to the prep room. On the Southeast side, the oven is closed from the mill area. The oven has probably been restored. The bottom platform of the oven supports the arch leading to the oven, and on each side of the oven is provided a raised preparation area.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Video done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Contiguous to the dining room 9, to the N.W. and the oven room #8, to the S.W.
column21: This room has a NW/SE axis. We enter this preparation room from the Southwest from room 8, across a large stone threshold and step down approximately 1 foot. The floor is obscured with vegetation and debris; however, remnants of 2 supports for a preparation table lie several feet from each end of the room on the axis. A small portion of a concrete floor with scattered white tesserae appears near the support, situated nearest the North end. There is evidence of plaster painted with a red lower register and a white upper register is present on the Southwest, Northwest and Northeast walls. The walls extend to an indeterminate height, and no ceiling is present. However, on the Northeast wall, approximately 2.5 meters high are 6 large beams, holed above which some red and white painted plaster survives. There are 2 square shaped smaller holes situated lower on the S.W. wall to the West of the threshold.* A terracotta roof tile juts into the room from the S.E. wall at the top, probably in order to preserve the oven which forms the other side of this wall.
column53: The photo team lead is Lee Payne
column74: Performed by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Situated contiguous to room 8, to the Northeast room 1 on the Southeast, and storeroom 2 situated to the Southwest.
column21: We enter the room from the doorway in the Northeastern wall. This stable is a large rectangular room on a Northwest/Southeast axis. It lies Northwest from street entrance 10. The room is poorly preserved with walls on all sides of varying heights. In the East corner of the Northeast wall is a portion of the brick column which forms the corner of the exterior wall. A pile of rubble abuts the Western half of the Southwest wall. Lapilli and vegetation obscure the floor. There is no ceiling extant. The walls are opus mistum.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: This platform lies NW of the sales counter at the other end of the room. It is directly, situated to the NW of the doorway to room #8.
column21: This feature is a platform located in the Northern corner of the room. The platform is about 2 feet wide by about 5 feet long. There is a level surface of about 18 inches high. In the very corner of the room, the platform rises about a foot more and abuts the corner walls. Within this raised area, there is a concave opening, that is preserved. This suggests that this was a stand for one or more doliums. This platform is in very poor condition. The flat surface and curved sides are ceramic.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: Feature #3740, a water feature, is situated to the West
column21: In the N.W. corner of room 8 is a rectangular cooking platform. The top of theSoutheast front of this platform shows a heavily reconstructed front lip. The platform is covered with lapilli and cement. The Northwest wall shows a thick layer of plaster.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Recorded by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Contiguous to room 8, seen to the Southwest and the prep room, as seen to the Southeast.
column21: We enter the dining room from the Southeast. The room is sitting Northeast from the main entrance of the property. The room lies on a Northeast-Southwest axis. Upon entering the room, one feature worth noting is; on the Southwest and Northwest walls, there are unusual features of a coping or curb which juts into the room along the lowest level, but it does not appear on the other walls. It was painted red in the fashion of the plaster which can be found on all 4 walls, along the lower register. Evidence of plaster painted white, still exists to varying heights in varying amounts on each wall with the greatest concentration on the North and East sides of the Northwest and Northeast walls. There are faint remnants of a green dividing stripe situated between the red and white portions exist on the Northwest, Northeast and Southeast walls. Evidence of plaster crown molding is preserved on the Northwest and Northeast walls. The height of the room is indeterminate. No ceiling is extant. Remnants of white tesserae are mixed into a cement floor and can be seen under debris and vegetation.* Note, on the Southwest wall and even possibly the Northwest wall windows may have present, looking into the garden.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Taken by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: Room 2 is situated to the N.W.. Room 8 is situated to the N.E.. The bakery sits on the corner, A.D. 5. This room is contiguous to roads on the S.W. and S.E.  A contiguous feature is an exterior program, to which was located on the exterior of the S.E. wall.
column21: This room is the sales room for a large bakery. Access to this room is in 2 places from the street with the principle on the S.W. ,#10, and a 2nd entrance on the S.E. wall, #11. Entering from the S.W. doorway, one would step up on a raised threshold where one could face a Z shaped sales counter, feature #3737. This long rectangular room is on a S.W.-N.E. axis. In addition to the 2 street entrances, there is a door on the Western end of the N.W. wall. There is also, a doorway on the N.E. wall, leading into the bakery work area, #8 with a basalt threshold. The overall condition of the room is very poor, wall plaster survives only on the Eastern end of the S.E. wall.   The S.W. wall, situated in the South corner of the room has a cut opening, that runs all the way through to the exterior. The gray pompeian basalt threshold of door 11, steps up from the street and preserves cuttings running the entire length, this may be for a screen closing. The walls rise only to 4-10 feet, there is no original flooring that is left intact.
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick & Fran Capo

column14: It is contiguous to doorway #10
column21: A large sales counter steps out from the SW wall and turns parallel to the entranceway 10 and turns at a right angle to be parallel with entrance #11. The counter is about 7-8 feet on both long sides and is about 3 feet tall and 2 feet wide. It is rough stone and mortar construction (reconstruction?)
column53: Photo team is led by Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick & Fran Capo

column14: It is presently located West of the door way to room 6, which is the prep room. It is 2 meters N.W. of mill/catillas, 3726
column21: This is a mill/catillas fragment that is made of local stone. This fragment preserves approximately half of the catillas. The fragment preserves one side with a fitting block that extends from the rim to the base. The condition is poor
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick & Fran Capo

column14: This is contiguous to room no. 1, situated to the S.E.
column21: This is a storage room aligned on a N.E.-S.W. axis. The room is very poorly preserved, no walls rise any higher than about 8 feet. There is no floor visible. There is no ceiling. There is no plaster visible. Because of its proximity to the sales counter, it suggests that it would serve as a store room. The entrance to this room is at the Southern end of the S.E. wall.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo.

column14: Located S.W. of the cooking platform is feature #3740, (water feature)
column21: Situated to West of the cooking platform is an interesting water feature. The top has a ceramic container on the N.W. wall. At the top, there is a hole in the wall of the water feature indicating that it served as a conduit , from the garden to this water feature. We see 3 descending layers (steps). This was a helpful way to get water into the bakery for the bakery and the animals. The Northwest wall shows evidence of thick plaster. There are remnants of tile(s), they are embedded in the top front of the water feature.
column74: Taken by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: This room is located N.W. of the street and adjoins the Kitchen atrium (room 2), seen to the N.W..
column21: This is the sales room of this establishment. The room has a SW-NE axis. One  enters from the street on the S.E. side through a doorway that is almost the entire width of the space. There is a 3 block threshold of pompeian stone with a channel, cut the entire length of the 3 blocks. The condition of the room is very poor; very little plaster remains on any of the walls. The room is constructed mostly of rubble and mortar, although the doorways were composed of brick.  There is a doorway in the N.W. wall, at the Western end. A large window is in the wall, seen North of the doorway. The floors are not visible and there is no longer a ceiling. The remains of the bottom of the staircase is situated in the West corner.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Room 3 (storeroom) is situated to the N.W..  Room 1 (salesroom) is situated to the S.E..
column21: We enter this square room, #2 from a low wide doorway, seen from the Southeast, on the Southern end of the partitioning wall. In antiquity, it appears that this room was a Tuscan atrium, as we note the small square impluvium, situated in the center of the room. There is little evidence left of plaster and paint on the walls. This, suggests, a structure may have been neglected. It appears, the last usage of this structure was for cooking because, I note a large cooking platform is situated on the Southwest wall in the southern half. It appears that this former house was re-conditioned, for  commercial use. A large high window or opening in the wall is situated between rooms 1 and 2, it interrupts the Southeast wall and could have been used for passage of goods between the 2 rooms.   Abutting the Southeast, situated along the South and Southwest portions are  2 large stone structures, these appear to have been cooking platforms that were joined together by a grill. One-half of this structure, the Southernmost, contains an arch underneath, for storage. Above this portion of the structure, lie two holes and an indentation that housed a shelf which was probably related to cooking.   Situated above the 2nd structure, which was probably the base for the other grill, is a large hole located high on the wall. On the Northwest wall, are 2 doorways. The Westernmost leads to a store room (3) and the Northernmost  to andron number (4). The Northeast wall contains more mortar than the other walls, and toward the East end of the Northeast wall, we note a small indeterminate structure. There are 6 beam holes situated approximately 2 meters high that may have been used for support, possibly of a shelf. The floor is obscured with lapilli and an overgrowth of vegetation. The walls indicate an indeterminate height, but a 2nd story. (Esch.) noted a terracotta puteal which has now been found in another room. There is no ceiling extant, present.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Room 6 is situated to the N.E..
column21: One enters the room through a door, situated on the Northeast wall that divides this from an adjacent room. A terracotta puteal (well head) that is from an earlier atrium. On the N.W. wall, at the level of my chest, you see a terracotta pipe that extends back (39 c.m.)). Some wall shows remains of a lararium, and adicular niche and some plaster remains. Seen, on the S.W. wall at 5 and one-half feet (approx.) we see 6 large beam holes an estimated 5 feet higher, its probably a candle niche. The S.E. wall, that is heavily repaired; shows 4 candle niches with irregular placements.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Room 5, (storeroom) is present to the N.W..
column21: Proceeding through the long hallway #4, we enter room 6, situated at the door in the East corner on the S.E. wall of this. The N.E. wall is a restored high wall. This abuts onto the House of M. Lucretius Fronto. Esch, says there is a door in this wall, giving entrance to the House of Lucretius. Staff sees no evidence of the door today. Situated on the same wall, there is a high rectangular window with an uneven top frame. The well shows minimum remains of stucco. The floor is composed of pounded dirt and lapilli. On the Northeast wall, there is one high rectangular window, seen at the same level. On the N.E. wall, there is one high rectangular window, at the same level on the N.E. wall, there is an opening with a wooden lintel. On the Southeast wall, there are small traces of plaster.  There are no ceiling walls, there are signs of heavy restoration.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Situated contiguous to feature 3747, to the Northeast
column21: Feature number 3745, abuts the Southeast wall situated at the South end, as we enter the doorway and abuts over half of the S.W. wall with a gap for a grill, situated in the center; therefore what appears to be 2 structures was actually one structure joined by a missing grlll. The entire structure was approximately 10 feet in length and approximately 2-3 feet high at it's highest point. The building material, are random bits of rubble, marble and terra cotta. The structure is in disrepair. However, traces of painted plaster can be seen on the Southwest and Southeast walls, and over the Southernmost structure, we see; indications of a shelf situated approximately 4 feet above the surface.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Room #2 (kitchen) is situated to the S.E.. Room #4 (corridor) runs along the N.E. side of the room.
column21: This is a rectangular storage room. One enters into it, through a doorway in  S.E. wall. The axis of the room is N.W./S.E.. The room is in poor condition. No flooring is visible. No ceiling remains, either. The walls are rubble and mortar construction, preserving some plaster on each wall. On the S.W. wall, the plaster has a horizontal incision about 4 feet high, across the entire wall. The N.E. wall may have also had this detail, as the plaster only reaches that height.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: It is situated N.E. from the cooking platform, feature #3745.
column21: This platform may have been used as a low hearth, or for preparation, however, its use is not known. The feature is in disrepair and appears approximately 9 inches high on the N.W. end. The front face of the platform is badly broken and the S.E. face is crumbling. The structure abuts the N.E. wall, for approximately 2.5 feet. The material composition is rubbble.
column27: A measurement of # 3747, done by Hill
column53: Taken by team leader, Lee Payne
column74: The team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Beam holes are situated on the S.W. wall, to the S.W. of this feature.
column21: This waist high aedicular niche is situated on the N.W. back wall. It shows a minimal amount of plaster in the arch and shelf. The back of the shelf has been destroyed, the wall stones are visible.
column53: Photos taken by team leader, Lee Payne

column14: Atrium 3 is situated to the West
column21: This is a rectangular room, situated on a N/S axis. The North wall only survives in fragments. There is extensive restoration of the upper coorses in the E/S/W walls. The plaster survives on the E/S/W walls. It is divided into 2 registers, but there is no visible decoration. Situated, high in the center of the E. wall, there is a lined window, that is blocked in modern restoration. The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout the room. The doorway, seen at the N. end of the West wall with a stone threshold and a placing for the door.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The team leaders are Wernick and Capo.

column14: Corridor (7) is situated to the South.
column21: One enters the kitchen from the South, via corridor (7) on an E/W axis; off the atrium(3) and then from a corridor (7), perpendicular to (6) on a N/S axis. The Southern wall is badly damaged. There are no traces of plaster or paint. The East wall has a small platform attached to it's North base, which may have formed part of a latrine. The North wall is damaged, with no traces of plaster or paint. Attached to the corner of the North wall and running along the North wall, is a masonary cooking platform. On the West wall, the cooking platform is attached at the Northwestern end. High up on the wall, at the Northeast; there is a circular opening. No traces of plaster or paint remain. The floor is obscured by debris and lapilli.
column53: The photo leader is Rob Brown
column74: Done by Lisa Wernick and Fran Capo

column14: There is a cooking platform situated to the West
column21: Situated in the corner, between the North and East walls, there is a short masonry (brick tile and rubble) ledge positioned at knee height, which may have formed part of a latrine. There is no apparent evidence of a water supply or pipe drain. The structure is poorly preserved.
column53: The team leader is Rob Brown

column14: The latrine is situated to the East
column21: There is a large masonary cooking platform, located in the N.W. corner of the kitchen and it extends approximately two-thirds of the length of the North wall. No storage niches are present. There is a raised ledge, situated at the East end of the platform
column53: Team is led by Rob Brown
column74: Taken by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: Garden (15), seen to the East
column21: One enters the room through an entrance in the East wall. There is a raised stone threshold. The entrance is on an axis to the entrance of the house. The floor is obscured by capilli. There are 2 post holes situated on the North wall. They are arranged one situated above the other. There are poorly preserved fragments of painting on the North wall. The style is not discernible. There appear to be 3 distinct painted panels, where the predominant color is yellow, separated by borders of white. Traces of red border around the yellow panels are also visible. Seen, on the West wall, there are 2 post holes, arranged horizontally relative to each other and situated at a lower height than those on the North wall. At the northern end of the West wall, situated above the level of the post holes, there is an opening; it appears to be an opening; perhaps a window or entrance with a threshold, situated on the 2nd floor.  There are 4 yellow painted panels situated on the West wall, in a similar style to those on the North wall. On the Southern wall, there are 3 yellow painted panels, these are separated by thick white borders. Above my head height and placed centrally in the wall is an opening, possibly a window which is recessed. There are traces of white paint in the recess and perhaps a thin yellow border. (The recess appears to be circular in shape)  On the Eastern wall, the pattern of yellow painted panels continues. There are possibly 3 in number. The plaster on the wall is too badly damaged to be sure. At the intersection of the South and East and South and West walls, there is a vertical painted border, extending above head height.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The video team leader is Cavila

column14: Garden 14, is situated to the N.W..
column21: This is a small, rectangular room situated on an E/W axis. There is a small doorway, in the W end of the N wall; and it opens to the garden. The floor is obscured by lapilli. The N and E walls are poorly preserved. There is no extant wall finish or decoration. Situated, high in the S wall are the floors for the floor joists for the upper story.  In the center of the W wall, there is a well preserved drain pipe, made of terracotta. It is extending down from the floor above. At the base of the pipe, situated in the S.W. corner is latrine (6303). Eschebach and PPM, identify this as a kitchen.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The video team leader is Cavila

column14: Atrium 7, to the West
column21: There is a large rectangular room, it is situated on an E/W axis. There is a wide open doorway, situated through the West wall to Atrium 7. There is no visible threshold. The floor is obscured by lapilli. The N, E, and S walls are under extensive restoration. Extensive plaster survives on the N, E and S walls with visible decoration on the N and S walls. The plaster is best preserved on the N. wall. Identified, is a 3rd style with a black lower register with yellow trim, white is seen above with red trim. Red trim survives in the S.W. corner, with trims of plaster moulding seen at the junction of the ceiling.
column53: Rob Brown is the team leader
column74: The video team leader is Carlos Avila

column14: In the S.W. corner of the room
column21: There is low masonary support in the S.W. corner of the kitchen. Adjoining to the masonary support in the W. wall is a terracotta drain from the floor above. Adjoining the support in the S. wall, there is a low recess in the base of the wall. Possibly, this is the drain situated beneath the seat of the latrine.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown

column14: There is a platform that extends from this oven (3706) along the N.W. wall. There is a stone slab covering a well (3707) situated immediately S.W. of this oven.
column21: On the S.W. wall of the kitchen, there is a beehive oven that has a square opening to the kitchen. The oven is constructed of mortar and cut stone slabs. The base is cut stone.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Done by the team of Fran Capo & Lisa Wernick

column14: 27 is situated to the South
column21: This is a bombed out property. It is a rectangular room, situated on an E-W axis. All 4 walls of the kitchen are poorly preserved. There is a doorway at the W. and at the S. wall, with a stone stepped threshold to 27. The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout. In the center of the room from the N.W. wall, there is a masonry partition or other feature. There are plaster fragments in the W and N walls. Situated high up, are the remains of the East wall, where there are 4 holes for floor joists. This is identified as a kitchen by Fiorelli and Werscher.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The video team leader is Cavila

column14: To room 27 to the West and 21 to the South
column21: This is a rectangular room with an E-W axis. The room, on the whole, has poorly preserved walls. The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout. There is a wide doorway and a W. wall, with a stone stepped threshold, looking out to 27 (a garden?) The doorway, situated at the W and of the S wall, heading to atrium 21, has no visible threshold. There is white plaster with red trim and a blue border survives in the N.W. corner. There is a couch niche 6343, at the E end of the N. wall. Plaster survives at the N. end of the E. wall, with a pink colored hue.  All of this is part of a bombed out house.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown

column14: N.E. corner of the room.
column21: This is a low, rectangular couch niche, situated at the E. end of the N. wall. The base of this niche is obscured by lapilli and debris. The plastered interior face survives at the W end of the niche.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown

column14: This room is S.W. of the atrium. It's S.E. of room #4.
column21: This is a Dining Room. It's a restaurant space situated on a NW-SE axis. One enters this room from a doorway in the N.E. wall, by the North corner. The room is in poor condition. Part of the pompeian stone threshold remains. No flooring is visible and no ceiling remains. The walls are preserved from 8-10 ft. in height. Some plaster remains on the walls. However, very few; painted surfaces survive. On the S.W. wall, situated in the West corner, the wall steps back for about 2 ft., forming approximately a 6 in. deep niche. This room is positioned off the atrium, suggesting it's use as a Dining room.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: This room is situated N.W. from room 3. It is S.W. of the atrium.
column21: This is a Dining Room. It is a rectangular space, situated on a N.W.-S.E. axis. One enters this room from a wide doorway, almost the entire length of the N.E. wall. This room is in poor condition. There is some evidence of Opus sectile in a red pebble matrix, situated near the Northeast wall. No ceiling remains. The walls are preserved from 8-15 feet in height. The short wing walls situated on the N.E. side are partially covered with plaster with some evidence of paint as are the N.W. and S.W. walls.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: This room 7 is contiguous to the S.E., with room 6 and hallway 8.
column21: One enters from the peristyle garden situated by a Northeast doorway, across from a stone threshold and tall doorway. This is a large rectangular dining room with a good view, into the peristyle garden. The floor consists of lapilli and packed dirt.   Situated opposite this entrance, on the S.E. wall is another entrance with 3 steps to another room (6), with decorated walls and a small niche. There is no ceiling. The N.W. wall maintains one layer of coral/beige paint. The S.W. wall has almost one-half the wall plastered in this same coral/beige color. The S.E. wall shows brick and stone and a one third lower portion of the wall, shows plaster with gray and beige paint. The N.E. wall has a minimal amount of plaster, it is the color of dark gray.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terry Bruno.

column14: Room 15 is contiguous with corridor 8, situated to the N.W. and corridor 5 at the S.W..
column21: I enter this large rectangular dining room from the N.W., over a stone threshold, with evidence of a door. The floor is lapilli and compacted dirt, covering portions of terracotta, in cement. There is no ceiling. The 3 walls have been reconstructed to about 12 feet. On the West corner, is situated a doorway with a large lintel and stone threshold with evidence of a door jamb. Situated, on the S.W. wall and rebuilt to a high level, there is a small segment of plaster. The dado is the color of Coral with a yellow, double striped border. It contains a coral gray band, with topped with a yellow band. From there, plaster painted black extends almost to the height of the wall.  On the SouthEast wall, the lower one-fourth repeats the border colors of the South wall. Seen, at the center is evidence of a filled in good sized doorway, that's missing a large lintel. This wall is mostly plastered. The N.E. wall has about one-quarter plaster with a large rectangular niche situated near the East corner. The plaster color repeats itself, in the niche.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terry Bruno.

column14: The door leads to Peristyle area (8), on the Northwest
column21: We enter this large rectangular storage room through a low doorway situated in the West corner of the N.W. wall. There is no threshold, but there is a modern wooden lintel. As we enter, the room on a Northeast-Southwest axis, we notice the N.W. and S.E. walls jut into the room, slightly for approximately one-third of the length of the room. Seen, on the N.E. wall and the S.E. wall, is red and white painted plaster remains, in small areas in the East corner of the room is a modern utility pole.  This room is in disrepair, with walls preserved to an indeterminate height but restore
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: Contiguous to corridor 11 and garden 12
column21: I entered rm. 10 from corridor 11, to the SouthWest. The room runs on a Northeast-Southwest axis, and is in a state of disrepair. It appears, that the S.E. wall incorporated at least 3 of the columns on the N.W. end of the peristyle (12), to enclose the room.  One capital, can be seen atop the 2nd column. Evidence of plaster, painted red can be found on the: N.W., N.E. and S.E. walls. The walls rise to a height of 3 meters. The floor is obscured with lapilli and vegetation. The N.E. wall appears to have been reconstructed above the height of the others. There is no ceiling extant.
column53: Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leader if Terry Bruno

column21: Situated, at the East corner, there is a large square niche built into the Northeast wall, for a dining bench. There has been an effort to plaster the lower part in the same color red, as seen elsewhere in the dining room.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terry Bruno.

column14: Contiguous to Room 7, on the Northwest and room 5, to the North.
column21: This long rectangular room runs along a N.E./S.W. axis. We enter the room, from a low doorway, situated on the N.E.. There is a two step doorway, on the North corner of the room, which leads to room #7. Remnants of the plaster, remain on all low walls, particularly at the S.W. end of the room. Evidence of yellow, red and white paint remains, on the walls. Situated high on the S.W. wall is a tall, thin rectangular window, abutting the adjoining exterior wall, to the Northwest. The walls of the room are high up. No ceiling exists. The floor is covered with moss and debris.
column53: Photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: The storage space (16) is situated to the S.W.. Space (10) is to the N.E..
column21: This is a small space identified as the kitchen. It is in extremely poor  condition. It's a rectangular space on a  N.W./S.E. axis. There is a doorway, on the S.E. wall, that's terminating on the South side, with a column. From this low doorway, one enters the room w.here the Southwest side seems to have been only a low partition, instead of a wall. The room has plaster and a cut hole in the middle of the N.W. wall. No paint is preserved on any of the wall plaster. No features are preserved in this room. It may have had a rubble cooking platform. The room is presently filled with rubble. No flooring is visible and no ceiling is preserved
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: This space is N.W. of area 8. The kitchen room 9, is situated to the N.E..
column21: Aligned with the entrance corridor and corridor 8, one enters this space at the very back of the house. This is a small storage area in the Western most corner of the house. This small rectangular area is aligned S.W./N.E. and half of this space contains the arched cella penaria, which is preserved to approximately 4 ft. in height. The interior space is preserved plaster facing.  At the Northernmost side of this room, there seems to be only a low partition, separating this space from the kitchen. This house is in poor condition and the walls in this space are only preserved to 8-10 feet. No flooring is visible and no ceiling survives.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: This is the Western most corner of the house. It faces the partition to room 9. A latrine is located on the S.W. wall.
column21: This is a storage feature, (cella penaria). It is comprised of rubble construction, about 4 ft. in height. It has a flat surface, at the top. The sides and front are in poor condition. The arched interior has remains of plaster facing. This opens to the N.E. and it occupies the Western most corner of the house. Generally, it is in fair to poor condition.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terry Bruno

column14: The main door on the S.E., opens to are no. 9. The small door on the S.E., opens to room no. 5.
column21: This room is on a N.E.-S.W. axis, it's a dining room. It is located N.W. of the primary entrance. This room has two entrances. Entrance one, is a small doorway adjoining room no. 5. A larger doorway, on the S.E. wall, opens up to area 9. This room is in very poor condition. The walls preserve painted plaster. The S.W./N.W. wall preserves painted remains revealing a dado, a central zone and upper section. Some random blue paint can be seen. Above this, in the North corner is remaining evidence of molded vaulting. The walls are of uncut stone construction. There is no ceiling. The floors are not visible. Reconstruction in the room, includes metal brackets, holding plaster on the N.W., S.W. and N.E. walls.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The run time is 2:33  Video team leaders are Capo and Wernick

column14: Situated to the S.E. is room 9, which contains a 1st style architectural wall design. Seen, at about 5 feet, there is a lararium. (nediCulara)
column21: Enter, pass thru an old peristyle, it was last used as a fabric drying area. We pass an entrance on the Northwest. We pass through to a 2nd entrance on the Northwest. The N.E., determines this room. From the N.W., it was formerly a dining room, by virtue of location, orientation toward painted and plastered walls. The room is on a N.W./S.E. axis, to the entrance hall. There is no lintel. The room is on a N.E./S.W. axis. The rectangular room has no ceiling, this is evidence of a high zone. The floor is pounded dirt and lapilli. The S.E. wall, overlooks the garden, there is a window, positioned nearly 4 feet from the floor. A niche, on the N.E. wall, was for a dining couch. On the N.E. wall, 6 feet above ground, a window overlooks their neighbor. All 4 walls, retain evidence of plaster, the West corner sign of yellow with an aqua border. This appears  to be a 4th style painting. The East corner shows signs of black dado. Seen on the middle zone, is an aqua border.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The running time is 4:18  Done by Fran Capo and Lisa Wernick

column14: Contiguous to rooms 15 and 14, to the East.
column21: This room is situated along a S.E./N.W. axis, as we enter from rooms 13 and 14, on the N.E. wall. The room has  been determined to be a kitchen, supported by evidence from a bibliography, and a ledge that could have been a cooking platform in the South corner of the room, of the S.E. wall.  The room lies to the East of the primary entrance of the address. The general condition of the room is poor. The floor is obscured by debris and overgrowth. Plaster remains on the S.E. and S.W. walls and on the N.W. walls, with a small niche situated approximately 1.5 meters high on the West wall and a possible water feature with plaster in situ, on the Northwest wall, containing cocciopesto and plaster in a surround for some sort of container and an arch above, which reaches approximately 1.5 meters in height. Beam holes appear on the S.W. and N.W. walls at about 2 meters, and the ceiling is no longer extant.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: Video team leaders are F. Capo and L. Wernick

column21: Situated in the North corner, is a good sized couch niche with signs of black plaster and a stenciled black border, inside the niche. Seen, slightly off center, at the floor level; inside the niche is a stone rectangle, that more carefully demarcates the niche's location.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Contiguous, on the North wall, is a rectangular dining room, #15. Next, on the North wall is a hallway #4, which leads to the mill room. On the West wall is an entrance to a Dining room.
column21: We enter this square salesroom from a large entranceway, #19. The floor is pounded mud and lapilli. The East wall shows on the plaster, once; a stairway existed. On the East wall, there are 6 holes for shelves. The North wall shows a large entrance to a Dining room and a tall hallway to a mill room. Seen on the North part of the wall, are 4 holes for shelves. On the West wall, there is a large entrance equal in height to the entrance to the other Dining room, on the North wall. There is no sign of a roof. There is some plaster residue, but only on the West wall, where we see red colored plaster. Situated to the East wall, are 2 catilli. These catilli, appear to be the top parts of the 2 mills, from the mill room.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column21: At the entry to this bakery/restaurant; situated on the Southeast corner is a rectangular counter that is small in size. The surface and all the plaster is gone. This counter was added in the final years of the life of the city of Pompei.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Contiguous to room 1, situated to the Southeast and room #4, to the S.W..
column21: This is a rectangular room, which runs along a N.W./S.E. axis. We enter the area from a large doorway situated on the S.E. wall, from the sales room. There is a modern wooden lintel and no threshold. Supports for the doorway are made of brick. Evidence of plaster survives on the: S.W., N.W. and N.E. walls. There is evidence of red lower register, this survives on the N.W. and N.E. walls. There appears to have been a door which was blocked in antiquity to wards the Western end of the S.W. wall. 9, large rectangular floor joist holes are situated both on the N.W. and S.E. walls. There is a small window on the North portion of the N.E. wall, which would have been at the top of the 1st story. There is no ceiling, the floor is obscured with lapilli and vegetation.
column74: The video team leader it Terri Bruno.

column14: This room is situated to the West of the principle entrance. One goes through room one and enters the door, situated on the N.E. wall. Room one is directly N.E. of this room and room 3 is directly N.W. of this room.
column21: This is a dining room. It lies on a S.E./N.W. axis and is situated directly off room no. 1, with a door in the N.E. wall. There is a window on the N.W. wall, it is opening into the other Dining room (3). The room is in poor condition, despite efforts at heavy restoration. No flooring is visible. There is a reconstructed ceiling. Moulding is preserved on the N.E. and S.W. walls, suggesting a barrel vaulted ceiling. All 4 walls preserve, painted plaster. All 4, are in poor condition, they maybe in 3rd style. One can see a red dado. The central zone also has red panels. Although, some decorative details can be seen, it is impossible to discern any subject of figurative designs. Some panels may have been yellow. The door jamb, situated on the North side has 3 deep holes drilled for some kind of door fittings.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Room 5, is to the N.W.. Room 2 is situated to the S.E..
column21: This is a Dining room, aligned on a N.E./S.W. axis. This rectangular room is entered by a doorway, at the Northern end of the N.E. wall. There's a window in the Center of the S.E. wall, opening to room 2, and there is a window situated in the center of the S.E. wall, it's opening to room 2. There is a window in the center of the N.W. wall, opening into the Mill room, room 5. This room is in fair condition with heavy reconstruction. It's reconstructed with a ceiling sloping downward from the S.W. to the N.E. side. The high ceiling, situated above the S.W. wall allows for a very high painted wall. The painting in this room is 4th style, with a red dado with plants and tall central zones. Figurative central panels and present on the S.W. and the N.E. walls. The upper zone shows windows and outdoor spaces. Earlier researchers were able to identify figures in this room, however the present room condition does not allow this. No flooring is visible. The threshold is stone and has some cuttings for a door. One steps up into this room.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column21: The painting was not found. This is a negative feature sheet.
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: This mill room opens on to the street entrance (20), onto hallway (4), onto the stable (6) and onto the preparation room (7), onto the oven (13) and onto the processing room (14).
column21: We enter this mill work room of a bakery, from the East door. The door has 2 steps and animals could be moved through this door. This almost square room contains many openings. The floor is pounded earth, and lapilli and lava stones placed around the 4 mills. This mill room has a South entrance to a wall (4). There are minimal signs of plaster seen on the walls and there is a window to the Dining room and ? against the wall, (3790). T he S.W. wall has an entrance to a small rectangular room, that is stable (6). There is a lararium (3791) situated about 10 feet high on the wall with a discernable shelf; it's still plastered with no sign of paint left. There is a well, situated on the ground; adjacent to this wall. This West wall, in the year 2013, extends only 4 feet high, and we can see into the adjoining preparation room (7). There is a stone threshold, there to aid movement into this room with a door opening. On the N.W. wall, there is a wide opening, and we can see the baker's oven (13). It also opens to a processing room (14). The N.E. wall, on the street contains 11 large post holes that are about 10 feet high and some remaining dark colored plaster. The base of each of the 4 mills has been built up as a mill platform. There are no lead sheets. 2 mills are complete, one has a meta only and one is missing a meta and a catillus. We can see a catillus (3812) toward the N.W. corner. The asses have plenty of room to move around the mill stones. Mills (3798, 3794, 3795, and 3793)
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: It is contiguous to mill 3793, lararium 3791, and a 3792 well head, all of which are located N.W. of this feature.
column21: Remnants of a water trough remain low on the S.E. half of the mill room and run from the Southern corner adjoining the corridor to the East edge of the window. Only the outline remains, as the lip is gone, however, it apparently extended approximately one foot into the room.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: Contiguous to trough 3790 to the East, with well 3792 situated to the North. Mill 3793 is situated to the N.E..
column21: This is a small, slightly rectangular lararium situated high on the S.W. wall and West of the doorway to room 6. It is plastered on the inside and there is a   lip of brick faced with plaster; it appears to have been painted white in color.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: The lararium 3791 is situated to the S.W.. A catillus, #3796 is situated to theNorth.
column21: This is a well of eava stone. It is uncovered and filled with debris. It's small and square, with a circular opening. It is located in front of the S.W. wall on the Western end, being near a passage to the adjoining room, #7.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: Mill (3795) is situated to the N.W., mill (3798) is situated to the N.E..
column21: The third mill is complete, although damaged and made up of a rubble base, meta and cotillus
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne

column14: Mill (3798) is situated to the South, mill (3795) is situated to the West
column21: The Bubble base is situated in the North corner of the mill room (5) and it has no meta or cotillus
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Mill (3793) is situated to the S.E. and mill (3704) to the N.E..
column21: The 4th mill situated closest to the oven (13) has a rubble base, a meta and a catillus, which is damaged at the top showing modern repairs. Our photos will show the differences or varieties in the fabrication of the mills.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: The Northwest side of the oven is contiguous to a large processing room (3799). The hallway leads to the West, it connects to a hallway and an oven passageway, to a preparation room. (3800)
column21: From the mill room, we look into the next room and what is the West wall of the structure. Our passage is currently blocked by a catillus. The oven room is filled with an oven that bears a plaque of restoration in 2005. As we enter this oven room, we are standing in a hallway which leads directly to a preparation room, #12. Looking at this partially destroyed oven, we see wht seems to be an unexcavated area blocking access to the area that would allow the baker to work. We cannot get close to the oven, beehive or the enclosed area of the oven. The outside arch exists in only about one-fourth of its arch shape. There is an opening situated West of the preparation room. There is no oven opening to the East processing room. The interior of the oven is all rubble, with a large basalt post and lintel.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column21: This great oven, once had a full arched entrance, now only one-fourth of the arch, shaped with brick, exists. This was restored in 2005, and its portions are being held up by 4 rusty rods.   We can't get close to the entrance to describe the baker working in the oven. We must stand 3 feet away from the arch. We look directly at the rubble beehive enclosed portion of this oven. At the base is a basalt post and lintel entrance. The West side of this oven has a pass through to a preparation room. (3800) There is no pass through to the large processing room (3799), but the Baker could remove the loaves and hand them to a slave who would take them to the processing room. (3799)
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: The mill (3793) is situated to the West. The mill (3794) is situated to the North.
column21: Situated closest to the entrance (20), has a high rubble base and a meta in place.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Contiguous to the mill room (5) at the S.E. with the Oven room (13) being situated to the S.W..
column21: The processing room lies between the Mill room (5) to the S.E. and the oven room (13), in the SouthWest. The room is in a state of disrepair and is filled with debris, rubble and undergrowth to a depth of approx. 5 feet. Seen on the S.W. wall are 7 brick lined joist holes. On the N.E. wall, there are 12 brick lined joist holes, under which there is a small window, jutting out to the street. Only a fragment of plaster remains on the S.E. wall. The heights is undetermined, however, in the Western corner; we see indications that this was a high wall. No ceiling is present.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: Contiguous to the prep room, is room 11 to the S.W. and the oven room (13) to the N.E..
column21: This Prep room, 12 has two low doorways. One is situated on the N.E. and the other is on the S.W. wall. Situated in the middle of the room is a stone which may be the remains of a preparation table. There are remnants of plaster painted red, seen on the bottom and the colors of light yellow or white. Seen at the top, there are remains on all 4 walls. There are 9 circular holes on the S.W. wall situated about 2 feet above the doorway, in a line. There are 9 poorly preserved brick lined square holes, situated across on the N.E. wall. On the S.E. wall, at the level of approximately 5 feet high is a small vertically positioned rectangular window, the top of which aligns with the top of the previously mentioned support holes. The window is plastered on the inside, there is a tiny piece of ancient blue window glass, situated in the South corner. Centered along the N.E. wall is a small low sloped terra cotta lined pass through to the oven room. The floor is covered with vegetation and lapilli. Only 2 pieces of lava stone remain on the N.E. threshold and there is no ceiling. There are modern wooden lintels, on both doors.
column53: A redo, the team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: To prep room 12, situated to the N/N.E.
column21: We enter room 11 from the door on the Northeast, the doorway is low and narrow with modern wooden lintels. This small rectangular room lies on a N.E./S.W. axis. There is plaster painted red and possibly yellow exists on the facing of the doorway and N.E./S.E. and on the N.W. walls. The walls are preserved above a 1st story height. The room contains two basins nestled along the East side of the N.E. wall and in the South corner is a kneading basin. All of these items, are broken but are identifiable. Seen high, centered on the S.W. wall is a small rectangular window into the viridarium, with a modern wooden lintel and lead lintel situated at the top. This is evidence of plaster seen on the inner frame and there are fragments of ancient glass in situ, at the North lower corner. On both the S.E. and N.W. walls, at approx. the same height as the lower sill of the window are large holeas, one on each wall. Eleven circular holes, situated on the N.W. wall, line up approx. 4 ft. above the aforementioned hole. On the N.E. wall, at approx. the same height is a hole into the next room, possibly f.or light or air. It is above the 2 basins. The floor is obscured with vegetation and debris. No ceiling exists. Modern graffiti that is written in pencil exists on the door facing.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Contiguous to feature 8313, there is a quern to the N.W. and basins 3803 and 3804 situated to the N.E..
column21: A large lava stone portion of a kneading basin remains in the South corner of the room. Approx. one-third of the structure exists to its full height. The Southern portion is completely broken and missing. The Eastern portion is broken to approx. one-half of it's height. A large crack is on the N.E. face. The structure juts in to a fitting suitable for it's function.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: Contiguous to basin 3804 to the S.E. is a kneading bowl 3807 and a quern 8313, situated to the S.W..
column21: Only a fragment of the basin remains a top a rubble and lava stone support. The basin was terra cotta and had a lip.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne.
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: It is contiguous to basin 3803, situated to the N.W.. The kneading bowl is 3802 and the quern situated to the S.W. is 8313.
column21: This large basin is badly broken. Approx. two-thirds of it remains from the bottom to the lip. It is made of a terra cotta and shares the rubble and lava stone support with basin 3803. This feature is located in the East corner of the room. Rock and plants are present in the bottom of it.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: Contiguous to the mill room (5) to the N.E. and the prep room (7) to the N.W..
column21: This small square room, situated just S.W. of the mill room is thought to have been a stable due to it's close proximity to the work area and the trough. The entrance is sloped. There is no plaster apparent. There are 10 round holes situated on the N.W. wall, perhaps for joists. On the S.W. wall is a small window, which is in the Western corner. The floor is obscured with lapilli.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: This room is located to the S.W. of the mill room (5) Room 12 is situated to the N.W. Room 6 is situated to the S.E. and room 8 is at the S.W..
column21: This is a prep. room. It is a rectangular room, that is oriented on a N.W./S.E. axis. One enters this room from the Northern end of the Northeast wall from the mill room (5). Another entrance is located on the Southern half of the S.W. wall. This room is in very poor condition. The floors are not visible. The ceiling has not survived. The Southern end of the S.W. wall is of indeterminate length and may have extended to the stone threshold. Rough plaster remains on all 4 walls, without any trace of paint. The characteristic of this room, as a prep room; is supported by the presence of a large dolium (3808) seen in the Western corner and a stone basin (3807) situated in the South corner. A small window is located in the center of the N.W. wall, opening into room #12.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: This basin is located to the S.W. of the dolium, 3808
column21: This is a stone basin. The exterior is straight sided, with a rounded interior space. The diameter is about 4 ft.. This basin is complete and has 2 notches situated; in the rim about 8 inches apart. A drilled drain exists, at the bottom. This basin is in situ, situated in the South corner of the room.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne.
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: This dolium is N.W. of basin 3807
column21: This is a large ceramic dolium. It is complete except for a round drilled whole approximately 3 inches in diameter. This hole is located just beneath the rim. This dolium is presently located in the Western corner of the room.
column53: The team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The Video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: This room is situated to the S.W. of room 8. Room 10 is situated to the N.W..
column21: This is a small dining room. One enters along the Northwest wall and the room is on a N.W./S.E. axis and it is a rectangular space. The doorway is a tall wide, opening; almost the entire width of the room in the N.W. wall. Through this entrance, one can see the garden. (10) The room is in very poor condition. Although plaster remains on the walls, there is no trace of paint. The flooring is not visible and no ceiling remains. 8 pairs of joist holes are cut along the N.E. and S.W. walls, at about 8 feet high.  In the Eastern corner of the N.E. wall, there may be evidence of a niche into the wall rising up about 10 inches in height.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno

column14: At the rear of the N.E. mill room wall.
column21: There are 7 programmata outside the bakery mill room CIL, IV, 3674, 3678, 3680, 3683, 3703, 3702 and 5065. On the evidence of CIL, IV, 5065 Della Corte established Papirius Sabinius as the more logical owner of the business. The workers are supporting Papirius Sabanius as Aedile. The workers' names are (male) Pyranus, Calvus, T. Genialis, and (female) Statia, Petronia, and Olympian ica.  The writer of the programmata is Infantion.   In 2013, we can see one programmata in beige with large red letters.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: On the opposite side of the N.E. mill room wall.
column21: We are outside the entrance 20, looking at the wall that separates us from the baker's mill room. North of this entrance is a long bench filled with stones.  Fiorelli suggested the clients of Q. Bruttius Balbus, the owner of the adjoining home could sit there. We suggest that the clients of the bakery/restaurant could eat their bread products here.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Mill (3795), situated to the N.E., there is a well (3792); situated to the S.E..
column21: Finally, before the oven; room 13, there is a single catillus, perhaps from rubble base 3794, or perhaps it is there to replace an existing catillus.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Contiguous to 3802, to the S.E. and basins 3803 and the kneading basin 3804, seen to the N.E..
column21: A small round split quern, that is made of lava stone is situated next to the kneading basin and under the window of the S.W. wall.
column53: The photo team leader is Lee Payne
column74: The video team leader is Terri Bruno.

column14: Looks out onto the corridor to the N.W.. The entrance hallway and large garden is seen to the right, it's not visible from the room.
column21: The entrance faces N.W., off corridor with a large garden (6), situated in back of the house. There is no floor, however one sees: grasses, weeds and dirt. There is no evidence of a roof. The N.W. wall is badly damaged. There is reconstructed evidence of plaster and perhaps painting at the left of the entrance opening.  The S.W. wall is badly damaged. Traces of plaster seem possible here, there is painting and a window. There are 3 sides only- situated above eye level, facing and looking out on to the street.   The S.E. wall is badly damaged, only traces of plaster remain here. The N.E. wall is badly damaged. The facing wall to the left, finds traces of plaster that is very faint and a trace of paint.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The Video team leader is Carlos Avila

column14: Room 7 is situated to the North. Garden 6 is to the South.
column21: This is a rectangular room situated on a N/S axis. It is bombed out. Only the East wall survives with substantial collapse -apparent- and some evidence of modern restoration. It is poorly preserved, at the Northeast, and Southwest corners. No trace remains of the South or West walls. The Northeast corner is filled with earth and debris. The remainder of the floor is obscured by earth and vegetation. Eschebach, identifies this as a kitchen. Eschebach, also refers to a lararium painting, no trace remains of it; nor is it found in other literature.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The Video team leader is Carlos Avila

column14: Room 8 is situated to the South.
column21: This is a rectangular room situated on an E-W axis. The Northeast and West walls survive with a modern restoration effort. The North end of the East wall has a rectangular buttress. The buttress East and North walls contain preserved traces of plaster. The Southwest corner and South wall are no longer extant, so the entrance to the room cannot be defined. The floor is obscured throughout the room by vegetation, earth and debris. The room is identified as a storeroom by Eschebach. There is no ceiling.
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The video team leader is Carlos Avila

column14: The garden abuts on the far N.E. corner. Situated there, are 2 rooms; possibly a kitchen and a storeroom (7). To the S.W. corridor #1, adjoins the garden. The entrance is on the S.W. side, to room #5.
column21: This is a large open area running the width from N.W. to the S.E. axis. Situated on the N.E. side of the establishment, according to W. Jashemski, this area was badly damaged during the 62 A.D. earthquake. At that time, rubble was removed and subsequently the entire area was made into a garden. We see a large entranceway that is entered from corridor 1 on the S.W. side. There is no floor, for the walls there are fragments and there is no roof.  At the S.E. wall, seen to the right upon entering there are badly damaged traces of plaster.  The N.E. wall is badly damaged. There is some reconstruction with traces of plaster, the color is indiscernible. In the middle of the wall, there is an arched and recessed niche; it is possibly a lararium at one time. There exist traces of plaster and white paint -present- inside the niche.  The N.W. wall is badly damaged, there is evidence of a stairway seen to the right. It is facing the West wall, it is badly damaged. There is sign of some reconstruction and no trace of plaster. As you enter the garden space, the wall situated on the left side of the garden contains some traces of plaster with possible paint, on the plaster. The Western wall is badly damaged!
column53: The photo team leader is Rob Brown
column74: The video team leader it Carlos Avila

column14: Room 9 (#3929) is to the North West of this dining room.
column21: We step up slightly into a large rectangular room, the view is of a dining room. Because of this position and the view to a horticultural room. (This room is not a perfect rectangle.) The South East wall is shorter than the garden room wall. The walls are bereft of plaster and painting. These are very old walls, whereas the entrance piers are made of brick. The old walls are made of opus incertum. The room is raised to 6 inches above the garden room. The threshold is marble. There are no features in the room.

column14: Room 10 is to the E.
column21: From atrium we approach a garden room from two doors.  E. door has marble threshold.  There is a window that looks into the garden area.  As we enter Eastern threshold we see a rectangular garden.  The N.E. wall shows red paint on the lower register, all across the back of the room.  There is a raised bed on ceramic tile, portions of raised bed edged with terra cotta tiles, which were covered in red plaster.  This garden room has opening to the dining room (10), two openings to the atrium (2), traces of plaster are found on the S.W. wall.  There is a large window in the center of the S. wall.  From the garden we move to Room 10, totally open to the garden's N.E. room. A gutter around the garden bed has an irrigation ditch, two drains on N. wall of garden bed that connects to the water drain, to water the garden.  The ceiling is no longer extant, the floor is dirt.  In the N. corner of the N./N.E. wall, about 6 feet up, is a lararium niche which had been plastered over.  The open area around the garden appears to have been roofed on the N., S., W., passage ways. On the E. wall there are 4 indentations for the wall roof beams, two on the N. side, 2 on the S. side.

column14: The room is to the south of room 13 and to the northeast of storeroom 14.
column21: This room is a small rectangular kitchen. The doorway is in the middle of where the ruined NW wall would be. To the E of the doorway the wall contains traces of painted plaster: red in color and on the lower part with very faint painted decorations above. Along that east wall, you first see a preparation(feature #3935) platform low to the wall. Continuing to the south end of that wall,the major cooking platform (12-3932) touches the wall. The southeast wall also shows traces of red plaster and a ceramic drain runs down the south corner of that wall and a second drain is to the southeast immediately to the adjacent cooking platform. The cooking platform runs from the east corner 3/4 of the way along the southeast wall towards the south corner.Immediately adjacent to the cooking platform, based upon the evidence of the wall pipe is latrine.(feature # 3933)The southwest wall shows only faint evidence of plaster with no color remaining.On the southeast wall at the top are 5 posthole openings showing evidence for an upper level.

column14: Feature 3935 (prep) is situated to the North East of  latrine (3933), seen to the South West.
column21: This rectangular cooking platform is located in the South East corner of room 12. It runs lengthwise along the South East wall, constructed of masonry, the platform is today covered with moss with no visible tiling or decoration. The cooking platform is approximately knee high.

column14: The rooms is situated in the South West corner of the structure address, 9.6.3. This room is to the East of room 15. This room is South West of the kitchen (12).
column21: The storeroom is a situated square on a North West to South East axis. A door is located in the North corner and is of extremely low height, giving the impression that this would have been a servants room. Plaster remains on the South East and South West walls in light/small quantities. On the South West wall, at head height, there is a square window opening to the street. A second doorway is located in the corner of the North wall and is greater in height than the other door. In the South corner of the room, a ceramic pipe runs through the wall and is visible through cracks in the plaster. On the South West wall is a rectangular window that opens at waist height to address 9.6.2 and a square indentation in the wall is seen above the window. It indicates a possibility of a second level to the house. The West wall, seen directly across, appears to be reconstructed and there is no matching indentation. The floor is ground dirt. There is no ceiling.

column14: Immediately to the southwest of the cooking platform (#3932) and across the room to the southwest of platform (#3935)
column21: In the south corner of the southeast wall of room 12, it appears to be a latrine. Identification is based upon 2 large ceramic pipes running through the wall in the southwest corner and the fact that it is adjacent to the cooking platform.

column14: Directly adjacent to the cooking platform (#3932) and across the room to the northeast of the latrine (#3933)
column21: This low rectangular platform stands about 20 centimeter tall in the middle of the northeast wall of the kitchen directly touching the cooking platform to the southeast. Very little remains of the platform, other than some plaster work situated on the northwest edge.

column14: The drain is situated northeast. (#3937)
column21: On the northeast wall there is a red ceramic drain pipe that runs the height of the wall, ends in cites above the garden bed, the plaster is covered with orange, red, and pink paint.

column14: Feature 3936 (drain) situated north, drains to the west.
column21: Situated in the northeast wall (red), there is a drain pipe which runs the height of the wall, 3 inches above the garden bed. It is covered with orange, red, and pink plaster patches.

column14: It is contiguous to the dining couch, #3940, to the west.
column21: The semicircular couch is made of solid masonry construction.  The couch is shaped like a 'C' with the opening facing the south west direction.  The couch has a high arched back covered with masonry on all sides.  The back of the couch, to the north west, is covered with red plaster.  The center back of the couch directly abuts a protruding rectangular pillar from the temple building.  The back to the north east and east is also stucco with red plaster.  Overall the construction is of concrete.  The interior of the bench has a seat.  Above the seat the concrete is covered with red plaster.  There is little plaster remaining on the seat itself.  From the seat to the ground there appears to be a black and white striped vertical fresco pattern.  The two ends of the couch are also frescoed, but only the south east end has any remaining red-covered plaster.

column14: This feature is south of the ramp (1-3948) and surrounds the table (4-3958).
column21: This is the south triclinium located in front of the temple portico.  This was an outdoor dining area.  No ground surface is visible.  The triclinium constructed of large benches of opus incertum covered with a level of cocciapesto and an outer surface of plaster conserving red paint.  This painted plaster is preserved along the lower side of the southern couch as well as the southwest corner of the western couch.  Plaster is also preserved on the northern end of the eastern couch.  There is preserved plaster on the outer wall of the eastern couch and the southern couch.The outer base of the temple is also plastered and painted red.

column14: This feature is contiguous to ramp (1 - 3948). This feature surrounds the table feature (4 - 3957).
column21: This is the north east triclinium located in front of the Temple Portico. This was an outdoor dining area. No ground surface is visible. The triclinium is constructed of large benches of opus incertum covered with a level of coccia pesto. The benches have an outer surface of plaster painted in red paint. This painted plaster is preserved on the inner walls of the eastern couch. There are also smaller remains at the counter of the north couch and on the inner northern corner of the west couch. The couch ends facing the south - towards the ramp (1-3948) - also preserve plaster with red paint; as does the western outer edge of the couch. There is some plaster on the outside wall of the east bench. The ground level has a lower cut, exposing more of the wall height than on the south triclinium (4 - 3940).

This wonderful pedimental sculpture has been placed in a modern frame, at the appropriate height above portico entrance. The central area of the pediment is occupied by two large figures. To the left is Dionysis who is holding in his left hand a bunch of grapes, his right arm is stretched out and his right hand is holding a goblet. He is smiling and has abundant curls. He wears a short girded tunic. To the right is a reclining female figure, who may be Ariadne or Aphrodite. The female figure's head is now missing. Her right hand is on her abdomen, her left hand holds her veil. To the left bottom of Dionysis, beyond his goblet is his pet panther, stretched out to receive a wine sprinkling. To the right of the female figure, at her feet is a putti holding a fan in his right hand, and his left hand rests on one of his wings. Between the central figures is a Thrysus. The temple is totally covered on top by plexi glass.

column14: The ramp is in the central space between the triclinia north (3939) and triclinia south (3940). It is on the west side of the portico in the exterior space (4-3955).
column21: This is an entrance ramp situated at the counter of the western wall. It extends outward from the portico into the central area of the dining forecourt. It rises from about 7 centimeters above present ground level to approximately less than 1 meter in height at the portico entrance. It is aligned with the temple on an east-west axis. The construction of this ramp is opus incertum with a cocciopesto layer and pebble surface. There is an oscan inscription across the east end of the ramp. On the south side of the ramp there are 3 blocks along the edge which appears to be insitu.
There were furrows and root cavities visible at the time of excavation.
There were furrows and root cavities visible at the time of excavation.
There were furrows and root cavities visible at the time of excavation.

column14: This horticultural area is to the east of space 4 and to the south of the temple.
column21: The horticultural area is to the south of the temple structure and is in an east west configuration. It  contains a semi-circular dining couch (#3938) and a negative feature (#3942) of vine plantings.  The current area is in a triangular shape which narrows towards the east end.  The temple wall runs along the north edge and contains a lower masonry step.  A second plaster covered step is covered in red paint.  The upper wall with white plaster remains in pieces.  The upper wall is recessed from the second step with the exterior remains of two to three columns showing.  Currently there are pieces of the upper metope construction.  The ground is now covered with modern gravel.   Jachemski says when excavation occurred planting furrows and root cavities were visible.

column14: To sacred space is to the east, the ramp is to the west, room 7 is to the north, room 5 is to the south
column21: We enter the Temple of Dionysus from a ramp that slopes upward towards the east. Over our heads there is a pediment. The room is a portico in the most ancient part of the temple.
