There are 8 very large columns - which are probably doric - and supporting the temple roof. The floor shows minimal evidence of concrete. Columns show evidence of concrete painted with red paint. Between the columns there are benches. Benches would be part of any eating and drinking ritual. There are 3 benches between the columns along the south wall. There is 1 bench between 2 columns along the western wall, south of the entrance ramp. There is an additional bench between 2 columns along the western wall to the north of the ramp. Columns show tiny portions of marble fluting. There is a possibility of a doorway previously existing on the north wall. There is a bench on the north wall. The huge ashler walls surround the back portion of the oldest part of the temple. Most benches have been finished with modern cement and show traces of red paint on the south west limits of the portico. There are 2 prepared threshold stones leading to the sacred space area, and other. There are blocks of worked architectural components within the room that have fallen from architrides.

column14: Triclinia (#3939) is to the west, the temple is to the south, area 6 is to the east.
column21: Area 7 is located on the north side of the temple and is of uncertain dimension because of the presence of the remains of modern walls. The axis of the space is east west. The ground is now modern gravel and dirt but original excavation reports speak of grapevines and planting furrows. The side wall of the temple appears to have had 2 steps with a later addition of the wall above them. The bottom step is of undecorated masonry. The facing of the second step shows remains of plaster with red paint. The temple wall above that is contiguous to room #3, this section of the interior contains remains of white painted plaster. Continuing along the wall to the west, a rectangular block protrudes with plaster remaining only on the west side. To the west of the lock, is a short wall of opus incertum, followed by round column with remains of plaster in a fluted pattern decorating the exterior only, while the interior of the column is plain. To the west of this column is an entrance way into temple room 2, followed by another similar round column also with fluted decoration on the bottom exterior. There is another short opus incertum wall. Both of these opus incertum walls appear to have been added to the portico (room 2) at a date later than the walls surrounding the sacred space. To the farthest west they are capped by another round column with no evidence of exterior decoration. The back of Triclinium (#3939) is made of opus incertum covered with plaster and directly delineates the west end of the space. The area today contains many large stone blocks that originally may have been part of the temple, likely  the frieze.

The south wall has 3 columns and 3 benches.  Along the west wall there are 2 very large entrance columns framing the opening for the ramp.  Benches are on either side of the columns of the west wall.  Two large columns on the north side preserve evidence of fluting.  There are 2 benches on this wall.  All 7 benches preserve painted red plaster.  Several benches, on seat portion, show inch 2 to 5 cm of modern cement reinforcement.

column14: It is contiguous to space (5) to the south west back wall of the temple to the west, and to space seven to the south west.
column21: This horticultural area (6) consists of the irregularly shaped space at the back of the temple.  Modern walls limit what we can know of the actual area.  The axis of the space is in a north south direction.  The ground has new modern gravel and dirt, but original excavation reports (see citation) speak of grapevines and planting furrows.  The back wall of the temple appears to have had two steps with a later addition of the wall above them.  The bottom step today is of undecorated tufa masonry.  The facing of the second step shows remains of plaster with red paint.  The temple wall above shows plaster remains of white paint.  The area today contains many large stone blocks that were originally part of the the temple, likely the frieze.

column14: It is centrally located on the east wall of room three. The location is directly to the east of the preparation feature (#3953).
column21: The rectangular storeroom runs in a north south orientation. The storeroom appears to be cut out and dug below room three. At the north end of the depression there may have been stairs leading down; only one now remains. The east wall is created unevenly from the large block structure of the temple wall. The west wall is also unevenly constructed with masonry jutting out on the west wall. The south wall is narrow and flat and could possibly require further digging downward. Construction is of masonry, opus incertum on the three interior walls. Floor is composed of lapilli rubble. No roof covers this below the ground spot.

column14: It is contiguous to the east of room two  (#3949) and to the west of the horticultural area, six (#3946).
column21: This space is a sacred space.  The large rectangular space runs on a north south axis.  It is accessed by an open masonry threshold, from the west.  The wall construction is of large tufa blocks in the Samnite style. The floor is cocciopesto and is partially intact.  The ruined floor areas are covered by lapilli.  In the centre of the room is a P-shaped preparation structure (#3953) of more recent opus incertum, construction.  There is no remaining plaster on any of the interior walls of this room except for a small amount on the base of the north east wall.  The storeroom (#3951) is located at the east end of this room in the middle of the wall.

column14: This feature is an inscription in the ramp (1-3948) and is white in color.
column21: This is an oscan inscription is in white stone on the pebble surface of the east end of the ramp (1-3948). The translation is Oscan - "Oppius appidius oppi filius trebius mezius trebii filius aediles - ovius epidius son of ovius and trebuis mettius, son of trebius, aediles"(Cooley, 2004). This inscription refers to donors.

column14: This space is located west of the portico (2). It is outside of the temple.
column21: This space is a forecourt at the western entrance side of the temple. No original ground surface is visible. Presumably, this was an open space with no walls except for the exterior western wall of the temple portico. Excavated post holes attest to a pergola covering (not discernable). This space would have been used for dining. Flanking both sides of a central ramp are 2 triclinia (3939 (north))(3940 (south)) covered in plaster and painted couches. There is a circular table (3957 (north)) (3958 (south)) in the centre of each space.

Two post holes were recognized by plastic coverings. One is located directly south of the ramp (1-3948) and the other is located at the northern end of the south triclinia (west bench). These holes presumably held posts for a pergola covering the triclinium area.

column14: This table is centered in the space inside the north triclinium (4-3939).
column21: This circular table is centered in the space of the north triclinium.  It is circular and is constructed of opus incertum and was covered with a thick plaster layer with ocra, red and black paint splashes.  This plaster is on top and around all sides.

column14: It is located centrally in room three (#3952) with the storage space (#3951), to the east.
column21: The preparation platform is in the centre of the sacred space in room three which is the innermost room of the temple (#3952).  The masonry structure is made of opus incertum, and the tile pieces appear to have come from Roman times, while the construction of the temple appears Samnitic.  The preparation platform is square, with a thick wall continuing from it to the north, giving it a shape of a sideways letter P.  There isn't any  plaster appearing on the outside of either the square platform or the short wall. The shape of the interior of the platform is uncertain, although the presence of some of the interior masonry indicates that it may have been round.  The interior of the platform is now filled with rubble from about 18 inches, or  30 centimetres down.

column14: This table feature is centered in the space inside the north triclinium (4-3939).
column21: This table is centered in the space of the south triclinium. It is circular and is constructed of opus incertum and was covered with a thick plaster layer. This plaster is preserved in a small section on the eastern side of the table. The plaster is painted with ocre red and black splatters.

column14: The dining room is located West of atrium (2). It is South West of cubiculum (4). It is North West of fauces (1).
column21: The dining room (3) is on a North West axis and is rectangular. It is entered from the door from the atrium on the East corner of the North East wall. The doorway is not exceptionally wide, however the sight line would run through the atrium to the garden behind. The doorway has slight remains of a cement threshold. The South East wall was originally covered with scored plaster; but no painted plaster remains. The South West wall runs along the street-side of the building and contains a high rectangular window as well as two post-holes indicating a second story or a shelf. Most likely a second floor. The wall has signs of plaster and scoring. The North West and North East walls are patched, but otherwise identical to the first 2 with no windows or post-holes and scoring is present. A faint trace of what might be red plaster remains on the North East wall next to the doorway. The floor is lapilli.

column14: This preparation room is S.W. of the atrium and is S.W. of room 14-3934.  It is N.W. of the kitchen (12-3930)
column21: This is a preparation room.  It is a small rectangular space on a N.E.-S.W. axis.  One enters the atrium from the N.E. side of the room.  No original top flooring exists.  In the N.E. corner of the room there is a cutting through the floor.  In the N. corner of the room there is a well.  The well is topped with a ceramic putile (13-3960), the putile is in situation.On the S.W. side of the room is a low doorway to a store room (14-3934).This room is a step up from the atrium.  There is a grey stone threshold.The walls are preserved to about 2.5 meters.  The upper portions have been reconstructed.  The walls preserve traces of plaster, over an opus incertum construction.

column14: This well is located just to the North of the doorway leading to the atrium (2).
column21: This is a well located in the North corner of the preparation room (13-3959). The well is stone lined. It is visible to a depth of 1/2 meter. The well is covered by a ceramic putile. This is in situ and level. It is decorative with a base molding and rim. The putile is intact except for chips missing from the rim and base.

This space was noted as a triclinium by Eschorbach. But in the bombed state of this house, there is no evidence pointing to the function of this room. This space is northwest of the fauces in the western corner of the house. It is a rectangular space on a northwest - southeast axis. The entrance to this room is in the eastern corner along the northeast wall. All that remains are minimal traces of walls. Near the doorway plaster is observed on a partial standing wall. At the corner of the northeast wall a curved plastered section steps back into that wall. (situated at wall bottom)

column14: The room is to the east of fauces 1 and to the south of atrium 3.
column21: In a ruined bombed - out structure, all that remains is evidence of a masonry cooking platform to identify room 2 as a kitchen. The room appears to be L -shaped at an east west axis. With the cooking platform located to the south tucked under an external staircase. Little of the walls remains, but the wall to the southwest has some red plaster. It appears that the doorway to the room would have been in the northeast corner. The floor is rubble. Identification of the room is based on Eschebach.

column14: This space is contiguous  to the atrium which is North of this garden.
column21: This space has been classified as a garden. The area is not fully excavated so only the South West end and the North West parts of the space are visible. The original space was almost square. One would enter from the atrium (1) through a door in the Northern corner of the North East wall. This North East wall also had a doorway towards the Eastern end accessing room (3). Only the South West and North West walls are visible. The floor surface is not visible. No roof remains. The condition of the space is very poor. The North half of the North West wall is brick. There is a large window in the Northern half of the wall looking into room (5). The Western end of the North West wall has a small high window looking into the house 9.6.5 room (13). This wall preserves plaster and paint with a large red panel towards the center of the wall. There are 5 small holes above the window corresponding to the partition wall which would have held small roofing beams creating a roofed storage area. This storage area has 3 pairs of holes in the South West wall, presumably for shelving. The interior of this space was plastered. Possible hinge or bolt hole on Southern wall of storage area. The Southern corner of the garden is occupied by a large lararium. The South West wall between the lararium and the storage area was plastered and painted with red panels. Other than the brickwork on the North West wall, the walls are incertum.

This is a large ornate lararium located in the southern end of the garden (4-3977).  This has a large apsidle niche with a pedimented front.  The niche is flanked at the corners with plastered, molded, fluted corinthian columns and the interior of the niche is topped by a large plaster sea shell.The niche is flanked with smaller (possibly cornthian with a patera) columns supporting the niche arch.  A band of molded floral decoration runs across the interior of the niche.  The front surface is painted with an unidentifiable sea serpent in the right hand corner of the front with red and blue floral vine below.The pediment of this structure has egg and dart molding.  The pediment has one patera centered, with a torch (?) to the left.The painting within the niche preserved a yellow background with birds and flying puti.  The alter is in situation.  It is square brick with a white stone top.

column14: It is placed in the southeast corner of room 2.
column21: In the southeast corner of room 2, tucked under an external staircase there is a masonry cooking platform. It is rectangular in shape and in a very ruinous condition. No surface top remains but there is a small amount of plaster on the southwest corner that shows original construction.

column14: Room is to the southwest of cubiculum 4, west of atrium 2, and northwest of fauces 1.
column21: Dining room 3 is in the northwest corner of the property. It is entered from atrium 2. The room is large and rectangular and on a northeast - southwest axis. The doorway is extremely high and located on the northeast wall. The north part of the wall shows evidence of black painted decoration and frescoing with a piece of white crown molding at door height with 3 round post holes below it, running in a vertical direction. The east portion of this wall contains cupboard niche (3965) with plastered wall above. At about the height of 5 feet, there is a cut out in the masonry which may have been an attachment for the door. Another round cutout appears to be close to the same location but on the door jam instead of the wall. Turning the corner to the southeast, plaster remains through most although no decoration is evident. The southwest wall was also plastered covered with reminisce still remaining today with square post holes indicating an upper story. The northwest wall also would have been plaster and contained a high rectangular window. The floor is rubble. Room is identified as a dining room despite the narrow doorway because of the size of the room and the view through the atrium, tablinum, and peristyle beyond.

column14: This niche is in the E. corner of the room, next to the doorway.
column21: Directly to the S.E. of the doorway in room #3, on the N.E. wall, is an indented area, fully plastered, that appears to have been cut out for the placement of possibly a cupboard.  The indentation was plastered over and appears to have 4th style wall painting on it.  The niche looks like it is approximately 4 feet high by 3.5 feet wide (see drawing for exact measurements).  The niche abuts the E. corner of the room.

column14: Room 20 is to the SE of fauces 1, to the SE of atrim (2), and to the S of cubiculum 19.
column21: Entered from the NE corner, the rectangular dining room (20) is on a NW-SE axis, immediately to the SE of the fauces.  Entering from the atrium, there is a cement threshold with indentations showing the presence of a door.  Much of this room is rubble from the bomb that hit the property next door.  With walls only remaining on the NE and SW sides, the ruined NE wall is of opus incertum and undecorated.  The SW wall, on the street side of the building, shows traces of 4th style painting with white fields and red trim all around.  The floor is rubble.  This room was identified as a dining room because of it's view through the atrium and tablinum to the peristyle beyond.  It also is of a slightly larger size than a cubiculum would be.

column14: Peristyle is to the north.
column21: We walk through a large threshold from the peristyle area. This is a dining room by virtue of its shape, by virtue of its shape, by virtue of its view to the peristyle, and by virtue of the small patches of plaster on 3 of the walls. On the south corner there is white, red, and a small segment of yellow. There is a small high window in the wall to allow breezes. The floor is covered with weeds and stones. In the northwest corner there are a pile of stones. This is a large house. The room leads to a large peristyle. In order to move to the primary entrance you need to move to an area between this room and the tiblinium. The northwest section of the north wall has an ancient partition which contains the high window. The ceiling is no longer extant.

column14: Room 9 Atrium southwest
column21: This dining room is in the northeast wall opposite the peristyle.  We have determined it is a dining room. Diners would look at the peristyle, but not see the Atrium.The general condition of this room is bad, some plaster remains on the walls and the floor is not visible. It has a wide doorway, which looks out on the peristyle. The door to the peristyle is very wide and only one side of the door exists.There are no features in this dining room other than some white plaster on the southeast wall and the northwest wall. No ceiling is extant. This area has much green foliage.

column14: The room is northeast of the peristyle, and is southeast of the street.
column21: This is a large kitchen. It is a rectangular space on a northwest - southeast axis. On the northwest wall at the west corner is entrance 7 from the street. On the southwest wall in the west corner there is a door to the peristyle (9). To the northeast of the room is a latrine in the north corner of the house and to the southeast of the latrine is a storage room (3972). This kitchen has a cooking platform in the north corner of the room along the northwest wall (3970). Near the corner of the northeast wall is a long rectangular vat (3971). In the east corner along the southeast wall is a doorway into room 14. In the south corer along the southeast wall is walled in brick archway. The condition of this space is poor. A stone threshold at entrance 7 is visible but no other floor surface is exposed. There is no roofing present. The walls are preserved at about 4 meters. The southwest wall preserves plaster with a projecting dado at about 1 1/2 meters height. This dado is of an orange and pinkish color. One small low window and a small niche are in the south corner of this wall and the window looks into the peristyle.The brick arch in the southeast wall is set back from the surface of the wall. The arch way is filled except for a window at the apex of the arch. This wall was also plastered and has remains of the pink dado. The doorway in the east corner along the southeast wall is in very poor condition and is braced with modern scaffolding. Except for the brickwork arch the rest of the room is opus incertum. Two joist holes are visible on the southwest wall and two are visible in the east corner of the northeast wall. These holes are not aligned to each other across the room.

column14: This cooking platform is located N of doorway 7 and NW of the vat (11-3971)
column21: This rectangular platform, at the N corner, along the NW wall of the kitchen (11-3969), is of rubble construction.  It is preserved to it's full height in the N corner where a ceramic tile surface is preserved.  Along the NE edge the remains of the partition are visible.  A small trace of plaster coating remains at the lower eastern corner of the platform.

column14: Room (8) is to the northwest of atrium (1), to the west of room 9 and to the east of room (7).
column21: Room (8) is identified as a dining room based on it's size and position overlooking the atrium. The rectangular room is accessed by a stone threshold from the atrium on the south east side of the room. The dining room has a northeast and southwest axis. The walls are of opus incertum. The floor is coccio pesto. Faint traces of plaster can be seen high up on the northwest wall and a post-hole type opening is to be found in the upper north corner.

column14: This Vat is situated southeast of the cooking platform(11-3970), and is along the southwest wall of room #13 (13-3972).
column21: This is a rectangular Vat located in the center of the northeastern wall of the Kitchen (11-3969). The northwest side of the Vat is made of ashlar, with the exterior plastered. The southwest and southeast sides of the Vat are made of rubble construction. The Vat abuts the northeast wall, but the rubble construction is not flush with the rest of the wall and it abuts to the eastern end of the wall.The Vat has not been emptied and the interior is not visible.

column14: This room sits to the NE of the kitchen (11-3969) and the vat (11-3971).
column21: This is a small rectangular space which may have served as a storage room.  The entrance is at the western corner, along the SW wall, off of the kitchen (3969).  The room is on a NW-SE axis.  This space is in very poor condition and is being braced with modern scaffolding.The NW wall is only preserved to a maximum of 1.6 meters (approximately).  The NE wall is preserved to 4 meters and the SE wall is preserved at a higher level.  These walls are opus incertum, with plaster preserved on NE and SE walls.  The SW wall appears to be a later addition.  No floor is visible and no ceiling remains.There is a series of 4 holes along the NE wall, at about 3 meters height, which may have held a joist for a low ceiling or a shelf.There is an opening on the SE wall which may have been a small window looking into the next house (?).

column14: This lararium is just south of the small window on the southwest all. The brick archway in the southeast wall is directly east of the lararium. The vat (3971) is to the north.
column21: In the south corner along the southwest wall is a small lararium. This is a small rectangular niche with a sloping top. Traces of plaster remain along the top (sloped) and southeast side.

column14: This kitchen is to the back of the atrium behind the dining room. Room (7) is to the northeast of the kitchen.
column21: We have determined that this is a kitchen with a cooking platform in the southwest corner. It is a small rectangular room. There are traces of light beige and orange paint on the southeast wall. The northwest wall that borders the street is totally missing. The entrance is shored up in the shape of a barrel vault. The ceiling is gone. The floor is pounded ground.

As you enter the kitchen, you see a cooking platform in the southwest corner. It is rectangular in shape. The top is covered with soil and weeds. We cannot see a lip. Some tile and brick are discernible from the front. There is a triangular receptacle, to hold wood.

column14: The latrine is to the south east of the cooking platform (#3984) in the east corner of the kitchen room (five).
column21: We have identified the space in the east corner of the kitchen room (five), as a latrine.  This is based upon the wall curvature in that corner, as well as the possibility that the pieces of the terra cotta, that we see in the corner, were part of a water pipe coming from the floor above.  The space today is covered with fresh and loose stones, but was previously identified by Eschebach.

column14: The niche is on the west corner of the southwest wall.
column21: We have determined that in the west corner of the southwest wall of dining room (3) there appears to have been an indentation at floor level rising about 60 centimeters that may have been a niche used for couch placement.  This is determined based upon the appearance of the plaster in a downward curving fashion.  In addition the lowest level of painting, the dado, appears to set this indentation off when viewed from a distance.  Wall construction behind was of opus incertum.

column14: The platform is northwest to the latrine (3985)
column21: In the north corner of kitchen (5) sits a rectangular masonry structure in fairly ruinous condition. The structure is unusual in that the storage area under the platform counter is square, lacks the typical arch, and is located at the north end (rather than the usual central placement). The top shows remains of a tiled surface, but very little is extant. The cooking platform's short end abuts the northwest wall and the longer end abuts the northeast wall. The platform stands about knee high.

column14: The kitchen is contiguous to the tablinum (6) to the south.
column21: We have determined that this is a kitchen in the house of Dido and Aeneas based on the evidence of a cooking platform in the north corner as well as a latrine in the northeast corner. This is a square room oriented in a northeast, southwest alignment. It is northwest of the tablinum (office), the atrium, the shop, and the street. The original floor surface is not visible due to the pounded earth, lapilli, and green weeds that are now present. Remnants of stairs are visible in the west corner of the room. No ceiling remains and there are very few patches of plaster on the walls. There are no windows, but there is a door on the southeast wall, leading to the tablinum (6).

column14: This space s northwest of the atrium (space 2). It is southwest of spaces 5 and 6.
column21: We have determined that this room is a dining room. This is a rectangular space on a southeast-northwest axis. The entrance to this room is a wide opening in the southeast wall. This room opens to the atrium (space two) at the southeast. On the northwest wall there is a large central window opening to a light well with a well-head adjacent to the southwest wall of the light well. There may have been a decorative fountain in this small space. A door leading into space six is located in the eastern corner of the northeast wall. The room was highly decorative. The condition is poor. The walls are opus incertum in the central areas, while on the southeast wall, the northwest wall, and the eastern end in the northeast wall, there are alternating courses of brick and cut stone. On the western corner of the southwest wall, there is a cut niche (3-3983). Preserved paint reveals a low dado. the walls were decorated with large panels of alternating colors, including red and yellow. On the northwest wall, the corners preserve a border of green paint. In the upper northern corner there are remains of decorative molding. This border may have slightly arched across the northwest wall although there are eleven beam holes cross this wall just above the height of the molding. There is no visible flooring surface. There is no ceiling preserved. There is some conservation and restoration of walls.

We have determined that this is a small food and drink shop because of the following two reasons: first, it's location is on Via D'Dabbondanza; and the presence of a counter with dolia inserts, and a hearth.  The room runs on a northwest/southeast axis, off the street at the south corner of region 9, insula 7.  The southwest side of the space contains a food counter (#3992) in an L-shape, with a preparation platform (#3994) situated behind.  The southwest wall also contains a series of holes indicating a shelf (#3993) or an awning, it was fixed to it.  A beam hole high above may indicate an upper story, but it is uncertain based upon the remains.  The wall has remnants of plaster covering it with traces of red paint.  There is a tag stating that parts of the wall were restored in 1985.  The northwest wall also has some traces of plaster with red paint and is made of opus incertum.  There may have been an ancient doorway to the room behind.  We believe that the fill in the door area is modern, but it is not labeled as such.  If it is modern, there would be a step up to the door.  The northeast wall has traces of red and white plaster and is made of opus incertum.The southeast wall has a high doorway to the street, it is reached by a high step up.  The threshold is granite with a deep cut where the closed shop door would have been. The door appears to be connected on the northeast side.  Inside of the doorway, there are traces of decorated plaster.  There is some plaster on the exterior wall as well, facing the street.  The floor was tiled with cocciopesto, but very little remains.  No ceiling, remaining.

column14: The prep platform (3994) is to the northwest.  The shelves are to the west.
column21: The L-shaped counter shows repurposed marble on the top.  Five dolia are seen, recessed into the platform.  Four have a ceramic lip.  All of the dolia are filled with lappilli about 12.5 centimeters from the top.  As part of this L-shaped counter, there is a stone and tile hearth.  On the long exterior side to the southeast of the counter are traces of red, painted plaster.  The counter is located in the south corner at the front of the store front.

column14: This feature would have been on the wall going from above the counter (1-3992) and the preparation platform (1-3994).
column21: We have determined that three small holes through the plaster on the southwest wall were cut to hold a shelf. Those holes are approximately three meters high and are aligned horizontally across the wall. The two end holes are located roughly forty centimeters above two more holes which may have held the brackets for the shelf.

column14: this platform is west of the counter (#1 -3992)
column21: We have determined that this feature is a preparation platform.  It is located in the west corner of the room.  This platform has two blocks, the higher one is in the corner and the smaller lower one is to the south of the large one.  These form a step-like platform.  The platform is opus incertum covered with a gray mortar.  There is some ceramic tile and brick inlaid into the surface.  It is in fairly good condition.  It is only missing a small section of the lower step.

column14: This room is to the northwest of the atrium (#2), and it is northwest of space #6.
column21: We have determined that this space is a dining room.  It is a square room on a northwest-southeast axis.  This room  is entered through a doorway on the eastern end of the southeast wall.  This room opens to the atrium (#2).  There is a white marble threshold, at this entry.Although the walls are preserved to over four meters, the room is in poor condition.  The original floor surface is not visible.  There is no ceiling remaining.  The walls are opus incertum.  Plaster is preserved on all four walls and painted surfaces can be seen along the bottoms of the southeast and northeast walls.  These areas show red paint.  So little paint remains, it is difficult to discern the style.  There are lines in red and yellow on the upper northeast wall which may indicate fourth style.  The only remaining upper molding is a horizontal band situated along the upper northwest wall at the north end.

column14: This room is continuous to Preparation Room (11) to the west and room 9 to the northeast.
column21: This room is determined to be a dining room because of it's slightly irregular rectangular shape, the room's location, the room's large doorway, and the painted plaster walls. There are two entrance piers with no discernible threshold at the northwest entrance to the room. This room would have overlooked the peristyle and interior peristyle garden, but these peristyle's are now gone. The entire Eastern side of this house is now piled bomb debris. The floor is now pounded earth with green weeds. On the northeast wall remains red and white plaster which continues on the southeast wall and the southwest wall. The southwest wall has moldings and portions of a cornice. The wall continues two and a half meters above the molding. In the west corner of the southwest wall there is a low doorway to a small room (11). There is no ceiling remaining to this room.

column14: The room is contiguous to room 9 (peristyle) to the north. Room 10 (dining room) is to the east.
column21: We have determined that this is a preparation room. It has a low doorway in the west wall that leads to a dining room (10). A high window is located in the southeast wall. There are post holes for a second floor, in the southeast wall. There is a doorway in the northwest wall that leads to the peristyle (9). This room shows traces of a barrel vault ceiling however no ceiling remains. There are plaster patches of red seen on the east wall and other patches of plaster on the south wall. The ground is a pounded soil with weeds.

column14: This room is to the northwest of a small room possibly a preparation room.  It is to the northeast of the atrium and ala.
column21: We have determined that this is a dining room based on it's location off of the atrium to its southwest side.  Also the large size of this room suggests a dining room as does the white marble threshold. This room is roughly square in shape with a northeast/southwest alignment.  The entrance to this room is located at the south corner of the southwest wall with a fairly high doorway.  It is adjacent to another doorway in the south corner of the southeast wall.  There is no original floor surface visible; the room is in very poor condition.  No ceiling remains.  The walls are preserved for two to four meters in height.  The walls are constructed of opus incertum.  Plaster and paint remains indicate Fourth Style, however, there is very little paint remaining.  This room would have had two stories.

We have determined that this is a market space primarily due to its location on the forum as well as its large size. It is on a northwest/southeast axis. It is rectangular in shape and is divided into two rooms by simple pillars of opus latericium. Room one (to the south) is one step lower than room two. The floor is made of a stone and ceramic mix in a clay basis and although we do not have levels it appears the floor slopes from the near (southwest) of the building to the front (northeast). The southeast wall of the building was bombed in World War 2 and have since been restored. The southwest/northwest walls are well preserved. The southeast wall in room one is reconstructed. The southwest wall is in both rooms one and two as well as the northwest wall in room two. These two walls preserve three courses of support holes for shelves where the walls are visible. These rooms are currently used for artifact storage for items found in Pompeii. The northeast facade, facing the forum, consists of a series of nine opus latericium pillars flanking eight large openings. Only the third entrance in room one moving north from the east corner preserves traces of a double swinging door. In room two the second entrance from the east corner moving toward north also has traces of a double swinging door. Directly to the southeast in the forum is located the mensa ponderaria.

column14: the atrium (3) is to the west
column21: We enter this kitchen from a hallway from the atrium. This doorway is very narrow and low. Looking from the center of the room we see a barrel vault extending into the room over the narrow door on the north wall. On the south wall in the south east corner we see the remains of a cooking platform. The storage area of the cooking platform only protrudes partially above the present floor level. Currently there is no ceiling. There are three walls with no signs of plaster. The only remaining plaster is within the barrel vault. The floor is filled with large blocks of rubble and is highly irregular.

A small cooking platform is identified on the south wall, in the southeast corner.  We identify this by the small arched fuel storage area and a cooking surface.  There are no refinements to the cooking surface.  Most of it is obscured by floor ruble.

We have determined that this is a market space primarily due to its location on the forum as well as its large size. It is on a northwest/southeast axis. It is rectangular in shape and is divided into two rooms by simple pillars of opus latericium. Room one (to the south) is one step lower than room two. The floor is made of a stone and ceramic mix in a clay basis and although we do not have levels it appears the floor slopes from the near (southwest) of the building to the front (northeast). The southeast wall of the building was bombed in World War 2 and have since been restored. The southwest/northwest walls are well preserved. The southeast wall in room one is reconstructed. The southwest wall is in both rooms one and two as well as the northwest wall in room two. These two walls preserve three courses of support holes for shelves where the walls are visible. These rooms are currently used for artifact storage for items found in Pompeii. The northeast facade, facing the forum, consists of a series of nine opus latericium pillars flanking eight large openings. Only the third entrance in room one moving north from the east corner preserves traces of a double swinging door. In room two the second entrance from the east corner moving toward north also has traces of a double swinging door. Directly to the southeast in the forum is located the mensa ponderaria.

Identified as a home structure. We determined that this room is a dining room. This identification is based on the location within the structure. It would overlook the atrium (however this portion is not excavated) there are no features in this room. The conditions of this room suggest it is a dining room. It is rectangular in shape the walls are plastered and painted on all four walls. Door is very high in north end of northeast wall opening to atrium. Northeast wall has picture framed in yellow and red but subject cannot be ascertained. Other three walls also show centrally framed picture spaces. Southwest wall has high windows (12 meters up) and evidence of molding at cornice level. Floor is lapilli. No ceiling remains but evidence of post holes for roof on northwest and southwest walls.

column14: to the north east of serving room 2
column21: We have determined that room number 3 at the back of shop 6.10.1 is a serving room based upon the elaborate third style decoration on the walls. Serving room 3 opens from the south west to serving room 2. Both serving room 2 and serving room 3 are behind a locked gate for which the key is not available. The square room is on a north east/south west axis and has a red bordered dado which contains rectangular paintings that cannot be identified today. Directly above the dado is a narrow band or register of paintings that appear to be of four-legged animals. Above that were white frescoed walls with unidentifiable paintings that are very worn today. The room has a square window in the north east wall  which appears to have been a doorway that was sealed in antiquity (before the final decoration of the room) On the two sides of the window are some round indentations. On the south east wall near the east corner is a small rectangular window. On the exterior of the room on the south east wall is another doorway, walled up in antiquity, that was covered up by plaster (in the interior of the room) in the final phase of the structure's life.

column14: To the northeast of counter room 1.To the southwest of serving room 3 adjacent to the northwest with serving room 4.
column21: Based upon the high level of decoration and its location immediately behind a counter room with a cooking platform, we have identified room 2 as a small serving room.  The room is on a northeast/southwest axis.  The room is entered through a doorway on the southwest side which has a cement threshold.  Another doorway on the northeast wall, with no threshold, continues to serving room 3.  Today the room is behind a locked, iron and barred door which is rusted shut.  The walls visible from that door are all frescoed with remains of red and white painting with designs visible from the door unidentifiable. The floor appears to be of clay.  Modern wood beams hold up a renovated cement ceiling.  On the northwest wall around elbow height is a rectangular indentation identified as a lavarium by Boyce (180).  He described a painting that cannot be seen today.

The dark is presently a dark floor. We have determined that the structure at 6.10.1 is a large food and drink shop. We have reached this identification due to (1) location at street corner, (2) present features of serving counter, hearth, as well as multiple frescoes on the walls, (3) previous research. One entered room four from the north corner of northeast wall (counter room). Threshold raised four inches of concrete and stepping back to level of shop in front. The sides of walls entrance are rubble masonry with traces of plaster and faded red paint on the northwest side. The ceiling and wooden lintel over entrance door are modern. Inside the room facing southwest wall (entrance) is rubble work with traces of plaster. On northern side of southwest wall fresco remains (6711) pertaining to dining. Facing northwest - on northwest wall entrance (19) near middle of the wall there is a raised threshold and step up to level of room (rubble concrete). The northwest wall has traces of plaster and painting. Painting is divided in three main areas. The lower portion has a band of red paint at the same level around all four walls separating the scenes. On northwest wall and all walls the mid region contains frescoes. The upper painted level on all walls is gone. On northwest wall, western side of entrance (19) no fresco remains but traces of red, black, yellow border. We conjecture two frescoes that are no longer extant on western part of northwest wall. On northwest wall, eastern side of entrance (19) there are traces of red border paint and two frescoes. Closest to entrance feature (6712) of wine delivery and on eastern side of northwest feature (6710) a fresco of a man pouring wine. On northeast wall there is rubble interior with traces of red border paint and stucco and traces of fresco with a mans feet only remaining on northern side of northeast wall. One the southeast wall with rubble interior there are traces of stucco and painting as well as five original frescoes with a red border separating the low register from the mid register. Traces of red border define the five separate frescoes. On the eastern part of the southeast wall the first fresco is too badly damaged to identify. Moving form east to west on same wall is fresco feature (6709) showing a tavern scene. The next fresco moving west feature (6798) is a man serving wine. Feature (6707) shows people eating with sausages presumably hanging above. The fresco on western side of southeast wall is too badly damaged, but appears to be a face.

The feature appears to be a square fresco, approximately one and one half meters from the ground. It shows painting in blue, white, red, yellow, and brown. It's damaged.  There are four people sitting at the table eating and a small serving person/child standing, in yellow, on the table.  This person appears to be serving a dish or pan.  There is painted hanging food above the people consisting of sausages, meats, and unknown food objects.  Located on the southeast wall; it has a red border and white background.

The painting appears to be 1.5 meters from the ground.  It is a square fresco with two men, the man closer to the eastern side is dressed in yellow with a blue cloak and appears to be holding a cup. The man in the brown tunic appears to be holding some type of drinking vessel.  This fresco is located on the southeast wall, with a red border and a white background.

This is a square fresco approximately 1.5 meters from the ground.  There is tavern activity, possibly gaming, with a table and a man in red with a blue cloak possibly holding a drinking vessel.  There are four men around a table.  It is located on the southeast wall with a red border and a white background.

This painting is on the north west wall on the eastern side of the  entrance at VI.10.19. The fresco is 1.5 meters off the ground with a red border and a white background. Two figures are shown standing. A man in a brown tunic is  pouring a drink with his left hand into a cup held by a man with a yellow tunic, possibly a blue cloak and spear. The serving man is holding what appears to be keys in his right hand

This is a square fresco, situated approximately 1 1/2 meters off the ground.  It is located on the southwest wall, northern side of the entrance.  There is a red border with a white background.  There appears to be four people, one in blue with a drinking cup.  The painting is damaged.

This painting is on the northwest wall, eastern side of the entrance (VI.10.19).  The fresco is 1.5 meters off the ground, with a red border and white background.  It is badly damaged, and appears to be two donkeys with a wine cart.

column14: The counter room is to the southwest of serving rooms 2 and 4, and is situated to the northeast of the street.
column21: We have determined that the structure at 6.10.1, is a large food and drink shop. We have reached this identification due to the following visible characteristics: (1) location on a street corner, (2) the presence of an L shaped counter and cooking platform, (3) a large opening to the street. One enters from the southwest. The L shaped counter blocks part of the opening, leaving a narrow passageway by the south corner of the threshold. The threshold is at sidewalk level. The cooking platform directly abuts the south corner between the southeast and southwest walls. Situated directly above the cooking platform about 70 centimeters from the cooking platform surface is a narrow rectangular indentation. Seen much higher up on the same wall is a fairly square opening, topped with a piece of terra cotta which may indicate the presence of an upper story. There are several other scattered cuts, jutting into the wall, but its impossible to determine if they are identical or due to site destruction. The northeast wall contains five doorways with stone thresholds. They lead to back serving rooms and are constructed of large blocks. Each doorway has a course of bricks and stone situated above, giving it the appearance of an arch. A little plaster remains on this wall and it was originally painted red. The northwest wall appears to be mostly reconstruct-ed. Remains of red painted fresco are found on the bottom, running under the storage in the northwest corner. A rectangular opening indicates something inserted into the wall, it's situated directly above some of the red plaster. Stepped shelves, are stretching from counter (6704) to the southwest wall. These provide an outline for a semi arched storage area situated below. The floor is made of lapilli rubble. There are no ceiling remains.

column14: To the north of cooking platform 6705.
column21: This is an L-shaped counter, with one side facing the street.  The "L" of the L-shaped counter is positioned with a southwest side (which faces the street) and a southeast side (facing a side interior wall of the shop).  The front side of the counter facing the street has a marble floor molding with cut marble inlaid above.  At the south corner of the L, the counter facing the street protrudes slightly before recessing to the southeast side of the counter.  A painted decoration appears on the front of the southeast side.  The northeast end of the counter today is undecorated but appears to have been previously plastered.The inside of the L is masonry covered with plaster.The top surface of the counter is pieced marble. There are three holes along the long southeast countertop of the L.  In the center hole some terra cotta is visible.  These are unusually narrow as they appear to fit an amphora rather than a dolium.At the west corner of the counter there is a series of at least six marble-covered display shelves that are the width of the counter itself.  The rise of these stepped shelves creates a partial arch, open below, creating a storage area.

column14: This platform is located to the south of counter 6704
column21: This brick cooking platform is located in the south corner of counter room 1, immediately adjacent to the open threshold to the street on the south west. The counter is made of flat rectangular bricks, mortared in between. There is a storage insert opening on the north west side of the cooking platform at floor level. Unusually, rather than an arch this storage area appears to be square and topped with wood. A modern wood insert is in situ today. The top of the cooking platform contains a C-shaped raised support structure with arms to support cooking pots above the fire. On the north east end of the cooking platform the top of the platform was a tiled surface.

We have determined that this contains a feature that is an L shaped counter.  It is a Food and Drink shop. It has a good sized L shaped counter. The foundation base is rubble and modern cement. There is a marker indicating this. It was reshaped , reconstructed in 1985. The short end of the L faces the street. There are traces of red plaster on the bricked peirs. This portion of the counter is faced with reused marble. The long side of the L sits on, what appears to be remains of a rectangular hearth. The floor of the heart contains shaped and cut tiles. The L shaped counter is placed on the S.W. wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is situated to the N.W. of the counter room (1).
column21: It is determined, the large room to the back of the counter room is a large open space, and therefore seems to be where food would be eaten rather than being an area for storage and food space. The room is L shaped and runs on a S.E./N.W. axis, with the bottom of the L turning to the N.E., on the N.W. end of the room. The room is reached by stepping up on a threshold, situated on the S.E. end of the room. A wall would have extended for approximately a quarter of the space from the S.W. side, to the step. The long S.W. wall contains slight occasional traces of plaster. Situated, directly behind the small wall, on the S.W. side, the remains of a ceramic pipe descends through the wall from the floor above. Through discussion, it was considered; a possibility of the pipe leading to a latrine, but this was not confirmed by the available evidence.Situated, high toward the top of the wall are post holes indicating an upper story was present. A round hole seen half way up the wall may have indicated something was attached. For the next item, there was a door that was blocked off in antiquity. All walls are constructed of opus incertum.Moving to the N.W. wall, it appears to be closed off from the property, situated behind in antiquity. Scattered bits of plaster remain, but nothing that can provide a clear idea of how the room was decorated. To the N.E., we have the stepped wall that provides the bottom portion of the L.The furthest portion to the N.E., is simple opus incertim, while the S.E. shows some old block construction, also. As the wall rejoins the long portion of the L, there is an indentation for a well (3982) and a lararium (   ). The lararium is situated directly to the N.E., as you enter from the steps and had a rectangular construction with a canted roof, comprised of a 30 degree angle leading up from the N.E. to the East. The back of the shrine is made of terracotta and the picture that had originally been on it, has been cut out. The floor is composed of rubber lapilli, with no roof present.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Situated on the North end of the N.E. wall.
column21: Situated on the floor, near the N end of the N.E. wall is a square stone well cap with a round cut out seen in the middle of it. The cap is currently covered with a broken meta that does not appear to belong here. The wall is indented above the well, to allow easy access.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is situated N.W. of the street and it is S.E. of room (2-3981)
column21: It is determined, this space is the front room of a food shop. It is a rectangular space, located on a S.E/N.W axis, that opens up to the street at the S.E. end. This food shop or Caupona has a street front L shaped counter (1-3980). The threshold of 3 large blocks of Tuf has a channel situated down the center for shutters, and it is seen across the entire front of the shop. The counter occupies the Southwest half of the front of this room. The N.W. portion of the room provides access to the rear of the room, as well as the space situated behind it, (#2). No original floor surface is visible. The condition of this space is poor with conservation on the walls and counter. The walls are opus incertum, with brick seen at the front of the shop. The walls preserve plaster and are painted in red and yellow. These colors are visible in some places on all the walls. The back wall at the N.W. side of the this space is only partially preserved, on the N.W. side. Seen there, are 5 blocks of limestone creating a threshold, and one can step up to the room behind it (2-3981).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified Oplontis A as a villa. We have determined that this is a serving room based on its location within the structure; adjacent to a dining room and near the kitchen and its large size. A large, high door opens on the north wall into a small corridor which opens to the kitchen. There are no particular features in this room. There is a modern ceiling. The walls are painted in third or fourth style, which shows an interest in updating this room, visible from two aristocratic dining rooms. The floor is cement and shows remnants of opus sec tile. As noted, doors open directly onto a dining room an a corridor with a door to kitchen.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the east of the large dining room (15) and to the west of the preparation room (10A).
column21: We have determined that this is a dining room.  This is based on the character and location of the room as well as previous attribution by the excavators.  This is a large rectangular room aligned on a north/south axis.  One enters the room through a wide entrance the width of the room on the south, which is open to a portico (13) to the south of the room.  On the southeast corner of the wall is a door to a prep room (10A). In the southwest corner of the west wall is a doorway into the large dining room (15).  Room 14 has been highly conserved and the condition is excellent.  The floor is mosaic with a rectangular space defined in the entrance section of the room (south end of room).  A Greek key pattern in polygonal mosaic crosses the east/west axis of the room just north of the entrance area. The dining space is denoted by a central panel placed on the floor, which indicates the three seating areas.  This panel is a polydrome lattiae pattern.     The east and west walls are richly decorated in second style frescoes, with the frescoes revealing internal spaces with doors, ornate columns separating the panels, and elaborate cornices and friezes above.  These spaces provide glimpses beyond the wall, of exterior spaces.       On the west wall a small tholos (round building) rises in the center with a statue of a female figure within.  The north wall continues this scheme with a basket of fruit at each side in an upper window (feature 14-4002 and 14- 4003).  Portions of an upper molded cornice remain, and the ceiling is reconstructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is west of feature 14-4063.
column21: We have determined that this fresco detail is food and drink related because it depicts a bowl of pomegranates.  This is not in very good condition, however, a footed bowl appears filled with fruit and is positioned on the shelf.  This detail is located on the north wall towards the upper west side. It appears to be placed in an opening against a blue back ground.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: round garden light well (     ) to the north, colonnade (   ) to the south
column21: We have identified Oplontis A (Villa of Poppaea) as a villa structure. We have determined that the last usage of this room is as a dining hall. We have identified this as a dining hall because of its location within the structure. Also, the characteristics of the room that identify it as a dining hall include: large mosaic floor with a white background, grey stripe border and chips of green, red, yellow and black in the main area. On the north side is an interior circular garden that serves as a light well. On the south side are the shutters of large windows within the remnants of a massive volcanic strike. The windows on this wall open to a view of a mosaic floor and three columns. The easternmost of the three engaged columns is painted with a spiralling egg-shaped motif in reds and brown. We see a rectangular garden beyond the colonnade. One quarter of the room along the west side, is obscured by volcanic deposits which are held up by modern masonry. The southern end of this obstruction, along the western wall, has a bench. This gated portion is holding sound and light equipment. On the north wall, there is one doorway on the eastern end and a small painted wall between that and the large opening to the round garden. The floor of the smaller door shows post-holes for door furniture and a square geometric, black and white mosaic. On the east wall there is a wall painting covering the full wall. This painting is majestic and contains Apollo's Tripod in the central zone, flanked by painted columns,and zones of architectural elements with theatrical masks and peacocks. The doors opening to views of interior gardens on the north and south also help identify this as a dining room. On the southern end of the east wall is a door to a triclinium for overflow guests. This has a concentrically striped rectangular mosaic floor and two post-holes for door furniture. The room is protected by a modern ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is east of feature 4002.
column21: We have determined this fresco is related to food and drink because this detail depicts a straw basket filled with figs. This basket is depicted as resting on the shelf at upper section of the east side of the north wall. The basket is in front of a blue background. It is located on the east of the north wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This is an exceptionally large cooking platform. It has a tiled surface covering most the top. It has a large lip, along its back edge against the north wall and the east wall. There are three semi circular openings along the front of the platform, to the floor; used for fuel - charcoal or wood. There is no cooking equipment in situ.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified Oplontis A as a villa.  Room 7 is a kitchen.  We have identified this room as a kitchen due to its location in the villa, for it is a large room where many slaves could work, and it is close to the dining rooms.  We have identified a very large cooking platform (4007), two preparation platforms (4009 and 4010), and a water basin (4008).The floor is pounded mud and concrete.  The walls are very high.  There is one high window on the north wall above the cooking platform for venting smoke and a large high window opening to a corridor wall.  The walls were plastered and painted, but the paint is badly preserved.On the west wall is a low doorway to a storage room (100).  It is in a barrel vault.  On the south wall is a high and wide doorway to a hallway.  There is a very high reconstructed ceiling.Sources include Jashemsky, Clark, and Scavi guide.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This is a large water basin on the east wall between two preparation platforms. It is three quarters of a circle, made of stone and cement. The wall behind and above it shows evidence of space for drainage. The interior is round and on the east wall, there is a small drainage hole. On the front, there is a large hole that opens to the kitchen floor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Too cooking platform (4007) and to water basin (4008)
column21: This is a rectangular platform, one half the height of the cooking platform and joined to the cooking platform and the east wall. It is made of cement and stone.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The storeroom is situated to the east of kitchen 7, and to the west of dining room 15.
column21: In the Roman Villa Oplontis A, we have identified a small space to the east of kithchen 7 as room 100, storeroom.  We have made this determination based on the room's size (small, almost square), location off the kitchen, and the fact that the west wall appears to have had an arched opening that was blocked into a traditional rectangular door in antiquity.  The wall above the arched opening is made of opus reticulatum with vaissoirs delineating the arch, indicating a later construction date than the opus incentum in the remaining walls.  The room was plastered and painted with remnants on all four walls.  The west wall contains a small doorway, centrally located, and the possibility of a window opening high above.  Behind some of the plaster can be seen indications that the west wall may also have been arched at one time.  High square post holes in the north, east, and south walls suggest some sort of upper story on the structure above.  The reconstructed west wall appears to have stopped and been capped mid-point.  The floor is clay.  The current ceiling is a reconstruction and is extremely high.  The ceiling height is based on a line above the arch on the west wall, 123 centimeters above the existing door.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the east of hallway 6. To the north of portico 33. To the west off tepidarium 18.
column21: In the Roman Villa of Oplontis A, we have determined that the usage of room 17 is a dining room. This identification is based on a location that includes a large window overlooking the peristyle garden, 33, on the north wall, as well as remains of painted decorated plaster work. Access to the room is through a fairly wide, although not exceptionally tall, doorway from hallway 6, in close proximity to the very large dining hall, 21. The room may also be accessed through a doorway in the southwest corner of the west wall. With three large steps coming up from tepidarium 18. Currently there is also a rectangular opening at ceiling level in the southeast corner of the south wall. The walls have a black dado at floor level, red panels directly above, and what appears to be a fourth style, cream based, painting above. No decorative elements, besides outlining are visible. The floor is black and white mosaic. The threshold of the west door had a geometric pattern with door inserts on either end. The north two thirds of the floor is delineated by two horizontal blue black stripes. The remaining one third of the floor to the south has a black, double striped, rectangular pattern. In the northeast corner of the room there is a short cylindrical, cement object with a wooden central piece, held together currently by thin wire, that we cannot identify as either ancient or modern Much of this room appears to be reconstructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is to south of room 20, to the west of room 17 and corridor 6 and to the east of garden 34, room 30 and corridor 3
column21: We have identified Oplontis A as a Roman villa. We have determined that the last usage of Room 21, the dining hall was for parties and receptions. This identification is based on: 1) the room location in line with the atrium entrance of the villa; 2) the large window in the south wall overlooking garden 20; 3) the great columned opening in the north allowing access and viewing of the large unnumbered garden space; 4) the source identification in guide books. Beginning with the north opening two extremely large fluted columns delineate the threshold with masonry mimicking the fluted pattern on the two side walls. The threshold is marble with a step up from the garden. In between the columns and walls there are three floral patterned black and white mosaics with marble inserts that each show door fasteners to close off the room. The west wall has a large threshold opening on its northern end with remains of the same type of mosaic patterning and slightly larger inserts for doors. The west wall is opus incertum below and opus reticulatum on the surface. The door jambs and wall corners throughout are  of flat brick courses with stonework between. There are series of openings scattered within the opus reticulatum indicating something attached to the wall. These continue on the south and east walls as well which are of the same construction as the west wall. The east wall also has a doorway and mirrors the west wall. The floor is mosaic in black and white and today there is a modern ceiling covering the space. The room is undecorated and, based on field reports, was under construction.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the north of passageway 4. To the east of hallway 3. To the south of dining hall 21. To the west of hallway 6.
column21: In the Roman Villa of Oplontis A, we have determined that the last usage of room 20 was an enclosed garden. The room is on a north - south axis with a large window opening to dining hall 21 and a columned low wall opening towards portico 4 and atrium 5. A water channel runs completely around the exterior walls encircling a raised planting bed. Walls are brightly painted and originally contained garden paintings per Jashemski. A highly decorated cornice is visible on the east and west walls with an egg and dart pattern carved below and faces with water spout mouths carved above. The north wall is not as intact with only slight traces of the egg and dart pattern visible. Entrance to this garden room is in the north west corner. The room has been determined to be a feature based upon Jashemski's report of cavity indicating a stake, " propping up the limb of a tree... heavy with fruit or nuts." No ceiling is present. The water spouts indicate that the room was open to the sky. Columns in southeast and southwest corners not round - on the outside edge, they square to the wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To Room 12 to the southPortico 13 to the east
column21: In the Roman Villa A at Oplontis we have identified room 11 as a Diaeta based upon its location off peristyle 13.  The room is L-shaped with doorways on the north and south walls.  A shuttered window (shutters fossilized and still remaining) opens on the east wall.  The room is elaborately painted in the third style with architectural elements, including columns, gateways show perspective, and landscapes along with one human figure faintly visible.  Decorative elements including winged figures, gold pots and wreaths crown these panels.  There are also two series of squares painted to look like marble at the same height.  The painting is fully colored.  Above the painted walls there is a cornice, with a painted frieze (subjects unidentifiable) topped with an even more elaborate carved wooden cornice.  The ceiling consists of two arches, both with geometric designed, plastered surfaces.  The L-shaped room is divided by these arches into two niches with a square connector.  Inside the niches the arches have remains of painted ceiling plaster.  The subject of paintings in the arches cannot be determined.  The square portion of the room is also topped with cornice molding.  A small protion of the floor remains, showing it was constructed of black and white mosaic with a geometric pattern dividing the south niche area.  The west niche may also have had this, but no floor remains.  The doorway on the south wall, and the doorway on the north wall, have partial in situ remains of their original doors.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the south of water feature 16. To the east of room 18.
column21: At the Roman Villa Oplontis A, we have determined that room 31, (partially excavated) is a dining room based upon its size and its location with a view across water feature 16 into the dining room 15. The south wall is the unexcavated wall, with the remaining three walls, the east, north and west, all showing remains of highly decorated painted plaster. The north wall has a small doorway opening to room 18, which is part of the bath complex. The large entrance to the room is on the north wall and is only partially excavated. The threshold from the that doorway contained a black and white, floral mosaic pattern, with a small step down over a marble sill. The sides of the doorway, at floor level, had cutouts for door hardware. The opening itself is very high. The mosaic floor was white with two black border stripes. The paintings on the walls contained a lower red dado with panels above with a yellow background and a black and red trim. Architectural elements are visible on the north and east walls but no central images remain. Above that is a pattern of painting, also with the yellow background and red trim, in diamond shapes, with what appear to be central medallions. No ceiling remains. The fresco remnants stop at the height of the large entrance with plain stonework above.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to the ritual room to the north and the atrium to the west.
column21: We have determined that this is a storeroom for food and drink due to its location and close proximity to the atrium.  This is a rectangular space on a north/south axis.  The space is partitioned down the length of the room, with the west section adjacent to the corridor wider than the east section.  Presently, this space is gated and locked but can be seen from a doorway along the corridor (3) which opens to space 4, allowing a view through a door at the northwest corner of the west wall of space 22.  A second view is through a door in the northeast corner of the north wall of room 22.  This door opens onto the ritual room (number 27).  A third view into this room is possible through the door from room 25 which opens through the south end of the east wall.  The partition is reconstructed of wooden beams and plaster panels.  The space is presently filled with amphorae.  The walls are reconstructed to the original height with a rough opening at the upper portion of the south wall.  There is evidence of plaster on the east wall.  The ceiling is reconstructed.  The original flooring is not visible.  The general condition is fair.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is located to the west of the peristyle courtyard number 32.  Storage room 22 is to the south.  Room 26-4017 is to the north.
column21: We have identified this space as a Ritual Space in the Villa of Oplontis A. It is Room 27.  On the plan we have adopted from Jashemski.  This is determined to be a food and drink space due to the altar feature (27-4019), located in a large niche in the center of the west wall.  This room is a rectangular space, aligned along a north/south axis.  This large room is richly decorated, although in poor condition.  There is an entrance to the room along the west end at the southwest corner.  There is a large, high entrance in the center of the east wall, as well as two small doorways along the south wall into storage space 22.  Another doorway along the west wall is located in the north corner, and opens to room 2.  In the east end of the north wall is a doorway into room 20.  The main entrance to this room is the large doorway on the east wall, which is flanked by two large windows.  These windows look out to Area 32, an open peristyle.  The smaller square windows are centered over the two windows and doorway.  The eastern wall has some plaster preserved at the bottom and two sections at the upper end of the room.  Remnants of frescoes preserve Fourth Style decoration.  A line of these holes are still visible, related to the peristyle ambulatory.       The west wall of this room has a large niche occupying the center of this wall.  This large niche is decorated with Fourth Style frescoes including a dark red dado below high ochre panels and white Fourth Style patterns at the upper wall.  The ceiling is vaulted over the niche.  There is some molded decoration at the tops of the walls.     Although the lintel to this niche is reconstructed, there is a large section of carbonized wood in situ at the south end.  The Fourth Style decoration continues outside the niche to both sides and is visible.  Traces continue on both north and south walls.  The lower panels outside the niche are red instead of ochre.  The floor of this room is mosaic, white background with a black border defining the rectangular space of the room with floral dot pattern filling the inner rectangle.  The niche is also defined by a black border.  The ceilings are reconstructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: in a recessed area on the eastern wall of room 27.
column21: We have identified Oplontis Villa A as a domestic villa. We have determined that the last usage of this feature 4019 is as an altar. This feature is described as: 1) an altar/lararium within room 27; 2) it is located on the eastern side in a recessed area facing the west; 3) the general condition is restored and modern. The base is heavily reconstructed; 4) The approximate size is 2 m. by 1.5 m.; 5) its attributes are as a lararium. It contained possible shelves to hold religious objects. The shrine is attached to the eastern wall. The exterior of the base of the shrine is painted. There is a red border with a  painted, marbleised border. The centre is a large red circle with a yellow-orange border. The front of the base is damaged and reconstructed with no trace of paint. The exterior north side of the base is reconstructed and badly damaged with traces of red paint. On the surface of the base sits a domestic shrine which is badly damaged. It appears to have been reconstructed in both modern times and in antiquity. The space is defined by two walls at the north and south side jutting out possibly half way into the space. Today there appear to be to ledges along the inside of the space. One of the ledges appears to serve as a shelf for ritual objects.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This space is to the west of the ritual space (27) and to the north of the niche containing the altar (27-4019)
column21: We have determined that this is a storage area due to its small size and location. It has been conjectured that this would have held food storage or food preparation items. This is a small rectangular space on a north south axis. The only entrance is on the west wall at the northwest corner. The north, east, and west walls are preserved to a great height and support a reconstructed ceiling. The south wall is a partition wall and is not preserved to the ceiling. The construction is opus incertum. A small portion of plaster is preserved along the bottom of the north wall and the south door jamb. The south door jamb preserves a band with paint. This storage area is presently filled with stacks of roof tiles, bricks, and other construction debris. No original floor is visible although there is a stone threshold at the door. Overall the condition of this space is poor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: On the western side of the room there is a large entrance on to portico (24) with a view of a garden (59). On the south side an entrance opens on to a joining corridor.
column21: We have identified Oplontis Villa A as a domestic villa structure. We have determined that the last usage of this room 23, is a dining room. This identification is based on : a) room location within the structure - off peristyle (24) with a view of a garden (59) ; b) the presence  of designated food and drink features (wall paintings) ; c) certain characteristics to include walls, doorway, and the floor; and d) previously identified as a salone. Feature description : 1) the features in the room are wall paintings ; 2) the paintings are located on the north and south walls ; 3) the condition of the paintings is good to excellent with some damage ; 4) the paintings are set within the entire wall ; 5) the paintings are of food and drink objects. The ceiling and upper walls are reconstructed with a partial row of plaster molding, partially reconstructed in situ, approximately three quarters of the way up. The floor is white mosaic with a black border defining a central space. The room appears to be square. The west wall has a large entrance with a marble threshold of two low steps. Evidence of door jambs in the marble threshold step (western). Inside the room looking west at the western side on the north end, three quarters of the way up there is evidence of a repaired cornice/molding. There are traces of restored wall painting of a possible shield and traces of paint in the upper register running above the doorway. On the eastern wall, the cornice/molding is restored about three quarters of the way up. The entire wall is painted in second style with architectural features. There are two painted Corinthian columns.  There are four painted doorways. Two appear to be slightly ajar. In the center of the wall there is a painted scene with a red painted border. The scene cannot be identified. Above is a painted theater mask, flanked by two painted vessels. A painted garland hangs from the top of the fresco.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The wall is on the north side.  The entrance to the room is on the west side.
column21: There is a large wall painting on the north wall.  Running along the top is a partially reconstructed cornice/moulding.
