The lower register as been damaged and partially restored with yellow, red, and black architectural features similar to First Style.  The entire wall above shows architectural features with six painted pilasters, which have corinthian capitals.  The color scheme appears to be yellow, blue, red, and black. From the eastern side, the first three of seven panels are damaged.  The fourth central panel has traces of a pedestal with a domed serving cover presumably protecting the food.  The fifth panel in the middle register has traces of possibly a bowl leaning against the pilaster.  The sixth panel from the eastern side has a well preserved pedestal base painted with geometric design in borders.  The pedestal holds a platter of fruit, possibly pomegranates,  covered by a very sheer veil, possibly silk.  From behind the painted pedestal is a painted staff with some type of decoration and possibly grain.  The seventh panel is badly damaged.  Sitting on top of the architecture directly above the second panel from the east is a ribbed rimmed glass bowl with handles on either side.  The fruit is not easily identifiable but may possibly be apples, pomegranates, and grapes.Above the fourth central panel from the east, sitting on the architecture, is a large glass bowl without handles, containing fruit possibly figs and apples.  Over the sixth panel there is a third glass bowl sitting on the painted arhitecture.  This bowl matches exactly the glass bowl above the second panel with ribs, rim, and glass handles.  The painting is better presented with a fig, possible pomegranate and apple.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This wall has an opening on the west side and a doorway to the corridor along the south.
column21: The south wall bottom low register follows the other four walls with yellow, red and blue architectural features (Style One).  This wall is reconstructed, the wall painting (Style Two) is damaged and partially reconstructed.  As part of the reconstruction, etched into the new plaster are designs tracing what may have been the original wall painting.  As in the north wall, there are panels in the mid section with five panels visible.  The entrance way to the corridor to the south replaced the last two.  The first panel from the east wall appears to be painted architecture.  The second panel has a painted bird, possibly a peahen.  In the third panel from the east wall there is a painted presentation of green grapes sitting on a ledge, and possible apples.  The fourth and central panel has a pedestal raised on four possible struts.  Sitting on the pedestal is a single layer cake with red sides, a white top, and fruit or flowers sitting on top.  The remaining panels are cut by the entrance.  Above the second panel from the east wall, there is a badly damaged glass bowl, juxtaposed with the glass bowl on the northern wall.  In the center panel above, sitting on top of the architecture, is a glass bowl also juxtaposed to the north wall.  The bowls appear to be identical.  Above the doorway is speculated that there was also a glass bowl juxtaposed to the glass bowl in the north wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified Oplontis A as a villa. We have identified this room as a dining room. It is contiguous to the large portico to the south and to dining room 23, to the southwest and a storage room (4017) to the west and to a short corridor on the east. We enter this rectangular dining room through a very large door from the portico. There is a marble threshold with door posts. There are no particular features but there are characteristics associated with a dining room. The room is small. Mosaic floor seems to indicate placement for one bench. There is a decorative mosaic rectangle filling most decorations, with cream background with reds, aqua, yellow, and blue motifs in three horizontal zones. On the west wall is a door (iron gate, padlocked) to a room storing approximately one hundred amphorae, (storage room 4017).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Situated against the East wall is seen one rectangular, high concrete support strut. There are two struts, a shorter and wider strut jutting out from the South wall (positioned close to the door). The platform, supported by these struts is not present.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The garden is situated to the east of the pool and to the west of a long horizontal border of volcanic rock.
column21: We have identified this exterior space as a garden on the east side of the Villa of Oplontus A.  This is the long narrow space bordering on the east side of the pool.  This identification as a food-related garden is based on Jashemski, who noted a lemon tree in this area.  Presently this is a level area which may have been an open space with a covered colonnade, or an area with statue bases, to the east.  This area with the statue bases is presently planted with two lemon trees and other trees and two bushes.  Remains of volcanic rock debris are visible attesting to the west side of the colonnade.  Each statue base has a drain passing through from east to west.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room: Situated immediately to the west of Room 83 and to the north of Room 81. No unexcavated access exists.
column21: We have determined that Room 82 is the western most in a series of three processing rooms just outside the pool and residential area. The room is rectangular, no excavated doorway is visible. The room is only partially excavated, but appears to contain one very large basin partially excavated in the floor of eastern portion of the room. Also at the northeastern corner, appearing to be inside the large basin, is a smaller, square basin, also with cement walls. Some traces of plaster remains on the walls, but it is impossible to say how it was decorated. No roof remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opens to north of passageway 81.
column21: We have identified room 83 as part of the production area of the villa.  We have determined that the last usage of room 83 was a processing room.  Set off from the residential area of the villa there is a series of three rooms, this is the middle one, partially excavated.  This room is narrow and rectangular, with traces of painted plaster that appear to be of the "zebra striped" pattern.  The floor is clay, with a doorway and threshold off of passageway 81.  The floor is excavated in a slope to the west and exits through a low arch into a possible drain into room 84.  Plaster remains on the inside of the arch indicate its existence pre-excavation.  Although modern holes are cut into the east and west walls, these do not appear to have existed in antiquity.  Visible brickwork on the south wall suggests a window, mid-wall height, currently looking at the unexcavated area.  We believe that this room is the most feasible of these excavated rooms to contain the torcularium (olive oil press), as suggested by Jashemski.  No ceiling exists.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opening from the west area 91.  Attached via a small arch.  Room 83 to the east.
column21: The western-most room of the series of food processing rooms on the south excavated area of the villa has been identified as one of the processing rooms with size unidentifiable, it has been excavated on three sides and is quite small.  Plaster remains on all three walls.  Decoration is not visible.  The north and west walls appear to have been divided into two horizontal areas by a slight ridge at dado height.  On the west wall an arch with slight remains of plaster is very small and located at the base of the wall.  It appears to lead into this room via a sloping floor from Room 83 which could channel liquid through the arch into what may be an excavated drain in Room 84.  The east wall has a bricked column attaching it to the Villa area 81/91 and to the column's south is a marble window sill or threshold leading into this room.  Opening size is not determinable.  The floor and ceiling of the room have not been excavated.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Rooms:  Corridor (85) to the south, corridor/anteroom (66) and colonnade (60) to the north, corridor (77) to the west and garden/pool to the east.
column21: We have identified Oplontis A as a villa. We have determined that Room 78 is a diaeta room. Identification is based on the unique location at the southwest corner of the pool complex. We note that we can see outside walls on the north side of the pool, that duplicate this arrangement. The east wall of this diaeta has one very large window, one average sized window, and two very small, mid-level windows, all looking out to the east, overlooking the garden, sculptural display, and pool. The south wall is divided into three sections. One portion, on the east end, has a mid-level large window. The second portion is a curved, convex wall that cuts the corner of room diagonally, and includes a door that leads to a highly decorated corridor. The final part of the south wall contains a small high square window. The west wall centers the room. The north wall duplicates the three sections of the south wall. the door in it opens to the pool complex of colonnade via a highly decorated corridor.The doors in the western corners of the south wall and the north wall have marble thresholds. The ceiling has modern plaster, but has cut-aways showing a decorative style incorporating roof tiles. The main area of flooring has a diamond shaped pattern in colored marbles. The area between the edges of the protruding walls of the north and south convex entrances and the west wall is patterned with squares and triangles.There was marble floor molding all the way round the base of the walls, only some of which is extant on the east wall. We are pleasantly surprised at the coolness of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the west portico #60.  To the south is passageway #63.  To the north east is passageway #67.  There is an entrance to room 75 on the north west side.
column21: We have identified Oplontis Villa A as a domestic villa.  We have determined that the last usage of this room (#65, feature #4032) is a dining room.  This identification is based on the room location within the structure.  It faces east with a wide entrance and view of the large pool.  There are no clearly obvious food and drink features.       The characteristics that suggest a dining room are the mosaic floor, large entrance with view, possible serving passage on western side, elegant wall paintings, and niche on western side and previous research indicates a salone.  The floor is mosaic, white with black border, defining space within the dining room.  The ceiling is all reconstructed.  Along the western side of the room, there appears to be a separate area defined by the wall structure, mosaic floor, and niche attached to the western wall.  This area to the west is clearly accessible to the main room.       On a north/south axis there are two large openings on the north and south walls, each with well planned views of planted areas and garden paintings.  The entire room was purposely planned with views on all sides.  A base molding of stucco painted to look like marble, reconstructed around the room.  In total there are five entrances to other rooms.     The east is a large monumental opening, reconstructed, with evidence of a marble threshold with door jambs.  The interior of the east wall is reconstructed, partial plaster remaining but no wall painting.  Traces on the south portion of the east wall is a base molding painted to look like marble.              The south wall has an entrance to (63), area 63 appears to be a corridor for servants because it is painted with white and black stripes.  The center of the south wall is a large opening with a marble ledge.  Evidence of door jambs are present to close off.       This opens to a recessed rectangular enclosed area with elegant garden paintings on the three walls and of a painted fountain with birds.  The color scheme is gold, yellows, red and blue.  On the west side of the south wall it is divided by an attached pillaster defining a secondary space.  On the far west there is another exit for corridor (63).  In the lower register there remain marble panels which have been reconstructed.  The wall above has been stuccoed but there are no traces of paint.        The western wall has two large openings to a garden (56).  They flank a central large niche jetting out to the room.  On the south side of this wall below the window are black and white marble panels.  In the center of the wall is a large niche on a base of marble projecting into the room.  It has been reconstructed with traces of unidentifiable paint.  At the top of the ceiling there is a reconstructed stucco cornice /molding in red, blue and white.  The window opening to the north has another marble ledge with evidence of door jambs.       The north wall on the northwest side has an opening to a corridor (67)  for slaves, with black and white striped paintings.  This passageway connects to the central dining hall.  There is a large pillaster separating this room into sections.  In the middle of the north wall there is a large opening with a marble ledge.  This looks directly onto (68).  Room 68 was painted with elegant garden paintings of fountains and birds.  The color scheme is gold yellows, red, blue and green.  The view to the north through room (68, 69, 72) is of a fountain in room (74) identical to the fountain on the south wall of 65.  The wall is restored with stucco but no paint.  On the west side of the north wall there is an entrance to room (15).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as Oplantis A.  We have determined that Room 69 is a dining hall.  This room is the central dining hall of the pool complex.  This dining hall dominates the east wing of the villa.  This dining hall could hold three to five complete sets of triclinia benches.  You would approach this room from the existing colonnade on the east side.  There are no food and drink features.  There are characteristics that determined this to be a dining hall including the size of this huge rectangular  space.  On the east side, the room is totally open to a view of the pool and lemon trees beyond.  On the north wall there is a door opening to a room where diners could await their time to dine.  Centered on the north wall is a huge window with a marble ledge, overlooking a garden with garden paintings.  This garden room has a large window aligned with the first, that allows a view through another dining room, through a third window to a second garden room with the same painted garden walls.  There are also small, high windows on the north and east walls of the garden room.From almost any location in this dining hall, you can see five distinct garden decorations, bird baths, peacocks, plants and flowers.  Main zones are yellow background, lower and border zones are red backgrounds.  Lower red zone is tall.In the dining hall, there is another door on the north wall located on the west end.  This leads to the slaves' corridor, with black and white stripes.  On the west wall, there is a huge window overlooking a garden or orchard area.On the south wall, the two doors flanking a centered window duplicate the same arrangement as on the north wall.  These open to slaves' corridor, garden room and waiting room.  In this garden room there are four bird baths and one large flower pot.  The ceiling is a modern covering shaped like a pediment.  The floor is covered in beautiful marble squares and triangles.  One third is still extant.  There is incomplete molding around the base of the west and north walls.  The walls were plastered but no colors are visible now.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the west is portico (60).  To the southwest is room 72.  To the southeast is corridor (71).  To the northeast is entrance (87).  To the northwest is the entrance to (88).
column21: We have identified Oplontis Villa A as a domestic villa.  We have determined that the last usage of this room (74) is a dining room.  This identification is based on: A) The room location within the structure, it faces west with a wide entrance and view of the large pool; B) The characteristics that suggest a dining room are the mosaic floor, large entrance with view, possible serving passage on eastern side; and C) Previous research indicates a salone.  There are no clearly obvious food and drink features.  The floor is mosaic, white with black border, defining the space within the dining room.  The ceiling is totally reconstructed.  Traces of original stucco molding have been inserted in the reconstruction.  The ceilings is divided into nine areas, four with recessed diamonds, two a piece; four plain, yet arched slightly.  The central panel is defined by geometric recessed areas.  Along the east side of the room there appears to be a separate area defined by the wall structure, mosaic floor and niche attached to the west wall.  The area to the west is clearly accessible to the main room.  On a north/south axis, there are two large openings on the north and south walls, each with well panned views of planted areas and garden paintings.  The entire room was purposely planed with views on all sides.  Remnants of a base molding of stucco painted to look like marble remain in a few areas around the room.  In total there are five entrances to other rooms.  The east opening is a large monumental opening, with a few small pieces of the marble threshold remaining.  The interior of the east wall is reconstructed, partial plaster with no wall  paintings.  The south wall has an entrance to (72).  Area (72) appears to e an ante room.  The center of the south wall has a large opening with a marble ledge.  Evidence of door jambs present to close it off.  This is directly onto (70).  This appears to be a garden area with water feature.  There is a smaller window higher up which is also looking into (70).  Room 70 is painted with elegant garden paintings of fountains and birds.  The color scheme is gold, yellows, red, blue and green. The view to the south through (70, 69, 68, 65) is of a fountain (65), identical to the fountain on the north wall of (74).  The wall is restored with stucco, but no paint.  On the west side of the south wall there is an entrance to corridor (71).  The west wall has no openings.  In the center of the wall is a large niche on a base projecting into the room.  It has been reconstructed.  At the top of the ceiling there is reconstructed stucco cornice/molding in red, white and blue.  The north wall has an entrance to (87).  Area (87) appears to be a garden with water features.  There are door jambs present.  In the center of the north wall is a large opening.  This opens to an unusually shaped garden area.  The walls are covered with elegant garden paintings of similar style, design and color.  To the northwest is an opening to room 88.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is north of the garden light wall.  This room is east of the large garden fronting the villa.
column21: We have identified this room as a dining room in Villa Oplontis A.  This identification is based on the size and shape of the room as well as its location in the east wing of the villa.  The shape of this room is unusual, essentially a square space with a rectangular niche stepping out from the north wall and an apsidal space stepping out from the south wall.  The only entrance to this room is in the center of the east wall.  The walls are highly reconstructed.  There is no original ceiling remaining, but two high concrete beams span the space across the north and south ends of the room.  The walls preserve a fair amount of plaster and a tall ochre-painted dado is preserved although the upper walls are cream colored.  The decoration is no longer visible, or may have not been completed.  The apsidal wall on the south side is pierced with a large curved window.  There is a second, independently carved window seen directly above the much larger window situated in the middle of the south wall.  This window has a marble sill and looks out into the light well with little garden with rich paintings.  The floor is marble.  It is a white field with a double black border delineating the central square of the room.  The apse and sides are defined by a single black line.  Over all the condition is fair.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room: This room is to the east of the front gardens to the north of the villa's main entrance. There is a corridor to the east of this room.
column21: We have identified this room as a dining room due to its size and location This is a large, rectangular space with an east to west axis. the room is almost square, with an opening niche along the southeast end of the south wall. There is no ceiling preserved and the upper walls are heavily reconstructed.The walls all have preserved plaster revealing a high black dado and solid cream-colored walls situated above the black dado. Any fresco decoration on this cream surface has either perished or was never completed. This matches the circumstances of the other surrounding rooms, situated south. The floor is mosaic. It reveals a white field with a black border. There is a wide doorway at the center of the east wall with a view out pass a hallway to the portico and pool. This room has a wide marble threshold. There is a smaller door in the entrance niche at the southeast corner of the south wall. This has a marble threshold. This doorway passes through to another square room which is to the east of Room 89. There is a large square window centered in the west wall with a view to the large garden to the north of this villa entrances, southwest of the window. The overall condition of this room is fair.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this unexcavated space as a diata.  this attribution is based on the visible remains which symmetrically match diata (78) at the opposite south end of the colonnade.  One can see the window on the south wall of this diata as well as the exterior molding above the curving portion of the north wall.  The exterior of this space has a cream background and floral dado and a simple pattern of ashlar blocks painted with thin red lines.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the north of portico 24.  To the west of portico 40.
column21: We have identified room 41 as a dining room because of its location and because there is a large window opening to the portico and a door opening to an unexcavated area which was probably a garden.  The primary entrance to this room is a wide doorway to the south, with a marble threshold with cutouts for door attachments on both sides.  The room is L-shaped, with two ends of the L forming rectangular niches on the north and west sides.  The west wall has a small door in its southwest corner leading to room 38.  The east wall has a large square window in its southeast corner leading to colonnaded garden 40/59.  The black and which mosaic on the floor delineates the two niches via a rectangle with double black lines in the southeast bottom corner of the L.  The walls are highly decorated with fourth style decoration, with small birds and winged creatures scattered throughout.  The dado is a dark red with central pictures delineated by yellow bands.  Beginning at the south wall west of the door and circling the rooms and the niches, the decorative scheme is of two white panels followed by a red panel repeating four times.  Above that is a register with a solid background with red, gold and black typical fourth style divisions.  Above that register is a plastered cornice, simply decorated in brown.  The ceiling would have been above that.  Currently the modern reconstruction is being held up by a mesh wire superstructure.  Where is painting does not remain, the walls are a mix of simple masonry, stonework and opus reticulatum.  On the niche to the east, one can see some remains of the triple black line with some unusual patterning setting off the niche itself.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: No contiguous
column21: Based upon the size and shape of room 83, as well as the fact that, as the most excavated of a series of three rooms, ti appears to be the most likely location for the torcularium, (olive oil press) as described in Jasemaki Volume 22, 598.
column53: E  phto Team Leader:  Rob Brown
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Other features, the floor below etc., surround the basin 4073
column21: Extending in a westward direction from the northeast corner of the processing room is a partial cement border of a water basin.  The basin itself is currently filled with dirt.  But the floor below to the west is about thirty centimeters down.  The basin contains a second basin (our feature number 4037) directly inside its north east corner.       As this area is not fully excavated we cannot tell the full dimensions of the basin.
column53: WPhoto Team Leader:  Rob Brown
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: In the northwest corner of the basin 4038.
column21: Inside processing room 82 in the northeast corner is a small square basin inset into the floor of a larger basin.  This basin is rimmed with concrete and the depth is not excavated.  The rim of the basin rises slightly over what is the excavated level of dirt.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It opens on the southeast side of peristyle/corridor 12.
column21: We have identified the House of the Working Painters as a house.  We have determined that the last usage of this room (4043) was as a dining room.  This identification is based on: a) the location of the room off the peristyle and colonnade; b) characteristics of the room including a monumental entrance aligned with a view of a pediment at the entrance to the colonnade,  peristyle, and garden.  The pediment suggests a temple facade. There is an elaborate mosaic in the center of the room and elaborate wall paintings.   In addition to the large entrance in the center, there is also a smaller entrance at the west end of the southwest wall where there appears to be traces of door jambs.  The exterior of this wall, along the colonnade, shows traces of plaster and paint which has been reconstructed.  The floor of this room is mosaic, white with a black border.  The center of the floor is paved in opus sectile in geometric designs in varying colors.  The ceiling no longer exists; however, the walls are tall, with paintings in three registers.  The wall has been reconstructed.  There appear to be three registers with traces of painting in the middle register on the south side of the wall.  The color scheme is black, yellow, green and red.  There is a figure set in painted architecture on the south side.  On the same wall, west side, in the upper register, there are traces of decoration.  On the northwest wall there are fine paintings in the middle register.   The paintings contain architectural structures.  The central panel is a picture that we cannot identify, however there is a sketch showing the legs and feet.  Along the border at the bottom of the central panel there are cupids racing in small carts with goats or deer.  On the north end of this wall there is a tondo painting of Mars and Venus.  Below the Mars and Venus there is a scene showing six figures.  The northeast wall is in three major panels separated by architectural design.  On the north side of this wall there is another tondo but it is unidentifiable.  The central panel  has been cut out.  The central panel is flanked by architectural features.  The north panel is painted, the east panel was in the process of being painted, with the artist's original sketches in situ.  On the easternmost side in the middle register, there is a painting of Ceres holding a staff.  Possibly the southeast wall is reconstructed.   In the middle register there are traces of painting of the east side.  There is another tundo, possibly of Venus and Mars.  There is painted architectural design.  In the upper register of the northwest wall there is a sacroidyllic paining which is badly damaged.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The feature is located to the northwest of peristyle 12 and to the southwest of  Room 6.
column21: We have identified room 8 as a dining room based upon its large door opening to a colonnaded peristyle in its south east wall.  The room is on a north west, south east axis and is brightly painted with cream based Forth Style decoration.  The central paintings in almost all panels have been removed.  Two small rectangular panels on both sides of the southeast door remain.  One is of a sacro-idyllic landscape but the other is of a painting of fish (our feature 4051).  The dado is painted bright red with floral and animal paintings.  Some volcanic material still remains in the room.  The floor is clay with marble inserts and the visible threshold is marble with cuts for door hardware.  A second much smaller door is in the east corner of the northeast wall.  No evidence of the ceiling remains.
column53: NorthwestPhoto Team Leader: Lee Payne
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: the room opens to the south/southeast from atrium 3
column21: We have identified this structure as a house. We have determined that the last usage of room 5 was as a dining room. This identification is based upon room size, evidence of room decoration, and the entrance off the atrium (room 3). The room is on a northeast -southwest axis and is entered from the south corner from atrium 3. No threshold remains in the doorway. The doorway is wide with plaster remaining on its east jamb. Midway up there are two large circular openings indicating door attachment. The southwest jamb of the doorway is of opus testaceum construction. The remainder of the southeast wall shows evidence of painted plaster with a red dado running along the bottom. The southwest wall also has painted plaster remains. At mid-wall height directly to the west of the doorway is a small square window which appears to have been a doorway in antiquity. The window directly abuts caupona VI.10.1 suggesting the two properties were connected at one time. In the northwest corner of the room is a small square masonry platform (feature 6512). The remaining two walls, the northwest and northeast, both contain decorated plaster remnants. Opus incertum construction between large tufa pillars suggest the room may have been open to these sides at one point in its history.Floor is lapilli and no ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 4 is located to the northwest off of kitchen 2.
column21: Feature 4044 is a long rectangular room in the north corner of the kitchen.  It has a narrow doorway right off of the back street entrance at the north corner of the kitchen.  The axis of the room is northwest/southeast.  The small size of the room and the location lead us to believe that it is either a storeroom or a posticum.  In the northeast wall there is a small square high window opening to the street.  The walls are frescoed and appear to have been painted red.  Wall construction is opus incertum.  A large block of tufa protrudes from the bottom of the south corner wall to the threshold, which appears to have been stone and clay and divided the room from the kitchen.  The floor is not visible.  No ceiling remains.
column53: Photo Team Leader:  Lee PayneNorthwest
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the west corner of dining room 5 (6511) is a rubble and concrete platform, low to the floor and square with plaster on the two visible sides. On the southeast side of the platform we can see remains of painted plaster indicating that this platform was placed here after the walls had already been plastered.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The feature is located in the south corner of kitchen 2 (4046) with the door on the northwest side.
column21: We have identified room 3 (feature 4045) as a storeroom. We have determined that the last usage of this space is a storeroom.  This identification is based on the location off kitchen 2.  There are multiple amphora (feature 4046) in eruption material about 1.5 meters above floor level.  The room is small with possible slit windows into the kitchen.  These walls have been reconstructed.  The entrance is on the northwest side, with a low door.  The room is unexcavated with possible traces of plaster and painting on the southwest wall.  The five postholes on the southwest wall suggest a roof or shelf.  The wall above the postholes continues on.  It appears there is a door jam.
column53: Photo Team Leader:  Lee PayneEast
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room (6513) looks out to a garden on the southwest. The northeast wall was next to a rear entrance to the property at VI.10.19.
column21: We have identified VI.10.2 as a domestic structure. We have determined that the last usage of this room 14 (6513) is as a dining room. This identification is based on the room location within the structure, with a clear view of a garden, as well as previous research. This dining room is located on the southeast corner of the house in the rear. The focus of the room is on a garden to the southwest. There is no longer any evidence of the entrance to this room, but it presumably opened to the garden. There is no evidence of a floor which today is rubble. On the southeast and northeast wall there appear to be post holes for a possible second floor. There is no evidence of a ceiling or roof today. On the northwest wall only a portion remains. This house was extensively bombed in 1942. On the portion that remains there appears to be ancient stucco, with some modern reconstruction in the top section. The northeast wall is better preserved with some modern reconstruction on the upper part. There are three post holes approximately 2.5 m from ground level. It appears that the lower part of the wall is partially concreted with no evidence of plaster or painting. On the southeast wall at the same level there are two rows of what appear to be post holes. There are four post holes at 2.5 m. At about .5 m. centered above these is a row of eight square openings that go straight through the wall and are possible post holes for an upper floor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: They are lying facing the west wall on/within the eruption material.In the southern corner of the kitchen (4047).
column21: The room is unexcavated but clearly visible are pieces of amphora.  There is one amphora fairly intact and one dolium fairly intact.
column53: Photo Team Leader:  Lee PayneSoutheast
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northeast of Via di Mercurio and to the southwest of atrium 3.
column21: We have decided that the property at VI.10.3 was primarily a shop with a small house attached behind. Counter room 1 opens directly to the street on the southwest and contains a large L-shaped counter with inserts for dolia. Also included in this room is a small square platform at ground level directly to the northeast of the counter that has been identified in some sources as a hearth. The room itself is squarish on a northeast - southwest axis divided in two by one arm of the L-shaped counter. The northwest - southeast stretch of the room is divided by a short crumbling wall on the southeast side. The northeast wall had doorways on its north and east corners with an opus incertum,   plastered painted wall between them. The entrance to the street is to the southwest and had a large stone threshold with channels with inserts for a folding door. Plaster remains on the walls and appears to have been painted red. A single post hole directly behind the street opening indicates the presence of an upper storey. The floor is rubble and no ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the northeast/east is preparation platform 6516.
column21: In counter room 1, an L-shaped counter runs along the street to the southwest and turns into the room to the northeast. The two arms of the L are of roughly equal size. In the arm of the L that stretches to the northeast (into the room) are two round inserts that probably held ceramic dolia. The street- front leg of the L stretching from northwest to southeast has a protruding angle at its top surface angling out over the large door threshold. The counter surface is marble tiled (reconstructed). On the inside of the leg of the L that runs from the northwest to the southeast is a large square opening for storage. Unusually, the counter surface stops just to the south of the open door leaving an approximately 60 cm. gap to the southeast wall of the counter room. The counter does not appear to be plastered.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the southwest/west is counter 6515
column21: The small, low rectangular platform is of block masonry construction. It is suggested in some sources (Eschebach) that it may have been a hearth but no evidence of a cooking surface remains today. It is attached to the counter at the east inside corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room apparently opens to the garden on the southwest wall. On the northeast wall it pens to the street at VI.10.18. On the northeast corner it opens to a storage area or corridor
column21: We have identified VI.10.3 as a shop house structure. We have determined that the last usage of this room (6517) is a dining room. This identification is based on past research. The entire room appears to be on a lower level. It is based on the northeast corner of the house at the back. There is a possible entrance on the southwest corner that enters into a possible garden on the southwest side of the room. There is a possible threshold and stone door jamb. There is no evidence of a step into the room from the garden. There is a drop of approximately 1 m. from the garden to the floor of the dining room. The southwest wall is badly damaged with a possible threshold to the southwest corner. There is no evidence of a floor - today it is rubble. To the southern side of the southwest wall there is a possible pilaster opening to the garden. This wall appears to have been filled in during antiquity. On the southern corner of the southwest wall at about 2.5 m. above the floor is a post hole that is matched by another possible post hole at the same height on the northeast wall. The northwest wall is reconstructed and patched up in modern times. There is a round hole at about one third of the way from the southwest corner (approximately 2 m. above the floor). There may be small traces of stucco. On the northern side of this wall is a narrow arched entrance to an apparent corridor or storage room. The door is 2.5 m. above the threshold, which is higher than the sloping floor. On the northeast wall there is a large entrance which is a step up from the street. To the south of the entrance is a small window whose ledge is approximately 3 m. above the sloping floor. At approximately a half metre to the east and below the window is what appears to be a post hole. There is modern reconstruction but no apparent stucco. The southeast wall is reconstructed with concrete with some possible traces of painting and stucco. To the eastern side there are three large post holes at approximately 4 m. On the western corner of this wall there is one single round post hole at approximately 4 m. The ceiling is not extant.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to the peristyle (12) to the southwest.
column21: We have identified entrance 9 as a house.  We have determined that room 2 is a kitchen due to its location within the structure.  This kitchen has a wide entrance with a low doorway on the southwest wall, opening to the colonnade.  We see a door to a storage room (3) on the southeast wall in the entranceway.  There is a door across from this entrance, on the northeast wall, that opens to the street.  This is secured by two doors or two sets of locks, evidenced by two sets of holes in the door threshold and circles for pivots.  Features in this room include a cooking platform, a lararium, latrine, and water basin.  Characteristics include a pounded mud floor, walls include very limited patches of plaster.  There are windows, high up on the northeast wall.  They are very unique in that they have large rectangular openings with a narrow opening to the street.  On the northeast wall there is a small recessed arch over the latrine.  On the southeast wall there are five post holes in two rows.  Beneath these holes are two additional holes on the same level as the lararium.  The northeast and southwest walls are pedimental in shape, suggesting a ceiling over the kitchen.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This small rectangular painting is located on the west end of the southwest wall in cubiculum (7) in the center of the middle register.  We have identified the painting as a table with an amphora laying on its side on the far left, with a shelf perhaps holding loaves of bread in the center, and maybe a cornicopia or a rhyton on the far right.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: A small rectangular painting of three fish and two clams is located on the southeast wall, directly to the south of the large door entrance.  The background of the panel is blue with a red border.  One fish is orange and two are gold.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is northwest of room six.
column21: This is a brightly decorated room with red and yellow panels over a black dado (Fourth Style) that we have identified as a cubiculum.  It opens up from the southeast on a northwest-southeast axis.  The southeast wall also contains a rectangular window.  The reason we took this room is a painting on the west end of the southwest wall that shows a scene of food.  The floor is clay with marble inserts.  The doorway has two marble pieces on either side that show placement for door hardware.  Decorated cornice molding surrounds the room and it has a cornice arch on the southwest wall.  A lemon and a pomegranite appear to be located within the arch.  There is no ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is contiguous to the peristyle locates south of the processing room.
column21: We have identified this space as a Processing Room within the House of the Working Painters due to the finds within the room. It is a rectangular room on a northwest-southeast axis. This room opens to the peristyle though a doorway on the southeast wall. This is a high doorway. The condition of the room is poor with piles of excavation debris in the south and east corners. The northwest corner contains a pile of partially excavated amphorae still in lapili. These amphorae are [Feature Number 9-4059] visible. A moratarium and fragments of roof tile are also visible with the amphorae. Toward the north corner of the room there are remains on the floor indicating the position of some processing equipment. These are formed in rough cement. The floor in this room seems to have been just plaster, but it is hardly visible. The walls are preserved quite high. There is no evidence of plaster. The south corner of the southeast wall preserves a square window which is still filled with volcanic debris, but preserves the original iron grid visible from the exterior of the room. No ceiling remains. There area several holes in the southwest wall, perhaps for shelving.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the NE of the peristyle and to the NW of the kitchen (2-4047).
column21: We have identified this space as a dining room within The House of the Working Painters.  This identification is based on the location of the room off the peristyle, the size of the room, and the quality and character of the printed decoration.  The shape of this room is almost square and so the axis of the room relating to the doorway is NE/SW.  There is one doorway to this room located along the SW wall toward the South end of the room.  This is a high, wide doorway.  The room is in good condition.  It appears the floor was plastered and painted red.  This is preserved throughout most of the room.  The walls are conserved to the height of the ceiling molding, and was probably a one story room.  No ceiling remains.  The color scheme in this room consists of a black decorated dado and red panels above in two registers.  The middle section is divided into panels by spindly, columnar motifs.  The panels are decorated with small floating figures (putti) and garlands.  The NW, NE, and SE walls have central framed pictures.  The upper register is divided into squares and rectangles with small figures, animals, and birds.  The arched areas on the upper portions of the NE and SW walls have pictures of food; features 5-4056 and 5-4055.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The cooking platform is on the south wall west of the latrine (4049) and east of the lararium (4057).
column21: There is a cooking platform on the south wall and against a small divider wall on the east. The modern workers have placed a wooden pallet over the platform, which is holding plaster bits. What we can see is some small portions of plaster on the bottom front wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The latrine is on the east wall east of the cooking platform (4048) and the lararium. It is south of the water basin (4058).
column21: This kitchen latrine has an arch on the wall above it. It is rectangular and very deep. The wood seat is not here. There is a cement bench adjoined to it on the south wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is accross the room from the painted feature, 11 - 4056, ehich is in situ on the NE wall.  It is above the doorway on the SW wall.
column21: This is a feature in Dining Room 11 -4054.  It is the painting located in the arched portion of upper SW wall.  This is a rectangular panel in the center of the arch.  It depicts an eel an a squid on a platform.  The sea creatures are painted realistically; the platform is brown and beige and the background is blue.  It is not completely intact in it's restored condition.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: (4049) latrine is to the south(4048) cooking platform is to the west
column21: This water basin is on the east wall, adjoining the latrine to the south and the outside door to the north. These are three walls that define the basin and a pipe that would drain water to the outside of the house, into the street.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This lararium is to the South of the cooking platform (4048).
column21: There is a lararium niche in the south wall above and to the east of the cooking platform and the post hole.  It is rectangular with no remaining decoration, except for a portion of the red painted ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is across the room from the painted feature 5 - 4055 in situ on the SW wall.
column21: This is feature is a dining room, 5 - 4054.  It is the painting in the arched portion of the upper north east  wall.  This is a rectangular panel in the center of the arch.  It depicts a large rope-handled basket of fish which is tipped on it's side on the top of a platform. The fish are spilling on to it.  An unidentified object is at the lower right foreground of this picture.  The fish and container are in realistic colors; the platform is brown.  The background in faded blue and cream.  Approximately 80% off this painting is intact.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: It has been determined that this is a feature. In the northwest corner of the room is a stack of possibly eight amphorae. Six of these are large, wide amphorae stacked upside down. Two tall necked amphorae are also in situ in the lapili, with one additional long, thin amphora lying on the top of the stack. The pile of amphorae is opposite floor cuttings in the north corner of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is situated in the lower east corner of the NE wall of the room (3-6518).
column21: We have identified this room 3 as a dining room and determined its last usage was as a dining room.  We have identified this feature as a couch niche.  This couch niche is located in the lower part of the NE wall on the east side.  The condition is fair, with some reconstruction in modern times.  The approximate size is 1.5 meters wide by .5 meters high by .25 meters deep.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature sits in the centre of room 3 (6518)
column21: We have identified this room 3 as a dining room. We have identified this feature (6520) as an Olive Crusher [trapetum]. The Trapetum is located in the centre of the room and appears to have been placed by early excavators. The general condition of the feature is good. There does not appear to be any restoration, neither ancient nor modern. The crusher/press is circular and has an approximate diameter of 1.5 metres. There is a base with a platform (circular) with metal rod in sit at the centre. There are 2 half-dome circular presses with a square space at the centre for a beam to crush the olives as it rolls around the circular basin.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This Dining Room is to the southwest and the peristyle garden is to the northeast.  Atrium 5 is southwest of Dining Room 14.
column21: We have identified property 6-10-6 as a house and room 14 as a dining room.  We have determined this based upon a large open threshold entrance to the peristyle garden, large size of the room, and elaborate painted decoration.  To the northeast, alternating courses of brick and stone frame the large the large threshold opening.  Only a small portion of the stone threshold remains.  A second opening to the room is found on the south end of the southwest wall and is a narrower although still fairly high doorway. The northwest wall contains remnants of First Style painting.  The very top of that wall contains a series of small postholes, too small to be beams for an upper story.  The northwest and southeast walls each contain two horizontal rows of two postholes each; one at ceiling level and one at about the wall's midpoint.  The walls are opus incertum with some reconstruction, and no plaster remains.  The doorway to Dining Room 14 is at the north end of the northeast wall.  Along the floor level at the southwest wall we see remains of a white and black mosaic border.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the northwest of Room 6.
column21: This space has been identified as a cubiculum.  This brightly decorated room, with red and yellow panels over a black dado (fourth style) , we have identified as a cubiculum. It opens up from the southeast on a northwest southeast axis.  The south east wall also contains a rectangular window.  The reason we took this room is a painting on the west end of the south west wall that shows a scene of food.  The floor is clay with marble inserts.  The doorway has two marble pieces on either side that show placement for door hardware.  Decorated cornice molding surrounds the room and has a cornice arch on the southwest wall.  A lemon and pomegranite appear to  be located within the arch.  No ceiling in the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Dining Room 14 is to the southeast and peristyle garden is to the northeast.
column21: We have identified house 6-10-6 as domestic and we have determined that room number 15 is a dining room. The room is located immediately to the southwest of a large garden, contains a large doorway opening to that garden and had elaborate pointed surfaces. The doorway is along the northeast wall and has a wide stone threshold. Walls on either side of the doorway are of a brick and stone construction in an alternating pattern. On the north corner wall there is a square posthole midway up the wall. The remaining three walls, the northwest, southwest, and southeast are all of opus incertum construction with traces of pointed plaster. The northeast wall appears to have had a high window opening. Painting on the southwest wall shows evidence of the First Style, and the southeast wall has two very high postholes indicating an upper story, and two lower postholes at the midpoint. There is a low doorway in the east corner of that wall. The floor is red cocctopesto. No ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Entrance on the northeast side of the room opens to the atrium. Window opening to the fauces on the northwest wall.
column21: We have identified the House of Pomponius as a domestic house. We have determined that the last usage of this room (3) is as a dining room. This identification is based on its location, opening to the atrium and the remnants of some nice wall painting. There is also previous research regarding this. The entranceway on the northeast side of the room opens onto the atrium has no evidence of a door jamb. There is concrete but no evidence of plaster on the doorway. The floor appears to be small pieces of terracotta set in concrete. There is no evidence of a ceiling. Some reconstruction on the walls. On the northeast wall traces of concrete and stucco/plaster with yellowish background paint but no identifiable paint. Appears to be First Style architectural. The ceiling was at least at 2.5 meters, although it is nearly four meters in heights which could indicate many options. The entrance is in the north corner of this wall with round holes on either side of the entrance at about 2.5 meters high. In the lower southeast corner of this wall is a recessed niche for a couch [Feature Number 6519]. The southeast walls has traces of stucco with yellow architectural style panels (Style 1), the southwest wall with eight equally sized panels in the middle region with yellow stucco plaster painted in the First Style. A long vertical niche cut into the wall approximately a meter and a half is cut into the wall at a little over halfway from the southwest corner. It is finished in stucco and intersects the panels. A large rectangular window sits in the upper register above the niche at approximately 3.5 to 4 meters above the floor. The northwest wall has evidence of stucco and plaster in the First Style. In the middle is a large window opening to the fauces.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the southwest is Room 24 which contains a water basin with drains to the peristyle garden (22).
column21: We have identified 9 - 7 - 20 as a house.  We have determined that the last usage of this room is a dining hall.  This identifications is based on the room location in the structure.  It has a very large doorway overlooking an arcaded peristyle (22). There are no specific features associated with food and drink in this room.  However, there is a large modern pediment ceiling.  The ceiling reaches a large second story because it has a rectangular window at the peak of the west wall.  The west, north, and south west wall as well as the east walls between the large door opening show brilliant red, yellow, white and black panel paintings intercepted by still extant square paintings. The dado at the base is the usual black with green aloe.  The floor is mosaic showing only black and white tesserae.  The room is on a north-south axis.  The ceiling was barrel vaulted as extant white molding.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northwest of space 41 and to the northeast of room 39.
column21: We have identified this space as a dining room in the house of Ianipendius D. Caprasius Felix.  This identification is based on the size and location of the room.  It's decoration and feature support this identification, as does the orientation and and character of the entrance way.  This room is in poor to fair condition.  Only small traces of plaster flooring remain.  This room is rectangular with a southwest - northeast axis.  The entrance to this room is in the east end of the southeast wall, which appears to be a wide opening onto space 41 (possibly an atrium).  The southeast wall is constructed of alternating courses of brick and cut stone.  The other walls are opus incertum.  Except for the southeast wall, the others are plastered and painted.  The condition of the paintings is poor, but a low dado is visible with cream colored panels above red borders and thin yellow spindly details.  This painting is third or fourth style.  No ceiling remains.  In the north corner of the northwest wall there is a couch niche (4068).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is contiguous to the latrine on the west, and frigidarium [22-4086] to the northwest.
column21: We have identified the Villa of Diomedes as a villa. We have determined that the usage of this room is a kitchen. The room is located within the villa facing the northwest exterior wall and is east of the frigidarium [22-4086]. There are several food and drink features [23-4072, 23-4073, 23-4074]. The room is a slightly distorted trapezoidal shape on a southeast-northwest axis. On the southeast wall we see stairs with a storage area underneath. The floor is pounded earth. This is a big kitchen. The ceiling is non-existent. The walls are opus incertum without a sign of plaster. There is a door at the southwest end of the cooking platform which leads to a latrine. There is no set pattern so probably this unroofed kitchen needed some light.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northwest of the peristyle (22). It is to the north of room 40.
column21: We have identified this space as a dining room in the house of IDC Felix. This identification is based on the size and location of the room as well as the character of its decoration. The overall condition of this room is poor to fair. It is a rectangular space on a northwest-southeast axis. The floor preserves several traces of opus sectile, with a round piece of red marble in the center of the room and several other pieces visible to the southeast of the centerpiece. The rest of the floor is cocciopesto. All four walls preserve fresco revealing a high black dado, a middle zone with alternating red and yellow panels, and an upper zone of cream color. This paint is too weathered to reveal further details. The door to the room is a tall opening on the east end of the southeast wall. We noted that Eschebach indicated another doorway in the eastern corner of the northeast wall, but this does not seem to be accurate. No ceiling remains. The walls are opus incertum. The north corner along the northeast and northwest walls have not survived to any great height so no windows are observed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Continguous to a possible small recessed latrine or a preparation room (31-4063) and corridor (29).
column21: This rectangular room is on a north south axis.  We have determined that room 32 - 4062 is a kitchen.  This identification is based on the fact that this room has a very low doorway and is in the part of the house with consistently low doorways.  We see there is a food and drink feature which is an L-Shaped cooking platform (4064) which has no recessed-to-the-floor storage nor tile surface.  The characteristics that identify this room as a kitchen is that the square room contains an L-shaped cooking platform that is in the east and south wall that covers a third of the room.  There is no modern ceiling and it could have been unroofed earlier.  The walls are without paint.  The floor is pounded earth.  There are no windows.  There is a recessed area in the north west corner, it's function undetermined.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Oven 4074 is to the west. The preparation platform 4073 is to the north.
column21: The first feature is a large cooking platform. Moss covers to the top-tiled surface. The southern end of the platform contains a small oven. The cooking platform contains two semi-circular floor recesses for fuel. The cooking platform is on the east wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: On the north wall is feature 23-4073. It is two stone struts able to hold a serving or cooking platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The cooking platform is to the north.
column21: In the southwest corner of the room on top of one quarter of the cooking platform [4072] is a small, well-preserved, beehive oven. The top surface could also be used for cooking.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is adjacent to the kitchen (32) which is to the south west.  Space 29 is to the north east.
column21: We have identified  this room as a preparation room in the House of Ianipendius D. Caprasius Felix.  This identification is based on the character and location of the space, adjacent to the kitchen (32).  The entrance to this room is through a low door opening to an L-Shaped corridor which leads east to area 29 and west to area 26.  This is a rectangular space on a south east and north west axis.  It is a small room constructed of opus incertum.  It is in poor condition, with plaster seen only on the south east wall.  There is a small window in the center of north east wall looking out to area 29.  No ceiling remains.  There is no visible flooring.  The floor is pounded earth.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The peristyle is to the south of doorway 24, to the north of tablinum room 40, with a series of other rooms opening on each side.
column21: We have identified the Villa of Diomedes as a domestic villa and we are identifying Area 21 as a front peristyle with a walkway around it. This peristyle opens directly off the street to the north. It is situated on a northeast-southwest axis. The central portion of the peristyle is enclosed by 14 columns, red below and white above and, per Jashemski, would have been a decorative garden with a fountain. Various dining rooms, bath complex, cubicula, and tablinum open off this peristyle. We are identifying this peristyle by the location of a food and drink painting [4070] now found in the Naples Archaeological Museum. The walls were painted frescoes but no trace of painted decoration remains today except for some red and yellow patches. The peristyle was open to the sky and the walkway today is covered with grass. There are stairs leading to the subterranean level located in the north corner of the peristyle. A wide room [tablinum] leading to a series of dining rooms is located on the south wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Corrider 29 is to the north east.  Preparation room 31 - 4063 is to the east.
column21: This L-shaped cooking platform, located along the east and south walls takes up one third of this square kitchen.  This platform is interesting because of it's structural omissions, such as there are no tiled surfaces, recessed storage areas for fuel, shelves, lips or windows above.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the Naples Archaeological Museum [inventory number 8634] is a wall painting of a cup with olives, tray with fish, and two partridges. "Pompeii in Pictures" reports that, according to Mau and Breton, this painting was located in this peristyle.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the north of an atrium (26).
column21: We have identified 9-7-20 as a house. We have determined that the last usage of this room 25-4065 is as a dining room. The identification is based on the location of this room looking out on the atrium. This is a good size N-S-E-W rectangular room with large patches of painted walls on all 4 walls. The dominant color is beige-white with red stripes. There is minimal detail to the painted walls. The floor is pounded earth. There is no ancient ceiling but there is a modern cover over most of the room. There is a large rectangular window in the north wall which overlooks a possible garden (29). The doorway is located in the southwest corner of the wall, and is of moderate height. Above there is an indication of a higher lintel. The east wall centrally divided by the window shows an indication for a good size dining room bench. This niche is painted in beige, red, and white.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: The feature in this room is a bench/couch niche.  This feature is located on the southeast wall and takes up the eastern half of the wall  It is large, tall, and high.  The red stripes on a beige background are apparent.  The dado is black, unlike the rest of the room where it is white.  The indentation for the bench is deep.  It appears to be square in shape rather than curved.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: fauces 1 to the southwest, vat room 13 is to the east, tablinum 11 to the northeast.
column21: We have decided that the House of Pomponius was a house but may have had some form of production activity. The presence of a vat room, trapetum, and an underground cellar, possibly for storage,may indicate the possibility of non-domestic activity. This room has been identified as an atrium due to its location, features, and previous identification in the literature. The atrium (room 5) contains a well and was listed by Jashemski as the findspot for the trapetum. The atrium opens on a northeast - southwest axis from the fauces in the southwest. A stone impluvium is centered in the room and we see typical Vitruvian construction in the symmetry of the cubicula on either side. Two alae flank the atrium and a tablinum is on the northeast end. A vat room opens off the east corner. The well is immediately to the southeast of the impluvium. A floor is no longer extant. Some traces of yellow and white paint remain on the southwest, southeast and northeast walls. The area is open to the sky. A cistern mouth is at the center of the southwest end of the impluvium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This couch niche is a low niche with a curved profile. It is set into the west corner of the south west wall of the dining room (40). The floor of this niche is a plaster floor which is partially preserved plaster and paint. The painted decoration appears to be a broad black horizontal band, with black and red vertical lines above and below it.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is located in the east side of the atrium.  It is southeast of the impluvium, with possible drainage through a channel from the impluvium.
column21: We have identified VI.10.6, the House of Pomponius as a house.  We have determined the last usage of this room (5) as an atrium (6523).  The identification of this feature as a well is determined by its shape, depth, and proximity to the impluvium.  The well is positioned on the east corner of the southeast edge of the impluvium.  The well is oval shaped.  The well is approximately 2.5 meters long x 2.0 meters wide.  This is edged and lined by large rectangular masonry rock.  There are traces of concrete lining.  At 2.5 meters down there appears to be a channel which could connect to the impluvium on the northwest edge.  The well appears to be six meters deep.  There is a large rectangular piece, possibly from a wall, which is sitting at the bottom of the well.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room opens to the ala (8) just to the southwest. There is a corridor (12) to the northwest.
column21: It has been determined that this is a storage room in the House of Pomponius. This identification is based on the features in the room. This space is a small square room on the northeast - southwest axis. The one doorway to this space is located on the western corner of the southwest wall. The western corner of the room is opus mixtum, while the rest of the room is opus incertum. The condition of this room is poor. It is not fully excavated. No ceiling remains. No original floor surface is visible. The full floor surface of this room is occupied by three deep vats ( feature 6526). Although the exact nature of these vats is not evident, it was determined that these vats may have held amphorae.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This feature is a group of three vats located in storage space (6525).  There are three vats of various sizes.  They are all rectangular.  The largest of the three vats is on a northwest-southeast axis and goes across almost the entire length of the southern part of the room.  The next largest vat is in the east corner of the room, and the smallest vat is located in the center of the northwest wall.  The vats are opus incertum and were all plaster lined. All vats are submerged below floor level.  It is thought that these vats had held amphoras.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Door opens to room 22 to the northeast.
column21: We have identified the Villa of Diomedes as a domestic villa. We have determined that the last usage of this room 28 (4075) was as a dining room. This identification is based on the location within the structure as it is off a frigidarium,  and the room has a large opening to a small peristyle around the frigidarium. This dining room is in the southwest corner of the portico and frigidarium (room 22) The entrance is on the northwest wall of the room. There is no evidence of a threshold. The floor is currently pounded mud with traces of concrete at the southeast corner. There is no ceiling extant but wall painting remains that suggests a very tall room. The room has modern reconstruction. On the northwest wall traces of painting, stucco and plaster remain on either side of the entrance but no identifiable subjects remain. Centered above the doorway is a window opening to room 22. On the northeastern wall traces of concrete and stucco remain but no painting is discernible. Most of the wall is modern reconstruction. On the southeastern wall (reconstructed) traces of stucco remain. No identifiable paintings remain. On the southwest wall are large sections of modern reconstruction. Little plaster and stucco remains. There are no traces of paint.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to a stairway on the northwest that leads to an outside door (17).
column21: We have identified 6.10.6 as a house. We have determined that the last usage of room 17 is a dining room. The room is located overlooking a damaged, colonnaded garden. This room is a good-sized, rectangular room. Evidently a bomb struck these back rooms so only three-fifths of the walls remain; the south wall and the west wall. The southeast wall has a small painted area. The southwest wall shows a relieving arch with no plaster. There is some rubble where there was once a wall. There is a tufa threshold made of blocks. There is no northeast wall when you look down on the pasticum. Currently there is no ceiling. The floor is pounded mud, and lapilli. There is a door on the west end of the northwest wall. The room is on a northeast/southwest axis.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is south of room 34 and north of an exterior garden.
column21: This room in the Villa of Diomedes has been identified as a dining room.  This identification was based on the size, shape, and the exterior view associated.  This space is apsidal.  It is approximately aligned in a north/south orientation.  The room is in poor to fair condition.  The floor is not visible except for a small threshold block, which has white mosaic remaining beside it.  The walls are mixed opus incertum and brick.  Plaster remains on all of the walls, preserving a red dado with red and ochre panels above.  The condition of the fresco work is very poor and the style is unidentifiable.  There is no ceiling remaining.  The north wall is divided in three sections.  To the western side is the entrance, which is narrow and partitioned by a tall wall.  Along the western wall of the entranceway there is a thick rubble and plaster addition which terminates in alignment with the partition wall to the east of the entrance.  The entrance partition sets off the central section of the north wall and is matched at the east side of this space by the projection of a stone feature, which seems to be some kind of double basin, but usage is undetermined.  The space created in the center of the north wall would be appropriate to hold a couch or other seating.  The apse of this room  is fairly large, with the wall punctuated with three large windows.  These three windows could be the focus of the room, with a view out to the garden.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the east of the vestibule 34 and it is to the south of peristyle 21.
column21: This space in the Villa of Diomedes has been identified as a small preparation room. This identification is due to the location , size and shape of the space. This room is on a north-south axis. The space is in fair condition. The only entrance to this room is a small door at the south end of the western wall. There is a small window on the north wall at the very northwest corner of the room. The west wall of this room is a partition wall dividing what had earlier been a large room. The decoration in this room continues the red panels seen in room 34. The preservation in this small space is a little bit better than the preservation in room 34 and remains of details, particularly of a cream colored dado,  are still visible. No original flooring is visible. No ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is north of dining room (33) and is west of storage room (32)
column21: This space in the Villa of Diomedes is identified as a vestibule associated with the apsidal dining room (33). This is a square room on a north - south axis which one enters from the peristyle (21) located to the northeast and leads into the dining room (33) to the south as well as a preparation room (32). The entrance to this room from the peristyle is a high doorway located near the northeast corner of the north wall. There are remains of the threshold blocks. No original flooring remains in this room. The walls are in fair to poor condition. The painted decoration seems to be Third or Fourth Style and is mostly red with pale yellow details. Two small painted sections were removed from the  eastern wall and a third painting was removed from the south wall. The west wall may have merely been a partition between room 35 and this space and may have had a very large central window. There is also a small window at medium height on the north wall. There are no remains of the original ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: An entrance to room 36 is on the western side and an entrance of the peristyle garden (21) on the northern side.
column21: We have identified the Villa of Diomedes as a domestic villa.  We have determined that the last usage of this room (35-4079) is a dining room.  This identification is based on the location of the room with an opening in its north corner to the peristyle garden (21).  The room is located on the southwest side of this peristyle garden, and the characteristics of the room, which include a large window on the south wall opening to a garden (currently unexcavated).  This window is filled in with tufa blocks and mortar.  On the west wall there is a threshold and doorway into room 36.  The doorway is on the northwestern end of this wall.  Today the wall is reconstructed to waist height for most of its length.  The entrance on the north wall is centered  and opens to peristyle (21).  There is no evidence of a threshold and the entrance is partially reconstructed.  There is no ceiling extant and the floor is lapilli and pounded mud, with traces of concrete on the south side.  On the north wall are traces of stucco and concrete and modern reconstruction but it appears to be a high ceiling.  On the northeastern side, upper register, are traces of a red painted border.  On the eastern wall there has been reconstruction with evidence of concrete, stucco, and plaster.  About 2.5 meters up there is an opening that runs almost the length of the wall, but this was filled in in antiquity.  On the south wall is a large window (filled in in antiquity) that opened to a large garden which is presently unexcavated.  There are traces of stucco on either side.  Traces of stucco and red paint remain in the lower register on southeast side of the wall.  On the western wall there is an entrance with a threshold to room 36 on the northwestern end of the wall.  There are traces of a door jamb on the threshold.  There are no traces of plaster on this reconstructed wall.  Today there is a large opening waist high which has been reconstructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to the swimming pool area (59) to the north east.
column21: We have identified this structure as the Villa of Diomedes. We have determined that the last usage  of this space was as a large dining garden/peristyle. This rectangular garden/peristyle is located in an immense lower garden area (59), surrounded by a colonnade. Jashemski describes five trees in the garden and other plantings. But the distinctive feature of the garden is the swimming pool located at its center which is overlooked by the dining garden. The pool is rectangular on three sides and crescent shaped on the fourth side. On the northwest and southeast corners are half-circular apses. This peristyle/garden, located west of the pool, is central to the atrium villa concept. There are no specific food and drink features. However, the size of the dining garden/peristyle suggests a prestigious dining area. The east and west colonnade are interrupted by doors. The floor is now heavy grass. One of the six columns shows a fluted Doric surface. There are four columns on the north-south walls. No flooring remains. The two columns located on the west side of the garden enclosure have traces of fluted plaster decoration remaining; white upper register, red lower register.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is contiguous to a small dining room (35) to the east and another room (46) which overlooks the bay.
column21: We have identified this structure as a villa.  We have determined that room 36 is a dining room on a northeast-southwest axis.  This is one dining room in a dining room complex.  The room is on the upper level.  It has a very large doorway overlooking space 44.  This rectangular room contains no food and drink features, however, the characteristics of the room suggest that it is a dining room.  The size would permit dining couches.  Currently there is no roof, although it is protected b a modern structure.  On the south wall at a high level, we see a portion of a high window.  On the east wall we see a large window to a smaller dining room (35) and a narrow doorway in the north corner.  Tufa stones serve as a threshold.
