There is another doorway to an adjoining dining room (46) on the northwest wall.  The floor is pounded earth.  On the northwest wall between the two dining rooms, at a high level, there is a long rectangular opening, perhaps for lighting.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is contiguous with walkway (44) to the east.  The dining garden (59) is to the west.
column21: We have identified the Villa of Diomedes as a domestic villa.  We have determined that the last usage of this room (80) is a dining hall.  This identification is based on the location of the room, the marble entrance is on direct axis with the tablinum;  it is raised one story above the impressive large garden (59) with a view of the bay of Naples to the south.  This is a very large room.  There is no ceiling and the walls have been badly damaged and reconstructed.  The floor is entirely reconstructed.  On the northeastern wall, on the northern corner, is an impressive entrance off corridor 44.  The threshold is marble with evidence of door jambs on either side and a slight step up.  At the southern end is an entrance paralleling the other, but no traces of marble remain.  The entire wall is reconstructed to approximately one meter.  At the eastern corner, abutting the southeastern wall, is a semi-engaged pilaster.  On the southeast wall there is a large window today.  The wall is mostly reconstructed.  On the southwestern wall there is a reconstructed outer wall.  Today the floor does not extend the full distance to the wall, but presumably did in antiquity.  The view would have been to a large garden one story below (59) and to the sea beyond.  This wall would be had an opening on axis with the dining feature and water feature in the garden (79) below.  The northwestern wall is reconstructed, with an apparent opening at the western end of the wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the north of walkway 44 and to the south of tablinum 40.
column21: In the residential Villa of Diomedes, we have identified room 45 as a dining room.  Although smaller in size than other dining rooms in this structure, the room was decorated and had a large opening looking south.  The southwest corner has a doorway with slight remains of a stone threshold.  The southern end of the room has an opening constructed of tufa block and may have had door hardware attached to it based on what appears to be a round hole about 50 centimeters up.  The north wall has a doorway opening with a marble threshold opening to tablinum (40).   That threshold does show evidence of door attachment.  The walls are of opus incertum and show faint evidence of panel decorations.  On the north wall, high up, there is a post hold opening which could indicate a roof or an upper floor.  No floor decoration remains.  The floor is now dirt and gravel.  The room is currently without a roof.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the south is dining room 36.  To the west is terrace 44.
column21: In the domestic Villa of Diomedes, we have identified room 46 as used for dining.  Its location on the upper level of the villa with a wide opening looking west, perhaps to the sea, indicates that usage.  The room is on an east-west axis.  The entire south end is open.  There is also a very small narrow doorway in the southwest corner of the south wall opening to an adjacent dining room(36).  The walls are of opus incertum and were frescoed.  Some restoration occurred in 1977 on the south, east, and west walls.  As to decoration of the walls, all that remains today is some red-tinted plaster.  The floor was cocciopesto, but very little remains.  No ceiling remains.  There is also no remaining threshold.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the east of colonnade 63.
column21: This space in the Villa of Diomedes is identified as a dining room  This identification is based on its size, location, and character.  This room is a large rectangular space on an east-west axis.  The location is garden level, with a large window opening to the west, allowing for a view of the garden through the colonnade.  This large window may have been arched.  The entrance to this room is in the southwest corner of the western wall.  The window opens onto passageway 68.  There is a small window in the center of the east wall.  There is no visible original flooring.  The ceiling was barrel vaulted and remains of this are present along the north wall.  The walls are opus incertum.  Plaster and frescos remain on all four walls.  Presently one can see some red dado and the panels above are shades of blue and cream colors with details in red.  The character of this room conveys great elegance.  This room was only observed from the upper floor level.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Kitchen room 24 is to the east.  Bath complex 25,26,27 is to the southeast.  Dining room 28 is to the south and peristyle 21 is to the west.
column21: We have identified Villa of Diomedes as a domestic structure and room 22 (frigidarium) is part of the personal bath complex.  The area is triangular in shape and contains a large rectangular tub (open to the sky) and a colonnaded walkway running north and east with six columns.  The area inside the columns would be open to the sky.  Two high large square recesses in the northeast wall suggest that a portico or awnings may have covered the tub.  The reason we are identifying this room in this database is the presence of a cooking platform in the northernmost corner of the walkway around the tub.  The room was brightly painted.  The floor appears to have been black and white mosaic.  Opening off the triangular frigidarium are four doorways:  one leading to the remaining rooms of the bath complex, one leading to the kitchen, one to a dining room, and one off the peristyle.  The main entrance to the frigidarium is in the south corner of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Tucked into the dead-end northwestern corner of the colonnaded walkway surrounding the frigidarium tub is a cooking platform.  The platform is created of brick masonry and is fitted up against walls to the north and west.  The platform stands a little lower than 68 centimeters high and has a horizontal triangular-shaped opening for storage underneath.  The top of the cooking platform is terra cotta tile.  The narrow northwest end of the platform top has a masonry support in an inverted U-shape built up on it.  The front of the cooking platform appears to have had a smooth masonry edging (a small portion remains).  The mosaic tile floor continues underneath and the frescoed walls appear to have been in place before the cooking platform was constructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: According to Pompeii in Pictures, a wall painting, now in the Naples Archeological Museum, was located on the north wall of this room.  The painting is of meat, game eggs, and produce.  On the right panel is a silver cup.  On the left panel is a bag of money (Naples inventory number 8643).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: These granaries are located to the east of the Imperial Villa as it rises up the hill.
column21: This structure is identified as a granary.  This identification is based on literature, location, and character.  From the literature we know that granaries were constructed where the upper stories of the Imperial villa had been.  This structure is a very long rectangular building which is divided into eight large vaults.  The construction is opus reticulatum.  Remnants of plaster coating are visible on the barrel vaults of the two western most vaults.  The southeastern facade was also plastered and probably painted.  The first vault is actually a half vault.  The second vault has a support to its southwestern side going the length of the vault.  These vaults are not fully excavated, but each vault clearly has a doorway on the southeast side, raised quite high from the ground level (loading docks), and there are holes at the floor level of the southeastern wall that appear to be ventilation holes.  The present condition is poor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The ambulatory is tot he west of Rooms 2 and 3.
column21: We have determined that space number 1 in the Imperial Villa is an ambulatory. This colonnaded space is very long and is bordered by 43 columns with a gutter on the west side. A recess in the north end of the colonnade is brightly painted and is today protected by a modern roof. The east wall was painted in Fourth Style paintings of which few remain. The southern end of the east wall contains the doors and windows that allow entrance to the remaining rooms of the Imperial Villa. Today the floor surface is of gravel and is completely open to the air. The modern reconstructed museum building is situated above this building and a row of terra cotta drains have been placed above to assist the escape of the water.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified the Imperial Villa as a domestic villa. We have determined that the last usage of this room [3-4090] is a dining hall. This identification is based on the room location within the structure opening with a view to a large ambulatory and possible garden to the west. The general condition of the room is partially restored. The size of the room is very large and impressive with a barrel vaulted ceiling. There are very fine and large paintings of mythological scenes on the northeast-southeast and southwest walls. There are smaller dimensional architectural paintings in relief upon the ceiling. It appears that the there was a marble floor because of definition remaining on the floor but no flooring remains. Previous research refers to the room as an oceus. All the walls are painted in Third Style in fine painting. The lower register is red with scenes bordering the middle register. Each wall has a middle register with a large impressive panel in the center. Above the red middle register panels there are painted scenes on a white background. In the upper register there appear to be painted architectural scenes on a black background. Only fragments remain on the southwest wall. The ceiling is painted and stuccoed in small to medium sized panels with central figured motifs. The upper section of the southeast wall finishes the barrel vault. It has architectural painted stucco relief molding around all edges.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The fauces (room 25) is to the E and the atrium (12) is to the south.
column21: We have identified IX-7-25 as a house-shop.  IX-7-24 is the front counter room.  This counter room opens to the north to the street. It has one dolia hole in the north side of the L-shaped counter and two in the south.  Food and drink features within this room are the counter (an L-shpaed counter with three openings) for dolia.  Another feature is a lararium (13-4109) with two components on the east wall above the counter.  On the souther wall of this counter room we see another lararium (4110) which opens to the counter room and the atrium  (room 12).  Characteristics of the room are its small rectangular size and the tall height of the counter.  There is no ceiling.  On the east wall there are painted plaster remnants with stenciled red rectangles.  The floor is cocciopesto and in some areas mud.  This counter room is totally open to the street.  There is a high threshold consisting of three tufa stones with a cut-in for the door and a door socket.  There is a large doorway to the atrium (room12).  The doorway to the atrium has a threshold for a door.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified the Imperial Villa as a villa structure. We have determined that the last usage of this room was as a daieta. This room is located at the southweset corner of the Imperial Villa. This has a prestigious location next to the reception room and the large dining hall. There are no food and drink characteristics visible. It is a good-sized room. The ceiling has been replaced. One quarter of the room has a barrel vault over a raised dais. About one-third of the walls are decorated in Third or Fourth Style. The colors are beige, white, red, green, and turquoise. On the north wall there are two doors, one close to the raised dais on the northeast wall and the other at the juncture of the northwest wall. There are two good-sized windows, one on the west side overlooking the ambulatory, the other overlooking a peristyle garden on the south. The floor is currently mud but shows a diamond-shaped tile pattern. Their pattern is repeated on the raised dais. The rectangular room is on an east-west axis. Currently this room has barred windows.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Lararium 4109 is to the northwest.
column21: There is a large L-shaped counter along the northwest entrance and turning southeast.  It has a reused marble top.  There are three circular holes in the counter (two on the east end and one on the north). The dolium lip on the north side of the counter is visible in the counter top.  The two dolia on the  southeast leg do not show lips.  On the north side of the counter there is one small and one large storage area.  On the east side of the counter there is another large storage area for the use of the salesperson.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 3 [4090] is to the north. Room 4 [4091] is to the west.
column21: We have decided that room number 5 is a dining room based on its large size and a series of arched windows overlooking a garden. The room is on a northeast-southwest axis and can be entered from a door in the west corner of the southeast wall; a door in the east corner of the southeast wall; or another door in the east corner of the northeast wall [this last door is slightly larger in width than the other two]. The room is very high and barrel vaulted. Elaborate paintings remain on the southwest, northwest, and northeast walls. The southeast wall is divided by three tall arched windows. The ceiling is reconstructed. The room is decorated in Fourth Style with large red panels with plain narrow borders on a yellow ground above a lower black dado. In the center of each wall is a landscape panel. The floor is of black and white tesseraeted mosaic but is largely covered with dirt. Doors do not appear to have threshold remaining except for the door on the southeast wall which is stone [today covered with gravel].
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The counter (4108) is to the east and south.
column21: The northwest lararium above the counter is a recessed square without paint.  Beneath the square is a recessed rectangle with white paint on the sides and a white marble remnant on the bottom.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The entrance opens to the northwest with a view of the ambulatory and presumably planted garden.
column21: We have identified the Imperial Palace as a domestic villa. We have determined that the last usage of this room [2-4094] is a reception room. This identification is based on the room location within the structure. The entrance to dining hall 3 is on the northwest wall. It served as an anteroom to the dining hall. The reception room opens directly onto the ambulatory on the northwest side. The entrance is large and tall, and centrally located. The floor is marble as is dining hall 3. There are no remains of a door jamb or threshold. The walls are tall. There are tall arches defining lateral recessed areas spanning the southeast to northwest walls forming an area approximately one-eighth of the main room on each side. There are entrances to hallways on the north and south corners of the southeast wall. The northeast wall has traces of yellow paint in the middle register. On the southeast is the grand opening to dining hall 3. On the southwest wall evidence of plaster and painting show a dado, a middle register and several higher registers. The panels are yellow with red and white spindly borders and one single small architectural panel in the higher middle register. The top remaining register has a cream background. The northwest wall cannot be viewed but contains the large opening to the ambulatory.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Lararium 4109 is to the northwest.
column21: This feature has been identified as a lararium.  It is located in the southeast  wall adjacent to the doorway to the atrium (room 12).  This is an arched opening with an apsidal back.  It is in poor condition without much trace of the back wall.  The floor of this niche is a flat ceramic piece, probably reused roof tile.  Some plaster remains in the arched area with a yellow painted surface preserved.  Although the upper portion seems to be missing which creates an unintended opening with the atrium, there does seem to be an intended opening at the lower section.  This opening appears to be a pass-through with a platform extending on other side of the wall in the atrium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The atrium (room 12) is to the northeast.
column21: This room has been identified as a dining room based on its location, characteristics and features.  This is a rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis.  The entire northeast wall is open and the space is an ala from the atrium.  There are no other doors.  No windows are preserved.  The room is in very poor condition.  There is no original floor level visible.  No ceiling remains.  The walls are opus incertum with brick at the southern and western corners.  All three walls are covered with remains of plaster and preserved paint. The preserved paint is mostly red and appears to go midway to the remaining wall heights.  A couch niche (4112) is in the center of the northwest wall.  This is a large curving niche with the paint well preserved.  The identification of other rooms in the structure is difficult due to the extensive damage caused by bombing and incomplete excavation.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The atrium [room 3-4102] is to the southeast. The dining room [2-4097] is to the east.
column21: This counter room is entered through a wide entrance from the northwest via a sidewalk. It is on a northeast-southwest axis. We do not see a threshold. Instead we see a series of flat stones which define the entrance as a step up from the sidewalk. This counter room is dominated by a large L-shaped counter located on the northwest side of the room across the entrance. It has a step-shelf and two small circular openings for amphoras or other containers. The size of the room is adequate for serving and for drinking customers. The ceiling does not remain. We see one post hole on the southwest which may indicate a second floor. The walls and the counter show evidence of painted plaster. The floors are not visable due to mud and lapili. There is no window. The door would open to the counter and to the entrance.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Latrine 6-4100 is to the northwest.
column21: We have identified this structure as a tavern.  We have determined that the room is a dining hall based on the fact that this room is a very large rectangle.  This is the largest room in the structure.  It is entered at the southeast side.  No ceiling survives, but there are three post holes on the northeast wall.  Near the entrance at the north end of the northwest wall there are two decorated terracotta moldings with waterspouts inserted in the wall.  The floor is irregular with dirt and lapilli covering the original surface.  the irregularity of the floor is probably due to bombing.  An archaeological trenc is located along the southwest wall and evidence of a black mosaic floor is visible in the baulks.  The northwest wall separateds the dinig hall from a latrine (6-4100).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This feature has been identified as a couch niche.  It is a large cutting into the center of the northwest wall of the room.  The back is a curved profile.  This niche preserves its plaster and paint over sixty percent of the feature.  There is a red background decorated with delicate lines and a floral pattern done in yellow and green.  Three small sections appear to have been chiseled out of the painting.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The atrium [room 3, 4108] is to the south. The counter room [1-4095] is to the west.
column21: We have identified this structure as a tavern. We have determined that this room [2-4097] is a dining room. The room is a small rectangular dining room with a doorway on the southwest to the counter room and a doorway on the southeast wall to the atrium. There are no food and drink features identified. There is no ceiling and the floors are mud and lipili. There is a window on the northwest wall. Third and Fourth Style plaster appears in patches on all the walls.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the east of the atrium [3]. It is directly northeast of corridor 5 and is opposite storage room [9] across the corridor.
column21: This space in the Tavern of Tertius has been identified as a dining room based on the size and location of the room. This room is in very poor condition, having suffered through bombing. It also appears it was never completely excavated. This is a rectangular space on a northeast-southwest axis. The entrance is a wide doorway at the western end of the southwest wall. This doorway leads out towards the atrium [3]. The walls are opus incertum, with traces of plaster on all four walls. This is in such bad condition that no paint is preserved. Seven post holes are aligned horizontally across the upper portion of the southeast wall, but the northwest wall is not preserved high enough to see these. There is a large, gray stone threshold. The quality of this doorway and threshold with channels to support a door support the identification of this room as a dining room. No ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is adjacent to entranceway [21] which is to the west of the room The doorway of this room opens to the area leading to the atrium [space 3] which is to the west.
column21: This space has been identified as a storeroom in the Tavern of Tertius. It is a rectangular room on a southwest-northeast axis. The identification as a storeroom is based on location and character of the room. The room is presently in very poor condition. The only doorway is in the north corner of the northeast wall. The northeast, southeast, and northwest walls are not preserved above one meter; the door appears to have been narrow. There is a window in the center of the southwest wall. The southwest wall preserves some plaster and three large post holes horizontally places to the west at the level of the window top. No flooring is visible and no ceiling remains. The southwest wall is fairly tall. Two beam holes are visible; one in the west corner of the room and the other fairly close to the south corner. The highest area of the preserved wall preserves a window cut in the center of this room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The atrium is southeast of the shop [1] with a doorway connecting the two. At the north corner of the atrium there is a doorway at the northwest into dining room [2] and a wide opening into the southeast wall into area [5].
column21: We have identified this space in the Tavern of Tertius as the atrium. This identification is based on the location, character, and previous descriptions of this property. The large entrance [21] directly enters this space at the south corner of the southwest wall. In the center of the space is a large impluvium. This has four columns and traces of built up wall surrounding the basin. The basin is not visible. No original flooring is visible. No ceiling remains. The walls are not well preserved. On the southwest wall there is a square lararium about two meters up the wall in the western corner. There is a small window adjacent to this lararium in the western corner. She southwest wall also preserves some plaster with traces of fresco, but is too minimal to identify details. A platform is located in the west corner. Per Eschebach, this may also have been a cooking platform. Overall this space is in very poor condition, having been bombed in World War II.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This cooking platform is located very close to lararium niche [4104] and is adjacent to the door into shop [1-4095].
column21: We have identified this feature in room 3 as a cooking platform. This is based on the location and character of the remains. It is in very poor condition but large stone blocks and rubble were used to construct this platform. The location in the west corner of the atrium places this directly below the small window and near the lararium [4104].
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This lararium is located near the western corner of the space, near the cooking platform [3-4103].
column21: This feature is identified as a lararium in the atrium of the Tavern of Tertius. This is a shallow, square niche with a marble bottom. Painted plaster is visible on the sides and upper surface of the niche with red paint on cream paint. This lararium is associated with the cooking platform [3-4103] which is nearby in the western corner of the space. This lararium, about two meters off the floor, is on the southwestern wall, and is at the same level as the small window in the west corner. Below the marble bottom of the niche can be seen remains of a shelf protruding front the wall. This section of the wall has plaster preserved around the lararium. Red paint is visible beneath the protruding shelf.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a tavern and this long room as a latrine room.  There is evidence of a latrine which is a feature of a latrine room.  The room is a long and narrow room on an northeast/southwest axis.  There is no ceiling.  All walls show small patches of red plaster.  The floor is of mud and lapili and appears uneven.  There is a window on the southwest wall over the latrine.  There is no evidence of a floor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: In the latrine room [6-4100]
column21: A long narrow passageway leads to the latrine located along the southwest wall of the narrow latrine. We have identified this feature because of the two mounds of stone on the southwest wall, the slope of the mounds, the window above the latrine, and the terracotta drain. This drain is in a recessed area of the outside wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This feature is the counter itself located within the counter room.  Within the room, the counter is located halfway on the northwest wall running east to west in the center of the room, the 'L' continues to the South.  There are two stepped shelves in the Northwest corner.  There are two small circular openings for dolia in the counter.  The counter has a small portion of painted plaster under the step shelves.  This counter does not have a top of reused marble that we often see.  rather, it is a rough stone surface.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to the storage room to the north and the dining hall to the south.
column21: This is at the entrance of the latrine room no longer present but listed in the Naples Archaeological Museum inventory # 112285 "Cacator cave malum."
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the west of puteo 6531 and to the east of 6533, 6532 and 6530
column21: In the very center of the sales room sits an extremely large, rounded dolium with a narrow neck and a broad lip on top. The dolium is made of terracotta and stands about 70 cm. tall from the current floor. There are some large cracks on the northwest side of the dolium and several small fractures around the lip but there is no evidence of repair. It is partially embedded in the ground. It is currently filled with lapilli and modern rubbish.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is to the northwest of via della Fortuna.
column21: We have identified Shop 6.10.10 as a commercial food and drink shop, small in size.  We have one room opening to the street to the southeast, located on the corner of another street to the southwest.  The shop contains several items of kitchen equipment (two dolia, a puteal probably over a cistern and some sort of stone mixing bowl).  The opening to the street on the southeast is a high step up from the sidewalk and the stone threshold contains evidence of doors and hardware.  Similar evidence is found on the opus testaceum door jamb about 100 centimeters up.  The eastern most door jamb contains remnants of plaster.  The southwest wall of the shop is primarily made of large tufa blocks.  It contains a lararium and post hole evidence of an upper floor and a very very high window.  Two other post holes are also located horizontally in what appears to be a reconstructed opus incertum area high up on the wall.  The northwest wall contains remnants of scored plaster and may have had two doorways in on earlier construction period.  There is one small hole near the center near the center top of the wall which may have been some sort of attachment.  Much of this wall has been reconstructed.  The northeast wall and the southeast wall to the east of the threshold all contain evidence of painted plaster.  Two holes midway up the wall indicate perhaps a shelf attachment.  The floor today is rubble and no ceiling remains.  The southwestern most door jamb has evidence of frescoed insert very high up, square in shape, like a lararium.  Immediately below this feature there is an L-shaped cut out and a rectangular cut out indicating some sort of attachment.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opening to the west off Atrium 3.
column21: We have identified address IV-10-11 as a house and we have determined that  Room 10 is a dining room. This determination is based upon the large size of the room, the decorated plaster, and its sightlines to the impluvium in the atrium The axis of the room is northwest to southeast with a stone thresholded opening in the southeast corner. Construction of the room appears to be very old being made of large tufa blocks and overall tufa stone. Small remnants of plaster remain on all four walls and it appears to have had a surface similar to cocciopesto flooring with a cement-like background with terracotta pieces inset. The southeast wall, next to the doorway was a plastered wall with a window opening to the ala. The southwest wall had a high window with a slit opening to the street, rectangular in shape, and another smaller window also with a slit near the west corner also opening to the street. Two postholes indicating an upper story were placed horizontally just above those windows. Two other postholes below the window course may have been used for wall attachments. The northwest wall has at its western end, at floor level, an arched recess, plastered over but filled with rubble that may have been a drain. One large posthole remains in the northwest wall near the north corner. A large portion of this wall is reconstructed. The northeast wall has little plaster remains and one low posthole. At its far east end, the door jamb has holes indicating door attachment. The floor today is lapilli and no ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the west of 6531 and 6529, to the east of the other 6533 and 6532
column21: A terracotta cylindrical dolium sits directly to the north of the kneading basin 4532. It is close to the southwest wall and just off center toward the northwest of the room. The dolium stands about 70 cm. high and is much more narrow in girth than the second dolium in the same room (6529). The lip is about 20 cm. wide and the neck of the dolium provides for an opening about half of its total girth. There appear to be some isolated etchings on the dolium but these may be modern graffiti. The sides of the dolium are at a right angle to the floor and turn in towards the top. There is a decorative band around the top of the cylinder.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The opening on the northwest side is tot he atrium [2].
column21: We have identified House of the Ship B as a house. We have determined that the last usage of this room [3-6534] is as a dining room. This identification is based on location within the house with an entrance to the atrium. The room is on the southeast side of the house and atrium. There is no evidence of food and drink in this room. Characteristics of the room are that it is mid sized with traces of painting. There is a window to the street on the northeast side of the room. It is a mid sized rectangle in the center of the wall about two meters from the floor. The room is entered from the northwest corner with no evidence of a threshold. No traces of flooring remain today. It is entirely rubble and debris. There is no trace of a ceiling. The northwest wall is damaged with some modern reconstruction. Traces of stucco remain. It appears to be at least 2.5 meters high but we cannot determine the height. The wall to the northeast is damaged but was reconstructed in modern times. Evidence of concrete and plaster remains but no painting is discernible. Midway up the wall and in the center is a medium sized window to the street. The southeast wall again is badly damaged and reconstructed in modern times with traces of concrete and stucco with no discernible painting. It is so badly damaged that it is not certain if there were any windows. The southwest wall is badly damaged; it has modern reconstruction. There is evidence of concrete amid plaster but no discernible painting. In the lower west side of the southwest there is a low platform that is 70 cm by 47 cm deep. The plaster of the southwest wall appears to go behind this podium which has undergone major modern reconstruction.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 18-6541 is contiguous to corridor 16 and to room 19 with a view and access to garden 20 via the northwest entrance. An entrance on the northeast side to corridor 16 and an entrance on the northwest side to room 21 remain.
column21: We have identified 18-6541 as a dining room. This identification is based on its location in the house with a magnificent view of a peristyle garden to the northwest. No traces remain of a ceiling but the walls are quite high and painted possibly in the Third Style. It is repaired with old but not ancient metal staples. The location and the characteristics of the room including the focus of the view, and research indicates this as a dining room.  The floor is in a white mosaic with a black border partially in situ. The large entrance off the portico [19] and garden [20] has traces of a masonry threshold but no door jambs can be evidenced. The northwest wall has a large entrance with modern reconstruction on either side. Nothing else remains. The northeast wall is badly damaged and has modern reconstruction. There is an entrance on the north corner to corridor [16]. There is a marble threshold but no door jambs. There is no evidence of paint or plaster. The southeast wall is badly damaged and reconstructed in modern times. Traces of concrete and plaster with evidence of badly faded design on a black background remain. The design is possibly red and yellow. It is geometric and sits on the western side in the middle register. The southwest wall is the best preserved. It is very high with three registers. It was reconstructed at the original excavation. There is evidence of concrete and plaster in the middle and upper registers possibly in the Third Style, possibly five panels with three larger central panels and two smaller-width flanking panels. Traces of painting remain of possible architecture and scenes that are barely identifiable. Color palette includes yellow, red, back, blue and white. The best preserved area is the upper register in the south corner. On the west corner there is an entranceway to room 21 with a marble threshold.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: the puteal is to the east of 6529 (dolium), 6530 (dolium) and 6532 (kneading basin)
column21: We have identified VI.10.10 as a food and drink shop. We have determined the last usage of this room as a sales room (1. 6528) We have identified this feature as a puteal on the northeast side of the room. It is cylindrical. It has been repaired in antiquity. It appears to be made of terracotta. It is filled with lapilli and modern trash. There are 14 metal staples in situ used for repairs. The base is round with two bands that have very worn decoration. The rim is lipped and approximately 6 cm. wide. The rim slopes to the straight sides. It is not apparent that it is in situ.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is contiguous to corridor 19 with access to garden 20 on the northwest side. On the northern side of the northeast wall there is an entrance to room 18. On the southeast wall there is a large entrance to corridor 22.
column21: We have identified 21-6542 as a dining room because of its location in the house with a large entrance on the northwest side to corridor 19 and a view of and access to garden 20. The room is large with very high ceilings and wall paintings. Research by Eschebach suggests that the room was used for dining. The ceiling is nonexistent. All of the walls have been reconstructed in modern times. The floor is lapilli and rubble today. The wall to the northwest side has a high and large entrance to corridor 19 and garden 20 with a marble threshold and evidence of door jambs. There is no evidence of ancient stucco or painting. The wall to the northeast is badly damaged and heavily reconstructed in modern times. There are traces of ancient plaster with possibly very faded yellow paint in the middle register. High in the reconstruction section are two square post holes. On the north side on the lower level is an entrance to room 18 with a marble threshold. The southeast wall, heavily reconstructed, has a large entrance to corridor 22. There is no evidence of plaster or painting remaining. The southwest wall is damaged and reconstructed in modern times. In the upper level it is reconstructed with three post holes, again from modern times. There is plaster and painting that is very faded. There are three discernible patterns with a middle and upper register, with a very faded possibly male figure in the center of the central upper register. The colors are faded yellow and red.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the northwest of Area 19.
column21: We have identified house VI-10-11 a a house and at the back of the house is a colonnaded garden [Room 20], with the remains of a triclinium as its center. The three exterior garden walls to the northeast and northwest abut property VI-10-7, the House of the Anchor. The southwest wall abuts the street and the southeast wall faces Area 19. The garden had a portico on the southeast supported by two pillars and four columns. According to Jashemski these were joined by a low wall which had a space at the top for plants. In the middle of the garden was a masonry triclinium which Jashemski suggests was probably shaded by a pergola. The back wall of the garden to the northwest has two rows of postholes. The lower row of postholes continues along the northeast wall. A door to the street is located in the southwest wall and has two steps up leading to it. Directly behind the colonnade on the southeast is a drain with a drain hole at the southwest end leading to the street. It is lined with stone. The southwest wall has a window to the street on either side of the doorway.
column53: handwriting was unclear on image #, could be image 29
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: below and to the west of lararium (6533) and to the west of dolium 6530 and dolium 6529 and puteal 6531
column21: Midway on the southwest wall sitting on the floor of the room (possibly built into the floor) is a gray granite vessel. Its shape is cylindrical. It stands about 50 cm. high. It has no protruding lip but does have a lifting knob on one side. The vessel may have been used for mixing liquids or storing other materials.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this feature 20-6544 as a masonry triclinium based upon its location in the center of the garden directly on an access with a large dining room 18 and the remains of masonry construction. There is also evidence of a serving table in the center. The open side of the triclinium is on the southeast side. The couch to the southwest has been badly damaged with just its base remaining. The northwest couch is attached to the southwest and northeast couch, and is badly damaged. The couch on the northeast side is also badly damaged. There is a square tufa stone small dining table in the center of the triclinium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the west of features 6529, 6530, 6531 and 6532.
column21: A square, partially plastered insert in the tufa bricks of the southwest wall, about 100 cm. from the floor is all that remains of this lararium. The lararium appears to have had a slightly arched top surface and was originally painted but few traces remain.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Preparation room 13 is  to the southwest, corridor 23 is to the northwest.
column21: We have identified structure VI-10-11 as a house and room 14 as the kitchen. This identification is based upon the presence of a cooking platform. The room is roughly square in shape and has a low opening to the southwest to preparation room 13 and to the northwest to passageway 23. On the southeast wall next to the cooking platform we see a small trace of red painted plaster. The walls are in a fairly rough shape of remaining architecture. The floor is rubble and the room is open to the sky. There is a step up in the doorway to corridor/passageway 23.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the southeast of room 8.
column21: We have identified structure Vi.10.14 as a house separate from VI.10.11 at the time of the eruption. We have determined that room 7 is a kitchen based upon the presence of a cooking platform. The room is rectangular and on a northwest - southeast axis. The cooking platform and preparation platform take up the southern half of the southwest wall. Entrance to the room was from a doorway in the north corner entering from room 8. The walls were plastered and painted with opus incertum beneath. The southeast wall appears to have two circular holes midway up as well as  a large post hole near the top on its south corner. The southwest wall is today extensively reconstructed although patches of painted fresco remain. This wall also retains three post holes high up indicating the presence of an upper story and three post holes near its west corner midway up the wall. The northwest wall extends as far as the doorway with a small dividing wall coming off it heading toward the southwest. The southeast wall is largely reconstructed. The floor is rubble and the room is open to the sky.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the corner of Room 14 stretching along the southeast wall is a cooking platform. The platform is made of masonry construction; has arched storage underneath; and a top of terracotta tiles. Although partially ruined today, most likely the cooking platform was rectangular in shape.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the northeast of hallway 12 and to the southwest of kitchen 14.
column21: We have identified 6547 as a house and Room 13 as a preparation room off the kitchen. We have based this determination on the location between the kitchen and several identified dining rooms, and the presence of a masonry preparation platform. The room is small and undecorated, and is entered from Area 12 on its southwest and kitchen 14 on its northeast. The southeast wall is composed of the remains of a staircase to an upper floor and most likely a latrine under the stairs. The latrine and the low doorway to the kitchen are to the northeast. Two niches in the wall above the suggested latrine have an arched shape and plaster inside. We suggest the one directly above the latrine in the east corner as a lamp holder, the other may be a lararium. The northwest wall contains remains of a rectangular platform on the north end. The platform is of masonry construction and appears to have had a brick front, and is rubble today. The floor is rubble and the room is open to the sky.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: n/a
column21: Stretching across the northwest wall of Room 13 is a ruined masonry preparation platform. It is rectangular in shape and based upon the presence of three partial brick courses at the bottom of the front of the platform immediately adjacent to the door to kitchen 14, it appears to have had a brick front. No top surface remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the southeast of preparation platform 6537
column21: A masonry cooking platform sits in the south corner of room 7. It is rectangular in shape with a flat surface and stands about 50 cm. high today. The northern corner of the platform is reconstructed and directly abuts a lower preparation platform (6537). The short end of the cooking platform abuts the southeast wall . The longer dimension abuts the southwest wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: On the southwest side there is a possible entrance to a corridor (no number), on the northwest side of the corridor there appear to be stairs to a second level. The kitchen appears to open onto the same corridor along the southeast wall.
column21: We have identified 24-6549 as a dining room based upon its size. There is no apparent ceiling, the floor is rubble and partially unexcavated. The whole of the area has been majorly reconstructed in modern times. The entrance was presumably on the southwest side across from the kitchen. No trace of the entrance remains. The wall on the northwest side is entirely reconstructed. The wall on the northeast side is badly damaged and only partially excavated. The wall on the southeast side is badly damaged and partially reconstructed in modern times. There are no remains of plaster stucco, concrete, plaster, or paint.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the northwest of cooking platform 6536
column21: In the kitchen (room 7) adjacent to the masonry cooking platform is a much lower, square preparation platform. Made of masonry, this platform stands about 15 - 20 cm. high. The southeastern end of the platform is against the cooking platform (6536) and the southwest side runs along the southwest wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Dining room 12 is contiguous to room 13 (a possible garden) to the northwest and to room 10 (hall) to the southwest.
column21: We have identified this room (12 - 6538) as a dining room based upon the room's location within the structure as it appears to open on to room 13, a possible garden area. Research suggests the presence of a triclinium (Eschebach). No entrance remains, but the entrance to the room appears to be off room 10 to the southwest. This dining and possible garden complex is on the northeast side of the house. The floor is rubble and there is no evidence of a ceiling. It is entirely open today on the southwest side, which is presumed to be the entrance but there is no evidence of a threshold today. The wall on the northwest side is nearly nonexistent except for blocks delineating separation from room 13. The northeast wall is heavily damaged and reconstructed. There is a medium sized window centered on the wall mid way up looking out to the street. There are small traces of plaster but no evidence of paint. The southwest wall is damaged and reconstructed. There is no evidence of plaster or painting.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: n/a
column21: We have identified 3-6539 as a preparation platform. This identification is based upon its location in the dining room. It is based in the northwest corner next to the entrance.  There is major reconstruction that is modern. The platform appears to be later construction than the plaster which goes behind the platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Dining Room #2 is entered from the Shop Counter seen to the Southeast. It is the 1st of several Dining rooms in this Hotel/Inn. The room is square, it shows scattered plaster fragments on all walls. The floor is currently covered by soil. The ceiling is no longer extant. The Southwestern wall is pierced by joist holes whose purpose is uncertain.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Situated to the West of the entrance VI-1-2, was located an L shaped masonry bench. The long arm abuts and is parallel with the SW wall of VI-1-2, as seen in a SE/NW axis. The short arm is roughly perpendicular to the long arm. The axis is situated to the West of a NE/SW axis. As reconstructed, the top is made of fragments of roof tiles and cement. The masonry structure was , from the most I can tell, covered with stucco. No decoration remains, if any.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Enter the Dining room from the Counter room(1), situated in the South corner of the S.W. Wall. The axis is South/North. The floor is covered with lapilli. This is rectangular room, in shape. The walls have no plaster. There is evidence of Opus mixtum and Roman brick work. There is no ceiling. There would be enough room for 3 Dining benches.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Enter the Dining room from the South Dining room (3). The floor is composed of stone and lapilli. This is a good sized, rectangular room. The axis is South/North. There is no plaster on the walls with the exception of the Southwestern corner, which contains 3 layers of plaster. There is no ceiling. The uncovered walls are a mixture of mixed stones and tuff rubble.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Counter area 1 is situated to the Southwest and Dining room 3 is situated to the Southwest
column21: Store room 5 is entered through a large entrance from the counter, area #1, situated to the Southwest. The small square room has fragmented plaster on the Southeast and the Northeast walls. There is no existing ceiling and the floor is covered with soil. There are traces of red paint, in the plaster seen on the lower Southeast and Northeast walls. There is no existing ceiling and the floor is covered with soil. There are traces of red paint apparent in the plaster on the lower Southwestern corner of the Southeastern wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 6, situated to the S.E.. Room 5, is to the East and room 4 is to the North. Room 3, is situated to the North.
column21: You enter the room from the SW, through a door situated to the NW of the counter. The room is roughly square in shape. The counter occupies the SE part of the room. Seen, opposite the N.E. end of the counter is a room situated to the NW, it is room #2. In the North corner is a doorway, leading to dining rooms, 3 and 4. Situated in the E corner, is a doorway leading to room #5. Seen, in the SE wall, behind the counter is a doorway that is leading to room #6. The height of the room is indeterminate. The walls are plastered, and no decoration remains. The floors of the room are indeterminate.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous. is room 2; to the N.E.
column21: The square counter room is open to the S.W. of the street. The Northwestern section of the room is occupied by an L shaped counter. The threshold of the large entrance door is covered with marble slabs, divided by a channel for a sliding door which extends for the length of the threshold. The walls running NW/SE, are about 2m high and are preserved. Situated in the middle of the Northeastern side is large brick plaster, in a position of adjoining. It is a stone foundation, for the stairs. The floor is now covered with lapilli. No longer is there an existing roof or ceiling. There are traces of plaster, seen on the N.W. wall, behind the counter.  Situated to the South of the entrance, it is framed by (7) blocks of stone, forming a pillar, while to the West; only (3) remain
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: The L shaped counter occupies the S.W. part of room 1. The counter is about 1 meter in height and appears heavily reconstructed. The top surface is covered, predominantly, in white marble slabs.  The counter is provided with a recess for a circular container. Situated towards the Northeast, seen at the bottom of the recess is a rectangular opening in the N.W. wall. On the West-ern end of the Southwestern side of the counter, there are traces of (2) shelves protruding from the Northwestern wall. Both were used for a display of goods.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to room #1 to the North and room #3, situated to the N.E..
column21: One enters the shop from the S.W. through the wide door. Approximately one-half of the door is blocked by the counter. The L shaped counter occupies most of the S.E. part of the room. The room is rectangular on the S.E./N.W. axis, seen in the North corner in the N.E. wall is a doorway to room #2. From the N.E. wall is a doorway to room #3. The original height of the building is unknown, but stairs situated in the East corner of the N.E. wall indicate the presence of a 2nd floor. The construction of the floor is indeterminate. Stucco,present on the wall, indicates that rooms were stuccoed and probably painted, even though no decorations remain there.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: The L shaped counter occupies the S.E. part of the room. The short arm of the counter takes up about the width of the doorway and is found on a S.E./N.W. axis. Situated at the Southeast end is a 2 step counter. The 2nd step serves as a square shaped shelf. The combination of the step and shelf, in effect, creates a covering for a cupboard that extends from the S.E. end of the short arm to the S.E. wall. The long arm of the counter meets the short end at the right angle and extends to the interior of the room, about three-fourths of the way in. The long arm lies on the N.E./S.W. axis. Seen on the N.E. end of the long arm and at a lower level, is a hearth. The hearth faces S.E.. The platform for the fire is defined by a 'U' shaped RIM. The width of the hearth, is evaluated as being wider than the width of the long arm of the counter. As reconstructed, the surface of the platform, but not the step or the hearth, is made of cement and broken pieces of marble.  As extant, the counter does not have any evidence of stucco decorations.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room U is located East of rooms 5 and 8; and South of rooms 10 and 12.
column21: The Dining room faces N.W. on a N.W./S.E. axis, on to a small garden. There are 3 entries. The S.W. entry  is visible from the property entrance, it includes a view through to the Dining room, from the street. The N.W. wall contains the main entrance and a small service entrance in the N.W. corner. The West wall contains the remains of white and red plaster but this is badly degraded. The doorway on the West wall looks as if it was formed in a material, that is no longer present. The walls survive, only to the 1st floor height, in this room. The lintel, situated in the West wall, is missing above the doorway. The N.W. corner of the North wall is covered in white and red plaster, with the upper 2 registers being visible.  A low service entry is present with a restored lintel and a marble sill with door pivots situated at both the West and East ends of the sill. The large opening situated on the North Wall is located in the middle of the wall. The lintel is missing but 2 segments of marble that have survived; one at each end of the doorway with a pivot hole seen in each.   In the N.E. corner, a wall painting survives in red and white, showing all 3 registers. On the East wall, plaster survives only in the upper 2 registers, in the colors of red and white. There is a nursing scene cut out of the wall, situated towards the S.E. corner. The South wall is covered with red colored plaster, with the middle and upper registers, being visible. In the S.E. corner, there are 2 beam holes, these can be seen to support a shelf and another 2 are visible in the middle of the wall. The walls are done in the 4th style. The floor is covered with lapilli, with the exception of cocciopesto, situated in the N.W. corner of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: East of atrium #4
column21: The Dining room is situated on a N/S axis, with the door in the S.W., opening to atrium #4. The opening has a marble sill with door fittings. Also, situated in the West wall is a blocked in window with a marble sill and what appears to be  an original wooden lintel. The wall was painted and plastered in antiquity. Evidence remains of a red dado with yellow panels located above a small section of crown moulding that remains in the N.W. corner. On the North wall, is exhibited, and is seen the best preserved plaster painting containing a ribbon pattern in red and yellow background with possibly a bird situated above. The panels appear to be outlined and white with diamond shapes. Dado was bright red on this wall and the frieze was white with yellow divisions and inset painted panels. A large portion of ceiling moulding remains situated in the N.E. corner and 9 post holes appear directly above. The East wall was made of large tufa blocks and it faces the street. The plaster is in a ruined state but occasional colorful traces show continuity within the other walls, in design. 2 higher openings seen in the wall, appear to face the street.  The South wall is mostly covered with remains of plaster, but the color is almost completely washed away. There may also have been a small high window, facing the fauces situated in that wall. There is no ceiling to the room. Most of the floor is lapilli, but a small bit of Opus signunum, primarily in a clay color remains in the S.E. corner and along the East wall. A long indenta-tion is present in the West wall, beginning about 1 meter to the North of the doorway. It may have provided fittings for a dining couch.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 17, is located to the West and room 15 is situated to the North.
column21: This is a square room with a plaster earth floor. There is an arched ceiling with traces of plaster. At the North end of the West wall, is a doorway with modern lintel and a threshold. At the East end of the North wall, a narrow doorway has been inserted with no threshold. Extensive restoration on all 4 walls, is apparent. The detail in the room, includes pieces of plastic.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 17, is situated to the North
column21: This is a rectangular room with an East/West axis. The doorway is situated at the West end of the North wall. It is a basalt threshold and a modern lintel. There is a plaster and earth floor, and an arched ceiling with modern restoration. There are fragments of undecorated plaster seen on all 4 walls. In the Southeast corner, there is a plastered recess for a drain pipe. Situated high in the center of the West wall, is an opening or a collapse, through to room 19.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 17, is situated to the North.
column21: The small rectangular room is situated on a North/South axis. The floor is obscured by earth and debris. At the West end of the North wall, is a doorway with modern lintel. No threshold is present. Situated high in the West wall, there is a plastered rectangular window, narrowing to the street, outside. Situated high in the East wall, there is a window or a collapse to room, #18. The ceiling is vaulted, with all 4 walls showing signs of restoration.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: In the N.W. corner of room #3.
column21: Situated on the West wall of Dining room #3, is a fairly long curved back couch niche. It is plastered, and begins 1 meter to the North of the doorway and is covered with red painted plaster.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is to the South East of kitchen 18 and to the South West of stairway 21.
column21: We have determined that the House of the Little Fountain is a domestic structure.  We have identified room 20 as a store room.  This identification is based on its location directly to the South East of the kitchen and the presence of post holds insets on which shelving would have been placed.  The room is rectangular on a North East - South West axis with an entrance no longer in existence on the North East wall. Some trace of red plaster remains on the north end of the North West wall.  Construction is opus reticulatum divided into three bands by coursed of flat rectangular brick.  The ceiling is reconstructed and two ceiling height post holes on the North West and South East walls indicate there was probably an upper storey in antiquity. Shelving post holes are located on the South East and South West walls.  A fairly high small windown is located on the North West wall that probably provided venting for the kitchen beyond  In addition, directly above the window are the remains of a fairly large round terracotta pipe.  The floor appears to be of concrete.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have determined that the room is a dining room within a residential structure.  This identification is based on the room location within the structure, on the presence of designated food and drink features, which are paintings, and on the structure of the room with a prominent window, vaulted ceiling and high doorway.The entrance to this room comes from the atrium (22) and is a tall doorway in the west end of the north west wall.  There is no threshold and the mosaic flooring no longer remains.The frescoes remain on all four walls, going to various heights, and are in fair condition.The vaulted ceiling remains, and has been conserved.  There is a large window in the upper arched section of the north east wall.  This has been conserved and is glazed.Generally the wall decoration consists of a red dado and white sections above.  These are in the fourth style.  Each wall has a central tableau (designated features 6551-6554).The north east wall is in the best preservation, with the frescoes preserved in part to the ceiling and with the wall and ceiling moldings intact.Atrium (22) is to the west and the room 25 is north west of it.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opens to the South corner of atrium 22 adjacent to the South-West entrance of room 20 to the South-West and alae 5 to the South-East.
column21: In the South-West corner of the South-West wall of room 28, which we have determined to be a store room, is found a plastered indentation which we have identified as a spot for a cupboard to be attached. Niche appears to stop about a quarter of the way up the wall. See measurements on drawing.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is contiguous to a large tablinum to the south east corner.
column21: We have identified this structure as a house.  We have determined the usage of this room as a dining room.  This identification is based on the dining room location within the structure as it has an imposing doorway overlooking an ambulatory and a garden area with gorgeous frescoes and a mosaic fountain.  In this room there is a food and drink feature, it is a dining couch niche.  The very wide entrance to the rectangular room allows entrance to the north east corner.  There is a couch niche that indicates of portion of a triclinium.  The walls show minimal evidence of painting.  The ceiling is modern and probably too high.  The floors of this room are of dust.  Some remnants of a marble threshold exists.  There is a door to the room to the south east which is a large tablinum.  Previous excavation reports include Eschebach and Jashemski.No other features.  Couch Niche northwest corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The fresco is to the North-East of the doorway in the center of the North-West wall. This room is contiguous to the atrium (22) which lies to the West of this dining room.
column21: This feature is a tableaux painted on the North-West wall of room 27 which has been identified as a dining room. It is a small square panel and although it is in fairly poor condition, it reveals a boar's head in front of a table with a large bowl of fruit or vegetables. The condition unfortunately reveals modern letters scratched through the painted surface.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: The couch niche is in the north-east corner of the room.  There is cream paint with small red painted section (stencilled) still evident on the NW wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified the House of the Small Fountain as a domestic structure.  We have determined the usage of Room 28 as a storeroom.  This identification is based on a) the small narrow size of the room, b) the presence of a series of post holes on two of four walls.  The room is on a north west, south east axis with a door on the S-E wall.  The room is narrow and rectangular with a high ceiling.  There are no windows but the N-E and S-W walls contains high post holes as an indication of an upper story above.  Ceiling is reconstructed, the walls are made of opus incertum with the lower portions covered with ruined frescos.  The S-E and N-E walls contain two rows of square post holes, one at shoulder height, one of a couple of feet above that (see measurements on drawing).  The S-W wall contains a cupboard niche 6571 in the south west corner of the room.  The floor today is dirt, but currently is unidentifiable.  The door on the N-W  wall has a stone threshold with door indentations and is quite high.Opens to the south corner of atrium 22 adjacent to the S-W entrance of room 20 to the S-W and alae 5 to the S-E.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This fresco is centered below the window on the north east wall.This room is contiguous to the atrium (22) which lies to the west of this dining room.
column21: This feature is a tableaux painted on the north east wall or room 27 which has been identified as a dining room.  It is a small square panel and is in very poor condition but there appears to be a prawn at the top half of the tableaux against a blue background with an unidentifiable object below.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is contiguous to the atrium (22) which lies to the West of this dining room.
column21: This feature is a tableaux painted on the South-East wall of room 27 which has been identified as a dining room. It is a small square panel in an extremely pooor condition and we are unable to determine the subject. We are assuming, however, that this was food-related, because three other like panels are food-related.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is North of the ambulatory (10) and adjacent to dining room (11) located to its East.
column21: We have identified a residential structure. We have determined the usage of the room as a dining room. This identification is based on the location within the structure, the presence of a high door, and the size of the room. The door to this room is located in the centre of the South-West wall. One enters from the ambulatory (10). The room is in very poor condition. The flooring is not visible. The walls preserve some plaster but no painting. There are ceiling beam holes along the South-East and North-West walls. There are also square holes midway up the South-East wall, which go completely through the wall. No other features are visible. The ceiling is a modern reconstruction.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This fresco is to the south east of the door way in the center of the south west wall.This room is contiguous to the atrium (22) which lies to the west of the dining room.
column21: This feature is a tableaux painted on the south west wall of room 27 which has been identified as a dining room.  It is a small square panel.  This depicts a dead duck lying across the surface and below what appears to be another dead bird hanging out of a basket.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: These are probably protective figures of gods securing the water system.Painting shows little sign of water damage.
column21: We see a vaulted inlet at the North-West side of the distribution center room.  Above this inlet are three holes for sockets for a restraining gate.  Above the sockets is a three figured painting of three naked nymphs standing upright in bronze which is unusual.  There is also a seated male figure, probably a river god, also bronzed.  River flowers frame the four figures.  Above the figures are two beige and green garlands.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified the structure of a Castellum Aquae as the water distribution center for all public and private water to enter the city. We have determined that the usage of the space is the Castellum Aquae based on the following criteria: - The location of the structure, which aligns with the aqueduct which enters the city at this point, and which can be seen with a maintenance hole outside the wall which is directly aligned with the water inlet channel.- This is a food and drink feature because it delivers drinking water to the city.This is a domed structure with a fully plastered surface (hydraulic plaster). Three windows are cut deeply through the dome on the East side and the South, and over the door in the South West. The only door is on the South West side. This is a low doorway.The system is designed so that water enters through the inlet at the North West side, filling the central basin. The floor of the basin slopes downwards to the tripartite outlet at the South East side. The water is channeled from the basin in three directions by raised dividers. A cutting to the North West of the divides most likely held movable doors. The water, once it is divided, is channeled downward to the three cut outlets. The perimeter from the doorway going West around to the outlet is a catwalk. This is symmetrically echoed on the North East side of the space. to the South of the door is a narrow, raised space, which is echoed on the Eastern side.The damaged condition of the walls surrounding the outlets does not preserve the continuation of this raised platform on the South East side. A small drainhole is located through the basin wall just to the North East of the door and may have drained water into the basin that seeped in through the doorway. In general the condition of the hydraulic cement is very good. The exterior of this building is a one storey square structure, set on a gray tufa stone socoe. The structure is brick. The facade on the South East side to the brickwork is in the form of three arches. This decorative treatment offers an aesthetically pleasing side to the city. The building is built right into the city wall, which can be seen on the North East and North West sides.The water outlets on the South East side are within the central archway and the stone level of the street would have presumably covered the start of the distribution pipes.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This is a quarter round platform in the south east corner of the tomb enclosure. It is higher than the other platform in the north east corner (6581) of the enclosure. This has a fourth style dado painting with a black background, deep red Pompeiian border and green plants.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: All other paintings in the room are on the south or east legs of the u.
column21: In the western leg of the u-shaped tomb enclosure on its northernmost wall there is a large painting of a pomegranate tree on a black or blue background. The painting is faded except for the pomegranates which you can make out clearly. Fifteen pomegranates are visible.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: On the short southern end of the rectangular tomb structure to the northwest of platform 6582.
column21: On the southern most exterior wall of the podium is a large wall painting of seven individuals seated on a dining bench (it appears to be a stibadium rather than a triclinium).  The second individual from the west side appears to be drinking from a rhyton.  There is a table in front of the diners on which we see dish ware similar to that in the tableware fresco on a different wall (6580).  In front of the table there are blue and yellow flowers.  On the eastern end of the wall there is another individual who may be holding a tray with service ware who seems to be standing behind a table which appears to contain various foodstuffs with possibly a pig in the center.  In front of the diners we see faint remains of another standing figure, but the condition of the painting doesn't let us know what that is.  This painting is separated from the dado by a wide strip of red paint.  The dado contains a nilotic scene with pygmies and water animals and boats.  I should also mention that the top of the painting has a peacock on either corner with a medallion with garland descending in the center.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It surrounds the tomb structure to the southwest and east.
column21: Surrounding the podium of altar tomb 6576 is a walled u-shaped space. The long arms of the u run in a north-south direction and the short arm of the u is on the south side of the tomb podium (the north side of the tomb podium abuts an exterior wall). Beginning with the east arm of the u, the axis runs north to south and the northern most end contains platform 6581. The southeastern corner contains platform 6582. The entire walkway is enclosed by a high wall and on both the wall and the podium there is a series of fresco paintings. The walls are of varying heights and the corners are topped with pyramidal merlins. The access to the tomb is located on the exterior west wall. Access is over a stone threshold and the door is very small. Over the door is a frescoed bump.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is directly below wall paintings 6579 and 6580.This is at the Northern end of the Eastern enclosure space (2).
column21: This feature is a rectangular platform. It is the entire width of the enclosure space at the Eastern side of the tomb structure. The top surface of this platform is cement. The South vertical face is frescoed in a bold opus sectile pattern with a large red circle in the center.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Above the platform (6582)
column21: We see on the southeast wall above the platform (6582) a beautiful blue feathered peacock.  On the northwest wall above the platform there is a table with possibly eggs and beneath the table is another peacock with a splendid tail.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is contiguous to platform 6581, which is below painting 6579 to the eastern side.This is on the north side of the eastern wall of the tomb structure.
column21: This feature is a wall painting on the north side of the eastern exterior wall of the tomb structure (1). Located over the platform (#6581), it is adjacent to wall painting #6580.Like 6580, it has a decorative vessel which is probably silver. This is a high pedestal, ovoid jar with a tall narrow neck and high strap handle.Two bunches of green grapes are suspended against this jar.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This painting is located directly above platform 6581 in the north east corner of the room.This is directly east of the tomb structure (1).
column21: This is a wall painting. 2A is located on the interior of the tomb enclosure, at the north east corner of the north wall.This well preserved fresco is located directly above a platform (6581), and is the full height of the enclosure wall.  This image represents a table with an elaborate silver service below and on the table.The silver below the table is a long handled strainer next to a tall strap-handles pitcher.  On the tabletop we see two long handled ladles, four spoons lined up in diminishing size, two kylix cups, four kantharos cups, two rhytons, two tall handled pitchers, two double handled bowls and one deep pedestal bowl in the center. These are all arranged with absolute symmetry.  Garlands drape the background in front of a red curtain.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Next to cooking platform  6558Cistern 6560Kitchen 6557
column21: There are stones placed before the latrine which suggest steps.  The latrine/toilet is built up with stone on three sides.  Above the toilet is a very small rectangular window opening to the cooking platform.  On the northwest wall is evidence of a square blocked up wndow.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Prep room and storage room
column21: We have identified this as a house and identified the room as a kitchen. It has a narrow relatively low door in the southeast corner. it contains food and drink features such as a cooking platform in the northwest corner with a latrine next to it in the northeast corner - a common kitchen placement. The conditions within the room: the walls are plastered, the floor is mud, and the ceiling is modern. Windows are placed appropriately to vent smoke. There is a rectangular window next to the lintel of the doorway.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This fresco is to the southeast of the fountain.This feature is south of corridor (9).
column21: This feature is a large fresco on the southeast wall of the ambulatory (10).  The fresco, which is in second style, depicts a harbor scene. The right side of the painting reveals a harbor with a boat inside and another outside. A figure crosses what appears to be a bridge to the harbor works. it carries a stick, with what might be fish, over its shoulder. Another figure is fishing on the banks. The left side of the painting is architectural with a small temple or shrine at the far left. Another structure, which may be a house or a temple with tower, is seen behind this. These buildings are on a podium. In front of this, there is a space with three figures. A female figure at the lower left holds a jug in her right hand and a large basket or bowl in her left hand. There is a large male figure and a smaller figure to her right. The small figure may be a pygmy or a mythological figure with a tail. He is holding a platter/tray with objects that may be cups.
