This appears to be a scene of a visitor to the temple being served refreshments. Although the fresco is in poor condition around the edges, most of the central area is well preserved.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northwest of passageway 9, tablinum 8, dining 11, dining 12, and is to the southwest of cubculi 13 and 14 and stairway 15.
column21: We have determined that the House of the Small Fountain is a domestic structure.  We have identified room #10 as an ambulatory.  We have made this identification based upon its large area which includes a peristyle colonnade surrounding an elaborate mosaic and shell fountain and its location at the rear of the house visible through the atrium and tablinum.  The room is rectangular and is on a southeast/northwest axis.  The space is elaborately frescoed showing mythological or sacred themes on a series of four panels.  The panel on the southeast wall contains images of food being offered, carried, and fish being caught.  Painting is described on feature sheet 6566.  The fountain and the remaining three panels sit on the southwest wall.  A series of three columns bisect the space with a fourth column dividing off the fountain from the northwest wall.  A water channel runs along the floor to the northwest of the columns.  The ambulatory walking area runs to the northeast of the columns in an L-shape culminating in the northwest corner of the room.  The ambulatory walking area is roofed.  Into the northeast of the water channel, the area is currently covered in gravel surrounding the fountain except for a square area immediately to the northeast of the fountain which is currently excavated showing water pipes connecting the fountain to the water channels.  The fountain itself is shaped like a small house protruding to northeast from southwest wall.  The fountain is covered with mosaic and shell with patterns of nature gods and water animals.  The area inside the colonnade had no roof but had a series of rain spouts that would have channeled water into the area (indicating that this was perhaps a garden).  The current floor of the ambulatory walkway is dirt and the original floor is not visible.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is contiguous tot he great silver service painting and to the grand banquet dining scene.  There are no other rooms.
column21: This is the eastern exterior wall of the podium of the tomb structure.  A large wall painting is presented.  You can see a figure on a podium with a foot stool. Seated on a bicsellum there is a golden garland over his head.  He is surrounded by attentive male figures, possibly seven figures.  the figure to the east of the duovir is a young man in a toga with a hand raised in supplication or thanks to the magistrate.  This is quite possibly Vestorius Priscus.  This could be the young 22 year old aedile Priscus doing his city duty to protect the food markets and provision of public and private eating and drinking.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Centered within the tomb enclosure and attached to the north exterior wall.
column21: A rectangular podium is covered with fresco with a garland decoration at the top in stucco and elaborate cornice work above the garland.  The frescoes consist of a scene with a man sitting on a bisellium surrounded by other men, the banquet scene described on Feature sheet 6577 and a fresco of possibly two fountains on tables.  On the top of the podium in a central position sits the burial altar.  Three sides carry scenes of of Dionysios holding holding a rhyton on the west side of the altar with maenads on the north and south ends.  The east side of the altar contains the inscription with two human figures (it is suggested they may be hermaphridic) standing on an umbrella-like structure with a similar structure above their heads.  The top of the altar contains the standard rolled pillow forms.  To the north and south of the altar, still on top of the podium, are paired ballustrades, each consisting of squared blocks topped by snakes coiled around omphaloi.  Paintings of assorted putti are on the exterior side of the blocks.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: 6570 wall painting6567 wall paintingThis room is to the east of the atrium (4) and to the southeast of the entrance (1).
column21: We have identified a residential structure.  We have determined the usage of this room as a dining room.  This identification is based on the location within the structure, the size and shape of the room, the great height of the doorway opening to the atrium, and the ample light from a large window as well as from the atrium.  This room is on a northeast/southwest axis and is rectangular in shape.  The doorway is at the west end of the southwest wall.  There is a narrow marble threshold flanked by square cuttings.  The floor preserves seven rows of randomly shaped colored marble, with a gray rectangular piece of stone in front of the doorway.  The floor matrix is pebble with random white tesserae lavapesta.  The large window is centered in the upper area at the northeast wall.  It is glazed (modern).  The frescoes are preserved, in most areas, to the plaster molding with voids mostly on the northwest wall.  The painting is fourth style, possibly third.  There is a decorated low red dado.  The walls are white above with architectural decoration and small vignettes at the center of the panels.  The two vignettes on the northeast wall are food related, as is the one in the east corner of the southeast wall (6569, 6570).  The ceiling is a modern reconstruction.  Two pairs of beam holes are aligned on the northwest and southeast walls. The northeast wall preserves the arched end of the vaulted ceiling.  This room is a smaller echo of room 27.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: stand alone
column21: We have identified this structure as a tomb attributed to Arellia Tertulla based upon its location immediately outside of the Vesuvius gate and from traditional literature. We have determined the type of tomb to be a schola or semicircular bench tomb. The tomb sits on a northwest to southeast axis with access from the northeast. At the center of the bench is seen a square base from which the inscription plaque is missing with a tall column on it. The square base sits upon another square base of opus incertum that raises the column itself above the back level of the bench. The opus incertum base is considerably  larger than the more visible column base. The bench itself is semicircular with drapery type curvature on either side of the column. There are two steps accessing the bench area from ground level. The seating area runs the full half circle sloping down with the northeast ends. At the southeast end of the tomb on the east corner there is a masonry support rectangular in shape that appears to have had some sort of wooden structure attached to it based upon the cuts in the stone. Some restoration is noticed at various areas of the bench particularly along the northwest end of the semicircle. in addition at the same end, one of our features is located on the down slope of the seat (6586) as well as another a couple of seats away (6587) that we hypothesize may be libation tubes. Traces of yellow are visible on the bench but we think this may be natural weathering. The floor of the seating has remnants of coccipesto paving. The tomb appears to be made of tufa stone.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is located at the most northern edge of the bench and is to the north of feature 6587, which is the other hole noted.
column21: We have determined that this feature may be a hole for a libation tube.  It is an intentionally drilled hole.  The depth of this hole has not been determined.  The outer edge of the hole is a squared opening with a shallow channel above.  This goes through the lower curved section of the seat of the bench.  This feature is located at the northern end of the bench.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the north of the tomb structure.
column21: About 40 cm to the north of the schola bench is a rectangular masonry slab, low to the ground (see drawing for exact measurements), that possibly was associated with the tomb.  The rectangular stone sits on a northeast-southwest axis.  On the side of the northeast end of the eastern corner are two round cut holes, one above the other.  The upper hole is much larger than the lower, and both are of unknown purpose. The south corner is partially broken, but appears to have a vertical V-shaped cut in the stone.  We have identified this as a feature simply because of its proximity to the tomb.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is located south of feature 6586, on the third block from the north corner of the bench.
column21: We have determined that this feature may be a hold for a libation tube.  it is an intentionally drilled hole.  It has a round opening, visibly drilled deeply through to the center of the block.  The hole is located in the third block from the north end of the bench.  The hole is on the back of the seat, where it begins to curve for the lower part of the seat bottom.  The depth of the hole was measured to be 14cm until blocked by earth and debris.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is north east of of the door.  This room is to the east of the atrium 94) and to the south east of the entrance (1).
column21: This feature is a small painted vignette at the center of the white panel at the north end of the north east wall.  It is related to food and drink because it shows a rail (bird species) that is eating a pomegranate.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This painting is to the east of the doorway.This room is to the east of the atrium (4) and to the south east of the entrance (1).
column21: This feature is a small painted vignette at the eastern end of the south east wall.  This is in fairly poor condition, but reveals a goat eating from a basket and is therefore related to food and drink.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This is a test record
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room opens on the north west side of atrium 4.
column21: We have determined that the House of the Small Fountain was a domestic property. Room #6 in that structure, we have identified as a store room. We have made this identification based upon the size and shape of the room; the narrowness of the doorway; and the presence of three series of post holes indicating wooden shelf placement along the walls. The room is entered from the south east by a very tall narrow bricked doorway with a marble sill with indentations that show door hardware attachment. The room is rectangular on a northwest southeast axis. Fresco is found on all walls with a red dado and white or perhaps yellow above. The northeast and northwest walls were constructed of opus incertum. The southwest wall appears appears to be constructed of masonry fill with brick courses. The door wall is reconstructed but shows traces of opus incertum above the door header. The north east,north west and south west walls have high post holes indicating the presence of an upper storey. Today a reconstructed ceiling covers the room. Evenly spaced in three rows into the thick plaster are squared post holes. There is a series of three by three on the south west wall, a series of two by two on the north west wall, and a series of one row of three on the north west wall. We would assume there were three rows all the way around the room but the  lack of plaster probably hides those on the adjacent walls. The floor today is packed dirt and probably originally contained some sort of pavement.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This bench is at the northern exterior of the tomb structure (6590) to the east of the doorway. It is to the east of bench 6595.This bench faces the Via delle Tombe.
column21: This feature s a bench on the facade of the Tomb of Marcus Cerrinius Restitutus. It is the eastern bench of a pair flanking the doorway on the northern side of the tomb (6590). The east edge of this abuts the city wall, and it is placed against the opus reticulatum between the wall of the tomb and the city wall.This bench is constructed of opus incertum. The stones were covered with a smooth layer of cement. This bench is in fair condition, although the western end is not intact to the upper surface. This feature relates to food and drink since it would provide a place for visitors to sit and eat.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have determined that the structure located immediately to the southwest of the Herculanean Gate is a vaulted niche tomb belonging to Marcus Cerrinius Restitutus whose epitaph says he is a member of the Augustalis. This identification has been made based upon the location of the tomb immediately outside the city gates on the street of tombs. The tomb was heavily restored in 1977. Today the tomb consists of two low walls with benches to the southeast and southwest of a vaulted niche opening (features 6595 and 6591). The opening is arched and the interior runs on a north-south axis. Running on each wall on the east and west sides are low benches preceding (feature sheets 6593 and 6592). The chamber is entered via the south over a stone threshold. The south wall of the tomb shows slight traces of painted plaster and a rectangular niche in the center of the wall. A dirt floor is all that remains. The tomb identification comes from an epitaph recorded in CIL but no longer present. The epitaph text reads M(arcus) Cerrinius / Restitutus / Augustalis Loc(vs) d(atus) d(ecreto) d(ecurionum). [Marcus Cerrinius Restitutus, Augustalis place given by decree of the decuriones.]
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Kitchen and hallway to stairs and garden area
column21: A good sized rectangular lararium niche is on the prep room wall.  No signs of color or figures.  We can't move close as the roof slabs are stacked close to it.  The walls in this room are bare of any plaster.  The lararium is situated in the western corner of the northwest wall, half way up. Dimensions of the lararium as per drawing measurements.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Kitchen and hallway to a cistern or to basement level.  Unable to visit pericolo.
column21: We enter the prep room from the kitchen.  We have determined the use of this room as a food preparation room.  There is a rectangular lararium niche and the room is dark.  There is a rectangular slit in the wall, a light source, and another small rectangular one above.  The walls are made of opus mixtum mixed with some brickwork.  On the southeast wall a low doorway leads do an open cistern or stairway to the basement.  The sign says "pericolo".   A walkway extends up to the little fountain.  The other end leads to stairways to the second floor.The room runs on a southwest to northeast axis.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Toilet and cooking platform. Narrow door leads to storeroom.
column21: At the entrance to the kitchen there remains a circular opening to a cistern. The circular opening is about 15 feet deep. Today it is covered by a rectangular wooden cover. The proximity provided a useful water source for the kitchen and the latrine. The cistern is located in the doorway area located on the eastern end of the southeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Cooking platform is next to the latrine. Opens onto the storage room and next to the preparation room.
column21: The cooking platform is a rather small rectangular surface top. The cooking platform is covered over by a partial dome. the platform has a front lip, no tiles are apparent. The nearest window is a high rectangular shape on the opposite wall. The platform is in the northwest corner of the northwest wall. We enter by the southwest door.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: See feature sheet.
column21: In this niche tomb there are identical benches within the tomb. The bench runs the entire length of the interior, it is low, made of opus incertum and shows signs of plaster. The bench runs north-south (on the east side). This bench would have allowed for resting, eating and drinking.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: Reference 2 CIL x 996 (cf p 967)Marble tablet, formerly insertedA(ub) Veio M(arci) f(ilio)  llvir(o) i(ure) d(icundo)/Her(um) quinq(uennali) trib (uno)/milit(um) ab popul(o)ex de(creto) d(ecurionum)To Aulus Veius, son of Marcus, Duovir with judicial powersfor the second time, quinquennais, military tribuneof the people, by decree of the decurions
column14: The monument is the second monument west of the Herculaneun Gate, along the via delle Tombe
column21: We have identified this structure as a schola type tomb.  We have determined that the usage of this space is a tomb, based on the location of this structure in the cemetery area directly outside the Herculanean Gate.The semicircular bench form of this tomb relates to food and drink by virtue of its being a place to sit, to eat, and to reflect. One enters the semicircular space up two steps on the north side.  The semicircular platform above reveals traces of cocciopesto flooring.  The curved bench is fronted by decorative lions' paws at each end.  This monument is placed on sloping terrain.  Nineteen wedge shaped blocks are cut to form the seats with slightly sloping bottoms and tall backs.  These are tufa and wew originally plaster covered, although no traces of plaster remain.  Behind the most central part of the bench are large blocks identified as foundation remains which held an inscription tablet and possibly a statue or column.   Opus incertum wall supports rear of bench, upper portions are modern reconstruction.  The original wall reached only the height of the bench back.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: See feature sheet 6592 bench
column21: In this niche tomb there are identical benches within the tomb. This bench runs the entire length of the interior; it is low, made of opus incertum and shows signs of plaster. The bench runs north-south (on the west side of the niche tomb). This bench is made available for resting, eating and drinking.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Travertine altar with statue of herm of Mercury now lost.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This bench is at the northern exterior of the tomb structure (6590) to the west of the doorway. It is to the west of bench 6591. This bench faces the Nia delle Tombe.
column21: This feature is a bench on the facade of the Tomb of Marcus Cerrinius Restitutus. It is the western bench of a pair flanking the doorway on the northern side of the tomb (6590). It is placed against the opus reticulatum between this tomb (6590) and the next (6589). This bench is constructed of opus incertum. The top surface of these stones was covered with a layer of cement, now missing at both ends. This feature relates to the food and drink since it would provide a place for visitors to sit and eat.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the north-west of peristyle courtyard (11) and to the north-east of room (14).
column21: We have identified the house of the Vetii as a domestic structure. Room number 15 we have identified to be a dining hall based on its large structure and its location directly adjacent to the peristyle court (11). The room sits on a north-west south-east axis with a large entry door on the south-east wall. The walls were originally made of opus incertum and were covered with a series of elaborate frescoes. The dado is black with ten human figures visible between areas of candelabra-style decoration. Directly above on all walls is a narrow band with red insets interspersed with ten small insets  with black background of mythological scenes. On top of that is a black band with the very famous paintings of cupids in various occupations. Ten occupations are currently visible with probably three removed or ruined from the south-west wall. On all three walls on the north-west end of the room directly above that are main panels with central figures (usually two individuals) divided by black vertical stripes of candelabra and floating figures. four of those paired figures remain intact, one is partially destroyed, and at least two appear to have been removed, probably to a museum. There is an architectural frieze with human figures above that in the same end of the room. More painting used to exists throughout, but some of the fresco is in ruined condition (see photos). On the north-east wall high above the door height where there is no plaster we see two squared post-holes which may be from reconstruction. A matching hole appears on the south-west wall. At the south corner of the same wall above door height is a square pass-through window looking towards room (14). Below that window is a narrow doorway connecting rooms (14) and (15). The door is located on the south-east wall and has a very small square window centred above it. The ceiling is reconstructed plaster but what may be original ceramic roof tiles are visible between pieces of broken plaster. The floor is currently lined with wood and is not visible. A plaque in the room gives dates of 1894 and 1895 for the excavation.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The wall painting is at the eastern end of the NE wall.
column21: This is a garlanded man on the dado within a square in a coloured toga with a faraway look in his eyes holding a jug and patera (block background).  The wall painting is at the eastern end of the NE wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This panel flanks the central section of the NE wall.
column21: This black panel above the dado figure which shows an altar which seems to be glowing.  Reading from left a woman holds a jug, patera with a deer beside her.  There is a man in active stance holding a short sword.  A woman flees holding a patera.  This panel flanks the central section of the NE wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This painting is at the northern end of the NE wall.
column21: Another black dado figure of a woman holding a staff in her right hand.  In her left she holds a tray with a hogs head on a draped plate.  This painting is at the northern end of the NE wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Image is northern end of NW wall.
column21: Dado panel seems to show a banqueting scene.  It looks as if figures are reclining on a stibidium.  It is difficult to make out the food being served.  Image is northern end of NW wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In this big central panel on the left side we see cupids in a tree harvesting fruit. To the right is a cupid collecting harvest. To the left is a figure with a ladder. There seems to be two cupids harvesting fruit in the tree. The painting is in the lower centre of the north-west wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The painting is to the northwest of figure 6604 and to the west of figure 6601.
column21: Near the west corner of the northwest wall above the dado in the solid black band is a painting of putti figures travelling on what appears to be a road.  Beginning on the right as we face the painting is a figure riding a tiger and holding a shield.  Directly behind is a winged figure whose back is to us holding a long staff.  To his left is a winged figure bowing, making an offering (probably of a drink) to two goats who are hitched to a cart.  The cart is being driven by a putti with a crop in his hand.  The cart appears to contain a reclining figure facing backwards being followed by hoofed satyr playing pan pipes.  The final figure to his left is a putti with an amphora being carried on his shoulder and a wand in his hand.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: No longer extant in the dining room is a painting which was located originally in the west corner of the room on the south-west wall. The painting depicted a baking scene of cupids working with the goddess Vesta present.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: On the dado of the south-west wall closest to the west corner is found a painting of a female dressed in a purplish chiton holding what appears to be a patera in her hands. The painting has a black background and is delineated by thin red vertical bands with yellow edging and various leaf forms make up the background.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is close to the western corner, west of the small door on the south west wall.
column21: This feature is a wall painting in situ on the south-west wall. The dining hall is decorated in the fourth style painting with a decorated black dado below large red panels which are divided by wide black vertical bands. Black band runs horizontally across the lower section of the red panels, creating a band below. This feature is a section of the black horizontal band. It is a vignette depicting wine making and wine tasting. Unfortunately both the left and right ends of this panel have been removed. In the remaining section we see a large group of standing amphorae, a cupid hands another cupid a bowl or cup of wine. To the right of these figures, two additional cupids pour wine from an amphora into a cup. At the right end of this panel were additional figures (now removed)...
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is directly west of the small door in the south corner of the room and is south west of the main entrance to the room.
column21: This feature is a wall painting in situ on the south end of the south west wall.  The dining hall is decorated in fourth style painting with a decorated black dado below large red panels which are divided by wide black vertical bands.  This feature is a black panel at the bottom of the black vertical band just above the dado.  Although in poor condition, the remaining segments depict three winged figures.  The figure in the centre holds a conical bowl.  the figure to the right holds a basket or elongated bowl filled with some food about to be placed on the altar or table in front of her.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This is an upper centre panel above the black framed panels. There are two figures in the centre, one reclining man with his head turned towards a standing figure of a woman in the act of pouring fluid into his mouth. This is a Dionystic figure with a faun left - behind it is a Thrysas holding figure of Dionysus.Upper register located on northern end of the north-west wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Enter from the slaves atrium and cooks private pornography room.
column21: Kitchen.  We enter this room from the atrium of the servants.  The floor is concrete and mud.  The room includes a water basin, elaborate cooking platform. On the north west wall there is an iron door opening to an interesting pornographic display.  There is no ceiling to the room. On the northeast wall there is a place for a candle holder.  There is a window above the blocked door. Along the north west wall there is a lead pipe held on to the wall by three brackets.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Attached to cooking platform.Enter from slaves atrium.
column21: Attached to the cooking platform (feature 66100) is a water basin. This partially circular basin has a long rectangular opening under the cooking platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: On the south east wall.  Enter from the atrium of slaves.
column21: We are looking along the south eastern wall at a great cooking platform with a front lip, rear shelf, recessed storage pit. The top is of pebbles.  Escheback said there were five cooking utensils on the cooking platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this space as a dining room. this determination is based on the location of the room just off the peristyle, the very large entrance across the entire south-west side of the room, and the formal decoration of this room in fourth style painting. This is a rectangular room on a north-east/south-west axis. One enters the room through the large doorway on the south-west side, across a broad tufa threshold. This threshold is two large blocks with cuttings for screens. The floor of this room is in very poor condition with sections of smooth plaster preserved near the centre and south-west side of the room. The walls are frescoed and preserved almost to the ceiling on sections of the south-east and north-west walls. The frescoes on the north-east wall are only preserved to about the middle of the wall. These fourth style paintings depict a red dado with large yellow panels above, which are divided by red bands and thin white ionic columns. The centre panel of each wall depicts large mythological scenes. The side panels on each wall are openings looking out to architecture beyond. The upper levels are  white and are also architectural vistas. The upper part of the wall and the ceiling are reconstructed.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified the House of the Vetti as a domestic space and room 16 as a dining room based upon its view towards the peristyle courtyard, its very large doorway and its rectangular shape.  The room is on northeast-southwest axis and is entered from the southwest from a very high door covering most of that wall.  To the southeast is a second doorway of average height entering to ala 17.  The room is covered with fresco painting on the southeast, northeast and northwest walls.  Much is in situ.  The dado is a series of panels painted to look like expensive marble and cut stone.  The central panels have red alternating with white backings and primarily deal with mythological scenes.  The white backed panels contain two figures (male and female) whereas the red panels are full mythological scenes.  The central panels are divided by architectural panels with four insets of nautical scenes on the long southeast and northwest walls and two food scenes topped with masks on the northeast wall.  Above the central panels is an architectural setting with figures positioned in doorway settings.  The central figure on the rear wall appears to hold a patera and rhyton.  The ceiling is no longer extant and very high upon the wall are post holes that probably indicate there was an upper storey.  The floor is covered with a wood walkway and no special flooring is visible underneath.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Kitchen 2 is to the north west.  Bedroom is to the north east.
column21: Large rectangular sales room on a north east / south west axis opening south to the Via di Nola.  A stepped tufa threshold with cuttings for a sliding door.  The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.  Against the southwest wall there are the bases for a preparation platform (4119).  Traces of red plaster survive on the wall adjoining the platform.  High in the wall above the platform is a small square hole for a floor joist.  Extensive restoration on the south west wall.  The platform is contiguous with the kitchen (room 2, 4120) that extends from this room to the north west.  In the north corner of the room there is a wide doorway with no visible threshold and an adjoining window.  Both have a modern lintel to the adjoining bedroom (room 3).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the central panel directly above a naval scene is a bearded head with brown curly hair leaning against a basket which appears to contain green vegetables and carrots. The basket is sleigh shaped, with the tall part of the sleigh abutting the head on the left as you face the painting. The painting is located directly to the east of the low door on the south-east wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the central panel directly above a naval scene is a grey bearded head that is bald leaning against a basket which appears to contain a drinking vessel and some food items including a fish. The basket is sleigh-shaped, with the tall part of the sleigh abutting the head to the right as you face the painting (the face faces right). The painting is located on the eastern end of the southeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Eschebach refers to a latrine in this room.  No trace remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The painting is located on the western end of the northwest wall.
column21: In the central panel directly above a naval scene is the head of an old man with a grey beard and moustache and head of scraggly grey hair.  He is looking toward the central panel on the wall as you face the painting and the back of his head leans against a sleigh-shaped basket filled with food and fruit (perhaps an artichoke).  The painting is located on the western end of the northwest wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: In the central panel directly above a naval scene is a beardless head with long brown curly hair, wide open brown eyes and a gaping mouth looking towards the major central panel in the room. The head leans against a sleigh-shaped woven basket with a handle containing two drinking rhytons and some other foodstuffs. The painting is located on the north end of the north-west wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the NW of negative feature 4122.
column21: Mostly ruined, the masonry base sits almost at floor level in the northern most corner of room 2, the kitchen.  This has been defined as a cooking platform by Eschebach.  It is rectangular in shape with its length along the NE wall in the North corner of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Abutting the south corner on the northeast wall is a small painting depicting a goat standing on the left side as you face the painting.  It is looking to the right.  The goat is in a structural space with a corner immediately to his right.  Leaning against the wall at a right angle to the goat is a sheaf of wheat.  A window follows to the right with two containers sitting on the window sill that appear to hold grain or some liquid or such similar food stuff.  There is another  similar container laying on its side below the window sill.  This long rectangular is framed with a grey band with a red lining insert.  Above in the center is a staring, horrified mask with high brown curly hair with a feather brush coming out to the left, from behind the head.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Above and centrally located on the same wall as FS6620 and 6621.
column21: In the centre of the north-east wall, above the central panels, sits the figure of a female. She is seated on a chair with an architectural background. In her right hand she holds and object that appears to be a patera. In her left hand we see a rhyton for drinking. The woman's body is seated facing out from the wall with her head turned slightly towards her left. The panel is framed on the two sides and top by red garland. This is the room's central figure as you look in the doorway directly above the central panel depicting Ixion on the wheel. Architectural structures are found immediately to her left and right.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the SE is sales room 1
column21: We have determined that V-1-2 is a small food and drink shop based upon (1) Escheback and (2) it's wide opening to the street.  We have decided that room 2 is a kitchen based upon the presence of a slight raised platform defined by Escheback as a cooking platform.  The room is rectangular with an opening to the SE to shop room 1 and it sits on a SE / NW axis.  There is a small window on the SW wall high up.  The NW wall has a series of large beam holes indicating an upper story.  The walls are mixed open incertum and brick courses with a relieving arch in the western most corner of the room where Eschenback says a latrine was located, however it is no longer there.  On the NW wall, almost directly above the cooking platform is a small recess with a flat tile that forms a possible shelf, possibly for a lamp.  The floor is rubble, and one stone indicates the previous presence of a threshold.  Room is open to the sky.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Abutting the north corner on the northeast wall is a small painting depicting two dead birds / one upside down, one feet down) laying on a flat surface with a fig to their left.  There are two windows above the birds.  The left window contain two figs.  The right window contains a single fig.  This long rectangular painting is framed with a grey band with a red lining insert.  Above in the center is a staring, horrified mask with high brown curly hair with a feather brush coming out to the right from behind the head.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is off the north-west side of the peristyle, in the north corner. It is north-east of dining room (#6611).
column21: It has been determined that this is a storage room, based on the accounts by Escherbach who notes that amphorae were stored in this room.The room is rectangular on a north-east/south-west axis. One enters a narrow, short doorway at the south-east side of the room from the peristyle. The floor seems to have been cocciopesto, remains of which can be seen at the north-west end of the room. The walls are plaster, without any traces of paint. There is a low doorway at the north-west side of the room leading out to areas (6). The south-west and north-east walls have three rows of three holes for shelving. The ceiling  is modern metal covering. There are two high narrow windows on the north-east wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have determined that this space is a dining room.  This identification is based on the location of the room off the atrium, its large entrance way, and the decorative scheme (fourth style) of the wall paintings.The room is rectangular on a northwest / southeast axis.  One enters at the north west side of the room.  There is a window centered at the upper section of the north east wall.  The floor is cocciopesto with a large centrally placed round marble slab and other tiles of coloured marble placed on the north western area of the floor.  The wall decoration has a low dark dado.  The central panels are decorated with architectural elements in a mythological tableaux on a white background.  The upper section is architectural, decorated with some figures, some holding bowls and fruit.  The ceiling is a modern covering.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Contiguous to the south-east of rooms (2) and (3) and to the south-west of room (4).
column21: We have determined that shop 'V-I-1' is a food shop based upon the counter prominent in the front room and the reports given by Eschebach. We have identified Room (1) as the counter room based upon the presence of a masonry counter and its location open to the sidewalk at the juncture of two streets. The room is rectangular and is on a south-west/north-east axis. The long end of the L-shaped counter faces the street to the south-east, with its other arm facing the street to the south-west. The room has doorways on the north-west leading to rooms (2) and (3), and on the north-east to room (4). Walls are of mixed opus incertum and brick construction. The floor is rubble and there is a step up from the sidewalk on both street sides. The counter appears to take up two thirds of the space in the shop. No ceiling/roof is present. The walls around the room show trace of plaster decoration but no painted colour remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: On the south west wall of the room.
column21: Two heavily resotred masonry supports for preparation platform.  Surface does not survive.  Abuts directly against south west wall of the room (1, 4118).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opens to the SE to room 1.
column21: We have identified structure 4115 as a thermopolium based upon a large L-shaped counter and its large door openings to two cross streets.  We decided that room 4 was a serving room based upon its proximity to the counter and its location to the NW of the counter room.  The room is square with its large opening to the SE and a high window between it and room 3 (4116).  At either side of the door opening are large stones that indicate a threshold was probably present in its past.  The current floor is rubble. Wall construction is opus incertum interspersed with brick work.  There are two structures / podium in the room which Escheback says were evidence of a staircase [western side of north west wall;  western side of SE wall] .  There is one other window on the SW wall opening to the street.  Currently there is no covering overhead and there are slight remains of plaster on the walls.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room (4114) to the south-east.
column21: Rectangular room north-east/south-west axis. Wide doorway  at the west end of the south-east wall, opening to the counter room (1). No visible threshold. floor obscured by lapilli throughout. Undecorated plaster survives in fragments on all four walls. Extensive restoration high on north-east and north-west walls. High along the length of the north-west wall are seven holes for floor joints - modern? In the centre of the south-west wall there is a square window opening to room (2).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: A very large masonry counter with a tiled top takes up about two-thirds of counter room (1). The counter is L-shaped with three openings for dolia facing the street to the south-east and one more dolia opening next to a hearth cut out on a south-west side. The dolia appear to be of different sizes with large dolia located on the north-east end of the counter adjacent to the building and its opposite counter on the south-west end. One of the smaller dolia is located between the two larger dolia and one is located to the north-west just before the hearth. The lips on three dolia to the south-east of the counter are missing, but the small dolia next to the hearth has a conciele lip that appears to be restored. The hearth is on the north-west end and is square in shape with some tiles sticking out indicating that the cooking surface was raised slightly above floor level. The south-east face of the counter has a marble fronted step above the threshold level which would access the large dolia to the north-east. There is masonry fill between the front of the counter and the street threshold at the north-east corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Peristyle 11, 12 to the south east. Corridor 29 to the south.
column21: Rectangular room on a north east/south west axis with wide doorway in the east wall, opening to peristyle. Marble threshold survives.In the south east corner there is a doorway through to corridor 29. Modern lintel, no threshold. Floor obscured by earth and lapilli throughout. Plaster decoration survives with alternating red, white and yellow panels. Insert in centre of south wall is not in situ - removed to Naples. Plaster moulding survives with red painted decoration. Several graffiti were found in this room - CIL 4.4043, 4044, 4045, 4046, 4047, 4048.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: V.M. Strocka "Das Bildptrogramm des Epigrammzimmers i Pompeji" i Rheinischens Museum 102 (1995) 269-290.
M. Staub Gierow.  "The House of the Greek Epigrams V.1.18. 11-12:  Preliminary Report" i Opscula Romana 31-32 (2006-7) 105-117.

M. Staub Gierow @Developments i Restudy of Cae Degli Epigrammi Greci (V.1.18, 11-12)"  p. Guzzo and M. Guidobaldi (eds)  Nuove Ricerche Archaelogiche Nell "Area Vesuiviana.  (Scavi 2003-2006) Rome 2008 p. 93-102.
column14: Peristyle (11, 12) to the south and dining room 19 to the west.
column21: Long rectangular room northwest/southeast axis with wide open doorway south to peristyle 11, 12.  Doorway has marble threshold with placings for door.  Modern lintel. Coccio pesto floor partially obscured by debris.  At the southern end of the west wall there is a doorway to dining room 19 (4139).  Modern lintel, marble threshold with placing for door.  The upper sections of all four walls are restored.  In the center of the east wall there is a modern hole through to the adjoining corridor.  Extensive third style painting survives on all four walls.  Black lower register with alternating red and yellow panels above.  Graffiti was found here CIL-4.4150.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: M. Staub Gierow "The House of the Greek Epigrams V.1.18.  11-12 Preliminary Report" i Opscula Romana 31-32 (2006-7) 105-117.

Guzzo and M Guidobaldi (eds) nuove richerche archaeologiche nell'area vesuviana. (scavi 2003-2006) Rome 2008 p93-102V.M. Strocka 'Das Bildprogramm dis Epiglammzimmers i Pompeji' i Rheinischens museum 102 (1995) 290-296
column14: To the NE of oecus, to the SW of dining hall 13, to the NW of peristyle 11/12Paintings - Sogliano PM 117
column21: We have identified V-1-18 as a house and have determined that room 19 is a dining room.  We have based this determination on its very large front opening to the peristyle garden, on the presence of central rectangular mosaic panel in the mosaic tiled floor and its very elaborate colorful frescoed walls.  The room is entered primarily from the peristyle, but also has an entrance to the NE from dining hall 13.  The room is roughly square.  The upper portion of the walls and roof are restored and the lower walls are frescoed and painted.  The dado is black with red, green and yellow lines setting off what appears to be garden symbolism. The main panels are red and it is only on the NW wall does any trace of painting remain in the form of a centrally located primary panel.  The panel appears mythological with a central couple, male and female surrounded by three winged cupids (Diana and Actaeon) (NW wall) and Judgement of Paris.  The third scene is no longer present.Graffiti was found here CIL - 4.4150
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is to the NE of corridor 3 and storage room 15, to the NW of storage room 5
column21: We have determined that 5-1-18 is a domestic house and that number 4 is a kitchen, based upon the presence of a large cooking platform topped with an oven.  The kitchen is on a southeast-northwest axis and is accessed  by a door in the south corner.  Walls are opus incertum with some reconstruction present.  Large post holes close to the top indicate that this was roofed with a second floor.  The walls were plastered.  The NE wall contains two windows providing ventilation and light from the street as well as an arched lararium with a shelf.  The SE wall has what appears to be a large looters hole above the cooking platform.  And high up (where the second story would be) is a second arched lararium.  The NW wall is missing but appears to have divided the room off from another space along the street wall.  The oven and cooking platform sit along the NE wall.  The floor is rubble with a pile of dirt that appears to be from modern excavation from the room adjacent.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Directly above and on the north west wall of cooking platform 4143, and to the north of lararium 4144.
column21: On the north west wall of room 4 (kitchen), directly above cooking platform 4143 sits a rather small oven with an arched opening, tiled on the inside with a slight bee hive roof. The oven is made of opus incertum and has a tiled, cemented base.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Directly above the cooking platform (4143).  Oven (4142) to the northwest.
column21: Shallow arched lararium in center of the northeast wall.  Plaster survives on all faces, but there is no extant decoration.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Immediately below lararium 4144 and to the SE of oven 4142.
column21: A large rectangular, masonry platform takes up the full NE wall of kitchen room 4.  It has a tiled surface and is made of opus incertum.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Corridor 3 is to the west.
column21: Square room with doorway in the south east corner to corridor 3. No visible threshold, modern lintel.The floor is obscured by debris. Extensive restoration on all four walls. In the west corner there is collapse through to the adjoining kitchen (4141).Undecorated plaster survives on the north, south, and west walls.High in the north wall there is a rectangular window that tapers to the street outside. Above the window are placings for floor joists for the floor above. Identification as a storeroom based on proximity to the kitchen.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Posticum (1) to the east.
column21: Square room, floor obscured by lapilli and debris throughout.  At the southern end of the east wall there is a poorly preserved doorway with fragmentary tufa threshold, opening to posticum (1).  Plaster survives on the north east and north west walls, with no visible decoration. High in the north wall there is a narrow rectangular window tapering to the street outside.  Identification as a storeroom is based on its proximity to the kitchen.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Kitchen, storage rooms and central atrium
column21: We enter this small atrium from the formal atrium where, on the east wall, we see a double stairway to the second floor.  We see a small impluvium and on the north wall we see the great lararium.  There is a good sized door to the kitchen and one to a large storage room 24.  Rooms 22 and 23 are also storage areas - also room 21.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Main atrium, kitchen, storerooms.
column21: We are looking at a huge aedicular lararium, which is topped with a pediment and supported by two fluted columns in this servants lararium. The pediment contains stucco sacrifice instrument - a knife, patera, and bucranes. Beneath the signs of sacrifice are two dancing lars. They hold elaborate rhytons and small buckets. Between them stands a male figure. He is probably a priest because his head is covered. He holds a small cachet. The colours are still brilliant. Beneath the figures is a huge crested snake. Comment: We were allowed two hours in this great house by Director Grete Stefani who stayed with us the entire time out. Thanks to her.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We enter this dining room from the atrium's north east wall, through a very tall doorway with a marble threshold.  It is a small rectangular room with plastered and painted walls.  The top of the plastered north west wall shows an arch in the plaster that suggests a possible barrel vault.  The painted walls have an almost continuous lower zone of cream with black border.  The middle zone on the south east wall show a central shuttered window with a painted scallop shell motif on top.  There are two framed rectangles of cream, turquoise, red and yellow - flanking a central panel.  The themes and colors are repeated on the north east wall, where there are two shuttered panels.  There are twenty small holes above the upper zone.  Above the upper zone in the eastern corner of the north east wall there is a robber's entry hole.  On the north west wall the colors and themes are repeated.  The painting is of a large window with big red shutters.  It has triangular, peaked top that shows depth.  Above the painted upper zone there are nine small holes in a line.  On top of the upper zone is a plastered arch.  On the south west wall is one similar window motif.  The floor is opus, a cement matrix with random fragments of colored marble.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room opens up to the atrium (17).  It is adjacent to the northwest side of (19)
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have identified this room as a dining room.  This identification is based on the location, as it opens on to the atrium (17) through a very tall doorway.  One enters the room over a wide white stone threshold with cuttings for a door.  A much shorter secondary doorway is in the western corner of the room, through the northwest wall.  This door also has a stone threshold and one steps down to the level of the dining room floor, although at the time of this visit the room is undergoing restoration and the floor is mostly covered.  We can see traces of a cocciopesto surface.  The walls are well preserved in height with a small, high window centrally placed in the northeast wall.  The painting decoration was first style with a dado supporting large panels, which may have been black separated by vertical red bands.  Above this panel level is a section of plaster encrustation (rectangular forms imitating colored stone blocks).  There are horizontal bands of plaster molding, one above and another below these rectangular blocks, best  preserved on the northeast and southeast walls.  On the northwest wall an arched molding springs from the north corner attesting to a vaulted ceiling on a northwest-southeast axis.  The ceiling above is reconstructed.  Overall the condition of this room is fair.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opposite the cooking platform. The atrium (slave/servant).
column21: This feature is a terracotta pipe located opposite the kitchen cooking platform. It is on the north wall adjacent to the locked metal door containing pornographic pictures on the walls of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Portico and colonaded water garden to the north west.  dining room 25 to the west.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have identified this room as a large dining hall.  We base this on its location, over looking water garden and nymphaeum. As we look at this garden we see "above a podium decorated with three large mosaic panels were niches each in the form of aedicula from the bottom of which water jetted down into a large pool with three shallow divisions.  In each niche above the jet there was a small base for a statuette.  In front of this ornate facade in the middle of the garden there was a shallow pool which had a jet in the center".  (Jashemski II  107).  There are nine columns surrounding the garden; two engaged and seven that show cement covering fluted doric columns and 1 with brick.  Two of the columns are connected to pillars that hold aquaduct pipes.  Water jetted out from these pipes into two fountain basins.  The alter base portion of the aedicula show mosaic patterns of squares and triangles with white, cobalt and Egyptian blue tesserae.  On the north east wall of the portico there is an arched lararium niche .  The threshold of the dining hall is open almost the full width of the room on the north west side.  The pattern of the mosaic floor show eleven double overlapping Greek keys across the threshold.  Beyond this there is a double black border around the whole floor of white background.  Most of the center of the floor is missing.  The two side walls show minimal evidence of plaster.  The south east wall show more plaster.Floor was restored in 1996.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is to the south west of area (29) of the peristyle and is south east of the corridor. Dining hall (24) is to the east.
column21: We have identified a domestic structure. We have determined the usage of the room as a dining room. This identification is based on: the location of the room opening on the peristyle colonnade (29); the size and dimensions of this room, which is a fairly large rectangular space on a south west/north east axis. A wide opening almost the entire width of the north east wall would have provided a view of the colonnade (29) with the two fountains between the columns towards the eastern end of the peristyle columns. A smaller doorway opens to the corridor at the northern corner of the north west wall. This doorway has a white stone threshold and is restored to a lower doorway than the main door. The present condition of this room is very poor. The floor is completely gone, exposing the lower level of the house (6789, root cellar). The walls are opus incertum with plaster remaining at the south corner of the south east wall, and the eastern corner at the north east side of the doorway, and on the north west wall. There are two lines of holes cut through the south east wall with the lower row comprised of three large round cuttings and with the upper row comprised of two smaller cuttings. The cuttings align with each other above. There are also two rows of holes cut into the south west wall. The bottom row comprises one rectangular hole in the south corner, a square hole in the middle and a square hole in the west corner. The upper row comprises a central rectangular hole and a rectangular hole in the western corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the west of the peristyle and colonnade (29) and (30) and is adjacent to the corridor at its south east side.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have identified the usage of room (28) as a dining hall. This identification is based on: the location of the room opening on to the peristyle with a view of the peristyle central fountain, as well as the nympheum; the main entrance to this room is a very high, very wide doorway on the north eastern wall with a white stone threshold; and the size of this large room. This room is generally in very poor condition. The floor is not visible in any part of the room, with only a cement layer visible in the north corner. Although the walls preserve some rough plaster, particularly in the north corner, there is no smooth stucco or fresco remaining. The walls are opus incertum and the north west wall has preserved plaster with ceramic embedded in the central part of the wall. The walls are preserved to various heights with no evidence of ceiling remaining. The only other features intact in this room are two doorways opening on to the corridor on the south east wall of the room, one in the south corner and one in the east corner. These doors are reconstructed lower than the doorway to the peristyle, while both doors have marble thresholds. The door near the east corner is wider than the door by the south corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This space is directly below dining room (25).  It is north east of preparation area (26) an access stairway.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have identified this area as a root cellar for food storage.  This identifications is based on the location of this space at a lower level below the dining room (6787) and accessed through the kitchen preparation area (26).  This large rectangular space is on a south west / north east axis, the perimeter walls supporting the walls of the dining room above.  It is uncertain how far down the original floor would have been as this has not been fully excavated.  Stone supports remain down the central sections, allowing for passage throughout the space.  Holes cut along the south east and north east walls held floor joists above the stone supports.  Traces of thick cement cover these joists providing support for the floor of the dining room above.  Near the center of the south east wall is an arch built into the stonework of that wall, but it is unclear whether this arch was originally an opening or whether it supported the structure of the wall.  The entrance to this cellar is at the south west end of the service corridor where one enters the doorway at the south east and crosses the preparation area (26) and continues down to a small landing and turns north east down a narrow passage to a doorway at the south corner of the south west wall of the cellar.  This passage may have been a stairway to the original floor level of the cellar.Both sides of the stairway wall present preserved plaster, as does the north east wall at the top of the stairs.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.This is a semicircular platform in the north corner of the room. There is evidence of a tiled surface. There is a small rectangular niche at the floor level. There is some evidence of painted plaster.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We walk along a corridor from the water garden, on the right passing two doors to room 28, and then past a corridor and on the left past a door to room 25 and a food prep area.  We enter in the east end of the northeast wall.  We identify this by location and by the presence of a bath furnace in the room.  There is also an "L" shaped cooking platform.  The walls show no sign of plaster.  There is no evidence of a ceiling.  The floors are rubble.  There is no window above the cooking platform.  The door opening is larger than other kitchen doors, with three steps down into the room.  The cooking platform has four storage areas below for wood or charcoal.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Preparation platform on north corner.Located near kitchen.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We enter from a corridor from the garden. The door is on the north west wall of the preparation room. We turn towards the west into a preparation room. There is some evidence of plaster on all of the rock walls. There is no evidence of a ceiling. The floor is pebbles. We identify this as a preparation room by its location near the kitchen and by the size of the kitchen, which is made smaller by the addition of a bath furnace. This is a villa urbana with five dining rooms, which would have required a large preparation space. We leave the south west portion of portion of this room and step up one step into the north western portion. This is adjacent to a stairway down to a root cellar. The south east wall and south west wall show niches for lights. In the north corner, there is a preparation platform with a niche on the north west wall for a light.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.This cooking platform is large and 'L' shaped. Its surface on the north west wall is interrupted by a large bath furnace. The south west wall of the platform shows a rear shelf. There are some storage areas: two under the south west portion of the platform, and two under the north west portion of the platform. On the north east wall, by the door, is an additional arched niche for storage that is not part of the platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.On the east end of the north east wall, there is an indented couch niche. The top of this indentation is curved. It is plastered.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This platform is to the south of the door to (11). It is to the north east of the door to (1).
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have identified this feature as a cooking platform due to its form as a low stone structure in parts covered by ceramic. This platform is located in the eastern corner of the atrium (2). It is clear that this was originally a rectangular platform to the east of the entry (1). This section preserves most of its ceramic tile surface. There is a raised lip along the south west end, still preserved in part. To this was added an extension to the east, as far as the north east wall. The northernmost corner of the platform curves to accommodate the doorway of (11). The surface of this platform is stone and ceramic tile.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances. Entrance 7 is the main entrance, Entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and Entrance 9 is the back entrance.We have determined that this space is the atrium based on the location directly north west of the entrance hall. This atrium has a stone impluvium with a covered well and opening to the cistern. Cooking platform (#6782) is located in the eastern corner of the atrium, along the south east wall. This is located just to the south of a passageway to house (7) (now blocked). This atrium is included in our study because of this cooking platform. Three doorways along the south west wall open to cubicula. There is also a door along the west end of the north west wall. An open tablinium is located center of the north west wall. A doorway to the north of the north west wall opens to (10). A door on the north end of the north east wall opens to (9). The condition of this space is poor, no flooring is visible, there is no roof, and doorways have been reconstructed. Very little plaster remains on the walls, with no traces of paint.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the southwest of rooms 5 and 6 is the northeast of room 2 and hallway 3.
column21: We have determined that this structure V-1-20 is a shop-house based upon the description of Eschebach and we have identified Room 4 as a kitchen.  The kitchen is rectangle sitting on a southeast northwest axis. There are 2 door ways entering from rooms 2 and 3 entering from the southwest and two door ways from rooms 5 and 6 to the northeast.  The northern most of the northeast doorways coming from Room 6 is very high.  Immediately abutting that in the north corner is a cistern going deep into the ground (4136).  Some trace of red plaster remains near the cistern on the heavily reconstructed, opus incertum walls.  Eschebach tells us that there was a hearth (4135) and a lararium (4137) that were originally in this room but are no longer in this room.  There are two piles of rubble that could be their remains.  There are no windows and no roof.  The floor is rubble.  Eschebach also tells us that part of this room was a garden.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: immediately to the northeast of room 8
column21: We have decided the structure number V-1-13 is a shop-house and room  number 9 is a kitchen based upon Eschebach's description of a room with a very high platform and two preparation platforms.  The room is almost square with a narrow doorway to the southwest opening up off the working area of a popina that also does metal work. The door is narrow with no threshold evident. Walls are opus incertum with the top of the street wall on the northwest side appearing to be reconstructed at the top. The room is currently open to the sky. The room contains an extremely high narrow platform of solid masonry, rectangular, long and narrow with no trace of a tiled surface remaining. The prep platform 4131 sits on the southwest wall next to the northwest of the open doorway, currently low to the floor. Prep platform 4132 appears to have stretched between two masonry ends (no counter service remains) and sits against the northeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Northeast corner of kitchen 4 (4134).  The room also contained negative features 4137 (lararium) and 4135 (hearth)
column21: Circular, plastered cistern with opus signinum surviving throughout.  The base of the cistern is obscured by debris.  The cistern has a masonry plastered cap inserted into the north east corner of the room and abutting directly against the doorway to garden 6, in the northeast corner.The plaster exterior face of the cap is contiguous with the plaster on the north wall.  The southern face of the cap is removed to facilitate access to the cistern.  On the interior face of the cistern at ground level there is a lip.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the northwest of feature 4131 to the southwest of feature 4130to the west of feature 4132
column21: We have identified a long rectangular, tall masonry structure in the west corner of room 9 as a cooking platform. The short end of the platform sits on the southwest wall with the long end of the rectangle abutting the northwest wall. The platform is taller than most cooking platforms but has been identified as such by Eschebach. There is no window evident but the upper wall is partially reconstructed. We believe that a gap at the northeast end of the cooking platform may have been a drain, indicating the possibility of a latrine. No plaster is evident.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Escheback refers to a laraium of which no trace remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the northeast of cooking platform 4129to the west of cooking platform 4132to the north of cooking platform 4131
column21: In the north corner of room 9, we have identified a potential latrine based upon an indentation running along the northwest wall as well as a possible drain underneath the northeast end of cooking platform 4129 which may indicate a drain. The area is square and slopes slightly down.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Atrium (28) to the west.
column21: Rectangular room northeast/southwest axis with wide doorway opening southwest to atrium 28.  Threshold does not survive.  Fragments of opus signinum flooring survives throughout with intact segment in the north corner extending along the northeast wall.  Pattern of diamonds surrounded by border of two lines of individual white tiles.Northeast wall and the southeast wall preserve red painted plaster.  No extant decorative detail.There are two substantial couch niches (4152, 4154) on the north northwest and east southwest walls.High in the center of the northeast wall, the base of a window survives tapering to the street outside.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the southeast of cooking platform 4129to the southwest of prep platform 4132to the west of latrine 4135
column21: Low to the floor, immediately to the northwest of the door, located on the southwest wall is a very low masonry rectangle that would have been a prep platform. It is immediately to the southeast of the cooking platform (4129).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Immediately below lararium 4144 and to the south east of oven 4142.
column21: A large rectangular masonry platform takes up the full north east wall of kitchen room 4. It has a tiled surface and is made of opus incertum.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: to the southeast of latrine 4130to the east of cooking platform 4129to the northeast of prep platform 4131
column21: Beginning in the east corner and running along the northeast wall we have identified two masonry structures as ends of a preparation platform. One end is approximately one meter high (see measurements on drawing) and immediately abuts the east corner of the room. The other masonry support is in a more ruined state and only sits about half that height today. The second  support is approximately midway of the northeast wall. Both structures are rough masonry. Pieces of broken terracotta are visible in each.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Couch niche (4154) to the south.
column21: Long, shallow, high, rectangular couch niche extending along the northwest wall from the north corner almost the entire way to the west corner.The niche is carved directly out of the wall with a stone base.  Red plaster survives with no visible decorative detail.  The plaster is the same as that in couch niche (4154) and on the northeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Couch niche (4152) to the north
column21: High, shallow, rectangular couch niche extending from the east corner along the southeast wall of the room.  The base of the niche is no longer extant.  The niche is plastered in red, identical to the plaster in couch niche (4152) and on the walls of the room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 2 (4127) to the east Corridor 3 to the east
column21: The large rectangular sales room sits on a  north/south axis. There is a wide open doorway to the street on the southwest wall with a step threshold. The floor is obscured with earth and lapilli. A masonry counter (4124) extends from the northwest corner to the center of the room.The upper register of the north wall is restored. At the east end of the north wall  is a lararium (4126).A low wall and supporting pillar are all that is left of a collapsed east wall. Facings of the wall survive on the north wall.A doorway with a fragmented threshold enters dining room 2 (4127) in the center of the east wall.A corridor extends west from the southern end of the east wall.Traces of plaster survive on the east wall while the south wall shows extensive  restoration. Traces of undecorated plaster survive in the southwest corner. At the southern end of the west wall there is a circular window, tapering from the street outside.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the southeast of corridor 17,to the northeast of room 16
column21: We have determined VI-8-20 is a commercial fullery and that the room is a kitchen based upon the presence of a large cooking platform and an oven.  The room was originally square but the addition of the oven made it more L-shaped.  A series of post holes on the northwest wall indicate a low roof line and a window on the southwest wall would have allowed the smoke to escape.  The kitchen is entered by a door on the northwest wall in the west corner.  The cooking platform sits opposite the door frame with the oven immediately to the northeast opening at platform height level.  The walls are opus incertum with traces of plaster on the northwest wall.  The floor is rubble today.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the northeast at platform height of cooking platform 4150
column21: To the northeast, sitting on top of cooking platform 4150, is a structure accessed through a rectangular shaped low opening, with a large interior chamber with a beehive style roof.  Next to the opening, to the southeast, is a very small rectangular access point.  Today the oven is enclosed in a structure of opus  incertum which is heavily restored.  Today's structure is covered with a slanted roof of tile so that the beehive is only visible from inside the oven.  The oven is quite large.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the northeast of platform height is oven (4149)
column21: The U-shaped cooking platform covers the southeast end of kitchen 16.  The platform is low and made of masonry.  No trace of the top remains.  The two arms of the U are narrow and protude to the northwest from the main surface of the platform.  The southwest arm is considerably shorter than that on the northeast.  The main portion of the platform sits against that southeast wall.  Immediately to the northeast, at platform height, is oven (4149).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Lararium (4126) to the northeast.
column21: A L-shaped masonry sales counter extends from the west end of the north wall to the center of the north wall and then south to the center of the room (4123).There is extensive restoration. The counter surface is plastered. Inserted into the counter are three large dolia and two small dolia. In the center of the east face is a large rectangular recess forming a "C" shape. At the southeast corner of the counter there is a terracotta water basin with plaster restoration around the top.No facing survives.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: There is a circular terracotta water basin. The basin is restored with plaster on the southeast and upper parts. The basin is embedded into the southeastern arm of counter 4124.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Northeast corner of the room (4123).Counter (4124) to the southwest.
column21: There is a shallow rectangular lararium niche (east end of the north wall) with plaster surviving on the rear and base. There is no visible decoration.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the southeast of room 6, to the northwest of room 8, to the northeast of peristyle 3
column21: We have identified room VI-8-20 as a commercial structure whose primary use was an industrial property/fullery.  We have determined that room 7 was a dining room based upon a large entrance to a peristyle garden, very high, well decorated walls and a mosaic floor.  The room is roughly square and is entered on the southwest from the peristyle of the fullery  The floor is white mosaic tile with black edgelines running around the perimeter of the room.  The threshold is of the same tile in a straight geometric key-type pattern.  Currently there is no evidence of any door or curtain attachments.  There are two low doors connecting this room with rooms directly to the northwest and southeast of it. There are also two windows along the northwest wall high up  which also make the same connection.  All three walls contain remains of fresco painting with the northeast wall in particular showing the breakdown of the dado and the central panels.  No trace of what was painted there really remains, just faint lines.
