The top of that same wall contains an indentation in the fresco which could show molding or roof line for an upper story.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 1 is to the southwest.
column21: This rectangular room is identified as a dining room because of its proximity to the counter room. The north wall is extensively restored with a modern window high in the center of the north wall. At the west end of the north wall there is a partially preserved recess with a down pipe of a drain. Extending along the north wall to the east there is a shallow recess (4133) with traces of undecorated plaster. Undecorated plaster survives in the center of the wall. Extensive restoration exists on the east and south walls; there is no visible decoration.Only the lower courses of the west wall survive, with a supporting pillar.The doorway to the sales room (1) is at the south end of the west wall, with a partially preserved threshold.The floor is obscured by lapilli and earth. The room has a northeast / southwest axis.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: North side of dining room from northeast corner.
column21: There is a long, shallow, high couch niche extending along almost the entirety of the north wall.  Traces of undecorated plaster survive.  The base is obscured by earth and lapilli.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This space is contiguous to the street on its southwest side and entrance 15 (1) to the northwest.
column21: We have identified this space as a sales room, entrance 16 and associated with structure 15.  It is commercial.  This identification is based on its location  opening to the street.  There is a step up from the sidewalk onto three gray stone blocks with a channel for shutters.  This is a small rectangular space on a southwest/northeast axis.  In addition to the street entrance there is a fairly wide open doorway in the northern half of the northeast wall which opens into the atrium (4).  The condition of this space is very poor, the upper section of the doorway to the street is reconstructed; only traces of plaster remain along the base of the northwest and southeast walls and on the brick pillars flanking the street doorway on the southwest wall.  There are also no visible remains of the floor or ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This sales room is contiguous to entrance 15, space(1) and is south west of atrium (4).
column21: We have identified a commercial structure and have determined the use of this room as a sales room.  This identification is based on the location of this space along the street and the large open store front.  This sales room is designated entrance (14). Access to this room from the street is a step up from the sidewalk onto the line of four grey stone blocks with a channel for a shutter.  At the south corner of the space these blocks do not continue all the way to the south east wall where Eschebach notes a wall or cistern on this plan.  This well is no longer visible.  This is a rectangular space on a south east/north west axis.  While the main entrance is along the street, there is another entrance to the atrium (4) at the eastern end of the north east wall.  The room is in very poor condition; no flooring is visible; the walls are very poorly preserved, although some painted plaster is still intact on each wall except for the western corner of the small section of the south west wall.  The north west wall has the most plaster, and a red panel can be seen.  On the north east wall, near the middle, there is a niche cut down to the floor.  The small, rectangular recess space of this niche had been plastered and painted.  Directly above this recess niche is the bottom section of a low window directly into the prep room behind (16).  Because of the poor condition of this area, perhaps bombed, no upper walls of ceilings remain.  Although nothing is visible in the room, Eschebach noted platforms.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This niche is north of the doorway which is to the eastern end of the northeast wall.  It is opposite the street entrance along the southwest side.
column21: On the northeast wall of this room, near the middle, there is a niche cut down to the floor.  The small, rectangular recess space of this niche had been plastered and painted.  Directly above this recess niche is the bottom section of a low window directly into the prep room behind (16).  This window may have been used to deliver orders from the prep room to the shop room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is northeast of sales room (17) and northwest of atrium (4).
column21: We have identified this space as a prep room within a commercial structure.  This identification is based on the location of this space directly northeast of sales room (17) with a pass-through window (6796) located in the south end of the southwest wall.  This is an almost square room which is entered from a doorway at the center of the southeast wall.  This doorway goes out to the atrium (4).  This space is in very poor condition.  Although plaster remains on all the walls, this is cracking and falling apart.  Paint is preserved only in hte south, east, and north corners of the room, where red vertical stripes can be seen, and small traces of horizontal bands very low on the wall, suggesting a small dado.  No flooring is visible; no ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This processing room is to the northeast of entrance area (1), and southwest of prep room (16).
column21: We have identified this structure as commercial.  We have identified this space as a food production (preserving) area.  Architecturally, this space is an atrium.  The identification as a food production area is based on the presence of two features: a platform (6808) and a fish tank (6798).  This working area is in the atrium of the structure, with an impluvium in the center (not centered in the entrance way (1)).  Both sales rooms (2) and (17) open to this space at the southwest side.  Entrance space (1) from door 15 also opens to this space between the two sales rooms (16) and (15). (14) and (16) also open onto this space.  This large open space provides a passage from the front at the southwest to the back through space (14) to the oven in space (12).  This space is in very poor condition, as is the rest of the structure.  The dark stone impluvium is in situ, but no floor or wall surfaces are preserved or visible, except for some plaster in the western corner.  No ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is to the east of platform(6806).  It is directly north west of the impluvium.
column21: We have identified this feature within the old atrium which is being used as a processing room (4) with a tank.  It is located in this space which is structurally an atrium, placed midway along the south east wall.  It is a large rectangular tank; with the long side abutting the wall.  The south west and north east sides are solid stone blocks.  The north west side is built of opus incertum on top of a low ceramic bottom course.  The interior of the tank was cement with some large ceramic inclusions.  It may have been completely plaster covered.  This tank may have held fish.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We have determined the usage of this room is a preparation room.  Some food prepared here for baking could include casseroles brought from private houses by slaves and servants.  We enter this room from the old atrium which is being used as a processing room.  We see a tufa threshold and tall doorway on the southwest wall.  The northeast wall includes part of the oven encasement (12, 6801) which is in adjacent room (12, 6803).  The floor is pebbles and mud.  There is a smaller door on the northwest wall in the western corner that can lead to the room with the oven (12, 6803).  There is clear but minimal evidence of plaster with cream and red paint in the north corner of the northwest wall and at the base of the north corner of the northeast wall.  This indicates customer usage and slave and servant usage, by virtue of the small door.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: This oven differs in many ways from typical baker's ovens.  The beehive component of the oven is enclosed, and is typical in interior but the door is a rhomboid, not arched.  There is no fuel storage area, and no water basin.  On the east side of the oven door, there is a narrow recessed area behind the room wall.  It does not give access to a preparation room and it is too narrow for moving loaves of bread (panis quadratus) outside of the oven door, to the south there is a platform.  There is no passage way to the room for baked bread.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Atrium and water garden.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with three entrances.  Entrance 7 is the main entrance, entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and entrance 9 is the back entrance.  We have determined room number 9 as a dining room based on the following criteria-Located next to an atrium and also overlooks a water feature.  There are two doorways in the North corner of the Atrium; on the North East corner, a door opens to the dinning room. We enter and we see a 'rectangularish' room that is wider on the Northwest end. The floor is mud and pebbles. The Northwest wall has a small dividing wall that overlooks an impressive garden with a water feature. The central part of the garden is a water feature (large rectangular) of a hydrolic cement. On three sides there is a wall, the top of which is plastered, allowing for people passing around and potted plants.  The floor of this walkway was covered in cement. At the entrance from the atrium there is a square block of cement with a circular cistern opening. Close to the cistern there is a few inches of pipe, coming out from under the raised walkway. We are speculating that there is more than one entrance area for the water.In the dining room the East and West walls show plaster. There are post holes that suggests a second floor above garden dinning room.In the dining room, the East and West walls show plaster.  There are post holes that suggest a second floor above the garden and dining room.  In the dining room, there is minimal evidence of plaster on all three walls.  In the East corner of the North East wall, there is a couch niche, which shows plaster.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: Page 125 shows a small oven in the northwest corner.  This is no longer visible.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Door to preparation room is to the east of the oven at the northeast end of commercial space.
column21: We have identified this commercial structure as a food & drink shop, other.  We have determined the usage of the room as an oven room.  The feature in this room is an enclosed oven.  There is an Eshcebach report of a second oven  that is gone.  The room is "L" shaped, with a rectangular garden in the north corner.  The room opens to a preparation room to the east corner that has a water tank.  The large oven is on the southeast wall.  It is encased in walls of medium lava stones.  It has an unusual opening, with no openings to side rooms, no storage space and no storage space for fuel.  This oven room and this commercial property have no mills for grinding wheat.  Wilhelmina Jashemski told Betty Jo Mayeske that Tatiana Warsher, author of the famous Pompeii Codex, told her of the common practice in Russia of designating a commercial oven for communal usage.  People on designated times would bring their casseroles to the oven to bake them.  This oven seems to be an example of this practice.  The project people have noted an absence of baking ovens in private houses.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: We enter from a small doorway from the oven room (12, 6804) on the north end of the north west wall.  There is a remnant of a tufa threshold.  This is a small rectangular room.  The south west wall includes the beehive encasement of the oven in the adjacent room.  In the south corner, we see the remains of a water tank.  In the east corner, there are remains of a platform.  There is no plaster or painting.  The floor is littered with broken amphorae, chunks of plaster wall and chunks of marble.  The floor itself is mud and stones.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Two large ashlar blocks are on a raised portion of the floor.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: on southeast wall with platform
column21: In the south corner of room, there is a tank, of two crumbling sides.  The interior show signs of hydraulic cement.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is located to the southwest of the impluvium and west of the tank (6798).
column21: We have identified this feature as a preparation platform based on its location within the old atrium functioning as a processing room standing at the northeast of the entrance way, as well as the doorway to the shop room (2).  This would provide a convenient surface for work.  The remains of this platform are meager.  Only the bottom of the stone construction remains in situ, forming a small rectangular structure abutting the small wall between the entrance (1) and the sales room (2) on its short edge.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column21: Eschebach identifies this as a caupona.  The property is unexcavated.  On either side of the shop entrance are benches (4156 and 4157).  On the exterior face of the property traces of white and red plaster survived.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the south west of bench 4156.
column21: To the south west from entrance 1 to the caupona sits a long, low bench along the sidewalk.  The property is unexcavated and the identification of it as a caupona is based on Eschebach, and based upon that we are taking this as a dining bench.  The bench is made from tufa stone.  Just to note, immediately above the bench is frescoed plaster which shows evidence of painting.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the northeast of bench 4156.
column21: Rectangular bench consisting of a single piece of tufa, immediately to the east of the sales room.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the SW of unexcavated Door 6.
column21: Eschebach tells us there was an altar in this space with a bench.  Very little remains.  What does remain is a simple masonry block along the sidewalk.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the northwest of atrium 6.
column21: We have identified structure V-1-28 as a shop-house based on the description of Eschebach, who has described this as a jeweler's establishment.  Room 5 we have identified as a dining room based upon its size and large door opening to the atrium.  The floor is rubble.  The walls are opus incertum, somewhat reconstructed towards the top.  Fresco traces remain on all walls with red plaster evident.  The northeast wall and the southwest walls have a series of post holes at the top indicating a second story.  The axis of the room seems to be northeast/southwest, with the doorway taking up most of the southeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the south west of area (29) of the peristyle and is south east of the corridor.  Dining hall (24) is to the east.
column21: We have identified this structure as a residential house with 3 entrances.  Entrance 7 is the main entrance, entrance 3 is the secondary entrance and entrane 9 is the back entrance.  We have determined the usage of the room as a dining room.  This identification is based on the location of the room opening on the peristyle colonnade (29); the size and dimensions of this room, which is a fairly large rectangular space on a south west/north east axis.  A wide opening almost the entire width of the north east wall would have provided a view of the colonnade (29) with two fountains between the columns towards the eastern end of the peristyle column.  A smaller doorway opens to the corridor at the northern corner of the north west wall.  This doorway has a white stone threshold and is restored to a lower doorway than the main door.  The present condition of this room is very poor.  The floor is completely gone exposing the lower level of the house (6789, root cellar).  The walls are opus incertum with plaster remaining at the south corner of the south east wall, and the eastern corner at the north east side of the doorway and on the north west wall.  There are two lines of holes cut through the south east wall; the lower comprised of three round large cuttings and with the upper row comprised of two smaller cuttings.  The cuttings aline with each other.  There are also two rows of holes cut into the south west walls.  The bottom row comprises 1 rectangular hole in the south corner, a square hole in the middle, and a square hole in the west corner.  The upper row comprises a central rectangular hole and a rectangular hole in the western corner.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the southwest off corridor 2 and the the northwest of cubiculum 4.
column21: We have determined that structures V - 3 - 4 is a domestic house and Room # 5 is a dining room.  We believe this because the room is large in size, opens to a garden area so it would have a beautiful view and has a marble sill with a large door opening.The room has opus incertum walls and there are traces of plaster remaining only on the Northwest wall.  There is no roof and the the floor is gravel today.  The room was roughly square in shape.  At the far west corner of the South west wall there are two small post holes that may indicate that there was am upper story.  There is also a door to the cubiculum next door on the southeast wall in the east corner.  It also has a marble sill.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the north of cistern 4164.
column21: In the east corner of horticultural space 14  is currently located a large dolium, broken across the top but with most of the body intact.  Eschebach listed the dolium as embedded but it now sits on top of the ground.  The bottom is flat and pieces of the rim indicate a large opening.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: A. Zaccaria, Rugggiv D. Cottica, C. Marat. Tomasella, L. Toniolo, 'Le Indagini Archeologiche dell', 'Universite La Fosuiri di Venezia Nella Regio V' (2008 - 2009):  Revista di Studi Pompeiani 21 (2010) 112 - 137
column14: Peristyle thirteen is to the east and Garden 14 is to the northeast.
column21: Rectangular room, Northeast / southwest axis with a doorway in the center of the east wall to the peristyle.  Traces of marble threshold survive with placings for a door.  Sogliano says there were also wood door jams of which no trace remains.  Floor is obscured by earth throughout.  There is possibly a window in the center of the poorly preserved north wall opening to the garden.  Plaster decoration survives on all four walls.  Decoration is fourth style with re lower register with red architectural elements and white panels above.  High in the northeast corner of the room, traces of arched ceiling and plaster molding survive.  Painting of Ariadne abandoned on Naxos no longer in situ on the west wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: A. Zaccaria Ruggiu, D. Cottica C. Maretina, E. Tomasella, L. Toniolo.  "Le indagini archeologiche dell Universita La Foscari di Venezia nella Region V" (2008 - 2009):  Revista di Studi Pompeiani 21 92010) 112 - 137.  NSC 1905   205 - 213.
column14: Dolium 4163 is to the north.
column21: The square tufa cistern cap is no longer in situ.  On the east side of the rim there is an indentation running from the interior face of the circular cistern to the exterior.  The cistern is located in the southeast end of the garden, to the east of dining room 17.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column7: A. Zaccaria, Rugggiv D. Cottica, C. Marat. Tomasella, L. Toniolo, 'Le Indagini Archeologiche dell', 'Universite La Fosuiri di Venezia Nella Regio V' (2008 - 2009):  Revista di Studi Pompeiani 21 (2010) 112 - 137, NSC 1905 205 - 213
column14: Garden 14 to the southwest, corridor 20 to the southeast.
column21: A rectangular room, northeast / southwest axis, with a wide doorway in the center of the west wall  opening to Garden 14 (Feature # 4162). Modern lintel with no visible threshold,  The floor is obscured by earth throughout.  Against the center of the north wall there is a pile of lime.  At the west end of the south wall there is a doorway to corridor 20 with modern lintel and tufa threshold.  On the north, east and south walls traces of undecorated plaster survive.  There is a blocked doorway from an earlier phase at the west end of the north wall.  Identified as a dining room on the basis of position with respect to garden.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the southwest of room 15 - 20, to the northwest of corridor 13 and triclinea 8, unexcavated areas are to the southwest and northwest.
column21: We have determined that structure V.3.4 is a domestic house and we have determined that the partially excavated space at the back of the house was a horticultural space (Room 14) based primarily upon the presence of a dolia and cistern and references from Eschebach referring to vines and a vineyard.  The space as present was partially excavated a short while back.  A tranch remains covered in its center.  Several rooms (our rooms 16 - 20) open up to the north of this space.  Other areas are still unexplored.  The dolia is located towards the southeast near the wall of room 17.  The cistern is to the south of the dolia closer to the entrance off corridor 13.  The space is rectangular and sits on a southeast / northwest axis.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is northeast of the preparation room (32) and northwest of the garden, and it is southwest of dining room (38).
column21: southeast We have verified this room as a dining hall.  It is situated on a northwest-axis.  This large rectangular room is located so that it may overlook a beautiful garden area.  Its location is next to a preparation room and a small dining room.  The entrance door is located on the southeast wall and is high and extremely wide.  We cross a marble threshold and then five black and white mosaic borders.  There are two large post holes for a big door.  In the center is a large rectangular emblem with ten squares on the long rectangular side and six on the shorter side.  Some of the squares show a diamond form.   This is perfect for observing while lying on a triclinium.  There are three bands of mosaic that border in this decorative rectangle.  The wall once displayed brilliant red and yellow paint, most likely third style. We see in situ a red dado on all four sides.  There is no picture totally intact on the middle yellow ground: several were removed.  There is a totally reconstructed ceiling over the entire dining hall.  There are no windows.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This space is to the northeast of the peristyle garden (30), and southeast of the colonnade area (33).
column21: We have identified this space as a small dining room, or diaeta, in a domestic structure.  This identification is based on the location of this space overlooking the peristyle garden (30).  The passage opens through the space from the colonnade area (33) out to a central open space (40) and onto a matching diaeta in the eastern corner of the house (41).  This suite of three spaces is in the northeast border of the peristyle garden.  In addition to the two doorways in room 39 there is a large central window on the southwest wall.  The windowsill preserves cuttings for a shutter.  The condition of this room is fair to poor.  The upper section is reconstruction going up the walls with a modern ceiling.  The floor surface is not visible.  All walls preserve painted plaster except the southeast wall, which has plaster but no traces of paint remain.  The other walls reveal a red dado with decoration, and a scheme of white panels above which appear to be in third or fourth style.  No distinct decorative images can be discerned at this time.  Clearly the orientation of this small dining space was positioned to enjoy the peristyle garden.  One entered through the doorway on the northwest wall.  The low door on the southeast side has clearly shifted downward and originally mirrored the door to room (41).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This space is to the northeast of the peristyle garden (30), adjacent to space (40) on its northwest side.
column21: We have determined that this is a dining room in a domestic structure.  It is a small dining room or diaeta.  This identification is based on its location opening to the peristyle (30) to the southwest; there is a low door in the west corner of the northwest wall.  Its large window to the garden space and its position as part of a suite of three spaces (39) and (40) bordering the peristyle at the northeast end.  This small square room mirrors the diaeta (39).  It is a small square space with a large window on the southwest wall with a wide sill and cutting for shutter.  The room is in fair to poor condition.  The flooring is not visible.  All walls preserve painted plaster.  Like room (39) there is a red dado.  The plaster is preserved best on the southeast wall, which in the east corner goes all the way to the ceiling.  One can faintly see two zones of white panels (third or fourth style).  In the eastern corner the stucco molding is also preserved above the second zone of white panels.  In the center of this wall (southeast) a central painting was removed.  The upper portions and ceiling of this room are reconstruction.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The cupboard niche (6841) is situated on the southwest wall.  The dining couch niche (6844) is located on the northwest side of the corner protrusion. The couch niche on the other wall of the corner (6843) faces the southeast.The dining room  is to the northeast of the large dining hall (34).
column21: We have identified the room as a dining room.  This room is northeast of the dining hall.  The doorway is one-third the size of the dining hall entry.  To compensate there is a square window above the lintel.  There is no threshold and the floor is mud.  The walls show dado red with distinctive fourth style flowers.  The remaining part of the walls are cream.  At the top in several places we see a nice molding.  There are three features that help identify this L-shaped room as a dining room. The protruding corner of this L-shaped room is on the northeast side, and has a couch niche on each wall (6843) and (6844). Couch niche (6843) faces southeast and couch niche (6844) faces southwest.  On the southwest wall there is a large depression niche for a cupboard (6841).  These walls which have been changed to provide more space for couches had been repainted in the fourth style.  Besides the dining room features we have discussed, the door overlooks a beautiful garden.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Situated next to the dining hall, which is northeast of the prep room.
column21: We have determined that the usage of the room is a preparation room based on the following criteria.  It has a a low entrance door and it is immediately next to a large dining hall.  It is a small rectangular room on a northwest-southeast axis, with a rectangular lararium niche on the southeast wall.  on the northeast wall there is a built-in space for a piece of furniture holding kitchen equipment.  The floor is stone and mud.  On the northwest wall there is a circular window and above that there are five post holes in a semicircular arrangement, perhaps for an awning over the window to protect cooking or preparing food.  Above that we see three in-line holes.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northwest of the atrium (19).  It is to the southwest of the ala (16).
column21: We have determined that this space is a dining room within a residential structure.  This identification is based on the location of the room directly off the atrium with its very tall door and also the decoration of this room.  This is a rectangular space on a northeast-southwest axis, similar to the adjacent room to the southwest (18).  This room is in fair condition.  A white threshold is in place in the tall doorway in the southeast wall, and there is a low secondary doorway in the east corner of the northeastern wall.  The doorway opens to the ala, and there is no threshold.  No flooring is visible.  All four walls preserve plaster and some paint.  The decorative scheme includes a red dado with broad panels above, perhaps white, which are divided by thin red bands.  Traces of stucco molding remain above these panels.  This molding is particularly well-preserved near the south corner of the southeast wall.  On the northwest wall in the west corner the plaster above the stucco molding has traces of painted decoration.  No ceiling remains.  On the north end of hte northeast wall is a slight curving surface suggesting a shallow couch niche.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the northwest of the atrium (19).  This dining room may be the reason for the cooking platform in the atrium.
column21: We have identified a domestic structure and determined that his space is a small dining room.  This determination is based on the location of this room adjacent to the atrium and the evidence of decoration.  This space is a rectangular room on a northeast/southwest axis.  The room is in poor to fair condition.  One enters from the atrium over a white stone threshold.  This doorway is very tall.  This room has no windows.  The floor surface is not visible.  The walls preserve some plaster with traces of paint.  The tops of the walls have had restoration; no ceiling survives.  This dining room may be the reason for the cooking platform just to the northeast of the doorway, out in the atrium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: water basin is contiguous to cooking platform on the southwest and latrine on northeast
column21: On the northwest wall abutting cooking platform (6833) there is a water basin separated from the platform by a partially collapsed wall. The front wall of this water basin is low with evidence of plaster remaining. Beside the basin there is a hydraulic cenex on all four sides, there is a terracotta draining to the latrine (6837) on the northeast wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is close to the lararium, which is just southwest of it.
column21: In the northwest side of the atrium are the remnants of a semi-circular platform.  It is low and one can see the top surface.  It is stone and mortar.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is close to the platform, which is just northeast of it.
column21: This famous lararium is in the west corner of the atrium.  There are small stepped platforms in the northwest and southwest corners and a cream marble surface.  There is a large marble sheath on the front surfaces and above that is a medium size section on the two front faces that has been removed and sent to the museum.  These famous panels show the destruction of the 62-63 AD earthquake, showing statues falling down.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The preparation room opens to the kitchen (6832) to the northwest and another preparation room (6836) to the northeast.
column21: We identify this room as a preparation room. It opens to the kitchen and is next to another preparation room, this room lies on a northwest/southeast axis. This one rectangular room with a pod and pebbletton. With only the smallest portion of painted plaster on the walls. This pod is open to the sky. In the northeast wall there is a rectangular shallow opening with a partial opening into the adjoining preparation room (6836)
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Two dining rooms (to the west), a tablinum (to the northeast), two front shops, and the main entrance are all contiguous to this room.
column21: We have identified the structure of V.1.26 as a house.  We enter a fauces, step up, and are greeted by a mosaic of a baby deer in repose.  We have determined that the usage of the room is an atrium based on the following criteria.  There is a very large impluvium surrounded by a black and white border.  We look beyond this to a huge tablinum, second style paintings on the wall in red and yellow.  A mosaic with a decorative emblema is on the floor.  On either side of the office are the remains of a herm and vital parts of the herm have been removed to the museum.  On the west side are two small dining rooms.  Located on the Northwest wall is a cooking platform [6826].  In the west corner of the atrium is the lararium of the Host.  There is a doorway to the atrium and a very large entrance to the street.  On the other side of the main entrance is a wide door [27].  Down the steps is a large shop (no food or drink).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The latrine is located northeast of the water basin.
column21: We approach this latrine to see large floor tiles sloping down into the latrine and a large toilet hole that slopes northeast to the street. There is a terracotta pipe remaining along the side of this toilet hole an angle. This large latrine was possibly made for multiple people.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The room is southwest of colonnade 33 and corridor 26 runs along the southeast side.
column21: This room has been identified as a dining room within a residential structure.  This identification is based on the fairly large size of the room; its location and wide doorway going out to the colonnade [33] and the enormous window on the southwest side opening into the ala [16].  This is a rectangular space on a northeast/southwest axis.  The main entrance is almost the entire northeast side of the room.  A secondary doorway is a small opening in the east corner of the southeast wall, going into the corridor [26].  A gray stone threshold is seen at the northeast doorway.  The floor is small, white, stone, irregular tesserae in a cement matrix and it is very poorly preserved.  Along he southeast wall there is also cocciopesto but it is impossible to determine the decorative scheme for this floor.  The poor condition of this room, with extensive restoration of the upper wall, also makes it difficult to determine the decorative scheme for this floor.  Small sections of plaster remain on the walls, revealing a red dado, but nothing above remains intact.  In the south corner of the southeast wall there is a couch niche [6842].  No ceiling remains.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is contiguous to the kitchen to the northwest and a preparation room (37) to the southwest.
column21: We have identified this room as a food and drink preparation room. We have made this identification by the opening to the kitchen and a pass through to another preparation room (37) opening to many dinning rooms. This is a small rectangular room with a floor of mud and pebbles on a northwest/southeast axis. The walls shows small signs of painted plaster. In the northwest corner there is a sign of a half circle basin attached to the wall which shows small segments of painted plaster. There is a small floor level hole in the southwest wall going through to the adjoining preparation room (35).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is to the southeast of the tablinum [25] and southwest of the colonnade [29].
column21: We have determined that this is a dining room within a residential structure.  This identification is based on: the location of this room, which opens directly on to the peristyle colonnade [29]; the form of this room, with its very wide doorway and very tall window to the atrium to the southwest; the great height of this room.  This rectangular space is on an northeast/southwest axis.  The room is in fair condition.  The walls are all preserved painted plaster.  The decoration is made up of a fairly tall dado and on each of the long walls there are three printed panels, with central panels painted red.  The center of the red panel on the northwest wall reveals a large, filled tunneling hole.  Large white bands are above the central panels going up the wall.  Very faint traces of decoration suggest architectural features.  Above this white panel, one can still see that preserved on the northwest wall is a horizontal stucco molding.  There is rough plaster above this.  The highest portion of the walls is reconstructed.  No ceiling remains.  The flood is not visible.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Close to the basin and niche cupboard
column21: We see a rectangular lararium that slopes inward at the top. The back wall shows orange points and there is a plaster around the niche. There are no other paintings.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Close to the lararium and basin.
column21: In the northeast wall we see a tall niche suitable for a cupboard for kitchen equipment.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This room is directly southwest of the garden [4] and northwest of spaces 6 and 7.
column21: We have identified a residential structure and determined the use of this space as a dining room.  This identification is based on: the large size of this rectangular space; the presence of a large couch niche [6845] in the southwest wall; the broad entranceway at the eastern end of the southeast wall; a large window on the northeast side overlooking [4]/  This is a large rectangular space on a northeast/southwest axis.  The doorway at the east end of the southeast wall is the only door to this space.  It is fairly high and is broad.  No threshold is visible.  The condition of this room is fair to poor with upper walls reconstructed and a modern ceiling.  No flooring is visible.  Over the large window in the northeast wall there is a small, central window.  Painted plaster remains on all four walls.  The northwest wall is intact to the ceiling in the northwest corner.  The painting scheme is barely visible; however there is a dado which may have been black.  The zone above is divided into large panels which appear to have been red, and the uppermost zone revealed slight traces of architectural spaces beyond the wall.  This may have been fourth style.  There may have been a tunneling hole in western half of the northwest wall, although modern plaster is covering this section of the wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is west of the entry to the room.
column21: There is a well defined niche cupboard in the southwest of this small dining room. There is a red dado and a cream top.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature shows that a couch would lie along the southwest wall below large window.
column21: This feature has been identified as a couch niche in the south corner of the southeast wall of dining room (27). It is a shallow recess which is fairly wide but short, and preserved some of its plaster and painted surface, which is red.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is east of niche 4844.
column21: Dining niche (6843) is on the northeast wall of the new corner of the room. It is a slight slope to permit more room for a couch. There is a red dado and a cream top.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This feature is west of niche (6843).
column21: The dining niche (6844) is on the southwest wall of the new corner of the room. It is a slight slope to permit more room for a couch. There is a red dado and a cream top.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: There is a cooking platform [6833] which shares a wall to the northeast with the water basin [6834] and another wall to the northeast with the latrine [6837].  There are two prep rooms on the southeast wall.  A hallway and a dining room [6846] lie to the southwest.
column21: We have identified this kitchen [6832] for the following reasons.  There are two main entrances.  One is a rear entrance to the street, the other to the gardens.  Two others are two additional rooms.  The kitchen is of a good size.  On the southeast is a door to the prep room, then another entry on the southeast to another prep room.  On the southwest wall there is a long hallway to the garden, then another entry steps down to a dining room.  On the northwest wall there is a small rectangular space.  There one sees a large cooking platform [6833] but most cooking platform attributes are missing.  There was a tiled surface to cook on.  There is a low wall connecting the platform with a water basin [6834] with a pipe.  This basin is coated with hydraulic cement.  Then one can see a latrine [6837] of good size, possibly for two people.  The walls show small portions of painted plaster.  There is no ceiling to the entire area described.  The exterior door (to the street) has a stone threshold.  The threshold shows indications for a large door and indications for a smaller door within the threshold.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This niche is located south of the doorway.
column21: We have identified this feature as a couch niche. It is a long indentation along the southeast wall. It is cut into the wall and is low and shallow. The length of this is uncommon. Frescoes can be seen along the back of the niche, preserving black paint.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is northeast of garden space (4) and southwest of kitchen space (1).
column21: We have determined that this is a dining room within a residential structure. We have identified it as a dining room for servants. We have based this identification on the location of the room, which steps down from the large kitchen (1). This identification is also based on the large scale of this room and the features which include a high platform along the entire northwest wall and a stepped platform in the south and west corners. The condition of this room is very poor. The floor is not visible. A row of five horizontal beam holes across the southwest wall suggest a low ceiling. Two holes in the remaining portion of the northeast wall align with the holes in the southwest wall. There is a window above the level of the holes in the center of the southwest wall. The poor condition of this room makes it difficult to determine whether it had any painted decoration; the only plaster remaining is at the southwest wall, but this seems to predate the addition of the partition wall on the northwest and southeast sides. It appears that the window on the southwest wall also predates the partitioning and roofing.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The cooking platform is contiguous to water basin 6834.
column21: Feature 6833 is a large cooking platform located along the northwest wall of the kitchen.  Most cooking platform attributes are missing.  There is evidence of a tiled surface.  There is no evidence of plaster on any remaining walls above this platform.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This platform is to the northwest of platform 6849.
column21: We have identified this feature in dining room 2 as a platform.  It is a narrow platform running along the northwest wall, terminating in the west corner with a stepped shelf.  The platform is stone construction, opus incertum, with the stepped shelf made of ceramic brick and tiles.  While this identified as a preparation platform, we have also noted that this could have served as a bench, making the nature of the room suitable for dining.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: This is located to the south of the stepped end of feature 6848.
column21: This feature has been identified as a stepped platform, occupying the south corner of the room.  It is constructed of ceramic tile supporting stone work, which was covered with cement.  There are two levels to this stepped platform; they are in poor condition.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is northeast to a dining room (38) and to the northeast of a preparation room in the kitchen and to stairs to the southeast to the basement.
column21: We have determined that the usage of this room is as a preparation room. We use the following criteria: This room is located next to a dining room with two couches and a stairway opposite it to a basement permanently locked and a large window opening to a preparation room to the kitchen. The stone threshold gives us entrance to this room has been modified to include a heavily recessed corner for storage. The floor is pebbles and mud. There is small potions of plaster and some painted plaster on the wall. There is no ceilings. The recess explains the 'L' shaped protrusion into the dining room. The recess shows cream paint on plaster.This room is on a southeast/northwest axis with the entry on the southeast and a window opposite in the northwest wall.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Fauces 1 is to the east.
column21: This is a small rectangular room on an east/west axis.  At the north end of the northeast wall is a low doorway to a fauces with a modern lintel and a stepped tufa threshold.  The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.  Plaster survives on the northeast and west walls with a red lower register and white above.  This is identified as a storeroom because of its utilitarian decoration and the function of the property as a whole.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the northeast of room  number 4, to the southeast of room II, to the northwest of room 14.
column21: In the bakery V-3-8 we have identified room 12 as a storeroom due to its small size, utilitarian painting and position immediately off a mill room #4. The room is roughly square with its tall doorway opening to its southwest into the mill room. The northeast wall has a tiny square window opening to the street outside, high up on the wall. Construction is opus incertum with patches of red and yellow plaster near the bottoms of the walls. Floor is lapilla. A small part of a mill sits in the south corner of the room a puteal sits in the west corner of the room. Neither appears to be situ. There is no ceiling
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Fauces 1 is to the east.
column21: This is a rectangular room on an east/west axis.  The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.  The room is entered through a door at the north end of the east wall with a modern lintel and stepped tufa threshold.  At the south end of the southwest wall there is a large block.  Undecorated plaster survives in places on all four walls.  At the east end of the southeast wall there are four circular holes for shelves.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The mill room is to the northwest of fauces 1, to the southwest of storerooms 10 and 11, to the west of storerooms 12 and 14, to the south of andron 15, and to the southeast of dining tablinum 5.
column21: In bakery V.3.8 the mill room is large, opens directly off of fauces 1, and was originally the atrium of a home.  The room has been identified by the presence of an almost intact mill, two mill bases, a large beehive oven, and an impluvium turned into a water basin.  The walls are opus incertum with a solid southwest wall abutting property V.3.7.  The northwest wall contains a lararium.  Also along this wall is dining tablinum 15, with its two windows and large doorway to the north.  It is followed by a doorway to andron 15.  The northeast of the room contains doorways to storerooms 10, 11, 12, and 14.  The southeast wall of the room contains the oven to the east and an entrance to fauces 1 in the center.  Platform 4181 takes up the remaining space to the south.  The three mills create an "l" shape along the southwest and northwest walls of the room, with space around them paved for donkeys.  The impluvium in the center of the room has been turned into a waterproof basin, with a cistern head on its north corner.  It is only around the mill bases that any trace of floor pavement remains.  The room is undecorated except for a trace of plaster by prep platform 4181.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room is located to the northeast of millroom number 4, to the southeast of room 10, and to the northwest of room 12.
column21: In bakery V-3-8 we have identified room number 11 as a storeroom based upon its location directly off the millroom and its utilitarian decoration. The room is almost square with a southeast/northwest axis and a door opening to the southwest. The door is fairly large with hardware indentations near the top. Walls are all opus incertum with traces of plaster on all walls. A window to the street high up and square is the located in the northeast wall. A series of post holes above the window indicate an upper story. There are faint traces of 7 post on the northwest wall that show that the room may have had an arched ceiling. Plaster work shows a red dado with cream or white above. Floor is Lappeli. No trace of a door jamb, or a door threshold remains. The northwest  wall has some plaster towards the bottom with a series of scratch marks which may indicate that the room was being redecorated at the time of the eruption.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: It is to the southwest of oven 4188 and to the south of all other features in the room.
column21: In bakery V.3.8, in the southern corner of room 4, two masonry ends are left which would designate a preparation platform.  The platform would have abutted the southeast wall, and the spacing of the two ends as well as their width indicate quite a large platform top (probably originally of wood).  The platform end in the southern corner of the room is just slightly higher than its partner, but there is no indication of what the original total height would have been.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room is entered to the northwest from mill room 4.
column21: In bakery V-3-8 we have determined that a large, square, elaborately decorated room, with a patterned coccio pesto floor was probably used as a dining tablinium. The room is entered from the south east by a large doorway, framed by two large windows looking out at the mill room and fauces to the street. Walls were made of opus incertum and were covered with plaster (today only a small section remain on all walls). The southwest wall however, near the south corner, has a good trace of 1st style block fresco. There are indications at the top center of that same wall of a very high window. An indentation in the wall running horizontally just below window level was probably in place for a stucco crown molding. Nice traces of a Greek key patter remains in the red coccio pesto floor with white marble insets. The room is currently open to the sky.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Prep platform 4181 is to the southeast, oven 4188 is to the east, and mill 4183 is to the northwest.  Basin 4187, cistern 4186, and mill 4184 can be found at varying degrees to the northeast.
column21: In bakery V.3.8's mill room 4 sits a base to a mill.  It is constructed in a circular form of brick and stone.  The interior of the circle is hollow.  No other parts of the mill remain.  Paving stones surround the mill on the ground, indicating the path around which the mill would have been turned.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Mill 4184 and cistern 4186 are to the east.  Mill 4182, basin 4187, and oven 4188 are to the southeast.
column21: Feature 4183 is a circular masonry base for a mill with modern restoration.  The placing for the mill survives in the center of the base.  The mill itself has been removed.  The base rests directly on paving.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Opens directly to the northeast off corridor 15, to the southeast of room 9, to the northwest of room 11.
column21: In bakery V-3-8 we have a very small, narrow room that was well decorated at one time. It had a low lararium or a shelf or that may have been a couch niche in one wall. The entrance is very low, arched and very narrow. From the corridor it appears there were two such low narrow arched doorways but one was completely blocked in antiquity (plaster covers the inside wall as well as the position of the lararium where that door would have been inside the room). We know the room was arched by the presence of a series of post holes on the northeast and southwest walls. Below the post holes on the northeast wall is a small square high window. Because of the location of the room, just off corridor number 5, and directly to the north of the mill room, we suggest that its function was storage when this house was turned into a bakery. Floor today is lappilli
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Cistern 4186, basin 4187, and prep table 4184 are to the south.  Mill 4182 is to the southwest.  Mill 4183 and lararium 4185 are to the west.  Oven 4188 is to the southeast.
column21: Feature 4184 is a circular masonry base and mill with modern restoration.  The catillus and meta are in situ but are now cemented together.  The interior face has the ties from earlier restoration.  The base is contiguous with the surrounding paving.  On the northern face there is a grafitto of the letter "A" on the catillus.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Immediately to the northeast off the north end of corridor #15.
column21: In bakery V-3-8 we have identified room #9 as a storeroom. The room is long and relatively narrow on a northwest/southeast axis. It appears to be accessed by a single door on the southwest wall at the south end that has a stone door sill that has a step up to it from the corridor. The room shows on the northeast wall only utilitarian  paintings and is currently still partially excavated. There is one window in the northeast wall high and narrow opening to the street. Directly below the window are a series of 8 post holes that appears to be in a semicircular pattern. The southwest wall is partially destroyed, making it unclear as to whether there was a second access door (I think not).
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Mills 4183 and 4182 are to the south.  Prep table 4182, cistern 4186, water basin 4187, and oven 4188 are all varying degrees to the southeast.  Mill 4184 is to the east.
column21: Feature 4185 is an arched, plastered lararium.  Plaster survives on the rear and left-hand faces and on the base.  Earlier plaster has been stippled to allow the adhesion of a second phase of decoration.  There is a red lower register with white above.  The earlier phase has a yellow lower register with red motifs and white above.  The lararium is inserted into the west end of the north wall.  To the west is the window into tablinum 5.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Basin 4187 and prep table 4180 are to the south.  Mill 4184 is to the north.  Mill 4183 and lararium 4185 are to the west.  Mill 4182 is to the southwest.  Oven 4188 is to the southeast.
column21: A circular cistern lined with opus signinum sits in the northern corner of the impluvium basin [4187].  The cistern is full of debris and is capped with a tufa puteal.  It was originally a kneading machine or basin.  Holes survive in the northwest, southeast, and west faces.  The lip of the cistern rests directly on the earlier opus signinum pavement of the atrium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: 4193, and 4194 to the southeast. 4192, 4191, 4190 to the southwest.
column21: Possible traces of a basin in the northern corner of the room. The existence of a basin is suggested by plastered floor and plaster inserted against the wall plaster of the north and east walls. No indication that the south and west sides of the basin survives.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: 4181 and 4188 are to the southeast.  4182, 4185, and 4183 are to the southwest.  4184 and 4187 are to the northwest.
column21: In the center of mill room 4, what was formerly in impluvium has been lined with pozzolano cement and turned into a water basin.  The northeast side of the impluvium has been built up with masonry and clearly shows the pozzolano lining.  The other three sides show the original cocciopesto, dotted with white marble pieces of the impluvium edge.  The remains of the impluvium are now filled with sand.  A cistern head [4186] sits on the immediate north corner of the impluvium.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: To the west of garden 7.
column21: We have identified structure V.3.8 as a bakery based upon a mill room with oven. Eschebach tells us that the large square area at the back of the building was a stable. The room is sitting on a southwest/northeast axis. There are no remains of plaster on any of the 4 opus incertum walls. There is no evidence of windows except a small vertical slit in the southwest wall. There are also 2 post holes in that same walls that appears to have had something attached, perhaps a shelf. The floor is rubble and overgrown with grass. The threshold is narrow and is the only access to the room. It is located in the east corner of the room. At the west end of the  southwest wall there is an indentation in the wall that appears to be almost a perfect circle, although it simply, maybe missing stone. There is no lintel or wall above the threshold and no ceiling.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: The oven is to the northeast of platform 4181 and to the east or southeast of all other features in the room.
column21: In mill room 4 one finds a large beehive oven with bricked surround, underneath storage, tiled stone surface, and large beehive shaped interior cavity.  Openings to both the oven and the storage are square.  The oven itself is built up with opus incertum, with the inside stone and brick.  The front of the oven (the brick surround) originally would have been completely arched.  Workspace exists between the brick surround and the oven body, with a pass-through in the west corner leading at an oblique angle to the east to prep room 13.  Inside the oven to the east is a circular hole about one meter above floor level that probably provided ventilation.  It is worth nothing that the storage below appears to be slightly off-center from the oven opening above, although both appear to be roughly the same size.  The remains of the curved brick arch extend approximately halfway up to each side of the oven.
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall

column14: Room 14 is to the north and room 4 is to the northwest.
column21: A square room, partially excavated, has been determined to be a prep room.  The room consists of the exterior of the mill oven, with a throughway to the east of the oven that accesses the oven's front in mill room 4.  Unexcavated volcanic debris abuts directly against the exterior face of the oven and the west wall.  The floor is obscured by lapilli throughout.  The room is accessed through a doorway with stepped threshold and modern lintel at the eastern end of the north wall.  Traces of undecorated plaster survive on all four walls.  In the north corner of the room is a possible basin [4203].  In the southeast corner of the room there is a preparation platform [4194].  Extending from the south wall to the center of the room are the masonry supports for a wooden platform [4192].  To the north of this and directly south of the oven is a kneading machine [4190].  In the eastern corner, abutting directly against the exterior of the oven, is a basin [4191].
column57: Lee PayneRob BrownAaron Randall
